text: A new law in Illinois allows any immigrant living in the country illegally to become a police officer.

claimReview.title: Illinois will allow some non-citizens to be police. But only those authorized to work and own a gun
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The law allows certain non-citizens to apply for police officer jobs. But they must be legally authorized to both work and carry a firearm in the country. Immigration law experts say this includes lawful permanent residents, or green card holders, as well as those in the country with permanent legal status but not yet full citizens, such as refugees and asylees. Those on Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, are technically listed as eligible but they’re currently prohibited from possessing firearms.
List (Page)

text: New York University has been working with a small, student-led task force to make racially segregated housing a reality in undergraduate student dorms.

claimReview.title: NYU is not implementing racial segregation in dorms
claimReview.textualRating: False. “NYU does not have and will not create student housing that excludes any student based on race,” the university said in a statement. After a student group applied to establish a dorm floor around themes of Black history and culture earlier in the summer, NYU clarified such floors must be open to students of “all races and backgrounds.”

text: A Connecticut ballot question on whether to allow early voting would also remove a requirement that ballots be sealed.

claimReview.title: Connecticut referendum will not change how ballots are sealed
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Nov. 8 ballot question lets voters decide whether state lawmakers should pass legislation establishing in-person voting ahead of Election Day. It would also remove an outdated reference to sending copies of election results to the secretary of state’s office “under seal,” which was the colonial-era practice of using hot wax to seal documents. Ballots themselves will still be sealed, and the results will continue to be delivered in a sealed envelope.

text: Video purports to show Muslims attacking Danish police in Copenhagen.

claimReview.title: Video does not show Muslims rioting in Denmark
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video being shared on Facebook, which shows protesters attacking a blue police van, was taken during a protest in Algeria.

text: “Did you know Roe v. Wade was passed only because Roe lied about being raped? She admitted it on live TV.”

claimReview.title: US Supreme Court did not rule to legalize abortion because ‘Jane Roe’ was raped
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. Supreme Court did not consider how “Jane Roe” became pregnant when making its landmark decision in 1973.

text: Video captures an American journalist reacting as a Russian Kinzhal missile hits land in Ukraine and causes a massive explosion.

claimReview.title: Video claiming to show Russian missile was created using visual effects
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was previously posted by a visual effects artist who has used the same background and sound effects in multiple videos. Hypersonic missile experts confirmed it does not resemble such a weapon.

text: Image shows a fundraising email by former President Donald Trump sharing “nuke codes,” following the federal search warrant executed at his Florida residence.

claimReview.title: Trump didn’t send fundraising email about ‘nuke codes’
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. Trump’s team did not send that email, a representative confirmed. An actual email with the same subject line and banner image contained different body text.

text: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos said that “only 0.02%” of children will die when returning to school during the pandemic.

claimReview.title: DeVos did not say 'only 0.02%' of children will die returning to school
claimReview.textualRating: False. DeVos did not say that students would die if they return to school. A spokeswoman with the U.S. Department of Education confirmed to the AP that the statement was falsely attributed to DeVos, who supports the reopening of schools and the return of children to classrooms.

text: Side-by-side photos show that CNN lightened the skin of the gunman who drove a car into a Seattle protest to make him appear white.

claimReview.title: CNN did not alter the skin tone of gunman who drove into Seattle protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. CNN did not alter the skin tone of the gunman who drove into a George Floyd protest in Seattle on June 7 and shot one person. One of the photos used in the image was manipulated to make the gunman’s skin lighter, and a CNN logo was added.

text: COVID-19 vaccines cause male infertility.

claimReview.title: No link found between COVID-19 vaccines and male infertility
claimReview.textualRating: False. Claims that the vaccines cause infertility in men are not supported by evidence, according to research and experts. There is some evidence that coronavirus infection may temporarily affect semen production.

text: A photo of Plymouth Rock sitting in a small amount of water proves that sea levels have not risen significantly over the last 402 years due to climate change.

claimReview.title: Photo of Plymouth Rock misrepresented to dispute rising sea levels
claimReview.textualRating: False. Plymouth Rock has not remained in its original location over the centuries, and sea level rise has been well-documented in the surrounding region, experts say. In addition, the photo also does not take account of regular tidal fluctuations.

text: One year during the COVID-19 pandemic, people who control hurricanes “forgot” to give the United States a hurricane.

claimReview.title: Hurricanes did hit US during pandemic, contrary to online claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The United States experienced hurricanes in 2020 and 2021. The claim also falsely suggests that humans, not environmental factors, determine when hurricanes hit.

text: “My family came to Jamaica from India to exploit the black African slaves we bought like cattle. Now I pretend to be African American to exploit them for votes,” says a caption with a 2017 photo of Democratic vice presidential candidate Kamala Harris.

claimReview.title: Kamala Harris’ family did not come from India to Jamaica to exploit Black slaves
claimReview.textualRating: False. Harris did not make that statement, and there is no evidence anyone in her family went from India to Jamaica to exploit Black slaves.

text: A video clip from 2007 shows Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden saying he will prioritize meetings with people who help fund his campaigns.

claimReview.title: Biden quoted out of context discussing lobbyists
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. This clip shows part of a larger answer Biden gave to a question about special interest groups in Washington during a 2007 town hall in Iowa. Later in the response, Biden said he supported public financing of elections and if he were elected president, he would push both political parties toward that goal.

text: Photos show four police officers who were injured by Democrats and Black Lives Matter rioters over the weekend in Portland, Seattle and nearby cities.

claimReview.title: Photos of injured police officers are not from recent protests
claimReview.textualRating: False. The four photos in a post being shared on social media show police officers who sustained injuries in various parts of Australia in 2006, 2009, 2012 and 2019. Their injuries were not related to Black Lives Matter protests or other demonstrations in the U.S.

text: Donald Trump pardoned “Tiger King” star Joe Exotic before leaving office as president of the United States.

claimReview.title: Trump did not pardon Joe Exotic
claimReview.textualRating: False. Joe Exotic did not appear on Trump’s pardon list.

text: Video of a man dangling from a helicopter in Kandahar, Afghanistan, shows the Taliban performing a public execution.

claimReview.title: Helicopter videos show Taliban attempt to hang flag, not execution
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a Taliban fighter attempting to hang the Taliban flag on a tall flagpole on Sunday, according to two Kandahar residents who watched it happen. The man hanging from the chopper was alive and could be seen moving in the video.

text: Former Fox News host Tucker Carlson was placed on a Ukrainian “kill list,” and is facing sanctions by the European Union for interviewing Russian President Vladimir Putin.

claimReview.title: Tucker Carlson was not put on a ‘kill list’ in Ukraine for Putin interview
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image being cited as proof that Carlson is on such a list was taken from the website of the Myrotvorets Center, a non-governmental organization that studies threats to Ukraine’s national security. Carlson’s entry appears as part of the group’s “Purgatory” project, which tracks individuals the organization deems to have deliberately acted against the national security of Ukraine. The conservative commentator has been listed in the project’s database since at least June 2023. In addition, Carlson has not been sanctioned by the EU, officials said.

text: Fox News said it is planning to replace prime-time host Tucker Carlson with Geraldo Rivera.

claimReview.title: Fox didn’t announce plan to replace Tucker Carlson with Geraldo Rivera
claimReview.textualRating: False. The network made no such announcement and a Fox spokesperson refuted that claim. The company said it would temporarily rotate hosts to fill the prime-time slot until a permanent host is named.

text: President John F. Kennedy said seven days before he was assassinated

claimReview.title: Conspiracy theory quote is falsely attributed to JFK
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no record of Kennedy saying this quote, multiple experts confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Under the Alabama abortion bill, if an alleged rapist is found not guilty the accuser will go to jail because her allegation is declared false.

claimReview.title: Alabama abortion bill doesn’t jail women for rape allegations
claimReview.textualRating: False. The controversial Alabama abortion bill that passed earlier this week does not address rape charges although the state’s legislature is considering a bill that would criminalize false rape allegations.

text: A headline on People magazine’s website reports that Klondike’s Choco Tacos were discontinued in response to the “woke mob” and recent allegations of “cultural appropriation.”

claimReview.title: Fake headline distorts reason that Choco Tacos were discontinued
claimReview.textualRating: False. A representative for People magazine confirms this headline was fabricated. Klondike said it was discontinuing its Choco Taco after a spike in demand over the past two years led to “tough decisions to ensure availability of our full portfolio nationwide.” It did not cite cultural appropriation as a reason.

text: Photo shows Democratic Rep. Ilhan Omar of Minnesota wiping away tears after learning U.S. forces in Syria killed Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show congresswoman crying about the death of IS leader
claimReview.textualRating: False. A photo of Omar wearing a black headscarf, rubbing her left eye to wipe away tears, was taken in April 2019.

text: Kathy Hoffman, the state superintendent of Arizona public schools, hates the Bible so much that she swore her oath on a Dr. Seuss book, she is pushing child sex education that would teach kindergartners about masturbation and sex positions, and she wants to put makeup on boys.

claimReview.title: Arizona schools chief not pushing age-inappropriate sex education
claimReview.textualRating: False. It’s true that Hoffman was sworn in using a children’s book, but it wasn’t one by Dr. Seuss. As for the sex education claims, these are “categorically false,” according to Richie Taylor, communications director for the superintendent. In summer 2019, Hoffman supported proposed changes to the state board of education’s sex ed rules. These changes did not have to do with age-inappropriate lessons, and they were rejected by the board. Hoffman supports LGBTQ rights but has not advocated for boys to wear makeup, Taylor said.

text: Vice President Kamala Harris disrespected the military when she failed to salute the military escorts when boarding Air Force Two on March 19 in Georgia.

claimReview.title: Vice presidents are not required to salute service members
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. president and vice president are not required to salute troops. A Pentagon spokesperson said the vice president is viewed as respectful toward the military.

text: A post circulating widely on social media Monday under the guise of a public service announcement says

claimReview.title: False report on social media warns of listeria in vegetables
claimReview.textualRating: False. No nationwide listeria outbreaks involving vegetables have been reported in December.

text: Photo shows a fire set at the children’s hospital in Columbus, Ohio.

claimReview.title: Photo shows fire at apartment complex in Ohio, not children's hospital
claimReview.textualRating: False. The fire in the photo occurred in an empty apartment complex in Columbus on Sunday, about a mile away from the Nationwide Children’s Hospital.

text: Video shows Britain’s Queen Elizabeth II reprimanding her daughter Princess Anne for not greeting Trump at a NATO reception at Buckingham Palace.

claimReview.title: Video does not show Princess Anne snubbing Trump at NATO reception
claimReview.textualRating: False. Princess Anne had already escorted President Donald Trump and wife, Melania, to shake hands with the monarch when the queen turned and looked at her daughter. “It’s just me,” Anne said, motioning that no more world leaders were left in the greeting line.

text: Actress Amber Heard plagiarized lines from the movie “The Talented Mr. Ripley” on Wednesday when she first took the stand in a trial over libel allegations by Johnny Depp, her ex-husband.

claimReview.title: Amber Heard didn’t plagiarize movie quote during trial
claimReview.textualRating: False. A review of nearly seven hours of footage from Wednesday’s proceedings shows Heard did not make comments that match a specific quote from the movie that was attributed to her online.

text: President Joe Biden said, “Buy a man eat fish, he day, teach fish man, to a lifetime,” mixing up a popular proverb.

claimReview.title: ‘Buy a man eat fish’ quote attributed to Biden is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. An internet search and a review of Biden’s recent public statements reveal no evidence to support this claim. This viral post appears to make fun of Biden, who grew up with a stutter and has been known to make verbal missteps, jumbling his words at times.

text: Health officials have determined the COVID-19 death rate for those under 70 is less than the flu, at just 0.04%.

claimReview.title: No consensus on COVID-19 death rate for those under 70
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. There is no consensus among researchers about how deadly COVID-19 is for different ages. The origin of the .04 percent statistic can be traced to a single scientific research paper that has not yet been peer-reviewed.

text: A video shows Vice President Kamala Harris saying in a speech

claimReview.title: Video of Kamala Harris saying ‘today is today’ was altered
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. The original footage, from a rally on reproductive rights at Howard University last Tuesday, does not contain this quote.

text: Photo captures Democratic Sen. Elena Parent of Atlanta counting votes.

claimReview.title: Photo shows poll worker in Pennsylvania, not Georgia senator
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows a woman counting ballots in Pittsburgh on Nov. 7, not Parent, according to video captured by The Associated Press. Posts making the erroneous claim compared the photo of the ballot counter with video and photos of Parent at a recent State Senate hearing examining alleged electoral fraud in Georgia. Parent confirmed to the AP that she was not in Pennsylvania at the time.

text: Gun manufacturers are “the only industry in America that is exempted from being sued by the public. The only one.”

claimReview.title: Despite Biden’s claim, gun makers can indeed be sued
claimReview.textualRating: False. While gun manufacturers have legal protections that shield them from most lawsuits, this does not mean they are exempt from being sued, according to legal experts. Nor are they the only industry with such protections. For example, COVID-19 vaccine manufacturers have legal shields as well.

text: Photo of a man lying on the pavement in blue pants covered in blood shows Haitian president Jovenel Moïse after his assassination early Wednesday.

claimReview.title: Photo being shared on WhatsApp does not show slain Haitian president
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo has been circulating online since August 2020. It shows a slain lawyer, not the assassinated president.

text: transparent; color

claimReview.title: Legislation introduced by Rep. Cummings did not seal presidential records, it improved access
claimReview.textualRating: False. Rep. Elijah Cummings, D-Md., introduced legislation in 2014 to improve public access to presidential records. He did not introduce a bill to keep President Barack Obama’s records sealed as posts being shared on Facebook state. The bill was introduced while Obama was president and passed.

text: “If I were to run, I’d run as a Republican. They’re the dumbest group of voters in the country. They believe anything on Fox News. I could lie and they’d still eat it up. I bet my numbers would be terrific.” -- Donald Trump in 1998 People magazine interview.

claimReview.title: Trump did not disparage GOP in 1998 People magazine interview
claimReview.textualRating: False. The president did not make such a comment to People magazine.

text: Fox News reported that Deutsche Bank has filed a notice to foreclose on former President Trump’s Mar-a-Lago club in Florida.

claimReview.title: Satirical post about bank foreclosing on Mar-a-Lago spreads as real
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim comes from a post by a parody account on X, the platform formerly known as Twitter. Fox News has not published any such report, and there are no public records supporting it.

text: Data from the U.K.’s public health agency confirms that those who have been vaccinated against COVID-19 are anywhere from two times to six times more likely to die from the delta variant than the unvaccinated.

claimReview.title: Vaccines do not make patients more susceptible to delta variant
claimReview.textualRating: False. The data from Public Health England did not show evidence that those who are vaccinated are more susceptible to dying from the COVID-19 delta variant. Rather, the data shows the Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines are highly effective against hospitalization from the variant.

text: Photo shows anti-lockdown protests in Vienna in November 2021.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Moscow in 1991, not recent Vienna lockdown protests
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo, taken by The Associated Press on March 10, 1991, shows hundreds of thousands of protesters in Moscow’s Manezh Square demanding the resignation of Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev.

text: Video shows Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden telling an audience that their taxes are going to be “raised, not cut.”

claimReview.title: Biden says he’ll raise taxes for high earners, not all Americans
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The full video shows Biden was referring to top earners who benefited from President Donald Trump’s 2017 tax cut, not Americans in general. Biden has repeatedly said he will eliminate parts of Trump’s tax plan but only raise personal income taxes for people who make $400,000 a year or more.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has changed its definition of vaccination because COVID-19 vaccines are ineffective.

claimReview.title: Experts say changes to CDC’s vaccination definition are normal
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The CDC has altered the language in the definition of vaccination on its website, including after the development of COVID-19 vaccines, but the changes were made to prevent potential misinterpretations, and did not alter the overall definition, according to the agency. Experts confirmed to The Associated Press that the changes reflect the evolution of vaccine research and technology.

text: An image of a newspaper article shows that True Bethel Baptist Church in Buffalo, New York, recently became the first church in New York to obtain a liquor license.

claimReview.title: Western New York church did not get a liquor license
claimReview.textualRating: False. This is not a genuine news article, The Buffalo News confirmed. There’s also no truth to the claim in the fake headline, according to Danetta McKinnon, pastor of administration at True Bethel Baptist Church.

text: France’s Interior Ministry and national police published a press release announcing that the country is restricting internet access in certain areas amid

claimReview.title: French government dispels fake press release claiming internet will be restricted during unrest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The government of France said in a tweet that an image of the supposed release circulating online is not real and that no such decision has been made.

text: A video shows a stadium of soccer fans singing in support of Palestine and against Israel during the

claimReview.title: Video of soccer fans supporting Palestine is not from the World Cup
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a 2019 soccer match between Moroccan team Raja Casablanca and Palestinian team Hilal Al Quds at the Mohamed V stadium in Casablanca.

text: A photo of tattooed, shirtless men sitting handcuffed on a bus is circulating on social media with a caption that suggests they are migrants headed to the U.S.

claimReview.title: Photo shows prisoners in El Salvador being transferred, not coming to the U.S.
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is from a mass transfer of violent prison inmates in El Salvador in 2015.

text: Attorney General William Barr’s investigation into antifa reveals that the organization was created by former President Barack Obama and liberal financier George Soros.

claimReview.title: Barr hasn’t announced that Obama launched antifa
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim stems from a satirical article. Barr has not opened an investigation into antifa, a term for leftist militants.

text: If COVID-19 vaccines kill people we would not find out because the Food and Drug Administration and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will not collect the data.

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on government efforts to monitor possible COVID-19 vaccine reactions
claimReview.textualRating: False. Both the CDC and FDA have monitoring systems in place and are tracking data on vaccine reactions.

text: Officials confirmed an Ebola outbreak at the Burning Man festival in Nevada, where a national emergency was declared.

claimReview.title: Burning Man flooding triggers false claims of Ebola outbreak, ‘national emergency’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Federal health officials told The Associated Press they have not received any reports of Ebola cases at the event. A screenshot of a supposed post from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirming such cases was fabricated. And while flooding prompted road closures and left attendees stranded, there is no record of a national emergency being declared.

text: Dansville Central School in western New York has put a litter box in a school restroom for students who identify as animals.

claimReview.title: Claim about litter boxes in New York school is unfounded
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s no truth to this claim, according to Dansville Central School District Superintendent Paul Alioto. The same false claim has surged in school districts nationwide in recent weeks, aided by politicians and candidates amid the culture wars and legislative action involving gender identification in schools.

text: U.S. Rep. Adam Schiff said the Jan. 6 committee will “scrub” evidence before the Republicans take control of the House next year.

claimReview.title: Posts distort Rep. Adam Schiff’s comments on Jan. 6 evidence
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Schiff, a California Democrat, did not say the panel is going to get rid of evidence. During an appearance on a CNN segment Sunday, he said that all of the evidence would be made public, but that the committee would “scrub” any identifying personal information that could compromise peoples’ security before releasing it.

text: A new United Nations report calls for decriminalizing sexual activity between adults and minors.

claimReview.title: UN report did not call for decriminalizing sex between adults and minors
claimReview.textualRating: False. A report published in March by the International Commission of Jurists in collaboration with the U.N’s AIDS agency called for enforcing minimum age of consent laws in a non-discriminatory manner. It did not call for decriminalizing all sexual activity between minors and adults, spokespersons for the U.N. and the commission confirmed.

text: Photo shows the statue of the Great Sphinx of Giza covered in snow.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Great Sphinx covered in snow
claimReview.textualRating: False. This photo shows a miniature replica of the Great Sphinx at Tobu World Square, a theme park in Nikko, Japan.

text: Pittsburgh protester waves sign stating Nazi slogan “Work Sets You Free.”

claimReview.title: Pittsburgh protester not waving sign with Nazi slogan
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image has been manipulated. The original photo posted by the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette on April 20 shows the protester holding a sign stating, “Free small business!” Although Nazi slogans were, in fact, used at a separate protest in Illinois on Friday.

text: A new study found that ventilators were responsible for nearly all COVID-19 patient deaths.

claimReview.title: Viral headline twists study about ventilators and COVID-19 deaths
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. The study being referenced found that a secondary pneumonia associated with mechanical ventilation contributes to a patient’s death when it doesn’t respond to treatment. But a study author said that the patients placed on a ventilator would have died without that intervention, and that COVID-19 is still the primary cause of death.

text: A video clip shows President Joe Biden inappropriately touching and kissing a young woman with curly hair and a black shirt.

claimReview.title: Video distorts Biden placing voting sticker on granddaughter
claimReview.textualRating: False. This clip is edited to remove context, distorting what really happened when Biden accompanied his granddaughter, Natalie Biden, for her first time voting. News footage shows that he placed a voting sticker on her upper chest, with her instruction, then kissed her on the cheek.

text: “Attorney General Merrick Garland has instructed the FBI to mobilize against parents who oppose critical race theory in public schools, citing ‘threats.’"

claimReview.title: The FBI is not targeting opponents of critical race theory
claimReview.textualRating: False. In a memo Monday, Garland directed federal authorities to address a rise in criminal conduct targeting school board members and public schools employees, following a request from the National School Boards Association. Garland did not single out critical race theory in his memo, and a Department of Justice press official said the claim amounted to misinformation.

text: “No workers present at the time that the Notre Dame Cathedral fire started...so who is this guy dressed in Muslim garb??” -- comments with a social media post of a blurry video clip that shows a person walking along the balcony of Notre Dame Cathedral during Monday’s fire.

claimReview.title: Video posted on social media incorrectly describes person on Notre Dame balcony during fire
claimReview.textualRating: False. The person was wearing a yellow vest and a hard hat.

text: 11pt;font-family

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent video of Chicago school for at-risk students
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The clip comes from a 2014 documentary web series about Moses Montefiore Academy, a since-closed specialized school within the Chicago Public School District for students with severe emotional and behavioral disorders.

text: Photo shows Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden taking a knee during the national anthem.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Biden kneeling for a photo, not for national anthem
claimReview.textualRating: False. This photo shows Biden kneeling to pose for a photo with dancers in Little Haiti in Miami on Oct. 5, according to Associated Press photo captions from the event. A spokeswoman for the Biden campaign confirmed that Biden was posing for a picture and told the AP the national anthem was not played at the event.

text: A document shows that Pfizer currently recommends against receiving its COVID-19 vaccine during pregnancy and while breastfeeding.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent outdated UK document on COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The document was published by U.K. health officials in late 2020 upon first authorization of the shot, when the vaccine rollout was still in its earliest stages. The same document has since been revised, in line with current recommendations that say the vaccine is safe and recommended for both groups.

text: A video shows sheep in Idaho who dropped dead a week after thousands of cattle died in Kansas.

claimReview.title: Video shows dead sheep in the country of Georgia, not Idaho
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the video does show dead sheep, the footage was actually recorded in August 2021 in the nation of Georgia, an editor for a regional media outlet that published the clip confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: The U.S. military found that COVID-19 vaccines for children contain the drug scopolamine.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines don’t contain scopolamine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The COVID-19 vaccines don’t contain scopolamine, according to experts and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Additionally, claims that the military made such a finding is false, a spokesperson for the Department of Defense told The Associated Press. This false claim spread as real after appearing on a website known for its satire and parody content.

text: Singer Hank Williams Jr. resigned from Country Music Television’s board of directors and artists including Carrie Underwood and Toby Keith have pulled their music videos from the network in recent days.

claimReview.title: No, Hank Williams Jr. didn’t resign from CMT’s board of directors. The network doesn’t have a board
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim about Williams Jr. originated on a website that publishes made-up, satirical content, and CMT does not even have a board of directors. CMT confirmed no artists have pulled their videos from the network.

text: Pfizer added tromethamine to its formulation for the COVID-19 vaccine for kids ages 5 to 11. Tromethamine’s side effects are severe and pose risks to human health.

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on Pfizer’s new COVID-19 vaccine formula
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine for children under 12 contains tromethamine, the company is also adding the ingredient to its vaccines for adults and teens. Experts say Pfizer’s clinical trials show the new vaccine formula containing tromethamine is safe. Several other FDA-approved vaccines use tromethamine.

text: A memo shows that President Joe Biden is sending $8 billion in military aid to Israel.

claimReview.title: Biden hasn’t signed a recent order sending $8B in aid to Israel. A 'memo' circulating online was altered
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The memo being widely shared has been altered. The original order was issued July 25 and authorized up to $400 million in military aid to Ukraine. The Biden administration confirmed the memo is fake.
List (Page)

text: Federal magistrate approved Kyle Rittenhouse’s $110 Million defamation suit against LeBron James.

claimReview.title: Kyle Rittenhouse did not sue LeBron James for defamation
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such ruling was made. Rittenhouse has not filed a defamation suit against the Los Angeles Lakers star or anyone else, his spokesperson told The Associated Press.

text: Newly discovered video from election night at the TCF Center in Detroit shows tens of thousands of illegal ballots were delivered 8 hours after the deadline.

claimReview.title: Video taken election night doesn’t show illegal activity in Detroit
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 8 p.m. deadline on Election Day in Michigan was for voters to cast their ballots, not for those ballots to be delivered or counted. In big cities such as Detroit, it can take several hours for ballots to go through security checks before being sent to counting locations. That process is customary and legal, according to Michigan Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson’s office.

text: A National Public Radio story headlined “Trump Supporters Storm U.S. Capitol, Clash With Police” was published on Wednesday at 9

claimReview.title: NPR headline not written before Trump supporters stormed Capitol
claimReview.textualRating: False. The story provided a running account of developments around protests at the Capitol as Congress met to certify electoral votes in the presidential election. The story was initially published at 9:33 a.m. and the headline was changed later in the day as the protests turned violent.

text: A video clip shows President Joe Biden “abruptly” leaving this year’s Thanksgiving turkey pardoning ceremony at the White House.

claimReview.title: Video misrepresents Biden’s departure from White House turkey pardon
claimReview.textualRating: False. In a full video of Monday’s ceremony, Biden spends several minutes speaking and taking photos with guests after pardoning two turkeys in an address before hundreds of attendees. He can be seen waving to the crowd, plus giving a thumbs up and a salute, before leaving the event.

text: Photos show diesel-powered generators at COP26.

claimReview.title: COP26 generators don’t use diesel, contrary to tweets
claimReview.textualRating: False. COP26 says it has generators on hand to provide backup power to temporary buildings and the generators are powered by battery, hydrogenated vegetable oil or solar — not diesel. The photos show electric-powered air handlers, chillers, and heaters, according to the manufacturer.

text: Photo of a massive, cyclone-like cloud shows Hurricane Dorian hovering over the Bahamas as it approaches the Florida coast.

claimReview.title: Image does not show Hurricane Dorian arriving in Florida
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image, a digital art work, was fabricated.

text: Video shows British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak lighting candles for the Diwali festival this week outside of his new office on Downing Street.

claimReview.title: Video of UK leader Sunak lighting Diwali candles is from 2020
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows Sunak lighting candles in front of 11 Downing Street ahead of the Diwali festival on Nov. 12, 2020, when he was chancellor of the exchequer, not prime minister.

text: A video shows Russian leader Vladimir Putin announcing Russia will send “help to Palestine” in the

claimReview.title: A 2021 video shows Putin celebrating a WWII anniversary, not promising to aid Palestinians
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from 2021 and shows Putin speaking at Russia’s Victory Day military parade. He doesn’t make any references to the Middle East conflict in the speech, but rather talks about the defeat of Nazism. Russia has so far issued carefully calibrated criticism of both sides in the Israel-Hamas war.

text: Henry Ford said

claimReview.title: Quote on government assistance incorrectly attributed to Henry Ford
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say Ford, the businessman who founded Ford Motor Company, never said this. Similar quotes have appeared online and in print over the years, but there is no evidence Ford was the speaker.

text: Joe Biden said he grew up in Section 8 housing, but it was not created until 1974.

claimReview.title: Biden did not claim he lived in Section 8 housing as a boy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Democratic presidential candidate did not say he grew up in Section 8 housing.

text: A video of Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla at a World Economic Forum conference in Davos, Switzerland, shows him explaining new Pfizer technology, a pill with a sensor that alerts “relevant authorities” when digested.

claimReview.title: Video shows Pfizer CEO at Davos in 2018 talking about another company’s pill
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 2018 video shows Bourla was referring to a pill that had been developed by a separate company and approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration months prior. The pill, which includes an ingestible sensor to digitally track whether patients take their medication, is used to treat people with schizophrenia, bipolar I disorder and major depressive disorder.

text: The state of Florida banned “To Kill a Mockingbird” in schools, along with a number of other popular titles on a “Banned Book List.”

claimReview.title: Florida didn’t ban ‘To Kill a Mockingbird,’ as fake list suggests
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for Gov. Ron DeSantis confirmed that the state has not banned “To Kill a Mockingbird.” A school district in Florida’s Palm Beach County removed the title from school libraries earlier this year as part of a review, but later returned it, according to district documents. The “Banned Book List” shared across social media this week is also bogus, and includes many titles that aren’t banned in Florida, according to groups that track book bans and challenges.

text: The U.S. Marine Corps arrested Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla and killed his bodyguards.

claimReview.title: Pfizer’s CEO has not been arrested by the US Marine Corps
claimReview.textualRating: False. Bourla has not been arrested, Pfizer confirmed to The Associated Press. The claim was made in a post by a website that says it publishes “humor, parody, and satire” and has previously published similar false stories. The site has since taken the post down.

text: Fox News covered a new chicken sandwich from Popeyes on Monday morning instead of a deadly mass shooting in Louisville, Kentucky.

claimReview.title: Fox didn’t cover Popeyes over Louisville shooting
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image claiming to show the broadcast was fabricated. Online archives show Fox News had extensive coverage throughout the morning of the Louisville shooting, in which five people were killed. Regardless, Popeyes did not announce a new chicken sandwich on Monday.

text: After a legal challenge from Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and a group of scientists, the U.S. Supreme Court has ruled COVID-19 vaccines are unsafe and “canceled universal vaccination.”

claimReview.title: Supreme Court hasn’t ruled on COVID-19 vaccines or ‘universal vaccination’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Supreme Court has not issued any rulings regarding the safety of coronavirus vaccines. Kennedy, a lawyer who has advocated against vaccines, called articles sharing the claim “misinformation.” He said he has been involved in dozens of lawsuits regarding vaccine safety, but none of them have reached the Supreme Court.

text: President Joe Biden once said he was about to "swoop down with Special Forces" and "gather up every gun in America," and now his administration is advertising giving out guns to people who get vaccinated for COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Video misrepresents Biden statements, policies on guns
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden was mocking false claims about gun legislation, not outlining actual plans, in this video from 2013. His administration has not advertised any federal program offering guns to people who get vaccinated.

text: Actor Robert De Niro was captured on video yelling at anti-Israel protesters in New York City.

claimReview.title: Video shows Robert De Niro rehearsing for a Netflix series, not yelling at anti-Israel protesters
claimReview.textualRating: False. De Niro was rehearsing a scene for his upcoming Netflix series “Zero Day” while the production was filming on a street in New York City, a Netflix spokesperson told The Associated Press. His comments are part of the script and had nothing to do with the Israel-Hamas war or protests around it.

text: The Atlantic published an article with the headline, “The Heroism of Biden’s Bike Fall” after President Joe Biden fell on Saturday as he tried to dismount his bicycle.

claimReview.title: Fake Atlantic headline spreads on social media
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Atlantic did not publish such an article, a spokesperson for the media outlet confirmed to The Associated Press. A screenshot purporting to show the headline is fabricated.

text: SM-102 is an ingredient in the Moderna vaccine that is not safe for humans or veterinary use.

claimReview.title: Moderna vaccine ingredient falsely targeted as unsafe
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media posts suggesting the vaccine is unsafe are comparing two different formulations of SM-102. In one, the lipid is used to coat messenger RNA in Moderna's vaccine so it can be delivered to cells. In the other, it is preserved in chloroform. The SM-102 used in the vaccine does not contain chloroform, which is toxic.

text: Photo shows body of ambassador “tortured” during Obama administration

claimReview.title: Photo shows soldier being tortured, not the U.S. ambassador to Libya
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo circulating on Facebook shows a soldier being tortured in Argentina by other soldiers in 1986.

text: Photo shows Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden kissing a 15-year-old girl on the lips.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Biden kissing his granddaughter, not a 15-year-old
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows Biden giving his 19-year-old granddaughter, Finnegan, a kiss during a campaign stop in Iowa in February.

text: California is still counting votes more than a week after the March 5 primary, a sign the election was rigged.

claimReview.title: California is still counting votes from Super Tuesday. Experts say that’s normal
claimReview.textualRating: False. It is not unusual for California’s vote count to extend long past Election Day and there has been no indication of widespread fraud in this year’s primaries, experts told The Associated Press. Factors that contribute to this lengthy process include the large number of people who vote by mail, provisional ballots and signature verification.

text: Photo shows Ghislaine Maxwell with the president of operations at Wayfair.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Ghislaine Maxwell with Wayfair’s 'president of operations'
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 2003 photo shows Maxwell, a British socialite and longtime associate of Jeffrey Epstein, with George Bamford, founder Bamford Watch Department. Wayfair, a company that sells furniture and home goods online, currently does not have a president of operations.

text: CNN confirmed that Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden plans to “step aside” after winning the 2020 election, making Kamala Harris president.

claimReview.title: CNN did not confirm unfounded claim that Joe Biden plans to step aside
claimReview.textualRating: False. CNN made no such confirmation. This claim takes a column published on CNN’s website out of context. There is no evidence of any plan for Biden to step down during his presidency.

text: Video shows Tiger Woods claiming victory before a match-winning putt drops in the hole at Presidents Cup.

claimReview.title: Tiger Woods did not celebrate Presidents Cup win before putt dropped in hole
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, which was taken as Woods won his first match at the Presidents Cup golf tournament on Dec. 15, was edited to make it appear he was so confident of making the putt that he took off his hat and walked over to shake his opponent’s hand before the putt dropped in the hole.

text: Photo shows the Republican Florida Rep. Matt Gaetz as a senior in high school with a mullet hairstyle and a tuxedo.

claimReview.title: ‘Senior photo’ of Matt Gaetz is fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. Gaetz’s face was superimposed onto a different man’s portrait, which has been circulating as a meme online for at least 11 years.

text: An image shows a social media post by actor Mel Gibson about “the end” of Israel and the country’s desire to “destroy everything” in its way.

claimReview.title: Mel Gibson did not post on social media about ‘the end’ of Israel
claimReview.textualRating: False. The post was not made by Gibson, who does not have any public social media accounts, the actor’s publicist told The Associated Press.

text: Put a small pea-sized amount of antibiotic ointment like mupirocin inside your nostrils. The ointment will kill any infectious germs when you breathe and should kill the coronavirus before it gets to your lungs.

claimReview.title: Antibiotic ointment not effective against COVID-19
claimReview.textualRating: False. The ointment will not protect you from the coronavirus.

text: Absentee ballots will not be accepted unless voters mail them with up to two stamps.

claimReview.title: USPS won’t reject mail-in ballots for too few stamps
claimReview.textualRating: False. Some states and counties do require voters to pay for their own postage on mail-in ballots, however, the United States Postal Service says its policy is to deliver all ballots, even those with insufficient postage. In those cases, the agency says that postage is collected from local election offices upon delivery of the ballot, or at a later date.

text: German satirical magazine Titanic published an October cover showing a cartoon of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy devouring money and military equipment with the title “Ewiger Appetit,” eternal appetite in English.

claimReview.title: German magazine didn’t publish cartoon cover depicting Zelenskyy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The magazine did not publish this cover. Online archives of the magazine’s recent publications show no record of such an image, and the magazine’s editor-in-chief confirmed to The Associated Press that the cover is not authentic.

text: George Zimmerman, the former neighborhood watch coordinator acquitted of all charges after fatally shooting Trayvon Martin in Florida in 2012, has been arrested in Atlanta for driving under the influence and is being held in Fulton County Jail.

claimReview.title: Man who shot Trayvon Martin has not been arrested on DUI charges
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Fulton County Sheriff’s Office told the Associated Press there is no record of this arrest. Fulton County jail records accessible online also didn’t show him as an inmate.

text: The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is restarting border wall construction in the Rio Grande Valley.

claimReview.title: Biden administration is repairing levee, not expanding border wall
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers clarified on Twitter that it has begun work to repair the Rio Grande Valley’s flood barrier system, which was previously partially excavated to make way for the border wall. The work does not involve expanding the border wall.

text: Mel Gibson is directing a film about the wealthy Rothschild family

claimReview.title: Mel Gibson is not working on a film about the Rothschilds
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for the Mad Max star says he’s never been involved in developing a movie about the wealthy Jewish family, and has no plans to direct such a film. Gibson was briefly linked to a role in “Rothchild,” a dark comedy about New York’s elite. The film, which was unrelated to the real life family, never materialized.

text: A 2018 study that looked at the effectiveness of N95 masks versus medical masks found that masks don't stop the spread of viruses.

claimReview.title: Study did not find that masks do not work
claimReview.textualRating: False. The study found that N95 masks and medical masks are equally effective at preventing viral respiratory infections and illnesses -- not that masks do not work.

text: Chelsea Clinton tweeted about Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, asking, “What kind of man pursues a physical relationship with an underling and has relations with her in their office?”

claimReview.title: Chelsea Clinton didn’t tweet about Bill Gates’ ‘behavior’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet was fabricated. A spokesperson for Clinton confirmed the tweet is fake, and it does not appear in an advanced search of her Twitter feed or in credible news reports.

text: Video of a young actor being filmed lying in a pool of fake blood shows propaganda being created for use in the Israel-Hamas war.

claimReview.title: A video spreading online shows the making of a 2022 film, not propaganda for the Israel-Hamas war
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is behind-the-scenes footage from the making of “Empty Place,” a short film about Palestinians lost to Israeli occupation. Some on social media are claiming it shows Israelis creating propaganda, while others are claiming that it shows Palestinians doing the same.

text: COVID-19 PCR tests weren’t developed using samples of the coronavirus and instead detect “something else.”

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on PCR test development
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. A PCR test created by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention at the beginning of the pandemic was developed with genetic sequencing of the coronavirus, rather than actual samples. But experts say that is a normal method, and the test was still designed to detect the virus and was proven effective in studies.

text: A clip shows actor Tom Hanks calling a young girl a “sexy baby” at a beauty pageant.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Tom Hanks beauty pageant parody
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The short clip is taken from a sketch that appeared on “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” in 2011. The full video pokes fun at the TLC reality series “Toddlers & Tiaras,” which followed the lives of child beauty pageant contestants.

text: Video of a vehicle driving along the Kerch Bridge in daylight shows Saturday’s

claimReview.title: Old video doesn’t show Kerch Bridge explosion
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video has been online since at least early May and an Associated Press analysis of the clip revealed evidence that it was edited to feature an explosion. Two video analysis experts also told the AP that the video appeared to be manipulated.

text: Video shows that a local news reporter can’t believe no one showed up for Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden and running mate Sen. Kamala Harris’ event in Arizona.

claimReview.title: Biden event attracted no crowd because timing, location weren’t widely shared
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was edited to remove the portion where the reporter says that Biden campaign officials have not been notifying the public about their events due to the coronavirus.

text: Australia is seeing its sharpest rise in deaths in 80 years because of the coronavirus vaccine.

claimReview.title: Spike in deaths in Australia from COVID illnesses, not vaccine
claimReview.textualRating: False. While a recent analysis found that the country saw a higher than expected number of deaths in 2022, it also concluded coronavirus vaccines weren’t the cause. Government officials and experts in Australia concur, saying the rise in deaths is largely the result of COVID-19 infections, not vaccine-related deaths.

text: Video captures a NASA “artificial cloud generation system” that produces rain.

claimReview.title: Video does not show a NASA cloud generation system
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video combines separate clips of rocket engine tests done at NASA’s Stennis Space Center in Mississippi, which as a result created clouds.

text: A video shows the words “You’re F-----” painted in large yellow letters on a road within former President Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Florida, following

claimReview.title: Video manipulated to show a profanity on Mar-a-Lago road
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. Footage posted on YouTube in April 2020 was edited to include the profanity. The Twitter user who originally shared the altered video acknowledged it was not real, but other social media users then shared it as authentic.

text: Photos of the London Olympics opening ceremony in 2012 prove that the COVID-19 pandemic has been planned for a long time.

claimReview.title: Photos of London Olympics don’t show prior knowledge of pandemic
claimReview.textualRating: False. The costumes and figures in the ceremony paid tribute to Britain’s National Health Service and to iconic British children’s literature. They had no relationship to the COVID-19 pandemic, which emerged nearly eight years later.

text: The county of Oxfordshire, England, which includes the city of Oxford, is imposing a “climate lockdown” that will confine residents to their neighborhoods.

claimReview.title: Traffic plan in Oxfordshire, England, isn’t a ‘climate lockdown’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Oxfordshire has approved a plan to put “traffic filters” on some main roads, restricting drivers’ access during daytime hours and freeing up space for buses, cyclists and pedestrians. But car owners can apply for daylong permits to bypass the new rules, and many other vehicles are exempt. All parts of the county will remain accessible by car, officials said.

text: A bus advertisement on knowing the warning signs of strokes in children is related to the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Ads raising awareness about strokes in kids are not related to vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The ad was placed in May of 2021 as part of pediatric stroke awareness month and is not related to COVID-19 vaccines. The Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have not listed strokes as a side effect for children taking COVID-19 vaccines.

text: A school board in suburban Pittsburgh voted to ban CNN from its classrooms.

claimReview.title: PA school board didn’t vote to ban CNN in classrooms
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Norwin School Board voted to remove television watching during homeroom classes at Norwin Middle School unless it is “student, teacher or administrator driven.” Teachers can still use their own discretion to show instructional videos from any source, including CNN, according to district Superintendent Jeff Taylor.

text: Video shows parents in Toronto being blocked by police as children were given the COVID-19 vaccine in exchange for ice cream, without parental permission.

claimReview.title: Video shows protesters at Toronto vaccine site
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows protesters outside of a pop-up vaccination clinic in Toronto, not parents being kept from children as they received vaccines. In Ontario, it is up to health care workers to obtain consent, and support of a parent or legal guardian is required for those too young to understand.

text: CBS and Hulu quietly removed an episode of “The Brady Bunch” about the measles because it didn’t show anyone becoming seriously ill and therefore didn’t fit the television companies’ ‘agenda.’

claimReview.title: CBS, Hulu did not eliminate Brady Bunch episode because family gets the measles
claimReview.textualRating: False. Measles are not to blame for a missing Brady Bunch episode on CBS and Hulu streaming services. Several of the classic TV show’s episodes are not available because CBS was unable to get copyright clearance to broadcast the shows.

text: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tweeted Aug. 30

claimReview.title: Manufactured tweet attributed to Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
claimReview.textualRating: False. The fabricated Twitter post falsely attributed to Ocasio-Cortez was shared on social media platforms as Hurricane Dorian gained strength off Florida.

text: Video shows French police symbolically dropping their handcuffs to declare they will no longer participate in national lockdowns to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

claimReview.title: French police tossed cuffs in protest, but not for lockdowns
claimReview.textualRating: False. This video is from June 2020 and does not show a protest against COVID-19 restrictions. The French police officers in the video were protesting new limits on arrest tactics and criticism of alleged violence and racism in their ranks after George Floyd’s death in the United States.

text: Jacob Blake, the Black man who police shot multiple times in Wisconsin on Sunday, was once charged for raping a teenage girl.

claimReview.title: Posts claiming Jacob Blake faces child rape charges are unfounded
claimReview.textualRating: False. No charges for sexual assault of a child have surfaced against Blake. Social media posts with these claims are shared without evidence. Blake was charged with third-degree sexual assault in Wisconsin in July for an incident that did not involve a minor.

text: When reporters asked President Donald Trump why he nominated Judge Amy Coney Barrett to replace the late Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, he said Barrett is “much better looking” than other women who have appeared on the court and “if people are more attractive, they get a fantastic amount of respect.”

claimReview.title: No evidence Trump commented on Amy Coney Barrett’s appearance
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence Trump ever made these comments. His public remarks about Barrett since her nomination have centered on her qualifications for the court, including her education, work background and clerkship for the late Justice Antonin Scalia.

text: A video shows an MSNBC news broadcast reporting on a fake FEMA news conference about the wildfires on Maui.

claimReview.title: Fake FEMA news conference took place in 2007, not during the recent Maui wildfires
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a controversial news conference staged by the Federal Emergency Management Agency during wildfires in Southern California in 2007. FEMA staff members posed as reporters during the informational session although some reporters were allowed to call in but only to listen.

text: Former President Donald Trump won the 2020 election. Democrats cheated.

claimReview.title: False claims question Biden 2020 victory
claimReview.textualRating: False. President Joe Biden defeated Trump in the 2020 presidential election, earning 306 electoral votes to Trump’s 232. State officials from both parties, election security experts and former Republican Attorney General William Barr said the election went smoothly with no evidence of widespread fraud.

text: Photo shows 19 lanes of bumper-to-bumper traffic on Interstate 405 in Los Angeles, with an additional frontage road holding more lanes.

claimReview.title: Image edited to widen Southern California freeway
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. This image has been edited to add lanes and cars to the freeway. The 405 has a total of 12 lanes in the part of Los Angeles where this photo was taken, not 19.

text: A photo shows comedian Chris Rock wearing a pad on his cheek during the incident at the Oscars where Will Smith slapped him.

claimReview.title: Altered photo fuels false claims that Oscars slap was staged
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The photo, which was originally published by Reuters, was manipulated to make it seem as if Rock was wearing a pad on his left cheek. Rock was not wearing a pad on his face when he was hit.

text: Brewing company Anheuser-Busch fired its entire marketing department in response to its partnership with a transgender influencer and the rollout of LGBTQ Pride-themed Bud Light cans that feature various pronouns.

claimReview.title: Bud Light maker didn’t fire marketing team over LGBTQ ads
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim about the marketing department initially spread as satire but some social media users shared it as real. Anheuser-Busch has not fired its marketing team, the company confirmed in a statement. Further, the cans were part of a limited rollout marking Pride Month in 2022 in Canada, and aren’t connected to the brand’s partnership with social media star Dylan Mulvaney.

text: A photo shows a crocodile swimming through a Floridian’s home following the landfall of Hurricane Ian.

claimReview.title: Photo altered to add Australian croc to flooded home
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. An image of a flooded room has been edited to add the crocodile. The original photo of the animal was taken by a nature cruise company in Australia’s Northern Territory, and shows a saltwater crocodile, which experts say is a species not found in Florida. Iterations of the edited photo have circulated online since at least 2020.

text: Under the proposed infrastructure bill, farmers will be taxed for each cow, including $6,500 a year for dairy cows.

claimReview.title: Infrastructure bill doesn’t include tax on cows
claimReview.textualRating: False. The infrastructure bill does not include those taxes. The same false claim was made in response to a separate, larger package being advanced by Democrats.

text: A new study from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that mask mandates have a negligible impact on coronavirus numbers.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent CDC study on mask mandates
claimReview.textualRating: False. The CDC’s Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report released March 5 found that state-issued mask mandates were associated with statistically significant decreases in county-level daily COVID-19 case and death growth rates, according to CDC scientist Gery Guy Jr., lead author of the study.

text: Authorities have released three defendants arrested on child neglect charges at a New Mexico compound, where the body of a 3-year-old boy was found in August.

claimReview.title: 3 defendants released in New Mexico compound case
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. Judge Emilio Chavez dismissed charges against the three defendants after prosecutors missed a 10-day deadline for a probable cause hearing in the case where the dead 3-year-old was discovered along with 11 children living in filth on the remote compound.

text: Video shows crowd chanting “F--- Joe Biden” during soccer game.

claimReview.title: Soccer match video edited to add anti-Biden chant
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was altered to add audio from a country music concert where the audience chanted the phrase. The original video shows a crowd at a 2016 soccer match between Argentina and Chile at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.

text: Troops in Washington turned their backs on President Joe Biden’s motorcade as it passed on its way to his inauguration at the U.S. Capitol.

claimReview.title: Troops did not turn their backs on Biden
claimReview.textualRating: False. The troops did not turn their backs on the newly elected president as a sign of protest. National Guard members were positioned that way in advance of the motorcade passing in accordance with safety protocol.

text: “Georgia’s new anti-voting law makes it a jail-time crime to drop off grandma’s absentee ballot in a drop box.”

claimReview.title: Delivering grandma’s ballot not a crime under Georgia law
claimReview.textualRating: False. The election bill signed into law by Republican Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp on March 25 has an exception allowing people to drop off ballots on behalf of their relatives.

text: A video shows a Doctors Without Borders medic in the West Bank city of Jenin take an assault rifle from a man lying on the ground and hand it to a man nearby who begins shooting.

claimReview.title: Video of West Bank fighting does not show a Doctors Without Borders medic giving a man a rifle
claimReview.textualRating: False. The man identified as a medic in the video does not belong to Doctors Without Borders, a spokesperson for the organization told The Associated Press. The international medical group works only in hospitals in that area. In addition, the man is wearing a vest that matches those worn by members of the Palestinian Medical Relief Society.

text: A video of ships being engulfed by an enormous sandstorm shows weather that is heading toward U.S. states including Florida and New York.

claimReview.title: Florida isn’t going to be hit by a massive sandstorm seen in footage from the Suez Canal
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a sandstorm in Egypt early last month as it blew over the Suez Canal. Although dust from the Sahara Desert has reached Florida multiple times this summer — a common occurrence known as the Saharan Air Layer — the sandstorm in the video has nothing to do with this phenomenon, meteorologists told The Associated Press.

text: A video shows a hidden entrance to a theater in Sicily where children are sacrificed by “elites.”

claimReview.title: Baseless child-sacrifice claim spreads about Sicilian theater
claimReview.textualRating: False. The theater in the video is Teatro Donnafugata, a venue built inside a castle in Ragusa, Sicily, that hosts musical performances and plays. The original footage was posted by an Italian quick-change artist in 2021 and makes no mention of child sacrifice. The hidden entrance to the theater shown in the video is used to reach its central box seats, Teatro Donnafugata said in a statement to The Associated Press.

text: A video shows a BBC News report confirming Ukraine provided weapons to Hamas.

claimReview.title: BBC did not report that Ukraine is sending arms to Hamas, a video was fabricated
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The widely shared video clip is fabricated. Officials with the BBC and Bellingcat, an investigative news website that is cited in the video as the source, confirm that neither outlet has reported such a claim. Experts say there is no evidence of Hamas making such a claim, either, and say there is no reason for Ukraine to arm the militant group.
List (Page)

text: Photos show a man in Africa who is the oldest person in the world and just celebrated his 146th birthday.

claimReview.title: African man isn’t oldest person in world at 146
claimReview.textualRating: False. The person in photos on social media posts is not a man named Mzee John Kiplagat from Kenya, as the posts claim. The images date to 2016 and depict Saparman Sodimejo, an Indonesian man who died at the purported age of 146, according to the photographer who snapped the images. But Sodimejo’s true age was never independently verified, and a spokesperson for the Guinness Book of World Records confirmed that neither Kiplagat or Sodimejo has ever held their record for oldest living person or oldest living man.

text: Lysol “knew” of the new coronavirus before the outbreak happened.

claimReview.title: Disinfectant maker not aware of new virus before viral outbreak from China
claimReview.textualRating: False. While Lysol products have labels that state they disinfect against “Human coronavirus,” it is not a specific reference to the new coronavirus that emerged in China in December. Coronaviruses are part of a large family of viruses that can range from the common cold to SARS, a viral respiratory illness that spread to two dozen countries in 2003 before being contained.

text: An emergency broadcast system test on Oct. 4 will send a signal to cell phones nationwide in order to activate nanoparticles such as graphene oxide that have been introduced into people’s bodies.

claimReview.title: Conspiracy theories about FEMA’s Oct. 4 emergency alert test spread online
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The Oct. 4 test of the nationwide Emergency Alert System uses the same familiar audio tone that’s been in use since the 1960s to broadcast warnings across the country. A spokesperson for the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which is overseeing the test, also said there are no known adverse health effects from the signal. The claims revive long-debunked conspiracy theories about the contents of the COVID-19 vaccine.
List (Page)

text: Video shows a large crowd of migrants climbing a fence at the United States’ southern border with Mexico.

claimReview.title: Video of migrants climbing Morocco-Spain fence misrepresented as US border
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows migrants climbing a fence between Morocco and Melilla, a Spanish enclave in North Africa, in March 2022. The same footage appeared in local news reports at the time, and circulated on social media.

text: Russian president Vladimir Putin has “ordered the destruction of all COVID-19 vaccine stockpiles.”

claimReview.title: Russia is replenishing COVID-19 vaccines, not destroying them
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence that Putin ordered all COVID-19 vaccines to be destroyed, nor is there any official government statement on the matter. The Russian Ministry of Health announced on March 4 that it had replenished supplies of Sputnik V, the country’s domestically developed COVID-19 vaccine following some shortages of the jab, according to a state-owned domestic news agency.

text: A photo shows people in Brazil protesting “election fraud.”

claimReview.title: Photo shows Brazil protest in 2016, not 2022
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo, published by The Associated Press, was taken in March 2016 and shows people demonstrating against then-president Dilma Rousseff over allegations of corruption.

text: New figures from the United Kingdom’s Office for National Statistics shows that three of the country’s largest cities, London, Manchester and Birmingham, are now all “minority white.”

claimReview.title: UK census data on ethnic demographics misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. ONS has five categories for white-identifying groups. The claim excludes several of these data subsets. The 2021 census data shows that white residents in London and Manchester across all categories still exceed 50% of the population. Birmingham, however, falls slightly under that with 48.6% of residents identifying as white across all categories.

text: Tweet from Chicago Public Schools cancels all classes until Friday, Nov. 1, because of the teacher’s strike.

claimReview.title: Chicago Public Schools did not tweet that classes are canceled until Nov. 1
claimReview.textualRating: False. Chicago Public Schools did not tweet that classes will be canceled until Friday, Nov. 1.

text: The CEO of Pfizer had to cancel a planned trip to Israel because he was not fully vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Pfizer CEO was fully vaccinated in March
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The Aug. 5 post making this claim lacks the critical context that the trip was canceled in early March, before many people had been vaccinated. Albert Bourla, the chairman and CEO of Pfizer, announced on Twitter that he received his second dose of the vaccine on March 10.

text: A hologram of a giant Barbie doll is being displayed in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

claimReview.title: Video of giant Barbie walking in Dubai was computer generated, not a hologram
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video appearing to show the giant toy was computer-generated and added to real footage from Dubai, the advertising agency that made the clip told The Associated Press.

text: White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki said, “If you don't buy anything, you won't experience inflation.”

claimReview.title: Image falsely attributes quotes on inflation to Psaki
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no record of Psaki making that statement, and the image sharing that quote was previously published as satire.

text: Iceland has declared that all religions are "mental disorders."

claimReview.title: Iceland hasn’t declared all religions 'mental disorders'
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim originated from a 2020 post on a satire blog. Iceland, which has a state church to which almost two-thirds of its population belongs, has made no such determination.

text: Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger has a brother, Ron, who works for a Chinese tech firm, Huawei.

claimReview.title: Brother of Georgia SOS is not a Chinese tech firm executive
claimReview.textualRating: False. Raffensperger’s office confirmed to The Associated Press his brother is not Ron Raffensperger who works for Huawei.

text: A new order from the Biden administration directed Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents to release all detained immigrants immediately.

claimReview.title: No, Biden did not instruct ICE to release all detained immigrants
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Biden administration tried to temporarily halt deportations for certain noncitizens, but did not order detained immigrants to be released from ICE custody. The false claim is based on the interpretation of a leaked email issued by a local ICE officer in Houston. The email in question was retracted the next day by the officer's supervisor in charge of the Houston office.

text: A “verified and approved” stamp that follows signature verification for mail-in ballots was “pre-printed” on envelopes during the 2020 election in Maricopa County, Arizona.

claimReview.title: Verification stamps weren't pre-printed on Arizona ballot envelopes
claimReview.textualRating: False. That claim is based on a misunderstanding of how scans of mail-in ballot envelopes are captured.

text: Video shows an attempted terrorist attack in Algeria where an airliner on its landing approach narrowly misses a fuel tanker that has pulled into its path.

claimReview.title: Video does not show attempted terrorist attack in Algeria
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip was taken from a video game and then circulated with false captions, including “Terrorist attack in Algeria, which fails to work because of the pilot's immense skill.”

text: A compilation of videos shows animals — including lions, an elephant and a rhinoceros — which were released from a French zoo by protestors during recent unrest triggered by the deadly police shooting of a teen.

claimReview.title: Videos of lions and other animals roaming city streets have nothing to do with protests in France
claimReview.textualRating: False. The videos predate the current riots in France and most were filmed in other countries, including the U.K., Nepal and the Czech Republic.

text: President Joe Biden has ordered dishonorable discharges for the 46% of troops who have refused to be vaccinated against COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Blog pushes falsehoods about discipline for unvaccinated troops
claimReview.textualRating: False. While troops who refuse to comply with the Pentagon’s recent vaccine mandate could legally be disciplined, including potentially being dishonorably discharged from the service, Biden has not ordered this action. In fact, the president does not have the authority to make those decisions, the Department of Defense confirmed in a statement to The Associated Press. Additionally, it is not true that 46% of troops have refused vaccines — the true percentage is considerably smaller.

text: $2.5 billion of American tax dollars has been allocated toward a welcoming center for immigrants coming to the country illegally.

claimReview.title: Claim that $2.5 billion has been allocated to immigrant ‘welcoming center’ is unfounded
claimReview.textualRating: False. There's no evidence of any such allocation. The closest match to the claim in U.S. legislation is in the $1 trillion bipartisan Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, which gives the General Services Administration about $3.4 billion for “construction and acquisition, and repairs and alterations of border stations and land ports of entry,” with $2.5 billion of that going toward items in U.S. Customs and Border Protection's five-year plan. However, CBP confirmed to The Associated Press that these items do not include a "welcoming center."

text: Photo shows Los Angeles County health director looking unwell.

claimReview.title: Photo edited to make LA County health director appear sick
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was manipulated to make the health director appear sickly, her face pale and her eyes ringed by dark circles.

text: Military ballot numbers in Wisconsin mysteriously decreased from 9,876 in 2020 to 1,573 in 2022, an unusually large discrepancy.

claimReview.title: Wisconsin military ballot data in widely shared posts is not official
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Wisconsin Elections Commission data shows that more than 1,900 military votes were cast in November’s election. That number, which is still being updated as clerks report their data, is higher than the 1,573 cited in the posts. While the number of military voters appears lower in 2022 than it was in 2020, that’s typical in a midterm election year, according to historical data.

text: Photo shows former President Bill Clinton with Jeffrey Epstein

claimReview.title: Photo of smiling Epstein, Clinton has been altered
claimReview.textualRating: False. A photo purporting to show Clinton, wearing a suit and red tie, next to Epstein, in navy zip-up sweatshirt, has been manipulated.

text: A black-and-white photo shows Rep. Ilhan Omar of Minnesota in a military uniform undergoing training.

claimReview.title: Photograph does not show Rep. Omar with a gun at a military camp
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photograph of a woman checking an automatic weapon was taken by The Associated Press on Feb. 25, 1978, before Omar was born. According to information with the photo, it was taken at a military training campus at Halane, Mogadishu.

text: Walt Disney will replace Benjamin Franklin on the U.S. $100 bill.

claimReview.title: Walt Disney will not appear on US $100 bill, claim started as satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim originated in a satirical article. A spokesperson for the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, which produces U.S. paper currency, told The Associated Press that it has never featured Disney on its notes and that it has no future plans to do so.

text: Rifles killed 297 people in the U.S. in 2022, while constipation killed 2,167.

claimReview.title: Constipation does not kill more people than rifles in the US
claimReview.textualRating: False. This statistic uses FBI data from 2018 for the first figure and cumulative Centers for Disease Control and Prevention data from a period of 15 years for the second. Neither agency has released data for 2022 on the number of people killed in the U.S. by either cause, but 2020 figures show at least 455 were murdered by rifle that year while deaths due to constipation were less than half of that.

text: Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden said if he had been president, not one person would have died from COVID-19.
