claimReview.title: Biden didn’t say zero people would have died from COVID-19 if he were president
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence Biden ever said this. He did say if President Donald Trump had done his job from the beginning of the pandemic, all the people who died of the coronavirus would be alive today. That’s a stretch, experts say.

text: New York hospitals, including NYU Langone Health, will not release newborn babies or infants in neonatal intensive care units, frequently referred to as NICUs, to parents who have not been vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Parents don’t need to be vaccinated to take their newborns home in New York
claimReview.textualRating: False. The New York State Department of Health and NYU Langone Health said no such restrictions exist.

text: A new study found that, after 90 days, the COVID-19 mRNA vaccines increase the chances that someone who is vaccinated will be infected with the omicron variant.

claimReview.title: Claim vaccines increase susceptibility to omicron unfounded
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. The observational study found that vaccines protect against infection from the variant but wanes over time, and protection is elevated with a booster. While the study results showed “negative” effectiveness 90 days after someone has been fully vaccinated with two doses, a study author and experts say that is likely the result of bias in the data, not an indication that vaccines are harming recipients.

text: Video shows a man unloading ballots from a white van and using a red wagon to secretly haul them into Detroit’s ballot-counting center in the middle of the night.

claimReview.title: Wagon filmed at Detroit vote center held camera gear, not ballots
claimReview.textualRating: False. The man in the video was a photographer for the local news station WXYZ-TV. He was using a wagon to carry camera equipment for a 12-hour shift, the station reported on Wednesday.

text: The Texas cities of Austin and Houston are part of a global alliance of cities seeking to eliminate meat and dairy products in order to combat climate change.

claimReview.title: Austin and Houston aren’t cutting out meat and dairy to combat climate change, despite online claims
claimReview.textualRating:
False. Officials with the two cities say they have no plans to impose such a ban. A spokesperson for C40 Cities, the alliance referenced in social media posts, says the group has suggested ways cities can reduce meat and dairy consumption, but it hasn’t called for an outright ban on the products, nor is it forcing member cities to adopt any of its recommendations.
List (Page)

text: COVID-19 PCR test instructions show a “list of the viruses that can cause a PCR test to give false positives.”

claimReview.title: Dozens of viruses aren’t causing positive COVID-19 tests
claimReview.textualRating: False. The list being cited on social media shows viruses and other pathogens that are used to ensure the COVID-19 tests are accurate for detecting only the coronavirus.

text: Photo shows a woman at a California protest against stay-at-home orders holding a sign that says

claimReview.title: Photo altered to show protester holding Obama conspiracy theory poster
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo has been altered. The woman’s sign said, “Give me liberty or give me death.”

text: VAERS report states that a baby died from blood clots and inflamed arteries after drinking breast milk from his mother, who was vaccinated against COVID-19.

claimReview.title: No evidence breastfeeding after vaccination is anything but safe
claimReview.textualRating: Missing Context. The death of a six-week-old baby profiled in an online article has no proven link to COVID-19 vaccines, nor have scientists documented an established connection between vaccines and adverse reactions in nursing infants. Rather, the claim is based on a report that was submitted to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System, a passive reporting platform that does not prove a vaccine caused the health issue.

text: Photo shows Obama shaking hands with Iranian President Hassan Rouhani.

claimReview.title: Photo altered to show Obama shaking hands with Iran’s president
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image was manipulated to replace the former prime minister of India, Manmohan Singh, with Rouhani. The original photo was taken in 2011.

text: Myriam Bourla, the wife of Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla, has died from complications of the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Pfizer CEO’s wife did not die or experience ‘vaccine complications’
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for Pfizer told The Associated Press that Myriam Bourla is “alive and well.” The official called the incorrect claims “lies” meant to undermine public confidence in the company’s COVID-19 vaccine.

text: Video shows a large number of Indian students in Toronto Pearson International Airport on Sunday waiting to be deported after their International English Language Testing Systems exams were found to be fake.

claimReview.title: Video does not show students awaiting deportation in Toronto airport
claimReview.textualRating: False. The students in the video were not being deported, and the reason they were waiting at the airport had nothing to do with faked language exams.

text: Yellowstone National Park officials have “closed down the park” due to a rising “volcanic uplift.”

claimReview.title: No, Yellowstone hasn’t ‘closed’ over volcanic concerns
claimReview.textualRating: False. The national park is open, though many roads are currently closed to automobiles for the winter. Experts say the ground at Yellowstone regularly rises and subsides but this has been trending downward in recent years. There are no concerns of an impending volcanic eruption.

text: Photo shows a massive protest in Trieste, Italy, against a new requirement that all workers show a COVID-19 health pass.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Swiss music festival, not recent Italian protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo doesn’t show Italy, and was taken in 2018 at Street Parade, a music festival in Zurich, Switzerland.

text: Democratic Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer had an “affair” in 1977 with his daughter’s best friend from high school when the girl was 16.

claimReview.title: False posts about Sen. Chuck Schumer originated as satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. Versions of this baseless story have been circulating since a satire site first made up the rumor in late 2017.

text: A study by scientists at Sloan Kettering discovered Messenger RNA inactivates tumor suppressing proteins, meaning that COVID-19 mRNA vaccines can cause cancer.

claimReview.title: Article makes false claims about mRNA vaccines and cancer
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 2018 study has no relevance to the COVID-19 mRNA vaccines. Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center confirmed the claim is false and misrepresents the findings of the study.

text: If you are unvaccinated, you can get COVID and have over 99% chance of survival. If you get vaccinated, you can STILL get COVID and will still have over 99% chance of survival.

claimReview.title: Survival rates for COVID-19 misrepresented in posts
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. On average about 98.2% of known COVID-19 patients in the U.S. survive, but each individual’s chance of dying from the virus will vary depending on their age, whether they have an underlying health condition and whether they are vaccinated. While people who are vaccinated can still get infected, these “breakthrough” cases are rare and vaccines dramatically reduce severe illness and death.

text: Using tampons can cause endometriosis by pushing endometrial cells back up into “your belly cavity.”

claimReview.title: Tampons don't cause endometriosis
claimReview.textualRating: False. Tampons pose no such risk, gynecologists told The Associated Press. Tampons absorb blood rather than blocking the cervical canal, and research shows that tampon use is not associated with a higher rate of endometriosis.

text: {"_ref"

claimReview.title: A photo that appears to show Trump's ear with no damage after the attempted assassination is actually from 2022
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken on Sept. 17, 2022, at a rally in Youngstown, Ohio, for then-U.S. Senate candidate JD Vance. Trump appeared at the Republican National Convention Monday night with a large, white bandage on his right ear. Myriad photos show his ear bloodied after a shooter opened fire at his rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, over the weekend.

claimReview.title: No, Starbucks is not sponsoring the Republican National Convention
claimReview.textualRating: False. Starbucks is providing coffee and other beverages to first responders at five RNC venues through a partnership with the Milwaukee 2024 Host Committee, according to a spokesperson for the company. It is not providing a cash sponsorship of any kind. The company has a similar partnership planned with the Chicago 2024 Host Committee for the Democratic National Convention in August, the spokesperson said. Both host committees are nonpartisan, nonprofit entities that serve as liaisons between the Republican or Democratic National Committee, respectively, as well as each convention’s host city and state.

text: A video shows Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy saying that NATO “can use nuclear weapons on Russia” in order to deter Russia from using its own nuclear arsenal.

claimReview.title: Zelenskyy did not ask NATO to strike Russia with nuclear weapons
claimReview.textualRating: False. Erroneous English subtitles were added to a video of Zelenskyy discussing what NATO should do to deter Russia from using nuclear weapons. In his comments, Zelenskyy called for “preemptive strikes” against Russia, but English captions added to the video change his words to make it appear he specifically mentioned the use of nuclear weapons. Ukrainian officials later said that Zelenskyy was referring to preventive sanctions and armed aid.

text: An image shows a TMZ headline saying Madonna is “clinically brain dead.”

claimReview.title: Fabricated headline spreads false claim about Madonna’s health
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image of the headline is fabricated, TMZ confirmed, and the pop superstar released a statement on Instagram this week saying she’s “on the road to recovery” after being hospitalized for a “serious bacterial infection.”

text: At the Huntington Place ballot counting site in Detroit after the Aug. 2 election, at least 50% of ballots lacked evidence of signature verification, and large bags and coolers under tables caused a security issue.

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on signatures, ‘large bags’ at Detroit ballot counting site
claimReview.textualRating: False. All the ballots counted at the facility had gone through the signature review process, according to Daniel Baxter, election administrator for the city of Detroit. The bags and coolers contained food and belongings for election workers who were not able to leave while ballots were counted, Baxter said. All workers go through a security screening and are constantly being watched during the counting process.

text: In 1977, Time magazine published a cover that said “How To Survive The Coming Ice Age.” In 2008, the same magazine interviewed the same experts to run a cover article titled

claimReview.title: Time magazine cover declaring ‘coming Ice Age’ is not real
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Time cover labeled in social posts as coming from 1977 is actually a cover from 2007, with the image altered to change the title from “The Global Warming Survival Guide” to “How to Survive the Coming Ice Age,” Time magazine archives show.

text: President Joe Biden mistakenly read the phrase "end of quote” directly from a teleprompter during a speech.

claimReview.title: Clip from Biden speech misrepresented online
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. During a Tuesday speech about the economy, Biden used the words “end of quote” to signify the end of a phrase he was quoting from John Furner, president and CEO of Walmart’s U.S. division. A short clip of Biden’s address has been taken out of context to falsely suggest he unintentionally read the phrase “end of quote” directly from a teleprompter script.

text: Walmart is offering 85 percent off storewide purchases with a Black Friday coupon.

claimReview.title: Attention Walmart shoppers: 85 percent off coupon is not real
claimReview.textualRating: False. Walmart did not release a Black Friday coupon offering 85 percent off.

text: Obama kicks reporter out of press briefing.

claimReview.title: President Obama did not kick reporter out of press briefing in 2015
claimReview.textualRating: False. Former President Barack Obama did not throw a reporter out of a 2015 press conference for asking a question, as a claim circulating widely online suggests.

text: A video of IRS agents in police vests shows the agency training members of a new law enforcement force.

claimReview.title: Video shows college campus event, not ‘new IRS police force’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video doesn’t show IRS agents being trained. The video was filmed in 2017 and shows special agents with IRS Criminal Investigation — the agency’s longstanding law enforcement division — conducting a simulation with college students. The single-day event is intended to offer educational opportunities to students. It is not an IRS training or recruitment program, an agency spokesperson said.

text: Bogus Nike coupon featuring Colin Kaepernick offers discount to ‘people of color’

claimReview.title: Bogus Nike coupon featuring Colin Kaepernick offers discount to ‘people of color’
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. Colin Kaepernick’s image does appear on a false coupon that offers a discount to “people of color.”

text: Searches of Michigan’s Voter Information Center show that dead residents voted in the Nov. 3 election, proving there was voter fraud in the recent election.

claimReview.title: Video does not show votes by dead residents in Michigan
claimReview.textualRating: False. Searches of the state’s voter information site are being shared on social media as proof that dead people cast ballots in the 2020 election. It actually shows legitimate voters. The Michigan secretary of state’s office confirmed that ballots of voters who have died are not counted in Michigan.

text: FIFA will preserve the feet of Pelé in its museum.

claimReview.title: FIFA isn’t keeping Pelé’s feet in a museum
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for FIFA confirmed there’s no truth to social media posts claiming that the organization will keep Pelé’s feet. The claim circulated on a social media page that labels itself as satire.

text: President Joe Biden restored taxpayer funding for the Wuhan Institute of Virology.

claimReview.title: Biden didn’t reinstate funding for Wuhan virus lab
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden has not directed funding for the Wuhan Institute of Virology. A National Institutes of Health grant that had funded some research at the lab was terminated in April 2020. That grant was reinstated during the administration of former President Donald Trump in July 2020, but all activities associated with it remain suspended until the grantee meets certain conditions, according to an NIH spokesperson.

text: Videos show children vanishing from a school bus and adults disappearing from a city street, among other places.

claimReview.title: Videos don’t show real people vanishing. They were made by a Christian group to depict the Rapture
claimReview.textualRating: False. The videos were created by a Christian organization to illustrate how the Rapture would appear on camera and encourage people to learn more about the group’s religious message.

text: A video shot in Gwinnett County, Georgia, shows a representative of election technology firm Dominion Voting Systems committing election fraud by downloading ballot tabulation data onto a USB thumb drive, manipulating it on a separate laptop and secretly taking the thumb drive out of the room.

claimReview.title: Video doesn’t show an election tech manipulating votes in Georgia
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a contract employee with Dominion transferring a report from an Election Management Server to a county computer so he could read it, according to Gabriel Sterling, a top official in the Georgia secretary of state’s office. Gwinnett County Communications Director Joe Sorenson confirmed this, saying the worker was “using a laptop to filter requested information,” not manipulate the data. A Dominion spokesman has said it would be physically impossible to upload foreign material to the company’s servers.

text: “Deceased people” cast ballots in Michigan’s Aug. 4 statewide primary election, and 8% of all votes cast were rejected because the voter was dead.

claimReview.title: False claims circulate about dead voters in Michigan
claimReview.textualRating: False. Michigan election authorities have not found any evidence votes were cast on behalf of dead people in the Aug. 4 election. Rather, a small portion of voters died after they voted absentee ahead of Election Day. These ballots were disqualified and represent 8% of all rejected absentee ballots, not 8% of all ballots cast.

text: BlackRock has a substantial stake in both Dominion Voting Systems and Fox Corporation, so

claimReview.title: BlackRock doesn’t own stake in Dominion Voting Systems
claimReview.textualRating: False. While BlackRock does own non-voting shares in Fox Corporation, it doesn’t have any in Dominion Voting Systems, both the investment firm and the voting machine company confirmed. Posts are misrepresenting shares that BlackRock owns in an unrelated energy company also named Dominion.

text: The CEOs of Twitter, Walmart and CNBC all resigned on the first day of the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

claimReview.title: Posts distort facts of high-profile company departures
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Twitter’s CEO did step down on Monday. CNBC does not have a CEO and its chairman did not resign. Nor did the CEO of Walmart; although the company said its chief financial officer would be stepping down — but not leaving the company until 2023.

text: According to NASA scientists, so-called “climate change” is mostly driven by factors unrelated to human activity.

claimReview.title: NASA scientists attribute climate change primarily to human activity
claimReview.textualRating: False. NASA scientists say recent climate change is driven almost entirely by human activity.

text: A video of aircraft flying at night under heavy fire shows Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.

claimReview.title: 3D animation misrepresented as footage of Russian invasion
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is a 3D animation intended to depict World War II, and has been online since last year.

text: An executive with the energy company BP named Brice Cromwell wrote a post arguing that high gas prices in the U.S are due to excessive imports of foreign oil and insufficient domestic oil production.

claimReview.title: Posts about high gas prices falsely attributed to BP executive
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no such executive at BP and the statement did not come from the company, a spokesperson for BP confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: A photo circulating online of first lady Melania Trump escorted by a Marine is captioned

claimReview.title: Marines did not volunteer by the thousands for sentry duty in Trump White House
claimReview.textualRating: False. Marines do not typically volunteer to be White House sentries; they are assigned.

text: Video shows an elderly woman being detained by police in Germany because she didn’t have her vaccine passport.

claimReview.title: German woman detained for failing to show ID, not vaccine passport
claimReview.textualRating: False. The woman in the video was briefly detained during an unauthorized protest because she did not provide German authorities with identification, police and witnesses said. According to authorities, only IDs were checked on the scene, not vaccination passports.

text: Vaccine-related strokes in pilots have caused an "epidemic of plane crashes."

claimReview.title: No ‘epidemic’ of vaccine-related plane crashes reported
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Federal Aviation Administration said it has seen no such pattern of crashes. In fact, FAA data shows that the fatality rate in aviation accidents has decreased since 2020. A recent small plane crash given as an example also has not been linked to the COVID-19 vaccine.

text: The World Economic Forum published a story about

claimReview.title: The World Economic Forum did not write about the omicron variant in July
claimReview.textualRating: False. The WEF first published an article about detecting variants of the virus that causes COVID-19 in July, but archived versions of the story shows it did not mention omicron. The article was then updated in November after the WHO’s announcement, the archives show.

text: The U.S. Consulate in the northern Iraqi city of Irbil was destroyed on Monday by an Iranian missile strike.

claimReview.title: Iranian missiles did not strike the US Consulate in Iraq
claimReview.textualRating: False. Iranian missiles hit an upscale area near the consulate, killing five civilians and injuring six. However, a U.S. defense official told The Associated Press that no U.S. facilities were struck or damaged in the attacks.

text: A video shows President Joe Biden sitting with first lady Jill Biden at the University of Pennsylvania commencement, “Pomp and Circumstance” playing in the background as some in the crowd sing a disparaging chant.

claimReview.title: Disparaging chants added to video of Biden attending Penn graduation
claimReview.textualRating: Altered Video. The footage has been edited to add the chant. “Pomp and Circumstance” and other ambient sounds were the only sounds heard in similar clips of Biden at the ceremony, which were posted on Twitter. Associated Press staffers covering the ceremony said they heard no anti-Biden chants during the ceremony.

text: A video of a cyclone-like cloud shows a supercell storm over Miami, Florida.

claimReview.title: Video of cloud over Miami is digital artwork, not a real supercell storm
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is a years-old digital artwork that has been animated. The artist has previously confirmed to The Associated Press that the image is digital.

text: Pennsylvania has decertified voting machines in the sparsely populated Fulton County after a software company called Wake TSI looked over the machines and confirmed the machines would have to be “retired.”

claimReview.title: Posts distort reason for Pennsylvania voting machine decertification
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Pennsylvania Acting Secretary of State Veronica Degraffenreid did decertify voting machines in Fulton County, but she did so because a third party had been given access to the machines, not because of any problems the company found.

text: Video shows a meteor breaking into the earth's atmosphere.

claimReview.title: Video shows rocket debris over Oregon, not meteor
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, which was filmed in March 2021, shows burning debris from the SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket over the Pacific Northwest.

text: A video shows Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy with cocaine on his desk during a video call with Elon Musk.

claimReview.title: Zelenskyy video was edited to add white powder
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video has been edited. The original footage, posted on Zelenskyy’s Instagram on March 5, did not show the white powder, and that part of his desk is clearly empty.

text: Dead bodies are being liquified and fed to the living through a process called aquamation.

claimReview.title: No, 'water cremation' does not recycle bodies into drinking water
claimReview.textualRating: False. Alkaline hydrolysis, also known as aquamation, is an alternative to cremation that uses water to break down the body. It leaves behind only fragments of bones and teeth, as well as a sterile liquid solution. The fragments are typically pulverized and given to the family of the deceased, while the liquid is generally sent to a wastewater treatment facility, a system separate from one that is used to produce clean tap water.

text: Video shows that Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden missed his introduction at a drive-in event in Flint, Michigan, on Saturday.

claimReview.title: Biden didn't miss his cue in Michigan, as edited clip suggests
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. This clip is edited and filmed from an angle that doesn’t show Biden’s entrance. Full video of this exchange shows that Biden emerged from a building and began jogging toward the stage moments after former President Barack Obama called his name. Biden then proceeded to give his speech as planned.

text: Photos of a goat-headed store mannequin and a girl wearing a black shirt with a pentagram design show Target is selling a line of satanic-themed children’s clothing.

claimReview.title: No, Target isn’t selling satanic children's clothes
claimReview.textualRating: False. The images were generated with an artificial intelligence text-to-image tool, according to the artist who created them. Target also confirmed it has never sold the merchandise.

text: Electrically-charged stones have been discovered in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim electrically-charged rocks found in Congo
claimReview.textualRating: False. While some minerals can serve as conduits for electricity, rocks can’t store electricity, experts told The Associated Press. A video circulating in connection with the claim shows a rock that is likely pyrite, a common mineral that can conduct electricity but cannot store it, experts say.

text: A video showing two men collecting ballots from a drop box a day after Election Day is evidence of “cheating.”

claimReview.title: Video showing ballot collection does not show evidence of fraud
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for the Los Angeles County Registrar-Recorder County Clerk’s office said the men in the video are staff picking up ballots so they can be counted.

text: Eight Iowa counties have more adults registered to vote than voting-aged adults living there.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate study makes false claims ahead of Iowa Caucus
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Iowa Secretary of State knocked down the false information, showing it was based on outdated information.

text: First two recipients of the COVID-19 vaccine in Britain are “crisis actors.” The image of the first person who was vaccinated on Dec. 8 was published in October, long before the vaccine was approved. The same nurse was photographed administering the vaccine to two people, in two locations 20 miles apart.

claimReview.title: First to get COVID-19 vaccine in UK were not 'crisis actors'
claimReview.textualRating: False. Both Margaret Keenan, 90, and "Bill" William Shakespeare, 81, received their COVID-19 vaccine on Dec. 8 at University Hospital Coventry.

text: The proper way to wear a medical mask is with the colored side on the outside if you are sick and don’t want to spread your germs and with the white side out if you’re not sick and want to stop germs from getting in.

claimReview.title: Online claims misrepresent how to wear a surgical mask
claimReview.textualRating: False. Medical officials say the colored side of the mask should be worn on the outside away from your face regardless if you are sick or healthy.

text: There are more than 18 million immigrants in the country without authorization but, unlike U.S. citizens, they are not required to pay taxes, rent, or receive vaccines.

claimReview.title: Immigrants pay taxes and housing costs, regardless of status
claimReview.textualRating: False. Recent estimates put the figure of immigrants in the U.S. without authorization at about 11 million. Regardless, they face taxation, housing costs, and work or school immunization requirements like U.S. citizens.

text: Resuscitation is not possible for many vaccinated people who become seriously ill from COVID-19. In some cases, their hearts are too “stiff” to respond to paddles used to deliver an electric shock. Microclots in surrounding tissue may be the reason.

claimReview.title: Claim about resuscitation in breakthrough COVID-19 patients is false
claimReview.textualRating: False. Emergency room physicians say they have heard of no such issues involving people vaccinated for COVID-19 who become sick, and the claim, which circulated on Twitter, was not supported by evidence.

text: Chelsea Clinton said, “It’s time to force-jab every unvaccinated child in America.”

claimReview.title: Chelsea Clinton did not say it’s time to ‘force-jab’ unvaccinated children
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence of Clinton ever making such a comment, and a spokesperson confirmed she has not. The fabricated quote stemmed from a website that is known to publish false news and misinformation. Clinton recently spoke at a conference on a new global health initiative called “The Big Catch-Up,” which aims to boost childhood vaccination rates, but does not involve mandatory immunization and will not focus on the U.S. .

text: Videos and images show that trash bins discovered outside an elections office in New Jersey’s Gloucester County contained blank and shredded ballots from the Nov. 3 election.

claimReview.title: No viable election papers were trashed outside NJ county’s elections office
claimReview.textualRating: False. The papers in the bins included outdated envelopes and instructional materials, as well as spoiled ballots that were not viable for any electoral use, the Gloucester County clerk’s office said in a statement. The documents were discarded legally.

text: Video of an interview between an Australian journalist and Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates shows the two sparred over what he has contributed to the world, and whether he has a behavioral pattern of stealing complex technology and profiting from it.

claimReview.title: Fake, combative dialogue added to Bill Gates interview
claimReview.textualRating: False. This made-up dialogue was edited into the original interview, which didn’t address these topics. The audio appears to have been generated by artificial intelligence tools, according to an expert in manipulated media.

text: The Ku Klux Klan was formed by the Democratic Party.

claimReview.title: Ku Klux Klan not founded by the Democratic Party
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Ku Klux Klan was not formed by the Democratic Party.

text: Human meat has been discovered in the freezers of an Oklahoma City McDonald’s meat factory, as well as in about 90% of other McDonald’s meat factories inspected so far.

claimReview.title: False claim of human meat in McDonald’s factories stems from old hoax
claimReview.textualRating: Satire. Human remains have not been found in McDonald’s factories. This false claim is a years-old hoax that first appeared on the satirical blog Huzlers.com in 2014.

text: Security camera footage from Jan. 6, 2021, shows a federal agent disguised as a supporter of then-President Donald Trump during the attack on the U.S. Capitol.

claimReview.title: Newly released Jan. 6 footage does not show a federal agent flashing his badge while undercover
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage shows Kevin James Lyons, a Chicago man who was sentenced in July to more than four years in federal prison for his role in the attack. Multiple images of Lyons at the Capitol, dressed as he is in the footage, appear in court documents.

text: Video shows a woman filling a white plastic bag with gas at a Kroger station due to gas shortages in the Southeast U.S.

claimReview.title: Video shows a woman filling plastic bags with gas in 2019, not 2021
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video being shared online is from 2019 and is not related to recent reports of panic-buying related to a shutdown of the Colonial Pipeline.

text: Warren Buffett donated $58 million to President Joe Biden’s campaign, so Biden canceled the Keystone XL pipeline as a favor to Buffett.

claimReview.title: Warren Buffett did not donate to Biden presidential campaign
claimReview.textualRating: False. Warren Buffett did not donate to Biden’s presidential campaign, nor did he endorse him. Buffett previously has voiced public support for the Keystone XL pipeline.

text: Dominion Voting Systems, one of the most widely used election technology firms in the United States, is owned by the company Smartmatic through an intermediary company called Indra.

claimReview.title: Smartmatic does not own Dominion Voting Systems
claimReview.textualRating: False. Both Dominion and Smartmatic have released statements saying no ownership relationship exists between the two competing firms. Indra Sistemas, a Spanish company, told The Associated Press in an email it has never developed any project or had a commercial, contractual or corporate relationship with either firm.

text: Maricopa County Board of Supervisors Chairman Bill Gates admitted that tens of thousands of early ballots dropped off on Election Day were mishandled when he said during a CNN interview, “We do not know where these are from.”

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Arizona official’s ballot comments
claimReview.textualRating: False. The interview clip circulating on social media doesn't show Gates admitting to misconduct. He was responding to a specific question from a CNN host about the geographic origin of absentee ballots in a batch that had just been tabulated. Gates was explaining that he couldn’t say which specific part of Maricopa county the various votes come from, because such ballots can be dropped off at any voting site in the county, and are processed in the order that they arrive at the tabulation facility.

text: Walmart recently announced it will require customers in its stores to be vaccinated for COVID-19 starting Nov. 1.

claimReview.title: Walmart is not requiring customers to be vaccinated
claimReview.textualRating: False. Walmart refuted this claim on social media and in an email to The Associated Press. The company has not made any public statements about plans to require proof of vaccination in its stores.

text: A study by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration proves that Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine causes blood clots.

claimReview.title: FDA study doesn’t prove Pfizer COVID vaccine causes blood clots
claimReview.textualRating: False. The study, conducted in part by researchers from the FDA, is being misrepresented. The research showed an association between elderly recipients of Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine and instances of pulmonary embolisms. However, the authors note that the findings do not prove a link to the vaccine. The FDA confirmed that the agency has not found any new causal relationships between the Pfizer vaccine and the potential adverse event.

text: Video of a flash of light and an explosion along a busy roadway proves a laser beam shot down from the sky sparked the

claimReview.title: A video doesn’t show a laser beam igniting Maui’s wildfires. It’s a transformer explosion in Chile
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The widely shared video shows a transformer explosion in Chile earlier this year. Additionally, a laser weapons expert tells The Associated Press that an attack by a directed energy weapon, as some online posts claim the video shows, would not be visible since its laser beam would be infrared.
List (Page)

text: The Conversation, a research-based publication, posted an article online titled

claimReview.title: The Conversation didn't publish anti-vaccine article
claimReview.textualRating: False. The outlet, which publishes articles written by academics and researchers, confirmed that the headline on the original article read: “COVID: unvaccinated people may be seen as ‘free riders’ and face discrimination.” The author of the original article also confirmed that the image was fabricated.

text: People should stop wearing masks because leaked emails show Dr. Anthony Fauci said masks aren’t effective against COVID-19. Emails also showed Fauci takes hydroxychloroquine and tells his family members to take it to prevent COVID-19 but did not want the general public to have a cure.

claimReview.title: Video misleads on Fauci emails
claimReview.textualRating: False. A trove of emails from Fauci, longtime director of the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, was released to media organizations, not leaked, and are now being misrepresented on social media. In February and March 2020, Fauci advised the public against wearing masks, but later updated his position, noting masks are essential to help curb the outbreak. Fauci did not state in an email that he takes hydroxychloroquine. In fact, he has repeatedly stated that the data does not support the malaria drug as an effective treatment against COVID-19.

text: Photos show Detroit election workers illegally delivering thousands of completed ballots for counting long after polls closed on Election Day.

claimReview.title: Photos of Detroit election ballot collection misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photos show election workers legitimately delivering absentee ballots to the city’s main facility for processing and counting, according to city officials and election experts. The ballots were being delivered to the office late in the night because under state law, they can only be collected from designated drop boxes after 8 p.m. on Election Day.

text: Video shows a London rally in support of President Donald Trump during the president’s state visit this week to England.

claimReview.title: Video of pro-Trump rally in England was taken in 2018
claimReview.textualRating: False. Footage of the pro-Trump rally was taken July 14, 2018, not during Trump’s most recent trip to the country.

text: The CEO of Starbucks said, “If you support traditional marriage, don’t buy our coffee.”

claimReview.title: Post twists words of Starbucks CEO on marriage
claimReview.textualRating: False. The company confirmed that the attribution is false. The purported quote has circulated online for years and appears to be a distortion of a remark that leader Howard Schultz made at a 2013 shareholders meeting, when he said that shareholders who disagree with the company’s support of same-sex marriage are welcome to invest in another company.

text: There is plenty of room in Chicago’s jail after the city’s Mayor Lori Lightfoot, who threatened to arrest people for violating stay-at-home orders, released rapists from it.

claimReview.title: Chicago mayor didn’t release rapists from jail
claimReview.textualRating: Partially false. Lightfoot threatened to “take you to jail” for violating stay-at-home orders, but the mayor doesn’t have the power to release detainees or inmates from jail or prison, including the Cook County Jail in Chicago, which is run by county officials.

text: A Black woman speaking at a community event with Joe Biden in Kenosha, Wisconsin, exposed the Democratic presidential candidate by saying she would not “go off” a paper she was provided by his campaign.

claimReview.title: Biden campaign did not give Kenosha speaker a paper with questions
claimReview.textualRating: False. Porsche Bennett was given the paper to read by her organization, not by Biden’s campaign.

text: Photos show the Vietnam Veterans Memorial marred by graffiti as a result of riots after the death of George Floyd.

claimReview.title: Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington not defaced during recent protests
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photos circulating on social media are from 2016 and show a Vietnam Veterans Memorial replica in Los Angeles, which was defaced in that year.

text: 100 million humans in the same place would emit enough radiation to be deadly.

claimReview.title: Radiation found in humans isn’t lethal, despite claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. Radiation experts confirm the human body contains trace amounts of radiation, but the levels aren’t nearly enough to be lethal, even if 100 million people were somehow packed into a single place.

text: Photo shows young people in Uganda stopping a policeman from stealing a ballot box during the country’s presidential election on Thursday.

claimReview.title: Photo of policeman struggling to hold ballot box in Uganda is from 2016
claimReview.textualRating: False. This Associated Press photo was taken during Uganda’s last presidential election in 2016. It shows a policeman struggling to keep hold of a ballot box as voters surrounded him after a long wait to vote.

text: Photo shows Lev Parnas, an associate of Rudy Giuliani, at Eric Trump’s birthday party 25 years ago.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Lev Parnas at a birthday party for a young Eric Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo which shows Eric Trump’s sixth birthday party is from 1990. Parnas would have been 18 at the time. The man in the photo is visibly older.

text: Performers Kid Rock and Jason Aldean removed all New York shows from their “You Can’t Cancel America” tour in support of former President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: Kid Rock and Jason Aldean did not cancel New York performances after ruling against Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim originated on a satirical news website that describes its content as “fiction.” There is no such tour — the pair’s “Rock the Country” tour, which begins in April, never included any stops in New York. Aldean’s concurrent “Highway Desperado Tour” started in July 2023 and has already included multiple shows in the state with more scheduled this year.

text: Video shows outgoing Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta publicly admitting that his deputy president, William Ruto, will win the presidential elections on Aug. 9.

claimReview.title: Tweet misrepresents Kenyan president’s speech
claimReview.textualRating: False. A tweet in English gave an incorrect description of the video, where Kenyatta speaks his mother tongue, Kikuyu. Kenyatta doesn’t say Ruto will win, instead he warns people against voting for Ruto.

text: Cheers by Philadelphia Phillies fans were so loud when Bryce Harper and

claimReview.title: Phillies fans’ cheers did not register on seismograph during Game 3
claimReview.textualRating: False. Fans watching Game 3 of the World Series on Tuesday were loud, but nowhere near loud enough to be measured on the seismograph at Penn State’s Brandywine campus. Geological experts tell The Associated Press that graphs purporting to show their cheers do not match seismic data recorded at the campus.

text: An image shows the first photograph ever taken of a sunset on Mars.

claimReview.title: Image of ‘sunset on Mars’ is an illustration
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image being shared on social media is an illustration of a sunset on Mars, which was created by a computer animator and so-called “space artist.” NASA’s Viking 1 lander took the first photos of a Mars sunset in 1976.

text: Celebrity pastor Joel Osteen is not allowing people to shelter in his megachurch in Houston, even as Texas residents are freezing and left without power.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim Joel Osteen’s megachurch denied Texans shelter
claimReview.textualRating: False. Lakewood Church, where Osteen preaches, opened its doors to Texas residents in need of shelter on Sunday. The massive facility, which housed multiple local sports teams before it became a place of worship, remained a warming center and shelter through the week, according to the church’s tweets.

text: The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the Build Back Better Act “will REDUCE the deficit by $100B+ over 10 years.”

claimReview.title: CBO found Build Back Better Act would increase, not reduce, federal deficits
claimReview.textualRating: False. The nonpartisan agency estimated that the bill would increase the deficit by some $160 billion over that period. The White House itself has projected a more-than $100 billion deficit reduction, but it is estimating that the IRS would collect more in new revenue than the CBO does.

text: A “Bill Gates factory that produces lab-grown synthetic meat” burned down in the Netherlands.

claimReview.title: Destroyed Dutch building wasn’t factory owned by Bill Gates
claimReview.textualRating: False. While a distribution center operated by a Dutch online grocery service was destroyed in a fire in the eastern Netherlands, the facility was not a factory that produced meat alternatives, nor was it owned or operated by Gates. The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation Trust invested in the e-grocer in 2021, but the trust is not a controlling shareholder.

text: A photo showing a doctor standing in front of empty hospital beds at a Reno, Nevada, auxiliary care site for COVID-19 patients proves that the coronavirus pandemic is a hoax.

claimReview.title: Nevada doctor's selfie used to claim COVID-19 is a hoax
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken the day the alternative care site was opened, and patients had yet to arrive. Renown Regional Medical Center said the site, which is housed in a parking garage, has treated 198 coronavirus patients since it first opened.

text: A video shows a priest who has been vaccinated against COVID-19 suddenly dying during a livestream.

claimReview.title: Priest in widely shared video collapsed, but did not die
claimReview.textualRating: False. The priest collapsed, but stood in front of his congregation the following day and later in the month, according to videos posted by the church on Facebook.

text: The daughter of World Economic Forum founder Klaus Schwab said in a roundtable discussion that, “permanent climate lockdowns are coming, whether people like it or not.”

claimReview.title: Daughter of WEF founder did not warn that permanent climate lockdowns are coming
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video used to support the claim contains no such comment. The fabricated quote came from a website known for publishing false news.

text: Court upholds North Dakota law stripping voting rights from Native Americans.

claimReview.title: Native Americans not stripped of voting rights in North Dakota
claimReview.textualRating: False. Native Americans are not barred from voting in North Dakota. However, a court ruling earlier this month upheld a state rule that requires voters to show an ID that lists a residential address, which can be a barrier for those living on tribal lands.

text: The National Guard was sent in on Wednesday to address war protesters at the University of Texas at Austin.

claimReview.title: National Guard soldiers were not called to address Israel-Hamas war protest at Texas university
claimReview.textualRating: False. The National Guard was not called to the university in response to the demonstration against the Israel-Hamas war, the Texas Military Department and a university spokesperson told The Associated Press. Texas state troopers responded at the request of university officials and Gov. Greg Abbott, according to a Texas Department of Public safety spokesperson. Local police were also on the scene.

text: Election officials in DeKalb County, Georgia, rejected 40,000 absentee ballots.

claimReview.title: Georgia county did not reject 40,000 ballots
claimReview.textualRating: False. As of Nov. 4, county election officials had only identified about 200 problematic mailed ballots. Officials were reaching out to voters in an effort to resolve issues before the Nov. 6 deadline to do so.

text: Viagra can cure COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Experts say Viagra isn’t a known ‘cure’ for COVID-19
claimReview.textualRating: False. Medical experts told The Associated Press that the use of Viagra to treat COVID-19 is “entirely unproven,” and cautioned against its use among COVID patients without further research. A spokesperson for Viatris, which markets Viagra, told the AP that the drug "is not indicated for COVID-19 or related symptoms."

text: A video shows a “triple jabbed Australian surgeon” in a green gown experiencing a stroke.

claimReview.title: Video shows doctor collapsing in early 2020, not COVID vaccine effect
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip has been online since January 2020, before COVID-19 vaccines were available, and was reported to show a Chinese doctor fainting.

text: Police in Paris ticketed protesters for carrying the French flag and saying the word “freedom.”

claimReview.title: Paris police didn’t give fines for waving flag, saying ‘freedom’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Paris police ticketed protesters for offenses related to “participating in a prohibited protest,” officials said in a statement issued to The Associated Press.

text: Photo shows U.S. Sens. Cory Booker of New Jersey, Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut and Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island, all Democrats, flouting social distancing measures by huddling without face masks during confirmation hearings for Supreme Court nominee Judge Amy Coney Barrett.

claimReview.title: Photo of Democratic senators huddling without masks is from 2018, not 2020
claimReview.textualRating: False. This Associated Press photo dates back to Justice Brett Kavanaugh’s confirmation hearings in 2018, before the coronavirus pandemic began.

text: Video shows French citizens chanting “We want Trump!” during recent protests.

claimReview.title: Video of protesters chanting support for President Trump was not taken in France
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was taken in London during a “Free Tommy Robinson” protest in June.

text: Michigan news outlets released election results a week before the state’s primary, which is proof of election fraud.

claimReview.title: Release of test election results fuels unfounded fraud claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. At least two local Michigan TV stations inadvertently published mock election results over the weekend while conducting routine tests of their systems in preparation for the Aug. 2 primary. The randomly-generated numbers were not real election results, nor are they an indication of fraud. Election results are reported through information that comes from local election officials. News outlets do not have direct access to ballots.

text: Video clip shows U.S. soldier opening a gate on a border fence and allowing migrants to enter the country illegally, in violation of U.S. code.

claimReview.title: Video prompts false claims that soldier allowed migrants to cross border illegally
claimReview.textualRating: False. Federal officials say the migrants had already crossed the border and were already on U.S. soil when they passed through the gated fence. An immigration expert also rejected claims the soldier's actions violated federal regulations dealing with undocumented immigrants.

text: Top defense contractor General Dynamics canceled its COVID-19 vaccine mandate after some 40% of employees declined the vaccine and threatened to quit.

claimReview.title: General Dynamics didn’t cancel a vaccine mandate
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s no truth to this claim, according to Jeff Davis, head of communications at General Dynamics. The company has not made any public statements about vaccine requirements.

text: “Finally, a judge has ruled Dominion Voting Machines were designed to create fraud.”

claimReview.title: Judge did not rule Dominion machines were designed for fraud
claimReview.textualRating: False. No judge has made such a ruling. In December, a judge handling a Michigan lawsuit allowed the release of a report that contained false claims about a human error in Antrim County and about Dominion machines, including the unsubstantiated assertion that the machines were designed to create fraud. The release of that report, which has since been debunked, did not amount to the judge endorsing its claims.

text: A photo shows cereal boxes filled with fentanyl that were recently seized by law enforcement officials in San Bernardino County, California.

claimReview.title: Officials: No fentanyl found in California cereal boxes
claimReview.textualRating: False. The county sheriff’s department said the photo is from one of its drug busts earlier this year. It shows pills suspected of being MDMA, a club drug often referred to as ecstasy or Molly, not fentanyl.

text: President Joe Biden reinstating Trump’s “Remain in Mexico” policy means he “admits Trump was right.”

claimReview.title: Court order requires Biden to reinstate ‘Remain in Mexico’ policy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Biden administration is reinstating Trump’s “Remain in Mexico” policy to comply with a federal court order, but the White House has publicly voiced opposition to the court decision. The Department of Homeland Security has also stated its intention to issue a new memo ending the policy.

text: “FDA vaccine advisory board said Friday unvaccinated are more educated on the vaccine than most people who have gotten it, and ‘we cannot adequately refute their concerns, which should make us all very uncomfortable.’”

claimReview.title: Posts misattribute statements to FDA advisory panel
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Food and Drug Administration’s vaccine advisory committee did not make these statements. Similar comments were made by a speaker who is not affiliated with the FDA or the committee during the open public hearing portion of its Sept. 17 meeting. Posts online have also misquoted portions of that speaker’s statements.

text: President Joe Biden signed a bill that will give law enforcement access to a “kill switch” that will be attached to ALL new cars in 2026.

claimReview.title: Posts distort infrastructure law’s rule on impaired driving technology
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the bipartisan infrastructure bill Biden signed last year requires advanced drunk and impaired driving technology to become standard equipment in new cars, experts say that technology doesn’t amount to a “kill switch,” and nothing in the bill gives law enforcement access to those systems.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention quietly lowered the milestones for early childhood development in response to the pandemic.

claimReview.title: National child development milestone changes not tied to pandemic
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts relied on research done prior to the pandemic to recommend changes to childhood development milestones used by pediatric professionals to identify developmental delays or disabilities.

text: Adidas posted an image on social media with the word “BYE” to announce the termination of the company’s partnership with the rapper formerly known as Kanye West.

claimReview.title: Posts share falsified Adidas graphic saying ‘BYE’ to rapper Ye
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image was not created or published by Adidas, a company spokesperson told The Associated Press. It has not appeared on any of the company’s social media pages.

text: Parents who can't find or afford baby formula right now, Enfamil and Gerber will send you a free case of formula.

claimReview.title: Companies not giving away free baby formula on request
claimReview.textualRating: False. The companies said they are not giving out free baby formula.

text: White House press secretary Jen Psaki announced Monday that the Biden administration is reforming Section 230 of the 1996 Communications Decency Act in response to Elon Musk's purchase of Twitter.

claimReview.title: White House didn’t tie Section 230 reforms to Musk
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While answering a question Monday about the Twitter deal, Psaki told journalists that President Joe Biden has long supported reforms to Section 230, a legal provision that generally exempts internet companies from liability for the material users post on their networks. Psaki did not announce any specific new reforms, nor did she say the administration was considering such reforms solely because of recent developments with Twitter. In fact, Biden said on the campaign trail in 2020, long before Musk’s proposal, that the section “should be revoked.”

text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi bought $1.5 million in “foreign oil stock” before President Joe Biden halted construction of the Keystone XL pipeline.

claimReview.title: No evidence Pelosi invested $1.5 million in ‘foreign oil stock’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Pelosi filed a financial disclosure form in January, which does not list any investments in oil companies. A spokesperson for Pelosi told The Associated Press that the claim is false.

text: Photo of woman in a military uniform shows “Ukrainian beauty” who “blew up 52 invading Russian tanks.”

claimReview.title: Posts spread fictional tale of ‘Ukrainian beauty’ who blew up 52 tanks
claimReview.textualRating: False. The woman in the photo is a military doctor, not a combat soldier, according to news reports, posts on her Facebook account and messages from her mother.

text: Authorities find tunnel connecting an old Arizona restaurant to Mexico

claimReview.title: Drug tunnel connecting Mexico and Arizona discovered
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. A drug-smuggling tunnel linking a home in Mexico to an old Kentucky Fried Chicken has been discovered.

text: There are more hunters in the U.S. than the world’s armies combined.

claimReview.title: Are there more US hunters than worldwide military personnel? By most measures, no
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Around 14.4 million people hunted in the U.S. last year, but there could be as many as 25-30 million hunters if you account for those who don’t hunt every year, experts told The Associated Press. By contrast, data shows that there were 43.3 million active duty and reservist military personnel worldwide in 2022, although this number drops to 20.8 million if only active-duty troops are counted as making up “the world’s armies.”

text: This fact check was published Oct. 12, 2023. A week later on Thursday, Oct. 19, an airstrike toppled a wall at the Greek Orthodox Church of Saint Porphyrios causing serious damage and death. CLAIM

claimReview.title: A medieval church in Gaza was not razed by Israeli bombing, contrary to online posts
claimReview.textualRating:
False. Officials with the church in Gaza say the structure remains intact and unharmed during the shelling.
List (Page)

text: Video of a fireworks display shows a celebration in northeast Brazil after Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva was elected president on Sunday.

claimReview.title: 2020 video shows fireworks in Croatia, not Brazil after election
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed in Split, Croatia, in October 2020, and shows a fireworks display celebrating the anniversary of a soccer fan group.

text: A tweet from the Obama Foundation featuring a picture of George Floyd went out on May 17, more than a week before his death, suggesting the nonprofit was aware of Floyd well before he died.

claimReview.title: The Obama Foundation didn’t tweet an image of George Floyd eight days before his death
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Obama Foundation simply updated its Twitter card image after Floyd’s death, which changed the preview image for the website when it’s linked on Twitter. That retroactively changed the image appearing on previous tweets pointing to the site.

text: President Donald Trump has to have an annual physical exam and release results to the public, and Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi should be required to do the same.

claimReview.title: U.S. presidents not required to undergo annual physical exam
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. president is not required to release the results of his annual physical exam.

text: Norway has banned gender-affirming care for minors.

claimReview.title: Norway didn’t ban gender-affirming care for minors, as headline falsely claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The country has not changed its guidelines on gender-affirming care for minors, which currently includes non-surgical treatments but recommends against surgery for under-18s in most cases. An independent Norwegian healthcare board not associated with the government recently proposed increased restrictions on such care — though not an outright ban — but it has no authority to institute the changes. Norway's health agency is considering the recommendations but confirmed nothing has been banned.

text: A video shows hundreds of birds filmed gathering on a residential block in Mexico because they were sensing a looming environmental crisis.

claimReview.title: Blackbird swarm video shows normal behavior
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say the behavior shown in the video is typical of blackbirds, which regularly congregate in large groups for safety.

text: Rocks were left on Ventura Boulevard in Los Angeles for "the next round of Antifa riots.”

claimReview.title: Encased rocks were not left for protesters, they are security barriers
claimReview.textualRating: False. The rocks, which are encased in a wire frame, provide a security barrier outside Chabad of Sherman Oaks, a synagogue on Ventura Boulevard in Los Angeles. The barriers are secured to the ground.

text: Photo shows the U.S. military “abandoned” its service dogs in cages at an airport hangar in Afghanistan after the U.S. officially

claimReview.title: US military does not own dogs photographed at Kabul airport
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The dogs seen in the widely-shared photo were not owned by the U.S. military, nor did the military leave them in cages at the airport, according to the Department of Defense. An official at the agency told The Associated Press that some of the dogs were strays, and others were owned by contract companies who were responsible for their care and safety.

text: A video shows Qatar’s emir threatening to cut off the world’s natural gas supply if Israel doesn’t stop bombing Gaza.

claimReview.title: Qatar hasn’t threatened to cut off natural gas exports, as online posts claim
claimReview.textualRating:
False. Qatar’s ruling emir, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani, says no such thing in the widely circulating clip, which is more than six years old. A spokesperson for the Qatari government also confirmed that neither the emir nor any other government official has threatened to cut off exports in response to the conflict. Qatar has the third largest natural gas reserves in the world.
List (Page)

text: A video clip shows a genetically modified mosquito with a serial number on its body that has been released as part of an experiment funded by Bill Gates’ foundation.

claimReview.title: Video on social media doesn’t show genetically modified mosquitoes
claimReview.textualRating: False. The insect in the widely circulating video isn’t a mosquito but an aphid, a common garden insect. The black markings on the bug’s body are naturally occuring. Researchers, including some funded by the Gates Foundation, have however released genetically modified mosquitoes in limited experiments in recent years.

text: Video shows officers spraying fake blood on themselves, proof that a Philadelphia shooting that left six officers injured Wednesday was staged.

claimReview.title: Officers responding to Philadelphia shooting did not fake gunshot injuries
claimReview.textualRating: False. The erroneous claim is paired with a 15-second clip taken from news footage that aired on WPVI-TV in Philadelphia during a standoff between police and a gunman on Wednesday. A review of the full version of the footage shows that the officer is bleeding as he runs toward a police car.

text: “Not one politician has died from the virus, lost their job, or had their business looted.”

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim ‘not one politician’ has died from coronavirus
claimReview.textualRating: False. Several state and local politicians in the United States have died from the coronavirus, according to reporting by The Associated Press. Politicians around the world have also lost their jobs during the pandemic.

text: A map shows that Poland has not been the target of any terror attacks, the lack of which is a result of the country’s “strict no-migrants policy.”

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent data on terrorism and migration in Poland
claimReview.textualRating: False. The map, built by the Center for Strategic and International Studies using the University of Maryland’s Global Terrorism Database, only includes terror attacks from 2012 through 2015. While the database does not have records of any terror attacks in Poland during that period, it shows there have been 42 from 1971 through 2020. Additionally, Poland is open to migrants as a member of the European Union. Regardless, the map does not prove migrants are the cause of the attacks in neighboring countries, and experts say the data shows they are in fact more likely to be victims of terror than perpetrators.

text: Photo shows U.S. Border Patrol agent with a bloodied face after being hit by a rock thrown across U.S.-Mexico border, in Chula Vista, Calif., along with text that says

claimReview.title: Social media posts misrepresent photo of U.S. Border Patrol agent with bloodied face
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is being misrepresented. A spokesman with the U.S. Customs and Border Protection told The Associated Press that the photo was taken in 2010 when a Border Patrol agent was struck in the face by a rock during in a confrontation with drug runners.

text: A video shows that swabs used for COVID-19 PCR testing contain dangerous radioactive and electromagnetically active residue.

claimReview.title: PCR swabs don’t emit harmful radiation
claimReview.textualRating: False. Swabs used in PCR testing are not radioactive and do not emit harmful radiation, according to experts. The machine in the video does not measure radioactivity; it measures electromagnetic fields, which could have been caused by static on the swab or radiation from a nearby cellphone. These fields are present everywhere in our daily lives, in household items such as microwaves, hair dryers and laptop computers.

text: Gretchen Whitmer, the Democratic governor of Michigan, is the niece of billionaire investor and philanthropist George Soros.

claimReview.title: Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer is not George Soros’ niece
claimReview.textualRating: False. A look at the lineages of Whitmer and Soros shows he is not her uncle. Chelsea Lewis, deputy press secretary for Whitmer’s office, told The Associated Press this claim is “absolutely false.”

text: Nintendo and Apple devices as well as the Roblox gaming platform are displaying on-screen messages explaining that they are disabled during the national period of mourning for the late Queen Elizabeth II.

claimReview.title: Mourning period for queen doesn’t affect tech devices
claimReview.textualRating: False. These messages aren’t real, and there are no such interruptions. Spokespeople for Nintendo and Roblox said these claims were unfounded, and a test by The Associated Press confirmed Apple products weren’t disabled as described.

text: A video shows an election worker in Clark County, Washington, improperly closing a ballot drop box 30 minutes early, making a voter put their ballot in a bag instead.

claimReview.title: Video of Washington election worker misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: False. The drop box was not closed and the election worker told the voter they could still deposit their ballot into the box if they did not wish to put it into the bag. Clark County election officials and the Washington Secretary of State’s office say election workers are able to collect ballots from voters near drop boxes to speed up the process, prevent the boxes from overflowing and to ensure that everyone who is in line can vote before the 8 p.m. deadline.

text: NASA said Feb. 10 is the only day of the year that a broom can stand on its own.

claimReview.title: NASA takes on the #Broomstick Challenge
claimReview.textualRating: False. NASA did not make that claim, but the U.S. space agency did take time Tuesday to address the false assertion as it spread widely on Twitter. Turns out, it’s just a balancing act and the date has no relation.

text: Footage of an aircraft carrier is part of a CNN report about Turkey moving a warship toward the Gaza Strip.

claimReview.title: CNN did not report that Turkey is moving a warship toward Gaza
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage shows decade-old clips of the USS George H.W. Bush and the USS Harry S. Truman with the CNN logo added in. The outlet did not report the claim, and an official in Turkey confirmed it is untrue.

text: The FBI, under Robert Mueller, let billionaire financier Jeffrey Epstein off with a weak plea deal after dozens of young girls accused him of sexual assault.

claimReview.title: Mueller didn’t strike plea deal with Jeffrey Epstein
claimReview.textualRating: False. Former Miami U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta _ not the FBI or Mueller _ signed a 2008 non-prosecution deal with Epstein, while he was under investigation for sexually abusing at least 40 girls in Florida and New York.

text: President Joe Biden’s administration did not send any representative to Dover Air Force Base for the dignified transfer of 13 service members who died in the Afghanistan suicide bombing.

claimReview.title: Biden attended Dover ceremony for 13 fallen service members
claimReview.textualRating: False. President Joe Biden and first lady Jill Biden both attended the mournful ritual to honor the 13 fallen U.S. troops on Sunday. They were joined by several top aides in the administration, including Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Mark Milley and Secretary of State Antony Blinken.

text: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that teachers, staff and coaches can now lead students in prayer in public schools.

claimReview.title: Posts distort Supreme Court ruling on coach’s prayer
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The nation’s highest court said that a public high school football coach was protected by the Constitution when he knelt and prayed on the field after games. However, the ruling specified that it was “private speech” and the justices in the majority emphasized the fact that the coach prayed after the games were over when he was not responsible for students. Constitutional lawyers say the ruling does not give school employees unfettered freedom to lead students in prayer at school.

text: A video shows a guest on ABC’s “The View” telling former U.S. Rep. Will Hurd to “shut the hell up” about former President Donald Trump, leaving Hurd and the co-hosts of the show speechless.

claimReview.title: Video altered to appear that GOP presidential candidate Will Hurd was shut down by 'The View' guest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is altered. It was created by someone who says his content takes a “satirical approach.” It uses footage from Hurd’s July appearance on the talk show but adds elements, including a new, confrontational guest and an edit suggesting the show frantically took a break.

text: There are no longer new variants of the coronavirus that causes COVID-19.

claimReview.title: No, coronavirus variants haven’t ‘disappeared’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Public health officials continue to track and monitor emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. They can be seen on the World Health Organization website.

text: Hillary Clinton tweeted on Sunday, “Hurricane Dorian has already devastated the Bahamas and is about to devastate the Great State of Florida. Please help us help the victims by giving a huge donation to Clinton Foundation Today. We rebuilt Haiti and we’ll rebuild Nassau and Orlando.”

claimReview.title: Fabricated tweet falsely claims Hillary Clinton solicited hurricane donations
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image that appears to show Clinton soliciting donations for Hurricane Dorian was fabricated. It was not tweeted by her or from her account.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention updated its website to reduce the coronavirus death count from 64,283 to 37,308.

claimReview.title: The CDC did not reduce the US coronavirus death count
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are citing numbers from a page on the CDC website that provides provisional death count numbers for the coronavirus. The page clearly states that the National Vital Statistics Systems data shown may be incomplete.

text: Taking Tylenol "ruins" your ability to kill viruses, and has harmful effects on your body. You need to have a fever when fighting off viruses.

claimReview.title: Over-the-counter pain relievers don’t ruin your ability to fight a virus
claimReview.textualRating: False. Medical experts say fevers are a signal that your immune system is working, but aren’t needed to fight viruses, and prolonging a fever can be dangerous in certain situations. There is also no evidence that Tylenol – or any other pain-reliever containing acetaminophen, its active ingredient – “ruins” the immune system. Experts agree that taking the drug as directed is safe, especially when taken for a limited period of time.

text: Three doctors at one hospital system in Canada recently died from COVID-19 vaccine shots.

claimReview.title: Posts baselessly link Canadian doctors’ deaths to COVID shots
claimReview.textualRating: False. The hospital system for which the doctors worked called such claims “simply not true.” Public information about the deaths indicates that two died from cancer. The third was “seriously ill,” according to his office, though the exact cause of death hasn’t been publicly reported.

text: The World Health Organization is working on an agreement among nations regarding future pandemics that would “bypass” the U.S. Senate and “reshape America.”

claimReview.title: WHO ‘pandemic treaty’ won’t ‘reshape’ America
claimReview.textualRating: False. Discussions about the proposed agreement are in their early stages but all indications are that it would take the form of an official convention or treaty, which would require approval by the U.S. Senate, according to an expert involved in the process. Regardless, the proposal also doesn’t seek to take away sovereign rights. It is meant to encourage international coordination so countries are better prepared to weather future pandemics.

text: Former Vice President Joe Biden’s presidential campaign released an ad suggesting that voters should value his heart over his brain.

claimReview.title: Ad credited to Biden campaign was fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bogus ad features an edited photo of Biden. A spokesperson with his campaign said it was not created or released by the campaign.

text: A clip shows then-House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi openly admitting how Democrats get the media to legitimize lies using a tactic called the “wrap-up smear.”

claimReview.title: Video takes 2017 clip of Nancy Pelosi discussing smear tactics out of context
claimReview.textualRating: False. A clip of Pelosi speaking at a 2017 press conference has been edited to remove context. Pelosi was describing a tactic she accused Republicans of using against Democrats. In other portions of her response not shown in the clip, Pelosi makes it clear she is not talking about her own party.

text: Former President Donald Trump’s Facebook and Instagram accounts were restored following a global outage that affected the platforms.

claimReview.title: Trump’s social media pages didn’t ‘reappear’ after Facebook outage
claimReview.textualRating: False. Trump’s Facebook and Instagram pages did not reemerge on the platforms this week, because they were never taken down. A Facebook spokesperson confirmed to The Associated Press that Trump’s pages have remained visible, though dormant, since his initial January suspension.

text: Photo of a little girl with blood on her face is from the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.

claimReview.title: Photo of injured child is from Syria in 2018, not Ukraine in 2022
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken in a hospital after a bombing in Syria in 2018. It has no connection to the conflict in Ukraine.

text: Australia is punishing unvaccinated people who cough or sneeze in public with fines and jail time.

claimReview.title: Queensland is not punishing unvaccinated people for coughing in public
claimReview.textualRating: False. Authorities in Queensland, Australia, are not punishing unvaccinated people who cough or sneeze in public. However, people who intentionally spit, cough or sneeze on public officials or workers face fines and jail time under a public health order.

text: Nearly nude person whose body is covered with words is said to be Democratic presidential hopeful Beto O’Rourke.

claimReview.title: Nearly nude person in photo is not Beto O'Rourke
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is not of O’Rourke, the former congressman from Texas.

text: An audio clip features President Joe Biden speaking in private about the recent

claimReview.title: Fake audio falsely claims to reveal private Biden comments
claimReview.textualRating: False. The audio is not authentic. It has glaring signs of manipulation, including speech patterns that are not normal. Experts say it was likely created using an artificial voice generator.

text: Members of the United States Congress recently voted to exempt themselves from IRS audits of their personal finances.

claimReview.title: Congress didn’t exempt its members from IRS audits
claimReview.textualRating: False. Congress has not voted on any such measure, according to spokespeople for the IRS, the Speaker of the House and the House Ways and Means Committee.

text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi blocked the National Guard from coming to the Capitol during the Jan. 6 insurrection.

claimReview.title: Pelosi did not block the National Guard from the Capitol on Jan. 6
claimReview.textualRating: False. As Speaker of the House, Pelosi does not direct the National Guard. Further, as the Capitol came under attack, she and the Senate Majority leader called for military assistance, including the National Guard.

text: Wisconsin has “3,129,000 registered voters,” but counted 3,239,920 votes.

claimReview.title: Wisconsin has not counted more votes than there are registered voters
claimReview.textualRating: False. According to the Wisconsin Elections Commission, the state had 3,684,726 active registered voters as of Nov. 1. As of Wednesday afternoon, there had been nearly 3.3 million ballots counted in the presidential race, according to The Associated Press.

text: Photo shows a bag of red blood from an unvaccinated individual and a bag of darker red blood from a person who has received the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines do not change color of blood
claimReview.textualRating: False. COVID-19 vaccines do not change the color of blood.

text: Carbon dioxide is good for crop growth, so efforts to remove it from the atmosphere will destroy the planet.

claimReview.title: Carbon dioxide helps plants grow. That doesn't mean more of it is good for the planet
claimReview.textualRating: False.
