Excess carbon dioxide does increase growth in some crops, but it also decreases their nutritional value and has other negative impacts on the planet, such as increasing droughts and fires through climate change. Overall, the negatives far outweigh any benefits, experts say. Additionally, researchers are only looking at bringing CO2 levels down to those from a few decades ago.

text: Not a single Democratic presidential candidate wore an American flag lapel pin during the first round of Democratic debates.

claimReview.title: Lapels tell the story, flag pins were worn at Democratic presidential debate
claimReview.textualRating: False. Several of the 20 candidates running for president wore American flag pins.

text: Video shows woman dropping off multiple ballots in Upper Dublin, Pennsylvania, when the state only allows each voter to submit one ballot.

claimReview.title: Pennsylvania ballot drop misrepresented as voter fraud
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. According to Montgomery County election officials, the woman captured on video was acting as a designated agent, and was dropping off multiple ballots on behalf of some disabled voters. Election officials say she delivered each mail-in ballot with a completed designated agent form in accordance with the county’s interpretation of state law.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention revoked Emergency Use Authorization for coronavirus PCR tests because they were inaccurate, led to false positives and confused positive influenza cases with COVID-19.

claimReview.title: CDC encourages use of new tests that detect both COVID-19 and the flu
claimReview.textualRating: False. PCR tests are considered the gold standard for coronavirus testing. CDC announced after this year it will be withdrawing its request to the FDA for Emergency Use Authorization for one early PCR test, not because that test is inaccurate, but because it can only detect coronavirus. Newer tests can now also test for influenza at the same time.

text: Video shows a military attack by U.S. forces ordered by President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: Video game misrepresented as showing a US military attack under Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage is from a mobile video game published to YouTube in 2015.

text: Shell is eliminating 9,000 jobs because of President Joe Biden.

claimReview.title: Biden policies did not lead to thousands of Shell layoffs
claimReview.textualRating: False. Energy producer Royal Dutch Shell announced in September before Biden was even elected, that the company would cut up to 9,000 jobs worldwide. A spokesperson with Shell confirmed to the AP that the thousands of positions would be cut to reduce costs and to transition to low-carbon energy.

text: Those who have had COVID-19 have natural immunity against the disease and do not need a vaccine. No one should be vaccinated without first testing for COVID-19 antibodies.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines offer benefits even to those previously infected
claimReview.textualRating: False. Studies have shown that infection from COVID-19 provides short-term immunity, but that protection fades over time. In addition, natural immunity differs from person to person. Even those who have had COVID-19 can benefit from the vaccine because it boosts existing immunity.

text: Victoria Lee, a professional MMA fighter who died in December, was killed by the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: An 18-year-old MMA fighter’s death was unrelated to the COVID vaccine
claimReview.textualRating: False. Lee’s sister said that the 18-year-old took her own life.

text: A U.N. aircraft parked in Ontario, Canada, shows the organization sent troops into Ottawa disguised as Canadian police officers.

claimReview.title: UN plane at Canada airport is not related to Ottawa protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media posts are sharing a video showing a U.N. plane near the North Bay airport, a city in Ontario, where Voyageur Aviation Corp. provides aircraft maintenance and charter flights for the U.N. The plane has been there for weeks for regular maintenance, a company representative said.

text: Video shows people deliberately starting wildfires so the media can report on it as climate change.

claimReview.title: Firefighter’s video was miscaptioned to make false climate change claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, which was filmed in Arizona in July 2020, shows a controlled burn -- a tactic used by firefighters to contain fires.

text: The CEO of the pharmaceutical company Pfizer has not yet received a COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Pfizer CEO is vaccinated
claimReview.textualRating: False. Albert Bourla, the chairman and CEO of Pfizer, received his second dose of his company’s vaccine in March after waiting a few months for individuals at greater risk from the virus to get vaccinated.

text: Photo shows a ‘Whites Only’ sign hanging on a window in Creedmoor, North Carolina.

claimReview.title: ‘Whites Only’ sign in photo was for a movie shoot
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The sign was a prop for a movie about racial segregation that was filming in Creedmoor, according to a statement on the city’s website.

text: Gas shortages resulting from Friday’s Colonial Pipeline cyberattack have led NASCAR to postpone this weekend’s race in Dover, Delaware.

claimReview.title: Fuel disruptions did not cause NASCAR to postpone upcoming race
claimReview.textualRating: False. NASCAR has not postponed the race, the association confirmed to The Associated Press in an email. This bogus claim arose from an image of a tweet from an account impersonating a Fox Sports reporter.

text: Dominion voting machines in El Paso County, Colorado, failed an accuracy test during preparations for a recount following the June 2022 primary election.

claimReview.title: Misinformation spreads about election recount in Colorado county
claimReview.textualRating: False. A test of the county’s equipment, required by law before a recount, found no issues, county officials and Dominion Voting Systems confirmed to The Associated Press. The machines, fed dummy ballots that had been left partially blank, correctly flagged those ballots for additional human review. The process showed that the machines are working as intended, not failing.

text: Photo shows convoy of Trump supporters heading to Washington, D.C., for protests in January.

claimReview.title: Photo of Bay Area truck rally was taken in October 2020, not January 2021
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo capturing a convoy of cars draped with Trump flags was taken at a truck rally in Pleasanton, California, in October 2020.

text: The Department of Justice has dropped all charges against FTX founder

claimReview.title: No, prosecutors did not drop all charges against Sam Bankman-Fried
claimReview.textualRating: False. Federal prosecutors said last week that they are no longer pursuing one campaign finance charge against Bankman-Fried, but confirmed he is still set to face other charges at an October criminal trial. He may also face a second trial on additional charges next year.

text: In 2016, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz tweeted, "I'll believe in climate change when Texas freezes over."

claimReview.title: Fake tweet attributes climate change comment to Sen. Ted Cruz
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet is fabricated. It cannot be found on Cruz’s verified Twitter account, nor is it on websites that track deleted tweets by public officials.

text: Milwaukee Election Commission Executive Director Claire Woodall was fired in recent days for her role in rigging the 2020 presidential election.

claimReview.title: Replacement of Milwaukee election official unrelated to 2020 election
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for Milwaukee Mayor Cavalier Johnson said Woodall’s removal had nothing to do with how she ran elections, adding there “was no indication of election impropriety” in Milwaukee’s 2020 vote. He pointed to internal issues “that raised” concerns as the reason for the dismissal.

text: George Soros owns SmartMatic voting machines

claimReview.title: Soros not owner of company that assembles voting machines
claimReview.textualRating: False. George Soros, a philanthropist who donates to liberal political causes, does not own a company that assembles voting machines, despite what a photo circulating online suggested.

text: First lady Melania Trump concedes by announcing her last Christmas at the White House, according to the White House website.

claimReview.title: Melania Trump did not concede election with Christmas announcement
claimReview.textualRating: False. The website shared by social media users was not associated with the White House.

text: The Shell-operated deep water oil platform known as the “Mars/Olympus” platform has broken loose following Hurricane Ida and is now “free within the Gulf of Mexico.”

claimReview.title: Shell oil platform did not break loose during Hurricane Ida
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. Coast Guard and Shell confirmed the oil platform did not break loose.

text: Colloidal silver products can help prevent or protect against the new coronavirus from China.

claimReview.title: Colloidal silver has not been shown effective against new virus from China
claimReview.textualRating: False. The silver solution has no known benefit in the body when ingested, according to officials with the National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health, a federal scientific research agency.

text: The head of Drag Queen Story Hour was arrested for child pornography.

claimReview.title: Man charged for child porn didn’t work for Drag Queen Story Hour
claimReview.textualRating: False. A man who was arrested on child pornography charges last year had previously run a separate organization that acted as a nonprofit fiscal sponsor for Drag Queen Story Hour’s Milwaukee chapter. But he never worked for Drag Queen Story Hour, nor did he help plan its events, according to the group’s executive director.

text: A video filmed on Wednesday night shows a protest by the New York Police Department over the release without bail of migrants who

claimReview.title: The NYPD did not stage a protest over the release of suspects in Times Square officer attack
claimReview.textualRating: False. The NYPD did not stage such a protest, a spokesperson for the department told The Associated Press. The spokesperson and a representative of the police union said they did not know what the video showed and when and where it was taken.

text: Photo shows the millions of people protesting in Hong Kong.

claimReview.title: Photo of Hong Kong protesters was manipulated
claimReview.textualRating: False. An Instagram user who took the photo manipulated it, which made the crowd appear larger.

text: The Pentagon stated that any abortion laws enacted as a result of the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade will not be recognized.

claimReview.title: Pentagon statement on SCOTUS abortion ruling mischaracterized
claimReview.textualRating: False. This mischaracterizes a Friday statement on the ruling from Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III. The statement said the Department of Defense was “examining this decision” and evaluating internal policies to ensure access to reproductive health care for service members, their families and its civilian workforce “as permitted by federal law.” While the statement didn’t elaborate, it did not say the Pentagon would defy the court, nor did it say it would violate any state laws that may be enacted. A Pentagon spokesperson told The Associated Press that the suggestion the department would ignore the ruling is “false.”

text: During a press conference, presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden relied on a teleprompter to answer reporters’ questions.

claimReview.title: Biden did not use teleprompter to answer reporters’ questions
claimReview.textualRating: False. The teleprompter was not turned on when the former vice president was answering questions.

text: President Barack Obama freed Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi from prison during his presidency.

claimReview.title: President Obama did not free Islamic State leader al-Baghdadi from prison
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Islamic State group leader, who died Saturday during a raid on his compound by U.S. forces, was not released in the Middle East under Obama.

text: Vice President Mike Pence tweeted after his debate with Democratic rival Kamala Harris that an Instagram page had released evidence Harris received the questions beforehand.

claimReview.title: Pence tweet alleging Harris received debate questions early was fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet was not sent from Pence’s account.

text: Bill Gates tweeted in support of adding vaccines to the food supply to solve “the problem of vaccine hesitancy.”

claimReview.title: Fake tweet on vaccines in food supply attributed to Gates
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image of the tweet was fabricated. It was published as part of an illustration for a video and article by NewsPunch, a site known for spreading false news. No such tweet was sent from Gates’ official account, a spokesperson from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation confirmed.

text: A photo of three nude women in front of a line of policemen is said to show three Democrats campaigning.

claimReview.title: Photo shows 3 nude women protesting in Mexico, not Democrats campaigning
claimReview.textualRating: False The photo comes from a 2005 protest in Mexico City.

text: Video shows the British army’s Band of the Grenadier Guards playing “The Imperial March” from “Star Wars,” Darth Vader’s theme song, as President Trump inspects the guard at Buckingham Palace.

claimReview.title: British army band did not play Darth Vader’s theme song during Trump visit
claimReview.textualRating: False. The British military band played a compilation of U.S. military songs as Trump visited Buckingham Palace Monday.

text: Former President Donald Trump signed an order to deploy 20,000 National Guard troops before his supporters stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, but was stopped by the House sergeant at arms, at the behest of Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

claimReview.title: Trump did not sign an order to deploy 20,000 troops on Jan. 6
claimReview.textualRating: False. While Trump was involved in discussions in the days prior to Jan. 6 about the National Guard response, he issued no such order before or during the rioting. Speaker Pelosi does not control National Guard troops.

text: Two images of beams of light reaching up the sky prove recent wildfires on Maui were started by an “energy weapon.”

claimReview.title: Old photos are being misrepresented online to fuel a conspiracy theory about the Maui wildfires
claimReview.textualRating: False. Both images are unrelated to the fires on Maui. One photo shows the launch of the SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from a California military base in May 2018. The other shows a flare from a controlled burn at an oil refinery in Ohio the same year.

text: A video showing a beach club in Kyiv proves the war in Ukraine is “fake.”

claimReview.title: Video of a beach party in Kyiv is being used to raise doubt around the war in Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video does show partygoers at a beach club in Kyiv, but it doesn’t prove the war is fictitious. The front line of the war is in the eastern part of the country, far from Ukraine’s capital city. But that has not spared the capital, which has regularly been attacked by Russia with missiles and drones.

text: Democratic senators in summer 2022 voted to hire an army of 87,000 IRS agents who will audit and harass the middle class.

claimReview.title: Posts, campaign ads distort IRS funding
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The Inflation Reduction Act, passed in July, provides funding to potentially hire that many IRS employees over the next decade as existing employees quit and retire, but the new employees will not all be hired at the same time and many will not be auditors. Audit rates for those earning less than $400,000 are not expected to rise in relation to historic norms, according to the Treasury Department.

text: A screenshot shows a social media post from Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announcing the “Digital Existence Act” in response to a new COVID-19 variant.

claimReview.title: A post from a parody Trudeau account about a ‘Digital Existence Act’ is being misrepresented as real
claimReview.textualRating: False. The post on X, formerly known as Twitter, is from a parody account, not from Trudeau’s official social media accounts. No bill with the title “Digital Existence Act” has been introduced to the Canadian Parliament.

text: Actor Tom Hanks wearing a T-shirt that disparaged Trump voters (photo)

claimReview.title: Tom Hanks not wearing political T-shirt
claimReview.textualRating: False. Hanks was not wearing a T-shirt that said, “I was going to be a Trump voter for Halloween but my head wouldn’t fit up my ass,” as shown in a photograph that has been circulating online.

text: California Gov. Gavin Newsom has been defying his own stay-at-home order and fleeing to Montana.

claimReview.title: California governor did not violate his stay-at-home order
claimReview.textualRating: False. The governor has not left the state since the stay-at-home order was issued.

text: Images from a large crowd gathered at a campaign rally for President Donald Trump, and from a sparsely attended event for Democratic nominee Joe Biden reflect voters’ true preferences.

claimReview.title: Crowd size at Trump and Biden events reflects approach, not voter preference
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The candidates have taken different approaches to campaigning during the COVID-19 pandemic. While the Biden campaign has instituted social distancing measures and limited the number of people at events to prevent further spread of the virus, the Trump campaign has allowed a large number of people to access rallies. Additionally, Biden maintains a national lead over Trump, according to polls, with a narrow margin of difference in Iowa and Arizona where the images were taken.

text: In a span of two weeks in late June, a total of 850 died due to myocarditis in the city of Monterrey, in Mexico’s northeastern state of Nuevo León.

claimReview.title: Post falsely claims 850 died of myocarditis in Monterrey, Mexico, in two weeks
claimReview.textualRating: False. Authorities of the Health Ministry in Nuevo León told The Associated Press that it is not true 850 people died of myocarditis during that period. The post containing the erroneous information distorts figures provided by a state official who in late June said there had been 380 cases of deaths due to myocardial infarction — or heart attacks — not myocarditis, a condition where the heart muscle is inflamed.

text: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has been “hiding out” in the U.S. as a convoy of truckers and protesters demonstrate against vaccine mandates in Ottawa.

claimReview.title: Canadian prime minister remained in Ottawa area amid protests
claimReview.textualRating: False. Trudeau was recorded giving a press conference in the Canadian capital region on Monday, the same day that some social media users falsely claimed he was in the U.S. Public itineraries released by the prime minister’s office also show that he has remained near Ottawa, the capital of Canada, for more than a week. The prime minister’s office confirmed to The Associated Press that Trudeau has not left Canada.

text: A Washington Post columnist published an opinion article with the headline

claimReview.title: Washington Post headline calling to ‘cancel midterms’ is altered
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such article appeared on The Washington Post’s website, according to digital archives of the news outlet’s site and a Post spokesperson. A Twitter user who posted a popular version of the altered image later clarified that it was meant to be satire.

text: Dr. Anthony Fauci’s experiments include one that magnified terror in the brains of monkeys and subjected them to frightening stimuli.

claimReview.title: Fauci had no involvement in study on monkey threat responses
claimReview.textualRating: False. Fauci, who is the nation’s top infectious disease expert and the longtime director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, was not involved in this research. The study was conducted in a different division of the National Institutes of Health from the one in which Fauci works.

text: Image shows Antarctica from space.

claimReview.title: NASA visualization of Antarctica from space is computer generated
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The image is not a photograph, but a visualization of Antarctica created in 2007 using data from NASA’s Terra and Aqua satellites that orbit around Earth. The visualization portrays sea ice conditions on September 21, 2005.

text: The U.S. is not providing cash to Ukraine; it only supports the country through donated military equipment.

claimReview.title: US has provided money, not just equipment, to Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the U.S. is indeed providing weapons and equipment to Ukraine, it has also provided billions in financial assistance to the country following Russia’s invasion.

text: Local Fox affiliate reported voter registration problems in Detroit related to "fraud" in the 2020 election.

claimReview.title: Lawsuit alleging voter roll problems in Detroit was dropped
claimReview.textualRating: False. Fox 2 Detroit aired a news segment in December 2019 about a lawsuit alleging that Detroit had over 2,500 dead people on the voter rolls -- including one born in 1823 -- along with duplicate registrations and voter records with missing information. The lawsuit was dropped in June 2020 -- months before Election Day -- after election officials in Detroit took “remedial actions” by updating voter rolls.

text: In Florida’s Miami-Dade County, 23% of mail-in ballots have been rejected for missing signatures.

claimReview.title: False posts spread about ballots without signatures in Miami-Dade County
claimReview.textualRating: False. The correct number is about 0.5%. About 2,265 of the 433,235 mail-in ballots that had been submitted to the Miami-Dade County Elections Department by Thursday morning were flagged for rejection because of missing signatures, according to Robert Rodriguez, assistant deputy supervisor of elections for the department.

text: Donald Trump was never called a racist until he ran for president.

claimReview.title: Donald Trump was accused of racism long before his presidency, despite what online posts claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. The federal government sued Trump for allegedly discriminating against Black apartment seekers in the 1970s. Black pastors also accused the New York businessman of stirring racial animus during the “Central Park Five” rape case in the 1980s. Native American groups criticized him for making derogatory remarks about tribes seeking to build casinos in the 1990s. Trump was also a leading voice of the “birther” conspiracy that baselessly claimed former President Barack Obama was from Africa and not an American citizen.

text: The White House cut President Joe Biden’s feed at a virtual event with top House Democrats because they did not have confidence in him answering questions.

claimReview.title: Biden did answer questions from House Democrats at virtual event
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden did take questions after his introductory remarks at the House Democratic Caucus Virtual Issues Conference on Wednesday but the event was closed to the press after the initial comments, so the video feed was cut.

text: Video shows a New York Times editor, Carlos Tejada, talking about taking the booster shot the same day he died of a heart attack.

claimReview.title: Video shows Canadian comedian, not New York Times editor
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows Stewart Reynolds, a comedian from Canada.

text: Nadine Dorries, the U.K. secretary of state for digital, culture, media and sport, suggested in a tweet that people should use dogs or cats to stay warm in the winter.

claimReview.title: Fake tweet about dogs wrongly attributed to UK culture secretary
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. There is no record of Dorries’ account publishing such a tweet, and her office confirmed that she did not post it.

text: A video of air defense systems and other military equipment slowly turning at an intersection in Romania shows them being transported toward the Moldova border as tensions rise in the region.

claimReview.title: Video shows military parade preparations, not war activity in Romania
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a military parade in Alba Iulia, Romania, hundreds of miles from the Moldova border. The clip dates to November 2022 and is not related to Russia’s war against Ukraine, according to Romania’s Ministry of National Defense.

text: Dr. Fauci has sat on Microsoft's board of directors with Bill Gates as his boss.

claimReview.title: Fauci has not served on Microsoft’s board of directors
claimReview.textualRating: False. Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, has never served on Microsoft’s board of directors.

text: A video from a 1985 hearing exposes Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden for using the N-word, stating

claimReview.title: Joe Biden was quoting racist comments when he used the N-word in 1985
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden was not making the statement himself, he was reading a racist statement made by a state legislator during a redistricting process in Louisiana that was overseen by a deputy attorney general nominee. Biden was questioning the nominee under oath about the comments during a U.S. Senate hearing.

text: Historic photo shows Ukrainian nationalist leader Stepan Bandera with Nazi friends.

claimReview.title: Old photo shows German military official, not Ukrainian nationalist leader
claimReview.textualRating: False. While Bandera did fight alongside Nazi soldiers during World War II, the image actually shows German military officer Reinhard Gehlen.

text: Photo shows a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report with many claims about face masks, including that cloth masks trap exhaled carbon dioxide and collect mildew within 30 minutes, risking your health.

claimReview.title: CDC did not say wearing a cloth face mask traps carbon dioxide and ‘risks your health’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The document in the photo is fake and falsely attributed to the CDC, the agency told The Associated Press. The CDC recommends the use of cloth face coverings in public settings to slow the spread of the coronavirus.

text: Puerto Rico has received $91 billion from Congress for hurricane disaster relief, more than any state in the U.S.

claimReview.title: Congress did not give Puerto Rico more hurricane relief than any U.S. state
claimReview.textualRating: False. Congress has approved $41 billion in aid for recovery efforts in the U.S. territory after Hurricane Maria struck in 2017. About $11 billion of that aid has been dispersed.

text: Climate change isn’t real because hurricanes in Florida and across the U.S. haven’t increased in frequency, intensity or landfall in more than a century.

claimReview.title: Misleading claims downplay climate change’s effect on hurricanes
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While studies have found no evidence of an increase in hurricane landfalls in the past century in Florida and across the U.S., experts say this data doesn’t disprove the fact that climate change is a real phenomenon impacting hurricanes in other ways. Globally, the intensity of tropical cyclones has been increasing, and studies project that trend will continue, even as the frequency of the storms is expected to remain steady or decrease.

text: Photo shows former President Bill Clinton looking frail and sick, showing “what happens when you sell your soul.”

claimReview.title: Photo manipulated to make Bill Clinton appear ill
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The photo was edited to make Clinton look ill. The former president’s skin was far less red and his eyes more blue in the original photo taken in 2014.

text: Santa was arrested at a Christmas market in Germany because he wasn’t wearing a mask.

claimReview.title: Santa wasn't arrested for mask violation at German market
claimReview.textualRating: False. A man in a Santa costume was detained by police at a Christmas market in Stralsund, Germany, but not because he wasn’t wearing a mask. Police said the man refused to show identification at an unregistered protest against vaccine mandates.

text: Vaccine ingredients include “monkey kidneys” and “aborted fetal cells.”

claimReview.title: Post misleads on vaccine ‘ingredients’
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. Those are not vaccine ingredients. Researchers have used cell lines derived from cells taken decades ago from fetuses and monkeys to grow viruses necessary to create some vaccines, but the viruses are purified.

text: Dr. Michael Baden was the medical examiner for Gabby Petito’s autopsy and also served in the same role for President John F. Kennedy, George Floyd, Jeffrey Epstein, Martin Luther King Jr. and Phil Spector.

claimReview.title: Michael Baden did not perform Gabby Petito autopsy
claimReview.textualRating: False. Baden, a former New York City chief medical examiner, did not perform the autopsy of Petito, a 22-year-old woman who was killed while on a cross-country road trip with her boyfriend, nor did he serve as the medical examiner for the other cases. Baden was quoted by news outlets discussing Petito’s autopsy, but he has not been involved in the process.

text: Photo shows snowfall at Lake Tahoe.

claimReview.title: Photo shows snow wall in Japan, not US winter storm
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows a snow corridor at the Tateyama Kurobe Alpine Route, a mountain sightseeing trail, which runs through the alps in northern Japan between Toyama and Nagano.

text: The U.K. government recently changed its COVID-19 vaccine guidance to advise against Pfizer’s shot for pregnant and breastfeeding people.

claimReview.title: UK didn’t change guidance on COVID vaccines and pregnancies
claimReview.textualRating: False. The guidance has not changed. Social media users are misrepresenting a section of a summary report about Pfizer’s shot that was published by the U.K.’s medical regulatory agency in late 2020 as part of the initial authorization process. The agency confirmed that subsequent, real-world data supports vaccinating people during pregnancies and while breastfeeding.

text: The family of the late Venezuelan president Hugo Chavez owns 28% of the election technology company Dominion Voting Systems.

claimReview.title: Family of Hugo Chavez does not own Dominion Voting Systems
claimReview.textualRating: False. Dominion has been majority owned since 2018 by Staple Street Capital, a New York private equity firm. The company is privately held and does not disclose its financials, but Dominion CEO John Poulos said in an April letter to the House Committee on Administration that no investor besides himself or Staple Street Capital owns more than a 5% stake. As well, Dominion does not have any ties to Venezuela, according to Eddie Perez, a voting technology expert at the OSET Institute, a nonpartisan election technology research and development nonprofit.

text: A video shows a fire spreading across a street amid strong winds during the Maui wildfires.

claimReview.title: A video of fire blowing across a street is from Ohio in 2022, not the Maui wildfires
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is unrelated to the recent fires in Maui. It shows an incident from 2022 in Cleveland, Ohio, where high winds fueled a fire downtown.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention admits it is collecting people’s DNA without their permission by conducting genomic sequencing on COVID-19 test samples.

claimReview.title: CDC tweet spurs misleading claims on genomic sequencing
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The CDC and many public health labs conduct genomic sequencing to understand the virus’ genetic makeup and identify variants. While human DNA may be present in samples, public health experts told The Associated Press that labs are not sequencing that DNA and the samples submitted are not provided with the patient’s identity.

text: Videos of election workers in Arizona’s Maricopa County photographing ballots and using a USB flash drive in a secure area, and a photograph of destroyed election equipment, show election workers committing potential legal violations.

claimReview.title: Election footage falsely presented as misconduct in Arizona county
claimReview.textualRating: False. Video footage from different dates and different locations was spliced together to make it falsely appear that an election worker was wrongfully photographing ballots, according to a county official. The footage involving the flash drive showed a routine data retrieval process, while the photograph of an exposed hard drive was from a professional forensic audit. The videos and images show activity in the elections department in 2021, and had no impact on the 2020 election.

text: Uncounted ballots that got mixed with counted ballots at voting sites in Arizona’s Maricopa County were not included in the final midterm election results.

claimReview.title: All votes counted in Maricopa County, despite online claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. While such ballots were mixed at two separate voting centers on Election Day, they were properly vetted and accurately tabulated, according to Megan Gilbertson, a spokesperson for the Maricopa County Elections Department.

text: A video shows “concentration camps” that the Federal Emergency Management Agency is building in Hawaii.

claimReview.title: Videos of homeless housing in Hawaii and California misrepresented online as FEMA camps
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The video includes snippets from at least three separate housing projects that FEMA was not involved in. One clip shows “tiny homes” built in Hawaii for military veterans and homeless people. Another depicts a California city’s similar efforts to provide homes for people without housing using the tiny house model. Other clips in the video show quarantine housing in Australia during the COVID-19 pandemic.
List (Page)

text: Photos of the Statue of Liberty from 1898 and 2017 show that sea levels have not risen significantly.

claimReview.title: Statue of Liberty photos don’t disprove sea level rise
claimReview.textualRating: False. Sea level rise in the New York City area as well as globally has been documented by scientific bodies. The comparison of the two photos is misleading because it doesn’t account for tidal fluctuations, experts say.

text: Photo shows Democratic Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer without a face mask in a room full of people, ignoring her own COVID-19 guidelines directly after a Nov. 15 press conference announcing more stringent measures to reduce the spread of the virus in the state.

claimReview.title: Photo of Michigan governor without a mask was taken in February
claimReview.textualRating: False. This photo is from an event on Feb. 24, before Michigan had its first confirmed case of the coronavirus, the photographer told The Associated Press. Whitmer wore the same jacket for her press conference on Nov. 15, but she wore a mask during that event. Whitmer spokeswoman Tiffany Brown confirmed the photo without the mask was not taken on Nov. 15.

text: Photo shows a news story that The New York Times posted on June 27, then quickly pulled down, which claimed U.S. President Donald Trump died of a hydroxychloroquine overdose.

claimReview.title: The New York Times did not publish or pull down a story claiming the president died
claimReview.textualRating: False. This image is fabricated and does not reflect work by The New York Times. The false rumor that Trump overdosed and was pronounced dead originated as a prank on TikTok.

text: An image shows the Houston Chronicle reported and tweeted that Texas gubernatorial candidate Beto O’Rourke challenged his political opponent, Republican incumbent Gov. Greg Abbott, to a fight.

claimReview.title: Fabricated tweet reports made-up O’Rourke quote about fighting Abbott
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The Chronicle did not publish that tweet or post a story reporting as much, the news organization confirmed.

text: Nina Jankowicz, the director of the Department of Homeland Security’s Disinformation Governance Board, said she wants verified Twitter users to be able to edit other users’ tweets.

claimReview.title: Old comments by disinformation board director misrepresented online
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Comments Jankowicz made during a January 2021 presentation, more than a year before she was named to lead the disinformation board, are being misconstrued. A video of Jankowicz’s full remarks shows she was explaining an existing program offered by Twitter that allows certain users to write notes contextualizing claims made in tweets. Jankowicz did not say she personally wanted verified users to edit tweets, nor has she said she plans to implement something similar through the board.

text: The Food and Drug Administration will require that ice cream cartons be sealed with plastic after a video surfaced online of a teenage girl licking ice cream from a carton in a store and returning it to the shelf.

claimReview.title: FDA says no packaging changes after teenager licks ice cream in store
claimReview.textualRating: False. The FDA has made no such requirement.

text: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis has signed a bill requiring college students and professors to register their political views with the state.

claimReview.title: Posts mischaracterize Florida law on college campus surveys
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bill, which DeSantis signed into law a year ago, requires public universities to conduct annual surveys assessing the extent to which competing viewpoints are presented and students and employees “feel free to express their beliefs” on campuses. The legislation does not mandate respondents register their political views with the government, according to the bill’s text and analyses by legal experts. Notices about the survey sent to students and faculty this year made clear it was anonymous and voluntary, according to communications reviewed by The Associated Press.

text: Former President Donald Trump claimed on social media that the late Queen Elizabeth II knighted him in private.

claimReview.title: Trump did not claim that Queen Elizabeth II knighted him
claimReview.textualRating: False. Trump published no such post, and a supposed screenshot circulating online has been fabricated, a Trump spokesperson confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Iceland, where nearly the entire adult population is fully vaccinated, is setting daily records for new infections, mostly among the vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Misleading claims surround new COVID-19 infections in Iceland
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The rate of COVID-19 is more than twice as high in unvaccinated individuals in Iceland as it is in vaccinated people.

text: Video shows two men at a church wedding discovering discarded and torn ballots marked for President Donald Trump in the trash.

claimReview.title: Video does not show discarded ballots in Oklahoma
claimReview.textualRating: False. Officials with the Oklahoma State Election Board said the video shows spoiled ballots where the voter marked more than one option. The ballots were discarded at a polling place.

text: An image shows protesters in France leaning out of a police van as it speeds down a road during

claimReview.title: An image of people commandeering a police van is from a Netflix movie, not protests in France
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image is a screenshot of a French movie called “Athena” which premiered at the Venice Film Festival and was released on Netflix in 2022.

text: A movie theater worker tweeted that he was fired after he refused to add a mysterious liquid that turned out to contain “nanobots” into the drinks of customers watching “

claimReview.title: A theater didn’t put ‘nanobots’ into drinks of ‘Sound of Freedom’ moviegoers. The tweet was a joke
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Canadian comedian who originally posted the tweet confirmed to The Associated Press that it was a joke. He added that he’s never worked in a movie theater and that he’d found the images in the post online.

text: A photo shows a “Build the Wall” sign in the yard of a house on Martha’s Vineyard.

claimReview.title: ‘Build the Wall’ sign added to photo of Martha’s Vineyard house
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The photo circulating online, which shows a real house on Martha’s Vineyard, is a manipulated version of an image that appeared as part of a magazine story in 2020. In the original, there is no “Build the Wall” sign.

text: The Austrian government is hiring people to ‘hunt down’ unvaccinated people.

claimReview.title: Austrian city hiring workers to administer fines, not 'hunt' unvaccinated
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Officials in Linz, Austria, are hiring employees to administer fines to those who flout Austria’s planned COVID-19 vaccine mandate, which is slated to go into effect in February and will apply to all residents ages 14 and up. But the phrase “hunt down” mischaracterizes the new positions, which are administrative jobs.

text: Climate, weather or meteorological events that we would classify as “extreme” have declined in severity over the last 20 or 30 years.

claimReview.title: Extreme weather events are becoming more severe, not less
claimReview.textualRating: False. Scientific research has documented how events including extreme precipitation, droughts and forest fires have become more frequent and severe as a result of climate change. While the impacts of climate change vary across the globe, scientists agree that overall, human-caused warming is supercharging these extreme events.

text: The United Nations said that “children must have sexual partners.”

claimReview.title: Posts falsely attribute quote on child ‘sexual partners’ to UN
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence the organization has ever made that statement and a spokesman called the claim “false.”A website attributing the quote to the U.N. points to a document that does not include that statement.

text: A photo shows the Statue of Liberty in New York City draped in the colors of the Ukrainian flag.

claimReview.title: Statue of Liberty in Ukrainian colors is in France, not New York
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo actually shows a smaller replica statue in Colmar, France, local officials confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: In an interview, Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates said he expects 700,000 people to develop negative side effects from a coronavirus vaccine.

claimReview.title: Bill Gates did not say 700,000 people will have negative side effects from a coronavirus vaccine
claimReview.textualRating: False. Gates used the number 700,000 theoretically, to demonstrate how important it is to create a vaccine that works for older age groups without side effects.

text: An Illinois bill would change how individuals who committed criminal offenses are referred to under state law, replacing “offender” with “justice-impacted individual.”

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Illinois bill rebranding some criminal offenders as ‘justice-impacted individuals’
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The bill, HB 4409, would not relabel all people who commit crimes as justice-impacted individuals — just those in the state’s Adult Redeploy Illinois program. Adult Redeploy Illinois is intended to reduce incarceration, in part, by placing individuals with any probation-eligible offense in community corrections programs rather than in prison.

text: A photo shows pallets of bricks along a Washington, D.C., street that were intentionally placed in the area to encourage violent protesting after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.

claimReview.title: Bricks stored on DC street for pre-scheduled construction
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bricks were stored along the road for work on an unrelated construction project that had been planned months in advance and residents were notified about at least 10 days prior to Friday, the day the court released its decision, triggering protests. The ongoing alley paving project began Thursday and was scheduled to run through June 30, but those along the construction route were told by June 16 of the planned work in the area, according to District Department of Transportation records.

text: A video shows a child trafficking rescue operation.

claimReview.title: Attempted escape from Syrian camp misrepresented as child trafficking rescue
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows people discovered hiding in the tank of a water truck in 2020 as they attempted to escape from a camp in Syria where tens of thousands of people linked to the Islamic State group were taken after its defeat.

text: Wearing a mask harms the kidneys by increasing carbon dioxide in the lungs, lowering pH and increasing acid which overwhelms compensatory mechanisms in the body.

claimReview.title: Wearing masks does not damage kidneys
claimReview.textualRating: False. Wearing a mask to prevent the spread of the coronavirus does not damage kidneys nor does it increase carbon dioxide in the lungs, resulting in other issues.

text: Uber, Lyft to offer free rides to polls on Election Day

claimReview.title: Uber, Lyft to offer free rides to polls on Election Day
claimReview.textualRating: True. The ride sharing apps announced they will offer free rides to polling stations on Election Day in an effort to get voters to the polls.

text: The packaging insert with the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine is suspiciously blank, containing no information about ingredients and side effects normally found with a vaccine.

claimReview.title: COVID vaccine package insert is blank because up-to-date information is online
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The paper insert states that it was intentionally left blank and that FDA-authorized fact sheets are available electronically, according to a J&J representative. This is intended to ensure vaccinators and consumers refer to the most up-to-date information about the vaccine during the FDA’s emergency use authorization, the representative said.

text: Video shows that Abraham Aiyash, a Democrat who was elected to Michigan’s state legislature, threatened Monica Palmer's children during a Zoom meeting.

claimReview.title: Michigan state representative-elect did not threaten election official’s family
claimReview.textualRating: False. In the full clip, Aiyash, a representative-elect in Michigan’s House of Representatives, was criticizing the actions of Monica Palmer, one of the Republicans on the Wayne County Board of Canvassers, who had initially refused to certify election results on Nov. 17 declaring Democrat Joe Biden the winner. Palmer alleged voting irregularities in Detroit, a majority Black city. Aiyash said that Palmer was denying voters a voice, and said she was “racist.” Social media users shared a shortened clip of Aiyash’s remarks that were taken out of context. A longer clip capturing Aiyash’s comments confirm he did not make a statement threatening Palmer’s family.

text: Black Lives Matter posted on its official Twitter account

claimReview.title: Tweet attributed to Black Lives Matter is fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Black Lives Matter official account never posted the statement. The image shared on social media was fabricated.

text: President Joe Biden caught on camera sniffing a baby.

claimReview.title: Video edited to make it sound like President Biden loudly sniffed a young child
claimReview.textualRating: False. The loud sniffing sound was added to the original video, which merely shows the president leaning in to speak with a baby being held by its mother at a recent event. The original clip doesn’t include any sniffing sounds.

text: A new study shows that a second dose of a COVID-19 vaccine decreases sperm count and after a third shot “it’s almost unrecoverable.”

claimReview.title: Video misrepresents study on COVID-19 vaccines and male fertility
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. A new Israeli study did report a reduction in sperm count about three months after a second dose of Pfizer’s vaccine — but the effect was temporary and disappeared in subsequent samples. Experts say this is likely due to a fever, which can follow vaccination or infection and temporarily affect sperm production. The Israeli study did not examine the effects of a third dose.

text: Three North Carolina healthcare systems are diagnosing toddlers with gender dysphoria and “transitioning” them.

claimReview.title: North Carolina hospitals: We are not ‘transitioning’ toddlers
claimReview.textualRating: False. Officials with Duke Health, University of North Carolina Health and ECU Health say that while they do accept young children as patients, staff only provide general counseling to parents and families at that age. They do not offer medical procedures such as gender-affirming surgeries or hormone treatments to toddlers.

text: Increased incidence of a meat allergy linked to tick spit in the U.S. is connected to a project funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation that involves genetically modifying cattle ticks.

claimReview.title: No, a meat allergy caused by ticks is not tied to a Gates Foundation-funded program. Here’s why
claimReview.textualRating: False. The program to create a modified cattle tick, with the goal of reducing their population and protecting livestock, has thus far been limited to lab work in the U.K., according to a representative for the company conducting the research. The ticks in question have been largely eradicated in the U.S. and do not bite humans, an expert said.

text: Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg spent more than $400 million in 2020 to elect Joe Biden, violating campaign finance rules that limit donations.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Mark Zuckerberg’s election spending
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While Zuckerberg and his wife, Priscilla Chan, collectively donated at least $400 million to two nonprofit organizations to help various government election offices across the country, the funds were not contributions to Biden’s 2020 presidential campaign and did not violate campaign finance laws.

text: People who have received COVID-19 vaccine booster shots are at a greater risk of dying from the virus.

claimReview.title: Video spreads false claim that vaccine booster shots increase risk of death
claimReview.textualRating: False. Research shows the opposite – booster shots reduce the risk of hospitalization and death, experts said.

text: Texas billionaire H. Ross Perot left $100 million to the Trump 2020 campaign when he died.

claimReview.title: Late billionaire Perot did not leave $100 million to the Trump campaign
claimReview.textualRating: False. Perot, who died July 9, did not donate millions to the Trump campaign as reports online state.

text: U.S. Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor dined with Democratic congressional leadership at a restaurant on Friday.

claimReview.title: Justice Sotomayor didn’t attend dinner with Democratic leadership
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim is based on inaccurate reporting from Politico, which has since issued a correction. The news outlet erroneously reported on Saturday that Sotomayor attended the dinner, but later said it had mistakenly identified Iris Weinshall, Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer’s wife, as Sotomayor.

text: A proposed California bill would allow school mental health professionals to remove minors from the custody of their parents or guardians who don’t consent to the child receiving gender-affirming surgeries.

claimReview.title: California bill on youth mental health services distorted on social media
claimReview.textualRating: False. The legislation, AB 665, would amend an existing law that allows minors 12 and older to receive mental health counseling or therapy without parental consent. Currently, the law applies only to youth covered by private health insurance. It contains no language that would allow school mental health professionals to remove children from the custody of their parents or guardians. The bill does not authorize any gender-affirming surgeries without parental consent.

text: CBC published an article with the headline

claimReview.title: CBC didn’t publish article saying trust in media at ‘all time high’
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image was fabricated to look like a Canadian Broadcasting Corporation story online. The broadcast company said in a public statement that the image was fake and it did not publish a story with this headline. A search of online archives found no such article by the CBC.

text: A video of only one shopper turning up for a Black Friday sale this year shows how President Joe Biden’s economic policies have negatively impacted consumer spending in the U.S.

claimReview.title: Years-old video of empty store on Black Friday was filmed in London, not the US
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed in London and in 2017, prior to Biden’s presidency.

text: Video shows a man collapsing after receiving his fourth COVID-19 vaccine dose. He didn’t make it out of the clinic.

claimReview.title: Person in vaccine clinic video fainted and ‘recovered without incident’
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The person in the video fainted at a spring 2022 vaccine clinic, but “recovered without incident,” according to a representative from the Ontario, Canada, health agency that hosted the event. No deaths have occurred at any of the agency’s clinics, he said.

text: The NIH now recommends vitamin C, vitamin D3 and zinc for the prevention and treatment of COVID-19.

claimReview.title: NIH hasn’t recommended supplements as new COVID-19 strategy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The National Institutes of Health does not currently recommend, or advise against, those supplements for fighting COVID-19.

text: Photos show children being taught Satanism in libraries in the U.S. during an event called SatanCon.

claimReview.title: AI-generated images of satanic kids’ event misrepresented as real
claimReview.textualRating: False. The images were generated with an artificial intelligence tool and posted online. The Facebook user who created the images confirmed to The Associated Press that they produced the images and posted them on the social media platform. The Satanic Temple, creator of SatanCon, told the AP that they do not hold satanic events for children.

text: In Alabama, a 12-year-old girl impregnated during a rape can be “thrown in prison for life” if she has an abortion.

claimReview.title: Social media posts distort Alabama abortion law
claimReview.textualRating: False. A law passed in 2019, which is currently blocked from taking effect, includes criminal penalties for providers who perform abortions — but not for those who receive them. It would ban most abortions and does not include exceptions for rape.

text: The late Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg tweeted on the day she died that she had information that would lead to the arrest of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.

claimReview.title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg did not author a tweet about Hillary Clinton
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet was fabricated. Ginsburg did not use a personal Twitter account.

text: Videos show Capitol rioters who were removed from flights because they are on the federal no-fly list.

claimReview.title: Videos do not show Capitol rioters on no-fly list that were removed from flights
claimReview.textualRating: False. American Airlines reviewed two videos circulating widely on social media and confirmed to The Associated Press that in both incidents the people were either removed or escorted off because they refused to wear mandated face masks to stop the spread of COVID-19 on flights.

text: Rudy Giuliani has fired Alvin Bragg, Manhattan’s district attorney, for his “fake prosecution” of former President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: No, Manhattan DA investigating Trump hasn’t been fired
claimReview.textualRating: False. Giuliani is a former New York City mayor and U.S. attorney who has represented Trump; he has no authority to remove Bragg from his position. Under state law, a governor could initiate a process to remove a district attorney from office.

text: News reports say Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's psychiatrist died by suicide.

claimReview.title: A 13-year-old satirical blog post about Netanyahu’s ‘psychiatrist’ is being shared as real news
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim comes from a 2010 satirical blog post. The author confirmed to The Associated Press that the post was satire.

text: Photo shows Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in a Tigger costume.

claimReview.title: Image manipulated to add Trudeau’s face to man in Tigger costume
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image has been altered to include Trudeau’s face. Versions of the photo have appeared online for more than a decade with different faces edited in.

text: Video shows a maintenance worker sticking “duct tape” on a Spirit Airlines aircraft before takeoff.

claimReview.title: Video shows speed tape, not duct tape, on Spirit Airlines plane
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tape seen in the video is “speed tape,” a spokesperson for Spirit Airlines confirmed. The tape, which is made from aluminum, is used for temporary, minor repairs on aircrafts, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.

text: A photo shows a bullet hole in former President Donald Trump’s suit jacket, proving that he was shot in the chest during an

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent photo to claim Trump was shot in the chest and saved by a bulletproof vest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo actually shows a fold in the suit jacket of a Secret Service agent protecting Trump. Another Associated Press image taken moments before clearly shows that there is no hole in Trump’s jacket. What appears to be a hole can be seen diminishing as the agent moves in video of the shooting’s aftermath.

text: Video provides data-supported evidence that the election technology firm Dominion Voting Systems committed election fraud by transferring vote ratios between precincts in Philadelphia.

claimReview.title: Philadelphia does not use Dominion Voting Systems technology
claimReview.textualRating: False. Dominion technology isn’t used in Philadelphia’s elections, so the company had no part in tabulating votes there. Despite a flurry of false claims about election results in battleground states like Pennsylvania, there’s no evidence of widespread fraud or irregularities in the 2020 election.

text: A study conducted in Iceland found that the more COVID-19 vaccine doses you take, the more likely it is that you will be reinfected with the virus.

claimReview.title: Study did not find vaccines increased COVID reinfection
claimReview.textualRating: False. This claim misrepresents the findings of the study, which was not intended to determine causation, the authors told The Associated Press. The research does not support the claim that vaccination increases reinfection rates.

text: COVID-19 vaccines contain aluminum, a toxic ingredient that enters the brain and causes disease.

claimReview.title: US and EU COVID vaccines don’t contain aluminum
claimReview.textualRating: False. The COVID-19 vaccines that have been authorized for emergency use in the United States do not contain any aluminum. Nor do the AstraZeneca or Sputnik V vaccines. Some Chinese COVID-19 vaccines, as well as some vaccines used against other diseases, do use tiny amounts of aluminum to help boost the immune response. This method is safe and the quantity of aluminum is trivial compared to what humans encounter elsewhere in everyday life, experts say.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has not advised people to get second, third or fourth polio vaccine shots.

claimReview.title: CDC recommends multiple polio doses, contrary to false claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The CDC recommends children receive four doses of a polio vaccine to complete the full regimen, and three doses for people who are immunized as adults.

text: Talk show “The View” settled a lawsuit filed by Kyle Rittenhouse for $22 million and issued a formal apology.

claimReview.title: ‘The View’ hasn’t settled a lawsuit with Kyle Rittenhouse
claimReview.textualRating: False. Kyle Rittenhouse has not sued ABC’s “The View,” nor has any lawsuit been settled for $22 million, his spokesperson told The Associated Press. A spokesperson for ABC also confirmed that the claim is false.

text: Photo shows Rep. Elise Stefanik giving the middle finger following testimony to the House Intelligence Committee by former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch.

claimReview.title: Photo manipulated to show congresswoman making obscene gesture
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image of the Republican congresswoman from New York was manipulated to make it appear she was making the obscene gesture.

text: An electronics recycling truck photographed in a parking lot outside the Gwinnett County Voter Registrations and Elections Office in Georgia was shredding computer hard drives in order to destroy evidence related to the Nov. 3 election.

claimReview.title: Truck in Georgia parking lot was not destroying election equipment
claimReview.textualRating: False. The truck was onsite to pick up surplus equipment as part of a project to replace desktop computers with laptop computers, according to Joe Sorenson, communications director for Gwinnett County. “The project is unrelated to the election and the area being used does not have access to the elections facilities,” Sorenson told The Associated Press in an email.

text: Video clip shows that Dr. Anthony Fauci is opening up “the possibility that the COVID-19 vaccine could be making people more likely to be infected by the virus.”

claimReview.title: Clip of Fauci discussing theoretical vaccine concern is from March 2020
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The clip is from March 2020 and reflected concerns that scientists publicly aired as the vaccines were being developed. Experts say those theoretical concerns have not materialized.

text: An organization is seeking online donations of human bodies as a way to end world hunger.

claimReview.title: ‘Human Meat Project’ is not promoting cannibalism, it’s conceptual art
claimReview.textualRating: False. The website for the Human Meat Project states in its terms and conditions that it is a conceptual art piece meant to “give an understanding of the importance of accepting any services’ policy and agreements.” Organizers of the project didn’t respond to messages seeking comment.

text: A protein naturally found in egg yolks protects against COVID-19 in humans, which is why there is an egg shortage.

claimReview.title: Study doesn’t prove egg yolks protect against COVID-19
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim misrepresents a 2021 study by a group of Chinese researchers who immunized hens with part of the coronavirus spike protein in order to extract antibodies from yolks in the hens’ eggs. Experts say these antibodies would not be very useful for humans, nor do eggs naturally provide these antibodies. Further, the current egg shortage is caused by an avian flu outbreak leading to reduced egg production and a rise in prices.

text: The Biden administration is secretly flying migrants from the southern border to communities across the U.S.

claimReview.title: Posts lack context on government migrant flights
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While it’s true that the Biden administration does transport migrants, both adults and unaccompanied minors, to various locations by plane, claims circulating online omit the fact that these flights also happened under prior administrations, according to experts and federal officials.

text: The Earth is spinning faster and days are getting shorter, a change that is noticeable and cause for immediate concern.

claimReview.title: Earth spinning faster is no cause for concern, scientists say
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. On June 29, the Earth recorded its shortest day since the adoption of the atomic clock standard in 1970, at 1.59 milliseconds less than 24 hours, due to an increase in the planet’s rotational speed. However, scientists told The Associated Press that this is a normal fluctuation that people won’t notice and don’t need to worry about.

text: A video clip shows liberals dressing up as supporters of former President Donald Trump before taking part in the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, proving the riot was an inside job.

claimReview.title: Video shows comedy TikTokers on Jan. 6, not proof Capitol attack was an inside job
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip was filmed by comedian Walter Masterson and content creator Peter Scattini, who posed as Trump-friendly reporters on Jan. 6, 2021, to interview people at the “Stop the Steal” rally that preceded the Capitol attack. Both men posted videos showing extensive footage from the day’s events, which include the shot of them donning Trump paraphernalia and patriotic garb in an effort to blend in with the crowds. They explain in the videos that they went to the rally to make comedic content and express disbelief about what happened.

text: The Pfizer coronavirus vaccine is made up of 99.9% graphene oxide, a toxic compound.

claimReview.title: Pfizer vaccine does not contain graphene oxide
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Pfizer vaccine does not contain any graphene oxide, a Pfizer representative confirmed to The Associated Press. The study referenced in this bogus claim is not peer reviewed, nor is it supported by Spain’s University of Almeria as some have claimed.

text: Video shows former CIA Director John Brennan speaking out about “his Muslim faith” in Arabic.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent former CIA director’s comments on the Middle East
claimReview.textualRating: False. In the video, Brennan discusses his time as a student in the Middle East. At one point he speaks in Arabic, but he makes no mention of Islam as his faith.

text: There are no laws requiring people to pay their taxes.

claimReview.title: Yes, you are legally required to pay your taxes
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Internal Revenue Service and several tax experts confirmed to The Associated Press that Title 26 of the U.S. Code requires individuals to pay income taxes. They said that faulty legal arguments claiming there’s no such law have been around for decades but have not been successful in court.

text: Donald Trump invited National Guard members to stay at Trump Hotel in Washington so they don’t have to sleep in a cold parking garage.

claimReview.title: The National Guard received no offer to stay at Trump Hotel in Washington
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson with the National Guard Bureau told The Associated Press they had not received any offers to stay at Trump International Hotel Washington, D.C., the former president’s hotel. The National Guard members assigned to Washington were all provided hotel rooms by the military. The issue that arose last week was over where the troops could take rest breaks.

text: A video of a whirling mist creating havoc on a beach in Florida was filmed during Hurricane Idalia.

claimReview.title: A clip of a waterspout at a Florida beach is being misrepresented as Hurricane Idalia
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a “waterspout” on June 16 at Clearwater Beach on Florida’s west coast, according to a description of the clip on Storyful, a social video licensing agency, and news reports at the time.

text: Tesla CEO Elon Musk said that Will Smith slapping Chris Rock received more attention than Ghislaine Maxwell’s trial and that it was “interesting” that a social media account tracking Maxwell’s trial was banned after it gained a following.

claimReview.title: Quote falsely attributed to Elon Musk spreads online
claimReview.textualRating: False. Musk didn’t say this. A post circulating online falsely attributed comments made by a separate Twitter user to Musk.

text: Canada recently issued a list of 18 words and phrases that people are no longer allowed to say because they might offend someone.

claimReview.title: Canada did not ban 18 words and phrases
claimReview.textualRating: False. Canada has not issued any such list. The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation published an article on words people might want to “think twice” before using, but this does not reflect any government policy.

text: Teenage climate activist Greta Thunberg has a “handler,” Luisa-Marie Neubauer, who has ties to the “ONE Foundation managed by Bono, Bill Gates and George Soros.”

claimReview.title: Climate activist Greta Thunberg does not have 'handler'
claimReview.textualRating: Mixed. Neubauer volunteers for the ONE Campaign, an international organization that fights extreme poverty and disease. But she does not serve as a "handler" or "supervisor" for Thunberg, whose environmental activism began a little over a year ago in Sweden.

text: President Joe Biden admitted he is governing like a “dictator” in an interview with ABC News host George Stephanopoulos.

claimReview.title: Clip of Biden using term ‘dictator’ to describe executive orders lacks context
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Biden said that he doesn’t believe tax increases should be passed by executive order. The executive orders Biden has signed so far in his presidency have not addressed tax policy.

text: Video shows an Irish dance group performing a routine to the Queen song “Another One Bites the Dust” outside Buckingham Palace on Thursday

claimReview.title: Irish dance video was posted months before Queen Elizabeth’s death
claimReview.textualRating: False. The group, known as Cairde, posted this video on Twitter and TikTok in January, months before Elizabeth’s death. “Dancing to ‘Queen’ for the Queen,” the group wrote alongside the video, referring to the British rock band, which released “Another One Bites the Dust” in 1980.

text: Members of Congress gave themselves more than $40,000 in pay raises this year while only giving Americans $1,200 checks and voting to give just $600 more.

claimReview.title: No, Congress did not give itself a pay raise this year
claimReview.textualRating: False. Congress did not give itself a pay raise this year.

text: President Joe Biden misspelled the word “billion” while addressing reporters after debt ceiling talks with congressional leaders at the White House.

claimReview.title: Biden did not misspell ‘billion’ in remarks about debt ceiling
claimReview.textualRating: False. C-SPAN video shows Biden spelled out “billion” correctly in his May 9 remarks, although it is harder to hear in lower-quality footage circulating online and was misspelled in a White House transcript.

text: Footage of representatives in Slovakia’s parliament throwing water on Ukraine’s flag shows the country saying “no to NATO.”

claimReview.title: Video of Slovak politicians pouring water on Ukrainian flag misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Slovakia is a member of NATO. The video shows far-right opposition lawmakers throwing water on the Ukrainian flag on Feb. 8, as the parliament was debating a military defense treaty between Slovakia and the United States, and as Russian troops massed near the border of Ukraine. The measure was approved by the majority of lawmakers and the president the following day.

text: A clip shows Moderna CEO Stéphane Bancel admitting the company produced 100,000 COVID-19 vaccine doses in 2019, before the pandemic began.

claimReview.title: Moderna CEO’s remarks on 2019 vaccine supply mischaracterized
claimReview.textualRating: False. During a session at the World Economic Forum’s meeting in Davos this year, Bancel was discussing the number of doses of any vaccine that Moderna produced for clinical use in all of 2019. He never specified that the 100,000 doses were COVID-19 vaccines. Transcripts of other interviews with Bancel show he has made similar remarks in the past, making clear that the 100,000 doses in 2019 refer to any vaccine.

text: New York City is giving credit cards to migrants living in the U.S. illegally.

claimReview.title: Migrants in New York City will receive prepaid debit cards, not credit cards, for designated goods
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The city is launching a pilot program that will provide migrants with prepaid debit cards to buy only food and baby supplies, according to a spokesperson for the mayor. Participants will be allowed to shop with the cards at bodegas, grocery stores, supermarkets and convenience stores. The goal is to cut costs, officials said.

text: Photos of Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden, Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer and U.S. Sens. Kamala Harris and Cory Booker together at a rally show that none of them are wearing masks, revealing their hypocrisy during the coronavirus pandemic.

claimReview.title: Photos of Biden, Whitmer, Harris and Booker without masks were taken in early March
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While it is true that the politicians are not wearing masks in these photos, social media users are sharing them without important context: They were taken at a campaign rally in Detroit on March 9. That was before the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention began recommending Americans wear masks and before Michigan announced its first presumptive positive coronavirus case.

text: Kamala Harris, a U.S. senator and former Democratic presidential candidate from California, said on June 18 that once President Trump is no longer in office “and we have regained our rightful place in the White House,” his supporters will feel the “vengeance of a nation.”

claimReview.title: Kamala Harris did not threaten Trump fans with the ‘vengeance of a nation’
claimReview.textualRating: False. This fabricated quote originated with a satirical article in 2019 and is now being shared out of context. There is no evidence Harris ever said this.

text: Photo shows Russians burning a pile of Ukrainian history books in 2022.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Russia supporters burning Ukrainian history books in 2010
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows Russia supporters setting fire to Ukrainian history textbooks in March 2010 in Simferopol, a city in Russia-annexed Crimea.

text: In an interview, Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden confused President Donald Trump with former President George W. Bush.

claimReview.title: Biden was speaking to George Lopez in widely shared clip
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Biden and his wife, Jill, were being interviewed by actor and comedian George Lopez during the virtual “I Will Vote” concert.

text: A video shows a defendant’s emotional reaction to being sentenced to 137 years in jail.

claimReview.title: South Carolina man received 15 years in prison, not 137
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a man named Jacob Morgan reacting to a judge’s finding at a preliminary hearing in 2015. Morgan was sentenced nine months later to 15 years in prison — not 137 — for setting a fire that killed his 14-month-old stepbrother, according to York County, South Carolina, court records and Morgan’s attorney.

text: The World Economic Forum tweeted that the “internet must be reformed” as part of the “next step for the Great Reset.”

claimReview.title: World Economic Forum did not tweet 'internet must be reformed'
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no record of the WEF posting such a tweet, and a representative said it was “categorically fake.”

text: Photos shared on Reddit of a woman — wearing a Coca-Cola sweatshirt and black skirt in one picture, a NASA shirt in another — show Salvador Ramos, who officials say fatally shot 19 children and two teachers in Uvalde, Texas. Another photo of a woman holding a green bottle to her mouth also shows Ramos.

claimReview.title: Posts misidentify photos of trans women as Uvalde school shooter
claimReview.textualRating: False. None of those images show Ramos. The two images shared on Reddit were posted by a woman named Sam, who confirmed her identity to The Associated Press and has posted new images since Ramos was killed by authorities on Tuesday. The image with a green bottle is of a woman named Sabrina.

text: A recent court filing revealed that 3,600 “duplicate” ballots were cast for Biden and illegally counted in Fulton County, Georgia during the 2020 election.

claimReview.title: Trump misleadingly cites ‘duplicate’ ballots in disputed Georgia county as proof of election fraud
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. A state review of the county’s audit of the 2020 presidential race found errors and inconsistencies in the vote count, including some double counting of ballots. But the errors weren’t enough to alter the election results, according to the review and outside experts. They also weren’t deemed criminal, as social media posts claim.

text: France sent troops to fight in the Russia-Ukraine war.

claimReview.title: No, France did not deploy troops to fight with Ukraine against Russia
claimReview.textualRating: False. The French Foreign Ministry said in a statement on X that France has not deployed troops to Ukraine, calling the claim “disinformation.” Reports of the deployment cited a May 3 blog post by Stephen Bryen, a deputy undersecretary for the Department of Defense during the Reagan administration.

text: Video shows people in Hong Kong “rebelling against the COVID police state by cutting down and destroying security cameras.”

claimReview.title: Hong Kong protest video is from 2019, not 2022
claimReview.textualRating: False. Despite suggestions that the video is current, it shows protesters downing a “smart lamppost” in August 2019, before the COVID-19 pandemic.

text: Fox News was banned from operating in the United Kingdom for promoting right-wing “propaganda.”

claimReview.title: Fox News wasn’t banned from UK, contrary to false claims online
claimReview.textualRating: False. Fox News voluntarily stopped broadcasting in the U.K. in 2017 after failing to cultivate a sufficient audience. U.K. regulators did not ban the channel from operating in the region.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued a travel advisory for Florida due to increased cases of leprosy.

claimReview.title: No, the CDC didn’t issue a travel advisory for Florida over an increase in leprosy cases
