claimReview.textualRating: False. A CDC journal published a report about increased incidence of the disease in Florida that suggested that travel to the state should be considered when conducting contact tracing. But the agency didn’t advise people not to visit.

text: Minimum wage of $19 at LaGuardia Airport in New York City has resulted in $7 croissants.

claimReview.title: Minimum wage is not $19 for workers at New York’s LaGuardia Airport
claimReview.textualRating: False. Minimum wage at LaGuardia Airport will not reach $19 until 2023.

text: Footage purporting to show astronauts aboard the International Space Station is staged and was actually filmed on Earth.

claimReview.title: Social media posts falsely claim space station footage is faked
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for NASA and space science experts say the footage is legitimate and that there is ample evidence to show that there are real people on the massive research complex floating above Earth. Additionally, examples cited as proof of an elaborate hoax are easily explained. Footage of astronauts in space suits working underwater is from training exercises at NASA, for example, and video glitches are due to satellite transmission interruptions.

text: U.S. Sen. Mitt Romney is threatening to leave the Republican Party and join the rival Democratic Party.

claimReview.title: No, Mitt Romney has not threatened to leave the GOP
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The Utah senator’s office said there is “zero truth” to the notion and confirmed the former GOP presidential candidate remains a registered Republican. In April he filed paperwork with the Federal Election Commission that he’d be seeking re-election as a Republican.
List (Page)

text: A Facebook post states that Christmas merchandise sales are no longer permitted in Dearborn, Michigan, featuring a photo of a billboard that says “NO CHRISTMAS TREES DEARBORN CANCELLED ALL XMAS PERMITS.”

claimReview.title: Toys to trees, no restrictions on Christmas sales in Dearborn, Michigan
claimReview.textualRating: False. The city has not banned the selling of Christmas merchandise.

text: A new law in Kansas authorizes genital inspections of children in order to play sports.

claimReview.title: Kansas law doesn’t authorize genital exams for student athletes
claimReview.textualRating: False. The law, which bars transgender athletes from participating in girls’ and women’s sports from kindergarten through college, doesn’t mention anything about genital inspections. It remains unclear how the law will be enforced in different age groups.

text: The Atlantic published a cover story with the headline

claimReview.title: The Atlantic didn’t publish article calling Muslim parents ‘far right’
claimReview.textualRating: False. A screenshot purporting to show this article on The Atlantic’s website is fabricated. The outlet did not publish such a story. No record of it appears online or in archives of its cover stories, and a spokesperson for the outlet confirmed it is not authentic.

text: In a normal year, there is a lot of flu but no COVID-19, while during the pandemic, there has been a lot of COVID-19 and no flu.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 and flu cases both rising, despite claims online
claimReview.textualRating: False. While flu cases plummeted as COVID-19 cases soared early in the pandemic, coronavirus and flu cases are both on the rise globally, according to the World Health Organization. In the U.S., the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports thousands of hospitalizations and deaths from the flu and a significant rise in COVID cases and deaths through the fall and early winter. The flu and the coronavirus are distinct viruses, contrary to claims that they are the same.

text: Los Angeles County disqualified nearly 30% of recall ballots or ballot signatures in the attempted recall of the county’s progressive District Attorney George Gascón.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent failed attempt to recall Los Angeles DA
claimReview.textualRating: False. The county didn’t disqualify ballots or ballot signatures. It disqualified nearly 200,000 of about 716,000 signatures on petitions calling for a vote to recall Gascón. As a result, the recall attempt failed.

text: Photo shows the “Japanese ambassador to Ukraine,” who “stayed in Kiev,” wearing Japanese armor and holding a sword.

claimReview.title: Social posts misidentify photo of Ukrainian ambassador to Japan
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows the Ukrainian ambassador to Japan, who is currently in Japan.

text: Photo shows CNN journalist “covered head to toe in black in 24 hours” after Taliban took over in Afghanistan.

claimReview.title: Photos of CNN journalist covering Kabul lack context
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Two photos of Clarissa Ward, chief international correspondent for CNN, circulated on Twitter -- one where she wears no head covering and another where she wears an abaya. Social media users suggested that this shows the contrast of life before and after Taliban rule. Ward explained that the first image is from a private compound, while the other was captured in public, when she was on the streets of Kabul interviewing Taliban fighters. Though she acknowledged that she’s now covering her head somewhat more fully.

text: Photo shows a $25 million home that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has purchased in Florida.

claimReview.title: Pelosi didn’t purchase $25 million mansion in Florida
claimReview.textualRating: False. Pelosi’s office said there is “no such pending sale” and the brokerage that listed the property also confirmed that the buyer is not the speaker.

text: President Joe Biden was impeached for high crimes and misdemeanors in June 2023.

claimReview.title: Lauren Boebert filed articles of impeachment against Biden. That doesn’t mean he was impeached
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden has not been impeached. The House voted last month to send articles of impeachment introduced by Republican Rep. Lauren Boebert to its Judiciary Committee and its Homeland Security Committee for review. Articles of impeachment, issued solely in the House, detail the charges against an elected official, but impeachment only occurs if the articles are approved by the chambers’ members.

text: A video shows a strange light that appeared in the night sky in Turkey before Monday’s magnitude 7.8 earthquake.

claimReview.title: Clip shows rocket in Kazakhstan, not ‘strange light’ before Turkey quake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was captured in Kazakhstan in September 2022 and shows a Soyuz spacecraft passing through the night sky.

text: New York Gov. Kathy Hochul is trying to create “quarantine camps” in which people can be held against their will if they have COVID-19 or other diseases.

claimReview.title: New York Gov. Kathy Hochul is not trying to create ‘quarantine camps’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Officials have repeatedly said that the state has no intention to build quarantine camps. Critics are misrepresenting a temporary rule adopted during the COVID-19 pandemic that outlines powers by state health officials to isolate or quarantine people for the purpose of controlling a highly transmissible disease. The rule said that people can be isolated or quarantined in interim housing, rather than just their own homes, but doesn’t mention camps. It was deemed unconstitutional by a judge, who said the state overreached, but also did not mention camps.

text: Humans and other mammals injected with an mRNA vaccine die within five years.

claimReview.title: Baseless claims about safety of mRNA vaccines circulate online
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no scientific evidence to suggest humans or other mammals given an mRNA vaccine die within five years, experts told The Associated Press. In fact, there’s ample evidence that mRNA vaccines, including those to prevent COVID-19, are safe and effective.

text: Paid actors were brought in to pose as students during President Joe Biden’s Nov. 30 visit to Dakota County Technical College in Minnesota.

claimReview.title: Actors didn’t pose as students at Biden college event
claimReview.textualRating: False. No paid actors attended the event, the college confirmed. Only a handful of students were invited to the visit, and several of them told The Associated Press they saw no fake students there.

text: Dr. Theresa Tam, Canada’s chief public health officer, developed Bell’s palsy after receiving the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Posts baselessly claim Canada health officer had vaccine side effects
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence that Tam developed Bell’s palsy after receiving the vaccine. Anna Maddison, a Public Health Agency of Canada spokesperson, said Tam has never had the condition, a form of facial paralysis or weakness. And an expert who reviewed the video of Tam being cited for the claim saw no signs of the disorder.

text: The rate of teenager deaths in the U.K. increased significantly from 2020 to 2021, coinciding with the timeline of when teenagers in the country began receiving COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Articles misrepresent data on teen deaths in the UK
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. This claim is based on a flawed analysis of health data. It wrongly implies the COVID-19 vaccines caused teenagers to die when there is no evidence to support that. Experts said no known deaths among teenagers in the U.K. have been linked to COVID-19 vaccines.

text: Judge Amy Coney Barrett, the current nominee for the U.S. Supreme Court, told CBS News in an interview in 2016 that election year nominations are inappropriate and she does not support nominations that would “dramatically flip the balance of power on the Court.”

claimReview.title: Amy Coney Barrett interview doesn’t prove she opposed election year nominations
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Social media users are sharing a clip in which Barrett lays out reasons why people may oppose an election year nomination. However, in the full interview, she says she doesn’t think precedent establishes a rule that favors either side of the argument.

text: Two white men in trench coats went to a Walmart in Bowie, Maryland, earlier this week and threatened to kill all the Black people inside, but were caught by an undercover officer.

claimReview.title: Claims of Walmart threat in Maryland are false
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Bowie Police Department said in a statement that no such threat was reported, and a Walmart spokesperson confirmed the claims were unfounded.

text: A photo shows police capturing Brian Laundrie, the boyfriend of Gabrielle “Gabby” Petito, who was killed while the two were on a cross-country trek to visit national parks in the U.S. West.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show police capturing Brian Laundrie
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows the capture of Patrick McDowell, a suspect wanted in the fatal shooting of a north Florida sheriff’s deputy, not Laundrie.

text: Graph shows that over 100,000 votes for Joe Biden in Wisconsin “came out of nowhere.”

claimReview.title: Graph shows thousands of ballots reported at once, overwhelmingly for Biden
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Milwaukee didn’t finish counting absentee ballots until 3 a.m. The outstanding ballots at that point -- including 169,000 from Milwaukee -- overwhelmingly broke for the Democrat. Based on the counting of in-person votes, President Donald Trump initially had the lead in Wisconsin on election night, but once all the votes were counted, Biden picked up the win. The counting of those outstanding ballots shows up as a big surge in the tally, but those votes didn’t come “out of nowhere.”

text: Kim Kardashian posted an Instagram Story showing that her eldest daughter drew a beheaded person, as well as five graves where four people and a dog were buried.

claimReview.title: Posts claiming to depict Kim Kardashian’s daughter’s art are edited
claimReview.textualRating: False. This image has been edited to add a screengrab from “Scary Movie 3” and shared as a joke. In the real post from February 2021, Kardashian’s daughter’s art featured a mountain.

text: The United Kingdom is banning anyone under the age of 50 from getting COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: UK not banning COVID-19 vaccines for people under 50
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the country will stop widely providing the vaccine to those under 50 next month, anyone deemed to have a clinical need, such as those at risk of severe illness, as well as frontline healthcare workers and caregivers, will still be able to get the shot.

text: A video shows U.S. Marines arriving in Israel amid

claimReview.title: Old video shows US Army arriving in Romania, not Marines landing in Israel
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from 2022 and shows soldiers from the U.S. Army’s 101st Airborne Division arriving in Romania.

text: President Joe Biden just revoked $250 million in spending on the United Negro College Fund that Trump pledged to give to historically Black colleges for the next 10 years.

claimReview.title: Biden did not revoke millions in funding from HBCUs
claimReview.textualRating: False. The United Negro College Fund is not funded by the federal government. Also, Biden has not taken any steps to reduce funding to historically Black colleges and universities.

text: A video shows protesters attacking the Israeli Embassy in Bahrain amidst the

claimReview.title: A video from 2012 is being misrepresented as an attack on the Israel Embassy in Bahrain
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed in 2012. It shows protesters attacking a police station in Sitra, Bahrain.

text: Video shows a father who promised to dance with his daughter at her wedding dancing alone at her grave instead, after she was killed during protests in Iran surrounding the country’s strict laws requiring women to wear Islamic headscarves.

claimReview.title: Video of man dancing shows Azerbaijani TV show, not mourners in Iran
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip is from an episode of the fictional Azerbaijani television program “Ata Ocaği,” which was uploaded to YouTube in 2018.

text: Georgia’s GOP gubernatorial candidate Brian Kemp sued over claims of suppressing thousands of minority voters

claimReview.title: Georgia Gubernatorial candidate Brian Kemp sued over voter registrations
claimReview.textualRating: True. A federal lawsuit has been filed against Georgia gubernatorial candidate Brian Kemp for preventing minority voters from registering.

text: Video shows ships waiting to enter the Suez Canal now that the canal has reopened after a stuck container ship blocked it for six days.

claimReview.title: Video does not show boats in Suez Canal
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was uploaded weeks prior to the massive ship becoming lodged in the canal, and appeared online with a caption saying it was taken during a flight over the port of Chittagong in Bangladesh.

text: Transgender children as young as 5 years old are being given hormones to transition.

claimReview.title: Tweet distorts health care for trans children
claimReview.textualRating: False. Guidelines and health care professionals say hormone treatments should be an option for young adults who are mature enough to make an informed decision, typically around 16. Experts say young transgender children who haven’t reached puberty are offered support, not medical interventions.

text: A California bill would allow mothers to kill their babies up to seven days after birth.

claimReview.title: Headline misrepresents a California reproductive health bill
claimReview.textualRating: False. A bill in the California legislature, AB 2223, is being falsely represented. It was introduced to provide legal protection to women who lose their child due to pregnancy complications, and those who have abortions. It does not legalize the killing of infants.

text: President Joe Biden’s face appeared pinched inward while he gave a speech on the second anniversary of the Jan. 6 Capitol attack.

claimReview.title: Biden’s face edited in video of Jan. 6 remembrance speech
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. A clip of Biden’s Friday speech marking the attack's anniversary was edited to change his facial appearance.

text: CNN footage shows that Russian President Vladimir Putin is on “America’s doorstep” with nuclear bombers in the Caribbean.

claimReview.title: Video of Russian bombers is from 2018 training exercise
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The footage being shared online is from a 2018 CNN news broadcast that described a 10-hour Russian training mission over the Caribbean. It does not show recent developments amid the ongoing invasion of Ukraine.

text: A Florida doctor was removed from a Sarasota hospital board meeting for testifying that ivermectin was effective against COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Florida doctor wasn’t removed from meeting for ivermectin claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. Dr. John Littell testified Tuesday before the Sarasota County Public Hospital Board, claiming that ivermectin was effective in treating COVID-19, and finished his remarks. He was later removed from the meeting after he approached a member of the board as the meeting took place, which a spokesperson said presented a safety risk.

text: A Delta Airlines pilot who had recently been vaccinated for COVID-19 died mid-flight within the last 10 days, forcing the plane to make an emergency landing.

claimReview.title: No evidence for claim that a vaccinated pilot died during flight
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s no truth to this claim, according to a Delta Airlines statement issued Wednesday. An internet search found no credible news stories reporting that this happened, and the Federal Aviation Administration told The Associated Press it had not heard of any incident matching this description.

text: Video shows a man on a train vomiting a massive amount of blood after being infected with the new respiratory virus sweeping China.

claimReview.title: Video does not show man sickened by new virus in China
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is almost a year old and the man on the train is battling liver cancer.

text: Tonic water or quinine supplements can be used to prevent or treat coronavirus symptoms.

claimReview.title: Drinking tonic water will not prevent or cure coronavirus
claimReview.textualRating: False. Medical experts say as of now there is no proven medication or home remedy that can cure coronavirus.

text: A member of President-elect Joe Biden’s COVID-19 task force recommends “withholding food stamps and rent assistance from those who refuse coronavirus vaccines.”

claimReview.title: Posts mislead about vaccine outreach report
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim mischaracterizes the recommendations of a working group that includes a member of Biden’s COVID-19 task force. The group put out a July report with recommendations for how to ensure widespread, voluntary access to a COVID-19 vaccine once there is a safe, available option. Nowhere in the report does it suggest withholding social assistance to those who decline to be vaccinated.

text: Everyone living in the Ohio River basin, as shown in the yellow area of

claimReview.title: Posts misuse Ohio River map to distort contamination area
claimReview.textualRating: False. The map shows the region of land whose surface water drains into the Ohio River, not the region that gets its drinking water from the river. Many counties in the map get their drinking water from other sources, experts said. Contaminants including butyl acrylate have been detected in the Ohio River, but the amounts so far don’t pose a risk for cities that rely on the river for its drinking water, according to the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency and outside experts.

text: CDC numbers reported that among children 5 to17 who had COVID-19, there was one death per 174,803 cases. Pfizer and Moderna trials with children showed one death per 1,000 vaccinated, so California is actually mandating a vaccine with a mortality rate 174 times higher than the virus.

claimReview.title: Post shares false statistics about kids and COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The statistics in the claim are all wrong. Pfizer and Moderna trials with children did not show any deaths.

text: The World Health Organization admits mothers who have been vaccinated against COVID-19 are giving birth to babies with heart defects.

claimReview.title: A WHO report of infant myocarditis cases in Wales is being misrepresented on social media
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for the WHO confirms the global health agency has made no such declaration. The claims reference a WHO report on a recent rash of infant myocarditis cases in Wales. But the report says the cases have been linked to enterovirus, and makes no mention of COVID-19. Public health officials in Wales also say most of the mothers weren’t even vaccinated against the coronavirus during pregnancy.

text: Photo shows a massive wall currently set up in front of the White House.

claimReview.title: Image of fortress-like wall protecting White House is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. This image was fabricated using an aerial photo of the White House from 2009. It’s true that additional anti-scale fencing was set up around the White House before Election Day. However, the fencing does not resemble the wall in this image.

text: President Joe Biden has called for a “driving tax” that is estimated to be 8 cents per mile.

claimReview.title: Mileage tax study, not actual mileage tax, proposed in infrastructure bill
claimReview.textualRating: False. The administration has not proposed that tax. A provision in Biden's $1 trillion infrastructure bill before Congress would establish a national study to assess how such a tax could be implemented. It would not actually enact that tax, nor it does not outline a rate of 8 cents per mile.

text: Conservationist Jane Goodall said

claimReview.title: Conservationist Jane Goodall’s words on population distorted
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. This misrepresents Goodall’s remarks and is not a real quote. While she did say many of the world's environmental problems would be relieved if the population was that of 500 years ago, she did not advocate for depopulation efforts.

text: A photo shows a group of children who were left disabled by a vaccination program in Africa.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show African children disabled by vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image was taken in 1998 in Sierra Leone and shows children affected by polio because they were not vaccinated.

text: There is no coin shortage. Coins get recirculated, they don’t just disappear. They’re trying to usher in a cashless society.

claimReview.title: Government isn’t working to usher in a 'cashless society'
claimReview.textualRating: False. The coins aren’t being circulated because businesses are closed and sales are down during the pandemic. The government isn’t pushing the U.S. into a cashless society, either. The U.S. Mint is actively producing more coins to alleviate the short supply.

text: Customs locked down a port in Delaware after 62 girls were found locked inside a shipping container.

claimReview.title: No evidence 62 girls were found in a Delaware shipping container
claimReview.textualRating: False. Law enforcement investigated the rumor and found no evidence of any such incident.

text: Election technology firm Dominion Voting Systems lost its lawsuits against attorney Sidney Powell and former President Donald Trump’s personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani.

claimReview.title: Dominion lawsuits against Powell and Giuliani are ongoing
claimReview.textualRating: False. Dominion’s defamation lawsuits against Powell and Giuliani are ongoing, according to legal records.

claimReview.title: No ruling yet in Dominion lawsuits against Powell and Giuliani
claimReview.textualRating: False. Legal records show that Dominion’s defamation lawsuits against Powell and Giuliani are ongoing in May 2022.

text: The newest Israeli data on COVID-19 infections indicate a complete vaccine failure on every level. The data from Israel shows that nearly all serious cases and deaths are among the vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on Israel vaccine data
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The claim ignores the fact that Israel has only a fraction of the COVID-19 cases that it had in January, before vaccines were widespread. Furthermore, the majority of adults in Israel are now vaccinated with two Pfizer shots. No vaccine is perfect at preventing breakthrough cases, but the data shows vaccines are reducing the number of people who are severely ill, hospitalized or die from the virus.

text: Audit finds 1,900 licenses issued in dead people’s names

claimReview.title: Audit finds more than 1,900 licenses issued in dead people's names
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. A state audit found that more than 1,900 driver’s licenses were issued under the names of dead people.

text: A report released this week in Michigan shows Dominion Voting Systems machines in Antrim County, Michigan, were “intentionally designed with inherent errors to create systemic fraud and influence election results.”

claimReview.title: Report spreads debunked claims about Dominion machines in Michigan county
claimReview.textualRating: False. This report rests on falsehoods about a human error in Antrim County and about Dominion machines, according to state and local officials. The initial vote reporting error in Antrim County was isolated and has been identified and explained by election officials. It was caused by a clerk’s failure to update media drives for certain tabulators to reflect the correct ballot content. It was not a machine problem.

text: MAD Magazine ran a cartoon of Donald Trump in 1992.

claimReview.title: MAD Magazine did run a satirical Donald Trump cartoon in 1992
claimReview.textualRating: True. There was a cartoon of Donald Trump featured in MAD magazine in December 1992.

text: The terms “conspiracy theory” and “conspiracy theorist” were created by the Central Intelligence Agency following the

claimReview.title: ‘Conspiracy theory’ coined long before JFK assassination
claimReview.textualRating: False. Recorded use of the phrase “conspiracy theory” dates back to at least 1863, and it was notably invoked in reports following the 1881 shooting of then-President James A. Garfield, more than 60 years before the CIA was established. An academic review of the digital library JSTOR found the term “conspiracy theorist” had been published at least in the year before Kennedy’s death.

text: Satanic-themed shirts and pins from a London-based designer are part of Target’s line of merchandise celebrating the LGBTQ+ community.

claimReview.title: UK designer’s satanic apparel not part of Target’s Pride collection
claimReview.textualRating: False. While some items made by the brand Abprallen were among those featured by the big box retailer as part of its Pride month collection, none of the items bore satanic imagery. The three items featured had images of UFOs and planets instead.

text: Images show that a variety of wild animals are loose in South Orange, New Jersey after they escaped overnight from the Turtle Back Zoo when the remnants of Hurricane Ida caused flooding at the facility.

claimReview.title: Animals didn’t escape zoo in NJ storm
claimReview.textualRating: False. These images are old. Turtle Back Zoo tweeted on Thursday that its animals “weathered the storm well and remain safe and secure within the facility.”

text: Emergency U-shaped road was built in Japan in less than 24 hours.

claimReview.title: Bridge in Japan built in months, not 24 hours
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bridge which is part of Japan’s national highway, took nearly four months to complete after a landslide took out part of the highway.

text: A screenshot shows that Shinzo Abe, the former prime minister of Japan who was assassinated on Friday, tweeted

claimReview.title: Fabricated tweet circulates after Shinzo Abe assassination
claimReview.textualRating: False. Abe did not tweet this statement, which is a reference to a long-running internet meme. A screenshot purporting to show the tweet has been fabricated. Abe’s verified Twitter account uses a different username and profile picture than the ones shown in the altered image. The Japanese text in the altered image does not mention Clinton, either.

text: Footage of aircraft getting targeted by ground fire shows the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

claimReview.title: Video game misrepresented as footage of Ukraine invasion
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage is from the video game Arma 3, a representative from the company that makes the game confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Photo shows Kamala Harris standing between her father and mother, who is wearing a sari, at an event.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Sen. Kamala Harris with her parents
claimReview.textualRating: False. The two people pictured in the photo with Harris are not her parents.

text: The New York Times published an opinion piece calling on teachers to permit bullying of unvaccinated students.

claimReview.title: New York Times ‘headline’ about bullying unvaccinated students is bogus
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such article exists. A fabricated headline about bullying was made to look like it came from an opinion piece by the outlet, a spokesperson with The New York Times confirmed.

text: Video shows a television interview with Lucas Armitage, an 8-year-old boy who used his dad’s gun to shoot a burglar several times and then laughed so loudly it woke his dad.

claimReview.title: Interview with boy who claims he shot burglar is satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. This video was produced by The Onion, a satirical news website.

text: The Nashville school shooter can be seen wearing different shoes in two videos of the attack released by police, suggesting the incident was staged.

claimReview.title: No evidence Nashville shooter changed shoes during attack
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s no evidence to suggest that Audrey Hale, the shooter who killed three students and three staff members at a Christian school in Nashville on Monday, changed sneakers. Body-worn camera footage released by the Metropolitan Nashville Police Department shows Hale wearing black sneakers with a flame design and white stripe. The flame design cannot be easily seen in a separate surveillance video taken further away, but other elements on the sneakers match. Video compression reduced the original quality and distorted the colors on the sneakers, a video forensic analyst explained to The Associated Press.

text: Photo shows a federal police officer in futuristic-looking helmet and body armor, reminiscent of a "stormtrooper" in the “Star Wars” franchise, during a recent deployment in Portland, Oregon.

claimReview.title: Photo shows artist’s rendering of futuristic police gear, not a federal officer
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is an artist’s rendering of an imagined police vest. While federal police officers have appeared in Portland in recent weeks dressed in camouflage and tactical gear, this image of an officer in tactical gear covering his head, neck and torso is not real.

text: Erik Hooks, the deputy director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, has been arrested in connection with the agency’s response to the

claimReview.title: No, a top FEMA official was not arrested for treason following the Maui fires. The claim is satire
claimReview.textualRating:
False. A FEMA spokesperson told The Associated Press that Hooks has not been arrested. The claim originated on a website that says it publishes “humor, parody, and satire” and has previously published similar false stories about supposed arrests of public officials.
List (Page)

text: In 40 days, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Congressman Adam Schiff are up for reelection. U.S. Rep. Jerry Nadler, a Democrat from New York, is up for reelection on June 23.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely tout congressional elections within months
claimReview.textualRating: False. Terms for the three House members end in 2023. They will face reelection in November 2022.

text: CNN altered the color in Joe Rogan’s Instagram video to make him look sickly.

claimReview.title: No evidence video color was manipulated in CNN news segment
claimReview.textualRating: False. An analysis of the video used by CNN in a report about talk show host Joe Rogan contracting COVID-19 found no sign that the color had been altered. CNN confirmed no changes were made to the color of the video.

text: The New England Journal of Medicine posted a correction earlier this month that backtracked on its earlier statements. The journal now admits the COVID-19 vaccine may not be safe for pregnant women.

claimReview.title: Medical journal did not suggest vaccines are unsafe in pregnancy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The New England Journal of Medicine did not “backtrack” or suggest that COVID-19 vaccines could be unsafe for pregnant women. A recent correction in the medical journal addressed an error in how risks were calculated, but the paper still arrived at the same conclusion: that the vaccines were not found to be harmful to pregnant people. Informed by safety data, the CDC and obstetrician groups recommend COVID-19 vaccines for pregnant individuals, who face an elevated risk of severe illness if infected with the coronavirus.

text: A photo shows two small children holding hands and saluting Ukrainian troops following Russia’s 2022 invasion.

claimReview.title: Image of children saluting Ukrainian soldiers is years old
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was shared by Ukraine’s Ministry of Defense in 2016.

text: Shortly after Elon Musk reached an agreement to buy Twitter on Monday, Bill Gates was suspended from the platform.

claimReview.title: Elon Musk didn’t get Bill Gates suspended from Twitter
claimReview.textualRating: False. A screenshot purporting to show a suspension notice on Bill Gates’ Twitter account on Monday is fake. Gates’ profile remained active on Twitter as of Tuesday and there is no record of it having been recently suspended.

text: A video shows a disaster response center that the Federal Emergency Management Agency has suspiciously opened in Chicago, even though the city isn't dealing with an emergency at the moment.

claimReview.title: New FEMA office in Chicago isn’t suspicious. It’s part of the agency’s response to summer floods
claimReview.textualRating:
False. FEMA has opened a number of disaster response offices in the city as part of its ongoing efforts to address flood damage in the Chicago-area following torrential rains that struck the region from June 29 to July 2. President Joe Biden issued a disaster declaration last month, allowing affected residents to access federal funding and other government assistance.
List (Page)

text: Photo shows Rep. Rashida Tlaib celebrating President Donald Trump’s impeachment.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Michigan congresswoman celebrating Trump’s impeachment
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo of the Michigan congresswoman was taken in November 2018, well before the House of Representatives voted on Wednesday to impeach the president.

text: Mail-in ballots are not the same thing as absentee ballots. One can be verified and the other cannot.

claimReview.title: Mail-in ballots and absentee ballots are essentially the same, both verifiable
claimReview.textualRating: False. All ballots have a series of built-in checks to verify voter identity and prevent fraud. Some states mail ballots to every registered voter, while other states only mail ballots to voters who request them. But the ballots are subject to that state’s verification requirements in either case.

text: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez wrote, in a tweet congratulating President Joe Biden, that the U.S. should “roundup all Conservative traitors,” referencing Auschwitz.

claimReview.title: Ocasio-Cortez didn’t publish tweet calling for conservative ‘purge’
claimReview.textualRating: False. A screenshot purporting to show the tweet was fabricated, and has been spreading online since early 2021. There is no record of Ocasio-Cortez posting the message.

text: The federal government wants to require Americans to present a health passport or vaccine certificate “on demand,” including for domestic travel.

claimReview.title: The U.S. government has no plans to require ‘vaccine passports’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. government has no plans to require so-called vaccine passports to travel domestically, or for any other purpose. While private businesses are considering vaccine passports for certain activities, Biden administration officials have said the federal government will not mandate vaccine passports.

text: California bill would restrict Christian pastors' speech and ban Christian books.

claimReview.title: A proposed California bill would not have banned the bible
claimReview.textualRating: False. A California bill proposed in February 2018 would not have banned the Bible or restricted Christian pastors’ speech, despite what a story widely circulating on social media suggested.

text: Video shows ballots cast for President Donald Trump by U.S. Navy personnel that were discovered in a Georgia dumpster.

claimReview.title: Papers found in Georgia dumpster were not Trump ballots
claimReview.textualRating: False. According to the Spalding County Sheriff’s Office, no ballots were found in the dumpster.

text: Half of President Joe Biden’s Twitter followers were found to be fake.

claimReview.title: Posts about Biden’s Twitter followers omit context
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. That estimate, of the official @POTUS presidential Twitter account, was calculated using a software company’s free tool that assesses a random sample of recent followers for signs they are bots, spam accounts, spreading propaganda or no longer active. The CEO of the company said it’s “unsurprising” that large accounts are widely followed by such accounts, and that Biden’s estimate is consistent with other high-profile accounts.

text: Former President Barack Obama has signed a $90 million deal with Netflix to produce a documentary about the impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: Obama isn’t producing Netflix documentary about impeachment inquiry
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim began circulating in September following publication of a satirical article in The New Yorker magazine. No such deal has been inked.

text: Former Nickelodeon actress Jennette McCurdy said

claimReview.title: Website falsely attributes quote to former Nickelodeon star
claimReview.textualRating: False. A representative confirmed she did not make that statement, and the website that made the claim cited interviews that do not include such a quote.

text: Two videos show Russian President Vladimir Putin warning the U.S. to “stay away” from the latest Gaza war.

claimReview.title: Old videos do not show Putin warning the US to stay out of the latest Gaza war
claimReview.textualRating: False. Both videos are months-old clips of Putin speaking about the Russia-Ukraine war, not the conflict in the Middle East, which have been miscaptioned in English. One shows Putin speaking at a meeting of Russia’s human rights council in December 2022, the other at a World War II commemoration event in February 2023.

text: Monkeypox can only be spread among gay men.

claimReview.title: Social posts push falsehood that monkeypox can only affect gay men
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the overwhelming majority of cases in the current outbreak in the U.S. and Europe have so far been among men who have sex with men, experts and officials say the virus can be transmitted to anyone.

text: A new 10-foot wall in front of the Federal Reserve building in Washington is a sign that the building is preparing for protests in response to rising interest rates.

claimReview.title: Fencing at Federal Reserve building is for construction
claimReview.textualRating: False. The building, known as the Eccles Building, is undergoing a renovation and expansion construction project, according to a statement on the Federal Reserve Board’s website. An Associated Press reporter confirmed at the scene that the fencing in front of the building is related to construction.

text: A bill passed by the Democrat-led U.S. House of Representatives would criminalize disassembling, cleaning and re-assembling your gun without a firearm manufacturer’s license.

claimReview.title: Bill would not criminalize disassembling and cleaning your gun
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bill, which is unlikely to pass the Senate, would ban ghost guns, or privately made firearms without serial numbers. The bill would not make it illegal for gun owners whose firearms have serial numbers to operate or clean their guns.

text: Fox News aired a chyron referring to the suspect in Monday’s University of North Carolina shooting as a “mostly white Asian male.”

claimReview.title: No, Fox didn’t refer to the UNC shooting suspect as a ‘mostly white Asian male’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The network did not air that chyron, a spokesperson confirmed to The Associated Press. A screenshot of Fox’s actual coverage was edited to change the text.

text: A video compilation, which includes clips appearing to show people in personal protective equipment posing for photos and someone in a body bag smoking a cigarette, shows that the COVID-19 pandemic was “faked.”

claimReview.title: Post misrepresents videos filmed during pandemic
claimReview.textualRating: False. The post misrepresents scenes from media reports, commercial projects and protests.

text: Video shows a stream of trucks traveling from South Carolina to Ottawa to protest COVID-19 mandates.

claimReview.title: Video doesn’t show South Carolina trucks en route to Canada protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The owner of a trucking company recently posted the video on social media but it was taken last year during an event for the Special Olympics South Carolina, according to a company official.

text: Dental products containing fluoride are unsafe because the substance has been directly linked to dementia and Alzheimer’s.

claimReview.title: Topical fluoride use not proven to cause dementia
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say there is no research showing that topical products containing fluoride — such as toothpaste and mouthwash — cause dementia or Alzheimer's. Fluoride is naturally present in water and also added to some public water supplies to promote oral health. But consuming high levels of fluoride isn’t without health risks, such as brittle bones, and some studies have suggested too much fluoride in young children may be related to IQ or neurodevelopmental issues.

text: One million pounds of rat meat is being sold as boneless chicken wings in the U.S.

claimReview.title: Social media revives false claim about rat meat sold as chicken
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image containing the claim has been used to create false posts about rat meat since at least 2016. A photograph featured in the image depicts a vendor in Thailand selling rats and is more than a decade old.

text: 1.4375rem; font-family

claimReview.title: No link between COVID vaccines and placental abnormalities
claimReview.textualRating: False. Research shows no link between COVID-19 immunizations and problems with the placenta, and many vaccinated women have carried their pregnancies to full term. On the contrary, women who get infected with the virus while pregnant have an increased risk of placental abnormalities. Medical experts recommend COVID-19 vaccination during pregnancy to protect against severe symptoms and reduce the risk of pregnancy complications.

text: Video shows Taliban fighters jumping on a trampoline this week as they celebrate their return to power in Afghanistan.

claimReview.title: Video claiming to show Taliban fighters on trampoline is months old
claimReview.textualRating: False. This video is not current and has circulated online for months.

text: Maui hosted a conference about making the entire island into a “smart city” in January and will host another summit next month about using artificial intelligence to govern the island, proving recent wildfires were deliberately set to transform these ideas into reality.

claimReview.title: Conspiracy theories falsely tie Maui wildfires to 'smart cities' and tech conferences
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences in January was not about turning Maui into a “smart island.” It is an annual gathering focused on emerging issues in the information technology sector globally. Next month’s Hawaii Digital Government Summit, similarly, is not specifically focused on using A.I. on Maui, but about how governments across the state can better adapt emerging technologies. It also takes place on another Hawaiian island, not Maui.
List (Page)

text: A photo shows former Ugandan President Idi Amin with England’s Queen Elizabeth II.

claimReview.title: Photo doesn’t show Ugandan dictator with Queen Elizabeth II
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 1971 photo shows the military dictator with former Israeli Prime Minister Golda Meir, not Elizabeth.

text: The first person to receive an experimental coronavirus vaccine during testing in Seattle is a crisis actor

claimReview.title: Beginning of vaccine testing marked by false claims around participants
claimReview.textualRating: False. All participants who volunteered for the vaccine test being led by Kaiser Permanente Washington Research Institute in Seattle were screened and had to meet a set list of criteria. They were not hired as actors to simulate a role.

text: A video of people helping a deer whose head is covered in snow was recorded in the U.S. during a massive

claimReview.title: Video of snow-covered deer is from Kazakhstan, not the US
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video of the snow-covered deer was recorded in Kazakhstan and has been online since at least March 2021, when it was featured in a local news report. The deer in the video appears to be a species that is not native to North America, a wildlife ecology expert told The Associated Press.

text: Photo of hundreds of tractors packing a street shows 2022 Dutch farmer protests against the government’s plans to cut emissions.

claimReview.title: Widely shared Dutch farmer protest picture is from 2019
claimReview.textualRating: False. This photo dates to October 2019, when it was shot by a photographer for ANP News Agency in the Netherlands.

text: A video shows President Joe Biden giving a speech about guns and being interrupted by people making vulgar anti-Biden chants.

claimReview.title: Clip of Biden gun speech was edited to add disparaging chant
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. This footage has been edited to add the chanting. The original video shows Biden was interrupted by just one person — a father whose son was killed at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida — who did not use the curse-filled chant.

text: “President Barack Obama resettled 70,000 Somali refugees in Minnesota. No wonder Rep. Ilhan Omar was elected.”

claimReview.title: Obama did not resettle 70,000 Somali refugees in Minnesota
claimReview.textualRating: False. Minnesota received only 6,320 Somali refugees under the Obama administration, according to data from the U.S. Department of State’s Refugee Processing Center.

text: In North Carolina, you can be charged with a class H felony if you have a concealed carry permit and carry while wearing a mask, according to state statute 14-12.

claimReview.title: North Carolina does not prohibit mask wearing and 'concealed carry'
claimReview.textualRating: False. North Carolina state statutes do not prohibit people with permits to carry concealed guns from doing so while wearing a mask.

text: A video shows people being hit by an unexpected wave amid a tsunami in Tonga.

claimReview.title: Video shows river in Indonesia, not tsunami in Tonga
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was taken in Indonesia and has been online since December 2021. It shows people being hit by a wave on the Kampar River in Sumatra.

text: The U.S. inflation rate jumped from 1.7% in 2017 under President Donald Trump to 14% in 2021 under President Joe Biden.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate inflation figures circulate on social media
claimReview.textualRating: False. While inflation has gone up during Biden’s administration, the numbers given in a popular social media post comparing the rate in each year from 2017 through 2022 are not correct, according to economics experts and U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics data. The correct percentage for 2017 was 2.1% while 2021 was around 7.0%.

text: Researchers from Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis released data showing that if you have had COVID-19, even a mild case, you are likely protected from the virus for life.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Washington University study on COVID-19 immunity
claimReview.textualRating: False. The researchers found that people who have recovered from COVID-19 have bone marrow cells that can create antibodies for decades, but that doesn’t mean those individuals will be immune to new variants of the virus. For example, many people who were infected with the original strain of COVID-19 have been reinfected with the omicron variant.

text: Arizona’s Maricopa County purged the machine records from the 2020 election the day before an outside review of the vote started.

claimReview.title: Election data in Arizona’s largest county was not ‘purged’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Maricopa County election officials confirmed they archived and retained all data from the November election. County election officials moved November 2020 election data off a server and onto backup drives as part of its preparation for an official audit the county commissioned in February 2021.

text: Pfizer was caught “funneling” $12 million to CNN host Anderson Cooper to promote COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: No, Pfizer wasn’t caught ‘funneling’ millions to Anderson Cooper
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence to support that claim, which is an outgrowth of comments made by anti-vaccine activist and presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Kennedy’s campaign said his remarks were intended as a “rhetorical” comment about the pharmaceutical industry’s influence through advertising.

text: Women who have gotten a COVID-19 vaccine are receiving letters instructing them to get screened for cervical cancer because the vaccine caused some 1,500 women to develop cervical cancer.

claimReview.title: Cervical cancer screening letter is routine, not linked to COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video making this claim appears to show a routine letter sent by Ontario’s health agency to remind eligible women to get regular cervical cancer screenings. These letters do not discuss COVID-19 vaccines. Experts told The Associated Press there is no evidence for any link between COVID-19 vaccines and cervical cancer.

text: The FBI headquarters building in Washington is completely closed, empty and walled off.

claimReview.title: FBI headquarters in Washington is open as usual
claimReview.textualRating: False. The building is open and fully operational, according to a statement from the FBI. A video spreading the false claim shows the back of the building rather than the main entrance, which is open.

text: “Maricopa County admits they DELETED and moved the election data to hide it from auditors AFTER they got a subpoena.”

claimReview.title: Arizona county didn’t say it moved election data to ‘hide it’
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Arizona’s largest county did not admit deleting and moving election data to hide it from auditors. The county has explained it was necessary to archive and move the data because there was not space for it to be stored on the server indefinitely.

text: In Fulton County, Georgia, 132,000 ballots had a “change of address” and the votes are likely to be “ineligible.”

claimReview.title: 132,000 ineligible ballots? Fulton County election officials call claim ‘baseless’
claimReview.textualRating: False. According to Fulton County election officials, these claims are “simply false and baseless.” One Twitter user who was sharing the false information pointed to screenshots of supposed voter files, saying that there were 132,000 change of address “flags.” Officials told The Associated Press that the photos do not show an official elections database.

text: Elon Musk, who recently purchased Twitter, reinstated former President Donald Trump’s account on the platform in October 2022.

claimReview.title: Trump was not reinstated on Twitter in October 2022
claimReview.textualRating: False. The former president’s account remains banned. Musk said last week that no major content moderation decisions or account reinstatements will happen until a new “content moderation council” convenes.

text: A video shows the Sunday crash of a passenger plane in Pokhara, Nepal, which killed all 72 aboard.

claimReview.title: Old video of Russian plane in flames circulates after Nepal crash
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was recorded in 2021 and was shot in Russia, not Nepal, according to Associated Press reporting.

text: Photo shows President Joe Biden’s nominee for director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives posing in front of rubble after a fatal 1993 raid on a religious sect’s compound in Waco, Texas.

claimReview.title: Man in Waco rubble image is not Biden's ATF nominee
claimReview.textualRating: False. David Chipman, Biden’s nominee for ATF director, is not the man in the photo, according to Chipman’s own testimony in a Senate confirmation hearing this week. An ATF spokesperson confirmed that Chipman was not the man pictured. ATF also clarified that Chipman arrived in Waco weeks after the raid and participated in the event “solely in a post-incident investigative review capacity.”

text: “We have lost 500 Billion Dollars a year, for many years, on Crazy Trade with China. NO MORE!”-- tweet by President Donald Trump on May 10.

claimReview.title: Trump overstates US trade deficit with China
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. trade deficit with China was not $500 billion last year.

text: Gas prices in the U.S. have risen to almost $9 per gallon.

claimReview.title: US gas prices aren't almost $9, as Trump claimed
claimReview.textualRating: False. Gas prices in the U.S., while high, are on average much lower than $9 per gallon. The national average gas price is around $4.60 per gallon, while the state with the highest average is California at roughly $6.10, according to multiple estimates.

text: A Florida bill signed into law by Gov. Ron DeSantis, which allows people to carry concealed weapons without a government permit, went into effect in April.

claimReview.title: Florida permitless carry law hasn’t taken effect, contrary to claims after beach shooting
claimReview.textualRating: False. DeSantis signed the bill in April, but the new law will not take effect until July 1.

text: Video shows Kenya Deputy President William Ruto saying, “I have grown my career from corruption.”

claimReview.title: Altered video distorts Kenya deputy president’s words
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. The audio in the clip has been manipulated to substitute in the word “corruption.” The original interview shows Ruto saying, “I have grown my career from nothing.”

text: Votes were eliminated in Arizona because people were made to use Sharpie pens to mark their ballots. This caused the tabulation machine to cancel the vote.

claimReview.title: Ballots marked with Sharpie pens were not invalidated in Arizona
claimReview.textualRating: False. Sharpies were allowed in Arizona but they do not affect the vote. And even if a ballot could not be read by a tabulation machine, it would be reviewed by a board that re-examines the ballots.The vote would not be canceled.

text: Video shows House Speaker Nancy Pelosi lashing out at CNN host Christiane Amanpour in an interview about Trump’s acquittal after being impeached.

claimReview.title: Video edited to alter CNN interview with Nancy Pelosi
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was altered to zoom in on Pelosi and selectively edit her response to Amanpour. The video also adds a final comment from Amanpour, which was taken from an interview she did at a film festival in 2019.

text: A photo shows actor Tom Hanks wearing a T-shirt that reads “46>45.”

claimReview.title: Tom Hanks photo altered to add political T-shirt
claimReview.textualRating: Altered image. A 2015 photo of Hanks in a soccer jersey was manipulated to add the T-shirt and slogan.

text: President Joe Biden said at a rally in Texas that he’s “going to take on those rapist Mexicans.”

claimReview.title: Posts mischaracterize Biden’s 2019 comments about Mexicans
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Video from the rally has been cut to change the meaning of what Biden said. He was not making derogatory comments about Mexicans. The full video of his remarks shows he was citing comments made by former President Donald Trump when he announced his candidacy for president in 2015 and referred to Mexican immigrants to the U.S. as “rapists.”

text: A photo shows Ukrainian soldiers surrendering en masse this month as the country is on the verge of losing its conflict with Russia.

claimReview.title: Old photo of surrendering Ukrainian troops misrepresented on social media
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The photo is more than a year old and was distributed by Russia. News reports at the time said it showed Ukrainian soldiers surrendering during the fierce battle in the coastal city of Mariupol. Experts monitoring developments in the Russian invasion also say there’s nothing to suggest Ukrainians are close to yielding.
List (Page)

text: Plankton in the Atlantic Ocean is 90% gone.

claimReview.title: Fact check: False claim that 90% of plankton has been lost in Atlantic Ocean
claimReview.textualRating: False

claimReview.title: Atlantic Ocean has not lost 90% of its plankton
claimReview.textualRating: False. This claim is based on a misrepresentation of a limited survey that reviewed water samples for plankton in a section of the Atlantic Ocean. The lead author told The Associated Press it was inaccurate to suggest his research reported that 90% of Atlantic Ocean plankton was gone. Experts who study global marine life say that if 90% of plankton in the Atlantic Ocean were gone, there would be severe collapse in the ecosystem as a whole.

text: A “Sudden Cardiac Arrest Awareness Form” is now being issued in Georgia high schools, suggesting a new phenomenon relating to the COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Georgia school form on sudden cardiac arrest risks isn’t new
claimReview.textualRating: False. That form has been given to families of Georgia students since 2019. A spokesperson for the high school association that published the document noted that it is distributed in accordance with state law.

text: A photo shows Harriet Tubman holding a rifle.

claimReview.title: Photo shows ‘Stagecoach Mary,’ not Harriet Tubman
claimReview.textualRating: False. The woman in the photo is of Mary Fields, not Harriet Tubman. Fields — also known as Stagecoach Mary for her work delivering the mail — was an African American pioneer in Montana during the late 19th century.

text: Fentanyl is the leading cause of death for adults in the U.S.

claimReview.title: Posts exaggerate adult fentanyl deaths in the U.S.
claimReview.textualRating: False. Fentanyl overdose deaths, while high, are not the leading cause of deaths among all adults in the U.S., experts say. Heart disease and cancer kill more people, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

text: Pfizer received FDA approval for a new monkeypox shot the day after the U.S. purchased millions of dollars worth of vaccine for the disease.

claimReview.title: Pfizer does not make vaccine for monkeypox
claimReview.textualRating: False. Pfizer does not make a monkeypox vaccine, nor did it recently receive approval for one, a company representative told The Associated Press. Jynneos, a vaccine for smallpox and monkeypox, is the only FDA-approved vaccine for monkeypox in the U.S. It was developed by the Danish company Bavarian Nordic.

text: They named the new COVID-19 variants after brain wave frequencies.

claimReview.title: Brain waves not a factor in naming COVID-19 variants
claimReview.textualRating: False. COVID-19 virus variants are not named after brain wave frequencies. Both virus variants and brain wave frequencies are named using letters from the Greek alphabet. But the names have no connection.

text: President Joe Biden went on air to blame Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis for Hurricane Ian.

claimReview.title: Biden didn’t blame DeSantis for hurricane
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden has made no such accusation. The Democratic president and the Republican Florida governor coordinated before the hurricane hit and again on Thursday morning, and Biden has said plans to visit Florida and meet with DeSantis. Biden declared an emergency for the state before the storm hit and declared a major disaster in parts of Florida early Thursday at DeSantis’ request, The Associated Press reported.

text: Photo shows a wind turbine that melted in the Texas heat.

claimReview.title: Texas heat didn’t melt wind turbine
claimReview.textualRating: False. Recent damage to a wind turbine in southeastern Texas was not related to heat, according to a spokesperson for RWE Renewables, which operates the turbine. The company is investigating how the damage occurred, with a recent storm being one potential cause.

text: Rep. Ilhan Omar of Minnesota said “My people did something,” in reference to the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

claimReview.title: Image distorts Rep. Omar’s 9/11 remarks
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image circulating on Facebook that shows the burning World Trade Center’s twin towers with photos of Omar laughing, wrongly asserts that the Democratic congresswoman said, “My people did something.”

text: A video shows Virginia Governor Ralph Northam during a 2019 radio interview speaking in support of infanticide, or “after-birth abortions.”

claimReview.title: Posts distort former Virginia governor’s comments on third trimester abortions
claimReview.textualRating: False. Northam was giving a hypothetical example of what could happen if a mother whose fetus had severe deformities, or wasn’t otherwise viable, requested an abortion while in labor. His comments came in response to a question about whether he supported state legislation that would have loosened restrictions on abortions later in pregnancy. Experts told The Associated Press that abortions in the third trimester are extremely rare.

text: A New Zealand grocery store posted a government-endorsed sign that reads, “We don’t hire the unvaccinated, go home.”

claimReview.title: New Zealand store didn’t post sign telling unvaccinated applicants to ‘go home’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The sign was not created or posted by the store, a representative said, adding that it was put up by members of the public and removed by employees. It was also not created by the New Zealand government or an official government document, a government spokesperson said.

text: A photo shows a white-haired dog covered in dirt who helped rescue at least 10 people in Turkey after an earthquake struck the country on Monday.

claimReview.title: 2014 photo of US rescue dog misrepresented after Turkey earthquake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image was taken in 2014 by a Reuters photographer after a deadly mudslide near Oso, Washington. It shows a rescue dog named Tryon who searched for victims after the destruction.

text: Dr. Anthony Fauci funded experiments on orphans with AIDS and 25 of them died.

claimReview.title: Articles misrepresent Fauci-linked research involving foster children
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, which Fauci runs, did fund clinical trials evaluating HIV and AIDS treatments that enrolled HIV-positive children both in and out of foster care. But the report that found that 25 children in foster care died during trials did not find that the trials were the cause of their deaths.

text: An image shows a tweet from CNN claiming “brave children” in Ukraine are signing up to fight in the war against Russia.

claimReview.title: Tweet attributed to CNN is fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. CNN published no such tweet, and an image purporting to show a screenshot of the post was fabricated. A photo in the bogus screenshot is at least five years old, and shows children at a paramilitary summer camp organized by the Azov Regiment, a far-right group that is now part of Ukraine’s national guard.

text: A fourth round of stimulus funds is automatically going out to residents in 10 states on Nov. 30.

claimReview.title: No, the IRS isn’t distributing 'stimulus checks' in certain states this month, despite claims online
claimReview.textualRating: False. The federal government is not releasing another round of stimulus money, the Internal Revenue Service confirmed. The IRS issued three rounds of such payments during the peak of the coronavirus pandemic. The last one went out nationwide nearly two years ago.

text: A video shows a real robot beating a human at table tennis.

claimReview.title: Video of a robot and human playing table tennis was created with AI visual-effects software
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video of two humans playing table tennis at the recent European Championships was digitally altered to replace one competitor with a computer-generated robot. It was created with a platform called Wonder Studio, which uses artificial intelligence to add and animate CGI characters into existing footage, the company confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Video shows President Donald Trump, members of his family and members of the Trump administration watching a screen and celebrating from a tent as rioters stormed into the U.S. Capitol building in a violent siege.

claimReview.title: Video of Trump family in tent was filmed before Capitol riot
claimReview.textualRating: False. The content on the screen, the commentary by Trump’s son and the music in the video indicate that it was filmed earlier on Wednesday, well before a mob stormed into the Capitol.

text: Ivermectin causes reduced sperm count or sterility in men.

claimReview.title: Male sterility not a known side effect of ivermectin
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration says claims that the parasite drug ivermectin can cause infertility in men are unproven. The study used to support the claims was based on about three dozen men in Nigeria a decade ago, and has been called into question for flaws in its research methods as well as problems with the journal's peer review process.

text: Vintage photo shows women members of the Ku Klux Klan holding up “Women of the Democrat Party” sign.

claimReview.title: Photo shows KKK members with “Lancaster County” sign, not “Women of the Democrat Party”
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was manipulated. The real photo, taken in 1925, shows KKK members holding up a sign that states “Lancaster County.”

text: Female rapper shown in a viral video is Eminem’s daughter.

claimReview.title: Eminem’s daughter not rapper in video
claimReview.textualRating: False. The performer in a rap video who has been identified by some people as Eminem’s daughter is not related to the famous rapper.

text: Video shows a Russian fighter jet falling through gray skies, catching on fire and plummeting to the ground after being shot down during Russia’s attack on Ukraine in February 2022.

claimReview.title: Social media users falsely claim video shows Russian jet gunned down
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video does not show a Russian fighter jet being shot down. The footage was published by The Associated Press in March 2011, and shows a warplane shot down by Libyan rebels.

text: A photo shows a poster distributed by the National Health Service in England warning that COVID-19 vaccines cause Bell’s palsy.

claimReview.title: NHS didn’t create poster claiming COVID-19 causes Bell’s palsy
claimReview.textualRating: False. Any such poster was not issued by the NHS, the public health service confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Data shows that COVID-19 vaccines are more deadly than the virus itself.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccine deaths do not outnumber virus deaths
claimReview.textualRating: False. This bogus claim rests on U.K. data presented without proper context, according to an Associated Press analysis confirmed by medical experts. Reports of death resulting from COVID-19 vaccination are rare. Meanwhile, more than 4 million people worldwide have died from COVID-19.

text: Video shows President Joe Biden telling Pope Francis, “You're the famous African-American baseball player.”

claimReview.title: Video shows Biden telling Pope Francis a story about Satchel Paige
claimReview.textualRating: False. In the full video clip released by the Vatican, Biden was telling Pope Francis a parable about aging, where he referenced American baseball player Satchel Paige, a Black pitcher who played the sport late into his 50s.

text: An image shows a CNN broadcast that adjusted the brightness to lighten the skin of the Memphis police officers charged in the killing of Tyre Nichols.

claimReview.title: Fabricated image of CNN broadcast shows officers charged in Memphis killing with lighter skin
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image is not from a CNN broadcast, a spokesperson for the network told The Associated Press. It was created using an image from a 2016 segment, which has been used previously as a template for similarly fabricated images.

text: Democrats have proposed a bill that makes it illegal to confront or fight back against looters, burglars and shoplifters, a move that basically legalizes crime.

claimReview.title: California bill does not make it illegal for employees to confront shoplifters
claimReview.textualRating: False. California bill SB 553, which awaits the governor’s signature after passing on Tuesday, doesn’t legalize crime or prohibit employees from confronting shoplifters. The bill would require businesses to have a workplace violence prevention plan that includes several provisions. Previous versions of the bill had a provision that prohibited businesses from requiring non-security employees to confront shoplifters and active shooters, but that language has been removed.

text: World Economic Forum executive chairman Klaus Schwab was recently admitted to the hospital in serious condition and might have died.

claimReview.title: The WEF’s chairman is still alive and well, despite claims online
claimReview.textualRating: False. Posts making these allegations began spreading widely after a website that says it publishes “satire, and comedic opinion pieces and editorials” posted an article about Schwab’s supposed hospitalization. A WEF spokesperson told The Associated Press that the claims are untrue.

text: When Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador rode in the U.S. presidential limousine sometimes referred to as “the beast,” it marked the first time a foreign leader traveled in the vehicle with a U.S. president.

claimReview.title: World leaders have ridden in US president’s limo
claimReview.textualRating: False. Several world leaders have traveled in the U.S. presidential Cadillac, including French President Emmanuel Macron, former Japanese Prime Minister Shinz Abe and former Russian President Dmitry Medvedev.

text: Massive explosions were reported Friday at a major U.S. military base in western Iraq.

claimReview.title: No explosions reported at US military base in Iraq
claimReview.textualRating: False. Security officials in Iraq confirmed to The Associated Press Friday that no such activity occurred at the base.

text: Climate change is not happening, nor are humans causing significant global warming. There is also no scientific consensus that climate change is occurring.

claimReview.title: Old video of Weather Channel co-founder fuels climate misinfo
claimReview.textualRating: False. The scientific consensus is that climate change is real and that greenhouse gas emissions caused by human activity are driving climate change, as The Associated Press has previously reported. The false claims stem from a years-old CNN interview with John Coleman, the now deceased co-founder of The Weather Channel. At the time, he had not worked at the network in three decades, and The Weather Channel rejected his claims in the same CNN segment.

text: A Florida law allowing military veterans without a bachelor's degree to teach in Florida also extends to their spouses.

claimReview.title: Florida law lets veterans teach without degrees, not their spouses
claimReview.textualRating: False. Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis approved a bill making veterans without a bachelor's degree eligible to receive a temporary five-year teaching certificate. However, that privilege does not extend to family members or spouses, according to the Florida Department of Education and an aide to the state senator who introduced the bill.

text: Gen. Robert E. Lee, who led the Confederate States Army in the Civil War, “opposed both secession and slavery.” He did not own slaves.

claimReview.title: Gen. Robert E. Lee owned slaves
claimReview.textualRating: False. According to historians, not only did Lee own slaves, but he also fought in court to keep working slaves from his father-in-law's estate. Claims casting Lee as an anti-slavery figure are tied to a false narrative known as the Lost Cause, which says the Confederate experience in the Civil War was not about slavery, but state’s rights.

text: Video shows Russian President Vladimir Putin speaking English to warn Americans about election interference.

claimReview.title: Deepfake video shows Putin speaking English
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is a deepfake generated by artificial intelligence and was created by advocacy group RepresentUs for an advertising campaign on protecting voting rights. The video has been online since September 2020.

text: A judge on Monday delayed proceedings in former President Donald Trump’s New York defamation trial until Tuesday, the day of the New Hampshire primary, which is proof of election interference.

claimReview.title: Delay of Trump defamation trial due to illness, not election interference
claimReview.textualRating: False. The trial was delayed on Monday because of a juror’s illness. Although the judge did not rule on when proceedings would resume before court was adjourned, a filing later that day said they would continue on Wednesday. It did not specify whether the timing was due to the primary schedule or to illness.

text: The Federal Emergency Management Agency is giving out one-time hazard compensation payments of up to $4,800 to Americans who have worked during the COVID-19 pandemic.

claimReview.title: FEMA did not authorize one-time $4,800 payments to individuals
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are sharing this bogus claim as a joke, with links that lead to a picture of a gorilla holding up its middle finger. FEMA has not authorized any such payments.

text: Magic Johnson contracted HIV from a contaminated Hepatitis B vaccine as part of a study run by Dr. Anthony Fauci decades ago.

claimReview.title: False claims circulate about Magic Johnson’s HIV diagnosis
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Lakers legend has said he believes he contracted the virus from unprotected sex. Johnson didn’t comment on the latest claims, but in the past has credited Fauci, who had been a leading researcher when AIDS first emerged, with helping him cope with his diagnosis, which prompted him to retire from the NBA.

text: The BBC shared a video that suggested Ukraine was responsible for a Friday missile attack on a train station in Kramatorsk, Ukraine.

claimReview.title: BBC-branded video on Ukraine train attack is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. This is a fake video imitating BBC’s branding and was not published by the BBC, the British broadcaster confirmed.

text: The Church of England will stop using male pronouns for God and will drop the phrase “our Father” from the Lord’s Prayer.

claimReview.title: Church of England hasn’t stopped use of male pronouns for God
claimReview.textualRating: False. The church has been in ongoing discussions about using gender-neutral language in written services, and recently said it is launching a new project on the matter in the spring. But there are no current plans to abolish the use of masculine pronouns and language for God, the church told The Associated Press in a statement.

text: The White House confirmed that people living in the country illegally who are convicted of rape or assault will not be deported.

claimReview.title: White House didn’t say immigrants convicted of rape would not be deported
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. On Monday, White House press secretary Jen Psaki acknowledged that new priorities for the enforcement of immigration laws may not include immigrants convicted of DUIs or assault. Rape convictions were not mentioned in a draft version of new interim guidelines from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

text: Video shows young boy’s reaction after a grandfather told to buy the video game Minecraft for the child’s Christmas present got Hitler’s “Mein Kampf” instead.

claimReview.title: Video of boy receiving ‘Mein Kampf’ instead of Minecraft is staged
claimReview.textualRating: False. A French humorist staged and filmed the mix up as a joke and then uploaded the video to his Instagram on Christmas Eve.

text: President Joe Biden recently announced that Americans not vaccinated for COVID-19 before 2022 will be sent to quarantine camps until they get their shots.

claimReview.title: Satire fuels false claims of ‘quarantine camps’ for unvaccinated in US
claimReview.textualRating: False. This claim appears in a fake news story on the financial satire website The Stonk Market. Biden has not made any such announcement.

text: Former Judge Janice Rogers Brown was the first Black woman nominated to the U.S. Supreme Court, but she was blocked by then-senator Joe Biden.

claimReview.title: Judge Janice Rogers Brown was not a Supreme Court nominee
claimReview.textualRating: False. Brown was never nominated to the Supreme Court. Biden and other Democratic senators blocked Brown’s nomination to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in 2003, although she was confirmed two years later.
