text: “Fox News Sunday” host Chris Wallace posted a tweet making a number of derogatory remarks about President Donald Trump, including “You’re a fraud. A charlatan. A thug. A loser.”

claimReview.title: Tweet fabricated to make it appear it came from Fox News host Chris Wallace
claimReview.textualRating: False. Wallace does not have a Twitter account and “Fox News Sunday” did not tweet the post from its account.

text: Rare malaria cases reported in Florida and Texas recently were caused by a disease-control initiative backed by Bill Gates that involved releasing genetically modified mosquitoes in the U.S.

claimReview.title: A Bill Gates-tied mosquito project is not responsible for recent US malaria cases
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation doesn’t finance any modified mosquito release projects in the U.S. And experts say the types of mosquitoes that are used for that initiative in Florida are not capable of transmitting malaria.

text: Washington state passed a bill that will incentivize people to report hate speech and bias on a 24/7 hotline with a cash reward.

claimReview.title: A new Washington state law does not offer cash for reporting hate speech
claimReview.textualRating: False. The final version of the bill, SB 5427, signed by Washington Gov. Jay Inslee, a Democrat, on Tuesday, does not offer any such compensation. In its original version, the bill outlined a fund that would have allowed for victims of hate crimes or bias incidents to receive up to $2,000. All versions of the bill stipulate the establishment of a reporting hotline that will be staffed during business hours, not 24/7.

text: President Donald Trump tweeted on Feb. 25,2015

claimReview.title: Stock market tweet falsely attributed to Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet was not written by Trump. It was fabricated and it was first posted in 2018, not 2015.

text: Democratic Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York protested the treatment of immigrant children when Donald Trump was president and said he was putting “kids in cages.” Now, President Joe Biden is doing the same thing but calling them “overflow facilities for unaccompanied migrant children” and Ocasio-Cortez is smiling.

claimReview.title: Ocasio-Cortez criticized both Trump and Biden for immigrant youth conditions
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ocasio-Cortez, an outspoken critic of the Trump administration’s treatment of immigrant children, also criticized the Biden administration’s recent move to reopen a Trump-era temporary facility in Texas to house immigrant children who arrived at the border without parents. A photo in some of the posts of Ocasio-Cortez smiling has no association with the recent news.

text: Trump’s “Make America Great Again” caps are made in China, not the U.S.

claimReview.title: Official Trump MAGA hats are made in the US
claimReview.textualRating: False. The hats are made by a manufacturer in California.

text: An image shows former President Donald Trump dancing with a teenage girl at a party at Jeffrey Epstein’s private island.

claimReview.title: Image claiming to show Trump dancing with underage girl is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. Trump’s campaign and an expert on synthetic images say the image isn’t real. The visual has the telltale signs of one made using programs powered by generative artificial intelligence.

text: Half of the police officers in Canada’s capital city resigned on Monday in support of protests against vaccine requirements.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim 50% of Ottawa police quit over protests
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s no truth to these claims, according to both the Ottawa Police Service and the Ottawa Police Association, a union representing the vast majority of officers in the agency. To date, none of the OPA’s 2,000 sworn or civilian members have quit over the protests, according to OPA president Matt Skof.

text: Video shows Belgian farmers using tractors during a protest in support of “freedom convoy” demonstrations in Canada against COVID-19 vaccine mandates.

claimReview.title: Video shows 2015 farmer protest, not rally against COVID mandates
claimReview.textualRating: False. The protest in Belgium had no relation to the ongoing demonstrations in Canada against vaccine policies. The video was taken in 2015, years before the COVID-19 pandemic. It shows a protest in Brussels, the European Union capital, by farmers upset about falling agricultural prices.

text: Photo shows explosions from Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Israeli air strikes in Gaza, not Russia attack on Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image was captured in May 2021 and shows Israeli air strikes in the Gaza Strip.

text: Video shows the U.S. Navy near Taiwan ahead of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit.

claimReview.title: Video shows US military training exercise, not Navy near Taiwan for Pelosi’s visit
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for the Navy confirmed to The Associated Press that the video was filmed on Sept. 25, 2020, and shows a biennial U.S. military training exercise featuring several ships and aircrafts in the Philippine Sea.

text: Norway has “reclassified” COVID-19 as a “common flu” after finding the disease is no more dangerous than influenza.

claimReview.title: Norway didn’t declare that COVID-19 is no more dangerous than flu
claimReview.textualRating: False. That distortion appears to be a misrepresentation of a health official’s recent interview with a Norwegian newspaper.

text: The late Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg wanted to lower the age of consent for sex to 12 years old.

claimReview.title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg did not advocate lowering the age of consent
claimReview.textualRating: False. This bogus claim emerged during Ginsburg’s 1993 confirmation hearings when official testimony misinterpreted a recommendation by Ginsburg in a 1977 text published by the United States Commission on Civil Rights. It has lingered in the public forum ever since.

text: Twitter has a feature that notifies users if a profile belongs to a registered sex offender.

claimReview.title: Twitter is not placing sex offender notices on profiles
claimReview.textualRating: False. Twitter does not have any such feature. A Twitter user created a hoax warning on their profile page to make it seem like Twitter was notifying people about a sex offender on the platform.

text: Coronavirus remains in the throat for four days, drinking water and gargling with warm water mixed with salt or vinegar eliminates the virus.

claimReview.title: Medical officials counter claims that gargling eliminates coronavirus
claimReview.textualRating: False. Drinking water and gargling with a mixture of warm water and salt or vinegar is not an effective way to fight or eliminate the coronavirus spreading in the U.S.

text: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, appears to be a clone or a robot in a video shared on Facebook.

claimReview.title: Video claiming to show Meghan Markle ‘clone’ is from wax museum
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. This video shows a moving figure in a special exhibit years ago at Madame Tussauds wax museum in London. It does not show the real Meghan.

text: The illness that scientists are labeling the omicron variant of COVID-19 may actually just be the common cold or the respiratory syncytial virus, both of which appear more often in the winter months.

claimReview.title: Scientists identify COVID variants through sequencing, not symptoms
claimReview.textualRating: False. Scientists detected the omicron variant by sequencing the genetic material of virus samples, not by noticing cold-like symptoms. And while it’s true that colds and RSV are more prevalent in winter, COVID-19 tests are designed to discern that someone has the coronavirus as opposed to just a common cold.

text: Photos show five white people who were beaten up by a Black Lives Matter “hate group” because of their skin color.

claimReview.title: Photos don’t show victims of a Black Lives Matter ‘hate group’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Several of the photos in this viral post have circulated on the internet long before recent Black Lives Matter protests. At least two have been identified online as victims of unrelated crimes in South Africa.

text: Officials counted “9 million mail in ballots” in an hour in the California gubernatorial recall election, whereas it took some states weeks to tabulate results in the 2020 presidential election.

claimReview.title: Quick results in California recall election not sign of ‘fraud’
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. California’s recall election results were tabulated quickly in part because election officials were able to process mail-in ballots prior to Election Day. While The Associated Press and others have called the election, official counting continues.

text: Video shows oil tankers backed up in Oklahoma.

claimReview.title: Video of vessels shot in Bangladesh, not Oklahoma or Suez Canal
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed during a flight in Bangladesh in February.

text: Images showing a litter-strewn room are of “Japan’s dressing room after Costa Rica match” in this year’s World Cup.

claimReview.title: Photos don’t show World Cup locker room littered by Japan
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photos date back to March, reverse image searches show. A spokesperson for the Italian soccer federation confirmed that the photos show a locker room in Palermo used by Italy’s team. The team apologized for the condition at the time.

text: Photo claims to show Hurricane Michael approaching Panama City, Florida, with a 35 mph speed limit sign in the foreground.

claimReview.title: Storm photo not of Hurricane Michael
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo showing a ridge of dark, ominous clouds that was widely shared on social media was not taken as Hurricane Michael hit Panama City, Florida, last week.

text: Marriage certificate proves Rep. Ilhan Omar of Minnesota was legally married to two men at the same time

claimReview.title: Rep. Omar wasn’t legally married to two men at the same time
claimReview.textualRating: False. Omar married Ahmed Nur Said Elmi on Feb. 12, 2009, according to a Hennepin County, Minnesota, marriage certificate, and filed for divorce in 2017. She married Ahmed Abdisalan Hirsi on Jan. 5, 2018, according to a marriage certificate.

text: Barbra Streisand has threatened to remove her music from Spotify if the streaming service doesn't “deplatform” Joe Rogan.

claimReview.title: Barbra Streisand hasn’t ‘threatened’ to pull music from Spotify
claimReview.textualRating: False. Representatives for Streisand confirmed to The Associated Press that the singer has not threatened to remove her music catalog from Spotify. Streisand has not made any such public comments, and as of Friday her music remains available on the streaming service.

text: Law enforcement officials in Canada report over 100,000 trucks and millions of people showed up last weekend in Ottawa for a vaccine mandate protest.

claimReview.title: Trucks, crowds at Canada anti-vaccination protest exaggerated
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such estimates have been provided by the law enforcement agencies named in posts circulating on social media — the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and the Ontario Provincial Police, representatives said.

text: Coronavirus cases without symptoms aren’t real. An asymptomatic patient is simply a healthy person.

claimReview.title: Asymptomatic COVID-19 infections do occur
claimReview.textualRating: False. The virus has been found in people who never went on to develop symptoms, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Researchers estimate that at least a third of people who become infected with the coronavirus never experience symptoms. People infected with COVID-19 can also spread the virus before they develop symptoms, experts say.

text: Americans need a passport to leave the country but “illegal aliens” do not need one to enter.

claimReview.title: US border is not open to those without legal permission
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. People trying to enter the U.S. must show proof they are an American citizen or provide documents showing they have permission to enter the country. The law also allows for those without documents who have a credible fear of returning to their home country to enter and apply for asylum. During the pandemic, however, most people encountered trying to cross the border have been immediately expelled without seeing a judge. In recent weeks, some families who are not expelled have been placed in removal proceedings.

text: NASA admitted that climate change is due to the Earth’s orbit around the sun, not greenhouse gas emissions.

claimReview.title: NASA did not attribute climate change to the Earth’s orbit
claimReview.textualRating: False. NASA has not made such a determination, a spokesperson for the agency told The Associated Press. The agency agrees with the scientific consensus that climate change is driven by greenhouse gas emissions caused by human activity.

text: The Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are mRNAs vaccines that skipped animal trials because using mRNA vaccines on animals triggers dangerous inflammation.

claimReview.title: Pfizer and Moderna did not skip animal trials
claimReview.textualRating: False. Pfizer and Moderna did not skip animal trials when testing their COVID-19 vaccines.

text: A 44-year-old migrant named Sahil Omar was identified as one of the shooters at the Kansas City Chiefs’ Super Bowl parade on Wednesday.

claimReview.title: Posts share erroneous information about suspect identification in Kansas City mass shooting
claimReview.textualRating: False. Three juveniles were detained and one was later released in the investigation into the shooting that broke out at the conclusion of parade festivities outside historic Union Station, police said. The name Sahil Omar along with the same description has been used before on social media to make similar erroneous claims in connection with a January explosion in Fort Worth, Texas, and a December shooting in Las Vegas.

text: A safety data sheet for Apeel Sciences, a company that makes a protective coating used to keep fruits and vegetables fresh, shows that its product can cause eye damage and allergic skin reactions.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent safety of produce-protecting solution from Apeel
claimReview.textualRating: False. The safety document being cited is for an unrelated cleaning product that uses the same name. That product is made by a different, U.K.-based company.

text: A new tax policy allows the IRS to “monitor all transactions involving bank accounts worth more than $600.” Another new policy taxes all payments of more than $600 made through applications like PayPal and Venmo.

claimReview.title: Online posts misrepresent scope of tax proposal, policy
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say current proposals and policies do not call for either of these actions. A proposal expanding banks’ IRS reporting requirements would allow the agency to see the total amount deposited and withdrawn annually from most bank accounts, but not individual transactions. A separate policy set to take effect in January 2022 will require mobile payment apps and users to report information about commercial transactions to the IRS. It will not impose an additional tax and will not apply to payments such as reimbursements between family and friends.

text: An image shows astronaut Bruce McCandless II floating untethered in space, above a mountain range on Earth.

claimReview.title: Photo of untethered astronaut floating in space is altered
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. While the top half of the image featuring McCandless floating in space is real, the bottom half has been altered to add the mountains. A photographer who originally spliced the two images together confirmed that it is altered, and NASA also confirmed that the image spreading on social media did not come from the agency.

text: Video shows Italians taking down the European Union flag and replacing it with Italy’s flag after a right-wing group, Brothers of Italy, won its national election.

claimReview.title: Video of EU flag removal in Italy is from 2013, not 2022
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, filmed on Dec. 14, 2013, in Rome, shows a member of a neo-fascist group, CasaPound, tearing down the E.U. flag.

text: Vaccines for the flu, measles, mumps and rubella were developed decades ago, yet the diseases haven't been eradicated, proving that the immunizations don’t work.

claimReview.title: Social media posts misconstrue the efficacy of vaccines for flu, measles, mumps and rubella
claimReview.textualRating:
False. Cases of measles and rubella have been virtually eliminated in the U.S., thanks to vaccines, according to public health agencies and experts. Flu and mumps vaccines, meanwhile, have helped drastically reduce the incidence of serious illness and death from those diseases. Other once-deadly illnesses, such as smallpox and polio, have also all but been eliminated in the country by vaccinations.
List (Page)

text: Lawyer Michael Avenatti claims his client has information on Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh

claimReview.title: Lawyer claims to have client with more information on Supreme Court nominee
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. Michael Avenatti, lawyer for porn actress Stormy Daniels, said Sunday he is representing a woman with information about high school-era parties attended by Kavanaugh. His confirmation hearings were thrown into turmoil when Christine Blasey Ford stepped forward and accused him of sexual assault when they were teenagers.

text: Photo of five teens standing up against a wall shows Sen. Bernie Sanders at Stonewall in 1969.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Bernie Sanders during the Stonewall uprising
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo does not show the Democratic presidential candidate.

text: Democratic vice presidential candidate Kamala Harris tells undocumented immigrants to vote in this election.

claimReview.title: Kamala Harris did not urge undocumented immigrants to vote
claimReview.textualRating: False. Posts online are misrepresenting Harris’ words.

text: Video shows former President Barack Obama trying to quiet members of a crowd shouting an anti-Joe Biden chant at a recent rally in Michigan.

claimReview.title: Video of Obama speech altered to feature anti-Biden chant
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. The footage, recorded while Obama spoke Saturday at a rally with Michigan Democrats in Detroit, was edited to feature the anti-Biden chant. The original clip shows the former president interacting with a heckler before the crowd begins chanting: “Obama! Obama!”

text: A photo from the

claimReview.title: Photo edited to make it appear Secret Service agents were smiling after attempt on Trump’s life
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was edited to make it seem as though the agents were smiling. In the original, taken by an Associated Press photographer, the same agents can be seen with neutral expressions.

text: Sea turtles can get high by eating jellyfish, similar to how marijuana intoxicates humans.

claimReview.title: Sea turtles aren’t getting stoned on jellyfish
claimReview.textualRating: False. Jellyfish do not contain properties that would result in sea turtles becoming high when indulging in the gelatinous marine animal, experts told The Associated Press. In addition, leatherbacks, one of seven sea turtle species, exist on a diet primarily of jellyfish and it would not be advantageous to their existence for their main food source to impair them.

text: The Pfizer vaccine contains potassium chloride, which is also used in executions by lethal injection.

claimReview.title: Posts online misrepresent Pfizer vaccine ingredients
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Potassium chloride is a salt that the body needs to function, but at large doses can be dangerous. The vaccine uses .01 milligrams of the substance.

text: In April 2016, before he was elected president, Donald Trump tweeted that President Barack Obama “should wait until he leaves office” to pick a Supreme Court justice. The tweet also said if Obama didn’t wait, “he should be fired.”

claimReview.title: Trump tweet about Obama’s Supreme Court pick is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. This tweet is fabricated. It does not appear in the Trump Twitter Archive, which tracks every tweet Trump sends, nor does it appear in an archive of deleted Trump tweets assembled by the nonprofit news outlet ProPublica. By April 2016, Obama had already nominated Judge Merrick Garland to the Supreme Court. The Republican-led Senate never voted on his choice.

text: The Keystone XL pipeline cancellation caused the current high gas prices.

claimReview.title: High gas prices falsely attributed to Keystone XL cancellation
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Keystone XL crude oil pipeline wasn’t yet operational when it was canceled in 2021, and wasn’t expected to be running until 2023. Rather, experts say gas prices are high due to other factors such as the global spike in the cost of crude oil and increased demand after pandemic lockdowns ended.

text: A new video shows a historic meeting between the leaders of North Korea and South Korea at their border, but the mainstream media isn’t covering it.

claimReview.title: News outlets didn’t ignore Korean leaders’ historic summit. A video of the meeting is 5 years old
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip is more than five years old and shows a moment that was captured by news outlets from across the world.

text: A FOIA response shows that according to the CDC, there is no known study showing masks help stop the spread of COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Studies support use of face masks in limiting spread of COVID-19
claimReview.textualRating: Missing Context. The FOIA response in question, from April, said the CDC was not aware of randomized controlled trials at the time assessing the use of cloth masks against COVID-19. The CDC instead linked to lab and observational studies supporting the use of face masks to help limit the spread of the virus.

text: A video shows a CNN reporter disguised herself as a Trump supporter and conspired with a Black Lives Matter activist to incite a riot at the Capitol on Jan. 6.

claimReview.title: Woman in video at Capitol with arrested activist is not with CNN
claimReview.textualRating: False. The woman in the video does not work for CNN. She is a filmmaker who said she was at the Capitol filming a documentary.

text: A photo shows President Barack Obama bowing to Iran Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei

claimReview.title: False image purports to show Obama bowing to Iran’s supreme leader
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo has been manipulated.

text: Drones were used to create a giant, illuminated skeleton near the Burj Khalifa for a Halloween display above pedestrians in an outdoor plaza.

claimReview.title: Sorry, the viral video of drones creating a skyscraper-sized skeleton over Dubai isn't real
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was fabricated. Experts said there are tell-tale signs that the “drone show” is not real, including that it moves faster than drone technology currently allows. In addition, the crowd below the skeleton shows no reaction to the mammoth display above them.

text: Photo shows thousands of protesters in Paris in January 2022.

claimReview.title: Photo shows large protests in France in 2020, not 2022
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was not taken this month. It was taken in January 2020 during nationwide strikes over the French government’s plans to raise the retirement age. It was published in the French newspaper Le Parisien at the time.

text: There is a “massive spike” in cancer rates, with certain types of cancers up 20 times the normal rate since the “Operation Warp Speed injections were first introduced.”

claimReview.title: Cancer rate not up 20 times from COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. U.S. medical professionals who study cancer rates say they have not seen a spike in cancer rates since the COVID-19 vaccines began. Clinical trials and data from the administration of shots around the world have not shown vaccinated individuals are more susceptible to developing cancer.

text: A video shows tanks deployed in the streets of China’s Henan province to protect banks from protesters whose accounts have been frozen.

claimReview.title: Video of tanks shows Chinese military exercise, not bank barricade
claimReview.textualRating: False. This video was captured in the eastern province of Shandong, China, more than 400 kilometers (248 miles) away from Henan province. It shows an annual military exercise unrelated to the bank protests, according to a front desk employee at a hotel visible in the clip.

text: A photo shows the Highland Park shooting suspect holding a Bible “in jail or rehab or a psychiatric center.”

claimReview.title: Photo altered to show July 4 shooting suspect in jail cell
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image of Robert Crimo ⁠— the man charged with murder after firing into a crowd at an Independence Day parade in suburban Chicago ⁠— has been manipulated. A photo of the suspect was digitally inserted into a stock photo of a prison cell that can be downloaded for free online.

text: Inflation was at 9% when President Joe Biden took the oath of office in January 2021.

claimReview.title: Biden cites erroneous inflation statistic to make his case about the economy
claimReview.textualRating: False. Inflation was at 1.4% in 2021 as Biden assumed the presidency, having risen from a low of 0.1% in May 2020, two months into the COVID-19 pandemic. It continued to increase steadily in the first 17 months of Biden’s presidency, reaching a peak of 9.1% in June 2022. Data released today shows that as of last month, it had fallen to 3.4%.

text: If you take away the states in question in the 2020 election, Trump won 25 states and Biden won 16. And Trump won 2496 counties to Biden’s 477, showing that Trump won 84% of America and Biden won 16%.

claimReview.title: Winning more counties doesn’t translate to an election win for Trump
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. There are no states in question at this point. States have certified their election results and electors have sent their votes to Congress showing President-elect Joe Biden won. This post also perpetuates the common misconception that winning a majority of counties indicates a nationwide election win. Land doesn’t vote — people do. Trump won many of the nation’s less populous counties, while Biden carried some of the most populous counties, securing more votes overall.

text: Ukrainian authorities warned the people of Transnistria in a text message that Ukraine was planning an attack on the region.

claimReview.title: Officials: Ukraine didn’t send text warnings in Transnistria
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Main Intelligence Directorate of the Ukrainian Defense Ministry and a Ukrainian member of parliament both said in separate statements that the country is not responsible for the message. The Ukrainian lawmaker also said Ukraine had no plans to carry out such an attack. A photo of the purported text message did not include a phone number, signature or other identifying details and showed no evidence it came from a verified source.

text: The 2020 election was declared illegal.

claimReview.title: State court rulings did not deem 2020 election ‘illegal’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The post making the claim highlights court rulings in three states, two of which — Wisconsin and Delaware —found certain voting procedures from the 2020 electionto be unconstitutional. However, they did not deem the procedures nor the election itself “illegal,” state officials and election experts told The Associated Press. Further, a similar ruling in Pennsylvania cited in the post was reversed, upholding a 2019 law allowing universal mail-in voting.

text: New data shows that inflation has dropped to half of what it was a year ago, marking a win for President Joe Biden.

claimReview.title: Inflation is worse than it was a year ago, despite online claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. While inflation has slowed in recent months, the latest government estimates show that prices are still higher in August 2022 than they were in August 2021.

text: Maps of recent wildfires across the Pacific Northwest show the fires stop abruptly at the Canadian border.

claimReview.title: Maps of wildfires ending at Canadian border only show US data
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. These maps only include American data. Canadian maps show there are fires burning in British Columbia. The western United States is experiencing a more severe fire season than western Canada this year for a variety of reasons, but scientists say climate change has contributed to more intense wildfires in both countries in recent years.

text: Photo shows large crowd in London protesting Tuesday against President Donald Trump’s state visit, with three large Trump baby blimps floating over demonstrators and large posters in the foreground.

claimReview.title: Photo of anti-Trump protest in London is altered and misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo, which was not taken during President Donald Trump’s recent visit to London, was manipulated to add more blimps and larger posters. It was taken July 13, 2018, during protests of a previous Trump visit.

text: A video shows a voter in New York City attempting to vote for the Republican gubernatorial candidate, Lee Zeldin, but encountering repeated issues with a machine, which is indicative of fraud.

claimReview.title: Video shows NYC voting error, not fraud
claimReview.textualRating: False. The voter was attempting to use an electronic ballot-marking device, which is used for accessibility purposes to complete a ballot, even though he had already filled in the ballot by hand. The machine is not used to cast and count ballots.

text: At least 98 people on the terrorist watchlist have crossed the border into the U.S. in fiscal year 2022.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent border encounters with people on terror watchlist
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While the U.S. Border Patrol has reported 98 encounters with people on the U.S. government’s terrorist watchlist along the southwest border, those individuals were stopped by border agents, and did not escape into the U.S.

text: Democratic Sen. Dianne Feinstein of California said, “all vets are mentally ill in some way and government should prevent them from owning firearms.”

claimReview.title: Quote calling all vets mentally ill attributed to Sen. Feinstein fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. Feinstein did not say that all veterans are mentally ill and that the government should keep them from owning firearms. The quote was fabricated.

text: Photo shows the Lincoln Memorial in Washington D.C., vandalized, the statue of Abraham Lincoln covered in graffiti and “BLACK + BROWN LIVES MATTER” written on the wall.

claimReview.title: Lincoln Memorial was not damaged during recent protests
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Lincoln statue was not vandalized during recent protests, according to a spokesman for the National Mall and Memorial Parks, although some graffiti was left at the steps leading up to the monument.

text: The European Union is now advising that pregnant women should not receive COVID-19 vaccines because of the risk of infertility and miscarriage.

claimReview.title: European Union didn’t advise against COVID vaccines for pregnant women
claimReview.textualRating: False. The European Medicines Agency continues to support COVID-19 immunizations for pregnant women, the agency confirmed. An announcement that concerns menstrual bleeding, which is being cited to spread the false claim, is from October 2022 and explicitly stated that the vaccines are still safe before and during pregnancy.

text: The FBI has confirmed that the “pizzagate” conspiracy theory is real.

claimReview.title: No, the FBI has not confirmed ‘pizzagate’ is real
claimReview.textualRating: False. The FBI says it has made no such announcement about the long-debunked rumor. No proof has even been produced to suggest “pizzagate” — a conspiracy theory that Democrats were harboring child sex slaves in a Washington, D.C., pizza parlor — is in any way credible. The claim comes from a website known to spread misinformation, which cited a statement from an FBI agent in an unrelated case.

text: Photo shows homeowner aiming a handgun at an armed protester in front her mansion in St. Louis.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show protester aiming gun at armed homeowners in St. Louis
claimReview.textualRating: False. The protester is not holding a gun, but a video camera and microphone.

text: Hooters is shutting down and rebranding.

claimReview.title: Hooters says it is not closing for a millennial-friendly rebrand
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for the restaurant chain told The Associated Press that this claim has “no validity” and that its concept “is here to stay.” The posts are misrepresenting a 2017 article that discussed some U.S. locations closing between 2012 and 2016, as well as changes the company made to its menu and decor more than a decade ago and a spin-off concept that opened in 2017.

text: President Joe Biden just announced that he is adding the U.S. as a signatory to the United Nations “Small Arms Treaty,” which would “establish an international gun control registry” in which other countries can “track the ‘end user’ of every rifle, shotgun, and handgun sold in the world.”

claimReview.title: Ad misleads on treaty regulating global arms trade
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no “U.N. Small Arms Treaty.” A separate U.N. agreement, the Arms Trade Treaty, regulates the international trade of a range of weapons. It does not track domestic gun sales. While former President Donald Trump symbolically withdrew from that treaty in 2019, the U.S. technically remains a signatory. The agreement was never ratified by the Senate, and Biden hasn't taken any further action on it.

text: The Danish toy manufacturer Lego sells a ‘Fall of Saigon’ kit, in which Lego bricks can be assembled to depict a helicopter evacuating people from a rooftop during the surrender of Saigon to North Vietnamese troops in 1975.

claimReview.title: Lego does not sell ‘Fall of Saigon’ kit
claimReview.textualRating: False. Lego sells no such product, a spokesperson for the Lego Group confirmed. Though no Lego kit exists to recreate this moment in world history, a group of Lego builders showed their own Lego creation depicting the fall of Saigon at a convention in Virginia in 2018.

text: The Israel Defense Forces confirmed it bombed a hospital in Gaza in a social media post written in Arabic.

claimReview.title: The Israeli military has not admitted it bombed a Gaza hospital, despite widespread claims online
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such post exists on the IDF’s social media pages and the military’s top Arabic-speaking spokesperson confirmed his office has issued no such statement.

text: Standard mouthwash has been proven to kill the coronavirus.

claimReview.title: No evidence mouthwash is effective at treating COVID-19
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While some studies show that mouthwash can inactivate SARS-CoV-2 in a lab setting, experts say there is no evidence that mouthwash is effective at treating or preventing the virus in the body.

text: Video shows police in Las Vegas putting a chokehold on a young black man selling water.

claimReview.title: Video shows Las Vegas police using a chokehold on water vendor in 2013
claimReview.textualRating: Mixture. A video circulating on social media does show police in Las Vegas using a chokehold on a man for selling water, but the incident occurred in 2013.

text: Video shows “white supremacists being chased out of DC by teens.”

claimReview.title: Video shows July clash between Patriot Front members and bystanders
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video circulating on social media on Tuesday shows members of Patriot Front, a group described by the Anti-Defamation League as white supremacist, in Philadelphia last July.

text: Public health data from Australia shows people vaccinated against COVID-19 are more likely to end up in a hospital ICU with the virus than those who are unvaccinated.

claimReview.title: Claims linking COVID vaccinations to ICU admissions are misleading
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While data does show higher admission rates among those with more vaccine doses, public health officials and virus experts say that doesn’t prove that receiving the shot itself makes you more likely to be hospitalized. Vaccinated people are expected to represent the bulk of ICU admissions because nearly every adult in Australia has received the immunization by now. Experts argue that old age and chronic conditions such as heart disease or diabetes are the primary factors determining who ends up in the ICU with COVID, and those people are more likely to have had more boosters to protect themselves.

text: Video of a person moving under a black body covering during a live German news segment shows a COVID-19 crisis actor.

claimReview.title: Video shows climate policy protest in Austria, not COVID-19 crisis actors
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows protesters taking part in a climate change demonstration in Austria.

text: After throwing a boomerang that hit his head upon its return, a man in Kentucky won a lawsuit he filed against himself for $300,000.

claimReview.title: Story of Kentucky man who sued himself is fiction
claimReview.textualRating: False. The story is fictional. It first appeared in a 1996 edition of Weekly World News, a publication known for publishing made-up claims. The name of the man who allegedly sued himself, Larry Rutman, of Owensboro, Kentucky, does not appear in county court records where the lawsuit would have been filed, a court official said.

text: Joe Biden and Kamala Harris forced troops to sleep on the floor of a parking garage, yet are spending millions on hotel rooms for immigrants who broke the law to get into the country. This would never have happened under Trump.

claimReview.title: Hotel rooms for migrant families spark misleading claims
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false.The Biden administration did authorize $86.9 million to provide hotel rooms and other services to families who cannot be expelled under a public health rule in effect at the border. But the post is wrong on the two other points. The Trump administration did use hotels to hold migrants at the border. And members of the National Guard who provided security at the U.S. Capitol in the days after the inauguration also had hotel rooms.

text: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau tweeted about the hashtag "#TrudeauMustGo" and said his government is “committed to regulating and censoring Canadian online content.”

claimReview.title: Tweet attributed to Canadian Prime Minister on trending hashtag is fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. Trudeau did not post such a tweet. There is no record of the post and a spokesperson from the prime minister’s office also confirmed to the Associated Press that the image of the tweet was fabricated.

text: Immigrants in the U.S. illegally on Tuesday stormed New York City Hall, demanding housing in luxury hotels rather than city shelters.

claimReview.title: No, immigrants did not storm New York City Hall in pursuit of luxury hotel rooms
claimReview.textualRating: False. Hundreds of Black immigrants assembled peacefully in City Hall Park during a hearing about racial inequities in New York’s shelter and immigrant support systems. They gathered there after it became clear that only around 100 people would be allowed into the hearing, The Associated Press reported. The New York Police Department told the AP that no arrests were made in relation to the gathering. Attendees said they came for a variety of reasons, such as to support City Council members at the hearing or to see if they could get information about jobs and housing.

text: A nurse who was one of the first health care workers to be vaccinated for COVID-19 in Chattanooga, Tennessee, on Thursday passed out on live TV after getting the vaccine and answering questions about how safe it is.

claimReview.title: Nurse who fainted after vaccine has condition that causes her to pass out
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Nurse manager Tiffany Dover did pass out after receiving her vaccine, but she explained to reporters afterward that she has a condition that sometimes causes her to faint when she feels pain. The United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says it has received reports of people fainting after nearly all vaccines, and scientists believe it is due to pain or anxiety associated with the vaccination process.

text: Los Angeles International Airport is adding urinals to its women’s restrooms.

claimReview.title: LAX airport hasn’t added urinals to women’s restrooms
claimReview.textualRating: False. One men’s restroom has been temporarily converted into a women’s restroom while that section of the airport undergoes construction, a spokesperson told The Associated Press.

text: A photo shows three Afghan women chained to one another, walking behind a man who holds the end of the chain.

claimReview.title: Supposed photo of Afghan women is fake; original, from Iraq, was altered to add chains
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was manipulated, and the chains were added. Photographer Murat Düzyol told The Associated Press he took the original photo in Erbil, Iraq, in February 2003.

text: Barack Obama said, “We simply cannot allow people to pour into the United States undetected, undocumented, unchecked, and circumventing the line of people who are waiting patiently, diligently, and lawfully to become immigrants in this country.”

claimReview.title: Obama’s 2005 remarks reflect strong stance on controlling immigration
claimReview.textualRating: True. The quote comes from a 2005 news conference where Obama, then a U.S. Senator from Illinois, spoke about immigration and those who employ immigrants.

text: Photo shows Donald Trump kissing the head of a young Ivanka Trump next to a Harley Davidson motorcycle and billionaire Jeffrey Epstein, who was arrested Saturday on child sex trafficking charges.

claimReview.title: Photo of Trump with daughter manipulated to include Jeffrey Epstein
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 1993 photograph of Trump and Ivanka next to a motorcycle has been manipulated to include Epstein, a 66-year-old hedge fund manager who was charged Monday with sexually abusing dozens of girls at his New York and Florida homes. He pleaded not guilty Monday to the sex trafficking charges. Epstein was registered as a sex offender after entering into a 2008 plea deal to avoid prosecution on federal charges of molesting teenage girls.

text: A 3D animation shows how the gravitational pull of the moon affects the Earth’s tides.

claimReview.title: Animation misrepresented as real portrayal of Earth's tides
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The animation was created by a Seattle-based artist who told The Associated Press that he intended for it to be an exaggerated visualization of the phenomenon, not a “fully accurate representation.” A more realistic depiction would also take into account details such as the Earth’s orbit around the moon and the relative distance between the two, as well as the effect of the sun on the planet’s tides.

text: Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene published a Twitter post reading, “How can the Titanic submersible run out of air if you breathe both in and out? I feel like this is more fake news BS.”

claimReview.title: Parody tweet about the Titanic submersible falsely attributed to Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene
claimReview.textualRating: False. Greene has never tweeted this statement and there is no evidence she ever made such a comment. A spokesperson for the congresswoman also confirmed to The Associated Press that the quote is fake. The fabricated quote stemmed from a parody account on Twitter that impersonates Greene.

text: A photo of a person holding a sign featuring pink, blue and white guns and the words “trans rights… or else” shows the shooter who killed six people at a private Christian school in Nashville, Tennessee, on Monday.

claimReview.title: Photo of Oklahoma protester misrepresented as Nashville shooter
claimReview.textualRating: False. The person who took this photograph confirmed it was captured in Oklahoma City before news of the Nashville shooting was widespread. It does not show the shooter.

text: A video shows North Korean leader Kim Jong Un saying in a speech that he blames President Joe Biden for the latest

claimReview.title: Video of Kim Jong Un doesn’t reference the Israel-Hamas war. The clip is old and mistranslated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from 2020 and the version currently circulating online features incorrect English captions. The footage actually shows Kim celebrating the 75th anniversary of the founding of the Korean Workers' Party; he doesn’t reference the conflict in the Middle East, Biden or Trump at any point.

text: On Feb. 18, President Joe Biden tweeted that comments on “minorities not being able to use the internet” were “taken out of context.”

claimReview.title: Biden didn’t tweet about ‘minorities not being able to use the internet’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet is fabricated.

text: A patent held by Moderna proves its COVID mRNA vaccine contains “programmable” nanotechnology that can interact with 5G communications technology.

claimReview.title: No, COVID vaccines don’t contain nanotechnology that can be programmed via 5G wireless networks
claimReview.textualRating: False. While it's true mRNA vaccines contain nanoparticles, the term simply refers to the size of the lipids, or fats, used as a coating in the immunization, according to experts. The term “programmable” is also used in the patent to refer to the ability to modify and adjust those nanoparticles depending on the need, they said. It does not mean they can be programmed to interact with wireless networks.

text: Florida, led by Gov. Ron DeSantis, has eliminated its tax on gas.

claimReview.title: Florida did not repeal its state gas tax
claimReview.textualRating: False. Florida’s longstanding state gas tax has not been repealed. In reality, Florida lawmakers approved a plan to temporarily suspend the gas tax for one month in October 2022.

text: Videos show an international advertising campaign asking Germany, China and Slovenia to support efforts to fight hunger in the U.S.

claimReview.title: Videos show US campaign to fight hunger, not international ads
claimReview.textualRating: False. The videos were part of a media campaign launched in 2015 by a U.S.-based nonprofit organization to raise awareness about food insecurity in America. They targeted a U.S. audience and did not air internationally, according to a spokesperson for the campaign. The videos took a satirical approach, designed to look like ads targeting people in the other countries, but they weren't distributed in those places.

text: A video shows a protester interrupting the funeral of Queen Elizabeth II on Monday to demand the British monarchy issue an apology for its role in the slave trade.

claimReview.title: Video does not show protester at queen’s funeral
claimReview.textualRating: False. This clip, taken from a 2007 BBC News broadcast, has been miscaptioned. It shows a protester interrupting a ceremony marking the 200th anniversary of the parliamentary action that ended the slave trade in the British Empire.

text: A digital screen at a Costco gas pump reads, “Don’t blame us. Blame Joe Biden.”

claimReview.title: Image of Costco gas pump screen was altered
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. This image has been manipulated to add the message. Visual clues reveal it isn’t genuine. Costco released a statement saying “manipulated images related to Costco gas stations” are “in no way affiliated with or approved by Costco.”

text: Anheuser-Busch is closing half of its U.S. breweries following backlash over a Bud Light marketing initiative.

claimReview.title: Satirical post falsely claims Anheuser-Busch closing half its US breweries
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim stems from a website that publishes satirical content. No such widespread brewery closure has been announced by Anheuser-Busch and a spokesperson for the company confirmed that the claim is false.

text: The Elizabeth Warren presidential campaign staged or digitally altered a text message exchange of a Bernie Sanders campaign volunteer calling Warren “Pocahontas.”

claimReview.title: Text message wasn’t fabricated by Warren campaign
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Sanders’ campaign confirmed to The Associated Press on Monday that the message was sent to a possible voter through Sanders’ messaging system by a rogue campaign volunteer.

text: People who received COVID-19 vaccines are now legally patented and no longer have human rights. This is because a 2013 U.S. Supreme Court ruling in the case of Association for Molecular Pathology v. Myriad Genetics, Inc. said that if a human genome is modified by mRNA vaccines then the genome can be patented.

claimReview.title: False claims tie patents to COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The posts misrepresent the court ruling. Humans cannot be patented, regardless of whether they are vaccinated or unvaccinated. COVID-19 vaccines do not alter people’s DNA.

text: A video shows riot police clashing with protesters in Iran amid demonstrations over the death of a 22-year-old woman detained by the country’s morality police last month.

claimReview.title: Video shows Iran Green Movement protest, not 2022 clash
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows an unrelated confrontation between protesters and security forces in Iran’s capital more than 10 years ago during Green Movement protests, which were sparked by allegations of vote rigging in the reelection of hard-line President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

text: A Pentagon official has confirmed that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and billionaire philanthropist George Soros are cousins.

claimReview.title: No truth to claims Zelenskyy, Soros are cousins
claimReview.textualRating: False. Zelenskyy and Soros are not related. An official from the U.S. Department of Defense and representatives for Soros and his foundation confirmed to The Associated Press the claim is false. The Pentagon said the allegation that one of its officials was the source of the information is also false.

text: Former President Barack Obama removed 500,000 pedophiles from a background check database.

claimReview.title: Bogus headline distorts old change to federal background check system
claimReview.textualRating: False. That claim originated on an unreliable website that distorted the facts about a change to the federal background check system used for firearms sales. The change concerned the definition of a “fugitive from justice” and was put into effect during the Trump administration. It did not focus on individuals accused of pedophilia.

text: A screenshot shows a Politico article about the war in Ukraine titled, “20 000 000 lives for the sake of freedom,” which reported that Ukraine will need to sacrifice millions of lives to win its war against Russia.

claimReview.title: Fabricated image tweeted by a Russian embassy shows a made-up Politico article about Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The screenshot of the article is fabricated and the news outlet has never published such a story, a spokesperson for Politico confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Images show the Soviet Victory banner projected by hackers onto the east side of Brandenburg Gate in Berlin on Tuesday night, prior to annual festivities celebrating the defeat of Nazi Germany in 1945.

claimReview.title: Hackers did not project the Soviet Victory banner on Berlin’s Brandenburg Gate this week
claimReview.textualRating: False. The images were fabricated. Berlin police and the company that manages the Brandenburg Gate confirmed to The Associated Press that the Soviet Victory banner did not appear this week on the monument, one of Germany’s most significant landmarks.

text: Newly leaked emails among Pfizer employees show that the company’s COVID-19 vaccine contains fetal cells.

claimReview.title: Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine does not contain fetal cells, contrary to online claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The emails cited say that the vaccine was tested, not produced, using a cell line that originated with a fetus in the 1970s. That information was already publicly available.

text: Photo shows President Joe Biden and his wife, Jill, celebrating with former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and her family during the week of Biden’s inauguration. No one in the photo is wearing a mask.

claimReview.title: Post uses 4-year-old photo to criticize Biden on masks
claimReview.textualRating: False. This photo is from 2016. Biden has been criticized for neglecting to wear a mask at times in the first days of his presidency after signing an executive order mandating masks on federal property, but this photo was taken long before the pandemic began.

text: Video shows fighter jets flying in unison over the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv as air sirens blare during Russia’s February 2022 attack on Ukraine.

claimReview.title: Video of Moscow flyover falsely described as fighter jets in Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The original video of jets flying overhead was captured during a rehearsal for a 2020 air show in Moscow. Audio of air sirens has been added to the footage.

text: The Federal Reserve is launching a new program that will give it the power to monitor, freeze and even seize private bank accounts based on a person’s behavior or political beliefs.

claimReview.title: FedNow won’t give agency power to seize bank accounts for political beliefs
claimReview.textualRating: False. Fed officials and banking experts say the new FedNow service does not give the agency additional surveillance and enforcement authorities. They say the service simply replaces the agency’s outdated system for banks to process checks and electronic payments.

text: Georgia nominee for governor Stacey Abrams wants to sandblast the face of Stone Mountain. (photo)

claimReview.title: Georgia candidate Abrams called for removal of Confederate memorial, did not say sandblast
claimReview.textualRating: Mixed. Abrams called for the removal of the Confederate memorial in Georgia in 2017, but never used the word sandblasting, according to a report by The Associated Press.

text: A video makes numerous claims about preventing the coronavirus, stating that hydroxychloroquine can prevent and cure COVID-19, and wearing masks and keeping people locked down have no value.

claimReview.title: Video falsely touts hydroxychloroquine as COVID-19 cure
claimReview.textualRating: The video contains a wide range of false information, much of which has been knocked down multiple times by doctors and researchers who study the coronavirus.

text: The suspected gunman who opened fire on Pakistan’s former Prime Minister Imran Khan was shot dead on Thursday.

claimReview.title: Gunman accused of wounding Pakistan's ex-PM wasn’t killed
claimReview.textualRating: False. The shooting suspect, identified as Faisal Butt, was arrested, not killed, according to authorities in Pakistan. Police released a video showing the person they identified as the suspect alive and in custody.

text: Kamala Harris was district attorney when 22-year-old Oscar Grant was fatally shot by police on an Oakland, California, train platform in Alameda County.

claimReview.title: Kamala Harris not Alameda County DA when white officer shot Black man on train platform
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Associated Press reported at the time of the 2009 shooting that the Alameda County district attorney was Tom Orloff, not Harris.

text: Target’s Pride collection features a bathing suit for kids that is labeled “tuck-friendly.”

claimReview.title: Target’s Pride collection features ‘tuck-friendly’ swimsuits for adults, not kids
claimReview.textualRating: False. The “tuck-friendly” swimsuits are only offered in adult sizes, according to a spokesperson for the company and Target’s website. Kids’ swimsuits in the collection do not feature this label.

text: Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, a Democrat, defunded the Michigan State Police and Department of Corrections with an executive order slashing tens of millions of dollars from the departments on July 22.

claimReview.title: Michigan governor isn’t defunding state police and prisons
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The state is not taking funds from the state police or prisons to spend on other public safety priorities. While Whitmer did issue an executive order that reduced funding for law enforcement and prisons, it went on to replace much of that money with funds from the federal Coronavirus Relief Fund, a move geared to help address a state budget shortfall. However, it is true that the move reduced overall funding for police and prisons somewhat.

text: An image of two Ukrainian men armed with mock rifles indicates that the Russian invasion of Ukraine is staged or fake and does not involve real combat.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent image of Ukrainians training with fake guns
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image shows Ukrainian citizens training for combat with fake rifles before the invasion began, not engaged in actual fighting. Russia has attacked several cities in Ukraine, including its capital, Kyiv, and Ukraine’s military and civilian soldiers have mobilized to fight off the invasion.

text: The chief health officer in New South Wales, Australia, posted a tweet on Jan. 15 that said

claimReview.title: Tweet attributed to Australian health officer is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet was fabricated. Dr. Kerry Chant, New South Wales’ chief health officer, never made any social media posts with this statement, a NSW Health spokesperson confirmed to The Associated Press. The health department also said the information in the fake post is incorrect.

text: //apnews.com/article/netherlands-wildlife-the-hague-a0809b0fb37e8923ac9184b86325d2e3">protest the government’s

claimReview.title: Old, misrepresented imagery shared amid Dutch farmer protests
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tank in the video wasn’t purchased by protesters. Instead, the video shows a vintage tank being returned to its owner’s warehouse after it was brought out to be featured at a museum.

text: A solar storm is heading toward Earth and could impact cell phone signals and cause blackouts.

claimReview.title: Solar storm is not heading toward Earth
claimReview.textualRating: False. No solar storm event is expected to take place this week. A solar flare occurred earlier this month.

text: Animal studies for COVID-19 vaccines were “stopped” because the animals were dying.

claimReview.title: False claim about COVID-19 vaccine animal studies circulates anew
claimReview.textualRating: False. None of the manufacturers of the COVID-19 vaccines used in the U.S. reported that preclinical testing was halted because of such animal safety concerns. The Texas state senator who made the assertion provided no evidence to support that claim.

text: A video shows Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis on Fox News’ “Hannity,” saying that

claimReview.title: Hannity video edited to add 2020 DeSantis footage
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. Video of a recent episode of “Hannity” has been edited to insert footage of DeSantis at a 2020 press conference, where he spoke about state authorities executing a search warrant on the home of a former Florida Department of Health data analyst.

text: Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg’s campaign funded the creation of the app that was used to tally votes during the Iowa Caucus.

claimReview.title: Pete Buttigieg campaign did not pay for Iowa Caucus app
claimReview.textualRating: False. Buttigieg’s campaign paid the company that created the app that failed during the Iowa Caucus for different technology services.

text: Police quickly released the manifesto written by the white gunman who

claimReview.title: Jacksonville shooter’s manifesto has not been released, despite claims online
claimReview.textualRating:
False. No documents written by the shooters in either case have been released. Jacksonville Sheriff T.K. Waters has publicly described materials left behind by the gunman as racist, but authorities have declined to say if they will be released. Nashville police, meanwhile, have said they intend to release the school shooter’s writings when they complete their investigation. But school officials and parents have mounted legal challenges to block the release.
List (Page)

text: The McCarran-Walter Act of 1952 bans Muslims from holding office in the United States.

claimReview.title: 1952 immigration law did not ban Muslims from holding public office
claimReview.textualRating: False. The McCarran-Walter Act did not ban specific religious groups from public office; it upheld a quota system limiting immigration by country.

text: President Joe Biden’s daughter-in-law Hallie Biden tweeted that former President Donald Trump won the 2020 election. She also tweeted that on election night, first lady Jill Biden phoned election workers to stop counting ballots and “rush in fake ballots.”

claimReview.title: Fabricated tweets originated from account impersonating Hallie Biden
claimReview.textualRating: False. The account that made these tweets is “fraudulent,” said the Beau Biden Foundation for the Protection of Children, whose board Hallie Biden chairs. President Joe Biden defeated Trump in the 2020 presidential election, earning 306 electoral votes to Trump’s 232, and there was no evidence of widespread fraud.

text: Chlorine dioxide will help get rid of the new virus from China.

claimReview.title: FDA warns against using chlorine dioxide against new virus
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration warns against ingesting the bleaching agent.

text: A tweet claiming “I just left the ER” and “we are officially back to getting crushed by COVID-19,” which has been copied and pasted by many Twitter users, is part of a fake bot campaign and doesn’t represent anyone’s real experience.

claimReview.title: ER doctor’s original tweet on delta variant is legitimate
claimReview.textualRating: False. The original tweet with this message comes from a licensed emergency medicine doctor and is genuine.

text: A recently unsealed indictment filed in the Western District of Pennsylvania shows that billionaire investor and philanthropist George Soros has been arrested for several serious crimes related to interference in the 2020 election.

claimReview.title: George Soros was not arrested for election interference
claimReview.textualRating: False. Court records show no such arrest. These bogus claims are based on a phony document, which appears to show charges against Soros, but is actually an indictment against six Russian hackers that was altered to insert Soros’ name.

text: Consuming pineapple juice, sesame seeds, parsley water with lemon or large amounts of aspirin are viable methods to end a pregnancy.

claimReview.title: Home ‘remedies’ don’t induce abortion as posts falsely claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. These home “remedies” don’t induce abortion, and taking large doses of aspirin can harm the gastrointestinal tract, according to doctors.

text: Photo shows a police officer wielding a baton while holding a masked person down at a COVID-19 protest.

claimReview.title: Photo shows police clash at encampment, not COVID-19 protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken while police were clearing a homeless encampment in Toronto, Canada, in July 2021. The image has nothing to do with demonstrations against COVID-19 measures.

text: “Shrek 5” will be released in movie theaters in 2020.

claimReview.title: ‘Shrek’ sequel not coming to theaters next year
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim is a hoax circulating online with a fake movie poster.

text: Data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that COVID-19 vaccines will not prevent any deaths among teenagers and lead to 100,000 to 200,000 severe side effects.

claimReview.title: Social media posts misrepresent CDC data on the effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines in teens
claimReview.textualRating:
Missing context. The CDC data from a recent presentation does not show the vaccine playing any significant role in preventing deaths among teens because they are statistically the least likely to die from the virus, experts explained. But the data shows the vaccine will prevent teens from developing serious symptoms that require hospitalization. Moreover, the “severe” side effects cited in the data refers to the degree of pain and discomfort associated with redness, tenderness, and swelling and other common adverse reactions to the shot.
List (Page)

text: President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris, who are both fully vaccinated, are wearing masks, proving that the vaccines are ineffective. They are also going against CDC guidance.

claimReview.title: Posts sharing photo of Biden and Harris mislead on mask guidance
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While studies have shown vaccines to be highly effective in battling COVID-19, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that fully vaccinated Americans wear masks in public spaces.

text: A Pfizer subsidiary called Zoetis has injected mRNA vaccines into 100 million wildlife animals in the U.S.

claimReview.title: Pharma company Zoetis isn't injecting wildlife with mRNA vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The company, which was a Pfizer subsidiary but is now independent, does not have any messenger RNA, or mRNA, vaccines for animals, a representative confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Nancy Pelosi snuck in $25 million worth of pay raises for Congress in the federal relief bill intended to help Americans amid the coronavirus pandemic.

claimReview.title: Federal rescue package doesn’t give Çongress pay raises
claimReview.textualRating: False. A proposal in the economic rescue package sets aside $25 million for the House of Representatives but “none of those funds will go to member salaries,” Evan Hollander, the communications director for the House Appropriations Committee confirmed to The Associated Press Thursday.

text: President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris sent tweets about staying cool and enjoying the long weekend for Memorial Day but did not acknowledge fallen soldiers or mourning families.

claimReview.title: Biden and Harris didn’t ignore military on Memorial Day weekend
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Posts criticizing Biden’s “stay cool” tweet and Harris’ “enjoy the long weekend” tweet fail to mention that both later tweeted about the meaning of Memorial Day. Biden also honored the nation’s sacrifices with a speech in Delaware on Sunday, and both the president and vice president attended a wreath-laying ceremony at Virginia’s Arlington National Cemetery on Monday.

text: Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Mark A. Milley has never served in combat or won a war.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Joint Chiefs Chairman Milley’s military record
claimReview.textualRating: False. Milley, the highest-ranking military officer in the U.S., has extensive combat experience, including tours in Afghanistan and Iraq. He is authorized to wear the Combat Infantryman Badge, meaning he has actively participated in ground combat.

text: California Gov. Gavin Newsom said the state will start collecting turkeys that weigh more than 10 pounds from grocers to limit people gathering in large groups for Thanksgiving Day.

claimReview.title: California not restricting sale of turkeys to curb large Thanksgiving feasts
claimReview.textualRating: False. The account that first shared the fabricated quote is a parody account.

text: A video shows a Boston Dynamics robot that has learned how to fight doing a backflip and throwing punches.

claimReview.title: Video does not show Boston Dynamics fighting robot
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video does not show a Boston Dynamics robot, the company told The Associated Press. It shows signs of being computer generated, according to a digital forensics expert.

text: A video shows Ukrainians attacking Russian tanks with American FGM-148 Javelin missiles.

claimReview.title: Video game footage misrepresented as missile attack in Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage is computer generated and shows a video game called Arma 3. The same clip was posted to a YouTube channel featuring Arma 3 gameplay on July 20, 2022.

text: The late John McAfee, the creator of McAfee antivirus software, owned a unit in the condo building that partially collapsed Thursday outside Miami and 31 terabytes of his files were located inside.

claimReview.title: John McAfee didn't own condo in collapsed Florida building
claimReview.textualRating: False. McAfee, who was found dead in his jail cell near Barcelona on Wednesday, didn’t own property at the beachfront Champlain Towers South Condo in Florida, according to an Associated Press review of public records. An image of a tweet in which McAfee claims to own such a property is fabricated.

text: A former World Health Organization vice president told a European Union summit that COVID-19 vaccines are killing more people than the virus itself.

claimReview.title: Video does not show former WHO vice president at EU summit
claimReview.textualRating: False. The speaker in the video was never a WHO vice president, he is a former vice chair of an immunization advisory group to the United Nations health agency. He was not speaking at an EU summit, but rather a public debate about vaccine mandates in Luxembourg’s Chamber of Deputies. Additionally, COVID-19 vaccines have not killed more people than the virus itself.

text: Photo shows a plane full of Afghan refugees being evacuated from the country this week, with not a single woman or child among them.

claimReview.title: Photo of Afghan men on plane is from 2018
claimReview.textualRating: False. This photo appeared online as early as 2018. It shows Afghan refugees being sent back to their country from Turkey, according to a story at the time from Turkey’s state-run news agency, the Anadolu Agency.

text: Video of a ferry swaying violently as it nears port was captured during Storm Eunice, a windstorm that is ripping through northern Europe this week.

claimReview.title: Video of ferry tilting in strong winds is from 2020
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was captured in Scotland in February 2020, when a different severe storm hit Europe.

text: A man pictured in a photo wearing a red baseball cap that says “Make Whites Great Again” is Derek Chauvin, a Minneapolis police officer videotaped kneeling on the neck of a black man during an arrest. The man, George Floyd, later died.

claimReview.title: Man wearing ‘Make Whites Great Again’ hat in photo is not Minneapolis police officer
claimReview.textualRating: False. The man in the photo is not Chauvin. Jonathan Lee Riches, a known internet troll, confirmed he is the man in the photo, but he says the image was altered and he was not wearing the hat.

text: A photo of a woman smiling and holding an American flag inside a government building shows Jan. 6 was not an “insurrection.”

claimReview.title: Photo shows woman at Kansas Statehouse rally, not Capitol riot
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While the photo was taken on Jan. 6, 2021, it shows a peaceful rally at the Kansas Statehouse in Topeka, not the violent attack on the U.S. Capitol that same day. The Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol reflects the legal and dictionary definitions of “insurrection,” as The Associated Press has explained.

text: Photo depicts Japanese police spraying looters and rioters with blue dye so they can be identified and arrested later.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Hong Kong police spraying protesters, not Japanese police spraying looters
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is miscaptioned and being shared out of context. A reverse-image search reveals it actually shows Hong Kong police spraying pro-democracy protesters in 2019 with water containing blue dye.

text: COVID-19 is “fading.” A second wave is unlikely because younger and healthy people don’t easily catch or spread it, so the virus “struggles to spread any more.”

claimReview.title: COVID-19 pandemic is not ‘fading’ in the United States
claimReview.textualRating: False. Data show the pandemic is spreading in the United States, not fading, and public health experts say both young and healthy people do catch and spread it.

text: Photo shows retired U.S. Navy Admiral Eric Olson among prisoners captured by Russian troops at the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol, Ukraine.

claimReview.title: US Navy admiral was not captured in Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. Reached by The Associated Press, Olson said he is not in Ukraine and was not captured by Russians. The State Department confirmed the claims are false.

text: Data from Public Health England on the coronavirus delta variant shows that patients are more than 745% more likely to die after two doses of the COVID-19 vaccine than unvaccinated patients.

claimReview.title: Post misrepresents data from Public Health England report on vaccine efficacy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.K.’s public health agency’s June 25 report on coronavirus variants did not provide evidence that people who are vaccinated are more likely to die. Rather, the report shows that COVID-19 vaccines are effective at preventing people from being hospitalized from the delta variant and no one under the age of 50 who was fully vaccinated died from that variant.

text: Photo of three men with soot-covered faces shows “Ukrainian firefighters.”

claimReview.title: Photo shows firefighters in Australia in 2019, not current day Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The picture is from 2019 and was taken in Australia.

text: A video of a caravan of cars filling the streets outside Trump Tower in New York City shows supporters of former U.S. President Donald Trump protesting his possible indictment in March 2023.

claimReview.title: Video of 2020 Trump Tower rally circulates ahead of possible indictment
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip was taken on Oct. 4, 2020, at a show of support for Trump after the former president tested positive for COVID-19.

text: A legal filing shows that Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis and Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, are involved with an Oklahoma diamond mining business.

claimReview.title: Filing doesn’t show DeSantis, Fauci are in diamond business
claimReview.textualRating: False. The document does not prove that either leader has a stake in the purported business named in the filing, Paragon Diamonds, LLC. Legal experts confirmed to The Associated Press that the filing appears to be bogus, meaning it was filed without any reasonable cause or is invalid. The company does not appear on Oklahoma’s business registry, and representatives for DeSantis and Fauci also confirmed neither are involved with such an entity.

text: A collage of nine images features the same Palestinian “crisis actor” pretending to be a wounded patient, a dead body and others in the ongoing

claimReview.title: A Thai child in a Halloween costume is being misrepresented to label Palestinians as 'crisis actors'
claimReview.textualRating: False. Not all the photos show the same man. The person who appears to be pretending to be a dead war victim is actually a Thai child wearing a Halloween costume last year. The wounded patient is actually a 16-year old Palestinian boy who lost a leg in the West Bank over the summer.

text: The U.S. Postal Service advises never to mail cash. Therefore, mailing a ballot is not secure.

claimReview.title: Postal Service does not warn to never mail cash
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The Postal Service advises customers it is preferable to send money using money order or check, but does not say to never mail cash. The agency offers insurance options for those who choose to do so.

text: A video of a purple cloud looming over a street as a car drives underneath shows East Palestine, Ohio, after a recent

claimReview.title: Oregon cloud video misrepresented as Ohio derailment aftermath
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed in Portland, Oregon. It appeared online as early as November 2022, long before the February 2023 derailment. Local weather experts said it looked like clouds they had seen in the state before and could be associated with a thunderstorm.

text: New Zealand intelligence officials published a booklet asking people to report friends or family members who are critical of coronavirus-related policy measures as terrorists.

claimReview.title: New Zealand isn’t asking people to report COVID-19 policy critics
claimReview.textualRating: False. The online version of the booklet, which is intended to educate the public about the behavioral indicators of possible violent extremism, makes no mention of coronavirus policy. The New Zealand Security Intelligence Service confirmed to The Associated Press that it is not asking people to report those who oppose COVID-19 public health measures.

text: NFL coaches unanimously voted to ban kneeling during the national anthem.

claimReview.title: Claim that NFL coaches banned ‘anthem kneeling’ is from a satire website
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are sharing a screenshot of a headline from a satire website. An NFL spokesperson confirmed no such vote has taken place.

text: Video shows antifa protesters blocking early morning traffic to prevent employed people from getting to work.

claimReview.title: Video shows environmental group protesting in San Francisco, not antifa
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a demonstration in San Francisco by the environmental group Extinction Rebellion. It is not related to the anti-fascist movement.

text: President Joe Biden signed an executive order in March 2022 that will introduce a cashless society, make paper money worthless, give the government new power to inhibit purchases and create a social credit score system like the

claimReview.title: Executive order does not usher in cashless society
claimReview.textualRating: False. The executive order doesn’t do any of these things. It urged the Federal Reserve to explore whether the central bank should create its own digital currency and directed the Treasury Department and other federal agencies to study the impact of cryptocurrency on financial stability and national security.
