text: Protesters looted Mall of America Wednesday night, with a video showing someone driving a car through North America’s largest shopping complex.

claimReview.title: Mall of America wasn’t attacked in Minneapolis protests
claimReview.textualRating: False. No incidents occurred Wednesday or Thursday at the Mall of America, spokeswoman Sarah Grap confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Image shows a detailed outline of a fetus’ foot pressing from inside a pregnant woman.

claimReview.title: Posts share fake image showing outline of foot on pregnant belly
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is manipulated. While it is possible to see the bulge of a fetus’ limbs as it moves in its mother late in pregnancy, doctors say details of a foot would not be visible because it would be inside the uterine wall.

text: A homeless woman says Donald Trump allowed her to live in his New York hotel for free, according to a video.

claimReview.title: Trump did not allow homeless woman to live in his hotel for free
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Trump Organization told The Associated Press in 2016 that there was “no validity” to the video.

text: Former President Donald Trump called Michael Cohen, his former lawyer and fixer, a “cereal liar” in a Truth Social post.

claimReview.title: Trump did not publish post calling Michael Cohen a ‘cereal liar’
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image purporting to show such a post was fabricated. It does not appear on Trump’s Truth Social profile and a Twitter user who first posted the image has since clarified it was a parody.

text: Hydroxychloroquine can be made at home by boiling citrus peels in water.

claimReview.title: Hydroxychloroquine cannot be made at home using citrus
claimReview.textualRating: False. Hydroxychloroquine, a drug used to treat malaria, lupus and rheumatoid arthritis, is synthetically manufactured and cannot be made at home using citrus.

text: The Department of Defense has canceled Fox News from Armed Forces Radio after the attacks against Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman.

claimReview.title: Fox News was not removed from Armed Forces Radio over Vindman testimony
claimReview.textualRating: False. Fox News is still running on the network despite claims online.

text: Polio has been found in New York City tap water.

claimReview.title: Post falsely claims NYC tap water contaminated with polio
claimReview.textualRating: False. The virus that causes polio has been detected in New York sewage samples, not tap water. Sewage (also known as wastewater) and tap water flow through separate systems, which eliminates the possibility of tap water being contaminated by sewage, city and state officials told The Associated Press.

text: When you click on the donate link on BlackLivesMatter.com, it takes you to the fundraising site ActBlue, and any unclaimed money is donated to Democratic candidates.

claimReview.title: Link on Black Lives Matter website does not donate directly to DNC
claimReview.textualRating: False. Posts online do not show ActBlue Charities, a nonprofit online fundraising platform, taking money from Black Lives Matter to donate to candidates. The link on the Black Lives Matter website takes you to the ActBlue fundraising platform where Black Lives Matter fundraises to “end state-sanctioned violence, liberate Black people, and end white supremacy forever,” according to the website.

text: A church in Boston was hosting a same-sex wedding ceremony when it was hit by lightning, sparking a fire that left no survivors.

claimReview.title: Massachusetts church was not holding same-sex wedding when it was hit by lightning and burned down
claimReview.textualRating: False. The First Congregational Church in the town of Spencer — which is in central Massachusetts, not the Boston area — did burn down on June 2 after it was hit by lightning. But there was no wedding being held at the time, nor any injuries reported, the local fire chief told The Associated Press.

text: After President Joe Biden offered to answer questions during a virtual meeting, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi was caught saying, “We don’t want him to talk.”

claimReview.title: Video of Pelosi supposedly caught on hot mic was manipulated
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video clip that appears to show the awkward moment was actually manipulated and was first shared online with a label identifying it as satire. The original video shows Pelosi did not respond when Biden said he would take additional questions.

text: Jewish man who lived through the Holocaust survives Pittsburgh synagogue shooting.

claimReview.title: Holocaust survivor lives through Pittsburgh synagogue shooting
claimReview.textualRating: True. An 80-year-old Holocaust survivor witnessed the synagogue shooting in Pittsburgh that left 11 people dead Saturday.

text: A court in Portugal ruled that only 152 people died of COVID-19 in the country, not 17,000.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Portugal’s COVID-19 death count
claimReview.textualRating: False. More than 19,000 COVID-19 related deaths have been reported in Portugal, not 152.

text: The World Economic Forum tweeted

claimReview.title: Tweet attributed to World Economic Forum is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet, which has spread online for months, is fabricated. There is no record that the World Economic Forum ever created such a post and the organization confirmed in a statement to The Associated Press that the tweet is fake.

text: A video shows a “top-secret military stealth plane” at Dyess Air Force Base in Texas that was visible on Google Maps, but was removed by the company.

claimReview.title: Invisible military aircraft not captured on Google Maps
claimReview.textualRating: False. Military and mapping experts agreed that the image, which appears to show the outline of an invisible aircraft, is not evidence of a “top-secret military stealth plane,” attributing it instead to a normal technical flaw in Google’s process for making high-resolution 3D maps. The image was created using this process, which involves stitching together multiple images, a company spokesperson told The Associated Press. The plane is visible on Google Maps when the program’s “globe view” feature is turned on, and on Google Earth.

text: A video shows Missouri Republican state Sens. Bill Eigel and Nick Schroer using a flamethrower for a “literal book burning.”

claimReview.title: Viral video shows flamethrower-wielding Missouri state senators burning empty boxes, not books
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows the two lawmakers burning empty cardboard boxes, not books, according to both politicians. It was taken on Friday at a fundraiser hosted by a local GOP group where flamethrowers were being auctioned. Eigel and Schroer were demonstrating the devices on the boxes, the event’s organizer confirmed.

text: A total of 19,888 fake driver’s licenses that were made in China and seized at the O’Hare International Airport were all registered to vote as Democrats.

claimReview.title: No evidence fake IDs seized at Chicago airport were ‘all registered to vote’
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. It’s true that U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers at Chicago’s busiest airport seized 19,888 fraudulent driver’s licenses, mostly from Hong Kong and China, between January and June 2020. However, there is no evidence to suggest they were linked to voter fraud.

text: Antifa is now carrying chainsaws, cutting down utility poles and starting more fires as wildfires rage across the Pacific Northwest.

claimReview.title: No evidence antifa carried chainsaws, cut poles amid fires
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence that antifa activists have wielded chainsaws, cut down utility poles or started fires currently spreading across Washington, Oregon and California. A captain from the Clackamas County sheriff’s office in Oregon alluded to these rumors during a public Zoom meeting on Thursday, but the office confirmed those reports were false during a Monday press conference.

text: It is a double standard that former President Donald Trump may be indicted over alleged hush money payments to a woman who accused him of sexual encounters, while former President Bill Clinton faced no criminal charges for paying a sexual harassment accuser $850,000.

claimReview.title: Faulty comparisons made between Trump, Clinton payments
claimReview.textualRating: False. Clinton and Trump’s cases have key differences, according to legal experts. Clinton’s $850,000 payment to Paula Jones in 1998 settled a civil lawsuit. The payment was public and legal, and the funds did not come from the government, nor did they amount to a campaign contribution. By comparison, the payment in Trump’s case was through a shell company and reimbursed by Trump, whose company logged the reimbursements as legal expenses in the final weeks of his 2016 presidential campaign.

text: Coronavirus has an HIV protein that proves it was genetically modified.

claimReview.title: Coronavirus is not genetically linked to HIV
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say the coronavirus has no HIV sequences in it’s genetic makeup.

text: The U.S. government “mysteriously lost” trillions of dollars the day before the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

claimReview.title: No, the US government didn’t ‘mysteriously lose’ trillions of dollars the day before 9/11
claimReview.textualRating: False. That long-circulating claim misrepresents remarks about $2.3 trillion in accounting entries that officials at the time said were insufficiently documented because of outdated technology. The entries were made during fiscal year 1999 and detailed in an early 2000 report.

text: The World Health Organization skipped two letters of the Greek alphabet, nu and xi, when naming omicron, a newly identified variant of the coronavirus.

claimReview.title: WHO skipped two Greek alphabet letters in naming coronavirus variant
claimReview.textualRating: True. The agency said it did so to stop people confusing nu with “new” and to avoid “causing offense” because Xi is a common last name.

text: Sexual assailants in the area around Texas A&M University are marking future targets’ homes by affixing zip ties to trash cans.

claimReview.title: Texas police quash rumors about zip ties on trash cans
claimReview.textualRating: False. Local police and a city spokesperson confirmed there’s no truth to this widely shared rumor. The zip ties are likely remnants from years-old practice by code enforcement officials to mark waste containers when there was a code violation, police said.

text: Photos show that “electromagnetic radiation” killed birds in Italy.

claimReview.title: Dozens of birds killed in a storm, not by radiation
claimReview.textualRating: False. The birds were killed during a storm in February in Rome. Strong winds knocked over a tree where the birds had nested.

text: Hunter Biden is

claimReview.title: Hunter Biden's gun charge isn’t the same as those previously faced by Lil Wayne, Kodak Black
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden has reached a plea deal that would allow him to avert the gun charge. He was also charged with illegal possession of a firearm by a drug addict while Lil Wayne was charged with illegal possession of a firearm by a convicted felon and Kodak Black was charged with making false statements to purchase multiple firearms.

text: New data on the numbers of births in the Australian state of New South Wales shows that coronavirus vaccines “destroyed” human fertility.

claimReview.title: Social media posts falsely suggest Australian birth-rate drop was caused by COVID vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The data being cited doesn’t mention vaccines at all and doesn’t draw any link to their impact on birth rates. Demographic experts in Australia say the drop in number of babies born in New South Wales hospitals, which is the focus of the chart, is explained by social and economic factors such as high housing prices, job insecurity and pandemic-era lockdowns. They also note that birth rates in Australia and other developed nations were already trending downwards years before COVID-19 vaccines were even created.

text: Greta Thunberg recently deleted a tweet she posted in 2018 in which she said that the world will end in 2023.

claimReview.title: Posts distort 2018 Greta Thunberg tweet on climate danger
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While Thunberg did delete a 2018 tweet about the urgency of addressing climate change, she did not say the world would end in 2023. Her tweet included a quote from an article that said an influential scientist warned climate change “will wipe out all humanity” unless fossil fuel use was ended “over the next five years.” Further complicating the issue, that article incorrectly summarized the scientist’s speech. He never made such comments.

text: A video taken on Baltimore’s Francis Scott Key Bridge shows a large explosion that occurred before the structure fell into the water below.

claimReview.title: Video from 2022 misrepresented as footage of Baltimore bridge collapse
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video circulated online in 2022, identified as showing security footage of an explosion that caused the partial collapse of the Kerch Bridge, which links the Crimean Peninsula with Russia. It was shared at the time on Russian Telegram channels and by major media outlets.

text: There are 3,141 counties in the U.S. Trump won 3,084. Clinton won 57.

claimReview.title: Hillary Clinton won more than 57 counties in 2016 presidential election
claimReview.textualRating: False. Trump won 2,626 counties while Clinton took 487 of them nationwide.

text: Three tennis players — Nikoloz Basilashvili, Nick Kyrgios and Dalila Jakupovic — were forced to drop out of this year’s Australian Open after they experienced chest issues.

claimReview.title: Players not forced to drop out of Australian Open due to chest pains
claimReview.textualRating: False. Neither Basilashvili nor Kyrgios has dropped out, and Jakupovic is not scheduled to participate in this year’s Australian Open.

text: Videos of black substances in the sky in California and Ohio show the release of genetically modified mosquitoes that are part of an initiative backed by Bill Gates.

claimReview.title: Genetically modified mosquitoes aren’t being released from aircraft around the US
claimReview.textualRating: False. Neither video shows mosquitos, modified or otherwise. One clip shows smoke from a show at Disneyland Park in Anaheim. The other is footage of an airplane releasing smoke as part of an air show in Cincinnati. The only company in the U.S. that releases genetically modified mosquitoes does so from boxes on the ground and its work here is not funded by Gates.

text: A video shows

claimReview.title: Altered clip of Manhattan DA Bragg spreads falsehoods amid Trump case
claimReview.textualRating: False. Bragg has made no such announcement. Fabricated audio was added to a 2022 video of the district attorney speaking at an event hosted by the New York University School of Law. A grand jury is still weighing an indictment against Trump, so Bragg’s office has not actually brought any criminal charges against the former president.

text: The Church of Sweden has declared 16-year-old environmental activist Greta Thunberg the successor to Jesus Christ.

claimReview.title: Church of Sweden did not name teen activist a successor to Jesus
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Church of Sweden made no such announcement. But in 2018, one of its parishes did, tweeting in Swedish: “Announcement! Jesus of Nazareth has now assigned one of his successors, namely Greta Thunberg.”

text: Texas court forces dad to allow son to undergo chemical castration.

claimReview.title: Court did not force dad to allow chemical castration of son
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such decision has been rendered by a Texas court. A judge ruled on Thursday that two Texas parents, who are in a legal battle over the care of their child, must jointly agree to medical treatment for the 7 year old.

text: Jane Fonda used sign language during her best actress speech in 1979 because the Oscars wouldn't offer closed captions. The Oscars didn’t have closed captioning until 2021.

claimReview.title: Closed captioning not new to the Academy Awards
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. It’s true that Jane Fonda used sign language when accepting the 1979 best actress award for her role in “Coming Home,” however, the Academy Awards have had closed captioning for the program since 1982.

text: Washington has been “completely empty” with none of its federal buildings operational since President Joe Biden was inaugurated.

claimReview.title: Article falsely claims Washington has been shut down ‘all year’
claimReview.textualRating: False. This conspiracy theory has no basis in fact. The nation’s capital city has been occupied and federal buildings have been in use in 2021 and 2022.

text: The Obama family’s personal chef had been writing a tell-all book when he was found dead with injuries to his head in less than 4 feet of water. The 911 call also didn’t go out until his body washed up on shore and Obama’s “personal coroner” conducted the autopsy.

claimReview.title: Obama's doctor didn't conduct his late chef's autopsy and the 911 call wasn't delayed, police say
claimReview.textualRating: False. Massachusetts State Police reiterated Monday that Tafari Campbell did not sustain any head wounds and was found in nearly 8 feet of water, not in less than 4 feet of water, when he drowned last Sunday. In addition, the 911 call came in shortly after he fell off his paddleboard, not hours later, and Obama’s physician didn’t do the autopsy, the state medical examiner’s office did, police said. Meanwhile, no evidence has been presented to support the claim that the former White House sous chef was working on a book about the Obamas. The notion originated from a social media account known to spread misinformation.

text: The Pakistani news outlet Dawn published a headline blaming recent record-breaking flooding on people not reading the Quran, rather than climate change.

claimReview.title: Fake headline links Pakistan flooding to Quran
claimReview.textualRating: False. Dawn did not publish the headline. An image was fabricated to make it appear the outlet ran such a story. The outlet confirmed in an article Tuesday that a screenshot purporting to show the headline was digitally manipulated.

text: COVID-19 vaccines are called Luciferase, have the patent number 060606 and come from a digital program called Inferno.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines are not called ‘Luciferase’
claimReview.textualRating: False. COVID-19 vaccines are not named Luciferase, nor do they contain an enzyme known as luciferase. Instead, that light-producing enzyme has been used in some COVID-19 research. The patent application and digital program mentioned in viral posts are not related to COVID-19 vaccines.

text: There was no flight movement over China as more than 9,000 flights were canceled across the country in a single day last week.

claimReview.title: Analysts: China flight cancellations follow normal pattern
claimReview.textualRating: False. While flight tracking estimates show that thousands of flights were canceled last Wednesday, this remains consistent with the high cancellation rates the country has experienced amid the COVID-19 pandemic, according to air traffic analysts. Thousands of flights still proceeded as scheduled, and multiple experts told The Associated Press that last week’s air patterns in China were not unusual.

text: The media is livestreaming the trial of libel allegations by Johnny Depp against Amber Heard, but didn’t do so for the criminal trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.

claimReview.title: Coverage of Depp’s libel suit misleadingly compared to Maxwell trial
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Maxwell’s trial was held in a federal court, which do not allow cameras. The trial of Depp’s lawsuit is being held in a Virginia court.

text: Cattle in the U.S. for years have been vaccinated for the coronavirus, yet the media says this will kill you.

claimReview.title: Cow coronavirus vaccine not related to COVID-19, not for humans
claimReview.textualRating: False. Cows are vaccinated for a coronavirus unrelated to the current coronavirus pandemic known as COVID-19.

text: Election results in Kentucky show rapper and music producer Kanye West ahead of President Donald Trump and Democratic nominee Joe Biden in the presidential race.

claimReview.title: Kanye West tweet showed mock election data, not results
claimReview.textualRating: False. The numbers shared by West on Twitter, purportedly from the Kentucky election, were not real results. They were mock election data used by The Associated Press as part of routine testing ahead of elections.

text: An Indiana school district circulated an internal email regarding a policy that would allow students who identify as animals — or “otherkin” — to use litter boxes, walk on all fours and be leashed, among other accommodations.

claimReview.title: Post about Indiana school’s ‘otherkin’ policy is satirical
claimReview.textualRating: False. The fabricated message originated on a satire page and is not a real communication from Kokomo School Corporation in Indiana. The principal at Kokomo High School confirmed the email was never sent by the school or the district, nor does it have such a policy.

text: An aerial picture of migrants crossing a bridge, some holding flags, shows an “invasion” of the U.S. that was “authorized” by President Joe Biden.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Central American migrants in 2018, not 2023 ‘invasion’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image in question, which shows Central American migrants traveling in Mexico toward the U.S., was taken in 2018.

text: A news clip shows compounds in the U.S. where Hamas was “training hidden in plain sight.”

claimReview.title: Compounds shown in 2019 news clip not linked to Hamas, despite online claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is a 2019 news report by Sinclair Broadcast Group about a man who had been arrested in 2018 on terrorism charges in New Mexico. Federal prosecutors there confirmed to The Associated Press that there was no indication he or other family members involved in the case were tied to Hamas.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends men shave their beards to protect against coronavirus.

claimReview.title: CDC not calling for men to shave their beards to protect against virus
claimReview.textualRating: Partially false. An infographic created by the CDC and titled “facial hairstyles and filtering facepiece respirators” is being misrepresented. The CDC did not release this graphic in relation to preventing the new coronavirus, nor did the agency recommend that people shave off their facial hair to protect against the virus.

text: Elon Musk’s Twitter account was suspended amid layoffs at the company on Friday.

claimReview.title: Elon Musk’s Twitter account was not suspended after layoffs
claimReview.textualRating: False. Musk’s account, @elonmusk, is still active. A separate account using an uppercase “i” instead of a lowercase “l” — resulting in a handle that appears identical in certain fonts — has been suspended. The fake account has been shared as authentic in the past.

text: Photo shows farmers blocking a freeway with tractors in the Netherlands on Sunday to show solidarity with truckers in Canada protesting COVID-19 vaccine mandates.

claimReview.title: Photo doesn't show Dutch farmers supporting truck protest in Canada
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo, taken in 2019, shows farmers and construction workers in the Netherlands protesting government measures to curb greenhouse gas emissions.

text: The health care worker who gave a COVID-19 vaccine booster shot to British Prime Minister Boris Johnson did not remove a cap on the syringe.

claimReview.title: British PM’s booster syringe was not ‘capped’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Video footage and images show the syringe was uncapped and the needle was injected into Johnson’s arm.

text: Video of a building collapsing in on itself near a busy road shows Turkey following Monday’s earthquake.

claimReview.title: Video of building demolition in Saudi Arabia misrepresented as Turkey earthquake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a building demolition in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, in January 2023.

text: A news headline says that screaming the F-word toward President Joe Biden might be illegal.

claimReview.title: Fake headline falsely suggests cursing the president is illegal
claimReview.textualRating: False. This is not a genuine news headline, and legal experts agree that the First Amendment protects the right to use expletives in reference to the president or anyone else.

text: Officials in East Palestine, Ohio, gave digital IDs to residents to track their long-term health problems as part of an emergency response pilot program ahead of the Feb. 3

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent East Palestine medical device program
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The East Palestine Fire Department is offering to distribute devices that would allow medical providers to quickly access patients’ medical information, such as medication allergies, through a QR code. The devices would not track people’s vitals and have not yet been distributed, the chief of the East Palestine Fire Department told The Associated Press. The department is still waiting to receive the devices.

text: More than a week before Election Day, a TV news outlet in Arizona published election results showing Democrat gubernatorial candidate Katie Hobbs beating Republican Kari Lake, which is evidence of election tampering.

claimReview.title: Arizona station displayed test election data, not real results
claimReview.textualRating: False. Fox 10 Phoenix accidentally broadcast a small graphic showing mock results as part of a test in preparation for Election Day, the outlet confirmed in a statement. The randomly generated numbers were not real election results, nor are they an indication of fraud. News outlets do not have direct access to ballots. Election results are reported through information that comes from local election officials.

text: Election officials in Arizona’s Maricopa County displayed a map of Republican voters in the county at its central tabulation facility in Phoenix, but did not have a comparable Democrat voter map.

claimReview.title: Maricopa County displays voter maps for both parties, contrary to claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. Heat maps showing past Republican and Democrat voter turnout are both displayed in the Maricopa County Elections Department’s central tabulation facility, according to a spokesperson for the department and a photograph she provided to The Associated Press.

text: Alberta's top doctor said that if you're feeling unwell and you don't have a COVID-19 test, you're still counted as a positive case.

claimReview.title: Canadian health official’s remarks about COVID-19 misrepresented online
claimReview.textualRating: False. COVID-19 cases in Alberta, Canada, are confirmed through testing.

text: A video shows a man in Turkey rescuing two puppies trapped under rubble after an earthquake struck the country on Monday.

claimReview.title: Video of puppies being rescued is from India, not Turkey
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was shot in India and was originally posted on social media in 2019 by an animal hospital and rescue center that operates in Udaipur, Rajasthan.

text: Photo shows CIA Director Gina Haspel, a Trump appointee, giving a thumbs up next to the body of a tortured and electrocuted Iraqi man in Abu Ghraib prison.

claimReview.title: Photo caption wrongly identifies woman in photo as CIA director
claimReview.textualRating: False. Haspel is not the woman in the photograph. It is a U.S. Army military police reservist who worked at the notorious prison in Iraq.

text: Photo purports to show Somali gang members beating a man on the street in Minnesota.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Somali gang in Minnesota
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was falsely captioned on social media to say “Somali gangs in Minnesota grow more dangerous”. It was taken in Birmingham, England, in 2009.

text: Photo shows a U.S. soldier “stealing” humanitarian aid from China

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent photo of US soldier loading relief supplies for Turkey
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo, first posted by the U.S. Army, shows a soldier in Adana, Turkey, supporting disaster relief efforts following the recent earthquake in the country. The soldier was carrying a tent that came from a pile of relief items donated by the international community to Turkey, a Department of Defense spokesman confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: COVID-19 vaccines don’t provide protection against the new omicron variant of the coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Claims mislead about COVID-19 vaccines’ effectiveness against omicron
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While it’s true that people who are vaccinated can still get infected with omicron, early research has shown that the Pfizer and Moderna mRNA COVID-19 vaccines are effective at preventing severe disease, hospitalization and death stemming from the new variant.

text: Video shows people throwing objects at a bus carrying Brazil’s national soccer team, after the team returned from the World Cup in Qatar.

claimReview.title: 2018 video shows people throwing eggs at commuter bus in Brazil
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed in March 2018, and does not show the soccer team’s bus. It shows demonstrators against Brazil’s leftist President-elect Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, police confirmed to The Associated Press. The vehicle, however, was just a commuter bus, and not actually part of da Silva’s campaign caravan.

text: California’s Proposition 1 will change the state’s constitution to allow taxpayer-funded abortions up to the moment of birth, regardless of the health of the mother.

claimReview.title: California Prop 1 wouldn’t legalize abortion until ‘moment of birth’
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Existing state-subsidized health programs cover abortion services for qualifying patients and these would not be modified by Proposition 1. The amendment does not mention prohibiting or allowing abortions late in pregnancy. But state law already restricts third-trimester abortions, and California legal experts told The Associated Press they don’t expect courts would interpret the amendment as expressly permitting them.

text: Video shows that the CEO of BioNTech, Dr. Ugur Sahin, will not take the COVID-19 vaccine that his firm developed with Pfizer.

claimReview.title: Posts cite old interview to falsely claim BioNTech CEO isn’t vaccinated
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media posts are misrepresenting an interview that Sahin gave in December 2020. He received the vaccine the next month, a company spokesperson confirmed.

text: Israel said that the

claimReview.title: Fake Mossad account spreads misinformation about airstrike that killed aid workers in Gaza
claimReview.textualRating: False. No Israeli officials have publicly made such a statement. An X account impersonating the Israeli intelligence agency Mossad wrote soon after news of the incident broke that it appeared to have been caused “by a side bomb planted by Hamas.” The Israeli military said in a statement sent to The Associated Press on Tuesday that the deaths “occurred as a result of an IDF strike.” Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu acknowledged that the country’s forces had carried out an “unintended strike” in Gaza.

text: Flavor enhancers made from aborted fetal tissue are being added to food products without consumers’ knowledge.

claimReview.title: No, food products don’t contain fetal tissue
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biotechnology companies have frequently used fetal cell lines in their research and testing, but flavor enhancers used in food products do not contain any tissue from aborted fetuses. The Food and Drug Administration said in a statement that it would not approve any food containing fetal tissue for human consumption and is not aware of this ever happening.

text: Freedom of Information Act requests show a dozen phone calls between Ray Epps’ cell phone and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office a week before the Capitol insurrection on Jan. 6, 2021.

claimReview.title: Post spreads baseless claim about Jan. 6 conversations
claimReview.textualRating: False. Such records would not be obtainable through FOIA requests, because Congress is exempt from the law, legal experts say. A spokesperson for Pelosi also confirmed that the claim is false.

text: Photo shows President Donald Trump posing for a photo with E. Jean Carroll, a New York-based advice columnist who has accused the president of sexually assaulting her in the mid-1990s.

claimReview.title: Photo misidentifies Trump accuser
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows Trump with another woman, Jill Harth, who has also accused the president of sexual assault.

text: Video shows health care workers celebrating a COVID-19 vaccine developed in France

claimReview.title: Video captures people in Spain honoring their health care workers
claimReview.textualRating: False. Researchers in France have not created a vaccine for COVID-19. The video shows police officers and citizens celebrating health care workers in March, and was filmed at the Clinical and Provincial Hospital of Barcelona in Spain.

text: Shahzada Dawood, one of the passengers who

claimReview.title: The World Economic Forum’s vice chairman was not on the Titan submersible
claimReview.textualRating: False. A page on the World Economic Forum’s website listed Dawood as “Vice-Chairman, Engro Corporation, Dawood Hercules,” referring to his family’s firms, not the forum itself. Dawood was a member of the World Economic Forum’s Family Business Community, but wasn’t an employee, a spokesperson said.

text: A photo shows the Russian warship Moskva on fire in the Black Sea.

claimReview.title: Photo shows 2019 ship fire, not Russian Moskva ablaze
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image has been manipulated. The original shows a 2019 fire aboard a Tanzanian commercial vessel in the Kerch Strait, near the Black Sea. The edited version was cropped, flipped horizontally and colored green.

text: Voting locations in Maricopa County, Arizona closed early without notice on Election Day.

claimReview.title: Voting locations in Arizona’s Maricopa County didn’t close early unexpectedly, despite claims online
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Seven drop-box locations out of the county’s 45 election sites closed earlier than 7 p.m. on Nov. 7. The closings were all scheduled and posted on the county’s election website, although some of its public messaging suggested all boxes would be open until 7 p.m.

text: Arkansas is switching to election ballots that are marked by hand rather than by machine.

claimReview.title: Arkansas isn’t ditching voting machines for paper ballots, despite claims online
claimReview.textualRating:
False. There’s been no statewide change in how voters cast ballots, elections officials and voter rights groups in Arkansas say.. Residents will still continue to use voting machines in nearly every county in the state. One rural county recently approved a plan to start using paper ballots that voters must mark by hand, and a final vote on that decision is expected later this month.
List (Page)

text: A May 3 tweet from the World Economic Forum asks, “Why is there such a stigma surrounding harvesting children’s blood?”

claimReview.title: World Economic Forum didn’t tweet about harvesting children’s blood
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet is fabricated, the World Economic Forum confirmed to The Associated Press. It doesn’t appear in a Twitter search, nor in an online database that archived the forum’s account over time.

text: Farmers and ranchers are required to inject livestock with mRNA vaccines.

claimReview.title: No, farmers aren’t required to vaccinate livestock with mRNA vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no mandate in the U.S. that livestock receive certain vaccines and there are no COVID-19 mRNA vaccines licensed for animals, as some online have suggested.

text: Photo shows a helicopter spraying a frozen wind turbine with chemicals in Texas.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show a helicopter de-icing a wind turbine in Texas
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is from 2015 and shows a helicopter de-icing a frozen wind turbine in Sweden with hot water, not chemicals.

text: Lab-grown meat is made out of cancerous animal cells.

claimReview.title: Animal cells used to create lab-grown meat are not cancerous, experts say
claimReview.textualRating: False. Meat grown in labs is made using cells taken from animals, but those cells are not cancerous and there are many safeguards in place to ensure that the end product is safe to consume, experts told The Associated Press. The false claim stems from the fact that, like cancer cells, those used in lab-grown meat often go through a process that allows them to divide indefinitely. But cells must exhibit other traits to be considered cancerous.

text: Video shows Louisiana law enforcement officers giving a message to antifa.

claimReview.title: Video does not show a sheriff’s captain sending a message to antifa
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from 2016 and shows a captain with a sheriff’s office in Louisiana sending a message to gang members.

text: The COVID-19 vaccines “are a gene therapy, NOT a vaccine.”

claimReview.title: No, COVID-19 vaccines aren’t gene therapy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The COVID-19 vaccines do not change a person’s genes, as gene therapy does, experts say. The shots from Pfizer and Moderna use messenger RNA, or mRNA, to instruct the body to create a protein from the coronavirus. The Johnson & Johnson vaccine, meanwhile, uses a modified adenovirus to trigger an immune response.

text: An online job ad shows that all new employees that the IRS intends to hire after a funding boost in the Inflation Reduction Act will be required to carry a firearm and use deadly force if necessary.

claimReview.title: IRS special agent job ad misrepresented online
claimReview.textualRating: False. A legitimate job ad for special agents within the small law enforcement division of the IRS that works on criminal investigations is being misrepresented online, officials and experts say. The job description does not apply to most potential new employees that the IRS will hire in the coming years. The vast majority of IRS workers are not armed.

text: Residents in the Queens Village section of New York City are receiving ballots that have been marked for Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden with instructions to just send them back to the Board of Elections.

claimReview.title: No evidence Queens residents received pre-marked ballots
claimReview.textualRating: False. Officials with the New York City Board of Elections said there is no evidence that residents in Queens are receiving ballots pre-marked for Democratic candidates.

text: A NASA study found that six to eight snake plants in a room with no airflow is enough for human survival. The agency therefore recommends 15 to 18 plants for an 1,800-square-foot home.

claimReview.title: NASA didn’t publish study on snake plants providing life-saving oxygen
claimReview.textualRating: False. The agency did not reach those conclusions or offer such recommendations, a spokesperson confirmed. The claim may be a distortion of a1989 NASA report focused on whether indoor plants can help clean the air, not sustain human life. An expert in plant biochemistry further said six to eight snake plants, as claimed, wouldn’t produce the level of oxygen required by a human in a day.

text: Photo shows all the exterior and interior lights out at the White House on Sunday night, as President Donald Trump hid in a bunker.

claimReview.title: Old image edited to show White House black out
claimReview.textualRating: False. The original photo was posted to a stock image site in 2015, before Trump took office.

text: Social media posts circulating on Facebook say the supermarket chain Aldi will close at 4 p.m. on Christmas Eve to give away leftover food to the homeless.

claimReview.title: Aldi not giving away food to the homeless after closing on Christmas Eve
claimReview.textualRating: False. Aldi stores in the U.S. and Britain will not hand out free food to the homeless on Christmas Eve.

text: Leaked text messages obtained by CNN showed that Virginia Thomas and Mark Meadows corresponded about Venmo payments and “coup buses” amid the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection at the U.S. Capitol.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent satirical story on Jan. 6 text exchanges
claimReview.textualRating: False. While CNN has published real texts between the pair, this exchange circulating online was invented for a satirical piece published by The New Yorker, and is being misrepresented as a genuine communication between Thomas, the wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, and Meadows, former White House chief of staff. A CNN spokesperson confirmed the news outlet didn’t “leak” messages detailing this exact exchange, and no such text messages have been publicly released by the U.S. House committee investigating Jan. 6.

text: A scientific study proved genetically modified corn isn’t safe to eat because it caused cancer in rats.

claimReview.title: Posts share retracted study to question safety of GM corn
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 2012 study cited by some social media users was retracted by the academic journal that originally published it, after the publication determined the research was inconclusive and unreliable. Food safety agencies in the U.S. and European Union have found genetically modified foods are just as safe as their non-modified counterparts, and experts told The Associated Press there is no credible evidence that genetically engineered corn is unsafe.

text: An image of people blocking traffic while praying on a highway was taken in India.

claimReview.title: Photo shows people praying in Bangladesh, not India
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken in Bangladesh, not India. Similar images of the same scene online show it was captured in 2020 during the Biswa Ijtema, an annual Muslim gathering in the town of Tongi.

text: An Iran lobbying group bribed Democrats to vote for the 2015 nuclear deal.

claimReview.title: Democrats took donations, not bribes, from US lobbying group
claimReview.textualRating: False. The politicians took donations from an Iranian American political action committee, a federally registered U.S. organization that cannot legally accept money foreign governments or companies.

text: Image shows former President Donald Trump’s Christmas card.

claimReview.title: 'Christmas card' attributed to Trump is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The black and white image has been edited. The photo of Trump was taken at a state banquet at Buckingham Palace in 2019, but was altered in a crass way and placed next to a Christmas message.

text: A video shows young students walking on a bridge of benches in a flooded Florida school that was open during Hurricane Ian.

claimReview.title: Video shows Houston school in 2019, not Florida during hurricane
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage is being misrepresented. The video clip was originally recorded at Durham Elementary School in Houston, Texas, in September 2019, during flooding caused by Tropical Storm Imelda, local officials confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Video shows Iran sending rockets to the U.S. Ain al-Asad airbase in Iraq early Wednesday morning.

claimReview.title: Video does not show Iran launching missiles at US bases in Iraq
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video clip has been circulating online since at least 2014.

text: U.S. Capitol flags are flying at half-staff in honor of President Joe Biden, who has died.

claimReview.title: Flags at the US Capitol are lowered for Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, not Biden
claimReview.textualRating: False. The flags are at half-staff in honor of U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who died Friday night, according to the office of House Speaker Mike Johnson. Biden is not dead. He was seen arriving at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware Tuesday afternoon for a flight back to Washington, according to a White House pool report. Multiple AP photos show Biden at the base. The president is expected to address the nation from the Oval Office Wednesday evening.

text: Bill Gates doesn't vaccinate his own kids, but a photo shows the children he harmed by administering vaccines in Africa.

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on Bill Gates’ work on vaccines in Africa
claimReview.textualRating: False. Gates’ children have been vaccinated, according to his former wife, Melinda French Gates. The photo, taken in 1998 for the World Health Organization, shows children with polio in Sierra Leone.

text: The number of votes for French far-right presidential candidate Marine Le Pen decreased from 14.4 million during a live count to 13.3 million when her defeat was declared.

claimReview.title: Clip shows French TV error, not election fraud
claimReview.textualRating: False. The TV channel France 2 displayed inaccurate figures at one point during an on-air live count due to a computing error, according to a statement from the broadcaster. The software that the channel used to display data from France’s Interior Ministry counted certain municipalities’ votes twice for both candidates, France 2 said. There is no record of the Interior Ministry officially reporting the inaccurate figures.

text: Video shows President Joe Biden speaking “total nonsense” saying, “My butt’s been wiped,” in response to a reporter’s question on immigration when returning to the White House.

claimReview.title: Posts attribute false quote to Biden during reporter exchange
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden, who had been unable to hear a reporter's question, jokingly responded to a reporter shouting questions as he left the presidential helicopter, “What must be what?”

text: Taking fish amoxicillin used in aquariums is the same as using amoxicillin prescribed by a doctor, just less expensive and does not require a prescription.

claimReview.title: Fish amoxicillin: not what the doctor ordered
claimReview.textualRating: False. Antibiotics available in pet stores have not been approved by the Federal Drug Administration and there is no evidence to say whether they are safe or effective for humans.

text: President Joe Biden placed the Medal of Honor improperly around a Vietnam War veteran’s neck, positioning the medal on the man’s back instead of his chest.

claimReview.title: Biden did not put Medal of Honor on veteran backward
claimReview.textualRating: False. Associated Press images and video show that Biden placed the medal correctly on the veteran’s chest.

text: Politicians receive full-pay retirement benefits even after serving only one term.

claimReview.title: Members of Congress do not receive their full pay upon retirement
claimReview.textualRating: False. Under federal law, members of Congress do not receive their full pay when they retire, and they must serve at least five years to be entitled to a pension.

text: The HIV variant recently found in the Netherlands is linked to the COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Virulent HIV variant is decades old, has no link to COVID vaccine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The previously unrecognized HIV variant had been circulating in the Netherlands for decades. Experts say there’s no connection between the vaccines and the variant, and vaccine trials have not shown that recipients are more susceptible to contracting HIV in general.

text: An image that shows California state Sen. Scott Wiener holding a book proves he grooms children for abuse.

claimReview.title: Image altered to change title on book held by California state senator
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. A photo posted to Wiener’s Twitter account that shows him holding a book called, “Gender Pioneers: A Celebration of Transgender, Non-Binary and Intersex Icons,” has been manipulated to change the book’s title, making it provocative.

text: The Polish postal service released stamps with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s portrait.

claimReview.title: Polish citizen, not postal service, created Zelenskyy stamps
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Poczta Polska, Poland’s postal service, confirmed to The Associated Press in an email that a customer created the stamps using “My Stamp,” a service that allows people to personalize and order stamps. The post office is not selling the stamps.

text: Wombats in parts of Australia stricken by wildfires are not only allowing other animals to take shelter in their deep burrows, but are actively herding fleeing animals into them.

claimReview.title: Wombats not herding animals into their burrows during Australia fires
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Wombats do not herd other animals. However, the large furry marsupials have been known to share their burrows with some small animals.

text: President Joe Biden has officially filed for reelection with the Federal Election Commission.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Biden 2020 campaign committee filing
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are misrepresenting an updated administrative document that was recently filed with the FEC by Biden’s principal 2020 presidential campaign committee. Biden has not formally filed for reelection, though he has said that he plans on running again in 2024.

text: A video clip shows Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy saying that Americans will have to send their “sons and daughters” to the war in Ukraine.

claimReview.title: Zelenskyy didn’t say US troops needed to fight in Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Zelenskyy was explaining that if Russia attacked NATO member states, which are U.S. allies, the U.S would likely send troops to protect those countries. He was not suggesting Americans would have to fight in Ukraine.

text: President Obama visited Arlington National Cemetery this weekend in the pouring rain.

claimReview.title: President Obama not pictured at Arlington National Cemetery this past Veterans Day
claimReview.textualRating: False. President Barack Obama did not visit Arlington National Cemetery over this Veterans Day weekend as some claimed on social media.

text: “Illegal aliens” will receive a $1,400 stimulus check through the COVID-19 relief bill.

claimReview.title: Immigrants without Social Security numbers are not eligible for stimulus checks
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The vast majority of immigrants without lawful status in the U.S. do not have Social Security numbers and cannot receive a $1,400 stimulus check. A small number of people who entered the U.S. on a temporary work visa and were issued Social Security numbers may be able to receive a payment, even if they overstayed their visas.

text: New York Judge Juan M. Merchan told the jury in former President Donald Trump’s hush money trial that they don’t need a unanimous verdict to convict Trump.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent New York judge’s instructions to jury in Trump hush money trial
claimReview.textualRating: False. Merchan said that to convict Trump the jury will have to find unanimously, on each of 34 felony counts, that he falsified business records and that he did so with the intent of concealing another crime — in this case, violating a state election law during his 2016 campaign. The judge said jurors could consider three different ways the law may have been broken and that they don’t have to be unanimous on this decision.

text: U.S. Border Patrol agents are giving Social Security numbers to immigrants who cross the border into the U.S. without authorization.

claimReview.title: Immigrants are not getting Social Security numbers at the U.S. border
claimReview.textualRating: False. Border Patrol does not give Social Security numbers to immigrants who cross the border, nor does it have the authority to, a spokesperson for the agency told The Associated Press. Immigrants living in the U.S. illegally aren’t eligible for Social Security numbers unless they meet certain criteria, experts say.

text: News report proves Queen Elizabeth II is taking ivermectin for her COVID-19 infection.

claimReview.title: News error prompts unfounded claim that queen is taking ivermectin
claimReview.textualRating: False. An Australian news outlet included footage of ivermectin in a segment reporting on the queen’s infection, but later said it was a “human error” and that it did not intend to “suggest the Queen is using Ivermectin.”

text: Video shows French firefighters turning their backs and walking out on French President Emmanuel Macron during a ceremony.

claimReview.title: Firefighters did not turn their backs on French president in protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. Macron was not at the event where firefighters were captured on video turning their backs on officials Saturday, Dec. 1, but the video is real.

text: Photo shows six Democratic lawmakers who are part of the self-styled progressive “squad” posing for a photo while wearing clothing emblazoned with Nazi swastika symbols.

claimReview.title: ‘The Squad’ did not wear clothing displaying swastikas
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The photo has been digitally manipulated to add patterns resembling swastikas.

text: Packaging inserts for the diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis vaccines list autism as a possible side effect on the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s website.

claimReview.title: Autism is not listed as a side effect of vaccines on federal agency’s website
claimReview.textualRating: False. Autism is not listed as a reaction on packaging for any of the diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis vaccines _ often referred to as DTaP_ currently used in the U.S., according to documents on the FDA’s website.

text: Video shows Rep. Ilhan Omar of Minnesota telling interviewer

claimReview.title: Video edits Rep. Ilhan Omar’s comment on radical white men
claimReview.textualRating: Mixture. While Omar did make those comments, a video that has been edited to remove a portion of her quote is being shared widely on social media.

text: Fifteen tennis players dropped out of the 2022 Miami Open due to COVID-19 vaccine-related complications.

claimReview.title: Miami Open withdrawals weren’t caused by COVID vaccine effects
claimReview.textualRating: False. None of the athletes who withdrew or retired during the tournament did so because of COVID-19 vaccine side effects, according to the official causes listed by the Association of Tennis Professionals, ATP, and Women's Tennis Association, WTA, and published by the tournament organizer. In total, 19 players withdrew or retired, due to causes including ankle, wrist and foot injuries, viral illnesses and heat illness.

text: A photo shows the U.S. F-22 Raptor fighter jet that shot down a suspected Chinese spy balloon now sporting a victory mark in the shape of a balloon.

claimReview.title: Image altered to add balloon-shaped marking on US fighter jet
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The original image is from 2020 and shows an F-22 at California’s Edwards Air Force Base, which posted the picture on its social media accounts at the time. It was edited to include the victory mark.

text: Pennsylvania election officials mailed out 1.8 million ballots but counted votes from more than 2.5 mailed ballots.

claimReview.title: Pennsylvania did not have hundreds of thousands of phantom absentee ballots
claimReview.textualRating: False. The statistic combines data from Pennsylvania’s June primary election, in which 1.8 million voters requested vote-by-mail ballots, and data from the general election, in which voters mailed back more than 2.6 million ballots that were counted.

text: Thousands of migrant children were “taken” after the Biden administration lost them. Biden also “got rid of Trump's human trafficking task force that he had in place — one of the first things in fact he got rid of, with his little executive orders.”

claimReview.title: TikTok video baselessly claims ‘thousands of migrant children’ in US were ‘taken’
claimReview.textualRating: False. President Joe Biden did not sign an executive order eliminating a human trafficking task force put in place by his predecessor. About 5,000 phone calls to migrant children released into the U.S., or to their sponsors, during the first half of the year went unanswered, but there is no evidence they were “taken” or that the U.S. lost them.

text: Former President Donald Trump won 2,497 counties in 2020, far more than President Joe Biden’s 477 counties, suggesting Trump actually won the election.

claimReview.title: Counties don’t decide presidential elections, contrary to misleading posts about 2020
claimReview.textualRating: False. It is true that Trump won significantly more counties than Biden, but those numbers come from an analysis immediately following the election that was later slightly updated. Regardless, it doesn’t say anything about the outcome of the election. County victories don’t play a role in deciding the president and county populations vary widely. Biden won the popular vote and the Electoral College.

text: A graph from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration displaying land and ocean temperatures over the last eight years shows that the Earth has been cooling, not warming, proving that global warming from carbon emissions is a hoax.

claimReview.title: Temperature graph misrepresented to deny climate change
claimReview.textualRating: False. A small portion of the graph showing only the period between 2015 and 2022 has been taken out of context to make the incorrect claim. The larger graph from which it was isolated displays temperature trends over more than 140 years, showing a dramatic upward trend. Experts say El Niño and La Niña cycles have impacted the last eight years, but more reliable climate data must be measured over periods of decades.

text: A cybersecurity firm hired by Arizona’s Republican-controlled Senate to review 2020 election results in the state’s largest county was unable to identify 86,391 voters, showing that these voters don’t appear to exist.

claimReview.title: No truth to claims that 86K voters ‘don’t appear to exist’ in Arizona
claimReview.textualRating: False. The firm, Cyber Ninjas, based its assessment on information in a private commercial database, which is not appropriate for determining whether or not a voter is a real person. A spokesperson for the company that owns the database told The Associated Press it estimates the list includes only about 80% of adults living in the U.S. Cyber Ninjas acknowledged in its report that “it is expected that most if not all of these individuals are in fact real people.”

text: An MSNBC clip from the night of

claimReview.title: Truncated MSNBC clip misrepresents Jan. 6 discussion
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The clip has been truncated. It shows host Rachel Maddow noting that rioters began breaching security barriers around the Capitol while then-President Donald Trump was still speaking at a rally elsewhere. But the clip cuts off before Maddow argues that the rioters were taking the opportunity to breach the barricades during the rally “so that the mob could follow them when Trump told them to."

text: A photo shows U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris with the late financier Jeffrey Epstein.

claimReview.title: Photo edited to show Kamala Harris with Jeffrey Epstein
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image posted online purporting to show Harris with Epstein is altered. The original image shows Harris with her husband in 2015 at a formal dinner in Los Angeles. The image was manipulated to place Epstein in the photo using a 2006 mugshot.

text: The use of Dominion Voting Systems machines with Sharpies and low image quality settings creates a pile-up of ballots sent to adjudication in Pennsylvania, which are then used to commit “massive fraud.”

claimReview.title: Video spreads unfounded claims about Dominion machines in PA
claimReview.textualRating: False. Dominion recommends the use of Sharpie pens because the ink dries quickly. Ballots are designed in a format that ensures ink bleeding through does not interfere with scanning. Two Pennsylvania counties that use Dominion machines said on Election Day that neither the Sharpies or image quality settings have presented issues with scanning ballots.

text: Climate change isn’t real because Florida has had 119 hurricanes since 1850.

claimReview.title: Climate change doesn’t cause hurricanes. But it may increase their frequency and intensity
claimReview.textualRating:
False. Scientists don’t believe climate change causes hurricanes but research has shown the gradual warming of the Earth’s surface may play a role in the intensity and frequency of the strongest ones.
List (Page)

text: Video shows how Walmart envisions shopping in the “metaverse.”

claimReview.title: Video shows 2017 Walmart virtual reality demonstration
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was a demonstration of what virtual reality shopping could look like, created for the 2017 SXSW conference by Walmart and Mutual Mobile, a tech consultancy and design studio. But the concept does not reflect the company’s current plans, a Walmart spokesperson said.

text: If Joe Biden picks Kamala Harris as his running mate she will not be eligible to serve as president because her mother is from India and her father is from Jamaica. That means, if Biden is unable to serve a full term as president, Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi would be next in line to become president.

claimReview.title: Kamala Harris is eligible to serve as president
claimReview.textualRating: False. Sen. Kamala Harris, a Democrat who represents California, is a natural-born U.S. citizen who is eligible to serve as president.

text: A declassified letter from the United States Director of National Intelligence proves that former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton planned the “Russia hoax” against Trump in 2016.

claimReview.title: Intel in letter is unverified, doesn’t show Clinton planned ‘Russia hoax’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The letter contains unverified Russian intelligence information and some lawmakers have criticized its release as a political move. The letter explains that in 2016, Russian intelligence had alleged that Clinton “had approved a campaign plan to stir up a scandal” against Trump. The document also clearly states that American intelligence officials do not know whether this claim is accurate, an exaggeration, or a lie.

text: The United States military is invading Haiti.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent U.S. response to instability in Haiti
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the U.S. and Mexico said Monday that they are preparing a U.N. resolution that would authorize an international mission to help improve security in Haiti, no such deployment has happened. The U.S. and Canada have sent armored vehicles and other supplies to aid the Haitian police.

text: An at-home rapid test that can detect both the coronavirus and influenza A and B is proof that COVID-19 and flu are the same disease.

claimReview.title: Combination COVID and flu test does not prove they are the same virus
claimReview.textualRating: False. The flu and the coronavirus are distinct viruses, and the product in the photo on social media tests separately for each. Such tests detect specific proteins that differ between the viruses, allowing them to discern between COVID-19 and flu infections, medical experts confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Video shows “the new congresswoman from Michigan” talking about "making all of America Muslim."

claimReview.title: Video does not show Michigan congresswoman speaking about Islam
claimReview.textualRating: False. The woman in the video is not Michigan Rep. Rashida Tlaib, it is Sharifa Alkhateeb addressing the “Muslim American Political Awareness Conference” in 1989.

text: Video shows Boeing 737 crash in southern China.

claimReview.title: Video shows flight simulator game, not Chinese airliner crash
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage is computer generated. It was created using a flight simulator game.

text: A video shows aboriginal people in Australia defending themselves with bows and arrows against authorities trying to forcibly administer COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Video doesn’t show Indigenous people in Australia protesting vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed in Brazil before the onset of the coronavirus pandemic. It shows a March 2019 demonstration in Sao Paulo by a group of Guarani Indigenous people who were protesting changes to health care infrastructure and resources.

text: A video shows a convoy made up of thousands of truckers, including many driving tractor-trailers, on its way to Texas to support the state in its

claimReview.title: Video from 2022 misrepresented to make southern border convoy look larger than it is
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a 2022 convoy of truckers who drove from California to the Washington, D.C., area to demand an end to COVID-19 restrictions. It is made up of clips from three news reports on the convoy and aerial footage from a local television station. A convoy calling to secure the southern border left Norfolk, Virginia, on Monday, their final destination Texas. However, a livestream by one of the participants showed about 40 vehicles participating as they left Jacksonville, Florida, on Tuesday morning.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention quietly confirmed that at least 118,000 children and young adults have “died suddenly” in the U.S. since the COVID-19 vaccines rolled out.

claimReview.title: Article misrepresents CDC data, falsely links deaths to COVID vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. Excess deaths — the difference between the observed number of deaths and the expected number in a specific period — were higher for those 0 to 44 years old in the U.S. in 2021 and 2022 compared to previous averages. However, the CDC has not attributed this increase to COVID-19 vaccines and experts told The Associated Press that it can likely be attributed to other causes, including more severe variants of the coronavirus. Confirmed reports of deaths caused by vaccination are extremely rare, even with millions of people vaccinated against COVID-19.

text: The U.S. Supreme Court has ruled that COVID-19 vaccines are not vaccines and that they cause “irreparable damage.”

claimReview.title: US Supreme Court did not issue order against COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Supreme Court has issued no such ruling. Posts on social media are reviving a long debunked claim, while some social media users are misrepresenting an unrelated October ruling by a New York state Supreme Court judge. That judge said New York City sanitation workers fired for not getting COVID-19 shots should be reinstated and given back pay, but did not rule on the efficacy of the vaccines themselves.

text: The malaria drug hydroxychloroquine, when used with the antibiotic azithromycin, can improve survival by nearly 200% when given to COVID-19 patients on ventilators.

claimReview.title: Study touting hydroxychloroquine flawed, experts say
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say the small study that this claim is based on proves nothing, and that enough evidence now exists from well-run studies to indicate that hydroxychloroquine is not effective for treating COVID-19.

text: Video shows armored tanks being moved into Los Angeles due to martial law.

claimReview.title: Tanks on train in Los Angeles show routine movement of equipment
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tanks were being transported as part of routine movement of military equipment, and are not related to the COVID-19 response, officials said.

text: The maker of Bud Light is going bankrupt as it faces ongoing backlash over a marketing campaign featuring a transgender social media personality.

claimReview.title: Reports of Bud Light’s demise greatly exaggerated, experts say
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for Anheuser-Busch InBev said there’s “no truth” to the claim the world’s largest beer maker is on the verge of financial ruin. Industry experts note the company remains financially sound, with billions of dollars in assets and a rising stock market price. Sales of Bud Light have ebbed in recent weeks, but not to the drastic level claimed by online critics.

text: Melania Trump is first FLOTUS to visit a combat zone since 1969.

claimReview.title: Melania Trump not first FLOTUS to visit combat zone since 1969
claimReview.textualRating: False. At least three first ladies have visited combat zones since 1969.

text: U.S. ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch refused to hang President Donald Trump’s photo in the embassy in Kyiv for over a year and a half.

claimReview.title: Trump portrait installed at U.S. Embassy in Ukraine when it was available
claimReview.textualRating: False. Yovanovitch did not refuse to have the president’s photo hanging in the embassy.

text: Canada is mandating psychiatric medication for those who refuse COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Canada isn’t mandating psychiatric treatment for unvaccinated
claimReview.textualRating: False. Canada has issued no guidance related to psychiatric medication and COVID-19 vaccines, according to the country’s public health agency. The claim misrepresents a section of a COVID-19 FAQ published by the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Ontario, which states prescription medications and referrals to psychotherapy may be options for patients who have serious anxiety linked to vaccination. An example was later added to the page to specify cases such as “extreme fear of needles.”

text: Lungs filling with fluid and kidney failure are actually side effects of remdesivir, a treatment approved for COVID-19, not symptoms of the disease itself.

claimReview.title: Lung and kidney damage caused by COVID-19, not antiviral drug
claimReview.textualRating: False. Critical COVID-19, not the drug remdesivir, has been known to cause fluid in the lungs and renal failure.

text: Video shows proof of Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot supporting the “New World Order,” a conspiracy theory built on the idea that the world’s most wealthy and powerful are plotting to overthrow democracy and install a single, global authoritarian government.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim Chicago mayor supports New World Order
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was edited to take her words out of context. Lightfoot was not planning a global coup, she was talking about ending a long-standing and unusual custom in Chicago called “aldermanic prerogative,” which gave aldermen absolute power on zoning and development decisions in their home wards.

text: There are nine U.S. consulates and one embassy in Mexico, where non-U.S. citizens can apply for asylum, without any risk of being separated from their children.

claimReview.title: Non-citizens cannot apply for asylum through a U.S. consulate or embassy
claimReview.textualRating: False. People cannot apply for asylum at U.S. consulates or embassy in Mexico.

text: Video captures a painting of former President Barack Obama falling off the wall as President Donald Trump’s portrait was unveiled at the Capitol in Colorado.

claimReview.title: Obama portrait did not fall as Trump’s was unveiled at Colorado Capitol
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was edited to make it appear that the former president’s portrait fell as Trump’s portrait was revealed during an event at the Capitol.

text: Video shows Ukrainian soldiers staging bodies in Bucha.

claimReview.title: Video shows soldiers checking bodies for explosives in Bucha
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, filmed by The Associated Press on April 2 in Bucha, a suburb of Kiev, shows soldiers attaching cables to the bodies to pull them off the street, in case Russian forces left the bodies booby-trapped with explosive devices.

text: President Donald Trump’s sister, Elizabeth Trump Grau has been tweeting support for her brother under the handle @TheBettyTrump.

claimReview.title: Parody account poses as president’s sister on Twitter
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Twitter account was created as a spoof.

text: Photo shows “Biden’s huge Delaware mansion,” one of the largest in the state.

claimReview.title: Delaware mansion in photo is not owned by Biden
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows a multi-million-dollar home in Delaware, but it doesn’t belong to Joe Biden, the property’s listing agent confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: A World Health Organization tool called VigiAccess shows thousands of adverse reactions from COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Posts on WHO vaccine reporting tool lack context
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The WHO list known as VigiAccess shows symptoms reported by people following vaccination. The reports, some of which are in the hundreds of thousands, are not vetted or verified, nor are they proof that the vaccine caused a particular symptom, according to a spokesperson from the organization that oversees the database.

text: Former President Barack Obama signed a law in 2012 allowing government propaganda in the U.S., and making it “perfectly legal for the media to purposely lie to the American people.”

claimReview.title: Obama did not sign a law allowing propaganda in the U.S.
claimReview.textualRating: False. In 2013, Obama signed legislation that changed the U.S. Information and Educational Exchange Act of 1948, also known as the Smith-Mundt Act. The amendment made it possible for some materials created by the U.S. Agency for Global Media, the nation’s foreign broadcasting agency, to be disseminated in the U.S.

text: COVID-19 is a man-made virus intentionally manufactured in a lab and released to the public.

claimReview.title: Research shows COVID-19 was not manufactured in a lab
claimReview.textualRating: False. Scientists say the molecular structure of SARS-CoV-2 rules out the possibility that the virus was created in a lab.

text: White, pink and light blue stripes on a version of the LGBTQ+ pride flag, known as the Progress Pride flag, were added to represent pedophiles.

claimReview.title: Video misrepresents colors in a 2018 Pride flag to malign LGBTQ+ community
claimReview.textualRating: False. Daniel Quasar, the designer who created the Progress Pride flag, told The Associated Press the colors represent the transgender community. Representatives of multiple LGBTQ+ advocacy organizations confirmed to the AP the meaning of the colors, which also appear on other pride flags.

text: Video shows President Joe Biden falling down the stairs of Air Force One while disembarking from a flight in Poland.

claimReview.title: Biden did not fall down airplane stairs while disembarking from a flight in Poland
claimReview.textualRating: False. The person shown taking a spill while coming down the steps of the aircraft at Chopin Airport in Warsaw is not Biden. Other footage and photos from his arrival in February show Biden using a different exit and walking down the stairs with no issues.

text: Scientists, including researchers from seven universities, found that 1,500 laboratory samples that had supposedly tested positive for COVID-19 were actually positive for influenza, proving that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention committed fraud.

claimReview.title: Study did not find 1,500 positive COVID tests were actually flu
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim, which has circulated before with slightly different information, is fabricated. There is no evidence of such a study, and the identity of the scientist said to have led the investigation cannot be confirmed.

text: Video shows a child shaking uncontrollably in response to the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Video shows child having epileptic seizure, not COVID-19 vaccine reaction
claimReview.textualRating: False. The child in the video has epilepsy and was experiencing a seizure, not responding to a COVID-19 vaccine, according to an Instagram post by his father. “Vaccines do not cause permanent seizure disorders” such as epilepsy, according to Dr. Paul Offit, a vaccine expert at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia.

text: Federal records show George Soros is the biggest funder of the failed app used by the Iowa Democratic Party during Monday’s caucuses.

claimReview.title: Image does not show George Soros’ donation to Iowa caucus app
claimReview.textualRating: False. The data shows a donation by Soros to the National Democratic Redistricting Committee, a group led by former U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder that has sued states over voting rights issues and legislative redistricting.

text: Video shows footage of a missile hitting the Pentagon on 9/11.

claimReview.title: Video does not show missile hitting the Pentagon on 9/11
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows American Airlines Flight 77 crashing into the Pentagon on Sept. 11, 2001, not a missile.

text: A close-up photo shows Wikileaks founder Julian Assange looking physically unwell and disheveled in London’s Belmarsh prison.

claimReview.title: Image of Julian Assange in prison is AI-generated
claimReview.textualRating: False. It’s a synthetic image, according to the creator, who posted it on Twitter. The Twitter user “The Errant Friend” told The Associated Press that it was created using Midjourney V5, an artificial intelligence text-to-image generator.

text: George Floyd posted a derogatory tweet about “trans folk” in 2011.

claimReview.title: Posts share fabricated George Floyd tweet
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image purporting to show such a tweet was fabricated. The post is dated 2011, but the account it names was created in 2022, more than two years after Floyd was murdered by a police officer. Floyd was also in prison in 2011.

text: King County detectives have been notifying locals about a serial killer in Seattle after several women in a southern section of the city and the nearby city of Burien were found dead with their bodies posed in the same way.

claimReview.title: No suspected serial killer in Seattle, despite online rumor
claimReview.textualRating: False. The King County Sheriff’s Office and Seattle Police Department both said they are not investigating a suspected serial killer. The sheriff’s office, whose jurisdiction includes Burien, said it had no evidence of deaths under investigation in these locations sharing similar characteristics.

text: Recently reported cases of Eastern equine encephalitis, or EEE, virus in Alabama were caused by a genetically modified mosquito project tied to Bill Gates.

claimReview.title: No, Alabama cases of EEE virus aren’t linked to Bill Gates or Oxitec’s modified mosquitoes
