claimReview.textualRating: False. A biotech company, Oxitec, has been releasing genetically modified mosquitoes, but only in Florida. Moreover, those mosquitoes are male, which do not bite humans and therefore aren’t responsible for disease spread. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation has funded Oxitec’s mosquito work abroad, not in the U.S.

text: A video shows the moment a Ukrainian missile struck the Russian warship Moskva in the Black Sea.

claimReview.title: Video shows 2013 navy exercise, not Russian warship Moskva
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage is miscaptioned. The video actually shows a 2013 Norwegian navy test missile strike, not the Russian ship being hit amid the ongoing war with Ukraine.

text: More than 1.4 million adverse events caused by the COVID-19 vaccines have been reported to the federal database VAERS through Sept. 9.

claimReview.title: Posts continue to misrepresent VAERS COVID-19 vaccine data
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. VAERS, a passive reporting system run jointly by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, relies on unverified reports submitted by the general public. It does not prove that vaccines caused the adverse events reported. Claims about the safety of the vaccines based on data from VAERS have been debunked by The Associated Press on multiple occasions.

text: Videos show pigs being killed by the Chinese government to control the new virus from China.

claimReview.title: Videos do not show pigs being destroyed because of the new virus from China
claimReview.textualRating: False. The videos circulating online are not related to the new virus outbreak from China.

text: A Facebook post shows Joel Osteen Ministries refusing to accept a prayer request submitted on the social media platform unless the person pays a $24.99 monthly donation.

claimReview.title: Joel Osteen is not charging for online prayers
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image circulating on Facebook that appears to show the popular televangelist demanding a donation in exchange for a prayer is a hoax, a spokesman for Osteen’s church told The Associated Press.

text: Video shows more than 7,000 soldiers in Washington, D.C., in the lead up to this year’s midterm elections.

claimReview.title: 2021 video of Guard troops in DC spreads ahead of midterms
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, which was posted to TikTok on Jan. 9, 2021, shows National Guard troops in Washington days after the Jan. 6 insurrection and ahead of President Joe Biden’s inauguration. The D.C. National Guard confirmed in a statement to The Associated Press that there are no plans to deploy soldiers for the midterms.

text: Photo shows German car caught in floodwaters with anti-Greta Thunberg sticker on rear window.

claimReview.title: Photo of flooding manipulated to add anti-Thunberg sticker on car
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was digitally altered to add the sticker on the rear window of the partially submerged car.

text: CNN displayed a banner during coverage of the mass shooting in Boulder, Colorado, stating the gunman was “factually Arab, but morally white.”

claimReview.title: CNN banner did not say Boulder shooting suspect was ‘morally white’
claimReview.textualRating: False. This manipulated image originated as satire. A recording of the broadcast and a CNN representative both confirmed the network didn’t display such text.

text: On his second day in office, President Joe Biden rescinded former President Donald Trump’s “executive order that helped combat child sex trafficking.”

claimReview.title: No, Biden didn’t rescind executive order fighting child sex trafficking
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no record of Biden rescinding such an order focused on child sex trafficking.

text: The flu shot increases your chance of catching COVID-19.

claimReview.title: The flu shot does not increase your risk of getting COVID-19
claimReview.textualRating: False. According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, there is no evidence that getting the flu vaccine increases your risk of contracting the coronavirus.

text: The Canadian Cancer Society recommends that transgender women get screened for cervical cancer.

claimReview.title: Tweet misleads on cervical cancer guidance for trans women
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The Canadian Cancer Society advises on its webpage that some trans women who have received certain types of vaginoplasties, also known as bottom surgeries, can be at a rare risk for cancer because of the tissue used in some procedures. Thus, those patients may need to be occasionally screened. The organization’s guidance makes clear that trans women who haven’t had bottom surgery aren’t at risk for cervical cancer and don’t need to be regularly tested for the disease.

text: Columbia University is holding separate student graduation ceremonies based on race, income and sexual orientation.

claimReview.title: Columbia University holds a main graduation, as well as smaller ceremonies
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Columbia holds a university-wide ceremony for all graduating students, a university spokesperson said. Smaller ceremonies celebrating individual communities are voluntary, and in addition to the main ceremony.

text: Photo shows David Chipman, Biden nominee to lead the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, holding a sign calling pro-gun activists “bullies.”

claimReview.title: Posts manipulate photo of Biden’s ATF nominee
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was manipulated. Chipman posted the original photo on Reddit in September 2019. It shows him holding a sheet of paper that says: “This is @David_Chipman Ask Me Anything.”

text: Video shows the Islamic call to prayer, which was recited at a rally held by prominent Congress Party politician Priyanka Gandhi to “appease” the Muslim community in Varanasi, India.

claimReview.title: Prayers from multiple faiths were recited at rally in India
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The rally featured prayers from multiple faiths. A full clip from the Oct. 10 rally shows that right after the adhan, which is the Islamic call to prayer, a Sikh prayer was recited, as was a Hindu prayer.

text: A 2019 clip of CNN election coverage shows a Republican gubernatorial candidate’s vote tally drop while his Democratic opponent’s total rises amid the ongoing count — evidence of fraud.

claimReview.title: CNN graphic does not show 2019 election fraud in Kentucky
claimReview.textualRating: False. In the clip, a CNN graphic does briefly display a drop in the Republican candidate’s total, but it was caused by a “typo,” according to a representative of the data firm that provided the numbers. The error was corrected by the firm minutes later.

text: There were more than 61,000 excess deaths among the millennial age group in the U.S. in the second half of 2021 because of COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines did not cause excess deaths among millennials
claimReview.textualRating: False. There was an increase in excess deaths — which is the difference between the observed numbers of deaths and expected numbers of deaths in a specific period — among millennials at that time, but health experts say there is no evidence vaccines played a role. Instead, contagious variants of the coronavirus were a major contributor to the toll.

text: Posts circulating widely online state that “The Democrats and President Obama gave Iran 150 Billion Dollars and got nothing, but they can’t give 5 Billion Dollars for National Security and a Wall?”

claimReview.title: Democrats and Obama did not give $150 billion to Iran
claimReview.textualRating: False. There was no $150 billion payout from the U.S. treasury to Iran, according to an AP Fact Check.

text: A table shows a list of planned COVID-19 variants and when they will be “released” to the public.

claimReview.title: Schedule of ‘planned COVID-19 variants’ is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. This schedule is fabricated. The table claims the delta variant was “launched” in June 2021, but it actually emerged several months earlier. It is impossible to predict with certainty when variants will emerge in the population, according to Dr. Christopher Murray, a public health researcher and director of the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington.

text: Soccer player Cristiano Ronaldo was sentenced to 99 lashes in Iran for hugging a woman.

claimReview.title: Iran denies viral claim that Ronaldo is facing ‘99 lashes’ for hugging an Iranian woman
claimReview.textualRating: False. Iran, via its embassy in Spain, denied the claim, saying it hadn’t issued “any court ruling against any international athlete in Iran.”

text: Florida is the most expensive state in the United States to live in.

claimReview.title: Crist misleads in tweet claiming Florida is ‘most expensive’ state
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While there is no one way to calculate cost of living, economics experts say Florida does not rank highly in most assessments. Some lists have singled out the state’s high property insurance costs and expensive housing in certain cities, but many other different factors go into calculating overall cost of living. The states with the highest cost of living are typically considered to be Hawaii, New York, California and Alaska — not Florida.

text: New York Gov. Kathy Hochul approved a

claimReview.title: NY governor didn’t issue memo ‘denying white people’ medical treatments
claimReview.textualRating: False. The post is referencing a memo from 2021 concerning the distribution of antiviral therapies for COVID-19 that said being “non-white race or Hispanic/Latino ethnicity” could be considered a risk factor to receive such treatments. It did not say white people with other risk factors couldn’t access the treatments.

text: Alberta Children’s Hospital is seeing a major influx of children suffering severe adverse reactions to the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Canadian hospital hasn’t seen kids with adverse COVID vaccine reactions
claimReview.textualRating: False. Alberta Health Services, the health authority in the Canadian province of Alberta and the operator of the children’s hospital, said on Twitter that it has not seen any pediatric hospitalizations related to the COVID-19 vaccines.

text: A chart shows that the city of Columbus, Ohio, plans to spend $359 million on its police, but only a few million dollars on schools, health and recreation for its 2020 budget.

claimReview.title: Image of city budget in Columbus, Ohio, is inaccurate
claimReview.textualRating: Partially false. The city does plan to spend $359 million on its police department this year but the chart leaves out how much the city spends on other crucial services, like EMS and fire crews as well as road repair. It also does not include the nearly $1.5 billion budget for Columbus City Schools.

text: A video of a beam of light traveling through clouds across the sky above the ocean was filmed in Lahaina, in Maui, around the time of the wildfires.

claimReview.title: Video of light flashing through sky above a beach was taken in Florida, not Maui, contrary to claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip can be found online and in news reports since at least June, predating the wildfires that broke out Aug. 8. The man who claims to have filmed the video told media outlets he recorded it in Florida.

text: Atlanta has deployed a “child militia,” equipped with riot shields and batons, outside Lenox Square shopping mall.

claimReview.title: Viral video shows adult members of the Georgia National Guard, not a ‘child militia’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The National Guard in Georgia told The Associated Press that the people shown in the video are adult members of the Guard, not a “child militia.” A spokeswoman noted that their regulations require members to be 18 years of age or older, or 17 with parent's consent.

text: An image of U.S. Rep. George Santos in a gray sweater and blue jacket is a mugshot taken Wednesday after he was indicted on federal charges.

claimReview.title: Months-old photo of George Santos misrepresented as mugshot
claimReview.textualRating: False. No mugshot has been released. The image circulating on social media is a cropped and edited version of a news photo taken on Jan. 10, 2023, outside a House Republican Conference meeting in the U.S. Capitol. The U.S. Department of Justice generally does not release mugshots as a matter of policy, a spokesperson confirmed.

text: Two researchers found that more than 1,500 athletes have suffered cardiac arrest since COVID-19 vaccinations began, compared to a previous average of 29 athletes per year, suggesting the vaccines are causing a dramatic rise in such cardiac issues.

claimReview.title: Claims baselessly link COVID vaccines to athlete deaths
claimReview.textualRating: False. The researchers cited a number from a blog that lists news stories about recent deaths and medical emergencies among people of all ages, from all over the world — some of which were attributed to other causes, such as cancer. The previous figure, meanwhile, is from a 2006 study that specifically reviewed literature for reports of sudden cardiac deaths among athletes under age 35. Comparing the two sources, with different methodologies, is not scientifically sound, experts told The Associated Press.

text: Prosecutors struck a secret plea deal with Jeffrey Epstein under the Obama administration.

claimReview.title: Obama administration didn’t oversee Epstein plea deal
claimReview.textualRating: False. Former President Barack Obama did not take office until Jan. 20, 2009, after then-Miami U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta _ who resigned Friday from his post as U.S. secretary of labor _ entered into a secret 2008 no-prosecution agreement with Epstein. The deal resulted in the billionaire financier avoiding federal prosecution on far more serious charges related to the sexual abuse of teenage girls.

text: Taking borax daily can help with a range of ailments, including osteoporosis, kidney stones, chronic fatigue and erectile dysfunction.

claimReview.title: Experts warn that borax cleaning powder isn’t safe to ingest, as social media posts claim
claimReview.textualRating:
False. Not only is there no evidence to support purported health benefits touted around the cleaning product, health experts say ingesting borax can be harmful or deadly to humans if swallowed.
List (Page)

text: NATO killed tens of thousands, if not hundreds of thousands, of civilians during a 2011 military intervention in Libya.

claimReview.title: Posts inflate Libyan civilian deaths caused by NATO in 2011
claimReview.textualRating: False. Estimates for how many civilians were killed during the NATO campaign in Libya vary, but experts told The Associated Press that figures placing civilian casualties in the tens of thousands are dramatically inflated. Nongovernmental organizations have also said that far fewer civilians were killed by the NATO airstrikes, with estimates ranging from 72 to 403.

text: NASA’s Mars rover has captured images of a doorway cut into a mountainside of the red planet, suggesting the presence of extraterrestrial life.

claimReview.title: Experts: Mars ‘doorway’ just small crevice on barren terrain
claimReview.textualRating: False. NASA officials and a Mars expert at Harvard University say the curious formation is nothing more than a narrow, naturally-occurring crevice in the rocky, barren terrain.

text: Photo shows Joe Biden posing with former Senate staffer Tara Reade, who has accused him of sexually assaulting her in the early 1990s.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Joe Biden posing with Zoe Baird in 1993, not Tara Reade
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 1993 image, taken by an Associated Press photographer, shows Biden, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee at the time, with U.S. Attorney General nominee Zoe Baird.

text: A video filmed from a moving car in the Ukrainian city of Bucha shows dead bodies moving in the street, including one body “waving” its hand and another body rolling over.

claimReview.title: Video does not show staged bodies in Bucha
claimReview.textualRating: False. Following Russian troops’ withdrawal from the city, social media users are sharing a low-quality, edited clip that’s being used as propaganda. The original video shows the bodies were not moving. The so-called hand movement shows a mark on the car’s windshield, while the other portion of the video shows a distortion from the side-view mirror, according to a review by The Associated Press and an analysis by an independent expert.

text: George Washington University Hospital stopped accepting patients due to a possible Ebola outbreak in recent days.

claimReview.title: GW University Hospital rebuts false claims about Ebola outbreak
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Washington, D.C., hospital does not have any Ebola patients and is still fully open, it said in a statement to The Associated Press.

text: Video shows Ukrainians burning down an Orthodox church in the village of Novopoltavka in Ukraine.

claimReview.title: Video of 2013 church fire in Russia misrepresented as Ukraine in 2023
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from 2013 and shows a Russian Orthodox church on fire in Ilyinka village in southern Russia.

text: Smithfield Foods was sold recently to China. The hogs will still be raised in the U.S., but slaughtered and packaged for sale in China before being sent back here.

claimReview.title: Smithfield Foods does not import food from China
claimReview.textualRating: False. Smithfield Foods does not import any products from China to the U.S.

text: The CEO of the bankrupt cryptocurrency firm FTX is the daughter of the chair of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

claimReview.title: Former head of FTX is not SEC chair’s daughter
claimReview.textualRating: False. The embattled former CEO of FTX, Sam Bankman-Fried, isn’t the child of SEC Chairman Gary Gensler, nor is the new CEO, John Ray III.

text: Shredded ballots found in Maricopa County dumpster appear to be votes from 2020 Election.

claimReview.title: Maricopa County ballots are secured in a vault, not shredded in trash
claimReview.textualRating: False. Election officials say all tabulated ballots from the Nov. 3 election are stored in a secure vault, including those that were ultimately disqualified. In addition, no evidence that legal ballots have been destroyed has been shared with election officials.

text: A public bus called “Not the 48” in Brussels takes riders to a mystery location for free.

claimReview.title: Brussels bus stop ‘Mystère’ is no mystery
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such bus exists, although the real 48 bus in Brussels does have a stop near the street Rue du Mystère called “Mystère/Mysterie.” The Twitter user who started the rumor revealed in later comments that he intended it as a joke.

text: A 42-year-old nurse in Alabama died after she received the COVID-19 vaccine Tuesday.

claimReview.title: Alabama nurse did not die as a result of receiving COVID-19 vaccine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Alabama Department of Public Health confirmed that no deaths have occurred as a result of the vaccines being administered Tuesday in the state.

text: “Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the current director of the World Health Organization (WHO) has been arrested by Interpol and is being held in prison for crimes against humanity and genocide.”

claimReview.title: WHO director-general not arrested, claim started as satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. WHO confirmed to The Associated Press that this is false. The information originated as satire.

text: Voters in Georgia cast 95,801 ballots for Democratic candidate Joe Biden, and marked no other races, compared to 818 voters who only marked their ballot for President Donald Trump. An investigation is needed.

claimReview.title: No evidence over 95,000 ballots in Georgia were only marked for Biden
claimReview.textualRating: False. Information on what races are marked on a ballot is not released publicly in Georgia, experts say. There’s no way to determine how ballots for Biden or Trump were marked without looking at the actual ballot.

text: Photo shows President Joe Biden kneeling in front of George Floyd’s son.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Biden with young boy in Detroit, not George Floyd’s son
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken on Sept. 9, 2020, shows Biden in Detroit with C.J. Brown. His father, Clement Brown Jr, owns a clothing store in the city.

text: A video shows a parking lot of cars that was set on fire by protesters in Marseille, France.

claimReview.title: A video of an Australian parking lot fire is being misrepresented as a protest in Marseille
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a fire at an auction yard in Perth, Australia, in April.

text: An image shows a CNN news story that reported the OceanGate submersible on its way to the Titanic wreckage site was found empty.

claimReview.title: Fabricated news report falsely claims Titanic-bound submersible was found empty
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image is fabricated. CNN did not publish any such story, a spokesperson for the network told The Associated Press. The submersible had not been found at the time of publishing.

text: California Sen. Kamala Harris called former Vice President Joe Biden a racist when they were facing off as potential Democratic candidates for president in 2019.

claimReview.title: Kamala Harris did not call Joe Biden a racist on the debate stage
claimReview.textualRating: False. Harris criticized Biden on certain topics related to race during a debate in June 2019, but she prefaced those remarks with “I do not believe you are a racist.”

text: The shooter who

claimReview.title: The Texas megachurch shooter has not been identified as transgender, despite claims online
claimReview.textualRating: False. Houston police said on Monday that its investigation has thus far determined that the shooter, Genesse Ivonne Moreno, identified as female despite using multiple aliases, including the name Jeffery — or Jeffrey — Escalante. Multiple court records identify Moreno as female, most recently in 2022.

text: On Jan. 24, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi purchased $1.25 million in stock from the electric vehicle company Tesla. A day later, on Jan. 25, President Joe Biden signed an executive order requiring all federal vehicles to be electric.

claimReview.title: Pelosi’s husband invested in Tesla, but not as viral post claims
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. It’s true that Pelosi’s husband invested up to $1 million in call options for Tesla stock in December, according to financial disclosure documents. Claims that the representative bought $1.25 million in shares one day before Biden’s executive order are inaccurate.

text: Presidential hopeful and U.S. Sen. Kamala Harris introduced a bill to forbid a police officer from drawing a gun without permission from their supervisor.

claimReview.title: Sen. Kamala Harris has not proposed new gun restrictions for police
claimReview.textualRating: False. Harris has not introduced such legislation.

text: A video shows Hamas fighters parachuting onto a sports field before attacking Israeli citizens during the group’s surprise attack on Israel.

claimReview.title: Video of parachute jumpers in Egypt mischaracterized as Hamas paratroopers during Israel attack
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage shows parachute jumpers in Cairo, Egypt, and has been online since at least September.

text: A video shows a robot attacking a human factory worker.

claimReview.title: Video of robot attacking factory worker is computer-generated
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The video was created with CGI technology by Sozo Bear Films, the production company told The Associated Press. It was first posted on the company’s TikTok account in January 2022.

text: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization has called on Ukraine to surrender to Russia.

claimReview.title: No, NATO has not urged Ukraine to surrender, despite what social media posts claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 31-nation alliance has made no such call. The organization in a statement pointed to comments its secretary general made this week stressing that NATO remains committed to supporting Ukraine and that any decision to negotiate peace would be up to the Eastern European nation.

text: More than 90% of all mass shootings have happened in so-called “gun-free zones.”

claimReview.title: Claims misrepresent mass shootings in ‘gun-free zones’
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The oft-cited figure comes from a study by a gun rights advocacy group that gun violence experts say is flawed. They say the study draws from federal data on “active shooter” incidents, which is not the same as a mass shooting. It also excludes gang-related incidents, yet includes military bases and other locations that aren’t arguably “gun free.” There is no definitive data on how many “mass shootings” occur in “gun-free” zones, because there is no consensus on how to define either term, experts said.

text: Photo shows Queen Elizabeth II sitting in a cart as several African men carry her through a river.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show people carrying Queen Elizabeth II across river
claimReview.textualRating: False. The person in this image is not Britain’s late monarch. A description from the news agency Agence France-Presse shows the photo was captured in Senegal around 1930, when the queen was much too young to be the person pictured.

text: Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer banned hydroxychloroquine for use against COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Michigan governor did not ban hydroxychloroquine
claimReview.textualRating: False. Michigan’s Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs released a memo in March asking for physicians and pharmacists not to stockpile hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine.

text: When the British news outlet Sky News tweeted a video interview with Prince Andrew, the FBI responded with its own tweet, saying, “Ooh, is he doing interviews now?”

claimReview.title: FBI did not reply to Sky News tweet about Prince Andrew
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The FBI did not send this tweet. British composer Nick Harvey confirmed to The Associated Press that he created the image as a joke.

text: Video shows Austrian news presenter collapsing live on-air due to side effects from the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Video of Austrian reporter collapsing predates pandemic
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, which captures Austrian Broadcasting Corporation reporter Rosa Lyon, was filmed on Sept. 24, 2019, before the pandemic began and well before COVID-19 shots were invented.

text: ESPN used a photo of former NFL player Larry Fitzgerald in an article on WNBA basketball star

claimReview.title: ESPN did not use photo of ex-NFL player in Brittney Griner article
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. A screenshot of a real ESPN article was manipulated, exchanging a photo of Griner for one of Fitzgerald. The original article never used an image of Fitzgerald, a company spokesperson confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam violated his stay-at-home order to travel to his vacation home in North Carolina.

claimReview.title: No evidence to support claim Virginia governor violated his stay-at-home order
claimReview.textualRating: False. Northam’s office says he has not left the state since the order went into place in March. Checks by a Republican senator in Virginia have found no evidence he has left the state since the order went into effect.

text: Video shows Boston police officers planting bricks at locations where protests are being held calling for justice in the death of George Floyd.

claimReview.title: Video does not show Boston police officers planting bricks at protest sites
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video does not show officers from the Boston Police Department, but police officers with Northeastern University who were unloading bricks from their truck after removing them from a sidewalk.

text: Photographs show the remains of OceanGate’s Titan submersible after U.S. authorities reported the

claimReview.title: Photos do not show remains of OceanGate’s Titan submersible
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. Coast Guard confirmed to The Associated Press that there are so far no public images of the wreckage. Two of the photographs being shared were actually taken in 2004 and show the remains of the Titanic itself; the other photograph was first shared on a Twitter account that identifies as a parody and spreads images created by artificial intelligence.

text: Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden will not hold any more in-person campaign events before the election.

claimReview.title: Joe Biden has not stopped campaigning in person
claimReview.textualRating: False. Claims that Biden has “called a lid” on in-person campaign events have no basis in fact. His campaign has announced he will make in-person campaign stops this week, in Georgia on Tuesday and Florida on Thursday.

text: Video shows dead fish washing ashore following the train derailment in East Palestine, Ohio.

claimReview.title: Video of dead fish not related to Ohio train derailment
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows dead fish on the shore of Laguna del Plata, a lagoon in the Santa Fe province of Argentina. It was filmed in late January.

text: Video appears to show presumptive Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden on “The View” avoiding a question about inappropriate touching.

claimReview.title: Video edited to make it appear Biden avoided question on ‘The View’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video features portions of Biden's April 26, 2019, appearance on ABC's daytime talk show "The View," but was edited to make it appear he failed to give a direct answer to the question, and stumbled through the response.

text: Video shows July 3 skyscraper fire in Moscow.

claimReview.title: Video shows previous fires, not July 2022 blaze at Moscow skyscraper
claimReview.textualRating: False. A fire did occur at a Moscow skyscraper on July 3, but a video being shared online claiming to show the blaze contains footage from other fires, including one in 2012.

text: Democratic vice presidential candidate Kamala Harris says that looters are just feeding their hungry kids.

claimReview.title: Kamala Harris didn’t say ‘looters are just feeding their hungry kids’
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence that Harris made a comment saying looters were motivated by the need to feed hungry children. Both Harris and Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden have condemned looting.

text: Video shows a massive banner on Trump tower in downtown Chicago with the words “concentration camps” over a photo of the bodies of a father and daughter who drowned at the U.S.-Mexico border.

claimReview.title: Video showing banner on Trump’s Chicago tower was fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip was created by a social media user known for fabricating political videos.

text: A report by health officials in the United Kingdom showed that the COVID-19 vaccines are “damaging the immune response” in people who were vaccinated after a previous infection.

claimReview.title: UK report did not find COVID-19 vaccines damage immune response
claimReview.textualRating: False. The report did not reach that conclusion. The finding being referenced dealt with people who were infected after being vaccinated — not the reverse — and experts say it showed that vaccine-induced immunity was working properly.

text: A screenshot shows a New York Times article with a headline stating that NFTs are the top expense for low-income men in 2021.

claimReview.title: Screenshot purporting to show New York Times article on NFTs is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image does not show an actual New York Times headline or article. The news organization’s executive director of communications confirmed to The Associated Press that The Times did not write or publish the article shown in the screenshot.

text: Voters in Detroit were prevented from casting ballots on Election Day after officials mistakenly said they’d already voted by absentee ballot.

claimReview.title: No voters turned away over Detroit absentee ballot glitch
claimReview.textualRating: False. Certain polling locations in Detroit had an issue checking-in voters on Tuesday morning, but that was due to a data glitch that was quickly resolved, state and city officials confirmed. No eligible voters were prevented from casting a ballot, they said.

text: The reason for a backlog of ships at a port in Los Angeles is a Trump-era executive order, which blocked countries from trading with the United States if they had been caught conducting "foreign election interference."

claimReview.title: Shipping backlog not related to foreign election interference
claimReview.textualRating: False. The backlog is a result of unprecedented consumer demand, according to a spokesperson for the Port of Los Angeles. It reflects the challenges that come with restarting the economy after disruptions early in the pandemic.

text: Democratic presidential candidate Beto O’Rourke is a convicted felon who can’t own a gun, and while campaigning for president has said he will send men house-to-house to take away guns.

claimReview.title: False claim suggests Beto O'Rourke was convicted of a felony
claimReview.textualRating: False. O’Rourke has not been convicted of felony crimes, nor has he faced felony charges. He did not call for house-to-house confiscation of guns, but he has said he would act to take AR-15s and AK-47s from the general public.

text: Video shows poll workers committing election fraud by stuffing ballots in Flint, Michigan.

claimReview.title: Ballot-stuffing video was shot in Russia, not Michigan
claimReview.textualRating: False. This video shows poll workers in Russia, not in the United States.

text: Medication abortions are dangerous, and result in high rates of infection and hemorrhage. Parts of the baby are also left in the womb following the procedure.

claimReview.title: Research shows medication abortions are safe
claimReview.textualRating: False. Research shows that medication abortions, which involve taking pills to end a pregnancy, are safe and effective, experts say. Complications after abortions using pills, such as infection, are rare.

text: A Pfizer document shows stiff person syndrome in a list of adverse events, suggesting the condition is caused by the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: No data linking COVID-19 vaccine to stiff person syndrome
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Experts say there is no established link between the rare neurological disorder and COVID-19 vaccination. A Pfizer document includes the condition in a list of medical events reported by some vaccine recipients, which are recorded regardless of whether the vaccine caused the event. Neither the document nor any available data have shown the vaccine causes stiff person syndrome, experts say.

text: An image shows the House Republicans' “

claimReview.title: Graphic misrepresents House GOP agenda
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image shows policies that don’t match the language in House Republicans’ actual plan. While Republicans lawmakers have suggested raising the age for Medicare, the Commitment to America does not give a specific age, and there is no evidence of lawmakers proposing other policies as worded in the graphic.

text: An Illinois couple received five vote-by-mail applications at their address so they will be able to send them back and receive five ballots “with no one the wiser.”

claimReview.title: Five vote-by-mail forms do not mean Illinois couple can get five ballots
claimReview.textualRating: False. Before election officials mail out a ballot to a voter, they verify the voter’s signature on the ballot request form matches the voter’s signature on file. Anyone who engages in the illegal behavior described in the social media post would be guilty of a felony.

text: Dr. Anthony Fauci “admitted” in a recent interview that face masks were a “failure.”

claimReview.title: No, Fauci didn’t say face masks were a ‘failure’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media posts are misrepresenting what Fauci said about masks and COVID-19 and omitting part of his response. The nation’s former top infectious disease expert said mask initiatives may have a small impact at the community level, but in the following sentence he said he believes a properly worn, high-quality mask can be effective protection for an individual.

text: President-elect Joe Biden is part of the “New World Order” conspiracy and confirmed an agenda to “microchip the masses."

claimReview.title: Video from 2005 does not show Biden promoting microchipping
claimReview.textualRating: False. The shortened clip that circulated on social media was missing context. Social media users posted a video from Sept. 12, 2005, of Biden, who was a senator at the time, questioning then-U.S. Supreme Court nominee John Roberts during a confirmation hearing. Biden was asking Roberts whether he would defend the constitutionally protected right to privacy.

text: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez said, “I don’t need truckers. I get my food from the grocery store.”

claimReview.title: Posts attribute fabricated quote about truckers to Ocasio-Cortez
claimReview.textualRating: False. The quote was published by a website as satire but was later shared by some on social media as if real.

text: Utah is launching a digital driver’s license that can, or will be able to, track a wide range of information such as vaccine records and dietary preferences.

claimReview.title: Utah digital licenses don’t track vaccine data, dietary preferences
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The state is indeed rolling out a mobile driver’s license, but officials say its scope is limited only to license information. Some have aired privacy concerns and said that such programs could eventually be expanded to other records.

text: A clip shows former President Donald Trump saying at a rally that “Israel has hypnotized the world” and has committed “evil-doings.”

claimReview.title: A misleadingly-edited 2019 clip of Trump quoting Rep. Ilhan Omar on Israel is circulating online
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Trump was quoting and criticizing a since-deleted 2012 post by Rep. Ilhan Omar at a 2019 campaign rally the former president held in Minnesota, but that context has been edited out of the footage to make it seem like the words are his own opinion.

text: Freak storm buries Mexican city in hail

claimReview.title: Summer hail storm freezes Mexican city
claimReview.textualRating: True. Mexico’s second largest city, Guadalajara, was hit with a hail storm Sunday.

text: The New York Post published a story with the headline, “Congress to Vote on Bill That Would Criminalize Questioning the Events Surrounding 9/11.”

claimReview.title: Posts share fake New York Post story saying a bill would make it illegal to question 9/11
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such article was published, a New York Post spokesperson told The Associated Press. An image made to look like a screenshot of a New York Post article was fabricated and shared on social media.

text: Brazil used Smartmatic voting machines to “steal” the October 2022 presidential election, similar to how the 2020 election was manipulated in the U.S.

claimReview.title: Smartmatic voting machines not used in Brazil’s 2022 election
claimReview.textualRating: False. Smartmatic, a voting technology firm, does not provide voting machines in Brazil and did not supply any services for the 2022 presidential election, a spokesperson for the company stated. Claims that Smartmatic helped flip the 2020 election in the U.S. to Joe Biden are baseless, The Associated Press reported.

text: Speculation is rising over Indian-origin of Sen. Kamala Harris to become U.S. vice president if Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden is elected.

claimReview.title: Kamala Harris was born in the US
claimReview.textualRating: False. Kamala Harris was born in Oakland, California, not India.

text: Photo shows Swedish teenage climate activist Greta Thunberg with billionaire liberal philanthropist George Soros.

claimReview.title: Image manipulated to show teen climate activist with billionaire George Soros
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was manipulated to include Soros.

text: Photo shows Queen Elizabeth II,

claimReview.title: Photo of queen wearing Trump sash is altered
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. In the original image, the queen’s sash does not show any text.

text: Japan stopped mandatory childhood vaccinations in 1994, vastly improving the country’s infant mortality rate. By contrast, the U.S. has the highest childhood vaccination rate and has “the worst infant mortality rate of the western nations.”

claimReview.title: Differing infant mortality rates in Japan and the US are not connected to vaccine policies
claimReview.textualRating: False. Both countries have similar and very high childhood vaccination rates, despite their differing policies. While it’s true that Japan has a lower infant mortality rate than the U.S., public health experts say it is not because of vaccines, which actually reduce death in vaccine-preventable diseases.

text: Taco Bell is offering $60 and Walmart is offering $75 to customers who share and comment on their posts.

claimReview.title: Taco Bell, Walmart offers on Facebook are fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. These offers are not real and were posted by accounts impersonating Taco Bell and Walmart, both companies confirmed.

text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who is in charge of overseeing the Capitol Police, is responsible for security failures that allowed the Jan. 6 insurrection at the U.S. Capitol to happen.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely cite Pelosi as responsible for security during Capitol insurrection
claimReview.textualRating: False. Pelosi does not oversee day-to-day operations of the Capitol Police.

text: A new Massachusetts law providing driver’s licenses for immigrants in the country illegally will also automatically register them to vote in elections.

claimReview.title: Immigrants not auto enrolled to vote under new driver’s license law
claimReview.textualRating: False. The law passed by Massachusetts state lawmakers this summer prohibits immigrants without legal permission to reside in the U.S. from being automatically registered to vote. The law specifically mandates that the state Registrar of Motor Vehicles develop procedures and regulations to ensure that license applicants who are not citizens are not automatically registered to vote.

text: The World Health Organization admitted that COVID-19 vaccines can lead to multiple sclerosis.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent research on multiple sclerosis and COVID-19 vaccines found in WHO database
claimReview.textualRating: False. A database on the WHO website includes an abstract for a conference presentation about research that examined two recent cases of MS. The research found there might be a potential link to COVID vaccines, but did not definitively conclude the shots triggered the neurological disease, according to the global health agency and multiple sclerosis experts. One of the research authors also stressed COVID infection carries a higher risk of triggering MS than the COVID vaccine.

text: Air traffic maps show that a government spy plane has been circling over the Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Phoenix to monitor an audit of Maricopa County ballots taking place there.

claimReview.title: No one sent a ‘spy plane’ to surveil Arizona election audit
claimReview.textualRating: False. The maps show a Phoenix Police Department aircraft responding to police calls unrelated to the audit, according to the department.

text: Defendants arrested in connection with the Jan. 6 Capitol riot have been “locked up for months on end without being charged.”

claimReview.title: Jan. 6 defendants have been charged with crimes
claimReview.textualRating: False. More than 700 people have been arrested in connection with the riot — and each one has been charged.

text: A video of a helicopter dropping flames on treetops in Canada shows wildfires in the country are “a set up.”

claimReview.title: Video of helicopter conducting a planned burn doesn’t show Canada wildfires are a ‘set up’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage shows firefighters conducting a planned burn last weekend on the Donnie Creek wildfire in northeastern British Columbia. The ignition was being used to help contain the fire by taking away fuel, not to spread it.

text: All California voters if you are registered to vote as an independent you will not be able to vote Republican come 2020. You must go online and change to Republican. California changed the rules and is hoping no one figures it out in time.

claimReview.title: Independents in California can vote Republican in 2020 presidential election
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The post does not apply to the general election this fall.

text: Carbonated water doesn’t hydrate the body.

claimReview.title: Carbonated water is as hydrating as still water
claimReview.textualRating: False. Carbonated water provides just as much hydration as still water and is acceptable to drink as a substitute, according to nutritionists.

text: Virginia was caught switching 100,000 votes from President Donald Trump to Joe Biden in Fairfax County.

claimReview.title: Allegation of ballot ‘switching’ in Virginia is false
claimReview.textualRating: False. Election officials say a spreadsheet error led to Biden receiving an extra 100,000 votes, but it was quickly corrected. Votes were not taken from President Donald Trump.

text: Face masks can decrease oxygen intake, increase toxin inhalation and shut down the immune system.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim that wearing face masks harms health
claimReview.textualRating: False. Medical professionals say wearing masks do none of those things.

text: A video shows pro-Palestinian protesters and police clashing in the streets of Barcelona, Spain, amid

claimReview.title: An old and unrelated video from Spain is being misrepresented as a pro-Palestinian protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from 2020 and shows people railing against COVID-19 restrictions in Spain.

text: A photo of a Kroger receipt shows the supermarket chain is charging customers to support Black Lives Matter with a “BLM charge.”

claimReview.title: Photo of Kroger receipt is altered to show ‘BLM charge’ instead of change fee
claimReview.textualRating: False. This photo is “absolutely photoshopped,” a Kroger spokesperson confirmed to The Associated Press. The original version of the photo shows a fee for the current nationwide change shortage, not a fee related to Black Lives Matter.

text: Pfizer admits in its COVID-19 clinical trial protocol document that vaccinated people can “shed” the vaccine, emitting materials that can spread to unvaccinated people by inhalation or skin contact.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccine does not spread by inhalation or skin contact
claimReview.textualRating: False. COVID-19 vaccines that are in use, including the Pfizer vaccine, cannot spread between people. Posts making the false claim are misrepresenting standard language in the protocol document intended to protect pregnant women and monitor their potential exposure during clinical trials.

text: An Irish news site published a headline claiming, “Monkeypox can live on door handles and toilet seats for 120 years and can infect anyone from 5 miles away.”

claimReview.title: Fake headline about monkeypox spreads online
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such headline was published. A post made to appear that it contained information from the site was fabricated and shared on social media.

text: Photo shows damage to properties in the aftermath of Hurricane Dorian in the northern Bahamas on the Abaco Islands.

claimReview.title: Photo shows damage after 2018 storm, not Hurricane Dorian
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows devastation in Florida following Hurricane Michael in 2018.

text: Vice President Kamala Harris said that Hurricane Ian relief will be distributed based on race, with communities of color receiving aid first.

claimReview.title: Harris comments on addressing climate inequity misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: False. During a conversation with actress Priyanka Chopra Jonas at the Democratic National Committee’s Women’s Leadership Forum in Washington on Friday, Harris spoke about distributing resources equitably to help vulnerable groups, such as low income communities and communities of color, recover from disasters related to climate change. She did not describe the structure that would be used to allocate aid to victims of the recent hurricane.

text: Italy has revised its COVID-19 death toll numbers, showing 97% fewer COVID-19 deaths than initially recorded. This represented a change from over 130,000 deaths to under 4,000 deaths.

claimReview.title: Italy did not revise its COVID-19 death toll
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Italian Ministry of Health has not revised the number of deaths attributed to COVID-19 numbers, official data shows. Health officials say statistics in an Italian National Health Service report on the number of people who died of the virus with no comorbidities are being misrepresented.

text: COVID-19 vaccines that rely on messenger RNA technology will teach the body to attack itself, leading to autoimmune disease.

claimReview.title: No evidence COVID-19 vaccines lead to autoimmune disease
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence that the so-called messenger RNA, or mRNA, vaccines made by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna cause autoimmune disease.

text: Five environmental scientists who died in a plane crash were heading to East Palestine, Ohio.

claimReview.title: Plane crash victims were going to Ohio plant blast, not derailment
claimReview.textualRating: False. Five employees of an environmental consulting firm died in a plane crash near Little Rock, Arkansas, on Wednesday, but they were not traveling to East Palestine, where a freight train derailed on Feb. 3. The employees were responding to an unrelated Feb. 20 explosion at a metals plant in a Cleveland suburb more than 60 miles away.

text: Photo shows Mennonites joining the “freedom convoy,” a protest against the vaccine mandate for truckers in Canada.

claimReview.title: Photo of Mennonites in buggies not related to trucker vaccine protest in Canada
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows Old Order Mennonites going to church outside the Waterloo region in Ontario on Jan. 16, photographer Michelle Graham confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Experts with the Food and Drug Administration revealed that the COVID-19 vaccines are killing at least two people for every person they save.

claimReview.title: Public commenter, not FDA, falsely claimed COVID vaccines kill many
claimReview.textualRating: False. FDA experts did not say this, and strongly refuted this false claim in an email to The Associated Press. A speaker who is not affiliated with the FDA made these statements during the open public hearing portion of a Sept. 17 FDA vaccine advisory panel meeting.

text: A video that’s circulating on social media shows Taliban fighters dancing to a Drake song after their takeover of Afghanistan this week.

claimReview.title: Video shows men dancing in Pakistan months ago, not Taliban celebrating in Afghanistan
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, which shows men dancing, was originally filmed in Pakistan months ago. And the audio was altered before it was shared this week.

text: A bank owned by Dominion Voting Systems, Sequoia Capital, donated $2 million to Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis.

claimReview.title: No, a Dominion Voting Systems-owned bank didn’t give Ron DeSantis $2 million
claimReview.textualRating: False. A venture capitalist with Sequoia, a firm that finances emerging companies, contributed $2 million to a political group that is supporting DeSantis’ presidential bid. But Dominion does not own Sequoia Capital; it bought the assets of an unrelated company called Sequoia Voting Systems in 2010.

text: A video shows a virus turning people into zombies on a train in China.

claimReview.title: Video shows Indonesian ‘zombie’ train event, not virus in China
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows actors and participants during a zombie-themed event in Indonesia called “Train to Apocalypse” hosted by an event company and Jakarta’s Light Rail Transit in 2022.

text: A COVID-19 test patent application is dated 2020 but was actually filed in 2015.

claimReview.title: Patent application doesn’t show COVID test was developed in 2015
claimReview.textualRating: False. The patent application, for a system to determine if someone has a viral infection such as COVID-19, notes that a related provisional patent application was filed in 2015. But while the earlier provisional application is related to the technology in the 2020 application, it made no mention of COVID-19.

text: The Idaho government is offering materials on “porn literacy” to students as young as 8 years old.

claimReview.title: Idaho isn’t offering children ‘porn literacy’ materials
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Idaho Department of Health and Welfare offers schools an optional sex education program called “Reducing the Risk,” but that curriculum — used in grades 8 through 12 — does not include lessons on pornography. The organization behind the curriculum has published content dealing with porn literacy for teachers, but that material is separate from Reducing the Risk.

text: A video shows a train transporting American tanks and infantry fighting vehicles in Poland, after President Biden announced that the U.S. will send tanks to Ukraine.

claimReview.title: Video does not show American tanks on a train in Poland
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed along Highway 40 outside of Gorham, Kansas, by a local resident. U.S. officials said that it will take “many months” to deliver the Abrams tanks to Ukraine, according to AP reporting.

text: Former President Donald Trump in a statement wished President Joe Biden a speedy recovery from COVID-19 and referred to his own fight against the virus as “Herculean.”

claimReview.title: Trump did not issue statement on Biden’s COVID-19 diagnosis
claimReview.textualRating: False. This statement is fabricated, a Trump spokesperson confirmed on Twitter. It does not appear among the former president’s public statements on his website or on social media.

text: A photo shows former German Chancellor Angela Merkel in handcuffs.

claimReview.title: Photo of Merkel touring former prison edited to add handcuffs
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. A press photo of Merkel was edited to add the handcuffs around her wrists. The original photo, taken in August 2017, shows Merkel visiting a memorial at a former East German secret police prison in Berlin.

text: Starbucks is imposing a $1 surcharge for ordering iced beverages without ice or less ice.

claimReview.title: Hold the ice? Starbucks not charging extra for requesting less ice in drinks
claimReview.textualRating: False. A company spokesperson says there’s no change in price for ordering an iced drink that’s less icy. Earlier this month, however, Starbucks added a $1 fee for ordering its popular line of caffeinated juices without water.

text: Footage from the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol shows that Jacob Chansley, who participated in the riot sporting face paint, no shirt and a fur hat with horns, was “led through the Capitol by police the entire time he was in the building.”

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent rioter’s actions in Jan. 6 Capitol attack
claimReview.textualRating: False. Court documents and video footage from the attack on the Capitol make clear that Chansley, who is widely known as the “QAnon Shaman” and is one of the most recognizable Jan. 6 rioters, entered the Capitol without permission, was repeatedly asked to leave the building and was not accompanied at all times.

text: Pfizer’s new pill to treat COVID-19 is just ivermectin repackaged.

claimReview.title: Pfizer’s new pill to prevent COVID-19 is not the same as ivermectin
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ivermectin and the drug being tested to treat COVID-19 are structurally different. As one infectious disease expert said, “The only way they are alike is that they are both pills.”

text: A video clip shows the original name of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation was the Bill and Melinda Gates Institute for Population Control.

claimReview.title: Gates Foundation wasn’t named the Institute for Population Control
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has had the same name since 2000, and grew out of the William H. Gates Foundation. The foundation in 1999 funded an institute at John Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health called the Bill & Melinda Gates Institute for Population and Reproductive Health. The clip shows a woman introducing a 2008 lecture at Vassar College by Dr. Laurie Schwab Zabin, the institute’s founding director. The woman mistakenly refers to the institute as the “Institute for Population Control,” but full video from the event shows that Zabin later corrects her and reiterates that it is the “Institute for Population and Reproductive Health.”

text: Photos posted by former President Barack Obama’s half-brother show a passport issued to Obama that proves that he was born in Nairobi, Kenya.

claimReview.title: Photos show passport of Barack Obama Sr., not former president
claimReview.textualRating: False. Malik Obama did post photos of an old British passport, but he confirmed in an email to The Associated Press that the passport belonged to their father, Barack Obama Sr., not the former president. Details in the passport, which was issued several years before the younger Barack Obama was born in Hawaii, match that of Barack Obama Sr.

text: Members of the public can call the phone number 844-721-7237 and enter access code 9991787 to listen to live audio of Ghislaine Maxwell’s trial.

claimReview.title: Ghislaine Maxwell trial audio isn’t accessible by phone line
claimReview.textualRating: False. The phone number is from prior court proceedings and the code is no longer active. Callers to this number who use the code will receive the message: “your access code was not recognized,” as verified through an attempt by The Associated Press. Further, there is no such telephone line to listen to the trial audio, according to a statement from the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York.

text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi called herself a “wife, a mother, a grandmother, a daughter” on the floor of the House of Representatives this week after banning that type of gender-specific language in all House communications.

claimReview.title: Removal of gender-specific terms from House rules does not amount to a ban
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. A resolution passed in the House in early January struck several gender-specific terms from a document outlining House rules in a move to “honor all gender identities.” The change did not ban lawmakers from using such language in floor speeches or other congressional communications.

text: Video shows a man sniffing Vice President Kamala Harris at an NCAA Tournament game.

claimReview.title: Man wasn’t sniffing vice president at March Madness game
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video clip of the moment was distorted to misrepresent what was happening. A wider shot of the moment, which can be found in a full replay of Thursday’s Kansas vs. Howard matchup, shows the man is leaning forward to briefly communicate with a woman behind Harris’ left shoulder.

text: An aerial video of a man lying on his stomach in the middle of a road, being detained by authorities, shows police arresting Maine shooting suspect Robert Card.

claimReview.title: The Maine shooting suspect is still at large, a video spreading online doesn’t show his arrest
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the video shows someone being detained in Lewiston, Maine, it doesn’t show Card. The video began circulating online Wednesday night, but officials said at a press conference the next morning that Card remains at large.

text: Video shows that Ukrainians are finding abandoned or captured Russian military vehicles.

claimReview.title: Video of blogger driving tank was filmed last year
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is not current. A Russian blogger who identifies herself as Nastya Tyman posted the footage on social media in February 2021.

text: When former KKK Grand Wizard Robert Byrd died in 2010, he was eulogized by Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden.

claimReview.title: Biden did not eulogize former KKK "grand wizard"
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Biden did eulogize Sen. Robert C. Byrd when he died, but Byrd was not a "grand wizard" in the Ku Klux Klan. He was a member of the KKK in the early 1940s but later renounced his affiliation with the hate group.

text: A video shows President Joe Biden openly admitting to selling state secrets.

claimReview.title: Social media posts misconstrue Biden’s joke about selling ‘state secrets’
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Biden was making a joke at the outset of a roundtable with India’s prime minister. The video clip circulating on social media cuts off Biden’s remarks just before he makes it clear it was in jest. The official White House transcript of the comments and a longer version of the video shows the president immediately said he was only “kidding.”

text: Germany’s new restrictions for people who have not received the COVID-19 vaccine, and a potential vaccine mandate for all, violate the Nuremberg Code.

claimReview.title: Germany’s new COVID-19 measures don’t violate the Nuremberg Code
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Nuremberg Code, a set of ethical research principles created after World War II in response to atrocities committed by Nazi scientists, concern research involving human subjects, not public health interventions.

text: Picture shows Chicago Theatre’s marquee with the message “F--- Trump” during the President Donald Trump’s visit to the city Monday.

claimReview.title: Chicago Theatre marquee didn’t display profanity toward Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. The theater’s marquee advertised a concert, it did not show a profanity toward the president.

text: American teenager who killed a Muslim refugee for raping his sister sentenced to prison

claimReview.title: Video misrepresents footage to depict teenager arrested for killing a Muslim refugee
claimReview.textualRating: False. A viral video portraying a teenager sentenced to prison for killing a Muslim refugee is actually using footage from Dylan Schumaker’s trial, a teenager found guilty of murdering his girlfriend’s son in 2013.

text: Video shows White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre refusing to answer a Fox News reporter’s question about fossil fuel production.

claimReview.title: Biden press secretary didn’t walk out on reporter’s question
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. This clip has been edited to remove Jean-Pierre’s answer. The full video, which was posted by the White House’s official YouTube account, shows she responded to Fox News White House correspondent Peter Doocy’s question.

text: Video shows a nurse pretending to vaccinate actor Anthony Hopkins for COVID-19, but actually squirting the solution in the syringe onto the ground.

claimReview.title: Hospital did not fake vaccination of Anthony Hopkins
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for the hospital that administered the shot confirmed that Hopkins received a full vaccine dose. The excess fluid visible at the end of the video occupied the “dead space” in the needle system. This exists in any medication given by injection, the spokesperson said.

text: A video of a woman positioning herself upside down in a chair-like object, her arms resting in stirrups and her knees on the seat, shows a concept for new airplane seats.

claimReview.title: A video filmed at a New York art exhibit is being misrepresented as a new airplane seat concept
claimReview.textualRating: False. The structure is an artwork that was part of an exhibition at a New York City gallery earlier this year. It was created by Swedish artist Anna Uddenberg.

text: A news report shows that monkeypox has been detected in drinking water.

claimReview.title: No, monkeypox wasn’t found in Georgia drinking water
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip comes from an Atlanta-area news broadcast explaining how wastewater — not drinking water — can be tested for evidence of monkeypox’s spread. Wastewater is used water from toilets, sinks, showers and household appliances, which is completely separate from stores of drinking water. There is no evidence to suggest monkeypox is spreading in communities through drinking water, according to multiple medical experts.

text: The United Kingdom’s national healthcare system has stopped coronavirus vaccinations in Europe.

claimReview.title: No, Europe has not stopped offering COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. Not only does the U.K.’s National Health Service not control healthcare policy in other parts of Europe, it also hasn’t stopped administering all COVID-19 shots within its own borders. The island nation has stopped offering primary and secondary doses of the vaccination to any resident who seeks it, but the elderly and those considered high risk are still eligible for the initial doses or booster shots going forward.

text: Election equipment in Arizona was not certified by an accredited testing lab before it was used in the midterm election.

claimReview.title: Arizona election equipment was certified ahead of midterms
claimReview.textualRating: False. Voting equipment used in the 2022 election in Arizona was certified by the Arizona secretary of state and the U.S. Election Assistance Commission, according to spokespeople and documentation from both offices.

text: Almost 3,000 were killed by Hurricane Maria

claimReview.title: Nearly 3,000 dead after Hurricane Maria numbers re-examined
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. An independent study ordered by Puerto Rico reveals the death total to be nearly double the government’s original estimate.

text: CNBC host Jim Cramer tweeted

claimReview.title: Posts attribute fabricated tweet to CNBC host
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no record of Cramer posting such a tweet and a CNBC spokesperson confirmed it is not authentic.

text: New York Judge Juan M. Merchan wouldn’t let the defense call campaign finance expert Bradley A. Smith to testify in former President Donald Trump’s

claimReview.title: Judge in Trump’s hush money trial did not bar campaign finance expert from testifying for defense
claimReview.textualRating: False. Merchan did not bar Smith from testifying. Trump’s legal team chose to not call on him after the judge on Monday declined to broaden the scope of questioning the defense could pursue. The ruling echoed his pretrial ruling on the matter.

text: Democratic Rep. Ilhan Omar, a freshman congresswoman from Minnesota who is up for re-election this year, vowed to cut Social Security entitlements for seniors if she wins another term.

claimReview.title: Rep. Ilhan Omar did not say she would eliminate entitlements for seniors
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence Omar ever said this. The article being shared on social media this week matches the text of an older, satirical article.

text: Air fryers emit a dangerous electromagnetic field that can harm a person’s DNA and cells.

claimReview.title: Air fryers don’t emit harmful radiation, despite claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts and appliance companies say the fryers don’t use radiation to heat food, as a microwave would. Instead, it rapidly generates radiant heat that an internal fan then circulates around the food, much like in a typical convection oven.

text: A Labour Party billboard in New Zealand features Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern’s photo alongside the text

claimReview.title: New Zealand billboard promoting ‘Christmas booster’ shots is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. This billboard does not exist. A photo taken in August 2020 of a different billboard has been manipulated to add the text. The unedited image shows the original billboard with Ardern’s photo alongside the Labour Party’s campaign slogan: “Let’s keep moving,” ahead of the country’s general election.

text: Years before his presidency, Barack Obama said, “The American Dream is to be Donald Trump.”

claimReview.title: Barack Obama didn’t say ‘the American Dream is to be Donald Trump’
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Obama didn’t say or write this exact quote. The claim mischaracterizes a line in a paper Obama co-wrote while studying at Harvard University’s law school.

text: Kyle Rittenhouse’s mother, Wendy Rittenhouse, drove him across state lines and dropped him off at the protest in Kenosha, Wisconsin, with a rifle on the night he shot three people in August 2020.

claimReview.title: Post falsely claims that Kyle Rittenhouse’s mom drove him to Kenosha
claimReview.textualRating: False. According to testimony in Rittenhouse's murder trial, he drove to Kenosha the day before the shootings and spent the night at a friend’s house, where the gun used in the shooting was kept. It wasn’t until the next day that he took the gun from the house and went to the Kenosha protests, where the shootings occurred. The testimony was not challenged.

text: Democrats in Congress voted to allow noncitizens to vote in elections.

claimReview.title: Democratic proposal would not allow noncitizens to vote in elections
claimReview.textualRating: False. House lawmakers are weighing a proposal to provide federal grants to help states and other jurisdictions translate election materials into other languages. The bill, an amendment to the Voting Rights Act, doesn’t expand voting rights to noncitizens. Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee voted against adding language that would say this explicitly, but experts say such a clause was unnecessary, as federal law already prohibits noncitizens from voting in federal elections.

text: Pennsylvania has sent “255,000 unverified” voters ballots for the midterm elections.

claimReview.title: No, Pennsylvania didn’t send 255K ballots to ‘unverified’ voters
claimReview.textualRating: False. That claim misrepresents state data, which lists many voters as “not verified” for internal workflow purposes and includes, for example, voters requesting permanent mail-in ballots whose identities were verified in the primary election but will be re-checked for the general election, officials said. It does not mean that the voters failed to provide correct identification information, nor does it mean their identities weren’t ultimately verified.

text: Proposed California Assembly Bill 262 will allow the state to take physical possession and control of individuals, force vaccinations and seize property.

claimReview.title: California bill does not propose forced vaccinations
claimReview.textualRating: False. The proposed state bill requires county and city health officers to alert other local government agencies when a communicable disease outbreak strikes a community.

text: “The guy who had 81 million votes had 22 people show up to hear him speak in Georgia yesterday.”

claimReview.title: Post misrepresents crowd size at Biden drive-in rally
claimReview.textualRating: False. This post refers to a drive-in rally where President-elect Joe Biden campaigned alongside Democratic Senate candidates in Atlanta on Tuesday. Associated Press reporters at the event confirmed that hundreds of people were either in cars at the venue or lined up along the motorcade route to see Biden. The president-elect has routinely limited crowd size at events to adhere to social distancing guidelines during the pandemic.

text: Video shows a murder of crows flying over Kyiv, Ukraine, signaling the “end of times.”

claimReview.title: Video shows birds in Texas in 2017, not Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, which captures a flock of birds on a freeway in Houston, was originally posted in January 2017.

text: Social media personality Andrew Tate has been released from custody in Romania, an interview with Fox News host Tucker Carlson shows.

claimReview.title: Video shows months-old interview with Tucker Carlson and Andrew Tate
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Fox Nation video interview was posted on Aug. 25, 2022 on Carlson’s social media accounts. Tate, along with three others, will be detained for 30 days in Romania during an investigation, The Associated Press reported.

text: Seventy members of the Chinese Communist Party sit on Pfizer’s investment board.

claimReview.title: List doesn’t show Chinese Communist Party members on Pfizer board
claimReview.textualRating: False. A photo being shared online showing a spreadsheet of 70 names does not list members of the Chinese Communist Party who have seats on a Pfizer investment board. In fact, there is no such panel. A Pfizer spokeswoman told The Associated Press that none of the names on the list match the names of members on any of Pfizer’s existing boards or anyone affiliated with the company’s Chinese-based subsidiary, Pfizer Investments Co., Ltd.

text: Minnesota’s U.S. Rep. Ilhan Omar and Attorney General Keith Ellison urged people to vote twice in same election.

claimReview.title: Minnesota's Rep. Omar and Attorney General Ellison did not encourage voter fraud
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media posts have twisted the meaning of a popular 2012 campaign slogan to suggest Omar and Ellison encouraged voters to cast ballots twice on Election Day.

text: California DMV accidentally registers non-citizens

claimReview.title: California DMV accidentally registers non-citizens to vote
claimReview.textualRating: True. At lease one non-citizen and perhaps more were registered to vote by the California Department of Motor Vehicles between April 23 and Sept. 25.

text: The Obama administration used tear gas at the border once a month.

claimReview.title: Obama administration also used tear gas at the border
claimReview.textualRating: True. The Obama administration used tear gas on average once a month from fiscal year 2012 to fiscal year 2016. The majority of uses were at the border with Mexico, according to Corry Schiermeyer, press secretary for U.S. Customs and Border Protection.

text: A retiree from the military received a letter of appreciation signed by Donald Trump, signaling that Trump may still be the president of the United States.

claimReview.title: Military retirees can request letters of appreciation from former presidents
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Military letters of appreciation can be requested from any of the living former presidents, so receiving such a letter from a former president does not indicate he is still in office. Joe Biden won the 2020 election and is the current U.S. president.

text: A video shows an Iranian whistleblower demonstrating how they hacked a U.S. voter registration database during the 2020 election and created fraudulent overseas military ballots.

claimReview.title: Iranian ‘hacking’ video fabricated to push election disinfo
claimReview.textualRating: False. A federal investigation found that the video was fabricated to make it appear foreign actors fraudulently cast overseas ballots. The falsified video was released by Iranian nationals who were later indicted on federal charges for attempting to push disinformation ahead of the 2020 election, according to court documents and statements released by the U.S. Justice Department and the FBI.

text: Schools in the Dayton, Ohio, suburb of Kettering are vaccinating children for COVID-19 without notifying parents or requesting their consent.

claimReview.title: Schools in Ohio suburb aren’t vaccinating kids without parental consent
claimReview.textualRating: False. Kettering City Schools has not allowed and would not allow any minor student to be vaccinated without parental consent, according to a statement from Scott Inskeep, district superintendent. This bogus claim originated in early August, before students had returned to classes in the district.

text: Denmark has become the first country to suspend COVID-19 vaccinations.

claimReview.title: Denmark still offering COVID-19 vaccinations
claimReview.textualRating: False. Denmark is ending broad vaccination efforts, meaning they will no longer send out vaccination invitations or reminders, but people can still get vaccinated against COVID-19 as needed.

text: Images show black bags full of ballots being deposited at a tabulation center in Arizona’s Maricopa County in order to manipulate vote totals.

claimReview.title: Black ballot bags a normal part of Arizona county’s vote count
claimReview.textualRating: False. These black bags are used to carry counted ballots, but the image doesn’t show them being used fraudulently. The bags are brought into the tabulation center during audits to confirm that initial vote totals accurately reflect the number of ballots cast. These audits are a normal part of the vote-counting process in Maricopa County, a county spokesperson and former county elections official confirmed, and do not suggest an effort to inflate one candidate’s votes.

text: The Wall Street Journal reported that a deadly blast at a hospital in Gaza City on Tuesday was caused by an American-made weapon.

claimReview.title: Wall Street Journal did not tie the Gaza hospital blast to a US-made bomb, contrary to online claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such claim appears on the newspaper’s website or in online archives of the site. The Wall Street Journal confirmed to The Associated Press that it has not reported anything of this nature. There have been conflicting claims about who is responsible for the hospital blast.

text: An old photo of Adolf Hitler shows him holding up a bible in front of a crowd, similar to how U.S. President Donald Trump held a bible in front of a church Monday.

claimReview.title: Viral image edited to show Hitler holding bible
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo has been edited to show Hitler holding a bible. In the original photo, he is raising his hand in response to children saluting him.

text: Old campaign buttons show that Republicans have always described Democratic Party’s policies as socialism.

claimReview.title: GOP campaign buttons on socialism lifted from cartoon
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image purporting to show past presidential campaign buttons that equate Democratic policies with socialism was taken from an editorial cartoon.
