text: The letter “S,” standing for Satanist, has been added to the umbrella term often used for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and other queer people.

claimReview.title: LGBTQ not updated to add ‘S’ for Satanist
claimReview.textualRating: False. LGBTQ advocacy organizations told The Associated Press that they had not heard of any attempts to add an S to the initialism to represent the word Satanist.

text: The U.S. Supreme Court voted to overturn the 2020 election results.

claimReview.title: False 2020 election ruling attributed to the Supreme Court
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Supreme Court has not voted to overturn any 2020 election results. Past legal challenges to the 2020 presidential election have failed in lower courts.

text: South Africa’s Mpumalanga province spent 15 million rand in taxpayer money to erect statues of anti-apartheid activists Oliver Tambo and Winnie Mandela.

claimReview.title: Taxpayer money didn’t fund political statues in South Africa
claimReview.textualRating: False. The statues, which are privately owned and located on private property, were not created using taxpayer money, according to statements from both the provincial government and the owner of the gardens where the statues are located.

text: Photo shows Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden campaigning “to end fossil fuels” at a recent car rally.

claimReview.title: Biden did not ‘campaign to end fossil fuels’ at drive-in event
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden did not mention fossil fuels at the drive-in campaign event in Atlanta where this photo was taken. His platform also does not call for immediately stopping the use of fossil fuels.

text: Turkish President

claimReview.title: Turkey’s president hasn’t threatened to intervene in the Israel-Hamas war. He is being misquoted
claimReview.textualRating: False. The conservative Muslim president has said no such thing. A social media post he wrote recently about the ongoing conflict has been misquoted.

text: An

claimReview.title: Virginia house explosion not caused by firefight with federal agents. None were there
claimReview.textualRating: False. No federal agencies were present when the house exploded, according to the Arlington County Police Department. An investigation into the cause of the explosion is ongoing, officials said.

text: Since the Affordable Care Act was passed, nurses are required to administer the flu or pneumococcal vaccine to every patient without their consent.

claimReview.title: Health care law does not mandate that nurses give vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. Mandatory flu or pneumococcal vaccinations are not a requirement under the Affordable Care Act passed by Congress in 2010, as a post circulating on Facebook suggests.

text: A video from a speech shows Vice President Kamala Harris repeatedly saying that most people who were hospitalized or recently died from COVID-19 were vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Altered video twists Kamala Harris statements on COVID vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. Harris did not make these statements, according to the original video of the speech distributed by the White House. In the falsified version of the video, its audio track was manipulated to make it appear Harris said vaccinated people were being hospitalized and dying from COVID-19, when she actually said this was happening among unvaccinated people.

text: Qatar’s government created an infographic with instructions on how to behave during the 2022 World Cup, including rules that ban alcohol, homosexuality and dating.

claimReview.title: World Cup ‘rules’ graphic created by citizens group, not Qatari officials
claimReview.textualRating: False. The infographic being shared online was not created or released by Qatar’s government, according to the state agency in charge of organizing the World Cup. The graphic was created by a Qatari citizens group and published on social media as part of a campaign called “Reflect Your Respect.”

text: A photo shows the Taliban flag flying on the tower of the Afghanistan presidential palace in Kabul on Sunday night.

claimReview.title: Photo digitally altered to show Taliban flag on Afghan presidential palace
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are sharing a manipulated photo that makes it appear that the Taliban flag is flying above the palace.

text: Video shows Muslims in Birmingham, England, blocking roads and attacking vehicles during Ramadan because “they want the roads closed so they can break their fast, eating on the road.”

claimReview.title: Video does not show Muslims blocking a road in Birmingham, England
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows violent soccer fans after a local game in Switzerland in 2018.

text: Photo shows rappers Ice Cube and 50 Cent wearing hats that support President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: Photo altered to show rappers in hats with message that supports Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was altered to add a “Trump 2020” message to the hats.

text: Video shows battle tanks stuck in the mud in Ukraine.

claimReview.title: Video shows a military exercise in Sweden, not tanks in Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The original video shows Swedish army members during an exercise in April 2022 near the Revingehed military training area in the south of Sweden, a spokesperson for the Swedish military confirmed.

text: Video shows New York City police blasting an Orthodox Jewish funeral with a water cannon.

claimReview.title: Video does not show police clearing a Jewish funeral with a water cannon
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed in Jerusalem in November 2017 when a group of ultra-Orthodox Jews were protesting compulsory military service.

text: Photo shows “Deadpool” actor Ryan Reynolds wearing a T-shirt that refers to various political losers, including the Confederacy, Nazis and supporters of former President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: T-shirt text altered in photo of actor Ryan Reynolds
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The original image shows the actor wearing a shirt with text reading, “CONQUER COVID-19.”

text: A series of images shows a great white shark that washed up on an Outer Banks beach in North Carolina.

claimReview.title: Images of beached shark in North Carolina are not authentic
claimReview.textualRating: False. The images, which first appeared on a Facebook account which shares synthetic images of the Outer Banks barrier islands, are not authentic. A shark expert told The Associated Press there were several signs the images are not real. In addition, officials in the area said they weren’t aware of any recent reports of beached sharks.

text: Roadside workers in various parts of the U.S. have been sickened or killed by fentanyl-laced water offered to them by a passerby while on the job.

claimReview.title: Claims of roadside workers being given fentanyl-laced water by strangers are without merit
claimReview.textualRating: False. Officials in the areas cited say they are unaware of any reports of such incidents.

text: Less than 5 cents of every dollar of the $4 trillion “infrastructure” bill actually goes to infrastructure.

claimReview.title: Posts underestimate infrastructure funding in American Jobs Plan
claimReview.textualRating: False. No matter how you slice it, President Joe Biden’s initial infrastructure proposal unveiled March 31 allocates more than 5% of its funding to items that are widely considered infrastructure. A bipartisan infrastructure deal that Biden endorsed in June also dedicates significantly more than 5 cents of every dollar to core infrastructure projects such as roads, bridges, waterways, railways and airports.

text: Planned Parenthood Federation of America tweeted that if you want to use your white privilege to do good, you can donate to the organization with a specific request that it be used to help minority groups access abortion.

claimReview.title: Parody account, not Planned Parenthood, posted white privilege tweet
claimReview.textualRating: False. This tweet originated as satire, from an account impersonating Planned Parenthood. The organization confirmed the tweet wasn’t genuine and said the account’s tweets “do not reflect Planned Parenthood’s values.”

text: Rigged voting machine discovered in Ohio precinct.

claimReview.title: Voting machine not rigged in central Ohio
claimReview.textualRating: False. An election official in Franklin County, Ohio, said a voting machine there was not rigged; a paper jam led to an issue where a voter's selection for governor on the voting machine was different than what appeared on a paper record.

text: The U.S. Embassy in Beirut was evacuated on Oct. 11.

claimReview.title: The US didn’t order the evacuation of its embassy in Lebanon last week
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. Department of State debunked the claim at the time and confirmed Wednesday that the embassy near the Lebanese capital remains open and operational. The embassy has allowed the family members of some government officials to leave on a case-by-case basis. It is also recommending U.S. citizens leave the country.

text: Former President Barack Obama was filmed saying the U.S. must surrender to the “New World Order.”

claimReview.title: Obama doesn't say U.S. must surrender to "New World Order"
claimReview.textualRating: False. Obama did not say at the secretive Bilderberg Conference that the U.S must surrender to the “New World Order” because they are “too small-minded to govern their own affairs,” despite reports circulating online with a video.

text: Angela Chao, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell’s sister-in-law, who died in February, had been CEO of the company that owns Dali, the container ship that crashed into Baltimore’s Francis Scott Key Bridge.

claimReview.title: Online posts erroneously tie Senate minority leader’s late sister-in-law to ship that hit Baltimore bridge
claimReview.textualRating: False. Chao was the chair and CEO of her family’s shipping business, New York-based Foremost Group. Dali is owned by Grace Ocean Private Ltd. and managed by Synergy Marine Group, both of which are based in Singapore. Danish shipping giant Maersk said it had chartered the vessel.

text: Colon cancer rates are on the rise because people absorb toxins from their microwave ovens.

claimReview.title: Microwave oven use not linked to colon cancer
claimReview.textualRating: False. The microwave energy that the appliances emit is not capable of causing cancer, experts told The Associated Press. While the rate of colorectal cancer among young people has increased in recent years, this trend is unrelated to microwave use, according to a colon cancer advocacy group.

text: Dr. Anthony Fauci’s wife is the chief of bioethics and human subjects research at the National Institutes of Health. That means she’s the one who rubber stamps exceptions to normal drug and vaccine testing.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines are approved by the FDA, not Fauci’s wife
claimReview.textualRating: False. The COVID-19 vaccines received emergency use approval from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, not the NIH.

text: Oktoberfest in Germany banned Budweiser brands.

claimReview.title: Satirical post falsely claims Oktoberfest banned Budweiser
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim stems from a satirical website that includes a disclaimer that everything it publishes “is fiction.” No such announcement has been made by either Oktoberfest or Budweiser, and the festival only allows beer from Munich breweries.

text: Video shows Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau being ignored by Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro at the Group of 20 summit in Osaka, Japan.

claimReview.title: Brazilian president did not snub Canadian prime minister at G-20
claimReview.textualRating: False. Video from the event was cut to make it appear that Bolsonaro rejected Trudeau’s attempt to shake hands.

text: A proposal in New York would mandate doctors submit patient vaccination records to the state.

claimReview.title: Opt out included in proposed NY vaccination records submission law
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Doctors will be required to submit immunization records for people 19 and older under this legislation; however, patients can opt out of submitting the records.

text: A photo shows a man in Poland gesturing with both his middle fingers at President Joe Biden.

claimReview.title: Photo shows man in Poland giving Biden thumbs-up, not middle finger
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The original photo shows an audience member giving Biden a double thumbs-up on Tuesday following the president’s address at the Royal Castle Gardens in Warsaw, Poland. Both Biden and the White House shared the photo showing the thumbs-up on their official Twitter accounts.

text: “Just be grateful you weren’t born in a 3rd world country like Los Angeles, California, USA” -- comment written on a photo showing makeshift shelters on train tracks, near apartment buildings.

claimReview.title: Photo shows makeshift camp in Paris, not Los Angeles
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is of a makeshift camp in Paris, not Los Angeles.

text: Research by scientists at the University of Queensland in Australia has proven that bananas bolster the immune system due to the super source of vitamin B-6 and helps prevent coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Bananas do not help prevent the coronavirus
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video circulating on social media that claims to show researchers at the University of Queensland finding a tie between preventing the coronavirus and bananas has been manipulated. Bananas do not help prevent the coronavirus.

text: The National Gallery in London is removing a portrait by Jan van Eyck due to complaints that the painting resembles Russian President Vladimir Putin.

claimReview.title: No, London gallery isn’t removing painting for Putin likeness
claimReview.textualRating: False. The painting is still on display at the National Gallery in London and there are no plans to remove it from the museum, a spokesperson for the museum confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates wrote an article for The Sovereign Independent in 2011 called “Depopulation by Forced Vaccination

claimReview.title: UK newspaper article wrongly attributed to Bill Gates
claimReview.textualRating: False. Gates did not write this article. The newspaper used a quote from Gates out of context to support the misleading idea, but the text of the story was written by another author, according to a web archive of the page.

text: Because 14 people in Pfizer’s placebo group died and 15 people in the vaccinated group also died, Pfizer’s data shows its COVID-19 vaccine does not reduce the risk of dying from the disease.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Pfizer data on vaccine efficacy
claimReview.textualRating: False. Those figures reflect deaths from all causes during Pfizer’s ongoing study of its vaccine. Pfizer’s data shows that the vaccine is highly effective at preventing serious illness. Data from countries that have used the vaccine widely shows it is also effective at preventing death from COVID-19.

text: Video shows a fracture in Earth’s crust created by recent earthquakes in Turkey.

claimReview.title: Video shows river erosion in China, not Turkey earthquake aftermath
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the severe earthquakes in Turkey this month did rupture the Earth’s surface, this video shows river erosion in China’s Loess Plateau, which is unrelated to earthquakes.

text: A video shows a makeup artist applying dirt and fake blood to a young girl on a stretcher, proving that people in Gaza are faking injuries in the

claimReview.title: A short film from Lebanon is being misrepresented to accuse Palestinians of staging injuries
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is behind-the-scenes footage from a short film made in Lebanon. The director of the film shared a post debunking the false claims around the clip.

text: A California bill would allow “illegal immigrants” to become police officers.

claimReview.title: Posts distort California bill allowing non-citizen police officers
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bill would permit non-citizens who are authorized to work in the U.S. to become police officers. Federal law already bars employers from hiring immigrants who are not authorized to work in the country.

text: Map shows the states where it’s possible for a 3-year-old child to receive gender-affirming surgery.

claimReview.title: Toddlers can’t get gender-affirming surgeries, despite claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The map shows which states have passed or are considering anti-transgender laws. Children as young as 3 are not qualified to undergo operations to change their gender, medical experts say. Nationally-recognized medical guidelines recommend patients be at least 15 years old to receive the surgeries, and only then in special circumstances.

text: Following a ban on face masks, protesters in Hong Kong use wearable face projectors that disable the facial recognition system used by the government.

claimReview.title: Hong Kong protesters not using wearable projectors to block facial recognition
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video circulating on social media that shows a wearable projector is conceptual. It doesn’t work.

text: Vice President Mike Pence “did have the right to change the outcome” of the 2020 election but chose not to use it.

claimReview.title: Vice president doesn’t have power to ‘change the outcome’ of elections
claimReview.textualRating: False. The vice president has no power to unilaterally “change” or overturn the presidential election results of a state under the Constitution or any law, experts say.

text: U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin sent a text to all active duty military personnel saying they all needed to be vaccinated for COVID-19 by 10 a.m. the next day or they would be court-martialed. As a result of the requirement, 12 F-22 pilots quit their jobs.

claimReview.title: US defense secretary didn’t require military to get vaccines overnight
claimReview.textualRating: False. A Department of Defense spokesperson explained that the department does not send mass texts to the force and is not aware of any Air Force pilots walking off the job. The false claim bears resemblance to a satirical article published earlier this month.

text: A video captures a single engine airplane crashing into a youth soccer game.

claimReview.title: Video of plane crashing into soccer field is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was digitally altered to add the plane crash. The edited clip was created using a visual effect that shows a plummeting plane, which can be downloaded for free and applied to videos. The original video, which does not include the plane crash, has appeared online since at least 2018.

text: Swiss regulatory agencies have formally approved the Sarco capsule, a mobile, 3D-printed chamber for carrying out assisted suicide.

claimReview.title: No, Switzerland has not approved a ‘suicide capsule’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The device — which is still a prototype — has not been approved for use by any Swiss agencies. The machine’s creator says he did not seek such approval because he believes his organization does not need it under current legal guidelines. SwissMedic, the national authorization agency for drugs and medical products, said it had not heard of the capsule until it gained widespread media attention recently.

text: "Looters" steal children’s ‘Thomas the Tank Engine’ mall train during Minneapolis protests.

claimReview.title: Photo of a children’s train being driven down a street is from 2014 protests in Ferguson
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo of people driving a children’s train down a city street was taken in August 2014 during protests in Ferguson, Missouri.

text: The coronavirus outbreak spreading from China is nothing new, patents were created around it years ago.

claimReview.title: Patents being shared online are not related to new virus in China
claimReview.textualRating: False. The patents being shared online are not related to the new virus that has sickened hundreds of people in China and caused concern around the world. The virus, which causes coughing, fever, breathing difficulty and pneumonia, was being blamed on Friday for at least 25 deaths in China.

text: A recently published study shows that ivermectin is more effective than remdesivir in reducing mortality when treating COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Flawed research abstract leads to ivermectin falsehoods
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The research detailed in the one-page abstract was not from a peer-reviewed study, nor was it a clinical trial. It relied on existing data from patient records and the full manuscript was withdrawn after the authors and reviewers found major flaws, including that the patients given ivermectin were on average younger and less sick than the hospitalized patients administered remdesivir. The researchers and experts told The Associated Press that the findings are no longer relevant.

text: Chuck Schumer accused of rape by daughter’s friend

claimReview.title: Statement falsely attributed to Sen. Chuck Schumer
claimReview.textualRating: False. A photo of U.S. Sen. Chuck Schumer, of New York, has been circulating online with an incorrect caption saying, “I’m Democrat Senator Chuck Schumer. My daughter’s 16-year-old girlfriend accused me of raping her. When nobody listened to her, she committed suicide. You are not to question my innocence!”

text: Video shows French President Emmanuel Macron becoming a “human wreath” during his official welcome to French Polynesia, as leis are layered over him from his head to his knees.

claimReview.title: Video exaggerates flowery welcome for Macron in French Polynesia
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was manipulated to add numerous garlands beyond those draped around his neck as he arrived in Tahiti for meetings in French Polynesia. News footage from the event shows Macron with leis reaching from his neck to his stomach.

text: The Biden administration “dedicated two commemorative coins” to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

claimReview.title: Private gift shop, not White House, selling coins honoring Zelenskyy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The White House Gift Shop, which is a private company and not part of the federal government, is selling the coins.

text: Book sales for bestselling author Stephen King have dropped “90% since he went woke.”

claimReview.title: Claims that Stephen King’s book sales have plummeted originated as satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim originated on a satire website. There are no credible indications that King’s book sales have seen a significant drop. As of Wednesday, his most recent novel, “Holly,” was No. 1 on multiple bestsellers lists, including from Publishers Weekly, The New York Times and USA Today. Representatives for King and his publisher also confirmed to The Associated Press that there is no truth to the claim.

text: Prosecutors in the District of Columbia recently filed criminal charges against Ivanka Trump and her brothers.

claimReview.title: Prosecutors in DC haven’t charged Trump’s children with crimes
claimReview.textualRating: False. District prosecutors have not filed any criminal charges against Ivanka Trump, or her brothers Eric Trump and Donald Trump Jr., according to a spokesperson for the Office of the Attorney General for the District of Columbia. The YouTube commentator who made the claim has also admitted it is false.

text: Video shows Dutch farmers protesting in the Netherlands in 2022.

claimReview.title: Video shows 2015 farmers’ protest in Brussels
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows farmers in Brussels protesting falling dairy prices in September 2015.

text: Police in Oklahoma used “PIG” as the name on a Starbucks order from a mobile application to plant a false story for sympathy.

claimReview.title: Starbucks’ employee responsible for 'PIG’ on order by police
claimReview.textualRating: False. A Starbucks employee wrote “PIG” on a Thanksgiving Day order placed in person by a police officer in Kiefer, Oklahoma. The officer was buying five beverages for 911 dispatchers as a thank you for working the holiday.

text: Video shows cops in India “brutally assault an elderly Muslim man” amid religious protests in the country.

claimReview.title: Video of Indian police hitting man is from 2020, not 2022 protests
claimReview.textualRating: False. Despite the footage being shared in 2022 with comments suggesting it is related to the recent protests, the video is from 2020. Authorities have said the incident occurred as police tried to disperse an unlawful gathering during COVID-19 restrictions.

text: During a eulogy for the late U.S. Rep. John Lewis, as part of an argument for mail-in voting, former President Barack Obama told a room full of people that "rooms full of people" are unsafe.

claimReview.title: Obama did not say ‘rooms full of people’ are unsafe during John Lewis eulogy
claimReview.textualRating: False. Obama never referenced “rooms full of people” in his eulogy. He argued that the 2020 election would depend on mail-in ballots “so people don’t get sick,” but he did not argue that in-person polling places should not be open.

text: White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was recently in a car accident while driving drunk and the Metropolitan Police Department of D.C. responded to the scene.

claimReview.title: Posts spread baseless claim about Karine Jean-Pierre
claimReview.textualRating: False. MPD has no record of such an incident or arrest, according to a department spokesperson. A spokesperson for the White House further confirmed that the claims are baseless. The claim first emerged from an anonymous Twitter account which provided no evidence and shared photos of old and unrelated incidents.

text: The Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that the majority of people who get sick with COVID-19 wear masks.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent CDC study examining mask use
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Masks are designed to prevent the spread of the virus by the person wearing it and some studies have shown that masks can offer some protection to those who wear them.

text: Former President Barack Obama is relocating to Kenya.

claimReview.title: Claim about Obama moving to Kenya stems from satirical article
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim originated from an April Fools’ Day article that was originally published by The Standard, a major newspaper in Kenya. Obama has made no such announcement.

text: Video shows 13 children lying on the floor dead after receiving the COVID-19 vaccine at a school in South Africa.

claimReview.title: Children in video died in stampede, not after receiving COVID-19 vaccine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, taken in 2020, shows children who died in a stampede at school in Kenya. The Department of Health in South Africa confirmed to the AP that the claim being shared was false.

text: The World Economic Forum published an infographic on diets that suggested that humans will eat “40% less food” by 2030 and that “fresh fruit and vegetables will be replaced by supplements made by WEF-partnered corporations,” among other things.

claimReview.title: WEF graphic on diet changes by 2030 is fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. Contrary to a WEF logo on that image, the organization confirmed to The Associated Press that it did not create the graphic.

text: During the Democratic presidential debate, “Trump” was said 1,326 times, “free” was said 683 times, Spanish was spoken 14 times and “America” was said twice.”

claimReview.title: Democrats spoke of America frequently during the debates
claimReview.textualRating: False. Nearly every Democratic candidate mentioned America during the first televised debates, held June 26 and 27 in Miami.

text: A governor who forces people to wear masks, keep distance from others and stay home has a mental illness known as Münchausen syndrome by proxy.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent mask and distancing orders as Münchausen syndrome by proxy
claimReview.textualRating: False. Münchausen syndrome by proxy is a form of medical abuse by which a caregiver makes up, exaggerates or creates health problems for someone in their care in order to get attention and sympathy. Statewide mask, social distancing and stay-at-home orders are different, child medical abuse experts say. Such orders aim to keep healthy people from getting sick, not feign illness.

text: On election night in 2020, a burst water pipe at a ballot processing site in Georgia’s Fulton County allowed workers to steal the election from former President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: Misinfo about 'suitcases' of ballots and a burst pipe in 2020 return after Trump's Georgia indictment
claimReview.textualRating: False. A water leak briefly delayed ballot processing in Atlanta’s State Farm Arena early that morning. Unrelated surveillance footage from the late evening showed workers removing ballot containers from under a table after confusion arose about when work was ending for the night. This was the subject of false claims that it depicted workers pulling out “suitcases” of illicit votes, but investigators later determined it was part of normal ballot processing and there was no evidence of improper ballots.

text: Former President Donald Trump spent Memorial Day in 2020 golfing, while President Joe Biden spent Memorial Day in 2021 paying tribute to fallen soldiers at a wreath-laying ceremony.

claimReview.title: Trump honored Memorial Day with back-to-back events in 2020
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Trump last year spent Memorial Day attending a wreath-laying ceremony at Virginia’s Arlington National Ceremony and giving remarks at Baltimore’s historic Fort McHenry. He spent the Saturday and Sunday before the holiday golfing at his private club in Virginia.

text: KitchenAid has stopped offering its famous stand mixers and other familiar appliances at Target stores following backlash over the retailer’s support of the LGBTQ+ community.

claimReview.title: Article claiming KitchenAid has pulled items from Target shelves is satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claims originated from a satirical news website that labels its content as “fiction.” KitchenAid products are still for sale on Target’s online store.

text: Kyle Rittenhouse has filed a $60 million defamation lawsuit against Whoopi Goldberg and Joy Behar, both hosts of “The View.” He has also filed a suit against CNN.

claimReview.title: Kyle Rittenhouse hasn’t sued Whoopi Goldberg, Joy Behar or CNN
claimReview.textualRating: False. Rittenhouse has not filed a lawsuit against any individual or organization, his spokesperson told The Associated Press.

text: This picture won the Pulitzer Prize in 1960. It shows a priest giving the last rites to a Cuban farmer, owner of his land. He refused to work for the Castro regime. He died by a firing squad after a trial by Che Guevara that lasted 4 minutes. You will never see this picture on a T-shirt.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Cuban farmer about to be executed under Castro
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is being misrepresented online to send a message about socialism.

text: A video shows President Joe Biden singing the children’s song “Baby Shark” while speaking in California.

claimReview.title: Video of Biden singing ‘Baby Shark’ is a deepfake
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. Footage from Biden’s remarks at a community college in Irvine, California, on Friday was manipulated using deepfake technology to make it appear he was singing the tune. The man who made the altered video told The Associated Press that he used deepfake technology to create it.

text: President Joe Biden’s outdoor signing of the Emmett Till Anti-Lynching Act, shown in numerous photographs, could not have happened on Tuesday because the White House South Lawn was completely empty and the weather was freezing cold.

claimReview.title: Biden signed anti-lynching act into law on Tuesday
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden signed the bill in the White House Rose Garden, not on the South Lawn. Associated Press photos prove the event happened on Tuesday, and government records of the bill’s progress show the same.

text: A bill signed into law this week by Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer prohibits vote recounts based on election fraud allegations.

claimReview.title: Michigan bill does not prohibit recounts based on allegations of election fraud
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bill, SB 603, does not prohibit such recounts, according to two state senators involved in updating the laws around recounts. It stipulates that candidates may request a recount if they have a “good-faith belief” that they would have had a “reasonable chance” to win the election if not for an “error” in the vote counting process. That means that the number of votes the petitioning candidate requests to be recounted must be greater than the difference of votes between them and the winning candidate.

text: Six hundred thousand Americans die from COVID-19 shots each year.

claimReview.title: UK data misrepresented in false COVID-19 vaccine claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. The number is based on an extrapolation of misinterpreted U.K. government data. Only nine deaths caused by COVID-19 vaccines have been confirmed by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Those cases were causally associated with rare blood clots caused by the Johnson & Johnson shot, which has been largely sidelined by officials.

text: U.S. Rep. Ayanna Pressley tweeted that IQ is a “measure of whiteness.”

claimReview.title: Fake tweet about ‘whiteness’ attributed to Black lawmaker
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for the Boston Democrat says the phrase was never tweeted from her account. A review of Pressley’s Twitter feed and archived versions of it maintained by watchdog groups also didn’t turn up such a phrase.

text: An image of grocery store shelves fully stocked with soup cans is from former President Donald Trump’s America, while an image of nearly empty grocery store shelves is from President Joe Biden’s America.

claimReview.title: Photos don’t show grocery shelves during Trump and Biden presidencies
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The photo described as Trump’s America was captured in 2012 in Australia, while the photo described as Biden’s America was taken after a hurricane in South Carolina in 2018, when Trump was president. It’s true that some grocery stores have temporarily struggled to keep shelves stocked during the pandemic, but these images are misrepresented.

text: Governments can “forcibly remove” people living on polluted land or water and require them to live in “smart cities” under a plan from the World Economic Forum and United Nations called Agenda 2030.

claimReview.title: UN, WEF agenda won't force people to live in ‘smart cities’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.N.’s 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, which the World Economic Forum is helping to implement through a partnership, outlines broad goals related to issues such as economic growth, equality and the environment. It does not discuss removing people from their homes, nor does it refer to the term “smart cities.” Regardless, the U.N. does not have the power to allow, or prohibit, countries to take such an action.

text: No test can identify COVID-19 variants. Tests can only determine if a person is positive or negative for the disease.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 variants tested through genome sequencing
claimReview.textualRating: False. Variants can be tested through genome sequencing, which can take place after a COVID-19 test comes back positive.

text: A woman who is raped and seeks an abortion in Texas could be put to death.

claimReview.title: Abortion in Texas is not punishable by death
claimReview.textualRating: False. Women cannot be put to death in Texas for seeking an abortion, although one lawmaker has proposed legislation that would criminalize the procedure.

text: Photo shows Ghislaine Maxwell, the ex-girlfriend and longtime confidant of sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, posing on a chair with United States Chief Justice John Roberts.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show John Roberts with Ghislaine Maxwell
claimReview.textualRating: False. Maxwell is pictured with French modeling agent Jean-Luc Brunel, not John Roberts.

text: A convicted felon was sworn in as mayor of Markham, Illinois after the state’s governor intervened.

claimReview.title: Convicted felon sworn in as mayor after receiving the most votes
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. Roger Agpawa was named the top vote getter in the 2017 Markham race for mayor, but an Illinois appeals court ruled against him in April. The court found that he could not accept the position due to a 1999 mail fraud conviction.

text: If a thief forces you to take money out of any ATM, you can punch in your PIN backward and the machine will immediately alert the police, take photos of the suspect and withdraw the cash but keep it stuck in the slot.

claimReview.title: Entering ATM PIN backward won’t alert police
claimReview.textualRating: False. No known ATM in the United States has this feature, according to ATM security experts. A similar system was patented in the late 1990s, but it has never been widely implemented.

text: A photo shows Queen Elizabeth II laughing at her husband, Prince Philip, who pranked her by dressing up as a palace guard.

claimReview.title: Photo shows queen laughing at bees, not Prince Philip
claimReview.textualRating: False. Though the photo is a real image from 2003, the queen was actually reacting to a swarm of bees that had interrupted a review of a British Army regiment, according to the original caption and the photographer. Philip, who was the colonel of that regiment, was dressed in its uniform, as he had done before on multiple occasions.

text: The BBC tweeted that Saudi Arabia had announced intentions to hold an “International Straight Pride Month” in June 2022.

claimReview.title: Fake BBC tweet pushes bogus claims of Saudi ‘Straight Pride Month’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Online searches and a statement from the British broadcaster confirm this is not an authentic tweet. Saudi Arabia has not announced plans for any such holiday.

text: Canada and the U.K. both banned Fox News.

claimReview.title: Fox News is not banned in Canada or the UK
claimReview.textualRating: False. Fox News has not been banned in Canada, where it remains authorized for distribution. The network also was not banned in the U.K., although Fox News voluntarily stopped broadcasting there in 2017.

text: Photo shows President Joe Biden kneeling down to the Israeli president, “pledging unconditional support to Israel.”

claimReview.title: Photo shows Biden kneeling to respect Israeli president’s aide
claimReview.textualRating: False. Multiple media outlets wrote about the photo, which shows Biden kneeling before Rivka Ravitz, chief of staff for the Israeli president, after learning she had 12 children.

text: The CEO of Anheuser-Busch resigned after the brewing company’s Bud Light beer brand partnered with Dylan Mulvaney, a transgender social media influencer, for a sponsored video.

claimReview.title: Anheuser-Busch CEO didn’t resign after Bud Light ads
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim started as a satirical article and used the wrong name in references to the CEO. Anheuser-Busch confirmed that the company’s CEO didn’t resign.

text: Pfizer has acknowledged in a statement it conducted “gain of function” research as part of its development of a vaccine and a separate medical treatment for COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Experts: Pfizer tests on COVID vaccines, treatment in line with industry standards
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts said nothing in a recent statement by the company suggests it’s conducting research designed to make COVID-19 more harmful, as some social media users claim. The company said the research was being done to assess the effectiveness of the vaccine and the antiviral medication Paxlovid against new COVID variants.

text: Photos in a Facebook post compare the environmental impact of the Keystone pipeline, which is shown minimally impacting the lush greenery around it, and a lithium mine, which is shown as a barren pit.

claimReview.title: Post misrepresents photos of Alaska pipeline and gold mine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The post mislabels the images, which show the trans-Alaska pipeline and a gold mine in Australia.

text: A video shows Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez crying on CNN due to backlash over Rep. Jamaal Bowman

claimReview.title: Video doesn’t show Rep. Ocasio-Cortez crying on CNN, contrary to online claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. Footage of Ocasio-Cortez’s interview on CNN’s “State of the Union” on Sunday morning shows she never cried during the appearance. The video circulating online includes a deceptive thumbnail of the Democratic lawmaker crying during an unrelated Congressional hearing in 2019.

text: Pfizer warns people not to have unprotected sex after the second COVID-19 vaccine dose for up to 28 days because of the risk of “birth defects due to genetic manipulation.”

claimReview.title: Video misrepresents Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine clinical trial protocol
claimReview.textualRating: False. Pfizer didn’t say that its COVID-19 vaccine may cause birth defects. A Pfizer document issued before the vaccine received emergency authorization from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration states that people who participated in clinical trials should take measures to avoid pregnancy. Pregnant women are excluded from clinical trials for safety purposes.

text: Photo shows Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer drinking beer at a bar during the COVID-19 pandemic, flouting social distancing restrictions.

claimReview.title: Michigan's governor didn't ignore social distancing rules for beer tasting
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is presented out of context. It was actually taken during the governor’s visit to Lansing Brewing Company in February 2019, more than a year before Michigan’s first confirmed case of COVID-19.

text: A train that derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, was carrying a chemical that was banned in 1974.

claimReview.title: Chemical on derailed Ohio train isn’t banned in all products
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Vinyl chloride, one of the chemicals on the freight train that derailed in East Palestine last month, was banned for use in aerosol products in 1974 by the Consumer Product Safety Commission. However, the compound is still allowed to be used in other products, such as plastic.

text: A video experiment shows how aluminum and mercury contained in vaccines can chemically react and cause clots.

claimReview.title: Video doesn’t illustrate reaction of vaccine ingredients
claimReview.textualRating: False. The original video shows two metals reacting and made no mention of vaccines. Small amounts of aluminum salts have long been used in vaccines as an immune booster, and a mercury-based preservative is used in some vaccines but its use has been scaled back. Those vaccine ingredients are not pure metals and would not have the chemical reaction shown in the video.

text: A Mayo Clinic doctor tweeted about purposely misdiagnosing the pregnancies of former President Donald Trump’s supporters to influence them to have abortions.

claimReview.title: Impersonator, not Mayo Clinic doctor, tweeted about misdiagnosing pregnancies
claimReview.textualRating: False. This years-old tweet came from an impersonator account, not a real Mayo Clinic employee.

text: A Pfizer warehouse in North Carolina damaged by a tornado was stocked with the company’s COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Contrary to claims, Pfizer plant damaged by tornado didn’t hold COVID vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. Pfizer does not manufacture or store its COVID-19 vaccine or treatment for the disease at the facility, a company representative told The Associated Press. The plant is used to manufacture sterile injectable medicines, such as drugs used in IV infusions.

text: Ireland’s government and a local diversity nonprofit distributed a flyer near Dublin instructing girls to stay indoors after 6 p.m. because of new immigrants “not accustomed to Irish cultural norms.”

claimReview.title: Fabricated flyer falsely claims girls in Ireland are under curfew
claimReview.textualRating: False. The two groups named on the flyer — the Irish Centre for Diversity and the Irish government as a whole — did not create or distribute the flyers, representatives for both confirmed to The Associated Press. Irish police said the matter is under investigation.

text: //apnews.com/article/fact-checking-afs

claimReview.title: False claims persist over shredded election trash in Georgia
claimReview.textualRating: False. Cobb County election officials hired a shredding company to destroy non-relevant leftover election materials. The images show inner privacy envelopes voters used to seal their ballots. The actual ballots and the outside envelopes with voter signatures have been preserved, along with other relevant materials.

text: United States Surgeon General Vivek Murthy in an interview on MSNBC advised vaccinated Americans to wear masks at home with their kids and outside.

claimReview.title: Surgeon general didn’t advise masking at home with kids
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Murthy did not say vaccinated Americans should wear masks at home with their kids. He briefly seemed to advise wearing a mask outdoors, but later specified that when there is a lot of virus circulating in the community, vaccinated people may want to wear masks in indoor settings outside the home.

text: Two images available from third-party mugshot websites show Mauricio Garcia, the gunman in Sunday’s deadly shooting at a Dallas-area mall.

claimReview.title: Dallas mugshots misrepresented as gunman in mall shooting
claimReview.textualRating: False. The mugshots show a person named Mauricio Garcia, but not the one who carried out the attack, according to the Dallas County Sheriff’s Department. The shooter had no prior criminal history, according to officials.

text: Only people vaccinated against COVID-19 are having random heart attacks.

claimReview.title: Heart attacks afflict people regardless of vaccination status
claimReview.textualRating: False. Both unvaccinated and vaccinated people suffer heart attacks, and research has not found any link between COVID-19 vaccines and a higher incidence of heart attacks, experts say.

text: Flights across the U.S. are backed up because pilots and crew are walking off boarded flights and refusing to take the mandated vaccine.

claimReview.title: Airline flight delays in Florida were not related to vaccine mandates
claimReview.textualRating: False. Recent delays and cancellations in airline travel were caused by adverse weather conditions, resurgence of leisure travel and a shortage of employees due to voluntary leaves of absence granted last year.

text: Klaus Schwab, the founder of the World Economic Forum, wrote a book that included a passage about a plan to kill billions of “useless eaters” through war, disease and starvation.

claimReview.title: WEF’s Schwab didn't write book about exterminating 4 billion people
claimReview.textualRating: False. The passage comes from a book promoting conspiracy theories written by an author called John Coleman.

text: In a clip, the president of Ireland is seen showing U.S. President Joe Biden where to stand during a photo op.

claimReview.title: Irish politician misidentified in clip with Biden
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip shows Biden posing with Seán Ó Fearghaíl, speaker of Irish parliament’s lower chamber, and Jerry Buttimer, speaker of Irish parliament’s upper chamber. Irish President Michael D. Higgins does not appear in the clip.

text: The NCAA is transferring medals won by transgender swimmer Lia Thomas to Riley Gaines, another former Division I swimmer.

claimReview.title: The NCAA is not taking medals away from transgender athlete Lia Thomas
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim first appeared in an article that is clearly labeled as satire. An NCAA spokesperson told The Associated Press that Thomas and Gaines tied for fifth place in the women’s 200-yard freestyle race at a 2022 championship meet and that the results are final.

text: President Joe Biden was caught fake driving a Ford F-150 Lightning truck during a visit to a Ford safety testing center Tuesday. A man in the passenger seat was operating the vehicle using a second steering wheel.

claimReview.title: Biden did not fake driving electric truck
claimReview.textualRating: False. The vehicle Biden drove had only one steering wheel, a Ford spokesperson confirmed. A frame-by-frame analysis of videos from the event shows Biden’s passenger was adjusting a camera that was resting on the dashboard, not steering the truck.

text: Republican presidential candidate Nikki Haley “changed” her name for political reasons.

claimReview.title: Social posts revive false claim about Haley’s name
claimReview.textualRating: False. The former United Nations ambassador has long used her legal middle name, Nikki. She was given the name Nimarata Nikki Randhawa at birth. Haley is her married name.

text: President Joe Biden “literally” convinced segregationist U.S. Sen. Strom Thurmond to vote in favor of the

claimReview.title: Biden didn’t get segregationist Thurmond to vote for the Civil Rights Act. White House says he misspoke
claimReview.textualRating:
False. Biden had not yet been elected to the U.S. Senate when the landmark law was passed in 1964, and Thurmond was among the prominent southern Democrats to vote against the bill. A White House spokesperson confirmed the president misspoke in his remarks. He said Biden intended to refer to his efforts in the 1980s to get Thurmond and other Senate Republicans to vote for legislation renewing the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
List (Page)

text: The current baby formula shortage was created by Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates because he invested in a company that makes artificial breast milk.

claimReview.title: Tech leader investments in biotech startup didn’t cause formula shortage
claimReview.textualRating: False. The investment by Gates’ firm, Breakthrough Energy Ventures, has nothing to do with the recent formula shortage. The firm gave initial funding in June 2020 to a biotech company working to cultivate lab-produced breast milk, but the product is not expected to be sold for at least another four years, according to the company. Experts told The Associated Press that the shortage is caused by pandemic-induced supply chain disruptions and a safety recall from a leading producer of U.S. infant formula products.

text: Kentucky Republican Sen. Rand Paul tweeted that he "will share irrefutable evidence how and why the COVID-vaccines are harming and killing people."

claimReview.title: Image falsely attributes tweet about vaccines to Rand Paul
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no record of the senator publishing this tweet. His office confirmed he did not make such a post.

text: President Joe Biden said during a recent speech, "We're going to keep at it to ensure the American people are paying their fair share for gas."

claimReview.title: Biden’s remarks on gas prices edited to distort meaning
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. A video of the speech was edited, shortening the quote and muddling its meaning. Social media users then claimed the president was suggesting that current gas prices are “fair.” But video of the full quote shows Biden actually said: “We're going to keep at it to ensure the American people are paying their fair share for gas, not being gouged for gas.”

text: Military band played the song “Hit the Road Jack” outside of White House before Donald Trump said farewell to Washington.

claimReview.title: Band did not play ‘Hit the Road Jack’ outside the White House
claimReview.textualRating: False. The audio in the video was altered. CNN’s Chief White House Correspondent Jim Acosta posted the original video on Twitter showing the band actually played “National Emblem,” an American march composed in 1902 and published in 1906.

text: Nobel prize winner Dr. Tasuku Honjo said that the coronavirus is not natural and is completely artificial.

claimReview.title: Japanese Nobel laureate did not say the coronavirus is not natural
claimReview.textualRating: False. The doctor denied that he made that statement circulating online.

text: Warnings for people to stay inside on Sept. 24, survival pack giveaways, a flier recruiting volunteers for a “mass casualty exercise” and an episode of “The Simpson” are evidence that a large-scale disaster will happen that day.

claimReview.title: Posts stoke unsupported Sept. 24 disaster theory
claimReview.textualRating: False. This conspiracy theory isn’t supported by credible evidence. It grew online after a German lawmaker misspoke while making remarks about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February.

text: Officials in Fulton County, Georgia, forgot to redact the names of the grand jurors who indicted former President Donald Trump this week in relation to his actions following the 2020 election.

claimReview.title: No, Georgia officials didn’t err in releasing Trump indictment with grand jurors' names
claimReview.textualRating: False. It is standard that indictments in Georgia include the names of the grand jurors, in part because it provides defendants the opportunity to challenge the composition of the grand jury, legal experts told The Associated Press.

text: All charges were dropped against Paul Pelosi, the husband of Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, after he was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence.

claimReview.title: False claims spread online about Paul Pelosi’s DUI arrest
claimReview.textualRating: False. Prosecutors are still reviewing the case and deciding whether to file charges against Paul Pelosi, the Napa County district attorney confirmed in a recent news release that was provided to The Associated Press.

text: A photo of a girl on a bus with a rifle shows “life in Ukraine, now.”

claimReview.title: Image of girl with gun is an old meme, not recent Ukraine photo
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows a Russian social media influencer, Ekaterina Gladkikh, holding a fake gun after a photo shoot. The photo was taken in March 2020, well before tensions began escalating between Russia and Ukraine in recent weeks.

text: A video shows Hawaii Gov. Josh Green saying he wants the state to acquire land destroyed in the Maui wildfire so that it can turn the town of Lahaina into a “smart city.”

claimReview.title: Hawaii’s governor did not tell reporters he wants to make Lahaina a ‘smart city’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows Green telling reporters on Saturday, during a visit to Lahaina with FEMA, that he won’t allow the town to become unaffordable for locals and that he is looking into how the state might preserve land in the community.

text: Video shows Odessa police dropping their riot shields and walking away, refusing to act against their people, as tensions heighten between Russia and Ukraine.

claimReview.title: Video shows police in Ukraine leaving their posts during 2014 protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is being misrepresented. It was filmed in Odessa, a key port city in Ukraine, on May 4, 2014. It shows Ukrainian police officers leaving their post during a pro-Russian demonstration outside police headquarters.

text: Pfizer documents show that 44% of pregnancies reported during its COVID-19 vaccine trial ended with miscarriages.

claimReview.title: Flawed calculation fuels falsehood on Pfizer vaccine and pregnancies
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim is based on a flawed calculation that, among other issues, twice counted some of the same reported miscarriages — which also were not established to be caused by the vaccine. Studies have found the vaccines do not increase the chances of spontaneous abortion.

text: Photo shows a federal agent disguised as a protester to incite violence in the protests demanding justice for George Floyd, who died after a Minneapolis police officer knelt on his neck for several minutes as he begged for air.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show a federal agent among protesters in Minneapolis
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken during a protest in Germany earlier this month, before Floyd’s death on Monday and the protests that followed in Minneapolis this week.

text: CNN ran an article on Veterans Day arguing that “we thank soldiers for their service” and “should also thank the media for the same reason especially when the stakes have never been higher.”

claimReview.title: CNN article comparing soldiers to media is from 2018, not Veterans Day
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. While the opinion piece is real, CNN did not run the story on Veterans Day. It was published in August 2018.

text: A photo shows Ghislaine Maxwell, the former girlfriend of Jeffrey Epstein who was convicted of sex trafficking, with U.S. Magistrate Bruce Reinhart, the judge who approved the FBI search warrant for Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate.

claimReview.title: Photo altered to include judge who approved Mar-a-Lago warrant
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. This image has been manipulated by combining two separate, unrelated photos. The photo of Maxwell was released in 2021 as evidence in her trial. The photo of Reinhart was published in 2017 on a publicly accessible Facebook page under his name.

text: Former President Barack Obama said that he would not “allow white people to kill Africans with their toxic vaccines.”

claimReview.title: Obama did not warn Africans against taking vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The fabricated claim grew out of a French TV segment where two doctors suggested that a tuberculosis vaccine be tested in Africa in trials to fight the coronavirus.

text: NASCAR, which recently banned the Confederate flag at its events, is now forcing its drivers to engage in Muslim prayer.

claimReview.title: Viral photo shows NASCAR drivers ‘kissing the bricks,’ not doing a Muslim prayer
claimReview.textualRating: False. A photo circulating with this bogus claim shows NASCAR drivers at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway taking part in a longstanding tradition called “kissing the bricks.”

text: Rep. Randy Fine, a Republican Florida state lawmaker, tweeted that elementary school children are a “small sacrifice” for the Second Amendment.

claimReview.title: Parody account misrepresented as Florida lawmaker
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet was posted by a parody account.

text: A photo of mail bins and envelopes on the side of the road shows discarded Trump ballots found in states such as California, Texas and Pennsylvania.

claimReview.title: Photo shows mail from 2018, not discarded Trump ballots
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo does not show ballots with votes for President Donald Trump. It shows mail bins and envelopes abandoned by a mail carrier in New Jersey who quit in 2018.

text: More than 80 U.S. senators voted to allow the North Atlantic Treaty Organization “to choose when Americans will have to go to war.”

claimReview.title: No, 83 senators didn’t vote to give NATO authority over US war decisions
claimReview.textualRating: False. Those senators voted against an amendment that simply reiterated that Congress, not NATO, has ultimate authority to declare war on behalf of the U.S. But that is already the case, and experts confirmed that neither the amendment itself, nor the vote on it, provided NATO any power over U.S. processes.

text: Video shows a Hindu temple in Birmingham, England, being set on fire during the Hindu festival of Navratri.

claimReview.title: Video shows UK supermarket on fire, not Hindu temple
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows an accidental fire that broke out at a supermarket in Birmingham on Sept. 19, the regional police department confirmed.

text: Colorado’s practice of sending mail-in ballots to every registered voter is unconstitutional and voters should only vote in person on Election Day.

claimReview.title: Colorado’s universal mail-in ballot system is legal, secure
claimReview.textualRating: False. Colorado state law explicitly protects mail-in voting and the U.S. Constitution gives states broad authority to run their elections, according to legal experts. Colorado’s mail-in voting system has been praised by experts as safe and secure, The Associated Press previously reported.

text: An image shows Candace Owens retweeting Fox News post and suggesting she had long-term side effects from taking the drug ivermectin.

claimReview.title: Image attributes fake ivermectin tweets to Candace Owens and Fox News
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no record of Owens posting that tweet and Fox News confirmed the supposed story and tweet shown in the image were fabricated. The image was previously shared on Reddit as satire.

text: McDonald's removed its American flags nationwide in support of antifa and Black Lives Matter.

claimReview.title: McDonald’s restaurants didn’t remove American flags nationwide
claimReview.textualRating: False. A McDonald’s USA spokesperson confirmed this claim is not true and there is no coordinated effort to remove American flags from its restaurants.

text: A video shows a company called Psychasec exhibiting technology that allows people to transplant their consciousness into synthetic bodies or “human sleeves.”

claimReview.title: ‘Human sleeve’ video shows Netflix promo, not real synthetic body company
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The exhibit, which appeared at the 2018 Consumer Electronics Show, or CES, was part of a promotional campaign for the Netflix sci-fi series “Altered Carbon.” Psychasec and its technology are fictional.

text: A video shows producers in Ukraine producing fake footage of Russia’s invasion.

claimReview.title: Video shows film crew shooting sci-fi movie, not faking Ukraine war footage
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is nearly a decade old and shows behind-the-scenes production work on a British sci-fi movie about aliens called “Invasion Planet Earth.”

text: British newspaper The Independent recently published a front page showing which countries back a ceasefire in the latest Israel-Hamas war, with 189 nations listed as “Yes” and the United States, United Kingdom and Israel under “No.”

claimReview.title: British newspaper headline about a cease-fire is old and not related to the latest Israel-Hamas war
claimReview.textualRating: False. The front page is from 2006, and refers to a monthslong war between Israel and Lebanon's militant Hezbollah group at the time. The U.N. General Assembly approved a non-binding resolution Friday that calls for a “humanitarian truce” in Gaza, with 120 voting in favor, 45 abstaining, including the U.K. Fourteen nations voted against the resolution, with countries including Austria and Hungary joining the U.S. and Israel.

text: The head of research at Pfizer says the COVID-19 vaccine causes female sterilization because it contains a spike protein known as syncytin-1.

claimReview.title: No evidence that COVID-19 vaccine results in sterilization
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Pfizer and BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine does not contain the protein syncytin-1, which is important for the creation of placenta. The head of research at Pfizer made no such claim.

text: A photo shows a large demonstration in Brasília, Brazil, on Republic Day to “protest the stolen elections.”

claimReview.title: Image shows Brazilian Independence Day rally, not election protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image was taken from a video that captured a rally in Brazil’s capital of Brasilia on Sept. 7, which marks Independence Day. It does not show a large protest on Republic Day, a separate holiday that was observed on Tuesday.

text: Video clips and still images show a facility where artificial wombs are being used to grow babies in labs.

claimReview.title: Video of ‘artificial womb’ concept doesn’t show real facility
claimReview.textualRating: False. The facility shown in the animations does not exist. The video is a concept design for such an invention. The creator told The Associated Press in a statement that there is not currently any work being done to create a prototype.

text: A video shows crisis actors being used to portray Palestinian victims of the ongoing

claimReview.title: Old story about the Gaza film industry misrepresented as proof Palestinian war victims are ‘crisis actors’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The widely shared clip is taken from a 2017 news report on the film industry in Hamas-controlled Gaza. That story features a makeup artist discussing some of the challenges for Palestinian women hoping to break into the local film industry.

text: In all of 2020, there were only 9,000 immigrants caught at the border without legal status. So far in 2021,108,000 entered the country.

claimReview.title: Claim that 9,000 border crossers were apprehended in 2020 is false
claimReview.textualRating: False. According to U.S. Customs and Border Protection data, there were 547,816 apprehensions at the southern border between January 2020 and December 2020. That compares to 178,883 apprehensions since January 1, 2021.

text: Photo shows two buses emblazoned with “Soros Riot Dance Squad” at a Milan, Michigan, gas station, offering proof that billionaire philanthropist George Soros and far-left militant groups are transporting out-of-town rioters to protests.

claimReview.title: Altered photo adds ‘Soros’ label to buses in posts alleging antifa-organized unrest
claimReview.textualRating: False. A photo of two unmarked buses was manipulated to add the words “Soros Riot Dance Squad” to the side of each vehicle. The buses are not being used to transport people to protests; they belong to a local transportation company and are providing a local shuttle service.

text: Golden retriever saved baby koala from a wildfire in Australia.

claimReview.title: Photos do not show dog and koala after wildfire rescue
claimReview.textualRating: False. Photos that show a baby koala snuggled on the back of a golden retriever was taken in 2018, not during the recent fires.

text: Photo shows a BBC reporter pretending to be on the frontlines of the Russia-Ukraine war while a woman stands casually in the background with a shopping bag.

claimReview.title: Image doesn’t contradict BBC report on Russia-Ukraine war
claimReview.textualRating: False. The still image from a March BBC news broadcast is being shared out of context. The full video shows the reporter was covering civilians fleeing Irpin, Ukraine, amid Russian shelling during the early days of the war. The Associated Press captured images of the same attacks.

text: Republican presidential candidate

claimReview.title: False claims question Haley’s eligibility to serve as US president
claimReview.textualRating: False. Haley is a natural-born U.S. citizen who is eligible to serve as president. The former ambassador to the United Nations was born on Jan. 20, 1972, in Bamberg, South Carolina, according to information on her official website when she was governor of the state.

text: A video of green lights illuminating the night sky in Hawaii was taken before the recent Maui wildfires.

claimReview.title: A video of green lights over Hawaii is from January and is unrelated to the fires on Maui
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The video does show green lights over Hawaii but it was from January 2023, not right before the fire. The original video was captured by a livestream from a camera on the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan’s Subaru Telescope. The observatory said at the time that a Chinese satellite was the likely source of the lights.

text: Reka Gyorgy, a Virginia Tech University swimmer, posted from her personal Twitter account

claimReview.title: Tweet falsely attributed to Virginia Tech swimmer
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet did not come from Gyorgy’s account. A Twitter spokesperson confirmed to The Associated Press that the user responsible for the tweet was suspended for violating the platform’s policy on the “creation of fake accounts.” Multiple representatives from Virginia Tech’s athletics department also said the account was not authentic.

text: Image shows that CNN published a Jan. 11 headline reading, “Doctor of Damar Hamlin confirms Cardiac Arrest was due to the 4th Booster Vaccine.”

claimReview.title: CNN didn't publish story linking Damar Hamlin collapse to vaccine
claimReview.textualRating: Altered image. The screenshot was manipulated to add the fabricated headline, a CNN spokesperson confirmed. The actual headline reported on the release of the Buffalo Bills safety from a hospital.

text: A video shows Spanish tennis player Rafael Nadal collapsing at a press conference because of COVID-19 vaccine side effects.

claimReview.title: Video of Rafael Nadal suffering health issue is from 2011
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip shows Nadal suffering from a leg cramp at a news conference during the U.S. Open tennis tournament in 2011, nearly a decade before the COVID-19 pandemic, according to reporting by The Associated Press.

text: Hellmann’s mayonnaise is discontinuing the product globally due to high inflationary import costs.

claimReview.title: Hellmann’s mayonnaise discontinued in South Africa, not globally
claimReview.textualRating: False. The popular condiment brand is only discontinuing sales of the mayonnaise in South Africa, according to a spokesperson for the brand. The confusion started when social media users misinterpreted a since-deleted post about the change on Hellmanns’ South Africa Facebook page, which didn’t specify the country.

text: Ukraine is responsible for a

claimReview.title: Posts falsely blame Ukraine for a missile strike on Kyiv children’s hospital
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ukraine’s Security Service wrote in a statement on Telegram that it found wreckage from a Russian Kh-101 cruise missile at the hospital and has opened proceedings on war crime charges. The Russian Defense Ministry claimed without evidence in a Telegram post that images from Kyiv showed the damage was caused by a Ukrainian air defense missile. As supposed proof of Ukraine’s responsibility, social media users shared old photos, falsely claiming they showed shrapnel from such missiles that was found at the hospital following Monday’s attack.

text: The Canadian province of Alberta lifted all COVID-19 restrictions after health officials couldn’t provide evidence in court that the virus exists.

claimReview.title: Alberta did not lift COVID-19 restrictions because of ‘freedom fighter’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Alberta relaxed its COVID-19 restrictions because the province hit predetermined vaccination goals. Patrick King, a Canadian resident, has been falsely credited on social media with driving the change. But that’s due to a misunderstanding of what happened in a court case.

text: A recent outbreak of unexplained hepatitis cases among children is being caused by the adenovirus vector used in some COVID-19 vaccines, including the Johnson & Johnson shot.

claimReview.title: Unexplained hepatitis cases not caused by COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The dead adenovirus used in the J&J vaccine is a different strain entirely than the one linked to the recent hepatitis cases, according to medical experts. Further, the J&J vaccine is not currently authorized for those under 18, and a recently-published paper documenting some recent juvenile hepatitis cases in the U.K. noted that none of the children had been vaccinated.

text: A screenshot shows Canadian news outlet Global News published an article with the headline

claimReview.title: Fake Global News headline about pronouns spreads online
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image is fabricated. There is no record of this headline on Global News, and the outlet confirmed in a statement to The Associated Press that it never published such an article.

text: A video shows a fire at a military warehouse in Italy that was storing COVID-19 vaccines. The fire occurred on the date members of law enforcement had to be vaccinated.

claimReview.title: No COVID-19 vaccines stored in building that caught fire in Italy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a fire at a barracks that houses Carabinieri, Italian paramilitary police, in Rome on Dec. 15, the deadline for members of law enforcement to be vaccinated in Italy. But vaccinations are not given at the site and no vaccines were stored in the building.

text: The identities of deceased Georgia residents Linda Kesler, Deborah Jean Christiansen and James Blalock were used to illegally cast ballots in the 2020 election.

claimReview.title: Officials debunk multiple claims of dead Georgia residents voting
claimReview.textualRating: False. No one voted using the identities of these deceased individuals, according to election officials in their respective counties. Georgia residents with similar names to Kesler and Christiansen voted, and Blalock’s widow voted using the name on her voter registration, Mrs. James Blalock Jr. One case of a ballot potentially cast using the name of the deceased Georgia resident Edward Skwiot is being investigated by local law enforcement and the secretary of state.

text: Arizona’s Maricopa County announced that more than 540,000 voters visited voting centers on Election Day. It also announced that only 248,000 Election Day ballots were counted. Therefore, the county “lost” some 292,000 votes.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim Arizona county ‘lost’ nearly 300K Election Day votes
claimReview.textualRating: False. This distorts county data. The county reported that more than 540,000 voters visited county voting centers on Election Day, but that figure includes about 290,000 people who dropped off mail-in ballots in person that day, the county said. The figure also included about 3,000 people who cast provisional ballots. The county does not list these as “Election Day” votes in its final results, but instead puts them in “early vote” and “provisional” categories.

text: Video clip shows a man being told he is banned from Walmart for failing to comply with the store’s new no carry policy.

claimReview.title: Man not banned from Walmart because of store's gun policy change
claimReview.textualRating: False. The man was banned from Walmart before the retail giant announced on Sept. 3 that it would discontinue sales of handguns and short-barrel rifle ammunition and request that customers no longer openly carry firearms in its stores, following a deadly mass shooting at its El Paso, Texas store.

text: Massachusetts reports that 45% of COVID-19 deaths in the state “last week” were among fully vaccinated people.

claimReview.title: Post misrepresents Massachusetts report on vaccinated COVID-19 deaths
claimReview.textualRating: False. The online post included data from the Massachusetts Department of Public Health for the week ending Oct. 9 that shows 45 newly reported deaths among vaccinated people in the state -- not that 45% of all COVID-19 deaths were among vaccinated people. Data on overall COVID-19 deaths for that period was not included.

text: CNN has reported that online payment service Cash App has gone bankrupt.

claimReview.title: Social media users spread false claim that CNN reported that Cash App is bankrupt
claimReview.textualRating:
False. A spokesperson for CNN says the network didn’t publish any such news article. The person who originally posted the claim on Facebook has also admitted it was made up.
List (Page)

text: Businesses owned by white men are not allowed to bid on a $2.3 billion grant funding redevelopment of New York’s John F. Kennedy International Airport.

claimReview.title: JFK airport project misrepresented as not allowing bids from white, male-owned businesses
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim distorts an announcement made last month that $2.3 billion in contracts were awarded to minority- and women-owned businesses, commonly referred to as MWBEs, for the airport redevelopment as of February 2024. The $19 billion project has made it a priority to involve certified MWBEs. However, the bidding has been open to all, with non-MWBEs awarded more than $5 billion in contracts as of February 2024, a spokesperson for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which runs JFK, said.

text: Photo shows the scene of an attack in New York City where many were injured this weekend.

claimReview.title: False claim about NYC attack uses photo from failed 2017 bombing
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is an Associated Press image from a 2017 pipe bomb attack beneath Times Square in which the suspect was the only one seriously injured. The New York City Police Department confirms officers haven’t responded to such a major incident in recent days.

text: A video of a woman scaling a brick wall while holding another woman by the hair is footage of a demonic possession in 1896.

claimReview.title: A video of a woman scaling a wall is computer-generated, not a 19th century demonic possession
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, titled “Wall Crawler,” was created by a French visual effects artist and originally posted to their Instagram and YouTube accounts in 2019.

text: A video shows Israeli soldiers placing a flag atop Gaza’s Shifa Hospital.

claimReview.title: Video shows Israeli soldiers raising a flag over a Gaza school building, not a hospital
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows the soldiers raising the country's flag over a United Nations-operated school in the city, not the hospital, a U.N. agency spokesperson confirmed.

text: Video shows actor Tom Hanks talking about the New World Order, a conspiracy theory built around the idea that a secret society of the wealthy and powerful are scheming to overthrow the U.S. and adopt a single, global authoritarian government.

claimReview.title: Video doesn’t show Tom Hanks talking about New World Order
claimReview.textualRating: False. Hanks wasn’t singing the praises of the New World Order in the video. He was just addressing the class of 2020 at Wright State University.

text: Former Rep. Trey Gowdy said he attended the premiere of the film “2000 Mules” at Mar-a-Lago and that he “always believed that rampant cheating occurred” in the 2020 election.

claimReview.title: Former US Rep. Gowdy didn’t praise film alleging election fraud
claimReview.textualRating: False. Gowdy confirmed he did not make that statement. A conservative commentator previously tweeted the same quote.

text: Kamala Harris was sworn into Congress as an “Indian-American,” and now plays the “I’m a black woman” card.

claimReview.title: Posts mislead about how Kamala Harris portrayed her heritage
