claimReview.textualRating: False. Kamala Harris for years has identified herself as both Black and Indian American. In interviews, she has regularly talked about how her mother, who was from India, raised her as Black.

text: Video shows “COV-19” is inscribed on equipment for 5G wireless towers.

claimReview.title: Video does not show 5G wireless equipment labeled “COV-19”
claimReview.textualRating: False. The circuit board filmed in the video is from a nearly decade old television box. A representative with Virgin Media, a British telecommunications company confirmed to The Associated Press that the device never had “COV-19” printed on it.

text: Swiss health minister Alain Berset was photographed in a hospital room in Switzerland with mannequins posing as COVID-19 patients.

claimReview.title: No, Swiss health minister did not visit a hospital filled with mannequins
claimReview.textualRating: False. Swiss Interior and Health Minister Alain Berset was not in a hospital but was photographed in a university training room for nursing students. The training room had medical mannequins to simulate patients.

text: A photo shows Volodymyr Zelenskyy in heavy makeup and a wig at a 1999 Pride event, years before becoming president of Ukraine.

claimReview.title: Photo edited to place Zelenskyy at NYC Pride parade
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The photo was taken in 2006 in New York City during an LGBT Pride event. Zelenskyy, then an actor and comedian, was not in the photo. Faces in the image were edited, including one that was manipulated to appear more like Zelenskyy.

text: Photos of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi getting the first dose of the COVID-19 vaccine show that the doctor never removed the orange cap from the syringe, so she never actually received the shot.

claimReview.title: Doctor who vaccinated Pelosi didn’t leave cap on syringe
claimReview.textualRating: False. The doctor didn’t leave a cap on the syringe. Photos by The Associated Press and other news organizations clearly show that the orange part of the syringe wasn’t a cap, and that the needle extended beyond it.

text: A photo of a woman breastfeeding her baby through a fence was taken at the US-Mexico border.

claimReview.title: Photo of woman breastfeeding through a fence was not taken at US-Mexico border
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image was originally posted in January 2013, and it was taken in Argentina.

text: A White House press release says that Dr. Monica Bertagnolli, President Joe Biden's pick to lead the National Institutes of Health, received tens of millions of dollars in research money from Pfizer.

claimReview.title: Claims misconstrue Pfizer grants received by NIH nominee’s nonprofit
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image circulating online has been manipulated; the official announcement didn’t include the funding statistics. Additionally, while Pfizer awarded grants to a nonprofit that Dr. Monica Bertagnolli headed up, the money did not go directly to her. The Biden administration, Bertagnolli and the nonprofit have confirmed the funding was largely used to support a major breast cancer clinical trial.

text: Photo shows Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis holding an orange T-shirt bearing former President Donald Trump’s face and text that says, “I’d love a mean tweet and 1.79 gas right now.”

claimReview.title: Manipulated photo shows DeSantis holding Trump T-shirt
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image was manipulated to change what is displayed on the shirt, which was actually promoting a fast food restaurant’s chicken sandwich.

text: Footage of a person moving under a “body bag” shows misleading news coverage of the war in Ukraine.

claimReview.title: Video shows climate protest in Austria, not war report in Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows protesters participating in a climate change-related demonstration in Austria in early February, and has no connection to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Some iterations of the video spreading online are edited to add audio from real NBC News coverage of the conflict and a fake news chyron to the unrelated visuals from Austria.

text: COVID-19 vaccines cause impotency and swollen testicles.

claimReview.title: Rapper’s tweet shares unfounded claims about vaccine side effects
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say that there is no scientific support for the claim that coronavirus vaccines result in those side effects.

text: A COVID-19 PCR test recently recalled for having too many false positive results was the only COVID-19 test available last spring, so its false results exaggerated the scope of the pandemic and fooled Americans into losing their businesses and their livelihoods because of social distancing restrictions.

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on recalled COVID-19 test
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Innova Medical Group COVID-19 test featured in recent false posts is an antigen test, not a PCR test, and it was not “the only test available” last spring. In fact, it was never authorized by the Food and Drug Administration for commercial distribution. PCR tests are considered the gold standard for COVID-19 diagnosis and they were used early in the pandemic. By May 2020, the FDA had authorized multiple COVID-19 tests for emergency use, including a different antigen test that has not been recalled.

text: Photo shows Tampa Mayor Jane Castor maskless at the Super Bowl.

claimReview.title: Photo of Tampa mayor without a mask was not taken at Super Bowl
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo of Castor was taken on Sept. 30 during a celebration for the NHL hockey team, the Tampa Bay Lightning, which won the 2020 Stanley Cup, a spokesperson for the mayor confirmed.

text: A social media post circulating online claims that “Christmas was illegal in the U.S. until 1836 as it was considered an ancient pagan holiday.”

claimReview.title: Christmas was not illegal in the U.S. before 1836
claimReview.textualRating: False. The details of this post are incorrect. Though Christmas was not as widely celebrated in the early 1800s, it was not illegal throughout the country. However, one colony did make it illegal to celebrate Christmas in 1659.

text: Photos show a boy who, at 11 years old, hacked the computer system of a Swiss bank and transferred $75 billion to his father’s account.

claimReview.title: Boy in courtroom images was charged with manslaughter, not hacking bank
claimReview.textualRating: False. An Associated Press photo shows the 14-year-old boy was appearing in court for the first time on charges of killing his father, not hacking a bank.

text: The COVID-19 vaccine is “shedding” from person to person. As a result, unvaccinated people who are in close proximity to vaccinated people are having changes in their period or miscarriages.

claimReview.title: No, COVID-19 vaccines do not ‘shed’
claimReview.textualRating: False. It is biologically impossible for a vaccinated person to spread the vaccine to someone who hasn’t been vaccinated, and evidence shows that the COVID-19 vaccine does not cause miscarriages in those who have gotten it.

text: Video shows an incoming call to a 5G iPhone setting steel wool on fire.

claimReview.title: Call to iPhone did not cause steel wool to catch fire
claimReview.textualRating: False. The flames captured in the video were added through a digital effect. In addition, Apple has not yet launched 5G capable phones yet.

text: Viral photo of a tornado was taken by a Ring doorbell camera at Newnan High School in Newnan, Georgia, about 40 miles southwest of Atlanta.

claimReview.title: School doorbell camera didn’t capture tornado photo
claimReview.textualRating: False. While Newnan High School faced damage from a deadly tornado this week, this photo is from a different storm in Texas in 2019.

text: A rain-enhancing process known as cloud seeding caused historic flooding in Tasmania, Australia, in 2016 and along Australia’s southeastern coast this year.

claimReview.title: Cloud seeding hasn't caused flooding in Australia
claimReview.textualRating: False. An independent investigation sought by Tasmania’s parliament into the causes of the 2016 flooding found that cloud seeding, a process aimed at increasing precipitation, had no impact on the severe weather. There’s no evidence to suggest it played a role in the 2022 floods in southeastern Australia, either. An atmospheric research expert told The Associated Press that cloud seeding would not change the dynamics of a cloud enough to cause massive flooding.

text: The Federal Emergency Management Agency just updated its guide on what to do in the event of a nuclear explosion to include COVID-19 precautions such as social distancing and wearing masks.

claimReview.title: COVID measures weren't recently added to FEMA nuclear guidelines
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While FEMA does include recommendations for protecting against COVID-19 in the event of a nuclear explosion on its website, this was not a recent update to the guide. The language around COVID-19 safety measures has been on the website since 2020, according to an archived version of the webpage and a FEMA spokesperson.

text: Time magazine published a cover this month featuring Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy with the text, “Ladimir Elensky refused to use the letters ‘V’ and ‘Z’ in his name and surname. As a token of support our office publishes this news piece without the letters ‘V’ and ‘Z.’”

claimReview.title: Ukrainian president not featured on April 25 Time magazine
claimReview.textualRating: False. Time magazine never ran this cover, and Zelenskyy has not made any public statements suggesting he has changed the spelling of his name. The cover has been fabricated using a photo from the Ukrainian president’s office website and adding the text.

text: Kansas City Chief CEO and owner Clark Hunt told NFL players, coaches and staff that they are all “simply paid performers on a stage” and he will “immediately fire” anyone who does not stand, with their hand over their heart, during the playing of the national anthem.

claimReview.title: Kansas Chiefs CEO didn’t threaten to fire players who kneel
claimReview.textualRating: False. Hunt did not hold such a meeting, although he has publicly expressed support for Chiefs players standing during the national anthem.

text: Patients who have myocarditis have a very high chance of dying within 10 years.

claimReview.title: Social media posts misrepresent myocarditis risks
claimReview.textualRating: False. Claims that patients with myocarditis, a condition where the heart muscle is inflamed, have a very high mortality rate come from a misreading of decades-old data that focused only on the most ill patients. Furthermore, while health officials say myocarditis may be an extremely rare side effect of the COVID-19 vaccine for young people, severe cases are even more unlikely.

text: Amazon has told delivery workers to stop driving for one hour during the Oct. 4 test of the national emergency alert system because phones and other electronic devices will be inoperable.

claimReview.title: Amazon hasn’t ordered delivery drivers to pull over during Oct. 4 FEMA alert test
claimReview.textualRating:
False. Amazon says it has not sent any directives to its employees or affiliates regarding the emergency alert. The Federal Emergency Management Agency says the national alert test will not render phones and other devices inoperable and that users can simply dismiss the notice. The test, featuring the same familiar audio tone that’s been used since the 1960s to broadcast national warnings, lasts just 30 minutes, not one hour.
List (Page)

text: There will be another pandemic in 2025 due to a virus called SEERS, or severe epidemic enterovirus respiratory syndrome.

claimReview.title: Fictional virus created for training exercise, not another pandemic
claimReview.textualRating: False. SEERS is a fictitious disease created for a public health training exercise that simulated a pandemic. A video made for the training includes a made-up news report that repeatedly states: “This is a fictional scenario.”

text: You can call a 1-800 number and enter your social security number to check on the status of the relief check the federal government is sending as part of the $2.2 trillion economic recovery bill in response to the coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Don’t call 1-800 numbers for status of relief check
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are posting prank 1-800 numbers, urging people to call to check on the status of their checks.

text: Photos show children who were trafficked as “sex slaves” being rescued from tunnel systems beneath Central Park in New York City.

claimReview.title: Photos show early responses to COVID-19, not a child rescue operation in Central Park
claimReview.textualRating: False. The images all show other events, mostly efforts to fight the spread of COVID-19 in March 2020, including at a field hospital in Central Park and a U.S. Navy hospital ship, also in New York City.

text: Video shows World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus saying he isn’t vaccinated against COVID-19.

claimReview.title: WHO chief is vaccinated against COVID-19, contrary to false claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip is from a documentary that shows Ghebreyesus championing COVID-19 vaccines and saying, at one point, that he had waited for better global vaccine equity before receiving his own shot. He has publicly stated that he was vaccinated in May 2021, weeks before the interview took place.

text: Train cars have been found in the U.S. marked with “COVID-19.”

claimReview.title: Photo altered to show train car labeled COVID-19
claimReview.textualRating: False. A cropped photo circulating on social media showing a rail car marked with COVID-19, the name of the coronavirus disease spreading around the globe, was altered to include the marking.

text: CNN reports that the Taliban banned menstrual hygiene products in Afghanistan, saying it goes against Sharia law.

claimReview.title: Fake news report makes false claim about Taliban edict
claimReview.textualRating: False. The report is fabricated. CNN did not publish such an article. A closer look at the post shows that the CNN logo was flipped and the font does not match the cable news network’s logo. In addition, no credible reports can be found to support any such action by the Taliban.

text: O.J. Simpson, the former football star and Hollywood actor, admitted on X before he died on Wednesday that he killed his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald Goldman. The post was deleted by the family.

claimReview.title: No, OJ Simpson did not admit on X to the 1994 killings of his ex-wife and her friend
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image of the alleged post was fabricated. The account that first posted it indicated in subsequent posts that it was a joke. A Feb. 11 post, in which Simpson says his “health is good” and that he is supporting the San Francisco 49ers in the Super Bowl, was his last. Simpson’s family made the final post on his account on Thursday to announce his death.

text: Repeated use of a November photo of President Joe Biden attending church proves he was lying about attending services on Sunday, Feb.7.

claimReview.title: Duplicate photos do not prove that Biden lied about attending church
claimReview.textualRating: False. The same photo of Biden in the church was shared in two separate tweets _ first in November and then in February _ leading to the accusation that Biden was not actually in church last Sunday. The Twitter who created the posts clarified the photo was taken last year and then reposted in February. Photos captured by The Associated Press show Biden did in fact attend mass on Feb. 7.

text: Players on the U.S. women’s national soccer team “turned their backs” on a World War II veteran playing the national anthem at a game Monday.

claimReview.title: US women’s soccer team did not snub veteran playing national anthem
claimReview.textualRating: False. The players turned to face an American flag located near the stadium’s scoreboard during the playing of “The Star-Spangled Banner.”

text: A Pennsylvania judge ruled that ballots received up until Nov. 14 will count in the 2022 midterm elections.

claimReview.title: Pennsylvania ballots not accepted a week after Election Day
claimReview.textualRating: False. Pennsylvania ballots, including mail-in and absentee ballots, must be received by county election offices by 8 p.m. on Nov. 8 to be counted, according to the state’s Department of State. A court in the state recently decided a case related to Philadelphia’s ballot-counting procedure, but that had no bearing on statewide ballot deadlines.

text: A graphic shows Biden's tax plan with top tax rates by state citing California at 62%, New Jersey 60%, New York 58% and New York City at 62%.

claimReview.title: Graphic shows top tax rates by state only for high-income earners
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The image shows tax rates only for high-income earners under Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden’s plan, not for the average American making less than $400,000 a year.

text: An image shows Arizona Democratic gubernatorial candidate

claimReview.title: Photo of woman in Arizona ballot-counting room is not candidate Hobbs
claimReview.textualRating: False. The woman in the photo is a party observer who monitors the vote count, according to Maricopa County’s official Twitter account. A spokesperson from Hobbs’ campaign confirmed the photo does not show the candidate. State law prohibits candidates from serving as observers vote counting locations.

text: Photo shows the front page of The Washington Times on Nov. 8, 2000, with the prominent headline “President Gore'' and a photo of that year’s Democratic presidential candidate, Al Gore. Since Gore ultimately lost the election to George W. Bush, the image shows that the newspaper initially reported the election results incorrectly.

claimReview.title: Photo of newspaper was edited to add ‘President Gore’ headline
claimReview.textualRating: False. This altered image has been circulating on the internet for at least 10 years. The Washington Times never ran a “President Gore” headline, it confirmed on Twitter on Sunday.

text: Photo shows Britain’s late Queen Elizabeth II and her son, King Charles III, bowing to Ethiopia's last emperor, Haile Selassie.

claimReview.title: Queen Elizabeth II not pictured bowing to Ethiopian emperor
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo does not feature Elizabeth or Charles. It was captured in 1955, a decade before Elizabeth made her first official visit to Ethiopia, and when Charles was just 7 years old.

text: A video of a laser beam starting an explosion at a gas station in Russia is an example of a directed-energy weapon in action.

claimReview.title: Video claiming to show a directed-energy weapon is actually an edited clip of an explosion in Russia
claimReview.textualRating: False. A 9-year-old video was altered to add the laser beam. An unedited version of the same footage can be seen in news reports from 2014 about an explosion at a gas station in Makhachkala, a southwestern Russian city on the Caspian Sea. Lasers powerful enough to start such a fire could not be seen by the naked eye, as they use infrared technology, an aerospace engineering expert told The Associated Press.

text: The Federal Aviation Administration loosened the requirements that airline pilots must meet for cardiac health because a large number have heart damage caused by the COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: New FAA cardiac health rules not prompted by COVID-19 shots
claimReview.textualRating: False. In October, the FAA widened the acceptable parameters it uses when screening pilots for a specific heart condition, the agency said in a statement to The Associated Press. However, the FAA explained that this change was made in response to new scientific evidence about the condition from its cardiology consultants, not adverse reactions to COVID-19 vaccines.

text: The campaign of Democrat Beto O’Rourke, who is running for Texas governor, engaged in voter fraud by sending pre-filled voter registration forms to dead people.

claimReview.title: Pre-filled voter registration forms are not proof of fraud
claimReview.textualRating: False. O’Rourke’s campaign did send out partially filled-out forms to encourage people to register before the Texas deadline, a spokesperson for the campaign told The Associated Press. However, experts and government officials say that sending such forms is permitted under Texas law, even if they are sent to dead people because of databases that are not up to date. Even if someone tried to return the form on behalf of a dead person, the applications are verified for eligibility by the state before they are approved. There are additional safeguards, such as signature validation, to protect against fraud if an actual ballot gets mailed on behalf of someone who has died — a rare occurrence, the AP has reported.

text: Mark Bedell, the superintendent of Kansas City Public Schools tweeted in response to rapper and influencer Bhad Bhabie’s post about sending private messages on OnlyFans, a social media platform that allows people to sell explicit content to subscribers.

claimReview.title: Kansas City schools superintendent didn’t tweet at rapper
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet came from an account impersonating the superintendent, both Bedell and an Associated Press analysis of the image confirmed.

text: A clip shows Green Party presidential candidate Jill Stein saying that “the Jewish people have a homeland in Poland” during an exchange with a man outside of Columbia University.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Green Party candidate’s comment on a Jewish homeland
claimReview.textualRating: False. Stein says that “the Jewish people have homeland” and does not mention the Eastern European country. A caption on the clip, which comes from a longer video first posted to Stein’s social media accounts, was incorrectly autogenerated to read, “the Jewish people have Poland,” according to a spokesperson for the candidate. Stein later posted another video of the exchange with the caption corrected. She further clarified her comment during an appearance in Columbia, Missouri, on Sunday.

text: The U.S. Department of Justice said international child sex trafficking is not an area of concern.

claimReview.title: The DOJ did not announce that international child sex trafficking is no longer a concern
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Justice Department has made no such declaration. The agency acknowledged that it recently updated language on its website, including removing a lengthy passage about international child sex trafficking from one page. But the DOJ says the issue is more thoroughly covered elsewhere on the site, namely as part of its recently released national strategy on preventing child exploitation. The agency also cited several recent cases it prosecuted dealing with international sex trafficking.

text: Photo shows the actor Tom Hanks quarantined at a hospital in Australia with a volleyball that looks like Wilson, his make-believe friend in the movie “Cast Away.”

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Tom Hanks quarantined in Australia
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was manipulated. It was not taken in Australia where Hanks and his wife, Rita Wilson, were hospitalized Thursday in stable condition.

text: Photo shows President Joe Biden asleep in his seat at the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office with a stack of executive orders in front of him.

claimReview.title: Photo appearing to show Biden asleep in Oval Office is fake
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. An image of Biden’s face with his eyes closed has been digitally superimposed onto a photo from Inauguration Day to make it look like the president fell asleep in the Oval Office on his first day in office. Associated Press photos from the event show that Biden was awake and wearing a face mask while sitting at the desk.

text: The deputy director of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention admitted that COVID-19 vaccines are causing “debilitating illnesses.”

claimReview.title: Posts distort CDC official’s remarks on reported vaccine reactions
claimReview.textualRating: False. This takes Dr. Tom Shimabukuro’s comments at the January meeting of the Food and Drug Administration’s Vaccines and Related Biological Products Advisory Committee out of context. Shimabukuro, the deputy director of the CDC’s Immunization Safety Office, was discussing reports of illnesses that people have filed after COVID-19 vaccination, but he never says the vaccines were proven to have caused the events.

text: The chimpanzee adenovirus vector used in AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine is causing the monkeypox outbreak.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines didn’t cause monkeypox outbreak
claimReview.textualRating: False. Adenoviruses and poxviruses are unrelated, and monkeys and chimpanzees are different species. Monkeypox is a poxvirus that originates in wild animals and occasionally jumps to people. The chimpanzee adenovirus causes the common cold in chimps. While the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine uses a harmless, weakened chimp adenovirus to trigger an immune response, the strain has been altered so it cannot infect humans with an adenovirus, nor could it cause monkeypox.

text: Video shows dead bodies waiting to be picked up in Wuhan, China, due to new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Video falsely claims to show bodies of virus victims in China
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows people sleeping in the streets in Shenzhen, China, a city over 600 miles away from Wuhan.

text: Photo shows a rally for former President Donald Trump in Waukesha, Wisconsin, on Aug. 5, 2022.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Wisconsin Trump rally in 2020, not 2022
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows a Trump campaign rally from Nov. 2, 2020, which took place at the Kenosha Regional Airport in Kenosha, Wisconsin.

text: It has been officially confirmed that the Insurrection Act has been secretly signed by President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: Trump has not invoked the Insurrection Act of 1807
claimReview.textualRating: False. The president has not invoked the Insurrection Act of 1807 in an effort to stay in office. To do so he would have to make a public declaration giving clear reasons for the move, which allows a president to call on the military to address a domestic crisis.

text: Only one film is scheduled to play at many major movie theaters nationwide from Jan. 7-8, and this may be related to a Jan. 6 news conference planned by former President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent movie schedules to push Jan. 6 conspiracy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The lack of listings in movie theater schedules has nothing to do with any political actions or other conspiracies. The single film — called “The 355” — currently listed this weekend is the only new movie premiering for most theaters, meaning tickets are open for advance sale. However, other titles that previously premiered and are still airing in theaters will be scheduled over the next few days, as is standard practice among most theaters.

text: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that a new COVID-19 variant is more contagious among vaccinated people than those who are unvaccinated.

claimReview.title: The CDC didn’t say vaccinated people are more at risk of a new COVID variant than the unvaccinated
claimReview.textualRating: False. In a risk assessment summary published Aug. 23, the CDC wrote that the BA.2.86 variant may be more likely to infect people with existing immunity to COVID-19, either from vaccinations or prior infections, than previous variants. It did not say that vaccinated people are at a higher risk than the unvaccinated.

text: Photos show former President Donald Trump being arrested by New York City law enforcement.

claimReview.title: AI-generated images of Trump being arrested circulate on social media
claimReview.textualRating: False. The images are fabricated and Trump has not been arrested. The person who created many of the images circulating on social media confirmed they were produced using Midjourney, an artificial intelligence text-to-image generator, and first posted as parody.

text: Video shows a huge pro-Palestinian rally in France in response to the Israel-Hamas war.

claimReview.title: Fans marching to a soccer game in Sao Paulo misrepresented as pro-Palestinian protesters in France
claimReview.textualRating: False. The widely shared clip shows fans of a Brazilian soccer team marching in Sao Paulo ahead of a game earlier this month.

text: Twitter CEO Elon Musk just revealed that Twitter’s algorithm “shadow banned” accounts using a list of terms and phrases, including “trump,” “epstein,” “soros” and “simulation.”

claimReview.title: Joke list of Twitter ‘shadow banned’ terms spreads as fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Musk has not made such an announcement. A Twitter user’s joke — claiming to show an image of the platform’s code featuring that list of keywords for banning purposes — was spread online as if it were real.

text: Louisiana mayor bans Nike products from city’s recreational centers

claimReview.title: Louisiana mayor bans Nike products from city’s recreational centers
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. Mayor Ben Zahn of Kenner, Louisiana sent a memo to the director of parks and recreation halting the purchase of Nike products by the city.

text: The governor general of Canada “said she needs 958,000 emails to remove” Prime Minister Justin Trudeau from office.

claimReview.title: Canada’s governor general didn’t call for emails to remove Trudeau
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Office of the Secretary to the Governor General said “no such registry or process exists.”

text: Adam Ali, a high school student from Solihull, a town in West Midlands, England, died from the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Teen’s death in England misrepresented by vaccine opponents
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ali, a 17-year-old student who died in September, had not been vaccinated against COVID-19. The cause of death is unknown, according to a spokesperson from the University Hospitals Birmingham NHS.

text: The gay dating app Grindr says if Florida doesn’t stop passing homophobic and transphobic laws, it will reveal every Republican legislator and party official who secretly uses the app.

claimReview.title: Grindr didn’t threaten to expose lawmakers using app
claimReview.textualRating: False. This claim originated on a satirical account. A spokesperson for Grindr denounced anti-LGBTQ legislation while confirming the app “protects the privacy of all its users.”

text: Border Patrol agent killed by attackers with rocks near the U.S.-Mexico border.

claimReview.title: Border Patrol agent not killed by rocks in ambush
claimReview.textualRating: False. A Border Patrol agent was not ambushed and killed with rocks near the U.S.-Mexico border despite what a photo circulating widely on social media suggested.

text: Rochelle “Silk” Richardson, half of the conservative talk duo “Diamond and Silk,” attributed her sister

claimReview.title: Silk of ‘Diamond and Silk’ didn’t say blood clot killed sister
claimReview.textualRating: False. A recording of Richardson’s remarks at the event contains no mention of blood clots. Hardaway died of heart disease caused by chronic high blood pressure, not a clot in her lung, according to her death certificate.

text: The World Economic Forum has declared that “fashion will be abolished by 2030” and that “humans will all wear a uniform.”

claimReview.title: The World Economic Forum hasn't called to abolish fashion and create a global 'uniform'
claimReview.textualRating: False. The WEF has never called to abolish fashion, a spokesperson for the organization told The Associated Press. Claims otherwise originated in an article by a website known for publishing misinformation, which misrepresented a 2019 report which merely suggests ways to reduce consumption-based emissions and has no connection to the WEF.

text: If a voter mails a ballot on Sunday and then shows up to a polling station to vote in person on Tuesday, election workers will not know whether the voter has already voted.

claimReview.title: States have checks in place to prevent voters from voting twice
claimReview.textualRating: False. States have various ways to protect against voters casting two ballots. Vote-by-mail ballots will be rejected in the verification process if it’s found a ballot was also cast in person.

text: Video of Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden deplaning in Tampa, Florida, during a campaign stop on Tuesday shows him waving to an empty field.

claimReview.title: Video does not show Biden waving to an empty field
claimReview.textualRating: False. An Associated Press reporter traveling with Biden confirmed he was waving to firefighters and other ground personnel outside the frame of the video.

text: Pouring water on home COVID-19 tests gives a positive result, evidence that they are unreliable or that they are detecting the disease in tap water.

claimReview.title: Using water on COVID-19 tests produces inaccurate results
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tests are not made to be used with other liquids, including water, and will provide inaccurate results in those situations. In addition, the virus that causes COVID-19 has not been detected in drinking water.

text: California Rep. Maxine Waters, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders have passed only six bills during their combined 67 years in office.

claimReview.title: 3 longtime Democratic members of Congress have passed more than 6 bills that became law
claimReview.textualRating: False. The three Democratic members of Congress have together served more than 80 years and have sponsored a total of 13 bills that became law.

text: Video shows thousands of Muslims praying in the streets of Paris.

claimReview.title: Video shows people attending Eid al-Fitr prayers in Moscow, not Paris
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed in Moscow near the Moscow Cathedral Mosque during Eid al-Fitr prayers on May 2.

text: Herbs including pennyroyal, mugwort and parsley are viable alternatives to abortion.

claimReview.title: Experts warn against using herbs as abortion alternative
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts strongly warn against trying to self-manage an abortion using any herbs, as many of these alleged remedies not only do not work but are dangerous or even deadly.

text: Video shows Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden botching the Pledge of Allegiance.

claimReview.title: Biden did not bungle the Pledge of Allegiance at a campaign stop
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden was not reciting the full Pledge of Allegiance. He was discussing, during a campaign stop in Manitowoc, Wisconsin, how he would govern as president. He also discussed coronavirus deaths in the U.S. surpassing 200,000 and details of his economic plan.

text: House Republicans are requiring Rep. Jamie Raskin, a Democrat from Maryland, to remove the headwear he’s donned on the House floor while undergoing chemotherapy.

claimReview.title: House GOP did not tell Raskin to remove head covering
claimReview.textualRating: False. Republicans have made no such request and have in fact been nothing but supportive, a spokesperson for Raskin told The Associated Press.

text: When former President Donald Trump was in charge, 18 months went by in Afghanistan when “we didn't lose one American soldier.”

claimReview.title: Trump misleads on Afghanistan casualties
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no year-and-half time frame under Trump’s presidency alone that no combat deaths among U.S. service members were reported. That occurred during the 18 months preceding the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan, which included months under the Biden administration as well.

text: A newly released document shows porn actor Stormy Daniels admitting she never had an affair with former President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: Posts share old Stormy Daniels statement as new info
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The signed statement with the denial was publicly released on Jan. 30, 2018. Not long after, Daniels recanted the statement and said that an affair had occurred. She said her denials were due to a non-disclosure agreement and that she signed the statement because parties involved “made it sound like I had no choice.”

text: The U.S. Army raided the Frankfurt office of the Spanish election software company Scytl to seize servers that had evidence of voting irregularities in the Nov. 3 U.S. election.

claimReview.title: False reports claim election servers were seized in Germany
claimReview.textualRating: False. Both the Army and Scytl told The Associated Press the claim is not true. Furthermore, Scytl does not have offices or servers in Frankfurt, Germany.

text: The word “dinosaur” was coined before the first dinosaur fossils were discovered, which proves that the prehistoric reptiles never existed.

claimReview.title: Meme falsely claims dinosaurs were only invented to prove evolution is real. There is no ‘dinohoax’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Humans have been finding dinosaur fossils for thousands of years, although experts widely credit an English surgeon and his wife for recognizing their significance after the couple’s 1822 discovery of dinosaur teeth in a forest south of London. An English anatomist and paleontologist coined the word “dinosauria,” the scientific name for dinosaurs meaning “terrible lizard,” in 1842.

text: A woman in Summit, Arkansas, was arrested on Friday after she trained deer to attack hunters and fed the animals meth.

claimReview.title: Story of Arkansas woman who fed deer meth is satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim first appeared in a post by a Facebook page that is clearly labeled as satire. A woman in a photo accompanying the post was arrested on multiple drug-related charges in Indiana last year. A second photo that shows a deer standing on furniture in a house was taken in Canada in 2019.

text: Photo collage proves vaccinations were staged.

claimReview.title: Photos show vaccinations being given, not staged events
claimReview.textualRating: False. The collage contains four photos of people being given vaccines: two of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi receiving the COVID-19 vaccine, one of Dr. Deena Hinshaw, Alberta's chief medical officer, receiving a flu shot in Canada, and another that shows a man in Sheffield, England, preparing for the COVID-19 vaccine.

text: President Donald Trump’s campaign sent an email asking supporters to donate as he recovers from COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Supposed fundraising email tied to Trump COVID-19 diagnosis was fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The email was fabricated. The campaign did not create or send it, according to the campaign’s communications director.

text: Sebastian Machado, a poll worker in Erie County, Pennsylvania, admitted he tossed out ballots that were filled out for President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: Social media user who claimed he threw out Pennsylvania ballots wasn’t poll worker
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Erie County Board of Elections confirmed in a statement on Tuesday that Machado is not a poll worker in the county and does not have any connection to the county’s election process.

text: An increase in death benefits paid out by life insurance providers in the third quarter of 2021 in the United States provides evidence that the COVID-19 vaccines, which became widely available in 2021, led to a spike in deaths.

claimReview.title: Vaccines didn’t cause increase in deaths and life insurance payouts
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim wrongly attempts to tie COVID-19 vaccines to a surge in deaths in the U.S. in 2021. Insurance industry leaders say the delta variant of the coronavirus and deferred medical care during the pandemic likely contributed to the increase in deaths. Even as millions of people got vaccinated against COVID-19 in 2021, reports of death after vaccination remain extremely rare, according to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention data.

text: Video shows Victoria’s Secret clothing tags have a chip in them that tracks buyers after they purchase a product.

claimReview.title: Tags in Victoria’s Secret bras are for inventory, not consumer tracking
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tiny barcode-like tag highlighted in the video is actually an ultra high frequency device used to track inventory in the store, said Justin Patton, director of a radio- frequency identification — RFID — lab at Auburn University. The passive UHF RFID technology has been used for more than a decade to track inventory in retail stores, but it isn’t functional outside the range of in-store RFID readers.

text: Rifles caused 454 deaths in the United States in 2020, while COVID-19 vaccines caused 20,622 deaths in the United States in 2021.

claimReview.title: COVID vaccines do not kill more people than rifles
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The claim that 20,000 people have died from COVID-19 vaccines misrepresents data maintained by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration. To date, a total of nine deaths in the U.S. have been linked to the shots, all related to rare blood clots caused by the Johnson & Johnson vaccine.

text: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives and David Chipman, who President Joe Biden has nominated to head the agency, laid siege on a religious sect’s compound in 1993, killing some 70 people.

claimReview.title: Biden’s ATF nominee investigated Waco raid but did not participate
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The ATF’s 1993 raid of a religious sect’s compound in Waco, Texas, did end in a fatal fire. However, Chipman arrived in Waco weeks after the raid and participated in the event “solely in a post-incident investigative review capacity,” the ATF confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Michigan county fears ‘vigilante’ serial killer after third pedophile murdered in one week.

claimReview.title: Michigan vigilante serial killer not on the loose
claimReview.textualRating: False. Law enforcement officials in Macomb County, Michigan, did not hold a press conference to announce that a vigilante serial killer is on the loose.

text: COVID-19 vaccines are causing a new illness called “VAIDS,” short for vaccine acquired immunodeficiency syndrome.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines don’t cause immunodeficiency syndrome
claimReview.textualRating: False. VAIDS isn’t a real condition, nor do COVID-19 vaccines cause a syndrome matching this description, an immunotherapy expert confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Texas lawmakers approved legislation in 2021 lowering the minimum age for carrying a handgun to 18.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent new Texas handgun laws
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. While Texas lawmakers did approve legislation in 2021 that allowed people ages 18 to 20 to obtain handgun permits under specific court orders, generally, the minimum age to legally carry a handgun in Texas is 21, according to experts.

text: A FOX Business story says a Kenosha, Wisconsin, car dealer whose car lot was burned during recent unrest killed himself because insurance would not cover the damage.

claimReview.title: Kenosha car dealer did not commit suicide over denial of insurance coverage
claimReview.textualRating: False. The story was fabricated and published on a page made to resemble FOX Business news. Anmol Khindri, whose family owns the Car Source dealership, is alive. He did recently tell reporters that insurance had declined to cover the damage caused by recent unrest.

text: During the vice presidential debate, Vice President Mike Pence said, “Trump and I trust the American people to make choices for themselves and their families — Harris and Biden want to mandate how you care for yourself.” And Democratic vice presidential nominee Kamala Harris said, “The American people aren’t equipped to make these decisions for themselves.”

claimReview.title: Social media users share distorted Harris quote from debate
claimReview.textualRating: False. Neither quote is verbatim what the candidates said, but while the quote attributed to Pence is close to a statement he made, the social media post distorts Harris’ quote. In reality, she was criticizing the Trump administration for failing to inform the American people about the threat of COVID-19.

text: Grave markers for a Ukrainian family that say they died on March 9 in Izium prove they were not killed by Russian forces, because Russian troops did not enter the Ukrainian city until weeks later.

claimReview.title: Ukrainian family killed in Russian attack, despite denials
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Ukrainian city of Izium was being heavily bombarded by Russian forces on March 9 and the family was killed in the attack. Associated Press journalists in Ukraine have spoken with a dozen people with direct knowledge of the attack on the high-rise building where the family lived. Reports from humanitarian groups, Ukrainian media and Ukrainian officials at the time also documented the destruction.

text: The COVID-19 vaccine from Johnson & Johnson enters the nucleus of cells, suggesting that the shot alters recipients’ DNA.

claimReview.title: Post misleads on J&J COVID vaccine, DNA
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The vaccine uses a weakened, modified cold virus. While the DNA from that adenovirus does enter the nucleus of cells in order to produce mRNA and prompt production of the spike protein of the coronavirus, experts say there’s no evidence the shots alter a person’s DNA.

text: Photo shows Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping holding up T-shirts that say “I (Heart) China.”

claimReview.title: Photo altered to show Biden holding “I (Heart) China” T-shirt
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was manipulated. In the original photo, the former vice president holds up a tee with Chinese text that translates in English to “China America two countries friendship everlasting.”

text: The U.S. Marine Corps “neutralized” a “fleeing FEMA convoy in Maui.”

claimReview.title: The Marines didn’t attack a FEMA convoy on Maui. The claim originated on a parody site
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are sharing a post from a website that says it publishes “humor, parody, and satire” and has previously published similar false stories. A Federal Emergency Management Agency spokesperson confirmed the claim is “unequivocally false.”

text: Hawaii passed a bill to keep former President Donald Trump off the ballot during the 2024 election.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent the status of a bill that could disqualify Trump from the ballot in Hawaii
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Hawaii’s Senate Committee on Judiciary voted on Tuesday to move forward a bill that could disqualify Trump from the ballot under the U.S. Constitution’s insurrection clause. The bill passed a first vote on the Senate floor late last month and would need to pass at least two additional votes on the floor to clear the Senate and move to the House.

text: Journalist Hana Mahameed is back on camera with her face covered in bandages after being wounded by an Israeli grenade in the latest Israel-Hamas war.

claimReview.title: 2015 image of journalist wounded in east Jerusalem spreads as new
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are sharing an image of Mahameed in 2015. Mahameed, an Arab-Israeli correspondent for a Lebanon-based TV station, said at the time that she was hit in the face by a sound grenade fired by Israeli police during a clash with Palestinian demonstrators in east Jerusalem.

text: Time magazine cover states that toxic vaccines are “Poisoning of An Entire Generation.”

claimReview.title: Time magazine cover that warns of toxic vaccines is fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. A Time magazine cover that warns of dangerous vaccines is not real.

text: Footage shows former President George H. W. Bush dying on live television.

claimReview.title: Video shows former President George H. W. Bush ill, not dying, at 1992 dinner in Japan
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video clip being misrepresented on social media shows Bush falling ill at a 1992 dinner with Japan’s prime minister. The late Bush died in 2018 at 94.

text: Over 40 million people in the United States have voted early in the 2022 election, surpassing 2018 and 2020, which means the ballots could be fake or fraudulent.

claimReview.title: 2022 early voting levels haven’t surpassed 2020, don’t indicate fraud
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. More people have voted early in 2022 than in the 2018 general election, but neither year beat 2020, when more than 100 million people voted early in the presidential election, according to experts who track that information. High early voting levels aren’t evidence of fake or fraudulent ballots.

text: California Gov. Gavin Newsom signed a bill “reducing penalties for sodomy with minors.”

claimReview.title: Posts spread old claim about California sex crimes bill
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The headline being cited this week is two years old, and is being shared with no information on the purpose of the bill. The legislation expanded judges’ discretion regarding sex offender registration only in certain statutory rape cases.

text: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said, “It’s time to ban cash to fight climate change.”

claimReview.title: No, Hillary Clinton didn’t call for banning cash to fight climate change
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no record of Clinton making that remark and the website making the attribution doesn’t provide any evidence for its claim. The Clinton Foundation confirmed she did not make that statement.

text: Scientists have warned that the “Earth will be swallowed by the sun.”

claimReview.title: The sun might swallow the Earth, but not for another 5 billion years
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Scientists predicted that the Earth could eventually be swallowed by the sun after they reported in a study published in May the first observation of a star engulfing a planet. But they made clear that if the Earth does meet this fate, it won’t be for another 5 billion years.

text: Salzburg Airport in Austria has a help desk specifically for people who intended to fly to Australia.

claimReview.title: No, an Austrian airport doesn’t have a desk for travelers who thought they were going to Australia
claimReview.textualRating: False. The European airport confirmed it does not have a desk for misguided tourists trying to get Down Under. The misconception stems from an advertisement for a technology company that ran on a baggage carousel at the airport, which joked about offering such a service.

text: A video clip shows people in Lebanon climbing a barrier on the border with Israel after war was declared following Hamas’ invasion of Israel in early October.

claimReview.title: Video footage from the Lebanon-Israel border is from 2021, not the latest Gaza war
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from a May 2021 protest in a Lebanese border village, held in solidarity with Palestinians amid the fourth Gaza war.

text: World Economic Forum executive chairman Klaus Schwab admitted that his plan for a “Great Reset” is being destroyed by a “political revolution” against the idea.

claimReview.title: The WEF’s chairman did not confess that a ‘political revolution’ is destroying his agenda
claimReview.textualRating: False. An article by a website known to publish misinformation misrepresented a speech Schwab gave on the future of governments worldwide at a 2017 conference in Dubai, three years before the WEF introduced the idea of The Great Reset. In reality, Schwab spoke about the need to develop new systems of government to reflect contemporary perspectives and what such systems could entail.

text: Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla has resigned from the company and admits that mRNA technology is not safe.

claimReview.title: Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla is not stepping down
claimReview.textualRating: False. Bourla never said that the vaccine technology is unsafe nor that he is resigning. Pfizer confirmed in a statement to The Associated Press that Bourla is still serving as the pharmaceutical company’s chairman and CEO.

text: The Arc de Triomphe in Paris has been adorned with a giant rainbow installation to celebrate Pride month.

claimReview.title: Video of massive rainbow installation at Arc de Triomphe was made using special effects
claimReview.textualRating: False. The installation seen in a widespread video was digitally created with special effects programs, the video’s creator told The Associated Press.

text: Postal service employees in Madison, Wisconsin, backdated the postmarks on late arriving ballots in the November election so they would be counted.

claimReview.title: Backdating ballots in Wisconsin would not have altered vote count
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ballots had to arrive by 8 p.m. on Election Day in Wisconsin to be counted in the 2020 election. The postmark was irrelevant. In addition, no evidence has been presented to show that any such ballot tampering occurred.

text: A New York City high school was shut down to house migrants who entered the U.S. illegally.

claimReview.title: Migrants in NYC were temporarily housed in a local school during a storm. The school has not shut down
claimReview.textualRating: False. In anticipation of a potentially damaging storm, nearly 2,000 migrants being housed in tents at an outdoor Brooklyn shelter were moved temporarily to a nearby high school in the borough’s Midwood neighborhood on Tuesday night. All of the migrants had left the school by early the next morning. Classes were held remotely on Wednesday and resumed in person on Thursday.

text: The United Nations has replaced all of its members’ flags with Pride flags.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Pride flags at Rockefeller Center, not United Nations
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows Pride flags displayed at Rockefeller Center, not the United Nations headquarters or any other U.N. property. While the New York City center does regularly display the flags of the 193 U.N. member states, it also routinely swaps them out.

text: A photo shows actor Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson wearing a T-shirt with the phrase “Keep America Trumpless” on it.

claimReview.title: Photo of Dwayne Johnson in anti-Trump shirt was edited
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image has been manipulated to add the message. The original photo, a promotional still for a 2015 film, shows the actor wearing a shirt that reads “Los Angeles Fire Department.”

text: The updated COVID-19 vaccine boosters were authorized without human trials to establish their safety.

claimReview.title: Claims lack context on updated COVID-19 boosters
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While clinical trials are not complete for the exact formulations cleared by officials, experts say the original COVID-19 vaccine trials and real-world use — as well as studies in people of very similar tweaked COVID-19 booster shots — provide ample safety data. The updates have been likened to changes to the annual flu vaccine.

text: Photo shows Dr. Anthony Fauci, Melinda Gates and Barack Obama at the Wuhan lab in 2015.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Obama at a lab in Wuhan, China, in 2015
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows then-President Barack Obama visiting the National Institutes of Health in 2014 along with Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, and then-Secretary of Health and Human Services Sylvia Burwell. They are listening to Dr. Nancy Sullivan, chief of the Biodefense Research Section of The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.

text: An antifa flyer is circulating, calling on people to “disguise” themselves as “Patriot Trump supporters” during riots on Nov. 4.

claimReview.title: No evidence flyer linked to antifa groups
claimReview.textualRating: False. A meme of the flyer has been circulating online at least since 2017. There’s no evidence that the meme is connected to antifa groups.

text: Video shows people protesting outside the “Rothschild’s castle” in Switzerland.

claimReview.title: Video shows protesters outside Swiss parliament, not ‘Rothschild’s castle’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage, which shows protesters being hit with water cannons, was filmed in front of barriers outside the Swiss parliament building on Bundesplatz plaza in Bern. The protesters were demonstrating against COVID-19 restrictions on Sept. 16, Swiss media outlets reported. A chateau owned by the Rothchild family is in Geneva.

text: The Biden administration is funding drug smoking kits that are being distributed by a Los Angeles-based organization.

claimReview.title: Video misrepresents funding of drug smoking kits in LA
claimReview.textualRating: False. No federal funding was used to provide the safer smoking kits that are being distributed by Being Alive, an HIV and AIDS-focused nonprofit in Los Angeles. The organization’s funding comes from the state of California, according to Being Alive staff and state officials. The safer smoking kits include sterile supplies intended to decrease harm caused to drug users.

text: The Red Cross says if you recovered from COVID-19 and had a vaccine, you cannot donate blood plasma because the vaccine wipes out natural antibodies.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines do not wipe out antibodies
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Red Cross did not make that statement. The organization is accepting blood and plasma donations from people who have been vaccinated, but has discontinued an earlier initiative to collect convalescent plasma from recovered COVID-19 to treat those with the virus. Experts say COVID-19 vaccines do not wipe out natural antibodies from COVID-19, and instead boost antibodies.

text: An update to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives’ background check policy allows people in the U.S. illegally to purchase firearms.

claimReview.title: ATF rules not updated to allow migrants to purchase firearms
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such update has been made. Federal law prohibits people in the country illegally from purchasing or possessing firearms, with “limited exceptions,” an ATF spokesperson told The Associated Press. The ATF does not have the power to change federal law, only implement it.

text: Soccer star Cristiano Ronaldo donated 1.5 million euros to Palestinians for iftar, the meal eaten each night to break fast during Ramadan.

claimReview.title: Cristiano Ronaldo did not donate money to Palestinians during Ramadan
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ronaldo did not donate money for that cause despite posts that circulated widely on social media over the weekend.

text: Minnesota Rep. Ilhan Omar tells residents “you don't have to be registered to vote in Minnesota.”

claimReview.title: Rep. Omar’s tweet on same-day voter registration misrepresented online
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Omar said that you do not have to be registered to vote in Minnesota because the state has same-day registration.

text: Video shows Ukrainian civilians throwing Molotov cocktails at Russian vehicles after Russia’s invasion in February 2022.

claimReview.title: Old video shows Ukrainian revolution, not Russian invasion
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from 2014, and shows Ukrainian demonstrators clashing with local authorities during anti-government protests.

text: Florida has halted COVID-19 mRNA vaccines for men ages 18-39.

claimReview.title: Florida men under 40 can still get COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The state’s surgeon general issued guidance in early October recommending against mRNA COVID-19 vaccines for this demographic. However, men ages 18-39 can still get the shots in Florida if they choose to.

text: A male prostitute was found in the home of former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

claimReview.title: False claim that a male prostitute was found in Nancy Pelosi’s home reemerges after Trump indictment
claimReview.textualRating:
False. Law enforcement officials confirm that the man who attacked Pelosi’s husband in their San Francisco home late last year was neither a prostitute nor an acquaintance of the family.
List (Page)

text: A photo shows a 7-Eleven gas station selling fuel for $7.11.

claimReview.title: Photo of $7.11 gas at 7-Eleven shows sign test from 2020
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The photo, taken at a Chicago 7-Eleven location, is more than a year old and shows placeholder numbers being used to test the sign before the location was open to the public, according to both the person who took the image and representatives for 7-Eleven. While gas prices in some parts of the country have exceeded $7 in recent weeks, this particular gas station was not charging that amount when the photo was captured, and is currently charging around $6.

text: A clip of Sunny Hostin, co-host of the talk show “The View,” shows her admitting to illegally voting on behalf of her son during the 2022 midterm election.

claimReview.title: Posts distort Sunny Hostin’s ‘View’ comments on Election Day
claimReview.textualRating: False. Her comments during the show’s Election Day episode are being misrepresented. The clip shows Hostin describing how she dropped off her son’s absentee ballot, not admitting to fraudulently casting votes in his name. A spokesperson confirmed that Hostin was the designated person assigned by her son to drop off his completed absentee ballot, which is permitted in the New York county where they voted.

text: A video shows various TV presenters from shows sponsored by Pfizer collapsing on camera due to side effects from Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: ‘Brought to you by Pfizer’ video is false, edited to deceive
claimReview.textualRating: False. This video is deceptively edited to suggest the TV presenters collapsed because of the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine, but The Associated Press has previously reported that those featured in the video collapsed for other reasons. COVID-19 vaccines are not causing a large number of people to collapse in routine settings, medical experts say.

text: Video taken by school staffer shows scores of banned books being removed from a middle school in Broward County, Florida.

claimReview.title: Video doesn’t show banned books being removed from Florida school, officials say
claimReview.textualRating: False. Officials in the school district say the books are being removed as part of a routine weeding out of old materials that coincides with a library renovation project, not because they were banned. The local teacher’s union and the state education department confirm it is unrelated to any bans and the old books are being replaced with newer ones.

text: Minors in Washoe County, Nevada, cast votes in the 2020 presidential election.

claimReview.title: Minors in Nevada county did not vote in the 2020 election
claimReview.textualRating: False. Washoe County officials said some minors in the county did receive ballots but they were flagged as invalid before the election started.

text: The European Union is working to create a “personal carbon credit” system in which individuals pay directly for the greenhouse gases they produce.

claimReview.title: EU not imposing a “personal carbon credit” system
claimReview.textualRating: False. Spokespersons for the EU’s legislative and executive offices say there has been no consideration of setting up such a system as it seeks to address the impacts of global warming. Climate change policy experts who have been closely watching the process say the EU has been focused on industry-level regulations, rather than ones directly on individuals.

text: Leprosy is making a comeback in Los Angeles and the city is at risk for an outbreak

claimReview.title: Fears of leprosy outbreak in Los Angeles unfounded
claimReview.textualRating: False. The number of leprosy cases in Los Angeles County has stayed consistent over the last decade and the area is not at risk for an outbreak, according to the Los Angeles County Health Department.

text: A video clip shows Biden stating that individuals should get vaccinated to protect themselves against hurricanes.

claimReview.title: Video clip misrepresents Biden’s comments on hurricane preparedness
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video clip, first posted on TikTok, was edited to remove key portions of Biden’s comments. A review of his full statement shows he said getting vaccinated against COVID-19 is a vital step in hurricane preparedness, necessary to protect people should they have to evacuate or stay in shelters.

text: The Biden administration is giving migrants free six-month stays in hotels, $1100 Greyhound bus vouchers and money for food.

claimReview.title: Posts mischaracterize details of Biden’s hotel plan for migrants
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Biden administration authorized $86.9 million for services for migrant families and roughly 1,200 hotel beds for short stays up to 72 hours -- not six months of continuous lodging. The government is not providing migrants released from federal custody with vouchers to travel by bus or food stipends.

text: The nasal swab test commonly used for diagnosing COVID-19 involves obtaining a sample from a protective layer of cells known as the blood-brain barrier. Disrupting this area can result in inflammation to the brain.

claimReview.title: Test for COVID-19 does not involve collecting a sample from the blood-brain barrier
claimReview.textualRating: False. The swab used in diagnostic COVID-19 tests does not touch the blood-brain barrier. Instead, it is placed in the nasopharynx, a cavity behind the nose where the highest yield of viruses can be collected.

text: A study published in the New England Journal of Medicine found that the effectiveness of Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine becomes “negative” within five months and destroys immunity garnered from prior infection with COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Study finds Pfizer vaccine boosts, not destroys, immunity from past COVID-19 infection
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the study found that the vaccine’s efficacy in children decreased over time, the study also determined that vaccination actually boosted the immunity of children who had previously been infected with COVID-19, compared to those who had only been infected, the lead author of the study told The Associated Press.

text: A new deposition says that on the morning of the 2018 mass shooting at a Parkland, Florida, high school, the officer assigned to the school was “literally stealing hundreds of dollars from the backpacks of students.”

claimReview.title: Parkland student didn’t accuse officer of ‘stealing’ money
claimReview.textualRating: False. A former student said in a 2019 deposition for a civil lawsuit that the school resource officer, Scot Peterson, removed $200 from his backpack during a search and questioned him about it, before returning the money. The suit, which in part accused Peterson of an unlawful seizure, was dismissed.

text: “They want us to believe that Joe Biden won 200 fewer counties than Obama but somehow got 9 million more votes? I don’t think so…”

claimReview.title: Counties won and votes received don’t correlate in presidential race
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. It’s true that President-elect Joe Biden received more votes than former President Barack Obama did in 2008, while winning fewer counties. Posts questioning Biden’s win based on these metrics lack the key context that the number of counties won does not correlate with the number of votes received nationwide.

text: California asked residents “to avoid charging electric cars amid power grid strain.”

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on California electric car charging
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The headline being shared was from a June 2021 heat wave — not mid-March 2022 — and was a voluntary recommendation that residents charge electric vehicles and do other activities outside of certain peak periods.

text: Congressman mocks sexual assault allegation against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, joking that Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said Lincoln groped her

claimReview.title: Congressman mocks sexual assault allegation against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, joking that Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said Lincoln groped her
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. U.S. Rep. Ralph Norman sparked outrage after he made an off color joke that Ginsburg said Abe Lincoln groped her, mocking Kavanaugh’s accuser.

text: NASCAR allows a Black Lives Matter-themed car, but won’t allow its audience to wear MAGA hats or other Trump clothing.

claimReview.title: NASCAR has not banned ‘Make America Great Again’ hats or other Trump gear
claimReview.textualRating: False. The auto racing association has not banned Trump-themed clothing, according to NASCAR spokesman Mike Forde.

text: The Federal Reserve is launching a digital currency app, FedNow, that will eliminate physical cash.

claimReview.title: Federal Reserve’s payment service FedNow would not replace cash
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Federal Reserve's FedNow is a service that allows banks and credit unions to transfer funds more quickly. It’s not a form of currency, nor is it a move towards eliminating cash, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System stated.

text: Photo shows an extremely tall building in Hong Kong with units squeezed together almost without end.

claimReview.title: Image of Hong Kong building is digitally altered
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The 2018 image of a residential building in Hong Kong has been digitally altered to make it appear taller and even more cramped with apartment units than it is.

text: Over-the-counter cold and cough medications are being pulled from drugstore shelves in an effort to start the “next plandemic" or force people to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Voluntary removal of popular cold-and-cough medications from store shelves fuels conspiracy theories
claimReview.textualRating: False. Not all cold medications are being removed from all store shelves. Some over-the-counter cold and cough medicines that contain phenylephrine as a single ingredient are being voluntarily removed at CVS stores after an FDA advisory committee found the ingredient to be ineffective. Medical experts tell The Associated Press that brands still provide other cold medications with ingredients to relieve symptoms like congestion, but they do not prevent illness like a flu vaccine would.

text: A study proves that COVID-19 PCR tests are actually human cloning devices.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 PCR tests are not human cloning devices
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 2015 paper describes how to clone a gene using a technique called polymerase chain reaction, or PCR. COVID-19 PCR tests create copies of a certain region of the virus’ genetic material to help detect whether the virus is present in a patient’s sample, experts told The Associated Press. But gene cloning is completely different from reproductive cloning, which is used to create an identical copy of an entire person or animal.

text: In a July 17 tweet, President Donald Trump says he is “SO MAD” the Pentagon abolished the Confederate flag and calls the flag a symbol of love.

claimReview.title: Trump tweet calling Confederate flag a ‘symbol of LOVE’ is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. This tweet was fabricated. It does not appear on either archived versions of Trump’s Twitter feed or databases that track deleted tweets by politicians.

text: Pfizer wants to thank taxpayers, lobbyists and politicians for a record $37 billion in profit last quarter.

claimReview.title: Pfizer did not profit $37 billion in most recent quarter
claimReview.textualRating: False. Financial information is not yet available for the fourth quarter, which ended Dec. 31, but the pharmaceutical’s most recent financial report shows it made a net income, or profit, of $8.15 billion in the third quarter. This post is not a genuine message from Pfizer.

text: A photo of a dog moving through rubble, and another of a dog lying next to the arm of someone trapped under rubble, were taken after the earthquake that struck Turkey and neighboring Syria on Monday.

claimReview.title: Old photos of dogs in rubble spread after quake in Turkey and Syria
claimReview.textualRating: False. The images were taken more than four years ago and can be found on stock photography websites, where they are credited to a Czech photographer.

text: Video shows church bells ringing out in Paris on Saturday to celebrate Democratic candidate Joe Biden winning the United States presidential election.

claimReview.title: Church bells did not ring across Paris for Joe Biden
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bells were not related to the U.S. presidential race, the Paris diocese confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Numerous government entities are exempt from President Joe Biden’s vaccine mandates, including the legislative branch, the judicial branch, White House staff, and employees with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Food and Drug Administration and the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. The U.S. Postal Service and vaccine makers Moderna and Pfizer are also exempt, as well as undocumented immigrants.

claimReview.title: List of federal vaccine mandate exemptions is inaccurate
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. An official with the U.S. Office of Management and Budget told The Associated Press that White House staff and employees of the CDC, FDA and NIAID are not exempt from the mandates. The Postal Service, Moderna and Pfizer are expected to be covered by Biden’s vaccine requirements for large businesses. Biden does not have the authority to pass mandates for the legislative and judicial branches. Further, undocumented immigrants were not mentioned in the mandates.

text: Video shows Hurricane Hanna knocking down Trump’s border wall.

claimReview.title: Video does not show Hurricane Hanna leveling border wall
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video does show heavy winds knocking down a section of border wall being built under the administration of President Donald Trump, but it was not taken as Hurricane Hanna passed over Texas this weekend.

text: “The Colorado Secretary of State is DELETING DOMINION DOCUMENTS from the official Colorado Secretary of State website.”

claimReview.title: Removal of Dominion document from Colorado site was temporary
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. A 2015 request-for-proposal document from the election technology firm Dominion Voting Systems was temporarily removed from the Colorado secretary of state’s website on Friday. However, it was only taken down for a day, to redact personal information of Dominion employees, Colorado Secretary of State Jena Griswold told The Associated Press. The redacted version was restored to the document’s original web address on Saturday.

text: A video shows that dropping juice onto an iHealth COVID-19 test panel returns a positive result, meaning the tests are unreliable.

claimReview.title: Video misuses COVID-19 test to cast doubt
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Dropping the highly acidic juice onto the test panel can cause the pH value to change “excessively,” leading to a false positive result, iHealth Lab’s medical research team told The Associated Press in a statement. The juice does not contain COVID-19, nor does it mean the test doesn’t work properly with correct use.

text: A CNN clip showing fires near Lviv, Ukraine, must have been staged or filmed elsewhere because a firefighter in the clip can be seen wearing a jacket labeled for the Canadian city of Edmonton.

claimReview.title: ‘Edmonton’ firefighter gear in news clip was donated to Ukrainians
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip was captured at an oil facility on the northeastern outskirts of Lviv and there’s no merit to claims that it was staged. A Canadian group called Firefighter Aid Ukraine donated the jacket to Ukrainian firefighters in need of equipment, the group’s founder confirmed in a phone interview Monday.

text: The sports apparel company Nike was quoted saying "we’re a $76 billion dollar company that can afford to let go of all ‘Make America Great Again’ customers."

claimReview.title: Nike didn’t say it could afford to lose MAGA customers
claimReview.textualRating: False. This quote is fake, according to company spokeswoman Sandra Carreon-John. It has circulated online since at least 2018.

text: Bud Light created a billboard advertisement that reads, “lol CRYBABIES,” after the company was targeted by calls for a boycott over a partnership with a transgender influencer.

claimReview.title: Bud Light did not call its critics ‘crybabies’ on a billboard
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Bud Light advertisement is not real, the owners of the billboard confirmed to The Associated Press. The actual billboard currently displays an advertisement for the streaming service Disney+.

text: Starbucks will stop accepting cash at its stores in the U.K.

claimReview.title: No, all UK Starbucks locations are not going cashless
claimReview.textualRating: False. Starbucks is not going cashless at all of its U.K. stores, but individual franchises can choose not to accept cash, according to a statement posted on the company’s U.K. Twitter account.

text: Video shows mourners gathering in North Korea at the funeral of the country’s leader, Kim Jong Un.

claimReview.title: Video does not show funeral of North Korea leader Kim Jong Un
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows the funeral of his father and former North Korea leader Kim Jong Il, taken in December 2011.

text: A photo shows Sasha Johnson, a British Black Lives Matter activist, in a motorized wheelchair after she was shot at a party in London.

claimReview.title: Posts share edited image of Black Lives Matter activist
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. While Johnson was critically injured when she was shot in the head in 2021, the photo circulating on social media is not authentic. A 2002 photo of the late theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking was edited to add Johnson’s image.

text: Country singer Luke Bryan pulled his videos from Country Music Television and said, “Time for the Bud Light treatment.”

claimReview.title: Claim that Luke Bryan pulled his videos from CMT originated as satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. That claim originated on a website that publishes made-up, satirical content.

text: Spain’s minister of equality said during a parliamentary hearing that children should have the right to consent to sex with adults.

claimReview.title: Spanish official’s comments on sex education mischaracterized
