claimReview.textualRating: False. Irene Montero, Spain’s minister of equality, did not suggest this when she spoke before a legislative commission last week. The left-wing politician was discussing provisions in a proposed abortion law that deal with sex education programs, including material about consent. A short video clip of her remarks was taken out of context.

text: The vaccine contains the virus. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said this.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccine does not contain live virus
claimReview.textualRating: False. Posts online are sharing a clip of Johnson to suggest that the vaccine contains the virus, which it does not.

text: The Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution and Title III of the U.S. Civil Rights Act prohibit businesses from asking people for proof of vaccination.

claimReview.title: Federal law allows businesses to ask for proof of vaccination
claimReview.textualRating: False. It does not violate the Fourth Amendment or the 1964 Civil Rights Act for a business to ask customers or employees for proof of vaccination, according to legal experts. States may prohibit businesses from requiring proof of vaccination for service, as Florida has done.

text: Over 500 mail-in ballots for Trump were found dumped at Marysville Precinct in Michigan, revealing voter fraud in the election.

claimReview.title: Michigan county did not dump Trump votes
claimReview.textualRating: False. Michigan election officials say the claim that 500 absentee votes were dumped is inaccurate.

text: Video shows President Joe Biden struggling to speak for a whole minute as he stumbles over his words in an interview with Nicolle Wallace on MSNBC.

claimReview.title: Video of Biden on MSNBC was altered to make it appear like he struggled to speak for a full minute
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. Footage of a 20-minute interview with Biden on the network in June has been edited down to only show moments where Biden briefly faltered in his speech.

text: Woman’s adopted pit bull suspected of killing her

claimReview.title: Woman’s adopted pit bull suspected of killing her
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. A Maryland woman, Robin Conway, was found dead in her backyard with the dog standing over her on Monday.

text: Photo shows a pile of bricks in Kenosha, Wisconsin, placed around the courthouse of the Kyle Rittenhouse trial.

claimReview.title: Photo shows pile of bricks in Dallas, not Kenosha
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image, which has been circulating online since 2020, shows stacked bricks in Dallas, Texas.

text: Hydrogen peroxide, a common disinfectant, can be absorbed through the skin to kill tumor tissue or cure cancer.

claimReview.title: Hydrogen peroxide does not cure cancer
claimReview.textualRating: False. Applying hydrogen peroxide to your skin won’t cure cancer, and trying to ingest it in other ways would be dangerous and ineffective, an oncologist told The Associated Press. The National Institutes of Health has found no evidence that the compound can treat cancer if rubbed on the skin.

text: Demetrius Griffin Jr., a Black teenager in Chicago, was killed in 2016 by “other Black kids” who burned him to death because he “refused to join their gang.”

claimReview.title: Black teen’s death in Chicago remains an open investigation
claimReview.textualRating: False. Griffin’s death remains an open investigation, according to Chicago police. There are no suspects at this time.

text: A photo shows President Joe Biden touching a child inappropriately below the waist.

claimReview.title: Photo of Biden was altered to suggest he touched a child inappropriately
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The photo was digitally altered to make it appear as if Biden’s hands were under the child’s shirt. The original photo, which was taken by an Associated Press photographer in 2021, shows the child stretching their shirt to show the president, who is pointing at the shirt in return.

text: A new autopsy report for George Floyd has been released in 2023, revealing he died from a drug overdose, not from the actions of arresting Minneapolis police officers.

claimReview.title: George Floyd’s autopsy report is not new, does not say he died of an overdose
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are sharing a page from the 20-page autopsy report that was publicly released by the Hennepin County Medical Examiner’s office in full on June 3, 2020. It has not been changed since. While the page says he had fentanyl and methamphetamine in his system, and did not have “life-threatening injuries,” the full report concludes Floyd died from “cardiopulmonary arrest,” not an overdose.

text: The World Economic Forum has proposed a ban on natural conception, advocating for all babies to be “lab-grown” by 2030.

claimReview.title: The World Economic Forum didn’t call for mandatory ‘lab-grown’ babies
claimReview.textualRating: False. The organization has not made such a proposal. The website making the claim, which has a history of sharing misinformation, links to an old WEF blog post about outside research into devices that could theoretically be used to save babies born prematurely.

text: Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg is charging a New York City parking garage attendant for attempted murder after he shot an alleged armed robber.

claimReview.title: Manhattan DA Bragg not prosecuting parking attendant over shooting
claimReview.textualRating: False. Police initially arrested the worker on charges of attempted murder, assault and gun possession over the Saturday incident, but Bragg’s office dropped the charges the following day. The man’s lawyer said a video of the altercation clearing his client of wrongdoing was sent to the DA’s office.

text: Mel Gibson is making a multi-part documentary on child sex trafficking

claimReview.title: Mel Gibson is not making a child sex trafficking documentary, publicist says
claimReview.textualRating: False. The actor’s publicist says he isn’t making any documentary about child sex trafficking. The founder of a Utah anti-trafficking nonprofit has previously suggested the actor provided initial support for a documentary in development, but he confirmed to The Associated Press that Gibson is not involved in making the film.

text: Video shows President Joe Biden wearing an outfit in the style of Communist authoritarian leader Mao Zedong to a diplomatic meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping on Monday.

claimReview.title: Biden did not wear ‘Mao’ outfit to meeting with Xi
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage shows Biden on Saturday during a summit of Association of Southeast Asian Nations leaders. Biden was wearing a traditional garment from Cambodia, the summit’s host nation. He met with Xi several days later in Indonesia, where photos show Biden wore a blue business suit and tie.

text: The manager of a Starbucks in North Carolina informed his employees they would be fired on the spot for saying "Merry Christmas" to customers.

claimReview.title: Starbucks manager did not ban saying ‘Merry Christmas’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Starbucks does not tell its employees how to greet customers, and the Twitter account that posted the claim does not belong to a Starbucks employee.

text: The captain of Dali, the container ship that crashed into Baltimore’s Francis Scott Key Bridge, is Ukrainian.

claimReview.title: Captain of container ship that caused Baltimore bridge collapse is Indian, not Ukrainian
claimReview.textualRating: False. A Ukrainian man who was listed on a maritime jobs database as captaining Dali for about five months in 2016 is being erroneously blamed for the incident online. The Dali’s captain and crew are Indian, Synergy Marine Group, the company that manages the ship, told The Associated Press. There were two pilots — local specialists who help guide vessels safely in and out of ports — navigating Dali at the time of the collision. Both are U.S. citizens, according to Synergy.

text: National Geographic is participating in a fundraising campaign on Instagram that will give $1 for every "like" on posts to benefit the Amazon following the fires.

claimReview.title: Fake donation campaign targets Amazon fires
claimReview.textualRating: False. National Geographic is not participating in a campaign circulating on Instagram to raise money for the Amazon.

text: Former President John F. Kennedy said, “There are people in Washington D.C. in positions of power to whom the border is just a nuisance. And I think some of them believe that illegal immigration is a moral good. It is not.”

claimReview.title: Immigration quote comes from Sen. John Kennedy, not JFK
claimReview.textualRating: False. This quote comes from Republican Sen. John Kennedy of Louisiana, not the former president.

text: In 2016, Republicans in the Senate voted unanimously to ban people from buying guns who were on the FBI’s terror watch list. Every single Democrat voted against it.

claimReview.title: Both parties failed to pass 2016 measures to ban guns sales to terrorists
claimReview.textualRating: False. Not all Democrats voted against it and the post lacks context.

text: Guinness World Records “certified” that the boat parade supporting President Trump in Clearwater, Florida, was the “largest boat parade in history.”

claimReview.title: No determination on whether Trump boat parade broke records
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Guinness World Records told The Associated Press on Monday that the application for the Clearwater boat parade supporting Trump is still being reviewed. It could take up to 15 weeks to confirm whether it broke the current record.

text: A video shows a major library in France burning during riots sparked by the killing of a teen by police.

claimReview.title: Video of a post office on fire in the Philippines misrepresented as library in France during riots
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the façade of a library in Marseille was reportedly vandalized during the unrest, the widely shared video shows the fiery destruction of a historic post office in the Philippines in May.

text: McDonald's removing artificial additives from its burgers

claimReview.title: Most McDonald’s burgers now preservative-free
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. On Wednesday, McDonald’s announced that most of its burgers are now preservative-free.

text: A video shows Sen. Dianne Feinstein returning to the U.S. Capitol in a hearse on Wednesday following her two-and-a-half-month absence due to illness.

claimReview.title: A video of Feinstein returning to the Capitol was edited to swap her sedan for a hearse
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. The video was edited to add in the hearse. In the original footage, Feinstein can be seen getting out of a silver Lexus sedan.

text: Video shows Denmark’s top health official fainting from her COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Vaccine not related to Danish health official’s collapse on camera
claimReview.textualRating: False. One of Denmark's top health officials, Tanja Erichsen, collapsed during an April 14 press conference to discuss the country’s decision to discontinue use of the AstraZeneca vaccine, but it was not related to the vaccine. She has not yet been vaccinated against the disease.

text: Screenshots of the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System show people who have died after receiving the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Data from vaccine reporting site being misrepresented online
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The VAERS system is an unverified reporting system that does not determine if a vaccine caused the events that are reported.

text: Merriam-Webster changed the definition of anti-vaxxer to now include those who oppose “regulations mandating vaccination.”

claimReview.title: Merriam-Webster’s update to “anti-vaxxer” misrepresented online
claimReview.textualRating: Missing Context. Merriam-Webster’s anti-vaxxer listing already included language similar to the clause being cited online, but the wording was changed to “regulations” rather than “laws.”

text: Basketball legend Michael Jordan ended his partnership with Nike because the company collaborated with Dylan Mulvaney, a transgender social media influencer.

claimReview.title: Michael Jordan hasn’t ended his partnership with Nike
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim originated on a satire website. There are no credible news reports indicating that Jordan is ending his partnership with Nike.

text: A video shows a tanker truck outside the governor’s mansion in Jackson, Mississippi, supplying the residence with water amid the city’s water crisis.

claimReview.title: Tanker not delivering water to Mississippi governor’s mansion in Jackson
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tanker, which is parked across the street from the governor’s mansion, is there as a standby solution for the headquarters of a bank at that location. A spokesperson for Gov. Tate Reeves confirmed to the AP that the tanker “is not supporting the Governor’s Mansion or any other state assets.”

text: A video shows a seal roaming the streets of Florida after Hurricane Ian.

claimReview.title: 2020 video of stranded seal filmed in Chile, not Florida
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was captured in October 2020, not this week during Hurricane Ian, and shows an elephant seal stranded in a seaside neighborhood in Puerto Cisnes, Chile.

text: A photo shows a UFO emerging from the ocean next to a naval ship and a large explosion.

claimReview.title: A photo of a US Navy test was edited to add a UFO rising out of the ocean
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The UFO was edited into a real image from 1982 of a U.S. Navy shock test. The altered version of the image — and others showing the supposed spacecraft close-up in the water — have been online since 2008 when they appeared in a short, fictional film called “The Orion Conspiracy.”

text: Over 500,000 vote-by-mail ballots in Virginia and 200,000 in Nevada were found under the names of dead people and pets.

claimReview.title: False claims circulate about mail-in-ballots in Virginia and Nevada
claimReview.textualRating: False. Election officials have not yet mailed absentee ballots in either state. There is no evidence that ballots have ever been sent to deceased voters in those states at that scale, or that pets have received ballots.

text: Actor Robert Downey Jr. has made a “shocking revelation and lifted the lid on a major Hollywood pedophile ring.”

claimReview.title: Robert Downey Jr. did not ‘blow the whistle’ on a Hollywood pedophile ring
claimReview.textualRating: False. The words attributed to the actor have circulated on social media for years and can be traced back to anonymous comments on a gossip blog. Downey has never said anything matching these statements, his attorney confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: The Mayo Clinic “quietly” updated its website in 2023 to say that hydroxychloroquine can now be used to treat COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on Mayo Clinic’s hydroxychloroquine webpage
claimReview.textualRating: False. A page about hydroxychloroquine on the hospital system’s website included outdated guidance that the malaria drug “may also be used to treat coronavirus (COVID-19) in certain hospitalized patients.” But archives show the text has been there since at least May 2020, a month before the U.S. Food and Drug Administration revoked its emergency approval for using the drug to treat COVID. After the Mayo Clinic page circulated widely in recent days, the organization took the page down and clarified that it does not endorse the use of hydroxychloroquine for treating COVID-19 patients.

text: “My father doesn’t need to rape women. It's more likely a woman would rape him. That's how popular he is.” -- Donald Trump Jr. on Sean Hannity’s radio show on Oct. 14.

claimReview.title: Fabricated quote falsely attributed to Donald Trump Jr.
claimReview.textualRating: False. Trump Jr. was not on Hannity’s show that day and there is no evidence he made that remark.

text: Photos show Americans filling their cars with plastic bags of gasoline and lining up at gas stations with red gas cans in recent days.

claimReview.title: Old photos fuel misinformation around gas shortages
claimReview.textualRating: False. While there are reports of panic-buying at some gas stations in the U.S. in the wake of the shutdown of the Colonial Pipeline, these photos were taken years ago and have nothing to do with current events.

text: Newly released video shows election officials in Arizona’s Maricopa County illegally conducting “secret" voting equipment tests ahead of last November’s contested midterms.

claimReview.title: Nothing ‘secret’ about Arizona voting machine testing shown on video, officials say
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video comes from the county’s live broadcast of the election process last fall and isn’t new footage. Election officials say it shows the installation and testing of new memory cards on ballot counting machines just days prior to the November election.

text: Mayor Eric Adams is banning meat in New York City.

claimReview.title: Hot dogs here to stay: No truth to claims of NYC meat ban
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the mayor has pledged to reduce food-related emissions in city facilities, meat is not being banned, according to his office.

text: President Joe Biden withheld 1,850 boxes of classified documents from his time as vice president.

claimReview.title: Claims misrepresent 1,850 boxes of Biden documents at Delaware university
claimReview.textualRating: False. The National Archives and Records Administration says the boxes of files referenced in that figure are actually Biden’s Senate papers, which are housed at the University of Delaware. The federal agency told The Associated Press the files of Congress members are considered their personal property and are not subject to the same restrictions as presidential records, which are considered government property. While the FBI has searched the Delaware university records as part of a larger search for classified documents, there is no evidence they were withheld from authorities in any way.

text: A video of wall-to-wall crowds in Madrid’s Puerta del Sol plaza shows a protest supporting Palestinians in the

claimReview.title: Video of an unrelated protest in Madrid is being misrepresented as a pro-Palestinian demonstration
claimReview.textualRating: False. The protest seen in the video has nothing to do with the Middle Eastern conflict. The footage was featured by a Spanish news outlet in coverage of a demonstration on Sunday opposing a deal that would grant amnesty to Catalan separatists in exchange for their support of a new coalition government in Spain.

text: A video shows only six people showed up to a recent rally with Democratic vice presidential candidate Kamala Harris in Orlando, Florida.

claimReview.title: Dozens following social distancing rules attend Harris drive-in-rally in Orlando
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video does not provide a full view of the audience. Harris and Democratic presidential candidate Joseph Biden are purposefully limiting attendance at their events due to the pandemic.

text: Proposed federal gun legislation expanding background checks for firearms would create a “national registration of firearms” and put gun owners in jail for transferring or handing their gun to someone, even if they are in a dangerous situation.

claimReview.title: Social media posts misrepresent bill expanding background checks for firearms
claimReview.textualRating: False. HR 8 prohibits using the bill to establish a national firearms registry and includes exceptions allowing temporary transfers between family members, or transfers between people for self-defense or for use at a shooting range.

text: President Joe Biden owns an island next to one previously owned by the late disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein in the U.S. Virgin Islands.

claimReview.title: President Biden does not own Caribbean island near Epstein’s
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden does not own property in the U.S. Virgin Islands, according to online property records and a White House spokesperson. James Biden, the president’s brother, bought land in the territory with his wife in 2005, according to the records.

text: Photo shows Nancy Pelosi at an indoor party, defying COVID-19 restrictions.

claimReview.title: Photo of Pelosi at indoor gathering was taken last January
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi at a gathering was taken last January in Washington, weeks before the U.S. introduced strict COVID-19 restrictions.

text: Only voting sites in conservative areas in Arizona’s Maricopa County experienced issues with tabulating ballots on Election Day.

claimReview.title: Arizona voting issues not confined to conservative areas
claimReview.textualRating: False. Voting centers across Maricopa County reported printing issues that stopped some ballots from being counted onsite, including in Democrat-leaning areas, like downtown Phoenix and Tempe, according to the Maricopa County Elections Department.

text: Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden “slipped up” and said he’s going to “tax your 401(k).”

claimReview.title: Biden tax plan will not ‘tax your 401(k)’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden has not proposed taxing retirement accounts known as 401(k)s. He has proposed equalizing the tax benefits for using such accounts. Tax experts say the proposed change would allow lower and middle income earners to benefit more than they had in the past from saving money in 401(k)s.

text: A left-wing antifa militant shot and killed a conservative attendee of a “Patriot Rally” in Denver on Saturday.

claimReview.title: Denver shooting suspect was private security guard, not ‘antifa militant’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The man in custody for a shooting during dueling protests in Denver on Saturday is a private security guard for a local news station covering the protests, according to reporting by The Associated Press. He has no affiliation with antifa, Denver police confirmed.

text: Photos that appear in a campaign ad for President Donald Trump show that former Vice President Joe Biden is “alone” and “hiding” in “his basement.”

claimReview.title: Trump campaign ad used altered photos to make Biden appear to be ‘alone’ when he wasn’t
claimReview.textualRating: At least two of the photos were taken long before the coronavirus outbreak, at events where Biden was with many other people, and were altered to remove people and objects and make him appear to be “alone” and “hiding.”

text: An image shows a bottle of rainbow-colored mayonnaise called “Gayo” that was released by Kraft to celebrate Pride Month.

claimReview.title: Posts spread image of satirical ‘Gayo’ condiment as real
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image was fabricated. It was first posted in 2022 by a social media user who goes by the name “Doctor Photograph” and frequently shares satirical images of fake products based on the real thing. Kraft Heinz, the company that owns the Kraft brand, confirmed to The Associated Press that “Gayo” is not real.

text: Video shows an enormous frog sitting on a table as its owner feeds it a banana.

claimReview.title: Frog video was created using visual effects
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. The frog in this video was enlarged using visual effects, the original poster said on his TikTok account. A visual effects expert confirmed that it’s altered.

text: A photo of two cans of AriZona green tea suggests the product’s price has been raised from 99 cents to $1.29.

claimReview.title: AriZona tea cans still priced at 99 cents, at least in the US
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The price printed on cans in the U.S. is still 99 cents, a spokesperson from AriZona Beverages confirmed. The photo circulating on social media shows a pair of Canadian cans of the tea beverage with prices in Canadian dollars. The can labeled 99 cents is several years old, and the company subsequently adjusted its recommended price in the country to CA $1.29 to reflect the current U.S. exchange rate.

text: A pre-print study found that the COVID-19 vaccines cause long-term brain damage.

claimReview.title: German study looked into COVID’s impact on the brain, not vaccine effects
claimReview.textualRating: False. The study being referenced, conducted by German researchers and not yet peer-reviewed, looked into the presence of the virus’ spike protein in the brain following infection. The paper did not explore vaccine side effects, a co-author confirmed.

text: U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a Democrat from New York, falsely claimed she faced rioters in the main Capitol building during the Jan. 6 insurrection.

claimReview.title: Ocasio-Cortez didn’t lie about location during Capitol riot
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ocasio-Cortez never claimed she was in the main Capitol building, nor did she claim she was face-to-face with a mob of violent rioters. In an Instagram Live video about the riots, she explained that she was in her office in a neighboring building on the Capitol complex, where she experienced a frightening encounter with a Capitol police officer who she said didn’t announce himself.

text: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. won a U.S. Supreme Court case against “all the pharmaceutical lobbyists” in which the court ruled that mRNA COVID-19 vaccines cause “irreparable” damage.

claimReview.title: Posts recycle baseless claim about mRNA vaccine SCOTUS case
claimReview.textualRating: False. There has been no such Supreme Court ruling, according to the court’s comprehensive online archive of opinions. Kennedy, a lawyer who has advocated against vaccines, told The Associated Press in 2021 that articles sharing similar claims were false. At the time, he said he had been involved in dozens of lawsuits regarding vaccine safety, but none had reached the Supreme Court.

text: Sen. Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, a Democrat from New York, said Judge Amy Coney Barrett is “wildly out of the mainstream” and shouldn’t serve on the Supreme Court because she is Catholic and a Christian. Therefore, Democrats officially oppose Catholics and Christians.

claimReview.title: Democrats don’t ‘officially oppose’ Catholics and Christians
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Schumer has used the words “wildly out of the mainstream” to describe the views of a judicial nominee before, but there is no evidence he has said that about Barrett. Democrats don’t “officially oppose” Catholics and Christians. Many Democratic politicians identify as Christian, including presidential candidate Joe Biden, a practicing Catholic.

text: Bath & Body Works’ safety data sheet warns its products aren’t recommended for pregnant women.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Bath & Body Works safety document
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Social media users are misrepresenting a document intended for companies and workers involved in handling the chemicals used to manufacture one product – specifically, an air freshener refill – made by Bath & Body Works. The warning is not for consumers.

text: President Barack Obama waited until October 2009 to declare a national health emergency amid the H1N1 pandemic after 20,000 people in the U.S. were hospitalized and more than 1,000 had died.

claimReview.title: Few sickened when Obama declared 2009 flu a health emergency
claimReview.textualRating: False. Obama declared a public health emergency in April 2009, after roughly 20 cases of the flu strain, more commonly known as swine flu, emerged. He declared a national emergency in October 2009.

text: Sweden has stopped using PCR tests to detect viruses.

claimReview.title: Sweden is still using PCR tests for COVID-19 detection
claimReview.textualRating: False. Sweden’s Public Health Agency confirmed to The Associated Press that the country is still using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests for COVID-19 and other viruses.

text: Ukraine’s president has surrendered and his country has fallen to

claimReview.title: No, Ukraine’s president didn’t surrender to Russia over the weekend, despite social media claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy did not surrender as social media posts claimed on Saturday, and the country remains at war with Russia. In a Sunday interview, Zelenskyy rejected the idea of peace negotiations and dismissed the notion that the two sides were locked in a stalemate.

text: The National School Boards Association is asking the Biden administration to label parents who protest school policies domestic terrorists.

claimReview.title: Posts mischaracterize school board organization’s letter to Biden
claimReview.textualRating: False. The organization — the NSBA, for short — is not asking Biden to label parents who protest at school board meetings as terrorists. The NSBA asked the administration to do an interagency investigation of threats of violence against school board members and said the threats “could be the equivalent to a form of domestic terrorism and hate crimes.” Biden has yet to publicly comment on the issue, and there’s no indication he or the Department of Justice has called protesting parents “domestic terrorists,” despite false claims to that effect by social media users.

text: BBC News published an article stating breathing too often can cause a heart attack.

claimReview.title: Image of BBC headline linking shallow breathing to heart attacks is bogus
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image being shared on social media that appears to show a BBC story was fabricated. The news organization did not publish such an article.

text: CNN reported that the cereal maker Kellogg’s announced that one of the mascots for its Rice Krispies cereal is transgender.

claimReview.title: CNN did not publish story on gender of Rice Krispies mascot
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media posts used a fabricated image to spread this false claim. The Kellogg Co. said it has not made any such announcement and a CNN spokesperson confirmed the image was fake.

text: The U.S. Supreme Court will hear a case to remove President Joe Biden from office and reinstate former President Donald Trump in his place.

claimReview.title: Supreme Court will not hear case to oust Biden, reinstate Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Supreme Court has not decided to hear such a case. On Feb. 21, the justices rejected for a second time to hear a case that cites baseless 2020 election fraud claims to call for the court to oust from office hundreds of elected officials, including Biden, as well as to prevent them from holding any elected government position again. Several days later, a website published an article incorrectly stating that the case was going ahead, but the post has since been taken down.

text: Photo shows Dr. Rachel Levine, President Joe Biden’s nominee for assistant health secretary, with her family.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Biden’s health nominee with family
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. Levine’s face was edited into this picture, which actually shows a British family that has been featured on various reality TV shows.

text: A new lawsuit against voting machine manufacturer Dominion Voting Systems has uncovered thousands of “duplicate ballots” in Fulton County, Georgia, from the 2020 presidential election.

claimReview.title: No, there isn't a new lawsuit revealing 2020 ballot fraud in Georgia. An old video is recirculating
claimReview.textualRating:
False. There is no new lawsuit revealing new information about the three-year old election results. A video being shared online to support the claim is actually from 2021 and is about a lawsuit challenging the 2020 vote count in the Georgia county. Additionally, the lawsuit isn’t against Dominion Voting Systems but local officials. And while the legal challenge remains pending in court, state and local election officials maintain there was no evidence of widespread fraud found in the many reviews conducted after the election.
List (Page)

text: The planet has an unlimited supply of oil.

claimReview.title: Video spreads false notion of unlimited oil supply
claimReview.textualRating: False. Crude oil supplies are not unlimited, experts say. Crude oil is not a renewable resource and humans won’t be able to extract all remaining untapped resources due to economic and technological limitations.

text: A Pakistani migrant delivering food is said to be patient zero of the new coronavirus in Italy.

claimReview.title: No evidence that food delivery man was coronavirus patient zero in Italy
claimReview.textualRating: False. Patient zero has yet to be identified in Italy.

text: A video shows the crowd at this year’s

claimReview.title: Video footage from the 2023 Army-Navy game was altered to add anti-Biden chant
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video has been edited to add the chant, which occurred at a concert in 2021. Unedited footage of the game shows the crowd, including a large contingent of Army cadets, singing and bouncing to an EDM song often played at Army football games and other sporting events.

text: Presentation slide shows the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s list of possible adverse outcomes of the COVID-19 vaccine include stroke and death.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent FDA committee presentation on vaccine side effects
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. No serious adverse effects have been reported by Pfizer in clinical trials, nor has the FDA found such evidence in its review of the data. The FDA said the slide being shared online lists possible severe reactions to the vaccine that the agency is watching for as a safety precaution despite no severe reactions being reported so far.

text: A photo shows Melania Trump with a shovel at Ivana Trump’s gravesite.

claimReview.title: Photo manipulated to show Melania Trump at gravesite
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image has been manipulated to combine three separate photos. One was released in 2019 by the White House, another was published by the New York Post on Thursday and the third was an altered image originally captured by The Associated Press. An Instagram account that first posted the composite image said it was a “satirical meme.”

text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Director Rochelle Walensky said in a “Good Morning America” interview that “over 75% of ‘Covid deaths’ occurred in people with at least four comorbidities.”

claimReview.title: CDC director’s comment on COVID-19 and comorbidities misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Walensky was discussing a CDC study that specifically looked at people who are vaccinated against COVID-19, a detail that was removed in some versions circulating online. She was citing the study’s finding that 78% of people who were vaccinated against COVID-19 but died from the disease had four other risk factors.

text: Vice President Mike Pence delivered empty boxes of personal protective equipment to a nursing home for a publicity stunt.

claimReview.title: Pence did not deliver empty boxes of personal protective equipment
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim went viral on social media after the show “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” aired a selectively edited clip of Pence joking about carrying empty boxes “for the camera.” The full clip obtained by The Associated Press confirms that Pence did not actually deliver the empty boxes.

text: Wearing a face mask for extended periods of time can cause pleurisy, an inflammation of the lining around the lung.

claimReview.title: Face masks will not cause pleurisy, experts say
claimReview.textualRating: False. Multiple experts told The Associated Press there is no medical evidence that wearing a face mask could lead to pleurisy.

text: Video shows a child climbing out of a window to escape Buckingham Palace.

claimReview.title: TV show promo misrepresented as Buckingham Palace conspiracy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 2015 video was used to promote the scripted E! TV series “The Royals.” The video has been misrepresented as real footage multiple times in the last few years.

text: A video of ransacked Chicago Walmart — featuring cash registers destroyed and merchandise on the floor as sirens blare — was taken in 2023.

claimReview.title: Old video of looted Chicago Walmart spreads anew
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video does show a Walmart store in Chicago, however the clip dates back to at least June, 2020. The store in the clip, in Chicago’s Kenwood neighborhood, was shuttered last Sunday.

text: President Joe Biden’s feet are not visible in an image posted by the White House, suggesting the image is not real or is photoshopped.

claimReview.title: Tall grass shrouds Biden’s feet in White House image
claimReview.textualRating: False. Associated Press images of Biden traversing the same lawn confirm that his feet were simply hidden from view behind lush, ankle-deep grass.

text: The Biden administration is giving people who enter the U.S illegally payments of $2,200 per month.

claimReview.title: No, migrants do not receive $2,200 each month from the federal government
claimReview.textualRating: False. People who enter the U.S. illegally are not eligible for federal cash assistance, with the exception of certain Cubans and Haitians, immigration experts told The Associated Press. Refugees and people granted asylum, as well as some other humanitarian migrants, are entitled to certain public benefits, including cash assistance related to their initial resettlement, though it is not as high as $2,200 each month.

text: Photos showing gasoline listed at more than $5 per gallon in Los Angeles show how much gas prices have risen under President Joe Biden.

claimReview.title: Gas prices in viral photos don’t reflect Los Angeles average
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The gas station in these photos has long charged well in excess of average or nearby prices, according to Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy, a website that tracks gasoline prices across the country. The average gas price in Los Angeles was $3.89 per gallon on Monday, and California’s average was $3.85 per gallon, De Haan said. The nationwide gas price average was lower, at $2.87 per gallon, up about 34 cents from last month’s average, according to a GasBuddy analysis.

text: CBS is suppressing a 2015 episode of The Late Show with Stephen Colbert that featured Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: CBS not hiding Trump’s televised interview on comedian’s show
claimReview.textualRating: False. Segments of the September 2015 episode featuring Donald Trump, after he announced his candidacy for president, remain available on the CBS website and The Late Show with Stephen Colbert’s official YouTube page.

text: Scientists have not isolated the COVID-19 virus, so a vaccine is not possible.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim COVID-19 virus has not yet been isolated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The virus was first isolated by Chinese authorities on Jan. 7, according to the World Health Organization.

text: The NFL is investigating AFC championship referee Ronald Torbert because his son made a large wager on the Kansas City Chiefs before they defeated the Cincinnati Bengals on Sunday.

claimReview.title: False claims of NFL referee investigation started as satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. This claim originated on a parody Twitter account, and elements of the post make it clear that it is fiction. An NFL spokesman confirmed as much.

text: Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg closed down New York City, called up 38,000 New York police officers and is spending an estimated $200 million in city funds as part of the

claimReview.title: Trump posts mislead on cost of arraignment in NYC
claimReview.textualRating: False. The New York Police Department currently has less than 34,000 officers, and not all of them were on duty for the arraignment Tuesday. Only a few streets near the Manhattan courthouse were closed. Additionally, while the exact cost of the proceedings are not publicly known, the $200 million figure is “made up,” a spokesperson for the New York City mayor’s office said.

text: A video showing large armored vehicles moving through downtown Philadelphia suggests looming military activity within the U.S.

claimReview.title: Military vehicles in downtown Philadelphia were part of a Flag Day celebration
claimReview.textualRating: False. The military vehicles were there for the city’s Stripes and Stars Festival, a Flag Day celebration, a public affairs officer for the Pennsylvania National Guard told The Associated Press.

text: Starbucks has begun selling a watermelon mug to signal its support for Palestinians amid the Israel-Hamas war and appease those boycotting the chain.

claimReview.title: Starbucks’ watermelon mug was part of its UK summer collection, not a show of support for Palestinians
claimReview.textualRating: False. The mug was part of Starbucks’ U.K. summer collection, which launched in May 2023, months before the conflict broke out, a company spokesperson told The Associated Press. Starbucks, as well as many customers, featured the mug in social media posts around that time.

text: Video shows Brexit Party leader Nigel Farage making disparaging remarks about the British people, including that they are racist and should be ashamed.

claimReview.title: Video edited to misrepresent Brexit Party leader’s comments
claimReview.textualRating: False. Comments Farage made in a YouTube video were edited to misrepresent what he said. In the full video, Farage was actually criticizing the media for their coverage. Farage’s radio show with LBC ended earlier this month.

text: Breastfeeding moms, wait until you're done nursing if you're going to get the vaccine. There is no research showing how it affects your infant.

claimReview.title: Early studies find no issue with vaccinated moms breastfeeding
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While COVID-19 vaccines have not been studied on pregnant and lactating women during clinical trials, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says that as a “non-replicating vaccine,” which does not reproduce in host cells, COVID-19 vaccines will not pose a risk to lactating mothers or their infants.

text: A video clip shows multiple Russian helicopters attacking a complex of buildings at dusk while taking fire from the ground.

claimReview.title: Video shows gameplay, not Russian helicopters
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip shows computer-generated imagery from the video game Arma 3, not actual military combat.

text: A recent video shows sacred Christian materials being transferred from a Kyiv cathedral to a secure bunker.

claimReview.title: Video of Ukrainian funeral procession misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video dates back to at least 2015 and shows a Ukrainian funeral procession, not the transfer of a Christian sacrament to a bunker for safekeeping.

text: Coca-Cola closely watching growth of cannabis-infused drinks

claimReview.title: Coca-Cola closely watching growth of cannabis-infused drinks
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. The Coca-Cola Company is watching the growth of drinks infused with cannabidiol, also known as CBD, which is a non-psychoactive element in the drug.

text: Video shows migrants beating children at the border of Greece and Turkey and forcing them to inhale smoke.

claimReview.title: Video shows migrant children choking on tear gas
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows migrant children choking from tear gas in the Turkish city of Edirne, on the border with Greece.

text: A CNN headline states, “Biden pledges $350 billion toward computer education courses for women in Africa.”

claimReview.title: CNN headline about billions for computer courses in Africa is fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image is altered. CNN did not publish the headline, a spokesperson confirmed. Last week, Biden announced the Digital Transformation with Africa initiative, a plan to invest more than $350 million in financing that would expand digital access across Africa.

text: First lady Jill Biden gave a speech with the Nazi flag in the background.

claimReview.title: Farmworker union's flag was backdrop for Jill Biden speech
claimReview.textualRating: False. The first lady gave a speech in front of the United Farm Workers’ flag, which features a black eagle surrounded by a white circle on a red background.

text: A major mosque in Iran raised a black flag to call Muslims to war over Israel’s attacks on Gaza.

claimReview.title: A black flag over Iran’s Imam Reza shrine isn’t a war cry. It represents mourning for Gaza victims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Imam Reza shrine said the flag was raised as a symbol of mourning for the lives lost in Israel’s strikes on Gaza. Experts on Islam and Iran confirmed the flag includes a passage from the Quran that is meant to comfort Muslims that their sacrifices will one day be rewarded.

text: The Internal Revenue Service audits the poor at five times the rate of the rich. Some 87,000 new IRS agents are going to focus on $600 Venmo transactions, not billionaires.

claimReview.title: Posts distort IRS hires, tax policy, as GOP takes House
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. A Syracuse University analysis did find that the IRS audits certain low-income wage earners more than five times more than other groups, in part because budget cuts have caused the agency to rely more on automated “correspondence audits.” But the agency’s new infusion of funding will not fund 87,000 employees at once, nor will it fund only auditors. A new tax policy requires mobile payment apps and users to report information about commercial transactions above $600 to the IRS, but it won’t add an additional tax or apply to personal transactions.

text: Michelle Obama’s mother stated in her will that possessions should go to her son, Michael Robinson Obama, proof the former first lady is biologically male.

claimReview.title: False story about former first lady’s mother originated as satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim, part of a conspiracy theory that includes several falsehoods, originated as satire.

text: A live map of vessels off the eastern coast of China shows cargo ship delays and backups caused by the country’s COVID-19 restrictions.

claimReview.title: Shipping map misrepresented amid China COVID-19 restrictions
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While the wait times and the number of ships have increased at Chinese ports in recent months, the map itself doesn’t show anything out of the ordinary, according to experts and MarineTracker, the website where the map comes from. The markers on the map represent all kinds of vessels, not just commercial cargo ships. And experts say the map would have looked similar in March 2020, the early days of the pandemic.

text: A Dominion Voting Systems employee named Eric Coomer said on an “antifa conference call” prior to the 2020 election, “Don’t worry about the election, Trump’s not gonna win. I made f-----g sure of that!”

claimReview.title: Post revives baseless claim that Dominion employee admitted to interfering in the 2020 election
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence of Coomer saying this, and he has denied it in a sworn declaration. Joseph Oltmann, a conservative podcaster, first made the claim six days after the 2020 election on his show, but also said at the time he couldn’t be certain it was Coomer who made the statement. He has not presented credible evidence to corroborate the claim. Coomer has since filed five defamation lawsuits related to these allegations.

text: A proposal on the ballot in Michigan at the 2022 midterm election would give inmates the right to vote from prison.

claimReview.title: Michigan referendum won’t give inmates voting rights
claimReview.textualRating: False. Proposal 2 would make significant changes to the state’s voting laws, but it doesn’t propose making any changes to the voting rights of felons, experts told The Associated Press. Under Michigan law, inmates will still be banned from casting ballots and those who have completed their sentences and have been released will be eligible to vote. Some opponents argue the measure, if approved, could lead to future legal challenges over inmate voting rights, though a majority opinion from the state’s supreme court said lawmakers would still be able to determine whether inmates can vote.

text: A 2005 study that found that “Chloroquine is a potent inhibitor of SARS coronavirus infection and spread” proves that hydroxychloroquine is effective against COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Chloroquine/SARS study doesn’t prove hydroxychloroquine works against COVID-19
claimReview.textualRating: False. The study does not prove that the malaria drug hydroxychloroquine is effective against COVID-19. Several studies have found that hydroxychloroquine has no benefit against the coronavirus.

text: Video shows a second explosion outside Afghanistan’s Kabul airport on Thursday near Baron Hotel.

claimReview.title: Video shows airstrike in Gaza, not explosion in Kabul
claimReview.textualRating: False. This video shows an airstrike in Gaza and has circulated online for five days.

text: Harvard College sent an email that revoked an admitted student’s acceptance due to the student’s social media posts.

claimReview.title: Harvard email saying student is ‘terminated’ is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The email isn’t authentic, a spokesperson for Harvard University confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: A new law passed by Congress “allows you to permanently remove any negative debt” from your credit report that is over two years old.

claimReview.title: Congress didn’t pass law allowing consumers to erase negative credit information after two years
claimReview.textualRating: False. The law referenced in the video to support that claim, the Fair Credit Reporting Act, has been around since 1970. The law requires that most negative information be removed from your credit report after seven years. Experts say there have been no legislative changes that allow consumers to simply remove negative, but accurate, information after just two.

text: U.K. supermarket chain Sainsbury’s has installed QR code scanners to check for COVID-19 vaccine passports.

claimReview.title: Sainsbury’s has not installed QR readers to check for vaccine passports
claimReview.textualRating: False. Sainsbury’s is currently testing a new store feature where customers can scan a QR code with their phone at entry so they can shop via the company’s app as they go and avoid checkout lines. It’s not related to vaccine passports, the company confirmed.

text: Bandages around former President Barack Obama’s hand on Friday are suspicious and suggest he was involved in the

claimReview.title: Obama’s bandaged fingers don’t suggest a role in his chef’s death. It’s golf tape for blisters
claimReview.textualRating: False. An Obama spokesperson said the Democrat was wearing golfer’s tape on his left hand, as photos have shown him doing many times over the years. Golfing experts confirmed the former president is wearing the tape properly and that golfers routinely use it to avoid blisters and split calluses.

text: The Mexican government is giving away free ivermectin in a COVID-19 medical kit.

claimReview.title: Ivermectin is no longer in COVID-19 treatment kits in Mexico
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While the government was until this month providing ivermectin in COVID-19 medical kits, officials confirmed to The Associated Press that the anti-parasitic drug is no longer included in the packet.

text: The juvenile detention center in Lee County, Florida, was not evacuated for Hurricane Ian and several children were found dead in the facility.

claimReview.title: No hurricane deaths at Fort Myers juvenile detention center, despite claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Southwest Florida Regional Juvenile Detention Center was evacuated before the hurricane and the storm didn’t kill anyone there, said Amanda Slama, communications director for the Florida Department of Juvenile Justice, which operates the facility. The facility documented the evacuation in an incident report, and local police confirmed to The Associated Press that no deaths in the center were reported.

text: Video shows Texas Sen. Ted Cruz swallowing a fly during a Fox News interview.

claimReview.title: Video of Ted Cruz supposedly swallowing fly was edited
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was manipulated. On June 27, 2019, Cruz, a Republican, appeared on the Fox News show “Hannity,” but there was no critter in the clip.

text: A Mexican news outlet reported that a member of a local organized crime group was pictured with a U.S.-made Javelin anti-tank guided missile that had been trafficked from Ukraine to cartels.

claimReview.title: Mistranslated news report sparks baseless claim about Mexican cartel getting weapon from Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video shows a news anchor claiming in Spanish that a cartel member had been filmed with a Javelin, but she only noted that such weapons have also been used in Ukraine, not that it originated there. Additionally, the anchor misidentified the weapon, which is an AT4, another anti-tank weapon. While AT4s are being used in Ukraine, experts say there’s nothing to indicate that the one in the video came from there, and that it’s far more likely to have come from other black market channels.

text: The Bank of England is removing paper money from circulation and moving over to the cryptocurrency financial system XRP.

claimReview.title: Bank of England switching paper currency to polymer, not cryptocurrency
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The Bank of England is phasing out paper bank notes for longer-lasting polymer ones, The Associated Press has reported. It is not switching to XRP.

text: Senator calls on men to ‘shut up and step up’

claimReview.title: Sen. Hirono tells men to 'shut up and step up' on Kavanaugh sexual assault accusation
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. Sen. Mazie Hirono told men to “just shut up and step up, do the right thing for a change.”

text: A bill introduced in Texas by Democratic state Rep. Terry Meza would repeal the state’s “castle doctrine” law, which allows a homeowner to use deadly force against an armed intruder. The bill, HB 196, would require the homeowner to “flee the home” at the first sign of intrusion, and if fleeing is not possible, “cooperate with the intruder.”

claimReview.title: Posts distort Texas bill on deadly force
claimReview.textualRating: False. Meza’s bill would not repeal the state’s “castle doctrine” law, and it wouldn’t alter actions Texans may currently take during a home invasion. Instead, it would amend the state penal code to require Texas residents to retreat if possible if someone outside the home threatens them or their property. Meza’s bill doesn’t instruct homeowners to “cooperate” with an intruder, nor does it prevent them from using deadly force in self-defense if they are unable to retreat.

text: A photo showing Jacksonville Beach in Florida crowded with people is a year old. It does not show what happened last week as some beaches reopened Friday.

claimReview.title: Photos accurately show reopening of Jacksonville Beach
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo of the beach was taken the evening of Friday, April 17, as Florida’s governor allowed some beaches and parks to reopen after being closed due to COVID-19. The photo was taken shortly after restrictions were lifted.

text: The campaign for President-elect Joe Biden paid Joseph “Skinny Joey” Merlino, who once controlled a Philadelphia organized crime family, to fill out 300,000 blank ballots.

claimReview.title: Fabricated tale claims ballot fraud by Philadelphia mob boss
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence this scheme happened. Merlino’s attorney denied the story and pointed out his client is not allowed to leave Florida where he is currently under supervised release. Election experts say not only would the alleged plot be impossible to pull off without it being detected, the claim is inconsistent with actual election data.

text: The majority of AIDS patients died from medication developed when Dr. Anthony Fauci led the nation’s response to the emerging epidemic, not from the virus itself.

claimReview.title: AIDS medication didn’t kill more people than the virus itself
claimReview.textualRating: False. While it’s true that Fauci had been a leading researcher when AIDS emerged in the 1980s, the claims that azidothymidine, commonly known as AZT, killed more people than the virus itself are baseless. Public health agencies from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to the World Health Organization, as well as prominent AIDS organizations and researchers, told The Associated Press the drug remains in use today as it’s been shown to be effective at keeping HIV in check when used in combination with other medications.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention removed information from its toxicological profile for vinyl chloride about how dangerous the gas is in regards to children, drinking water and cancer.

claimReview.title: Vinyl chloride draft report didn’t omit info on cancer, children
claimReview.textualRating: False. While a new toxicological profile released as a draft this month has been reformatted from the prior version, it does not omit such information nor downplay the dangers of vinyl chloride, a review of the documents by The Associated Press and independent experts shows.

text: Transportation Security Administration managers were told on Aug. 15 that by mid-September they, along with airport employees, will again be required to wear face masks and by mid-October the policy will apply to travelers as well. Further, the managers were told that COVID-19 lockdowns will return by December.

claimReview.title: Conspiracy theorist spreads false information about the return of COVID-19 mandates
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such announcement was made to TSA managers, an agency spokesperson told The Associated Press. A spokesperson for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which issued a now-expired travel mask mandate in 2021, confirmed that such rumors are “utterly false.”

text: Video footage shows that certain aspects of the wreath-laying ceremony for President Joe Biden at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier on Jan. 20 were different from past presidents’ ceremonies, proving Biden’s inauguration was fake.

claimReview.title: Wreath-laying ceremony video doesn’t show Biden faked inauguration
claimReview.textualRating: False. Differences between Biden’s ceremony and other wreath-laying ceremonies in the past can be attributed to cold weather and coronavirus precautions, according to a spokesperson for the U.S. Army Military District of Washington. Biden’s Jan. 20 inauguration was official and he is the 46th president of the United States.

text: A photo circulating on social media shows a banner advertising on-site COVID-19 vaccinations with text that states, “DON’T FORGET TO DONATE YOUR CHILDRENS ORGANS.”

claimReview.title: Altered photo falsely claims vaccine site urged parents to donate kids’ organs
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The photo was manipulated to include the line about donating children’s organs, according to a representative with the Boston-based healthcare nonprofit Mass General Brigham, which supported the event. The original photo of the banner can also be found online in an archived version of the New England Patriots’ website.

text: The COVID-19 vaccine rollout for children between the ages of 12 and 15 in England is being suspended due to an error with the paperwork.

claimReview.title: No interruption in England’s vaccine rollout for children ages 12 to 15
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.K.’s public health agency, Public Health England, confirmed that vaccinations were not suspended nor will they be delayed for children between the ages of 12 to 15. They also said the legal framework was in order.

text: Photo shows Martin Luther King Jr. alive in a hospital bed after he was shot in 1968. He died in the hospital after he was suffocated with a pillow.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Martin Luther King Jr. after a 1958 stabbing
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows King after he was stabbed in 1958. He survived the attack.

text: The fact that some Georgia counties cannot produce the original electronic ballot images from the 2020 election indicates that election fraud took place. Now the state has no way to verify that the ballots are legitimate reflections of what went through the machines.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent impact of missing ballot images in Georgia
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. It’s true some Georgia counties violated state law by failing to preserve electronic images from the original count of ballots from the 2020 election, but this does not prove fraud or affect the election outcome. Georgia counties still have all the paper ballots cast in the election, according to the Secretary of State’s office. The results of the presidential race in Georgia were counted three times, and all three tallies showed Democrat Joe Biden prevailing over Republican incumbent Donald Trump.

text: A video of a Republican voter being turned away from a Texas polling place due to staffing issues shows fraud happening during the 2022 midterm election.

claimReview.title: Video of Texas poll staffing shortage is from March primary
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The video was filmed during the state’s primary election in March, not the November general election. While it does show staffing issues that temporarily impacted at least one voter at one location in Harris County, Texas, it is not an example of fraud. A Harris County election official told The Associated Press in March that both the Democratic and Republican parties notified the county that they had staffing shortages. In Harris County’s split primary, each party was responsible for staffing their respective election.

text: California is mailing out ballots for the recall election because of the delta variant.

claimReview.title: California expanded voting by mail before the delta variant surge
claimReview.textualRating: False. The California Legislature passed a bill in February 2021, months before the delta variant surge, requiring that mail-in ballots be sent to all registered voters ahead of an election.

text: A candidate winning an election with a majority of mailed ballots is proof of fraud.

claimReview.title: Large numbers of mailed ballots not evidence of election fraud
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence that mail-in voting has historically caused widespread voter fraud, and fraud related to mail-in voting is exceedingly rare, The Associated Press has reported. All states verify mail and absentee ballots, regardless of how those ballots are cast.

text: A video shows the 2022 FIFA World Cup in Qatar opening with children reciting the Quran.

claimReview.title: Video of children reciting Quran at Qatar stadium is from 2021
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed on Oct. 22, 2021, and shows an inauguration ceremony for the Al Thumama Stadium, a World Cup venue in Doha.

text: George Soros endorsed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis as the Republican nominee for the 2024 presidential election.

claimReview.title: Soros did not endorse DeSantis in 2024 presidential race
claimReview.textualRating: False. During a keynote address ahead of last week’s Munich Security Conference, Soros said he hopes for a scenario in which DeSantis runs for and wins the Republican nomination so that former President Donald Trump will run as a third-party candidate, paving the way for “a Democratic landslide.” He did not express personal support for DeSantis as a political candidate.

text: Cancer related to human papillomavirus, or HPV, has not decreased, suggesting that the HPV vaccine doesn’t work and that health officials lied.

claimReview.title: Video misleadingly casts doubt on HPV vaccine
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. The HPV vaccine has been associated with a reduction in HPV-related cancers. A recent study did note an increase in stage IV cervical cancer cases among women, but the lead author noted that the rate of cervical cancer overall is decreasing and called vaccination “essential.” Experts say studies show the vaccine is effective.

text: A young man pictured in photos with former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, Democratic Sen. Charles Schumer, Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Elizabeth Warren, and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is the whistleblower.

claimReview.title: Photos do not show whistleblower with Warren, Pelosi and others
claimReview.textualRating: False. The man in the photos is Alex Soros, the son of billionaire philanthropist George Soros.

text: Canada is encouraging minors to commit suicide through its

claimReview.title: Canada isn’t pushing minors to end their lives. Current euthanasia laws don’t apply to them anyway
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users making the claim are sharing a screenshot from the website of an independent organization called Dying With Dignity Canada, which is advocating for certain minors with severe medical conditions to be able to end their lives. Medical assistance in dying, or MAID, is currently only available to adults 18 or older with a serious illness, disease or disability. Canada’s government has said it will pursue research about end-of-life options for young people, but a spokesperson for the country’s federal health agency said it has no immediate plans to lower the minimum age requirement for eligibility.

text: Video from the North Pole shows the moon eclipsing the sun

claimReview.title: Video of a huge moon over the ‘North Pole’ is computer generated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was created by a computer graphics artist, Aleksey Patrev, who states on social media that he is based in Odesa, Ukraine.

text: A proposed bill in Canada would subject anyone who misgenders others or engages in anti-LGBTQ protests to prosecution and a $25,000 fine.

claimReview.title: Posts distort proposed LGBTQ ‘safety zone’ bill in Canada
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bill would not institute a blanket ban on misgendering and anti-LGBTQ protests. The legislation, introduced by members of the opposition party in the Legislative Assembly of Ontario, would allow the province’s attorney general to temporarily prohibit people from engaging in acts of intimidation, such as threats or homophobic protests, within 100 meters (328 feet) of certain properties. Proponents say that the bill is intended to protect drag performers and LGBTQ communities from intimidation.

text: Lab-grown chicken that was recently approved for sale in restaurants is made from human cells.

claimReview.title: No, lab-grown chicken is not made using human cells
claimReview.textualRating: False. The two California companies that have been cleared by the Agriculture Department to sell lab-grown chicken in the U.S. — Good Meat and Upside Foods — told The Associated Press that each of their products are made using cells taken from chickens, not humans. This fact is also reflected in documents both companies submitted to the Food and Drug Administration as part of the agency’s safety evaluation process.

text: A video shows Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announcing in Hebrew plans to build settlements in the Gaza Strip, with a $5 billion investment from the U.S.

claimReview.title: Israeli PM announced plans to rebuild areas near Gaza border, not build inside the territory
claimReview.textualRating: False. Netanyahu’s comments were translated incorrectly in English captions added to the video. He was referencing a five-year, $5 billion plan approved by the Israeli government on Wednesday to rebuild communities near the Gaza border, in the country’s Western Negev region. Netanyahu does not mention a U.S. investment.

text: A photo circulating on social media shows an unidentified girl in a hospital bed “who was robbed, stabbed, and left for dead on the side of the road.”

claimReview.title: False reports of crash victim being stabbed and robbed are spreading virally in US cities
claimReview.textualRating: False. The reports are false, part of a hoax that has spread across the U.S. in states including Utah, Virginia and Mississippi. The photo is of a teenager who was critically injured in a 2016 car crash in Utah and has since recovered.

text: Mother Teresa sold babies.

claimReview.title: Shelter workers, not Mother Teresa, arrested for selling baby
claimReview.textualRating: False. While a nun and a worker at a shelter run by Mother Teresa’s charity in eastern India were arrested in 2018 for allegedly selling a baby to adoptive parents, the case came more than 20 years after Mother Teresa’s death. There is no evidence that she was involved in such activity during her lifetime.

text: Video shows a fake funeral in Gaza in 2021.

claimReview.title: Video of fake funeral was not taken amid Gaza fighting
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video circulated widely on social media accounts from Jordan in March 2020. Media outlets reported at the time that the video shows teens setting up a mock funeral as a tactic to get out of the house during COVID-19 lockdowns.

text: A video shows billionaire philanthropist Bill Gates telling world leaders at the 2022 G-20 summit that “death panels” will soon be required.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent 2010 clip of Bill Gates discussing health care
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip shows Gates in 2010 discussing health care and education systems at a forum hosted by the nonpartisan, nonprofit think tank the Aspen Institute, not at the G-20 meeting in Indonesia this week. While Gates did mention so-called “death panels” — a misleading term used by opponents of the Affordable Care Act — he was explaining why discussion about the cost of end-of-life care had become taboo. He never endorsed the idea.

text: Astrologists and geologists predict that a massive earthquake similar to the quake that hit Turkey on Monday will strike India and Pakistan in 15 days.

claimReview.title: Experts: Earthquakes can’t be predicted
claimReview.textualRating: False. It is not possible to predict earthquakes, according to experts. While parts of India and Pakistan are very seismically active and scientists do calculate the probability that earthquakes will occur in various regions, there is no way to predict when and where earthquakes will take place.

text: On Tuesday, hours before police say Robert Aaron Long, 21, killed eight people at three Atlanta-area massage businesses, he posted on his Facebook that China was engaged in a “COVID coverup” and “AMERICANS NEED TO FIGHT BACK AGAINST CHINA, NOW.”

claimReview.title: Racist Facebook post attributed to Atlanta shooting suspect is false
claimReview.textualRating: False. A Facebook spokesman confirmed to The Associated Press via email that the post is a hoax.

text: Wearing a mask can cause staphylococcus, serious lung infections and loss of consciousness due to restricted airflow.

claimReview.title: Wearing masks does not cause lung infections, loss of consciousness
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Masks do not restrict airflow or cause serious lung infections. Wearing a dirty mask with an open wound could lead to a staph infection but that is rare. Medical experts encourage the use of face masks to curb the spread of the coronavirus.

text: After President Donald Trump held a rally in Omaha, Nebraska, on Oct. 27, the supervisor of a bus company that was hired to shuttle supporters back to their cars said the buses left because the company had not been paid, passengers were not wearing masks and were singing ‘YMCA.’

claimReview.title: Satirical tweet about Omaha Trump rally buses spreads online
claimReview.textualRating: Satire. The claim originated as a satire but was then shared by social media users as real. In reality, the bus company hired by the Trump campaign for the Omaha rally did not abandon the job, though traffic caused delays.

text: The headline on this story has been corrected to show that Trump's first three children did not receive birthright citizenship. The Associated Press reviewed this story after it was surfaced to third-party fact checkers as part of an initiative with Facebook to assess the accuracy of news content.

claimReview.title: President Trump's first 3 children did not receive birthright citizenship
claimReview.textualRating: Mixture. It’s true that Ivana Trump was not a citizen until 1988, but the father of her children was a U.S. citizen and there would have been no special status needed to make them citizens.

text: Great apes in San Diego are getting the coronavirus vaccine while veterans and senior citizens who want it are still unable to get it.

claimReview.title: Apes in San Diego received COVID-19 animal vaccine, not human doses
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Apes vaccinated for the coronavirus at the San Diego Zoo received an experimental animal vaccine and did not take any doses meant for humans.

text: A photo of a Dallas Cowboys branded backpack sold on Amazon shows there is a child inside the backpack.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show a child inside a backpack sold on Amazon
claimReview.textualRating: False. The backpack is empty. A magazine featuring a woman’s face was digitally placed in the backpack to make it appear the bag had contents.

text: The American Red Cross banned people who have received a COVID-19 vaccine from donating blood because it is “tainted.”

claimReview.title: The Red Cross did not ban people with COVID-19 vaccinations from donating blood
claimReview.textualRating: False. No potential donors are deemed ineligible solely due to COVID-19 vaccines, a Red Cross spokesperson told The Associated Press. People who know they received a COVID-19 vaccine that is approved by the Food and Drug Administration may immediately donate blood if they are healthy. Those who received vaccines including ones that contain a weakened form of the virus that causes COVID-19 — or people who aren’t sure — are asked to wait two weeks before donating.

text: Photo shows Queen Elizabeth II’s corgis being carried off an airplane in London following her death in Scotland on Thursday.

claimReview.title: Posts miscaption 1993 photo of Queen Mother’s corgis
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is from 1993, and shows Elizabeth’s mother’s corgis being carried off a plane in London after a visit to Scotland.

text: Video shows a Ukrainian soldier acting for the camera.

claimReview.title: Clip shows music video scene, not Ukrainian soldier ‘acting’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a Ukrainian actor, Pyotr Sherekin, dressed as a soldier for a music video about the war, Sherekin and the production company that filmed the music video confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Video shows President Joe Biden giving the “same” speech months apart, in December 2021 and then in March.

claimReview.title: Video compares Biden remarks delivered days, not months, apart
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video compares portions of remarks that Biden gave two days apart, in December. The clips simply show he used similar language while discussing the same issue.

text: A top World Economic Forum official has said conspiracy theorists should be “eliminated.”

claimReview.title: World Economic Forum didn’t call for the elimination of conspiracy theorists, despite online claims
claimReview.textualRating:
False. Author and historian Yuval Harari didn’t say he wanted conspiracy theorists to be eliminated in a recent podcast interview, a review of the audio shows. He also doesn’t work for the non-governmental organization in any official capacity.
List (Page)

text: Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates wants to eliminate at least 3 billion people in the world, starting in Africa, in a plot involving vaccines.

claimReview.title: Bill Gates never said ‘3 billion people need to die’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Gates never said this. The billionaire philanthropist has spoken about the benefits of slowing the rate of population growth, but he has not advocated killing people.

text: The variants of the coronavirus that have been found in the global population were created by COVID-19 vaccines, which made antibodies that forced the virus to evolve.

claimReview.title: No evidence COVID-19 vaccines create new virus variants
claimReview.textualRating: False. COVID-19 vaccines reduce the spread of the virus, thereby reducing the likelihood that the virus will mutate to create new variants. Scientific evidence also shows a number of coronavirus variants emerged in the population before COVID-19 vaccines were available.

text: When registering to vote in North Dakota, 23,000 people used the same phone number.

claimReview.title: Voters did not register to vote in North Dakota using identical details
claimReview.textualRating: False. North Dakota does not require voter registration. It is the only state in the country that has no such requirement.

text: The Nuremberg Code explicitly states that mask mandates are a war crime.

claimReview.title: Nuremberg Code says nothing about mask mandates
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Nuremberg Code, a set of research ethics created after World War II in response to atrocities perpetrated by Nazi scientists, does not discuss mask mandates. Text circulating online that is said to show details in the code about masks is bogus.

text: Singer Mariah Carey received a “fake” vaccine.

claimReview.title: Video of Mariah Carey shows vaccination with retractable needle
claimReview.textualRating: False. The singer was injected with a safety needle, which retracts after the shot is administered.

text: A man who fired a handgun inside a Dallas-area gymnasium where children were attending a day camp exchanged gunfire with an armed staff member before he was fatally shot by police.

claimReview.title: Texas gymnasium gunman wasn’t confronted by armed staffer
claimReview.textualRating: False. A staff member did not exchange gunfire with the man, officials with the city of Duncanville, which owns and operates the sports complex, confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Former President Barack Obama admitted on camera that he was born in Kenya, not the United States.

claimReview.title: Video altered to suggest Obama admitted he was born in Africa
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was originally posted by a parody account on YouTube more than a decade ago. It had been altered to include the comments cited by social media users. The Democrat never said he was born in Kenya or that he wasn’t American.

text: A video shows an election worker wearing a black shirt and black mask in Delaware County, Pennsylvania, stamping ballots as received and then filling them in, which proves that voter fraud is taking place.

claimReview.title: Video shows Pennsylvania election workers transcribing damaged ballots
