claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, taken from the county’s official livestream, shows an election worker transcribing votes from damaged ballots to clean ballots.

text: The recent death of a red panda cub at Canada’s Toronto Zoo was related to the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Death of red panda cub in Toronto not linked to COVID vaccine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The cub that died was not vaccinated against COVID-19, a spokesperson for the zoo said. While the cause of death is not yet known, red panda cubs have a high mortality rate.

text: Video shows Swedish environmental activist Greta Thunberg arguing that climate change isn’t real.

claimReview.title: Video manipulated to make it look like Thunberg denied climate change
claimReview.textualRating: False. This video was manipulated. Thunberg was explaining why political leaders must make the public aware of the severity of the crisis, not disavowing climate science.

text: A video shows liberal filmmaker Michael Moore supporting former President Donald Trump in 2024.

claimReview.title: Video deceptively edited to make it appear Michael Moore expressed support for Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from Moore’s 2016 film “Michael Moore in TrumpLand,” released weeks before that year’s presidential election. It has been trimmed to make it seem as though the documentarian is backing then-Republican candidate Trump. In a longer excerpt from the same monologue, Moore argues that people will regret voting for Trump when they find out he “wasn’t going to do a damn thing for them.”

text: Photos show an abandoned school bus full of voting machines discovered in Buckeye, Arizona.

claimReview.title: School bus in Arizona held surplus office equipment, not voting machines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bus was full of office equipment purchased at a surplus sale, not voting machines, according to an investigation by the Buckeye Police Department and the Arizona attorney general’s office. It was not abandoned; the driver of the bus was in the vehicle, according to an employee at the gas station where the photos were taken.

text: A volcano emits more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere in a 24 hour period than all human activity over time.

claimReview.title: Humans emit more CO2 than volcanoes
claimReview.textualRating: False. Human activity produces far more CO2 than volcanoes, experts told The Associated Press, and overwhelming scientific evidence shows that climate change is caused by human behavior.

text: Country music star Jason Aldean has sued Whoopi Goldberg and ABC’s “The View” for defamation in relation to his song, “Try That In A Small Town.”

claimReview.title: Jason Aldean didn’t sue Whoopi Goldberg, ‘The View’ for defamation. A satire website made that up
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim originated on a website that publishes made-up, satirical content.

text: By reversing President Donald Trump’s tax cuts, Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden would raise taxes on 82% of Americans.

claimReview.title: Biden tax plan would not raise taxes on majority of Americans
claimReview.textualRating: False. The statistic misstates an analysis of Biden’s tax plan by the University of Pennsylvania’s Penn Wharton Budget Model. Analysts at the economic research-based initiative actually found that only 2% of American families would see their individual income taxes and payroll taxes increase under the Biden plan.

text: Image shows an article reported by The Associated Press, and published on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation website, that says that “44% of pregnant women in Pfizer trial had miscarriages.”

claimReview.title: Altered image falsely attributes COVID vaccine claim to news orgs
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. There is no record of the CBC website publishing that article — and the AP debunked, not confirmed, the claim about Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine trial and miscarriages.

text: A photo shows a billboard with a picture of Russian President Vladimir Putin and the word “Stability!” in Russian in front of a giant plume of flames and smoke.

claimReview.title: Posts share synthetic image of Ukrainian drone attack as real
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image is synthetic. It was created using Photoshop and artificial intelligence by an artist from Kherson, a city in southern Ukraine. The artist told The Associated Press that the image is a combined representation of Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian oil depots and Putin’s preordained reelection.

text: A widespread photo of an owl resting on a blue pad shows that the birds can sit with their legs crossed like humans.

claimReview.title: No, owls can’t sit ‘criss cross, applesauce’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ornithologists say owls can’t cross their legs in such a way because of their anatomy and that the photo being passed around is essentially an illusion. The photo was originally posted online in 2020 with a caption noting that the owl’s legs aren’t actually crossed.

text: Photo shows Democratic presidential hopeful Joe Biden kissing a young girl’s cheek.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Biden kissing a girl’s cheek
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is being misrepresented. The man in the photo is Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador.

text: Former President Barack Obama was just in China and is meddling in foreign affairs.

claimReview.title: Obama did not recently go to China
claimReview.textualRating: False. Obama has not visited China since November 2017.

text: No airplane debris was found at the site of the Pentagon attack on Sept. 11, 2001.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim no airplane debris found at Pentagon on 9/11
claimReview.textualRating: False. Security camera footage from the Pentagon shows American Airlines Flight 77 hitting the building, and photos from that day document an array of debris from the plane at the crash site.

text: A photo shows former NBA star Earvin “Magic” Johnson, who has HIV, donating blood in August 2022 to help COVID-19 patients.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Magic Johnson having blood drawn, not donating it
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image is miscaptioned. It comes from a 2012 documentary and shows Johnson getting his blood routinely drawn at a doctor’s appointment, not donating blood to the Red Cross recently. HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, can be transmitted through contact with the blood of a person who has a detectable viral load. The Red Cross does not accept blood donations from people who have ever had a positive HIV test and it screens all donations for the virus.

text: Using a blow dryer to shoot hot air into your sinuses will kill the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: A blow dryer will not kill the coronavirus
claimReview.textualRating: False. Medical professionals say the practice is dangerous and it will not kill the new coronavirus.

text: Photo shows “the 6th Russian aircraft downed by Ukraine.”

claimReview.title: Photo shows 1993 aircraft collision, not Ukraine-Russia conflict
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image shows a burning fighter jet after it collided with another during a 1993 airshow in the U.K.

text: An image of a map showing President Donald Trump actually won 410 electoral votes reflects election data from a server the U.S. Army seized from the election software company Scytl in Frankfurt, Germany.

claimReview.title: Debunked theory used to claim Trump won 410 electoral votes
claimReview.textualRating: False. Both the Army and Scytl told The Associated Press the claim that servers were seized is not true. Furthermore, Scytl does not currently have servers or offices in Frankfurt, Germany. The map being shared with the electoral vote information carries a website logo, “270 to win,” and can be replicated on that website using any numbers to show electoral votes.

text: Facebook has changed its hate speech policy to include posts that use the phrase "Let's go Brandon."

claimReview.title: Facebook hasn’t changed hate speech policy to ban anti-Biden phrase
claimReview.textualRating: False. A tweet alleging that Facebook changed its policy on hate speech to prohibit the phrase “Let’s go Brandon” was meant to be satirical, the post’s author told The Associated Press. A Facebook spokesperson also confirmed to the AP that the company has not changed its policy to ban the slogan, which is popular among critics of President Joe Biden.

text: “Japan has pulled the vaccines and substituted ivermectin — and in one month, wiped COVID out in that country.”

claimReview.title: Japan has not substituted ivermectin for COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. Japan has not stopped the use of coronavirus vaccines, nor has it substituted them with the parasite drug ivermectin, according to a list of COVID-19 approved medical products from Japan’s Ministry of Health. Additionally, the pandemic has not ended in the country, though new COVID-19 cases have plummeted from a summer peak. More than 1,900 new cases were still documented over the past week, according to data from Johns Hopkins University.

text: The sun does not cause cancer and people should stop wearing sunscreen because it is poisonous.

claimReview.title: Experts agree sun exposure is a cancer risk
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ultraviolet radiation from the sun is a major risk factor in developing skin cancer. While some researchers have raised concerns that certain ingredients in sunscreen may be harmful, skin cancer experts and federal health authorities agree that its benefits outweigh any potential risks.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention admitted that 98 million Americans were given a “cancer virus” through the polio vaccine.

claimReview.title: CDC did not say the polio vaccine gave millions of Americans a ‘cancer virus’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The CDC has made no such statement, and the claim misrepresents a fact sheet put out by the agency more than 10 years ago about some polio vaccines that were administered between 1955 to 1963. The agency has said that that 10-30% of the 98 million shots administered in that period were contaminated with simian virus 40, or SV40, but that most studies have found no causal relationship between SV40 and cancer in humans.

text: COVID-19 mRNA vaccines alter recipients’ DNA by changing its shape to a “triple helix.”

claimReview.title: No, COVID shots don’t change human DNA to a ‘triple helix’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The vaccines do not edit humans’ DNA. Social media posts are misrepresenting a years-old Moderna patent application regarding RNA technology that was not specific to the vaccines.

text: A study co-authored by Dr. Anthony Fauci showed that “most of the deaths” during the 1918-1919 Spanish flu pandemic were actually due to infections from face masks.

claimReview.title: A study by Fauci and colleagues didn’t blame 1918 Spanish flu deaths on masks
claimReview.textualRating: False. The study in question made no mention of masks. Instead, it found that many of the deaths were likely caused by a secondary bacterial pneumonia that followed influenza infection. There is no evidence masks were responsible, Fauci told The Associated Press.

text: A video taken from a balcony shows a sea of protesters packing the street outside former Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif’s London home in response to this week’s arrest of former Prime Minister Imran Khan.

claimReview.title: Video of 2022 London protest misrepresented after the arrest of former Pakistani PM
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a protest outside Sharif’s residence in April 2022. That protest was over Khan being ousted as prime minister.

text: The Smithsonian Institution admitted to destroying thousands of giant human skeletons in the early 1900s.

claimReview.title: Social media users dig up ‘giant’ lie about the Smithsonian
claimReview.textualRating: False. This claim is baseless and has circulated for years as satire, said Linda St. Thomas, chief spokesperson for the Smithsonian Institution.

text: A photo shows 21-year-old Lynn Dee Walker, the suspect in the Michigan State University shooting.

claimReview.title: Posts misidentify Michigan State gunman amid shooting
claimReview.textualRating: False. The person in the image is not the gunman and has no connection to the shooting. Authorities have confirmed that the gunman who killed three students and wounded five before fatally shooting himself was 43-year-old Anthony McRae.

text: CNN journalist Anderson Cooper wants Social Security payments to be withheld from those who are unvaccinated.

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on Anderson Cooper interview
claimReview.textualRating: False. In an Aug. 4 interview, Cooper asked Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates his position on whether the federal government should enforce COVID-19 vaccine mandates by withholding Social Security or other federal benefits from people who don’t comply. Cooper did not say he personally supports such mandates.

text: Photo shows “the 400 jets used by #COP26Glasgow attendees to get to a conference on reducing emissions and fossil fuels.”

claimReview.title: Posts use old photo to criticize jets flown to climate conference
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image was taken in New Orleans during the 2013 Super Bowl.

text: Myocarditis can’t be mild and it’s an irreversible condition. Once the heart muscle is damaged, it cannot be repaired by the body. Within five years of diagnosis, the death rate from myocarditis is 50%.

claimReview.title: Myocarditis is often mild, contrary to online claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. Myocarditis, inflammation of the heart muscle, is a mild, temporary condition in the vast majority of cases, according to experts. Irreversible scarring may occur rarely in a severe case, but even then, it may be possible for the heart muscle to heal with treatment. Experts say claims that patients with myocarditis have a high mortality rate are incorrect and misinterpret the scientific literature on the condition.

text: There are only three people who won the Ellis Island award for their work within the black community

claimReview.title: Award didn’t honor Trump for supporting black community
claimReview.textualRating: False. Trump was one of 87 people to be honored with the Ellis Island Medal of Honor in 1986 for his successful work as a developer in New York City, not for his work within the black community.

text: President Donald Trump appeared on Fox News in disguise, pretending to be an anonymous Nevada poll worker, to spread claims about voter fraud.

claimReview.title: Anonymous poll worker interviewed on Fox News was not Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. The anonymous person interviewed in the segment is not Trump. A comedian made an edited version of the original broadcast in which the person’s voice is overdubbed with a slowed-down version of Trump’s voice. The original interview was with a woman.

text: A picture shows former President Donald Trump being greeted by applauding police officers as he was booked in Georgia following his indictment in that state.

claimReview.title: A photo shows Georgia officers greeting Trump. But it wasn’t during his booking this month
claimReview.textualRating: False. That photo was indeed taken in Georgia but at an airport in June, two months before he was indicted over his actions following the 2020 election.

text: A photo shows a police booking photo of U.S. Sen. Raphael Warnock following an arrest two decades ago.

claimReview.title: Fake Warnock mugshot circulates ahead of Georgia Senate runoff
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The image has been manipulated to place Warnock’s face in the police booking photo. Warnock’s campaign confirmed to The Associated Press that the image is fake. The picture of the Democratic senator used in the manipulated image appears to be a screenshot from a 2017 television interview.

text: National Public Radio wants people to burn books written by white people.

claimReview.title: NPR did not suggest burning books written by white authors
claimReview.textualRating: False. A story published on June 6 on NPR’s website never mentions book burning. The piece recommends broadening and diversifying personal reading lists to go beyond white authors.

text: COVID-19 vaccines cause loss of pregnancy.

claimReview.title: Photo promotes false claim that COVID vaccines end pregnancies
claimReview.textualRating: False. Studies have shown that COVID-19 vaccines are safe to receive while pregnant and have found no increased risk of miscarriage or pregnancy loss for recipients, reproductive health experts told The Associated Press.

text: A Time magazine cover from 1977 featured a photo of a penguin with the headline, “How To Survive The Coming Ice Age.”

claimReview.title: Purported Time magazine cover about impending ice age is fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. This is a fake cover, the magazine confirmed when the bogus image circulated online in 2013. A real cover with the penguin photo in 2007 featured the headline, “The Global Warming Survival Guide.”

text: AT&T got a contract to do a forensic audit of Dominion Voting Systems machines and those machines were recently moved to Nashville, Tennessee — to the same AT&T building that was damaged in a Christmas morning explosion.

claimReview.title: AT&T not conducting voting machine audit near Nashville explosion site
claimReview.textualRating: False. AT&T did not have a contract to audit Dominion machines and was not holding Dominion machines in its Nashville building, both companies confirmed to The Associated Press. Authorities still don’t know the reason for the Christmas day bombing, but there’s no evidence it was election related.

text: A photo shows an Israeli soldier pinning a child to the ground with his foot while pointing a rifle in the child’s face.

claimReview.title: Years-old image does not show an Israeli soldier pinning a child to the ground
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo, which dates to at least 2012, has been cropped to show only a man’s legs, omitting key details that make it clear he is not a member of the Israeli military, such as the type of rifle he is carrying and details on his uniform. The Israeli Defense Forces confirmed to The Associated Press that the man, as seen in an image showing his entire body, is not one of its soldiers.

text: Disney-Pixar to release “Boo,” a film spinoff from the animated “Monsters, Inc.” franchise, in July 2020.

claimReview.title: Disney-Pixar is not releasing a “Boo” movie based off of “Monsters, Inc.” in 2020
claimReview.textualRating: False. Disney is not releasing a sequel to the popular animated buddy movie “Monsters, Inc.” next summer, despite social media posts of what appears to be a movie poster for “Boo,” which is the name of the child featured in the 2001 movie.

text: Video shows Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni doing martial arts in a white hat and robe.

claimReview.title: Video shows comedian, not Ugandan president
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows Ugandan comedian Teacher Mpamire parodying Museveni.

text: A photo of Major Biden, a German Shepherd, shows the dog is nearly as tall as President-elect Joe Biden when he is seated.

claimReview.title: Majorly manipulated photo of Joe Biden’s dog circulating online
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo has been altered to make it appear Major is much larger than he is in real life.

text: A photo shows that the bottled water that former President Donald Trump gifted to East Palestine, Ohio, residents was dark yellow in color.

claimReview.title: Bottled water Trump gave to Ohioans wasn’t yellow
claimReview.textualRating: False. This is a years-old photo that has been altered to discolor the water. AP photos of the bottles Trump handed out in Ohio show that the water appeared clear.

text: A recent video of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's cabinet meeting on security shows officials calling for the removal of Sikh soldiers from the Indian army.

claimReview.title: Indian security committee didn’t call to remove Sikhs from army
claimReview.textualRating: False. India’s Press Information Bureau said in a statement that no such conversation happened during the cabinet meeting. A video of a December meeting was manipulated to add audio that originated on a separate social media app among unrelated individuals, a review of recordings posted online shows.

text: On Oct. 31, President Donald Trump wrote a tweet saying, “If I lose the election, I’m nuking California.”

claimReview.title: Trump did not tweet about ‘nuking California’
claimReview.textualRating: False. This tweet was fabricated. It does not appear on Trump’s Twitter feed, or does it appear in an archive of deleted Trump tweets assembled by the nonprofit news outlet ProPublica.

text: Video shows U.S. shooting down missiles launched by Iran.

claimReview.title: Footage does not show US take down of Iranian missiles
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage is computer-generated.

text: The Inflation Reduction Act is responsible for the drop in the inflation rate observed in the year following its passage.

claimReview.title: Inflation Reduction Act can’t take much credit for drop in inflation rate, experts say
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While the inflation rate is indeed down from its peak, economists say the law can take little credit, and many provisions are just now starting to be implemented.

text: Using the new 988 mental health hotline “will automatically route your geolocation information to local authorities.”

claimReview.title: New 988 hotline doesn’t currently use geolocation services
claimReview.textualRating: False. The hotline does not currently have the capability to detect the exact location of a caller, nor does it “automatically” share such information with authorities. Federal officials held a recent forum to discuss the possibility of adding geolocation capabilities to 988 in the future to connect callers with nearby crisis centers and for rare cases of responding to imminent risk.

text: Statistics show that among members of Congress, 117 have bankrupted at least two businesses, 71 can’t receive credit cards due to bad credit and 84 have been arrested for drunk driving.

claimReview.title: Video recycles dubious statistics about lawmakers’ crimes
claimReview.textualRating: False. Those purported statistics have circulated via email and social media posts for years, but are not backed by evidence. The numbers were largely lifted from a dubious 1999 blog post that did not provide specific sources or details. While members of Congress have been accused of various crimes over the years, experts say there are no known databases that track such crimes committed by members of Congress.

text: Video shows China’s military exercise in Taiwan after House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit.

claimReview.title: Video shows 2020 military exercise in Matsu islands
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed in November 2020, and shows a live fire exercise carried out by the Taiwanese army in Matsu, a group of islands off the country’s coast.

text: Brock Turner, a former Stanford University student who was convicted of felony sexual assault in 2015, will be speaking at the Republican National Convention.

claimReview.title: Satirical claim about Brock Turner speaking at RNC fools some on Twitter
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim originated as a joke from a comedian on Twitter and the Trump campaign has called it “totally false.”

text: A Wisconsin mall Santa Claus and his elves beat up a young girl’s stepdad because she said he molested her.

claimReview.title: Bogus Wisconsin mall Santa story resurfaces online
claimReview.textualRating: False. This years-old tale isn’t based on real events. Officials in Milwaukee and a spokesperson for the mall named in a widely-shared story about the alleged assault confirmed to The Associated Press that it is false.

text: Colorado’s governor issued an executive order allowing hospitals to turn away unvaccinated people and prioritize vaccinated people.

claimReview.title: Colorado order doesn’t instruct hospitals to turn away the unvaccinated
claimReview.textualRating: False. Colorado Gov. Jared Polis signed an executive order recently that allows hospitals and emergency departments that are overwhelmed during surges in COVID-19 cases to stop admitting people and redirect them to other facilities, or transfer existing patients. However, the executive order makes no mention of unvaccinated people being denied care.

text: Video shows fans in a Toronto bar cheering as Golden State Warriors forward Kevin Durant’s June 10 injury is shown on a large TV screen.

claimReview.title: Video showing fans cheering over Kevin Durant's injury was manipulated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from 2016 and was digitally altered to change the image that appeared on the big screen.

text: Kenya has instituted the death penalty for all wildlife poaches regardless of nationality.

claimReview.title: Wildlife poaching in Kenya is not punishable by death
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no death penalty in Kenya. Poachers in Kenya face fines and prison sentences.

text: A Pfizer document reveals that 82%-97% of pregnant women who received the company’s COVID-19 vaccine “lost their babies.”

claimReview.title: Posts distort data on Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine and pregnancy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The flawed calculation misrepresents data from a Pfizer database of adverse events recorded during the first two months of the vaccine rollout. The registry included 270 reports of vaccination during pregnancy. No adverse events were recorded among the majority of those women. Of 34 women who specified outcomes, 28 reported the loss of a fetus or a neonatal death, five reported “outcome pending” and one reported a “normal outcome.” The misleading percentages were based on this small subset of the data.

text: President Joe Biden raised insulin prices after former President Donald Trump lowered them.

claimReview.title: Misleading claims cite Biden for insulin price increases
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. The president doesn’t set the price of drugs. The Biden administration repealed a narrow, Trump-era regulation that sought to lower the cost of insulin at federally funded health centers. The regulation was never implemented and experts say its impact was expected to be limited.

text: President Donald J. Trump tweeted, “My blood IS the vaccine!!!!!” on Oct. 5, 2020.

claimReview.title: Trump did not tweet his “blood is the vaccine”
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet, which was made to look like it came from the president’s verified account, was fabricated.

text: A photo shows former President Donald Trump alongside both his pregnant wife, former first lady Melania Trump, and porn star Stormy Daniels.

claimReview.title: Photo altered to show Donald Trump with Melania and Stormy Daniels
claimReview.textualRating: False. The three were not pictured together. An image of the Trumps at a 2005 fashion industry event was altered to superimpose Daniels into the scene. The images were taken at unrelated events months apart.

text: Video shows that a spectator was removed from a Wichita Thunder hockey game because she was wearing a sweatshirt emblazoned with the text “Let’s Go Brandon.”

claimReview.title: Woman was removed from hockey game for her actions, not her shirt
claimReview.textualRating: False. The woman was escorted out of the arena because she continued to use inappropriate language and gestures after multiple warnings, the hockey team said in a statement. Other spectators wearing identical sweatshirts stayed until the game ended.

text: Photo shows lion’s mane mushrooms growing in a swamp.

claimReview.title: Photo shows art piece, not lion’s mane mushrooms
claimReview.textualRating: False. This photo shows a person inside a suit made of platinum blonde hair extensions for a work by artist Susi Brister.

text: “Why such an invasive test for COVID-19 if it is so easily transmitted through droplets? A mouth swab would suffice if this was as deadly as they claim it to be. Someone is lying again.”

claimReview.title: COVID-19 nasal tests are designed to reach where the virus lives
claimReview.textualRating: False. Nasal swabs allow for a sample to be taken where the respiratory virus lives. Saliva tests for the virus have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration and are also available.

text: A black-and-white photo of a young boy clutching a huge pick shows an 8-year-old coal miner from Utah or Colorado in the early 1900s.

claimReview.title: This photo from the 1900s doesn’t show an 8-year-old miner, just a kid in a costume
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo, which belongs to the Helper’s Mining and Railroad Museum in Helper, Utah, was staged by the boy’s parents, the museum’s director told The Associated Press. Additionally, while 8 year olds did work cleaning coal at the time, they did not go underground with their fathers as actual miners until they were older, he said.

text: The best way to avoid COVID-19 altogether is to exercise, eat healthy and let your immune system beat it naturally.

claimReview.title: Vaccination is safer than risking COVID-19 infection
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence that exercise or a healthy diet can prevent a COVID-19 infection or the long-term disease that may result from it. The only known way to minimize risk of a severe COVID-19 infection is by getting vaccinated.

text: Video shows cows at a farm in Italy that were killed by COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Video shows cows sickened by chemical in plants, not COVID vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows cows that weresickened and died from consuming plants that contained high concentrations of a naturally occurring chemical that becomes toxic in drought conditions, according to a veterinarian who investigated the matter. The plant produced the dangerous chemical as the result of a drought.

text: If Joe Biden wins the presidential election but cannot serve his full term, vice presidential nominee Kamala Harris would become president and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi would become vice president.

claimReview.title: House speaker is not next in line to replace vice president
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. It is true that the vice president is next in line for the presidency. But the leader of the House of Representatives is not next in line for the vice presidency.

text: The COVID-19 mRNA vaccines are “gene-altering” and cause “your body to continue cloning the virus inside of you forever.”

claimReview.title: Video repeats false claims about COVID vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The vaccines do not edit humans’ DNA and they do not contain the live coronavirus.

text: Photo of fires and large plumes of smoke in an urban area at night shows NATO’s 1999 bombing campaign targeting Yugoslavia.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Baghdad in 2003, not Yugoslavia in 1999
claimReview.textualRating: False. This image misrepresented by a verified Russian Twitter account shows the U.S.-led invasion of Baghdad in 2003.

text: A booth at an LGBTQ Pride festival in Madison, Wisconsin, was handing out free letters qualifying transgender and nonbinary people for gender-confirmation surgeries.

claimReview.title: Services offered at Wisconsin Pride festival misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While the booth at the 2022 Magic Pride Festival in Madison had a banner that said “Letters of Readiness,” no letters qualifying people for gender-confirmation surgeries were given out, a licensed clinical psychologist who worked at the booth told The Associated Press. Attendees who visited the booth were offered lengthy consultations with licensed mental health professionals, culminating in a written report to be issued weeks later assessing their ability to move ahead with surgery.

text: Video shows CNN staged a news report in which its correspondent and her team sheltered in a ditch near the Israel-Gaza border during a rocket attack.

claimReview.title: No, CNN did not stage a report about a rocket attack on the Israel-Gaza border
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video’s audio was altered to make it appear the CNN team was being directed by someone off screen. In the actual report, which can be viewed on CNN’s website, a correspondent for the network describes the attack as it happens.

text: Fox News reports that California Gov. Gavin Newsom is trying to prevent former President Donald Trump from appearing on the state’s ballot in 2024 as a candidate for president.

claimReview.title: California’s governor isn’t trying to block Trump from the ballot, despite what fake headline claims
claimReview.textualRating:
False. Newsom’s office says no such proposal exists and that the Democratic governor hasn’t even floated such a notion. A spokesperson for Fox News also says the media outlet has never reported such an idea coming from Newsom. The claim appears to have originated from a parody account.
List (Page)

text: Video shows President Joe Biden saying, "The biggest problem we had in the Revolutionary War, is we didn't have enough airports."

claimReview.title: Video shows Biden remarking on Trump’s comments
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The video segment from a campaign rally in Tampa, Florida, last October shows Biden referencing former President Donald Trump’s comments.

text: A photo shows Lotta Volkova, the top designer for luxury fashion brand Balenciaga, dressed in a devil-like outfit while holding two red dolls.

claimReview.title: Former Balenciaga stylist not pictured in devil-like outfit
claimReview.textualRating: False. Volkova, a Russian stylist, is not Balenciaga’s top designer, nor is she the woman in the photo, her agent confirmed to The Associated Press. The image actually shows a model in a 2016 China Fashion Week show for Sheguang Hu, a Chinese fashion designer and performance artist.

text: During television election coverage of the Georgia Senate runoff races, 32,000 votes disappeared from GOP Sen. David Perdue’s vote count.

claimReview.title: Perdue vote count changed on television due to data reporting error
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Edison Research, the polling firm that provides election data to CNN and ABC News, told The Associated Press the change in the vote count was to fix an error that had mistakenly added 32,000 votes to Perdue’s count in Bibb County.

text: Remdesivir is “continuing to kill patients in the United States” and recipients have “a less than 25% chance of survival if they get more than two doses.”

claimReview.title: Nurse peddles baseless claim that COVID treatment remdesivir is lethal
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say claims that remdesivir, an antiviral medicine approved as a COVID-19 treatment, is killing patients are baseless. Clinical trials did not find that the drug increases deaths among recipients.

text: Nimrod Aloni, a general in the Israeli army, was captured by Hamas militants during a deadly incursion Saturday into southern Israeli towns near the Gaza Strip.

claimReview.title: A top Israeli general was not kidnapped by Hamas, contrary to widespread online claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for the Israel Defense Forces told reporters on Saturday that claims Aloni has been captured are not true. Aloni can be seen in a video and photo of top Israeli military officials discussing the conflict on Sunday.

text: Photo shows six people praying over a golden idol of former President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: Photo of people praying over golden Trump statue is fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. Though a 6-foot-tall golden statue of Trump’s likeness is real, this particular image was fabricated. The individuals in the original photo were praying around Trump himself, not a statue, at an “Evangelicals for Trump” event last year.

text: U.S. hospitals are earning a $48,000 government subsidy for every patient that dies from COVID-19 in their care.

claimReview.title: Hospital COVID payments tied to patient treatment, not deaths
claimReview.textualRating: False. Hospital industry officials and public health experts confirm the federal government provides hospitals with enhanced payments for treating COVID-19 patients, but the payments are only currently applicable to those on Medicare. The enhanced payments, which are slated to end in May, also aren’t contingent on a patient’s death but on the treatment or services provided to the patient, they said.

text: Video shows migrants trying to disrupt a parade of St. Nicholas in Austria only to have men dressed as Krampus, a goat-like Central European folk figure with horns, defend the festival.

claimReview.title: People who disrupted Italy ‘Krampus’ festival were local volunteers, not migrants
claimReview.textualRating: False. Event organizers posted on Facebook to say that the people in the video seen running from the devilish characters were locals dressed in padded clothing who volunteered to be part of the festivities in a town in northern Italy. The town’s mayor also said no migrants were attacked at the event.

text: It has been confirmed that roses laced with fentanyl are being used as a sex trafficking ploy in Clinton, Mississippi.

claimReview.title: Unsubstantiated claim of fentanyl-rose trafficking scheme spreads online
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While one person did make that claim online and in a call to the local police department, Clinton’s city attorney said the department was not able to substantiate the account. That individual declined to provide additional corroborating information to The Associated Press. The organization that runs the National Human Trafficking Hotline said it was not aware of any reports to the hotline that followed such a pattern.

text: There are 130,000 glaciers on Earth today, the same number as when former Vice President Al Gore was born.

claimReview.title: Has the number of glaciers changed in Al Gore’s lifetime? Experts say their mass is more important
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no way of knowing the number of glaciers when Gore was born in 1948, since there was no global inventory at the time, experts tell The Associated Press. A comprehensive global glacier inventory estimates there were roughly 215,000 glaciers in the world as of the year 2000, excluding the Greenland and Antarctic Ice Sheets. Regardless, experts say the best way to measure changes to the world’s glaciers over time — and the impacts of climate change — is to look at their mass, which has been dramatically decreasing.

text: A screenshot shows CNN published an article with the headline, “Should Women be allowed to breastfeed on the battlefield?”

claimReview.title: CNN did not publish article about breastfeeding on the battlefield
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such article was published. The screenshot was manipulated to add a different headline and photo. The image attached to the story has also been edited and shows actress Jessica Simpson in the film “Private Valentine: Blonde & Dangerous.”

text: A three-minute viral video features the fireworks display that was planned for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. The fireworks were set off near Mount Fuji recently because they could not be stored until the postponed date of the Olympics in July 2021.

claimReview.title: Video shows years-old fireworks simulation, not Olympic fireworks display
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video being shared on social media is not a real fireworks show, but a digital simulation. It does not appear to have any relationship to the 2020 Olympics — the video previously appeared on YouTube in 2015.

text: COVID-19 vaccines are causing a form of AIDS that is not related to HIV, long established as the cause of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome.

claimReview.title: No relationship between COVID-19 vaccines and AIDS
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence that the COVID-19 vaccines cause any kind of immune deficiency condition, let alone AIDS, experts say. Nor is there evidence that the COVID-19 vaccines damage the immune system.

text: Video shows attendees of the 2022 World Cup in Qatar converting to Islam.

claimReview.title: Video doesn’t show 2022 World Cup watchers converting to Islam
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was not taken at the World Cup this month. The clip has circulated online since May 2016, and shows an event hosted by a Muslim preacher in Qatar’s capital six years ago, according to pages for the event posted by both the speaker and the venue.

text: Polio stopped spreading when the pesticide DDT stopped being used, not when vaccines for the virus were introduced.

claimReview.title: Experts say toxic pesticide DDT not linked to polio
claimReview.textualRating: False. Polio vaccines are credited with ending epidemics of the disease in the U.S., and helping curb most cases globally, several medical experts confirmed to The Associated Press. The disease and its side effects, including paralysis, have been widely demonstrated to be caused by the polio virus, not a pesticide, the experts said.

text: A compilation of videos shows people collapsing because they have taken COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Video of people collapsing on camera doesn’t show vaccine reactions
claimReview.textualRating: False. Multiple people featured in the video have clarified that they collapsed or appeared ill for other reasons. COVID-19 vaccines are not causing a large number of people to collapse in routine settings, medical experts say.

text: A May 20 tweet sent and later deleted by U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a Democrat representing New York, argues that governors should keep businesses closed until after the presidential election because economic recovery will help get President Donald Trump re-elected.

claimReview.title: Ocasio-Cortez did not tweet that businesses should stay closed through the 2020 election
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet was fabricated. It does not appear in archived versions of Ocasio-Cortez’s Twitter feed or in databases that track deleted tweets by politicians. The congresswoman’s office also confirmed the tweet is not real.

text: Crew member dies after falling off balcony on set of Fred Rogers movie

claimReview.title: "Mister Rogers" crew member dies after falling on set of movie
claimReview.textualRating: True. A crew member working on a movie about Mister Rogers died after he suffered an apparent medical emergency and fell off a balcony of an apartment building.

text: Republican candidate settled 2006 sexual discrimination charge

claimReview.title: Gubernatorial candidate Shawn Moody settles sexual discrimination case from 2006
claimReview.textualRating: True. Republican gubernatorial candidate Shawn Moody settled a sexual discrimination case with a former employee for around $20,000.

text: Australian hospitals are overwhelmed by "vaccine-injured" patients.

claimReview.title: Overcrowding in Australian hospitals not caused by vaccine injuries
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video of Western Australia Premier Mark McGowan was taken out of context to support the incorrect claim. McGowan was discussing the impacts of the pandemic on the health care system generally, not referencing vaccine side effects, a spokesperson told The Associated Press. Hospitals across Australia have experienced diminished capacity, longer wait times and increased demand for years. These issues are being exacerbated by the pandemic, but are not related to COVID-19 vaccine injuries, according to government and health officials.

text: An order from the U.S. Department of Energy under President Joe Biden blocked Texas from generating adequate power during the recent statewide emergency because it would exceed pollution limits.

claimReview.title: Biden didn’t block Texas from increasing power during emergency
claimReview.textualRating: False. The order did the opposite of what social media users are claiming. It gave the Electric Reliability Council of Texas, which operates Texas’ power grid, emergency permission to produce enough energy to restore power to Texas homes, even if it temporarily exceeded pollution limits.

text: There have been one million COVID-19 vaccine adverse events reported to the federal database VAERS.

claimReview.title: One year into COVID shots, misleading VAERS claims persist
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. VAERS is an early warning system through which the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration keep tabs on signals of possible side effects from vaccines. However, the passive reporting system, which relies on unverified reports submitted by the general public, is not an official database for proving that the vaccine caused the adverse events reported.

text: London’s Metropolitan Police has launched an investigation into COVID-19 vaccine-related crimes.

claimReview.title: UK police haven’t launched criminal investigation into COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such investigation has been launched, according to the Metropolitan Police.

text: It is now legal in Canada to possess illicit drugs including heroin, fentanyl, cocaine and meth.

claimReview.title: Canadian province decriminalized, not legalized, some drugs
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. An exemption to Canada’s drug laws that will be tested in the province of British Columbia for three years decriminalizes the substances, but doesn’t legalize them. Canadians who possess up to 2.5 grams of such drugs for personal use will not be arrested or charged.

text: A legally-binding World Health Organization “pandemic treaty” will give the organization the authority to control U.S. policies during a pandemic, including those on vaccines, lockdowns, school closures and more.

claimReview.title: WHO ‘pandemic treaty’ draft doesn’t sign over US sovereignty
claimReview.textualRating: False. The voluntary treaty, which is in draft form and is still far away from ratification, does not overrule any nation’s ability to pass individual pandemic-related policies, multiple experts, including one involved in the draft process, told The Associated Press. The treaty lays out broad recommendations related to international cooperation on pandemic prevention, preparedness and response. Nowhere in the 30-page document are lockdowns, closures or specific citizen surveillance systems mentioned.

text: A Daily Beast headline stated that an off-duty Pentagon Police officer was ‘caught dealing fentanyl’ to children trick-or-treating.

claimReview.title: Officer not arrested for dealing fentanyl to trick-or-treaters
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Daily Beast did not publish a headline with that information, the news outlet confirmed in a statement. The actual headline reported on an off-duty officer who was accused of dealing cocaine. Police also confirmed that the officer’s arrest was not related to fentanyl or trick-or-treaters.

text: A video shows people at a July 4 White House celebration pretending to take photos of President Joe Biden with switched-off phones, proving the event was staged.

claimReview.title: Blank phone screens are not proof that a July 4 White House event was staged
claimReview.textualRating: False. The event was not staged. The screens are hard to see due to the glare of the sun and the low quality of the footage, but a longer and higher-resolution version of the same video clearly shows people taking pictures with their phones powered on.

text: Video shows protesters crowding the streets of Caracas during a Nov. 16 demonstration against Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro.

claimReview.title: Video does not show a November protest in Venezuela
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a January protest in Venezuela, not recent demonstrations.

text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy on Wednesday addressed the U.S. Congress while wearing a shirt emblazoned with a neo-Nazi symbol.

claimReview.title: Zelenskyy’s shirt featured Ukraine military emblem, not hate symbol
claimReview.textualRating: False. Zelenskyy wore a military T-shirt that featured the official emblem for the Ukraine Armed Forces. In its center, the emblem includes Ukraine’s official coat of arms. The image on his shirt did not match the Iron Cross or any hateful symbol, according to historians and extremism experts.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention should do studies on natural immunity instead of guns.

claimReview.title: Post falsely suggests CDC doesn’t study natural immunity to COVID-19
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. This claim falsely suggests the CDC does not study natural immunity to COVID-19. The agency has conducted multiple studies on the extent to which previous COVID-19 infection protects survivors from getting the virus again.

text: Olaplex, an American company whose products are designed to repair damaged hair, was banned in Europe because an ingredient it uses was linked to infertility.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim Europe banned popular hair care brand
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the EU banned an ingredient used in several beauty and hair products, saying it could potentially be harmful for reproduction, Olaplex removed that ingredient from its products in Europe before the ban was enforced.

text: As prime minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe went against orders from the World Economic Forum and declined to mandate COVID-19 vaccines, rejected 1.6 million doses of the drug and gave citizens ivermectin.

claimReview.title: Baseless post ties Shinzo Abe’s assassination to COVID-19 policies
claimReview.textualRating: False. Abe was no longer prime minister when Japan’s COVID-19 vaccinations began in 2021. While it’s true the country did not mandate the shots, it did not provide the parasite drug ivermectin instead. Due to contamination, more than 1 million doses of the Moderna coronavirus vaccine were recalled in September, but Japan continued to vaccinate people against the virus.

text: Workers with the Federal Emergency Management Agency are not required to be vaccinated against COVID-19, but are being used to replace health care personnel who are refusing to comply with vaccination mandates.

claimReview.title: Unvaccinated FEMA employees aren’t replacing noncompliant health care workers
claimReview.textualRating: False. FEMA workers are considered federal employees and are required to be vaccinated against COVID-19 by Nov. 8 under an executive order issued by President Joe Biden. Further, the agency is not sending its workers to replace unvaccinated health care personnel, a FEMA spokesperson said. The official told The Associated Press that the claim is “factually incorrect.”

text: A deadly contagion known as Disease X is emerging and under discussion at the World Economic Forum’s 2024 annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland.

claimReview.title: A panel of healthcare experts discussed ‘Disease X’ at Davos. But it’s only a hypothetical illness
claimReview.textualRating: False. Disease X is not real. It is the name given to a hypothetical pathogen that is being used to help plan for future health crises. Global healthcare experts this week spoke on a WEF panel called “Preparing for Disease X.” The name was coined by the World Health Organization in 2018.

text: Climate activists have vowed to kill millions of dogs in an effort to “reduce their carbon pawprint.”

claimReview.title: Calls to stem canine climate impact greatly exaggerated
claimReview.textualRating: False. Environmental and animal rights organizations told The Associated Press that they had not heard of any initiative to kill dogs in the name of environmental activism. The false claim was spread by a website known for publishing misinformation.

text: Car seats are being left in public places as a sex trafficking ploy to kidnap women.

claimReview.title: TikTok video spreads unsupported claim of human trafficking trap
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence that this is a ploy being used by traffickers, officials say. A viral TikTok video references a North Carolina police department’s announcement but ignores what it actually said: that, contrary to rumors, a car seat left in a Walmart parking lot was not found to be associated with trafficking.

text: A 75-year-old woman named Paulette Harlow was sentenced to two years in prison for praying outside an abortion clinic in Washington.

claimReview.title: Anti-abortion activist convicted for blockading a reproductive health clinic, not for praying there
claimReview.textualRating: False. Harlow was convicted in August 2023 of federal civil rights offenses for her role in the October 2020 invasion and blockade of the Washington Surgi-Clinic. Along with other anti-abortion activists, Harlow used force and physical obstruction to execute the blockade, according to the Department of Justice. She was sentenced to 24 months in prison on Friday.

text: A Democrat candidate in Cincinnati was just arrested for accepting bribes in exchange for votes as a part of a federal sting. Remind me again how voter fraud "isn't real?"

claimReview.title: Cincinnati councilman isn’t accused of voter fraud
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. A federal public corruption investigation in Cincinnati has nothing to do with election voter fraud. Cincinnati City Councilman P.G. Sittenfeld was indicted Thursday on six federal counts of bribery and extortion related to a city real estate development deal.

text: The gunman in the Uvalde, Texas, school shooting was arrested four years ago for planning a 2022 school shooting.

claimReview.title: Texas school shooter wasn’t arrested for threat in 2018, officials say
claimReview.textualRating: False. Texas law enforcement officials say Salvador Ramos, the 18-year-old gunman in the mass killing of 19 children and two teachers, was not one of the two juveniles arrested in a 2018 case in the same city.

text: McDonald’s cheeseburger patties are made from “pink slime,” a form of beef which contains a chemical called ammonium hydroxide.

claimReview.title: McDonald’s no longer uses ‘pink slime,’ despite rumors
claimReview.textualRating: False. McDonalds stopped using the by-product, known in the industry as lean, finely-textured beef, in 2011, according to a statement the company made on its website around that time.

text: The U.S. government gives immigrants who cross the country’s border illegally smartphones with unlimited texting and internet access.

claimReview.title: Phones given to US immigrants have limited uses
claimReview.textualRating: False. Immigration and Customs Enforcement does give some immigrants phones. However, they can only access an app called SmartLink, which is used to monitor immigrants after they cross the border, according to the agency, the company that makes the phones and an immigration expert. The devices are not connected to a cellular network and cannot be used to browse the internet, make unauthorized phone calls, or access apps other than SmartLink.

text: If you receive the COVID-19 vaccine and die, insurance companies will not pay out on the policy because the vaccine is experimental.

claimReview.title: Getting COVID-19 vaccine does not affect life insurance death payments
claimReview.textualRating: False. Life insurance policies have not changed because of the COVID-19 vaccination and getting the shot will not impact whether a policy pays out in the event of death, according to the American Council of Life Insurers. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has given emergency use authorization to three COVID-19 vaccines after finding them safe and effective following three phases of clinical trials involving thousands of people.

text: Mortgage contracts will soon be “null and void” because U.S. banks are switching to digital currency.

claimReview.title: Experts: Mortgages won’t be voided by a digital currency
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say the introduction of a digital currency wouldn’t automatically void home financing agreements, and there are no imminent plans to adopt a nationwide digital currency, regardless. The Federal Reserve has been exploring the idea for years, but has consistently said such a system wouldn’t replace physical cash and any final decision would rest with Congress.

text: A video shows MSNBC host Mika Brzezinski saying, “Elon is trying to control how people think. That is our job.”

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent 2017 ‘Morning Joe’ clip
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows Brzezinski talking about then-President Donald Trump on a Feb. 22, 2017, episode of “Morning Joe.” She does not mention Tesla CEO Elon Musk.

text: Harvard University professor Cornel West just persuaded Fox News’ host Tucker Carlson to get “on board” with democratic socialism.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent 2018 interview between Tucker Carlson and Cornel West
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The Tucker Carlson Tonight clip is from July 2018. In the interview, Carlson remarks he’s “basically on board” with the ideals of democratic socialism, but immediately followed up with arguments against the philosophy, stating “it’s never actually worked anywhere.”

text: Vice President Kamala Harris’ Twitter account blurred the presidential seal on President Joe Biden’s desk in a recent post because Biden isn’t really the president.

claimReview.title: Social media posts misrepresent reason for blurred presidential seal
claimReview.textualRating: False. Harris’ personal Twitter account shared a video first posted by the Democratic National Committee, which blurred the seal to avoid conflicting with a federal statute that limits how individuals can use the seal, according to a DNC spokesperson. Official White House channels, such as the vice president’s official Twitter account, frequently post imagesand videos of the seal unobstructed.

text: Voter fraud has been found after women’s maiden names are being used to cast ballots in other states.

claimReview.title: No evidence that people are stealing maiden names to vote
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence that this is taking place.

text: There is a connection between leprosy cases in Florida cited in a new report and the COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Florida leprosy cases highlighted in recent report aren’t linked to COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The report being referenced, published in a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention journal, relied on data about leprosy cases that predated the COVID-19 vaccines. Vaccines can’t give people leprosy, a bacterial infection formally known as Hansen’s disease. Some researchers have explored whether the vaccines could prompt an immune response that causes complications or prompts the disease to surface in people already infected, though even that association isn’t clear.

text: Joe Biden, while vice president, leaked the identities of special ops SEAL Team 6 who captured Osama bin Laden.

claimReview.title: Biden did not leak identities of SEAL Team 6 while vice president
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden, who is seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, did not leak the names of those involved in the raid that killed the al-Qaida leader despite posts circulating widely on social media.

text: A photo shows Republican Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene doing a Nazi salute while wearing a red Soviet Union T-shirt and cape.

claimReview.title: Photo manipulated to falsely show Georgia lawmaker doing Nazi salute
claimReview.textualRating: Altered image. The photo was edited to add Greene’s face, a comparison to earlier iterations of the image shows. The original photo has appeared online for more than a decade and shows a different woman.

text: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration released documents from Pfizer that confirm graphene oxide is in its COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: No, Pfizer doc doesn’t say graphene oxide is vaccine ingredient
claimReview.textualRating: False. The vaccine does not contain graphene oxide, the FDA again confirmed to The Associated Press. The document being cited online does not say anything about vaccine manufacturing, but instead describes using graphene oxide during a process of evaluating the vaccine’s spike protein under a microscope.

text: Three recent giraffe deaths at the Dallas Zoo may have been related to the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: COVID vaccines did not kill giraffes at Dallas Zoo
claimReview.textualRating: False. One giraffe at the zoo was euthanized after a serious knee injury, and the other two giraffe deaths, which both involved liver complications, are still being investigated. No animals at the Dallas Zoo have received COVID-19 vaccines, and giraffes will not be prioritized to receive them, zoo officials told The Associated Press.

text: In a

claimReview.title: Biden didn’t say Democrats would dump ballots
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden never said Democrats would cheat or that they would be dumping ballots in his Nov. 2 address. Video shows Biden urged voters to be patient as it takes time to count legitimate ballots legally.

text: A meme shows a list of 27 ingredients in flu vaccines, including mercury, formaldehyde, antifreeze, aluminum, “aborted baby” lung culture, monkey kidney cells, fetal cow serum and other concerning ingredients.

claimReview.title: Popular social media meme misrepresents flu vaccine ingredients
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Many of the ingredients listed in the meme, including monkey kidneys, aborted fetal cells and antifreeze, are not present in flu vaccines, though some have been used in vaccine development. Others are found in certain versions of the inoculations, but they are present in minimal amounts that have been shown to be safe for humans, according to vaccine experts and public health agencies.

text: The vitamin K shot given to babies contains benzyl alcohol, which is toxic to newborns.

claimReview.title: Post misleads on vitamin K shot ingredient, safety
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The shot, given to babies to guard against bleeding, uses a small amount of benzyl alcohol to protect against bacterial contamination. Experts say a newborn would need to receive much more, on the order of 100 times the amount used, for it to cause side effects.

text: A video from a movie set in Ukraine shows the country is staging Russian atrocities against civilians.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent video of Ukrainian film production
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, filmed in a town near Kyiv, shows the production of a Ukrainian film based on events from the war called “Region of Heroes,” the crew member who recorded the footage confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Video shows people dropping “dead” outside of a COVID-19 vaccination clinic in London after receiving a shot.

claimReview.title: Video does not show woman collapsing after COVID-19 vaccination in London
claimReview.textualRating: False. A woman who collapsed near a bus providing vaccinations to people in North Kensington, London, was just walking down the street. She had not received the vaccine at the mobile bus operating in the area.

text: A photo compilation shows a Ukrainian aircraft that hit a street sign while flying low to avoid radar detection amid the ongoing war with Russia.

claimReview.title: Photos of Ukrainian jet hitting sign are from 2020 exercise
claimReview.textualRating: False. One image in the compilation came from a Ukrainian newscast aired in August 2020. Footage uploaded to YouTube by the news outlet TCH shows the same plane, surroundings and angle with a caption stating the fighter jet had “demolished” a road sign along a highway during a training exercise. The second image, a close-up photo of the sign wrapped around the plane, was also published online at the same time in 2020, well before the current conflict.

text: Photo shows Egypt is projecting the Palestinian flag on its Giza Pyramids during the latest war between Palestinian militants in Gaza and the Israeli military.

claimReview.title: Image of pyramids lit with Palestinian flag is manipulated
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. An internet search reveals this picture was fabricated using a 2014 photo of the pyramids that did not feature the flag projection.

text: New Zealand is seeing its biggest increase in deaths in a century because of the coronavirus vaccine.

claimReview.title: Deaths rise in New Zealand due to COVID, demographic shifts
claimReview.textualRating: False. Government officials and experts in New Zealand say the rise in deaths last year is the result of the country’s first true wave of COVID-19 infections, which follow the lifting of the strict lockdown policy maintained during the first two years of the pandemic. They also say the country’s aging population is playing a role.

text: Photo shows antifa member who was tackled by Trump supporters then duct taped to an electrical box.

claimReview.title: Photo shows live street art, not a captured anti-fascist
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows a work created by the street artist Rallitox, for the 2015-2016 participatory art series “Human Stickers” in Berlin.

text: Searches on the National Institutes of Health website show that ivermectin is a cure for cancer but it is being suppressed.

claimReview.title: No, ivermectin isn’t being withheld as cancer ‘cure’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The website shows that some studies have explored the use of ivermectin in relation to cancer. There are no studies demonstrating the drug cures cancer in humans, experts say, but some are researching the use of ivermectin in combination with other therapies to treat breast cancer.

text: The Food and Drug Administration revoked its emergency authorization for two monoclonal antibody treatments even though they are highly effective in treating COVID-19.

claimReview.title: FDA’s move to halt use of two COVID-19 antibody drugs was based on data
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The antibody treatments from Regeneron and Eli Lilly helped patients infected with previous variants of the coronavirus, but they don’t work against omicron, according to several independent studies that the FDA used to make its decision. The FDA noted that omicron infections account for more than 99% of U.S. COVID-19 cases, making it “highly unlikely” the antibodies would help people currently seeking treatment.

text: The owner of five restaurants in Terminal C at Denver International Airport told employees they needed to get vaccinated for COVID-19 by Nov. 1 or they would be fired. None of the cooks, dishwashers, bussers or hosts showed up to work, so there were no restaurants open in Terminal C. The owner immediately sent an email reversing the vaccine mandate.

claimReview.title: Employee strike didn’t force Denver airport restaurants to close
claimReview.textualRating: False. “We have not had any concession employee strike, nor have any restaurants on Concourse C been closed other than their normal hours of operation,” said Alex Renteria, public information officer for Denver International Airport. “We can confirm this is false information.”

text: An advertisement shows that the International Legion for the Territorial Defense of Ukraine, which the government formed for foreign fighters, is recruiting homeless Americans to join the fight against Russia.

claimReview.title: Ukraine’s International Legion didn’t put out ad recruiting homeless Americans
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Ukrainian embassy in Washington confirmed to The Associated Press that the ad isn’t authentic.

text: An expert who debunked the “pizzagate” conspiracy theory has been jailed for possessing child sexual abuse images.

claimReview.title: ‘Pizzagate’ conspiracy theory revived online. Here's the facts
claimReview.textualRating: False. A former ABC reporter referenced in a meme circulating online was recently sentenced to federal prison for such crimes, but he never investigated the “pizzagate” conspiracy theory.

text: Bill Gates’ daughters have not received any vaccines, including childhood immunizations.

claimReview.title: Posts recycle baseless claim about Gates’ vaccination status
claimReview.textualRating: False. The billionaire philanthropist’s children are “fully vaccinated,” including against COVID-19, The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation confirmed in a statement to The Associated Press. Melinda French Gates also stated that her children had received all of their vaccines in a Facebook post marking World Immunization Week in 2019.

text: A video compilation shows public officials “dropping suddenly” because of COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Video shows public officials collapsing years before COVID-19 vaccine
claimReview.textualRating: False. Multiple people featured in the video were filmed collapsing at events years before the COVID-19 vaccine. Anti-vaccine activists are using the phrase “died suddenly” to falsely attribute deaths or incidents of people fainting to the COVID-19 vaccine.

text: Refugees resettled in the U.S. receive $2,125 per month from the government, while Social Security recipients only receive an average of $1,400 per month.

claimReview.title: Incorrect comparisons made between refugee aid, social security payments
claimReview.textualRating: False. Upon arrival in the U.S., refugee resettlement agencies typically receive a one-time, per person amount of $2,275 from the government to go toward housing, necessities and services for their clients, a spokesperson for the U.S. Department of State told The Associated Press. The money is not disbursed monthly. Social Security Administration data shows that the average beneficiary receives about $1,439 each month. The amount varies depending on the recipient.

text: A video circulating online shows a person firing an AR-15 rifle, and some posts identify her as Swedish environmental activist Greta Thunberg.

claimReview.title: Young woman who appears in a video firing a rifle is not Greta Thunberg
claimReview.textualRating: False. The shooter in the video is another young Swede named Emmy Slinge, who uploaded the original video to her Twitter account.

text: A news clip indicates a TV anchor prematurely announced the Walmart shooting in El Paso.

claimReview.title: Video does not show TV anchor knew of El Paso shooting before it occurred
claimReview.textualRating: False. The anchor on KFOX-TV in El Paso, Texas, did not announce the Walmart shooting before it happened. The newscaster was reading from a screenshot of a tweet, which had been captured in a different time zone, warning of a possible threat at a different Walmart in nearby Horizon, Texas.

text: Video shows Venezuelan Vice President Delcy Rodríguez saying that COVID-19 will not be contagious for up to a week.

claimReview.title: Manipulated video of Venezuelan Vice President Delcy Rodríguez has bogus audio
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video’s audio is manipulated. Rodríguez, right hand to President Nicolás Maduro, was discussing a proposal for the Russian-developed COVID-19 vaccine to be manufactured in Venezuela. Rodríguez made the remarks earlier this month during a meeting in Moscow. Her original audio was swapped out of the video, and bogus audio was edited into the video in its place.

text: Sen. Dianne Feinstein introduced a bill to mandate COVID-19 vaccines to fly domestically.

claimReview.title: Bill on domestic air travel includes options for unvaccinated
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The California Democrat introduced a bill last week that requires those who want to fly domestically provide proof of either vaccination, a negative COVID-19 test or recent recovery from the virus.

text: President Joe Biden’s State of the Union address in 2022 will take place on Groundhog Day.

claimReview.title: State of the Union address not scheduled for Groundhog Day
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden’s speech is scheduled for March 1, while Groundhog Day is on Feb. 2.

text: A Twitter employee named Jackson Mulholland who works on “developing terms & conditions for users” is resigning because he refuses to work for Elon Musk.

claimReview.title: Hoax tweet claims Twitter employee resigned, refused to work with Elon Musk
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Twitter user who posted the tweet identifies his content as “mostly satire” and the company said that there is no employee by that name.

text: The COVID-19 mRNA vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna are no longer authorized in the U.S. because of safety concerns.

claimReview.title: Shift to updated COVID vaccine isn’t tied to safety concerns
claimReview.textualRating: False. Federal officials instead merely sidelined only the original formulation of the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines, in favor of those companies' updated shots. The tweaked versions target the dominant omicron variant as well as an early strain of the coronavirus from the initial vaccines. The decision was not about safety, officials and an expert say.

text: Viewership during each of the four nights of the Republican National Convention was much higher than the four nights of the Democratic National Convention.

claimReview.title: Post uses incomplete viewership tallies for 2020 political conventions
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Available viewership metrics show more people overall tuned into the DNC than the RNC. The claim relies only on data from online streaming of C-SPAN’s YouTube channel, which represents a small fraction of the millions of viewers across platforms.

text: The IRS would collect nearly $850 million in taxes from a more-than $1 billion Mega Millions jackpot.

claimReview.title: Billion-dollar Mega Millions jackpot won’t trigger $850M IRS bill
claimReview.textualRating: False. The winner of the lottery jackpot that currently sits at $1.1 billion would expect to pay at least $135 million in federal income taxes if they choose to receive their earnings all at once, rather than over 30 years, according to a lottery official. The lump sum prize works out to about $570 million, but 24% is automatically withheld for federal taxes. The winner would also be subject to additional federal taxes that would result in owing closer to $210 million in total to the IRS -- still far less than the nearly $850 million claimed by social media users, according to a tax expert.

text: Forty-nine Democratic senators voted that it should be lawful to kill a full-term baby the moment before birth while it is still inside its mother.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent details of US Senate vote to codify Roe
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. Experts say this example is unrealistic and distorts the reality of abortion late in pregnancy. Abortions in the third trimester, which are extremely rare, typically occur because of a significant fetal abnormality, experts say. The bill that 49 Democratic senators voted to pass maintains the current constitutional standard that allows states to restrict abortions after fetal viability — the stage when a fetus is likely to survive outside the womb — but requires exceptions for risks to maternal life or health.

text: Man discovers that a rock he had been using as a doorstop is a meteorite worth $100K

claimReview.title: Rock used as doorstop is actually a meteorite worth $100K
claimReview.textualRating: True. A Michigan man took his doorstop to Central Michigan University where a professor uncovered that the rock was, in fact, a meteorite worth $100,000.

text: Special counsel Robert Mueller’s office deleted 19,000 text messages between former FBI lawyer Lisa Page and former FBI agent Peter Strzok.

claimReview.title: No evidence 19,000 text messages between FBI officials destroyed
claimReview.textualRating: False. A report by the Justice Department’s watchdog found no evidence that text messages between Strzok and Page were intentionally destroyed.

text: Two different men were identified in TV news interviews as the father of one of the children killed in the Uvalde, Texas, school shooting, proof that the shooting was a “hoax.”

claimReview.title: Identity of Uvalde victim’s relatives fuels conspiracies
claimReview.textualRating: False. While some reports identified both Angel Garza and Alfred Garza III as the father of Amerie Jo Garza, Angel Garza is her stepfather while Alfred Garza III is her father.

text: A preprint paper by the prestigious Oxford University Clinical Research Group, published Aug. 10 in The Lancet, found vaccinated individuals carry 251 times the load of COVID-19 viruses in their nostrils compared to the unvaccinated.

claimReview.title: Study on breakthrough delta cases in Vietnam misrepresented online
claimReview.textualRating: False. The study is being misrepresented. It found vaccinated health care workers with breakthrough infections caused by the coronavirus delta variant had higher viral loads — the amount of virus detected in a person — compared to patients infected with earlier strains of the virus. Furthermore, other studies that compare the viral loads between vaccinated and unvaccinated delta patients found similar amounts of viral material in the two groups.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has admitted it purposely distributed lethal batches of COVID-19 vaccinations to states with conservative-leaning populations.

claimReview.title: CDC didn’t say it gave out deadly COVID-19 shots in red states
claimReview.textualRating: False. The CDC has made no such admission and no reports of deadly batches of COVID-19 vaccines have been reported. Social media posts spreading the erroneous information are relying on a flawed analysis published by a website known to spread false information.

text: Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam said if people don’t give up guns, the National Guard will cut off their power, and have them killed.

claimReview.title: Fabricated quote about guns attributed to Virginia governor
claimReview.textualRating: False. The statement was fabricated. Since winning a majority of seats in the state legislature last year, Democrats have introduced multiple pieces of legislation around gun control, but Northam has said he has no plans of confiscating guns from current legal gun owners.

text: A public records request revealed that 20,713 votes that were included in the 2020 election night tally in Fulton County, Georgia, do not exist.

claimReview.title: Missing 2020 poll tallies in Georgia don’t prove 20,713 votes never existed. Other records are available
claimReview.textualRating: False. A complaint submitted to the Georgia State Election Board in July 2022 includes an email from Fulton County stating that ballot tabulator results, or poll tapes, printed on Election Day “do not exist” for 10 machines. But poll tapes are just one part of the paper trail that documents the vote, which is also recorded on memory cards and in official statements released by Georgia counties, among other procedures.
