Three separate counts of Georgia’s votes all found similar results in Fulton County, with then-candidate Joe Biden winning both the county and the state each time.

text: Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla says the company’s dream is to “reduce the population by 50%” in 2023.

claimReview.title: Altered video cuts Pfizer CEO’s comments on low-cost medicine program
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, recorded May 25, is altered to cut Bourla’s statement mid-sentence, twisting the meaning. A full video of the statement shows he states the goal is to “reduce the number of people in the world that cannot afford our medicines by 50%.”

text: Photo of Louisiana Gov. John Bel Edwards without a mask at the Baton Rouge Country Club was taken over Thanksgiving weekend, proving he did not heed his own advice about limiting gatherings.

claimReview.title: Photo of Louisiana governor at country club was taken weeks ago
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. This photo was taken in early November, before the governor increased the state’s coronavirus restrictions in response to an uptick in cases in the state. Responding to criticism about the photo, Edwards said he was standing up from a table where he was eating and put a mask on shortly after the picture was taken.

text: People have been sentenced to 20 years in prison for simply filming the riots at the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021.

claimReview.title: No one has been sentenced to 20 years for filming the Jan. 6 riots, contrary to congressman's claim
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The only person to have been sentenced to at least 20 years in prison in connection with the case is Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the extremist group the Proud Boys. But Tarrio wasn’t charged with filming the riots. He was convicted of seditious conspiracy and other crimes. The majority of defendants so far have received sentences of less than five years in prison.
List (Page)

text: Joe Biden’s running mate Kamala Harris this morning said that “American churches are PROPAGANDA CENTERS for intolerant homophobic, xenophobic vitriol.” She also called American pastors “knuckle-dragging disseminators of intolerance and enemies of social justice.”

claimReview.title: No evidence Kamala Harris called churches ‘propaganda centers’
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence Harris made either of these statements on Sunday morning, nor is there a record of her ever saying them. A spokesman for her office in the Senate confirmed the quotes are fake.

text: Former Fox News anchor Chris Wallace’s “first show on CNN received the lowest ratings in cable news history.”

claimReview.title: Chris Wallace's show on CNN streaming service hasn’t premiered
claimReview.textualRating: False. Wallace’s show on CNN+ hasn’t yet launched. It will air on a streaming service, not cable news.

text: People magazine footage shows that President Joe Biden is stumped for words and unable to respond during an interview as his wife, first lady Jill Biden, looks on.

claimReview.title: Video clip of Biden interview with People magazine was altered
claimReview.textualRating: False A spokesperson for People confirmed the clip shared on social media was altered from the magazine’s Feb. 3 interview with the president and first lady.

text: Video shows farmers in Ukraine working in a burning field amid the war with Russia.

claimReview.title: Video shows a burning wheat field in Michigan, not Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video of the burning field was filmed in the Crystal Township in Montcalm County, Michigan. The video was uploaded to YouTube on July 18, 2022.

text: Video shows a protester kicking a tear gas canister like a soccer ball as smoke billows around him during protests following the death of George Floyd.

claimReview.title: Video of protester kicking a tear gas canister was filmed in Lebanon, not US
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed in 2019 in Lebanon, well before protests demanding justice for Floyd, who died on Monday after a Minneapolis police officer kneeled on his neck for nearly 9 minutes during an arrest. The officer, Derek Chauvin, was charged with third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter.

text: The FDA Vaccines and Related Biological Products Advisory Committee held an eight-hour presentation on YouTube and admitted the vaccination is ineffective and connected to complications in pregnancy, causes new COVID-19 variants, and is less effective than natural immunity.

claimReview.title: Posts misattribute COVID-19 falsehoods to FDA committee members
claimReview.textualRating: False. Members of the committee did not say COVID-19 vaccines are ineffective nor that they have caused health issues. The comments were made by members of the public during the meeting’s open comment period.

text: In Latin, the phrase “Cor ona virus,” written with spaces between parts of the word, translates to “heart attack virus” in English.

claimReview.title: Coronavirus doesn't mean ‘heart attack virus’ in Latin
claimReview.textualRating: False. The word “coronavirus” in Latin, even when split up, does not translate to “heart attack virus.” Social media users are entering additional spaces when translating “cor ona virus” from Latin in Google Translate, which skews results in English. The tool translates some individual root words from Latin when the word is divided up in this way.

text: A graphic aired by Right Side Broadcasting Network showing inaccurate vote counts in Pennsylvania's gubernatorial race is evidence of election fraud.

claimReview.title: Media outlet showed inaccurate vote tally in Pennsylvania governor race
claimReview.textualRating: False. The numbers, which appeared in a livestream during the conservative outlet’s 2022 midterm election coverage on Tuesday, did not reflect the actual results in the election but an error by the media outlet, RSBN said in a statement. The media outlet stated that it made the mistake when manually entering the numbers during the broadcast.

text: The COVID-19 pandemic is “effectively over” and there’s no need for vaccines.

claimReview.title: Coronavirus pandemic is not ‘effectively over’ as op-ed claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim, made in an article by a former employee at the pharmaceutical giant Pfizer, ignores that large numbers of people continue to fall ill and die from the coronavirus in many parts of the world. The United Kingdom, which is the subject of the article, saw a surge in coronavirus cases this fall and exceeded 50,000 coronavirus-related deaths earlier this month. Experts say coronavirus vaccines will be powerful tools to help prevent millions of people from contracting the virus.

text: The National Institutes of Health recently added ivermectin to a list of COVID-19 treatments.

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on NIH COVID-19 guidelines for ivermectin
claimReview.textualRating: False. The NIH COVID-19 treatment guidelines website says the agency recommends against the use of ivermectin for the treatment of COVID-19, except in clinical trials. The page outlining data on antiviral medications has included an entry for ivermectin since at least June 2021.

text: Screenshot shows that Dominion Voting Systems, whose equipment was used in several battleground states in the 2020 election, has deep ties to the Clinton Foundation.

claimReview.title: Posts inflate ties between election system firm and Clinton Foundation
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. This screenshot from the Clinton Foundation’s website shows Dominion made a one-time philanthropic commitment at a Clinton Global Initiative meeting. The Clinton Foundation has no stake in Dominion and has never been involved in Dominion’s operations, the nonprofit confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: In a Facebook post, tennis star Serena Williams said that she was sick of COVID-19, black versus white, gay versus straight and Democrats versus Republicans, and that people should “stop thrusting your beliefs on others.”

claimReview.title: Tennis player Serena Williams didn’t write ‘I’m sick of COVID-19’ post on Facebook
claimReview.textualRating: Partly False. This is a case of mistaken identity. Another Facebook user named Serena Williams shared the comments. Screenshots of her post are being shared on social media, mistaking her for the tennis athlete.

text: Video shows tens of thousands of people protesting in Brussels under the slogan “Stop NATO.”

claimReview.title: Brussels protest was about rising cost of living, not NATO
claimReview.textualRating: False. Trade unions organized a national march in Brussels on Monday to protest the rising cost of living and call for an increase in wages, reporting from The Associated Press and promotional materials from the unions show. While at least one sign was pictured displaying an anti-NATO message, the majority of protesters were marching against the rising cost of living.

text: Former President Barack Obama was referring to his wife, Michelle Obama, in a video in which he says, “I walk with my husband Michael and hold hands.”

claimReview.title: Obama misrepresented in video quoting health care recipient
claimReview.textualRating: False. This claim takes Obama’s words during a 2015 speech out of context. He was quoting a woman who was able to get out of a wheelchair and walk with her husband again after she enrolled in health insurance and underwent knee replacement surgery.

text: Aerial video shows massive crowds protesting in London during President Donald Trump’s state visit this week.

claimReview.title: Aerial footage of London anti-Trump protest was taken in 2018
claimReview.textualRating: False. The aerial BBC footage of crowds gathering to protest Trump was taken last year, not this week.

text: An image shows a Facebook post by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau saying that people should avoid texting and talking on the phone with unvaccinated friends and family and “do everything you can to make life difficult for them until they comply.”

claimReview.title: Facebook post falsely attributed to Canadian prime minister
claimReview.textualRating: False. The post was fabricated. The message does not appear on Trudeau’s social media accounts, and his office confirmed to The Associated Press that it is not real.

text: Listings on Etsy selling downloads of pizza photos for thousands of dollars are just a disguise for pedaling child pornography.

claimReview.title: Claims that pizza listings on Etsy are selling child pornography are baseless
claimReview.textualRating: False. Etsy investigated the claims and found them baseless, a representative said. While no threat to child safety was established, the posts were removed from the online marketplace because they did not appear legitimate and had what seemed to be unreasonably high prices.

text: Nuclear weapons are fake because no camera could have survived the blasts seen in archival test footage.

claimReview.title: Nuclear weapons are real, contrary to conspiracy theory about archival test footage
claimReview.textualRating: False. Camera set-ups used to capture nuclear weapons testing in the U.S. were specially designed to withstand intense effects from the bombs. For example, cameras were encased in steel and lead, and positioned on towers rooted into the ground with concrete, as outlined in declassified military reports. Additionally, the existence of nuclear weapons is well documented, most famously by the atomic bombs the U.S. dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

text: A photo shows actor Sylvester Stallone wearing a shirt that says “There are 4 useless things in this world

claimReview.title: Sylvester Stallone didn’t wear shirt with political message
claimReview.textualRating: False. Stallone was not pictured wearing a shirt with this phrase. An old image of the actor was manipulated to add the words onto his plain black shirt.

text: Wearing face masks can cause fungal and bacterial pneumonia.

claimReview.title: Normal use of face masks do not cause pneumonia
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s no evidence that normal use of face masks can cause fungal or bacterial infections.

text: President Joe Biden used an image from the White House’s Fourth of July celebrations for a New Year’s greeting, but manipulated the image to add a Christmas tree with decorations.

claimReview.title: Biden staff didn’t manipulate photo for New Year’s greeting
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Biden’s New Year’s greeting shared on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram did use an image from July 4, but it wasn’t altered. An original photo captured in July matches the version the president posted on New Year’s Day.

text: The U.S. Marines arrested Colorado Supreme Court Justice Monica Márquez for voting to remove former President Donald Trump from the state’s presidential primary ballot.

claimReview.title: False report targets Colorado justice who voted to disqualify Trump from 2024 primary ballot
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim originated on a website that says it publishes “humor, parody, and satire” and has previously posted similar false stories. A spokesperson for the Colorado Judicial Department confirmed that the allegation has “no legitimacy.”

text: A disheveled room with transgender and NATO flags seen in a widespread photo belonged to the shooter who killed six people at a private Christian school in Nashville, Tennessee, this week.

claimReview.title: Unrelated 2021 photo misidentified as Nashville shooter’s room
claimReview.textualRating: False. That image was posted online as far back as 2021 by a Twitter user who shared the image — along with another picture of the room after it had been tidied. That account indicated in tweets this week that the image was being misrepresented.

text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that more than 16,000 American deaths had been caused by the COVID-19 vaccines as of Dec. 23.

claimReview.title: Posts mischaracterize CDC data on COVID-19 vaccine deaths
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. As of Dec. 23, the CDC reported that over two years it had received 18,007 preliminary reports through VAERS, a user-generated reporting system, of people dying after getting a COVID-19 vaccine. VAERS, run jointly by the CDC and the Food and Drug Administration, relies on unverified reports submitted by the general public. It does not prove that vaccines caused the adverse events reported. Claims about the safety of the vaccines based on data from VAERS have been debunked by The Associated Press on multiple occasions.

text: Italy’s prime minister has launched “Family Pride Month” to promote “traditional families” as a counterpoint to events celebrating the LGBTQ+ community.

claimReview.title: Italy hasn’t created a ‘Family Pride Month’ in response to LGBTQ+ celebrations
claimReview.textualRating: False. Anti-gay groups and LGBTQ+ advocates in the southern European nation confirm the government has made no such announcement. A longstanding, conservative event known as “Family Day” was held last month in Rome, but it is not sponsored by the government and is mostly focused on opposing abortion and same-sex marriage. Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni and other right wing politicians have attended that daylong event over the years.

text: The U.S. military has recorded a 500% increase in new HIV infections since COVID-19 vaccines were introduced.

claimReview.title: No, the military hasn’t recorded a 500% increase in HIV cases
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. military has not recorded any such increase. New HIV diagnoses among military members increased slightly from 237 in 2020 to 309 in 2021, then fell to 124 new infections recorded in 2022, according to figures from the U.S. Department of Defense. That’s a peak increase of 30% from 2020 to 2021, when COVID-19 vaccines were first introduced, and a decrease of nearly 60% from 2021 to 2022 when the rollout was well underway.

text: A video shows native Hawaiians being evicted from their property after the Maui wildfires.

claimReview.title: Decades-old footage of Hawaiians being removed from parkland misleadingly shared online as recent
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The video is from a trailer for a documentary made nearly 40 years ago. It shows law enforcement officials evicting Hawaiians who had been living in Waimanalo Beach Park on the island of Oahu.
List (Page)

text: You “don’t need data or service” to update your cell phone voicemail, so someone in a “dire situation” with no service should do so to alert callers to their location.

claimReview.title: Bogus cellphone ‘emergency tip’ shared on Instagram
claimReview.textualRating: False. Cellphone users would need service or some connection, or access to a landline, in order to update their voicemail greeting.

text: Photo shows a participant at a Pride event wearing a T-shirt with the words “trans kids are sexy.”

claimReview.title: Image of Pride event attendee altered to include comment about transgender children
claimReview.textualRating: Altered image. The photo was digitally manipulated to change the T-shirt. The original image shows the individual was wearing a plain white T-shirt.

text: Microsoft plans to “disable computers of users who share ‘non-mainstream content’ online.”

claimReview.title: False report claims Microsoft will ‘disable computers’ if users share ‘non-mainstream content’
claimReview.textualRating: False. An article by a website known to publish erroneous content misrepresented an interview with Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella on NBC about artificial intelligence. Nadella discussed how to reduce “unintended consequences” of AI, including misinformation, but made no mention of disabling computers.

text: The longest filibuster in American history was 75 days and occurred in 1964 when Democrats tried to block the Civil Rights Act.

claimReview.title: Post touting longest filibuster gets some facts wrong
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The longest multi-speaker filibuster in the United States Senate was in 1964, but it lasted 60 days, not 75, according to the Senate’s website. Democrats in Southern states led the protest, while Northern Democrats did not support it.

text: A video shows a worker at a voter registration drive in Florida registering people to vote without asking for proof of citizenship.

claimReview.title: Video of Florida voter registration drive used to mislead on proof of citizenship question
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. It’s true workers at the drive did not ask for proof of U.S. citizenship, but that’s because the law does not require such proof to register to vote. However, federal and state law stipulates that Florida voters must be U.S. citizens to cast a ballot in any race. Voters confirm their citizenship under penalty of perjury. Noncitizen voting is exceedingly rare in the U.S. as states, including Florida, have processes to prevent it.

text: There are 133 million registered voters in the United States so if President Donald Trump got 74 million votes, President-elect Joe Biden could not have received 81 million votes.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim there are only 133 million registered voters in the US
claimReview.textualRating: False. The number of registered voters in the U.S. is far greater than 133 million.

text: A post circulating on Facebook says that victims of the wildfire in Paradise, Calif., can go into any Goodwill in the state, show ID and proof that they fled from their home and “the manager at ANY Goodwill will give you blankets, clothes, toiletries and anything you need. Even things for your pets.”

claimReview.title: Only some Goodwill stores are offering wildfire victims free assistance
claimReview.textualRating: Mixture. Only some Goodwills are providing free assistance to victims of the wildfire in Northern California.

text: A federal website shows the U.S. Department of Defense awarded a COVID-19 research contract before the coronavirus had been publicly known.

claimReview.title: No, DOD didn’t contract for COVID research before pandemic
claimReview.textualRating: False. The government initially signed an agreement in late 2019 with a contractor, Black & Veatch, as part of biological threat reduction work in Ukraine, according to officials and documents. After the pandemic began, Black & Veatch hired another firm, Labyrinth Gold Health, to provide expertise for Ukraine’s COVID-19 response. The description of the work in a federal database was updated, but the original agreement date remained.

text: If your coronavirus test comes back positive, it may be because you have a common cold, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

claimReview.title: Having a common cold does not produce a positive test for COVID-19
claimReview.textualRating: False. Posts sharing this claim are mistaking CDC guidance on antibody tests as CDC guidance on tests for the virus. A common cold alone would not result in a positive COVID-19 test.

text: Bull shark sightings have been confirmed in the Great Lakes.

claimReview.title: Bull sharks have not been found in the Great Lakes, despite reports
claimReview.textualRating: False. Bull shark sightings have been confirmed in the Mississippi River as far north as Alton, Illinois, but reports of the sharks being found in the Great Lakes are either hearsay or hoaxes, multiple experts told The Associated Press.

text: Photos show two attackers from fatal Jersey City shooting

claimReview.title: False photos circulate claiming to show attackers from Jersey City shooting
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photos circulating on social media are from a murder case that dates back to August. They don’t show the assailants involved in Tuesday’s Jersey City gunbattle.

text: Every photo of President Joe Biden in the Oval Office is from 2021, proving that Biden uses a staged set and CGI.

claimReview.title: Plenty of proof that Biden has been in the Oval Office in 2022
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Associated Press has photographed Biden in the Oval Office on several occasions in 2022, including during an interview with the AP. Numerous events have also been captured at the Oval Office on video.

text: Photo shows Hurricane Ida evacuations causing gridlock in all directions on Interstate 10 through Louisiana early Saturday.

claimReview.title: Photo shows LA traffic in 2017, not Hurricane Ida evacuation
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image tweeted Aug. 28 claiming to show Louisiana evacuation traffic ahead of Ida’s landfall is actually a photo of traffic on Interstate 405 in Los Angeles over the Thanksgiving holiday in 2017, according to a previous Los Angeles Times article and internet archives of the photo.

text: Video of President Joe Biden was digitally altered to make it appear that he spoke to the press on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington on March 16, and a blurry microphone in the shot proves the video was manipulated.

claimReview.title: Video of Biden with reporters was not digitally altered
claimReview.textualRating: False. Multiple cameras captured the interaction between the president and the press. Video obtained by The Associated Press shows the video in question is authentic. The same video at higher resolution shows the microphone in question was much clearer than it appeared in social media uploads. The AP also took photos of the interaction that captured the microphone in question.

text: Speaking at a Mississippi rally, President Donald Trump mocked a woman who accused Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh of sexual assault

claimReview.title: President Donald Trump mocks Kavanaugh accuser
claimReview.textualRating: True. Trump imitated Ford at a rally in Southaven, Mississippi, on Tuesday.

text: Israeli Ministry of Health data shows that “zero healthy people” under the age of 50 have died of COVID-19 in the country.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Israeli data on COVID-19 deaths in young people
claimReview.textualRating: False. The ministry does not know how many “healthy” people — those without underlying conditions — between the ages of 18 and 49 died of COVID-19 because its data on previous medical conditions is incomplete. However, records show that in Israel the virus has killed at least 356 people in that age group. Information on underlying conditions is available for only 7.5% of those people, zero of whom had any.

text: The Declaration of North America, which President Joe Biden signed on to this month, will strip the U.S. of its sovereignty in order to form a pan-North American government.

claimReview.title: US didn’t sign away sovereignty with North American agreement
claimReview.textualRating: False. The declaration doesn’t impose obligations on the U.S. or change its status as a sovereign country, a foreign policy expert told The Associated Press. It lays out some broad commitments to goals like diversity and sustainability, but is not legally binding. A hypothetical treaty to alter the U.S.’ relationship with Canada and Mexico in such a way would require the Senate’s approval.

text: The CEO of Pfizer was arrested Friday by FBI agents, charged with fraud and was being held in federal custody while awaiting a bail hearing.

claimReview.title: Pfizer CEO was not arrested by the FBI, nor charged with fraud
claimReview.textualRating: False. Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla has not been arrested by federal agents nor has he been charged with fraud. A spokesperson for the company told The Associated Press the allegations are false. Further, Bourla is not listed in federal or local inmate rosters and a search of federal court records did not turn up any fraud cases against him. Bourla has remained active on social media and has made multiple TV appearances over the past several days.

text: The CEO of Pfizer refuses to get the COVID vaccine.

claimReview.title: Pfizer CEO received vaccine, did not refuse it
claimReview.textualRating: False. Albert Bourla, the chair and CEO of Pfizer, received his second vaccine dose on March 10, according to a Pfizer spokesperson and a photo Bourla posted to Twitter showing him receiving the injection.

text: COVID-19 vaccines make people produce a spike protein that is a toxin and can spread to other parts of the body and damage organs.

claimReview.title: Spike protein produced by vaccine not toxic
claimReview.textualRating: False. COVID-19 vaccines instruct the body to produce spike proteins that teach the immune system to combat the spikes on the coronavirus, and experts say these proteins are not toxic.

text: A photo showing a COVID-19 test kit that includes swabs labeled “positive” and “negative” proves tests are manipulated to give a predetermined result.

claimReview.title: Labeled swabs in some COVID test kits are for quality control
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo does not prove the tests are being manipulated. The swabs labeled “positive control” and “negative control” are included in test kits for quality control purposes to make sure the tests work properly. Experts and test manufacturers say the use of such controls are standard for most rapid diagnostic tests.

text: Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden forgot where the camera was and spoke to a screen in front of him instead, during an event in Iowa.

claimReview.title: Biden was facing audience not screen at Iowa event
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden was standing on an elevated stage where he was surrounded on all sides by an audience.

text: Photo shows presidential hopeful Sen. Bernie Sanders shaking hands with a young man and pointing to his T-shirt, which says

claimReview.title: Sanders supporter's T-shirt altered in photo, does not mention 9/11
claimReview.textualRating: False. The gray T-shirt worn by a Sanders supporter has no mention of 9/11. It shows a picture of labor activist Eugene V. Debs, who ran as a Socialist Party candidate for president five times between 1900 and 1920.

text: A photo of a plane underwater shows the wreckage of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has finally been found.

claimReview.title: No, MH370 hasn’t been found, underwater photo is a different plane
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows an old Lockheed Martin L1011 Tristar airplane in the Red Sea. The image comes from a video posted online by the Deep Blue Dive Center, a scuba diving company in Aqaba, Jordan. The Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 that vanished in 2014 remains missing.

text: A new, comprehensive study has found zero cases of Amish children with cancer, diabetes, autism or other serious medical conditions and few deaths from COVID-19 because Amish people don’t get vaccinated.

claimReview.title: No, Amish kids aren’t immune to cancer, diabetes and autism — and they aren’t vaccine-free, either
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s no new research supporting the claims. Experts who study Amish communities say most members have some level of vaccination and that research has shown significant deaths from COVID in the communities. They also say studies have documented cases of autism, diabetes and cancer among the Amish, albeit at lower rates in some cases than the broader population and for reasons that are unrelated to their vaccination status.

text: Social media posts say a man pictured onstage at a 2019 Donald Trump rally is the Minneapolis police officer who was videotaped kneeling on a black man’s neck during an arrest on Monday.

claimReview.title: Officer who kneeled on black man’s neck was not onstage at Minneapolis Trump rally
claimReview.textualRating: False. The man pictured in these posts is Bloomington Police Federation President Mike Gallagher, not Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin.

text: Harriet Tubman said

claimReview.title: False quote on freed slaves wrongly attributed to Harriet Tubman
claimReview.textualRating: False. Harriet Tubman, 19th century abolitionist and Underground Railroad conductor, did not say that she freed a thousand slaves and would have freed a thousand more if only they knew they were slaves.

text: Notre Dame has the state's biggest 'green' roof.

claimReview.title: University of Notre Dame now has the largest green roof in Indiana
claimReview.textualRating: True. Research shows that the University of Notre Dame now has the largest known green roof in Indiana.

text: A photo of a menacing cloud formation hovering over a cornfield was taken Tuesday by the Bonner Springs, Kansas, police department as tornadoes coursed through the region.

claimReview.title: Photo of massive storm cloud not from Bonner Springs, Kansas
claimReview.textualRating: False. A photojournalist captured the photo almost a year ago while covering storms about 200 miles away in the small town of Andale, Kansas.

text: An image shows a 103-year-old bride.

claimReview.title: Image of ‘103-year-old bride’ is AI-generated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image was made using artificial intelligence technology and photo editing software by artist Malik Afegbua, he confirmed to The Associated Press. It was first posted on Afegbua’s Instagram profile with an elaborate backstory that is labeled as “#Fiction.”

text: COVID-19 vaccines have resulted in some people becoming magnetic.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines do not cause magnetism in bodies
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said that COVID-19 vaccines do not contain ingredients that are magnetic and they will not result in a person developing magnetism.

text: Photo shows a newly hired Ugandan police spokesman shooting a catapult toward a news reporter because he asked an irrelevant question.

claimReview.title: Ugandan police spokesman did not use a slingshot to hit a reporter
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows Uganda Police Force Spokesman Fred Enanga aiming, but not shooting, a slingshot in a demonstration for reporters in April 2021. There was no projectile loaded into the weapon.

text: Clinical studies show that Nicki Minaj was correct that COVID-19 vaccines cause testicular swelling.

claimReview.title: Posts erroneously cite 'clinical studies' to back Nicki Minaj’s vaccine claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media posts referencing purported “clinical studies” actually cite data on unverified reports submitted to VAERS, which alone are not evidence that the vaccine is responsible for the events reported.

text: Photo shows Democratic Rep. Rashida Tlaib wearing the “symbol of Hamas terrorists.”

claimReview.title: Michigan congresswoman’s scarf is not a symbol of ‘Hamas terrorists’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Tlaib is wearing a keffiyeh, a checkered scarf that has come to embody Palestinian solidarity. The scarf does not represent the Islamist militant group Hamas.

text: Video of a tsunami wave crashing against a shoreline and hitting buildings as people run for safety shows Turkey’s shore after Monday’s earthquake.

claimReview.title: Indonesia tsunami video misrepresented as Turkey after earthquake
claimReview.textualRating: False. This video was shot during a tsunami in Palu, Indonesia, in September 2018.

text: Video shows Koko, a famous gorilla who learned and communicated with sign language, delivering her “last words to humanity,” which involved saying people needed to “fix,” “help,” and “protect” Earth.

claimReview.title: Video does not show ‘last words’ of gorilla who used sign language
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. This video does not show the gorilla’s final words. It was captured in 2015, three years before Koko died, and was a public service announcement for which the gorilla was provided a script and filmed in several separate takes.

text: Australia has announced plans for mass injections of mRNA vaccines into livestock.

claimReview.title: Australia hasn’t announced ‘mass injections’ of mRNA vaccines for livestock
claimReview.textualRating: False. Officials have announced no such plans and there are no mandatory vaccinations for livestock, the country’s Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry confirmed to The Associated Press. The claim misrepresents an announcement about research into potential mRNA vaccines for animals that could be used if disease outbreaks occur.

text: Video shows left-wing protesters storming Georgia’s Capitol building in Atlanta or engaging in an insurrection over a bill that would require photo ID for absentee voting.

claimReview.title: Left-wing protesters didn’t ‘storm’ Georgia Capitol
claimReview.textualRating: False. The individuals in the video entered the Capitol building lawfully and dispersed peacefully, with no violence or arrests, according to Franka Young, a spokesperson for the Georgia Department of Public Safety. Associated Press reporting confirms that the protest, which took place on Friday, did not amount to a storming of the Capitol or an insurrection.

text: A video shows a technical error causing a digital billboard near New York City’s Times Square to read “Glory to Urine” instead of “Glory to Ukraine” while Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was in town to speak at the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday.

claimReview.title: Video of a billboard near Times Square misspelling ‘Glory to Ukraine’ was fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. No ad related to Ukraine has ever run on the billboard at West 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue, and footage showing otherwise was fabricated, the company that operates the video display told The Associated Press. The footage also does not reflect the current appearance of that corner, so could not have been taken during Zelenskyy’s visit.

text: Video shows a rigged voting machine in Mississippi as a voter clicks the box for Bill Waller Jr. in the Republican primary runoff for governor and the machine switches the vote to Lt. Gov. Tate Reeves.

claimReview.title: Video does not show a rigged voting machine in Mississippi
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a voting machine malfunction in Lafayette County, Mississippi, during the August 27 runoff.

text: Scientists at a laboratory in Tennessee are trying to figure out whether parallel universes exist by attempting to open a portal into another dimension.

claimReview.title: Tennessee lab isn't trying to open parallel universe portal
claimReview.textualRating: False. Scientists at Oak Ridge National Laboratory in eastern Tennessee conducted an experiment in 2019 to study a type of “exotic” neutron behavior, which some news outlets referred to as searching for “portals” to “parallel” realities. But a spokesperson for the lab and the lead researcher told The Associated Press that such descriptions mischaracterize the experiment. The spokesperson said the use of the word “portal” was figurative, and the team “was not exploring a literal portal to a parallel universe.”

text: Governors in many states are suspending alcohol sales around the end of March.

claimReview.title: Prank sites aim to fool with reports of alcohol sales suspension
claimReview.textualRating: False. Posts about the suspension of alcohol sales because of the coronavirus, which have surfaced near April Fools Day, are being fueled by prank generator sites.

text: Photo of a blonde woman holding a French flag above a large crowd shows recent protests in Paris over the government’s latest coronavirus measures.

claimReview.title: French flag photo shows World Cup celebration, not protests
claimReview.textualRating: False. A reverse-image search reveals that the image shows celebrations in Paris in July 2018 after France won the World Cup.

text: The Titanic did not sink. It was switched with one of its sister ships, the Olympic, before it set sail.

claimReview.title: Claims the Titanic was secretly switched with a sister ship are unfounded
claimReview.textualRating: False. Irrefutable evidence exists to prove the Titanic is lying at the bottom of the North Atlantic Ocean, and maritime historians agree it would have been impossible for the Titanic and the Olympic to have been switched.

text: Video shows a Somali gang violently beating and robbing a man, part of a recent wave of violent attacks in downtown Minneapolis.

claimReview.title: Somali gang not responsible for recent attacks in Minneapolis
claimReview.textualRating: False. Minneapolis police have “no indication” that suspects charged in the Aug. 3 attack on a man outside of Target Field, which was captured on surveillance video, are Somali, police spokesman John Elder told The Associated Press.

text: Video captures a child yelling an expletive at Jill Biden as she begins reading a story to a group of students.

claimReview.title: Video of first lady’s book reading manipulated to add child’s comment
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video has been manipulated to insert audio of a child yelling a disparaging comment. A video showing Biden’s full remarks contains no such interruption.

text: Apple CEO Tim Cook fired back a sarcastic tweet after Twitter owner Elon Musk accused the company of limiting advertising on the social media platform.

claimReview.title: Apple CEO didn’t tweet sarcastic reply to Elon Musk
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Twitter reply shown in an image circulating online was originally from a Utah-based social media influencer. The tech YouTuber confirmed to The Associated Press his tweet had been altered to appear as if it was written by Cook in direct response to Musk’s comments on Twitter.

text: President Joe Biden called for people in Florida to prepare for Hurricane Ian by getting vaccinated against COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Biden’s 2021 comments on hurricane preparedness misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are misrepresenting an August 2021 video of Biden discussing preparedness during hurricane season amid the pandemic. In his remarks, Biden urged people in hurricane-prone states to get vaccinated in case they needed to evacuate or stay in a shelter, but he did not suggest vaccines could protect people from hurricanes.

text: Los Angeles police are doing “spot checks” and ticketing people for nonessential travel during the coronavirus epidemic.

claimReview.title: Los Angeles police not giving tickets for nonessential travel
claimReview.textualRating: False. Officials in Los Angeles, Los Angeles County and Santa Monica say no “spot checks” are being conducted to find people violating stay-in-place orders issued to address the spread of COVID-19, and no fines have been issued.

text: New York Judge Juan M. Merchan told former President Donald Trump on the first day of his

claimReview.title: Trump says New York judge won’t let him attend son’s graduation, no ruling has been made
claimReview.textualRating: False. Merchan said on Monday that he was not prepared to rule on a request from Trump’s lawyers that court be adjourned on May 17 so that Trump can attend the ceremony. He said his decision will depend on how the trial proceeds.

text: Documents “confirm Moderna created the Covid-19 virus.”

claimReview.title: Study doesn’t prove that Moderna ‘created’ coronavirus
claimReview.textualRating: False. A study found that a years-old Moderna patent included a genomic sequence that was a "reverse complement" of a small portion of the SARS-CoV-2 genome. Experts say that finding doesn’t say anything about the origin of the coronavirus.

text: Fauci’s sister “Angelique Fauci” published a book on the omicron variant of the coronavirus the same week it was discovered.

claimReview.title: Fauci’s sister did not publish book about the omicron variant
claimReview.textualRating: False. The self-published e-book, which Amazon removed from the website, was not written by Dr. Anthony Fauci’s sister. Fauci, head of the National Institute of Health and Infectious Diseases, only has one sibling. Her name is Denise Scorce.

text: Video shows NATO equipment that was sent to Ukraine.

claimReview.title: Video shows military equipment being returned to US
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows U.S. military equipment in a port in Gdynia, Poland, that’s in the process of being transported back to the U.S., a military spokesman confirmed. None of that equipment is going to Ukraine. The equipment belongs to the 3rd Armored Brigade Combat Team, 1st Cavalry Division, which was in Poland for Operation Atlantic Resolve, a U.S. military mission to support Europe and NATO allies.

text: A photo shows President George W. Bush meeting with Osama bin Laden.

claimReview.title: Osama bin Laden was digitally added to a photo of a post-9/11 Pentagon meeting
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The image was edited to add bin Laden. The original photo, which was taken at a Pentagon meeting the day after 9/11, shows Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz sitting where bin Laden appears in the altered version. Wolfowitz can also be seen in another image taken at the meeting from a different angle.

text: Photo shows President Donald Trump touching the face of a veteran who was “wounded so badly he had no arms.”

claimReview.title: Man greeted by Trump in photo did not lose arms in combat
claimReview.textualRating: False. The man in the photo was born without arms and has been featured in several news articles confirming that.

text: In Wisconsin, 23,000 people registered to vote with the same phone number, and records show 4,000 voters registered on Jan. 1, 1918.

claimReview.title: Posts on Wisconsin voter registration data lack context
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Before Wisconsin implemented its statewide voter registration database and election management system, some municipalities did not require voter registration. Where registration was required, there was no stipulation that phone numbers or registration date be listed. When cities transferred their data into a new statewide system, a default phone number and registration date was used to fill in that information when it was missing.

text: Video shows Democratic vice presidential candidate Kamala Harris committing a crime by campaigning outside a polling place in Cleveland, Ohio.

claimReview.title: Officials say Harris did not violate campaigning laws in Ohio
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ohio law prohibits engaging in any kind of election campaigning within ten feet of any elector in line to vote and within 100 feet of the polling site entrance. Harris did not violate this law, according to election officials.

text: A recent study in the New England Journal of Medicine found that unvaccinated COVID-19 patients remain contagious for less time than those who were vaccinated or had received booster shots.

claimReview.title: Study on COVID vaccination and contagiousness misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: False. The study found no significant overall difference in how long patients with the delta or omicron variants were capable of spreading the virus, regardless of vaccination status, according to two authors of the study.

text: Former President Donald Trump released a statement saying he was told his Twitter account would be restored and congratulating Tesla CEO Elon Musk on his purchase of the social media platform.

claimReview.title: Posts share fabricated Trump statement on Musk’s Twitter purchase
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image of the statement circulating on social media is fabricated, a Trump spokesperson confirmed to The Associated Press. It does not appear as a public statement on the former president’s website or on his official social media accounts.

text: A painting of several children wearing face masks with their countries’ flags on them appeared in 1994 at the Denver International Airport.

claimReview.title: Painting of children with flag masks was never displayed at the Denver airport
claimReview.textualRating: False. The painting does not belong to the Denver airport art collection and has not been displayed there. The image of it began circulating online in February of this year.

text: A video shows tall black fences put up Monday to block access to the Supreme Court building in Washington, an indication of impending “chaos.”

claimReview.title: Video of 8-foot-tall barricades at the Supreme Court is from 2022, not this week
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from May 2022 and shows fencing erected following the leak of a draft opinion that overturned Roe v. Wade. Shorter barriers are present in the area, but the building was open Monday and Tuesday during its usual visiting hours. Aside from people attending public sessions, it is otherwise closed to the public on days when the court convenes, as well as weekends and federal holidays. The building will next be closed on Wednesday for Juneteenth and then on Thursday, when the court is in session.

text: Pfizer admitted to the European Parliament that it had not tested the ability of its COVID-19 vaccine to prevent transmission of the virus before it entered the market, proving the company lied about this earlier in the pandemic.

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on Pfizer COVID vaccine’s impact on transmission
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Janine Small, president of international markets at Pfizer, told the European Parliament on Monday that Pfizer did not know whether its COVID-19 vaccine prevented transmission of the virus before it entered the market in December 2020. But Pfizer never claimed to have studied the issue before the vaccine’s market release.

text: A New York law that aims to crack down on nitrous oxide abuse makes it illegal for anyone under age 21 to purchase a can of whipped cream.

claimReview.title: New York law doesn’t ban minors from buying whipped cream
claimReview.textualRating: False. Customers of any age can legally buy canned whipped cream in New York stores without having to show identification, the bill’s sponsor confirmed to The Associated Press. The 2021 law made it illegal for New York businesses to sell whipped cream chargers — defined in the law as “a steel cylinder or cartridge filled with nitrous oxide” — to people under 21. The law wasn’t intended to apply to store-bought, disposable whipped cream cans, which don’t contain such cartridges.

text: Supreme Court nominee Ketanji Brown Jackson “says she gave pedophiles lighter sentences” because it is different when they use computers instead of mail to get volumes of child porn.

claimReview.title: Posts twist Jackson’s remarks on child porn sentencing
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Jackson was discussing a report by a federal commission, not explaining decisions in specific cases. The commission found in part that sentencing guidelines were outdated because of the ways in which the internet has affected volume.

text: Bill Gates is backing efforts to cut down 70 million acres of trees in order to fight global warming.

claimReview.title: Bill Gates-funded climate change venture doesn’t call for razing 70 million acres of trees
claimReview.textualRating:
False. There is no plan to cut down 70 million acres of trees. The U.S. Forest Service has a ten-year plan to reduce the risk of wildfires across millions of acres of forests in the American West through a combination of controlled burns, selective tree culls and other forest management strategies. Gates, separately, is among the investors in a company proposing to help thin out California's densely packed forests and bury tree remains in Nevada.
List (Page)

text: Only blue items survived the Maui wildfires and lasers do not impact that color, suggesting the island was actually hit by a directed energy weapon “attack.”

claimReview.title: Social media videos push baseless conspiracy theory that blue items were spared from Maui wildfires
claimReview.textualRating: False. The wildfires didn’t spare only blue things, with photos and videos clearly showing buildings and objects of many colors both survived and perished. And while lasers can affect various materials differently, one powerful enough to do such damage would still burn items of any hue, according to an expert. More importantly, there is ample evidence that Maui was ravaged by fires, while the notion that a weapon or laser was involved has been repeatedly debunked.

text: A video shows the earthquake in Turkey rattling ice sheets on a frozen river.

claimReview.title: Video of frozen river filmed in Chicago, not during Turkey quake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was posted on social media in February 2022 and shows a timelapse of intense winds over a frozen river in Chicago.

text: Bernie Sanders tweeted “finally” in response to President Donald Trump’s tweet that he has tested positive for COVID-19 along with the first lady.

claimReview.title: Tweet attributed to Bernie Sanders is from parody account
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet made to appear it came from Sanders’ account was created and shared by a parody account, not by the Vermont senator.

text: New York Senate just passed a bill that would “automatically register illegal immigrants to vote.”

claimReview.title: New York bill does not automatically register non U.S. citizens to vote
claimReview.textualRating: False. The legislation does not change who is eligible to vote, and it clearly states that people who are not U.S. citizens should not be registered.

text: President Donald Trump is cutting the payroll tax, and is cutting Social Security and Medicaid.

claimReview.title: Claims Trump cut Social Security mislead
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Trump has not cut Social Security, though he has said he intends to eliminate the payroll tax, which funds the retirement benefits program. He has proposed measures that would cut Medicaid.

text: The World Health Organization admits that PCR tests to diagnose COVID-19 gave massive false positives, overinflating COVID-19 case numbers.

claimReview.title: WHO did not say PCR test flaw led to overstated COVID-19 cases
claimReview.textualRating: False. A WHO press release is being misrepresented online to say it shows that polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests for COVID-19 caused large scale false positives.

text: Maps show a correlation between confirmed COVID-19 cases and where 5G wireless service has been installed.

claimReview.title: Maps do not show link between coronavirus and 5G wireless
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s no evidence that 5G, fifth generation wireless is related to or causes COVID-19. Both maps simply highlight densely populated parts of the U.S.

text: Video shows Somali pirates approaching U.S. Navy ship.

claimReview.title: Video misrepresents footage of pirates, US Navy training exercises
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The video is a compilation of clips, most of which do not involve the U.S. Navy and pirates together. It begins with footage of pirates approaching a container ship from Singapore in December 2017, an employee aboard the ship confirmed to The Associated Press. The end of the three-minute video briefly shows two separate 2010 still images of U.S. Navy ships after they were involved in destroying suspected pirate vessels. The rest of the video shows unrelated images and footage from various Navy training exercises.

text: An image shows a tweet from the U.K.’s Essex Police announcing that in an effort to increase diversity it is accepting “streamlined” applications from people with the “correct” minority backgrounds.

claimReview.title: Fabricated job ad attributed to Essex Police in UK
claimReview.textualRating: False. The tweet was fabricated, according to a Twitter post created in response by the Essex Police. An overview of the force’s five-year diversity, equality and inclusion strategy states that it hopes to “attract, recruit, progress and retain a more diverse workforce that better reflects our communities.” However, the Essex Police also notes in related materials that such objectives are “not about favouring some people over others.”

text: President Joe Biden first met first lady Jill Biden when she was a teenager who babysat his kids.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim Biden met first lady when she was a teenager
claimReview.textualRating: False. The couple met in 1975, when Jill Biden (then Jill Jacobs) was in her early twenties, according to several news reports and their own social media posts.

text: Bridget Brink, the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, was arrested on charges of high treason.

claimReview.title: The U.S. ambassador to Ukraine was not arrested
claimReview.textualRating: False. The State Department told The Associated Press that Brink has not been arrested. The claim was first made by a website that says that it publishes “humor, parody, and satire” and has previously published similar false stories.

text: Up to 49% of the ingredients in COVID-19 vaccines can be changed without the approval of the Federal Drug Administration because they are still manufactured under emergency use authorization.

claimReview.title: Manufacturers need FDA’s approval to alter COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. As part of the emergency use authorization process for vaccines, the FDA stipulates in letters to manufacturers that “no changes will be implemented to the description of the product, manufacturing process, facilities, or equipment without notification to and concurrence by FDA.” Regardless, the first two doses of the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are FDA approved for adults and some children, and are no longer under emergency use authorizations.

text: Doctors are not taught about vaccines in medical school.

claimReview.title: Yes, medical school students learn about vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Liaison Committee on Medical Education, which accredits medical schools in the U.S. and Canada, told The Associated Press that vaccine education is included in medical school training. The United States Medical Licensing Examination, a three-step exam for medical licensure, also includes topics about vaccines.

text: Video shows an aircraft being shot at in Culiacan, Mexico, during an operation to detain Ovidio Guzman, the son of imprisoned drug lord Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman.

claimReview.title: Clip shows Arma 3 video game, not capture of El Chapo’s son
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video showing an aircraft being fired at is computer-generated and is from the video game Arma 3, a spokesperson for the game confirmed to The Associated Press. Similar scenes of the game can be found posted online.

text: Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador endorsed Democratic candidate Beto O’Rourke for governor of Texas.

claimReview.title: Mexican president hasn’t endorsed in Texas governor’s race
claimReview.textualRating: False. López Obrador criticized an executive order issued by Republican Gov. Greg Abbott, who is running for re-election, but he did not endorse Abbott’s Democratic opponent.

text: Police in Ottawa, the capital city of Canada, are returning fuel they seized from protesters in response to an order from a judge.

claimReview.title: Police weren’t ordered to return fuel to Ottawa protesters
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no court order requiring the police to give back seized fuel, according to a spokesperson for the Ontario Ministry of the Attorney General. The Ottawa Police Service also confirmed that it isn’t returning fuel to protesters.

text: The FBI has cleared President Donald Trump “of any guilt, any connection” to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.

claimReview.title: FBI did not issue statement clearing Trump for Capitol insurrection
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no record of the federal law enforcement agency making such a statement.

text: Social Security Administration data shows the number of voters registering without a photo ID is skyrocketing in three key swing states, evidence that migrants who entered the country illegally are registering to vote in Arizona, Texas and Pennsylvania.

claimReview.title: Federal data does not show a soaring number of unauthorized migrants registering to vote
claimReview.textualRating: False. Election officials in all three states said the information being shared is incorrect. In fact, recent voter registrations in those states are well below the numbers being cited online. The posts are misrepresenting data from the SSA’s Help America Vote Verification system, which tracks requests by states to verify the identity of individuals who registered to vote using the last four digits of their social security number. Only U.S. citizens can vote in federal elections and noncitizen voting is exceedingly rare, as states have processes to prevent it.

text: Cobb County, Georgia election officials improperly destroyed ballots on the morning of Nov. 20.

claimReview.title: Georgia county destroyed election waste, not ballots
claimReview.textualRating: False. Cobb County election officials hired a shredding company to destroy “non-relevant” materials after the election. No ballots or materials relevant to the vote tally were destroyed.

text: A video from 1956 predicted the COVID-19 pandemic and other modern events.

claimReview.title: Video predicting COVID in 1950s is satire from 2020
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is satire and was uploaded to YouTube in February 2020, after the coronavirus had begun to spread widely, the creator of the video confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: A photo shows a Fox News broadcast with a chyron that says

claimReview.title: Fox News did not report that Soros owns the social network Parler
claimReview.textualRating: False. A Fox News spokeswoman confirmed that the image was manipulated.

text: Mail-in ballots were destroyed when a U.S. Postal Service vehicle caught fire in Georgia.

claimReview.title: USPS vehicle fire in Georgia did not destroy ballots: officials
claimReview.textualRating: False. A review found no ballots were in the vehicle when the Jeep caught fire, state officials confirmed. The fire, which is still under investigation, will not impact voting, an official said.

text: Washington, D.C., Mayor Muriel Bowser proposed using her power to remove the Washington Monument and Lincoln Memorial in the wake of George Floyd’s death.

claimReview.title: DC mayor did not propose removing the Washington Monument, Lincoln Memorial
claimReview.textualRating: False. Mayor Bowser’s office confirmed that the mayor did not call for the removal of the Washington Monument or Lincoln Memorial. The monuments are on federal land outside the mayor’s jurisdiction.

text: Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden said if your 8-year-old child wants to be transgender to make life easier, “they have a right to transition and there is no reason for you to deny it.”

claimReview.title: Biden did not say transgender children should be able to ‘transition’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are altering comments made by Biden during an Oct. 15 town hall to falsely suggest he supports sex changing medical procedures for young children. Biden said transgender children should not experience discrimination, but he did not say they “have a right to transition.”

text: Newspaper report shows Democratic candidate Pete Buttigieg was arrested as a teenager in 1998 for killing dogs.

claimReview.title: Newspaper faked to suggest Buttigieg arrested as a teen
claimReview.textualRating: False. A fabricated newspaper article was created to make it appear that Buttigieg had been arrested for killing dogs in the town where he served as mayor.

text: A video shows a child swearing at first lady Jill Biden and telling her to shut up.

claimReview.title: Video edited to show child shouting expletive over Jill Biden’s remarks
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. The video is from a speech the first lady gave on Monday evening to mark the Hindu holiday of Diwali. Audio from a separate video, of a child screaming at a teacher, was dubbed over the end of the Biden clip.

text: The recent cases of monkeypox are actually just shingles, and the cases are a result of the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Monkeypox not related to shingles or COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. Shingles and monkeypox are not the same and are caused by different viruses, experts told The Associated Press. While they both cause rashes with blisters, monkeypox belongs to the same family of viruses as smallpox, and shingles is caused by the herpes virus that causes chickenpox. One website misused a stock photo of a shingles rash in an article about monkeypox, and the story has since been updated to remove the picture. Experts say the vaccine cannot cause monkeypox, as it is spread by exposure to an infected human or an infected animal.

text: When the Republican Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis took office, Florida ranked 26th in the nation for teacher pay. Today the state ranks 9th in teacher pay.

claimReview.title: Florida ranks 48th in teacher pay, not 9th
claimReview.textualRating: False. Florida most recently ranked 48th in the nation in average public school teacher pay, according to the National Education Association, which compiles the data annually. It was ranked 47th when DeSantis took office. The state estimates it will rank 9th in the nation for starting salaries in the 2022-2023 school year, according to the Florida Department of Education.

text: A video shows Klaus Schwab, the founder and chairman of the World Economic Forum, calling for artificial intelligence to replace elections.

claimReview.title: The World Economic Forum’s chairman didn’t call for AI to replace elections
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows Schwab discussing a hypothetical future scenario, not endorsing it. Schwab, speaking with Google co-founder Sergey Brin at the WEF’s annual gathering in Davos, Switzerland in 2017, prefaced the scenario by saying that he has heard “fear” of how “predictive” technology could be used. He then asked Brin whether he could imagine a world in which elections are deemed unnecessary because the outcome can be predicted.

text: A photo of a man in a black hoodie shows Anderson Lee Aldrich, who was identified by police as the gunman in a mass shooting at a gay nightclub in Colorado Springs on Saturday.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Raleigh booking photo as Colorado Springs club shooting suspect
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are misrepresenting a booking photo of Landen Christopher Glass, who earlier Saturday allegedly lost control of a truck pulling a float for a holiday parade in Raleigh, North Carolina, striking and killing a girl participating in the event. The photo was released by the Raleigh Police Department.

text: An ad for British department store Marks & Spencer shows a Palestinian flag burning in a fireplace.

claimReview.title: A Marks & Spencer ad did not feature a burning Palestinian flag
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image shows red, green and silver paper hats — traditionally worn at British Christmas dinners — burning in a fireplace. It’s an outtake from a Christmas commercial filmed in August that was meant to “playfully” illustrate how people don’t enjoy some Christmas traditions, including donning the hats. The commercial was filmed before the start of the latest Israel-Hamas war.

text: A CNBC story on research into technology to combat climate change admitted that “chemtrails” are real.

claimReview.title: CNBC report on climate research didn’t confirm ‘chemtrails’ theory
claimReview.textualRating: False. The story reported on a federal plan to research technology such as “stratospheric aerosol injection,” the concept of placing materials in the atmosphere to reflect sunlight away from Earth. Experts say the idea is being investigated and not currently in use.

text: Hawaii recently passed a law that stipulates no new development can occur in the state unless a “natural disaster” occurs.

claimReview.title: No, Hawaii didn’t pass a law allowing development only in the event of a natural disaster
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Associated Press found no evidence of such a measure being approved in Hawaii. Officials and experts said they had never heard of such a law. The governor recently signed an emergency proclamation to address the state’s affordable housing crisis, but that measure does not concern natural disasters.

text: Photo shows military moms hosted by Melania Trump on Mother’s Day

claimReview.title: Photo does not show event for military mothers hosted by Melania Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo, which circulated on Facebook on Mother’s Day, May 12, is falsely captioned. Melania Trump did not host such an event on that day.

text: A video showing bodies moving after being covered by white cloths is evidence that deaths are being faked by Palestinians and Hamas during the Israel-Hamas war.

claimReview.title: Video from 2013 protest in Cairo misrepresented to falsely claim Palestinians are staging deaths
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from 2013 and shows students protesting at Al-Azhar University in Cairo, Egypt.

text: Video of soldiers rushing into a building with guns shows Russian troops in Ukraine during Russia’s February 2022 invasion.

claimReview.title: Video shows US troops in Iraq, not Russian troops in Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is more than a decade old, and shows American troops at a mosque in Samarra, Iraq.

text: U.S. aid to Ukraine was laundered back to the Democratic Party through the failed cryptocurrency exchange firm FTX.

claimReview.title: Posts spin baseless theory about FTX, Ukraine and Democrats
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Ukrainian government has not invested nor stored money in FTX, according to the country’s Ministry of Digital Transformation. These claims misrepresent a short-term initiative in Ukraine that used FTX to convert cryptocurrency donations for the war effort into government-issued currency. While FTX’s former CEO Sam Bankman-Fried has donated large sums to Democrats, records show he and other FTX executives also have donated to conservative groups.

text: Federal officials are recommending a new shot against

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on clinical trial deaths to suggest new RSV drug for babies isn’t safe
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. A dozen babies out of the thousands involved in the trials did die, many of them months after receiving the drug. But experts say there’s no indication that the drug, delivered by injection, caused the deaths. Many of the babies had existing comorbidities and one death was attributed to a car accident. And in the trials that involved both the drug and a placebo, the rate of death among the two groups was the same.

text: A video shows a bridge collapsing in India’s northeastern Assam state following heavy rains and flooding in May 2022.

claimReview.title: Video shows 2021 Indonesia flood, not recent damage in India
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is being miscaptioned. The footage was widely shared in 2021 and identified as showing a bridge being carried away by floodwaters in Indonesia.

text: President Donald Trump did not put his hand over his heart at the funeral for former President George H.W. Bush.

claimReview.title: Trump did cover his heart with his hand as Bush’s casket passed him
claimReview.textualRating: False. A photo circulating on social media that shows Trump standing with his arms to his sides as Bush’s casket is carried to the front of the National Cathedral was taken after he had dropped his hand from his heart.

text: When a customer elects to donate to charity at a store’s checkout counter, the store can write off that donation on its own end-of-year taxes.

claimReview.title: Stores can’t write off customer donations made at checkout
claimReview.textualRating: False. Stores can’t write off a customer’s point-of-sale donations, because they don’t count as company income, according to tax policy experts. Customers can write off their own donations if they choose. Stores are allowed to write off their own donations, such as when a store donates a certain portion of all its proceeds to charity.

text: Oscar-winning actress Nicole Kidman said in an interview that Donald Trump is the best president in the history of the United States and we must respect him.

claimReview.title: Nicole Kidman did not say Trump is the best president in the history of the US
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence of Kidman saying this. The posts appear to reference a 2017 BBC interview, in which Kidman said Americans should support “who’s ever the president because that’s what the country’s based on.” She later told Access Hollywood she was not endorsing Trump, but stressing that she believed in democracy.

text: Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine contains a DNA sequence called Simian Virus 40 that can cause health problems, including cancer.

claimReview.title: No evidence that DNA sequence used in Pfizer shot leads to cancer and other health issues
claimReview.textualRating: False. No evidence has been found to suggest DNA fragments used in the development of the coronavirus vaccine -- such as a portion of SV40’s DNA sequence -- are causing health problems in people who have received the COVID-19 vaccine.

text: A CNN report from Sept. 11, 2001, is evidence that no airplane debris was found at the site of the Pentagon attack.

claimReview.title: 9/11 news footage on Pentagon attack deceptively edited
claimReview.textualRating: False. The CNN report was deceptively recut to make it seem as though a correspondent at the scene, Jamie McIntyre, said debris from an airplane had not been found. In the real footage, McIntyre says that debris had not been found anywhere except the Pentagon, and describes in detail the parts of the plane that he did see. There is also photographic evidence of airplane debris found at the crash site.

text: CTV News reported that transportation officials in Canada are studying the creation of an “unvaccinated section” at the back of planes.

claimReview.title: Canada hasn’t proposed ‘unvaccinated section’ on planes
claimReview.textualRating: False. The purported screenshot of a CTV News headline was fabricated. Canadian officials say they are not considering such a policy for federally regulated transportation.

text: Video shows people “staging” Ukraine war footage.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent film about Ukraine war
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a behind-the-scenes look at the making of “Nadija,” or “Hope” in English, a feature film about a true story of a pregnant Ukrainian girl who was left alone after her family was killed in the ongoing war after Russia’s invasion. The film was shot in Latvia, not Ukraine. The film’s director posted the clips on TikTok.

text: A video shows a large lightning strike that occurred in Morocco prior to a recent earthquake.

claimReview.title: Footage of a fake alien invasion is being misrepresented as a lightning strike before Morocco quake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was not filmed in Morocco, nor does it show a lightning strike. It was posted in 2020 by a TikTok user who regularly shares special effects content depicting apocalyptic events and shows what appears to be an alien spacecraft attacking a neighborhood in Los Angeles.

text: Congratulations, Dr. Michelle Obama! Since her husband left the White House, and her children are out of the house, Mrs. Obama decided to complete her “PHD in law.”

claimReview.title: Michelle Obama didn’t recently earn a doctorate
claimReview.textualRating: False. Former First Lady Michelle Obama has not earned any new degrees since leaving the White House in 2016.

text: Do not bring down your mask to your chin. Your chin and neck become exposed to the virus. If you wear your mask on your chin, you are contaminating the inside of your mask. When you want to eat, drink or do any activity where you have to remove your mask, remove it completely.

claimReview.title: Post illustrates risks of not wearing masks properly
claimReview.textualRating: True. Wearing your mask around your chin or neck can lead to contamination inside of the mask.

text: Project Veritas captures President Donald Trump on video bashing his supporters.

claimReview.title: Video supposedly showing Trump bashing supporters is voiced by comedian
claimReview.textualRating: False. Conservative website Project Veritas did not upload the video. A parody account created the video. The audio featured in the parody clip belongs to comedian JL Cauvin, who confirmed to the AP that it’s his audio from an episode of Cauvin’s podcast “Making Podcasts Great Again,” where he impersonates Trump.

text: While hospitalized President Donald Trump said, “The doctors said they’ve never seen a body kill the coronavirus like my body. They tested my DNA and it wasn’t DNA. It was USA.”

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Trump’s remarks from Walter Reed
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence Trump made such a statement.

text: A headline states “UN Warns of Massive Refugee Movement from Africa

claimReview.title: Headline saying 500M African refugees headed to Europe is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. A headline made to look as if it were published by the New York Post on March 15 is fabricated. No such headline or related story appears in the news outlet’s online archives, and multiple representatives for the Post confirmed it had not published an article with that information. A spokesperson for the United Nations’ refugee agency also told The Associated Press that it has not issued such a statement.

text: The term “Black Friday” originated with the practice of selling off slaves the day after Thanksgiving.

claimReview.title: How Black Friday became associated with sales
claimReview.textualRating: False. The term was linked to a financial crash in the late 1800s, and in the mid-1900s became associated with shopping the day after Thanksgiving.

text: A drag performer flashed their genitals to children while reading aloud in a Minnesota library.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim drag performer exposed self to children
claimReview.textualRating: False. The performer in this 2019 photograph was wearing several layers of nude tights, said Hennepin County Library Communications Manager Joshua Yetman. “There wasn’t any exposure to children,” Yetman said.

text: The United States military has arrested Dr. Deborah Birx for conspiring with Dr. Anthony Fauci and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to push face masks on Americans during the COVID-19 pandemic.

claimReview.title: US military did not arrest Deborah Birx
claimReview.textualRating: False. Birx, former coordinator of the White House coronavirus response, has not been arrested. This false claim spread as real after appearing on a website known for its satire and parody content.

text: Senator claims Trump administration took $10 million from FEMA to fund ICE

claimReview.title: Senator claims Trump administration took $10 million from FEMA to fund ICE
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. Sen. Jeff Merkley said the Trump administration took $9.8 million from the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s (FEMA) response and recovery operation to fund immigration enforcement.

text: Ukrainians are selling used Russian tanks on eBay.

claimReview.title: Russian military tanks are not being sold on eBay
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image being shared on social media, purporting to show a tank for sale, was fabricated, according to an eBay spokesperson. Further, eBay prohibits the sale of military vehicles.

text: Etienne de Poncins, the French ambassador to Ukraine, recently resigned.

claimReview.title: French ambassador to Ukraine has not resigned
claimReview.textualRating: False. The ambassador and the Embassy of France in Ukraine confirmed that he has not given up his position and remains in Ukraine.

text: A photo shows U.S. District Judge Aileen Cannon in a “Team Trump” hat.

claimReview.title: Photo of Trump supporters does not show federal judge assigned to Trump case
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows two women at a rally for former President Trump in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, on Sept. 3, 2022. The photo was featured in an article about Cannon, but the story did not claim the image was of Cannon.

text: Joe Biden “caught red-handed” using a teleprompter during an interview.

claimReview.title: Biden was answering questions from a television monitor, not using teleprompter
claimReview.textualRating: False. Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden was answering questions from a monitor, not using a teleprompter, during a recent interview on Telemundo, a Spanish-language television network. @TelemundoNews confirmed on Twitter that Biden did not use the teleprompter: “Recent social media posts claiming @JoeBiden used a teleprompter during an interview with Noticias Telemundo and anchor @jdbalart are absolutely FALSE.”

text: Former President Barack Obama’s personal chef, Tafari Campbell, was found dead on the anniversary of Jeffrey Epstein’s death.

claimReview.title: Obamas’ chef wasn’t found dead on the anniversary of Jeffrey Epstein’s suicide
claimReview.textualRating: False. Campbell’s body was recovered from a pond on Martha’s Vineyard on July 24 after he went under water while paddleboarding a day earlier.
