A headline about Epstein in posts circulating online refers to the disgraced financier being found in his jail cell with injuries on July 23, 2019, but Epstein killed himself weeks later. He was pronounced dead on Aug. 10, 2019.

text: Video shows Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden saying the reason he has been able to stay sequestered in his home is because “some Black woman was able to stack the grocery shelf.”

claimReview.title: Video edited to remove context from Biden's comment about Black worker
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The video uses a clip of Biden speaking, but shortens it to make it appear he made a racist statement. In the actual video taken during a Sept. 15 veterans roundtable Biden hosted at Hillsborough Community College in Tampa, Florida, the candidate was making a point about various groups stepping up as essential workers during the coronavirus pandemic.

text: A screenshot from a Fox News report shows Democrats did not attend an April 9 Senate committee hearing on border security.

claimReview.title: Democrats did not miss Senate committee hearing on border security
claimReview.textualRating: False. All six Democrats on the committee were present at the hearing.

text: A television news station revealed results of the Illinois primary the day before the vote took place.

claimReview.title: Illinois news station accidentally airs practice graphics for Tuesday primary
claimReview.textualRating: False. The station, WCIA 3 News in Champaign, Illinois, accidentally aired what appeared to be results from the primary vote for president while rehearsing for Tuesday’s primary.

text: Papaya and ginger are natural birth control options, among other foods and herbs.

claimReview.title: Experts say fruits and herbs not effective at preventing pregnancy
claimReview.textualRating: False. Women’s health experts say there is no legitimacy to those claims.

text: Fox News posts a “fake picture” to show soldiers excited to see Trump in Afghanistan…forgets to take out the Universal Studios sign in the background.

claimReview.title: Photo of troops applauding Trump altered to include film studio sign
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image circulating on Facebook with the false claim was digitally altered to add a sign that makes it appear the photo was staged at the film studio.

text: Photo captured on the surface of Mars shows Earth, Venus and Jupiter lined up in a row in space.

claimReview.title: Supposed image of Earth, Venus and Jupiter from Mars is computer generated
claimReview.textualRating: False. A computer created this image. It was not captured on Mars, a NASA spokesperson confirmed.

text: First marijuana-derived prescription drug will cost $32,500 a year.

claimReview.title: Cannabis-derived prescription drug estimated to cost $32,000 annually
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. Epidiolex, a cannabis-derived drug, is estimated to cost $32,000 a year when made available..The drug used in the study is the first drug comprised of cannabidiol to be approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

text: In a July 20 interview on MSNBC’s “Morning Joe,” House Speaker Nancy Pelosi suggested removing President Donald Trump from the White House using “chemicals,” saying he “has to be fumigated” out.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent Pelosi quotes about Trump leaving White House
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Nancy Pelosi did say that if Trump lost the election, he would be leaving “whether he knows it yet or not,” and she used the word “fumigated” in an aside, but her words are being taken out of context. Pelosi never used the word “chemicals,” nor did she suggest removing Trump from office before the election.

text: Russia has “officially expelled” the World Health Organization and “closed all of its offices in Moscow.”

claimReview.title: Contrary to false claim, Russia hasn’t closed WHO offices
claimReview.textualRating: False. The WHO continues to operate offices in Russia, the organization confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Democrats voted to fine American citizens for not buying health insurance and conspired to give it to “illegal aliens” for free.

claimReview.title: Immigrants in the US illegally are not eligible for free health care under the ACA
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The Affordable Care Act did make U.S. citizens who did not buy insurance pay a penalty, but that is no longer in effect. The law excludes immigrants living in the country without legal permission from receiving tax credits or purchasing insurance on the ACA marketplace, and Democrats are not united in providing free coverage to them. Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden has not supported that proposal.

text: Receiving the COVID-19 vaccine shot makes you more likely to get AIDS or cancer.

claimReview.title: No, COVID-19 vaccines don’t cause HIV, AIDS or cancer
claimReview.textualRating: False. Clinical trials and data from the administration of shots around the world have not shown vaccinated individuals are more susceptible to developing cancer or AIDS. It’s not possible to get HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, from the COVID-19 vaccine because a new needle is used for every injection.

text: A United Nations “chief” said that Christians who don’t support pedophiles will be excluded from society.

claimReview.title: A UN expert did not urge Christians to accept pedophilia
claimReview.textualRating: False. A post by a website that is known to publish misinformation misrepresented a report by Victor Madrigal-Borloz, the U.N.’s independent expert on sexual orientation and gender identity. Madrigal-Borloz said in the report that freedom of religion or belief can coexist with LGBT equality. The report never mentions pedophilia, a disorder that is often falsely associated with the LGBTQ+ community, and Madrigal-Borloz confirmed he has never made such a comment.

text: The BBC tweeted that French President Emmanuel Macron said France needs to be prepared to take up to 60 million refugees from Africa and the Middle East over the next 20 years because sanctions against Russia will cause economic collapse in Africa.

claimReview.title: Fake BBC tweet spreads fabricated Macron quote
claimReview.textualRating: False. This never appeared on a legitimate BBC Twitter account, and it exceeds the number of characters allowed in a tweet. An image purporting to show a screenshot of the post was fabricated. The British broadcaster also confirmed the post wasn’t authentic. Macron has not argued that France, a country of 67 million people, needs to prepare for 60 million refugees.

text: BREAKING

claimReview.title: Pennsylvania counties haven’t done away with mail-in voting
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s no truth to claims that counties in Pennsylvania are doing away with mail-in voting. State law holds that any qualified voter across the state may apply for and vote using a mail-in ballot.

claimReview.title: Michigan didn’t mail 7.7 million ballots to voters
claimReview.textualRating: False. Michigan mailed applications for ballots, not the ballots themselves.

claimReview.title: Nigeria destroyed COVID-19 vaccines because they were expired
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Nigeria destroyed more than 1 million COVID-19 vaccine doses in December because they expired and could not be used.

text: When President Donald Trump was asked to address the Ku Klux Klan, he said “stand back and stand by.”

claimReview.title: Trump said ‘stand back and stand by’ about Proud Boys, not KKK
claimReview.textualRating: False. Trump’s “stand back and stand by” comment during the first presidential debate was directed toward the far-right group the Proud Boys, not the KKK.

text: The Trump administration places a ban on student visas for Nigerians until further notice.

claimReview.title: Trump did not ban student visas for Nigerians
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no such ban on Nigerians wanting to come to the U.S. to study.

text: Melania Trump said, “I wish people would focus on what I do, not what I wear.”

claimReview.title: Melania Trump said, “I wish people would focus on what I do, not what I wear.”
claimReview.textualRating: True. During her recent trip to Africa, the first lady was criticized for wearing an outfit seen as reminiscent of the country’s colonial past.

text: A U.S. Postal Service uniform store was robbed in Tennessee in a scheme to impersonate postal workers and break into homes.

claimReview.title: No reports of postal uniform theft, home invasion scheme: USPS
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. Postal Service’s law enforcement division, which investigates robberies and burglaries of postal facilities, among other crimes, says it has not received any recent reports of such a scheme; nor is it aware of any dedicated uniform stores run by the Postal Service. The police department in a Tennessee community where one social media user claimed the robberies took place also said it had no evidence of such crimes.

text: Photo shows Democratic nominee Joe Biden’s house.

claimReview.title: Property that false post calls ‘Biden’s house’ was sold by him in 1996
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden no longer lives at the DuPont mansion in Wilmington, Delaware, that’s shown in the photo in question. Biden formerly owned the house but sold it in 1996.

text: An Israeli settler knocked down and broke a statue of Jesus in a church in Jerusalem’s Old City.

claimReview.title: American tourist arrested for vandalizing Catholic church in Jerusalem
claimReview.textualRating: False. An American tourist was arrested for allegedly knocking down and breaking the statue, not an Israeli settler, according to Associated Press reporting.

text: A document dated Nov. 4, 2020, shows that election officials in Maricopa County, Arizona, wrongfully accepted 18,000 ballots after election day in 2020.

claimReview.title: Arizona county didn’t accept 18K ballots after 2020 election day
claimReview.textualRating: False. A form used by Maricopa County election officials is being misrepresented as proof that the ballots were accepted after election day. The form is actually a receipt that confirms when early ballots in unopened envelopes — received prior to the deadline on election day — were handed off to a private vendor to be scanned, a spokesperson for the Maricopa County Elections Department told The Associated Press. The CEO of the vendor, Runbeck Election Services, also confirmed the form’s purpose.

text: The Waunakee Community School District in a suburb of Madison, Wisconsin, has a “furry protocol” that allows students who identify as “furries” to opt out of speaking in class, sit and lick their paws during gym class and bark and growl in hallways.

claimReview.title: Wisconsin school district does not have ‘furry protocol’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The district does not have a protocol for students who identify as animals, and it does not allow disruptions at school, according to Superintendent Randy Guttenberg.

text: Mexico is planning to soon eliminate visa requirements for Russian nationals seeking to enter the country.

claimReview.title: Mexico: Visa requirements for Russians haven’t been eliminated
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Mexico’s ambassador to Russia says discussions between the two nations about mutually dropping visa requirements have been ongoing for years, but no agreement has been finalized. Eduardo Villegas Megías, Mexico’s ambassador to Russia, says there’s been no movement in the talks as Mexico remains neutral in Russia’s war in Ukraine.

text: President Joe Biden’s son, Hunter Biden, has been hired to teach a course on “fake news” at Tulane University.

claimReview.title: Hunter Biden is not teaching at Tulane University
claimReview.textualRating: False. The private university in New Orleans has not hired Hunter Biden. The president’s son will appear virtually as a one-time, unpaid guest speaker for a course on media polarization, according to Michael Strecker, the university’s executive director of public relations.

text: Minneapolis has set up a Sharia hotline for residents to report citizens who criticize Islam.

claimReview.title: Minneapolis has not created a 'Sharia' hotline
claimReview.textualRating: False. A hotline for Minneapolis residents allows any resident to report a variety of municipal issues, including potential hate crimes.

text: Former President Barack Obama is the first president to speak out against his successor.

claimReview.title: Obama is not the only president to criticize his successor
claimReview.textualRating: False. Several former presidents have made comments criticizing the policies of their successors, including George W. Bush, Bill Clinton, Jimmy Carter _ even Theodore Roosevelt.

text: Former President Donald Trump won’t be able to vote for himself in the 2024 presidential election because he was convicted in his hush money trial.

claimReview.title: Questions swirl around whether Trump can vote for himself in the 2024 election
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Trump, a Florida resident, will be able to vote in the election if he stays out of prison in New York, as Florida defers to other states’ disenfranchisement rules for residents convicted of out-of-state felonies. New York law only removes the right to vote for people convicted of felonies when they’re incarcerated — once they’re out of prison, their rights are automatically restored, even if they’re on parole.

text: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis is requiring all female student-athletes in the state to provide detailed information about their periods in order to compete in organized sports.

claimReview.title: Florida weighs mandating menstrual cycle details for female athletes
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Florida High School Athletic Association is weighing the recommendation from an advisory committee, but no final decision has been made. DeSantis’ education commissioner is a member of the association’s board of directors and the commissioner also appoints three others, but the association is a private nonprofit organization, not a state agency under the purview of the governor’s office.

text: “NASA just hired 24 theologians to assess how the world would react if we discovered alien life.”

claimReview.title: NASA hasn’t hired theologians to study reaction to alien life
claimReview.textualRating: False. NASA has not hired any theologians to study the potential reaction humans would have to the discovery of alien life. NASA provided some funding in 2015 to the Center of Theological Inquiry in Princeton, New Jersey, for a program to study the potential societal impact of finding life beyond Earth. The NASA-funded portion of the program ended in 2017, an agency spokesperson told The Associated Press.

text: Democratic philanthropist George Soros was a Nazi soldier

claimReview.title: Photo depicting George Soros as Nazi soldier untrue
claimReview.textualRating: False. A photo said to be George Soros as a Nazi soldier is actually a photo of Oskar Groening, a former SS sergeant at Auschwitz Birkenau, the Nazi German concentration and extermination camp, operated from 1940-1945 in Poland.

text: The Republican-led U.S. House of Representatives is giving itself a pay raise even as it proposes slashing federal spending for military veterans.

claimReview.title: Post misrepresents House reimbursement change, spending cuts
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The House is enacting new regulations that were approved during last year’s Democrat-controlled session, which will allow members to expense certain costs such as rent and food while in Washington. It does not increase their base salary, though may result in members receiving more in reimbursements than they previously had. Meanwhile, federal spending cuts approved by House Republicans neither explicitly target nor exclude veterans’ benefits, which the GOP insists will be spared.

text: A woman who claimed to be in a relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin during a “Dr. Phil” episode in 2019 is Tara Reade, the former Senate staffer of Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden who has accused him of sexually assaulting her.

claimReview.title: Tara Reade was not on 'Dr. Phil' talking about Putin in 2019
claimReview.textualRating: False. The woman who appeared on the “Dr. Phil” show was not Tara Reade despite posts online claiming otherwise.

text: Supreme Court nominee Amy Coney Barrett said “making an infant suck on your breasts is a sexual act” and those who breastfeed children should go to prison for child molestation.

claimReview.title: Amy Coney Barrett did not liken breastfeeding to child molestation
claimReview.textualRating: False. This quote did not come from Barrett. An internet search reveals the quote appeared in a Facebook comment that was shared on Reddit and other social media sites in early October.

text: President Barack Obama brought in more than 80,000 Muslims as refugees to Michigan alone.

claimReview.title: Obama did not settle 80,000 Muslim refugees in Michigan
claimReview.textualRating: False. Only 29,062 refugees total were relocated to Michigan during Obama’s eight years in office, according to data from the U.S. Department of State’s Refugee Processing Center.

text: A 44-year-old migrant named Sahil Omar was identified as the suspect of an explosion at a historic hotel in Fort Worth, Texas, on Monday.

claimReview.title: Blast at historic Texas hotel is being investigated as a natural gas explosion, no suspect is being sought
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such suspect is being sought in relation to the explosion, a police spokesperson told The Associated Press. Authorities say the blast “has the characteristics of a natural gas explosion,” but that the cause is still under investigation. The same name and description was used to make a similar erroneous claim about a shooting at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, last month.

text: Video shows a woman from the Pataxo indigenous tribe in Brazil, crying as she points to a fire burning behind her in the Amazon rainforest.

claimReview.title: Video does not show a woman distraught about a fire in the Amazon
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was not taken in the Amazon, and it is not related to the recent fires there. The video was filmed in the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais, southeast of the Amazon.

text: President Joe Biden needed a special medical team at the White House and was taken to the hospital late Sunday.

claimReview.title: False posts claim Biden suffered Easter health emergency at White House
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden was not at the White House on Easter Sunday; he celebrated the holiday at Camp David. Social media users shared a 2019 video clip of White House reporters and falsely claimed that the press was “scrambling” to cover Biden being admitted to the hospital.

text: Students in Ukraine posed in a swastika formation to celebrate Adolf Hitler’s birthday.

claimReview.title: Image doesn’t show Ukrainian children forming hate symbol
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image does not show Ukrainian schoolchildren forming a hate symbol, it shows a group of Russian students arranged in the number “55” to celebrate Cosmonautics Day on April 12, 2016. Footage from a Russian TV broadcast that day shows the group clearly arranged in the number during activities honoring the 55th anniversary of Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin becoming the first person to travel to space.

text: A screenshot shows an email telling employees they must wear a mask during Zoom meetings, in order to make another staff member feel comfortable.

claimReview.title: Email asking staff to wear masks on Zoom is from a satire account
claimReview.textualRating: Satire. The purported email was originally part of a video from a TikTok account labeled as satire, but that context was lost when it was shared to other social media platforms.

text: The man who killed the gunman at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, was an off-duty Border Patrol agent who had a child and spouse inside the school.

claimReview.title: Tactical team, not off-duty agent, killed Uvalde gunman
claimReview.textualRating: False. A U.S. Border Patrol tactical team shot and killed the gunman, according to the Texas Department of Public Safety. While an off-duty agent said he rushed to the scene with a borrowed shotgun, he clarified in televised interviews that he didn’t kill the gunman or go inside the classroom where the shooting took place.

text: U.S. Navy SEALs saved 15 missing Maui children who were locked in cages at a warehouse in Honolulu.

claimReview.title: False claim that Navy SEALs rescued missing Maui children from cages comes from a parody site
claimReview.textualRating: False. This claim originated as a story on a website that says it publishes “humor, parody, and satire.” The chief of police in Maui confirmed the information is untrue.

text: Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates owns the majority of America’s farmland and the investment firm BlackRock holds the majority of single family houses in the country.

claimReview.title: Bill Gates owns a lot of American farmland, but not the majority
claimReview.textualRating: False. The billionaire tech mogul and philanthropist has quietly amassed nearly 270,000 acres of farmland across the country, but that’s still a relatively small slice of the nation’s nearly 900 million total farm acres. BlackRock also does not own the majority of the country’s 80 million single-family homes. U.S. Census Bureau data shows fewer than 20% of such properties are rentals, and the vast majority of those are owned by individual investors, not institutional investors like BlackRock.

text: It is possible to predict earthquakes.

claimReview.title: Scientists cannot predict earthquakes
claimReview.textualRating: False. Earthquakes can’t be predicted, experts say. Scientists do calculate the probability that earthquakes will occur in various regions and early warning systems can detect earthquakes that have already started. But there is no way to accurately predict where and when earthquakes will take place.

text: George Floyd died from a fentanyl overdose, not from the actions of arresting Minneapolis police officers.

claimReview.title: Experts: George Floyd died from knee to neck, not drug overdose
claimReview.textualRating: False. The county medical examiner’s office ruled Floyd’s death a homicide due to “cardiopulmonary arrest,” not an overdose, even though he had fentanyl and methamphetamine in his system. Medical experts at the murder trial for one of the former police officers involved also testified Floyd died of a lack of oxygen from being pinned to the pavement with a knee on his neck, not from drug use. A jury unanimously agreed, finding the former officer guilty of murder and manslaughter.

text: Cameras abruptly shut off during a news conference when President Joe Biden was asked about the recent suicide bombing in Afghanistan and told reporters he gave the attackers a list of the Americans and Afghans still in the country.

claimReview.title: No truth to claim that cameras shut off in Biden news conference
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such incident happened. Biden on Aug. 26 told reporters he couldn’t confirm that any list of names was given to the Taliban, but said it “could very well have happened” in the midst of an evacuation effort. Members of his administration have denied sharing lists of Americans or others with the Taliban.

text: The letters in COVID-19 stand for certificate of vaccination identification and 19 stands for AI, artificial intelligence.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 isn’t an acronym for certificate of vaccination identification
claimReview.textualRating: False. COVID-19 stands for “coronavirus disease 2019,” according to the World Health Organization, which named it in February.

text: Half of Israel’s population now has AIDS, acquired immunodeficiency syndrome, due to receiving multiple COVID-19 vaccine injections.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines aren’t causing AIDS to surge in Israel
claimReview.textualRating: False. COVID-19 vaccines do not cause AIDS, and public health experts say cases of the virus that causes AIDS, human immunodeficiency virus, have not dramatically risen in Israel following mass vaccination.

text: Reports of a gas leak at a Kentucky polling place were an election-rigging tactic to gain more votes for

claimReview.title: A gas leak at a Kentucky polling place fuels false claims of election fraud
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson from Louisville Gas & Electric confirmed there was a legitimate report of a gas leak at a polling place in Jefferson County on Tuesday morning. The leak caused the polls there to close for 30 minutes. A judge extended voting at the location from 6 to 6:30 p.m. Between this location and another where voting was extended for 30 minutes, only one more voter cast a ballot after 6 p.m., according to the county clerk’s office.

text: “Joe Biden fired over 200 marines for refusing to take the COVID vaccine.”

claimReview.title: No, Biden didn’t ‘fire’ more than 200 Marines
claimReview.textualRating: False. As of Dec. 30, 206 Marines have been removed from the Marine Corps for refusing to comply with the Pentagon’s COVID-19 vaccine mandate — but the removals were made by U.S. Marine Corps leadership, not the president, according to a Marine Corps spokesperson. Disciplinary decisions for armed service members are handled by the respective military services, the Marine Corps and the Department of Defense confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Report shows that “Jeff Bezos' 9-minute joyride to the edge of space created more carbon emissions than 1 billion people produce in an entire lifetime.”

claimReview.title: Posts misinterpret space travel carbon emissions finding
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The report stated that an 11-minute trip to space would, per passenger, emit as much carbon as one person emits over their lifetime.

text: Video shows COVID-19 vaccine recipient in Toronto was given a “fake” needle.

claimReview.title: Video of vaccination in Toronto does not show ‘fake’ needle
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users shared a video of a health care worker in Toronto receiving the COVID-19 vaccine with false claims that the needle was “fake” because fluid leaked out while she was being injected. Experts say that it’s common for leakage to happen during an injection.

text: A photo shows a lion Russian President Vladimir Putin released in the streets to keep Russians at home amid the coronavirus pandemic.

claimReview.title: Lion not released on Russian streets to keep people home
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken in 2016 in Johannesburg, South Africa.

text: Photo shows actor Keaunu Reeves stealing a camera from the paparazzi in New York.

claimReview.title: Keanu Reeves did not steal a video camera from the paparazzi
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken during the filming of “Generation Um,” a 2012 movie Reeves starred in.

text: Germany has halted the use of all COVID-19 vaccines because they are unsafe.

claimReview.title: No, Germany hasn’t stopped using COVID-19 vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. Germany continues to use COVID-19 vaccines and is expected to receive updated booster shots that also target omicron strains, according to health officials.

text: Photo shows Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden and his running mate Kamala Harris posing at a table with masks on as several men burn American flags behind them.

claimReview.title: Photo of Biden and Harris posing in front of burning flags is altered
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. Biden and Harris did not pose in front of burning American flags. This is an altered image that blends two unrelated photos that were taken two months apart: one of Biden and Harris sitting at a table for a People magazine feature, and one of people burning American flags at a protest in Arlington, Texas.

text: A video posted on Twitter appears to show an Amazon blimp releasing drones to make deliveries.

claimReview.title: Video falsely shows Amazon blimp releasing delivery drones
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video showing a blimp with the Amazon name and logo dropping drones over Hiroshima Bay near the Japanese island of Itsukushima was fabricated.

text: Video clips show the judge presiding over former President Donald Trump’s fraud case in New York drinking from a bottle of alcohol during court sessions.

claimReview.title: Judge in Trump’s fraud trial was drinking water, not alcohol, as viral videos claim
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The green bottles in the videos match the label and distinctive design of Mountain Valley Spring Water, not Tanqueray gin, as online posts suggest. A court spokesperson and the Arkansas-based bottled water company both confirmed the judge was sipping from a Mountain Valley container.
List (Page)

text: The Arizona secretary of state’s office gave liberal groups exclusive access to online voter registration tools ahead of the 2022 midterm election.

claimReview.title: Arizona voter registration program was provided to all groups that applied
claimReview.textualRating: False. Both Arizona’s Democratic party and Republican party had access to an online voter registration program, as did civic groups. In fact, all organizations who sought to participate in the program, which helps groups register voters online and track registrations, were approved this year, according to the secretary of state’s office.

text: The World Economic Forum has declared that “Jesus is fake news” and “God is dead.”

claimReview.title: WEF never said Jesus is ‘fake news,’ despite claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The organization and its founder, Klaus Schwab, did not make these declarations, as some social media posts suggest. The comments, which are taken out of context, were made by Yuval Noah Harari, an author and historian who has spoken at WEF’s annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland.

text: “Rapid 8 month tested vaccine? Thalidomide was a RAPID APPROVED drug introduced in 1957, to address nausea and insomnia in pregnant women. It was marketed in 50 countries before being withdrawn in 1962 due to malformations in newborns. Be careful with what is coming.”

claimReview.title: Vaccine testing falsely equated with thalidomide development decades ago
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. There are different approval processes for the coronavirus vaccines and the drug thalidomide. Thalidomide was not approved for sale in the U.S. when first introduced in the 1950s. The drug did not undergo extensive trials as is being done with COVID-19 vaccines currently being developed.

text: Britain’s King Charles III ceded the throne to his elder son, Prince William, immediately after the funeral of Queen Elizabeth II.

claimReview.title: King Charles III hasn’t ceded throne to son
claimReview.textualRating: False. King Charles III remains the British monarch, while William is next in line for the throne.

text: Man accused of groping woman claims Trump says it is OK to do that.

claimReview.title: Florida man who groped woman on plane claims Trump said it was OK
claimReview.textualRating: True. A man accused of touching a female passenger’s breast on a flight from Houston to Albuquerque later told authorities that President Donald Trump said it was OK to “grab women by their private parts.”

text: Video shows trash bin blown into the sky by high winds during Storm Eunice in northern Europe.

claimReview.title: Video shows summer storm in east London, not Storm Eunice
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video captures a storm with high winds as it passed through Barking, a town in east London in June 2021.

text: A post circulating on social media states

claimReview.title: Calling 911 with a pizza delivery order not an official way to secretly seek help
claimReview.textualRating: False. Dispatchers are not trained to interpret a takeout pizza order as a covert way of seeking emergency assistance.

text: Video from the surface of Mars includes genuine sounds from the surface of the planet.

claimReview.title: Viral video does not include actual sounds from Mars
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Mars Curiosity rover, which was not equipped with microphones, captured the panoramic photograph that forms the basis for this video. The sound effects were edited into the video, NASA spokesman Andrew Good confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: Zimbabwean man invents electric car that doesn't need charging

claimReview.title: Electric car that doesn't need a charge was not invented by Zimbabwean man
claimReview.textualRating: False. A man from Zimbabwe did not build an electric car that never needs to be charged.

text: Video shows former President Jimmy Carter in 1978 stating

claimReview.title: Edited video distorts Jimmy Carter’s 1978 statement on Taiwan
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. The video is edited to cut Carter’s full statement, removing key context. The president said: “The government of the United States of America acknowledges the Chinese position that there is but one China and Taiwan is part of China.”

text: The plane carrying Germany’s national soccer team, which has a logo stating “Diversity Wins,” was forced to land in Oman because Qatar refused it entry for the 2022 FIFA World Cup.

claimReview.title: Germany’s ‘Diversity Wins’ plane was not denied entry to the World Cup in Qatar
claimReview.textualRating: False. A Lufthansa aircraft featuring the message “Diversity Wins” along with an illustration of people from different ethnic backgrounds has traveled in and out of Doha during the World Cup, according to flight records and a spokesperson for the airline.

text: The same people who criticized how immigrant children were treated under the Trump administration and claimed Trump put “kids in cages” are now okay with the Biden administration doing the same thing.

claimReview.title: Claim of ‘kids in cages’ hypocrisy is missing context
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Biden is reopening a surge facility first opened by Trump for teenagers who arrive at the border without their parents. A different facility, run by the Border Patrol, was a major focus of the “kids in cages” criticism in 2018, largely because the Trump administration held children there in cells partitioned with chain-link fencing after separating them from their parents. That family separation policy is no longer in effect.

text: A photo shows beer cans disguised as Pepsi that were smuggled into Qatar for the World Cup.

claimReview.title: Photo of beer disguised as Pepsi is from Saudi Arabia in 2015, not Qatar
claimReview.textualRating: False. Saudi border authorities shared the photo on social media in November 2015, when a smuggler attempted to pass off 48,000 cans of beer as Pepsi at Saudi Arabia’s border with the United Arab Emirates.

text: Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden’s tax plan will raise capital gains taxes, which means if you sell your home you will be taxed 40% on the profit.

claimReview.title: False claims about Biden's tax plan spread online
claimReview.textualRating: False. Under existing tax law, if you sell your primary residence, you will not be taxed on the first $250,000 in profit you make from the sale, and if you are married, the exemption is up to $500,000. Biden has not proposed changing that. His proposal would increase taxes on capital gains to 39.6% only for those making an income of over $1 million.

text: A video shows a Palestinian “crisis actor” removing his bandages to show his worried mother that his injuries aren’t real.

claimReview.title: No, video doesn’t show a Palestinian ‘crisis actor’ admitting to his mother his injuries are fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. Arabic-language experts and the Palestinian journalist who captured the emotional exchange on video say the injured man and others surrounding him were trying to calm the woman, who believed her son had been mortally wounded in an attack during the Israel-Hamas war.

text: The Amazon rainforest _ “the lungs of the Earth” _ produces 20% of the planet’s oxygen.

claimReview.title: Take a breath: the Amazon does not produce 20% of the world’s oxygen
claimReview.textualRating: False. Scientists say while the Amazon is important to the world’s ecosystem, it does not produce 20% of the world’s oxygen. In fact, the region absorbs about the same amount of oxygen it produces.

text: Dr. Anthony Fauci declared that anyone who is unvaccinated must be put under lockdown this winter.

claimReview.title: Fauci didn’t say that unvaccinated people must be locked down this winter
claimReview.textualRating: False. A website that is known to publish misinformation misrepresented general comments Fauci made about the role of lockdowns during a pandemic during an April 15 interview. Fauci said that while lockdowns have a purpose, they are not a permanent solution. He did not say that anyone, including unvaccinated people, should be locked down in the coming months. Fauci confirmed to The Associated Press that he did not make such a statement.

text: California illegally sends multiple mail-in ballots to voters, and photos of two ballots sent to the same voter prove it.

claimReview.title: Posts mislead about California mail-in ballots
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The two ballots featured in a widely shared photo were sent to the same voter because the person re-registered to vote. The person’s vote was not counted twice, according to a spokesperson for California’s Riverside County. In the rare instance that multiple ballots are sent to one person, California counties have procedures in place to prevent duplicate ballots from being counted.

text: A mug shot circulating on social media shows a serial killer who is currently on the loose and is abducting women after hitting their cars with his truck.

claimReview.title: A viral Facebook hoax is falsely claiming that a serial killer is on the loose in various US cities
claimReview.textualRating: False. This is a viral hoax that has spread in Indiana, Texas, Pennsylvania, Alabama and elsewhere in the U.S. The mug shot is of Jose Gilberto Rodriguez, a man accused of killing three people over four days in the Houston area in 2018 — but he was arrested that year and remains behind bars awaiting trial, officials in Harris County, Texas, confirmed this week.

text: Billionaire philanthropist Bill Gates abruptly pulled out of the 2023 World Economic Forum gathering in Davos, Switzerland.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim Bill Gates withdrew from Davos forum
claimReview.textualRating: False. Gates was never confirmed to attend this year’s forum, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation said in a statement provided to The Associated Press. A spokesperson for the World Economic Forum also confirmed that the claim is false.

text: A video shows Hyperion, the tallest tree in the world.

claimReview.title: Unnamed redwood tree mistaken as the world’s tallest tree
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a different, shorter tree, which is located in Humboldt Redwoods State Park in California. Hyperion — which is the nickname for the coast redwood that is the tallest tree in the world — is located more than 70 miles away in Redwood National Park, according to forestry experts.

text: California recently passed a bill that allows immigrants with work permits to become police officers, firefighters, attorneys and military service members.

claimReview.title: California police bill won’t affect attorneys, firefighters, military members
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. A California law enacted this month removes statewide citizenship requirements for police and corrections officers, but has no effect on job requirements in other fields. There is no statewide requirement that all firefighters be citizens. Aspiring attorneys in the state have been able to pass the bar exam for years without citizenship or permanent legal status. Noncitizens can join the U.S. military but must have a green card, not a work permit.

text: A

claimReview.title: WEF did not appoint McCarthy as House speaker
claimReview.textualRating: False. House members elect the speaker. The page on the WEF website identifies McCarthy as “Majority Leader of the US House of Representatives,” a position he held from 2013 to 2019 and which is different from the speaker role. Such pages are created for people who have attended a WEF event or written a blog published on the WEF website, a spokesperson for the organization told The Associated Press.

claimReview.title: No, Ohio’s new abortion-rights measure doesn’t allow for ‘financial’ exemptions to restrictions
claimReview.textualRating: False. The amendment does not include “financial reasons” as an exemption to the state’s restriction on abortions after a fetus has been deemed viable. Opponents argue that a stated exemption for “health” reasons could be interpreted to include financial considerations. But legal experts say that’s an inaccurate reading of the law, and no court has interpreted “health” that way in an abortion case.

text: A video shows a soldier being thrown to the ground as an airstrike hits an Israeli tank.

claimReview.title: Airstrike scene from a video game is being misrepresented as real footage from the Israel-Hamas war
claimReview.textualRating: False. The imagery is computer generated and was taken from the trailer for a video game called Squad.

text: People are getting Legionnaires' disease from bacteria in masks and the cases are being mistaken for coronavirus, driving the spike in cases.

claimReview.title: Bacteria in masks not causing Legionnaires’ disease
claimReview.textualRating: False. Legionnaires’ disease is a severe form of pneumonia that is caused by inhaling tiny water droplets containing Legionella bacteria. It is not spread person to person, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

text: Photo shows Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky receiving the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Sen. Rand Paul getting a hepatitis A booster shot
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken in February 2015 and shows the Republican senator receiving a hepatitis A booster shot. Paul has not received the COVID-19 vaccine.

text: A list of late-financier Jeffrey Epstein’s clients will be released in January, implicating other high-profile figures in sex crimes for which Epstein was awaiting trial when he died by suicide in 2019.

claimReview.title: Judge ordered release of people named in court documents related to Jeffrey Epstein, not his client list
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. A federal judge on Monday ordered the public disclosure of the identities of 150 people mentioned in court documents related to Epstein, The Associated Press has reported. The individuals named will include sex abuse victims and people with only a passing connection to the scandal, as well as Epstein’s employees and litigation witnesses. Most of the names were already public.

text: Video shows explosions in Beijing in September 2022.

claimReview.title: Video shows 2015 blast in Tianjin, not Beijing in 2022
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was taken in the port city of Tianjin, in northern China on Aug. 12, 2015 during a series of explosions at a chemical warehouse.

text: Congress made an official statement that there is no president-elect as of now which means Joe Biden is falsely claiming to be president-elect.

claimReview.title: Congress did not release a statement saying ‘there is no president-elect’
claimReview.textualRating: False. One congressman wrote a letter where he called on the General Services Administration to “follow the Constitution” and said there was no president-elect, but Congress has not made any official statement on the president-elect.

text: A CNN broadcast displayed a banner stating that a shooter was “factually Arabic, but morally white.”

claimReview.title: Posts recirculate old, altered photo of fake CNN banner
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image has been manipulated to feature fake text. A CNN representative previously confirmed to The Associated Press that the network didn’t broadcast the banner. The altered image, which originated in 2021 as satire following a shooting in Colorado, recirculated on social media after a man took hostages at a synagogue in Texas on Saturday.

text: Video shows bats, rodents and snakes being sold along with live dogs at the Wuhan market where the new virus from China originated.

claimReview.title: Video does not show Wuhan market thought to be ground zero for new virus
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was taken at a market in Indonesia.

text: Democratic U.S. Sen. Kamala Harris once said that if elected president, she would issue an executive order to send police to the homes of anyone who did not surrender their guns.

claimReview.title: Post misrepresents Kamala Harris quote on gun safety laws
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media posts circulating recently don’t accurately convey what Harris said. She said if elected president, she would wait 100 days for Congress to enact reasonable gun safety laws and if they failed to do so, she would take executive action. Harris clarified that her intention was not to confiscate legally owned guns.

text: President Donald Trump went his “entire life with zero sex assault claims” until he ran for president.

claimReview.title: Trump faced sexual assault claim before presidential campaign
claimReview.textualRating: False. At least one woman publicly accused Trump of sexual assault in a 1997 lawsuit.

text: The quote below Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis’ high school yearbook photo reads

claimReview.title: No, Ron DeSantis’ high school yearbook quote does not mention ‘Sir-Mixes-a-Lot’
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image of DeSantis’ entry in his yearbook was edited to add the quote. A spokesperson for the school district that oversees DeSantis’ alma mater confirmed to The Associated Press that the yearbook photo is authentic, but that there is no quote beneath it.

text: Texas Sen. Ted Cruz left his dog alone in a freezing house when his family traveled to Cancun during the statewide emergency.

claimReview.title: Ted Cruz didn’t leave dog unattended during Cancun trip
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The dog didn’t travel with the family, but it was “not left alone and was never in peril,” according to Jessica Skaggs, press secretary for the Republican senator.

text: A video shows a group of people who identify as “trans species” — as animals rather than people — demonstrating in Berlin.

claimReview.title: Video shows fetish festival attendees, not ‘trans species’ rights protestors
claimReview.textualRating: False. The people in the clip were attendees of a fetish festival that was held in Berlin at the beginning of September. They were participating in a gathering related to “puppy play,” a type of roleplaying in which at least one of those involved behaves like a dog.

text: A new study proves 8,000 more ballots were counted than voters who actually voted in Arizona during the 2022 midterm election.

claimReview.title: Study of 2022 Arizona election misrepresented on social media
claimReview.textualRating: False. The study by a pro-Trump think tank only suggested there was a “potential discrepancy” of some 8,000 votes in the election, with some counties reporting more votes than registered voters who cast ballots and others reporting more registered voters who cast ballots than votes counted. Election officials and experts in Arizona also caution that the research is flawed because it doesn’t account for fluctuations in county voter registration figures between Election Day and when the data was obtained, which they said is a more likely reason for any discrepancies.

text: The Canadian government left a dumpster full of rocks for protesters in Ottawa during demonstrations against COVID-19 restrictions.

claimReview.title: Rock-filled dumpster was for construction, not for Ottawa protesters
claimReview.textualRating: False. The dumpster was rented for a construction project that has been ongoing since last year, according to an owner of Mr. Dumpster, the rental company that owns the trash container. It was not rented by the government.

text: A Connecticut bill to change the state’s anti-discrimination laws will lead to pedophiles becoming a protected class.

claimReview.title: Changes to Connecticut’s anti-discrimination laws won’t make pedophiles a protected class
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bill will not change any laws that criminalize acting on pedophilia, nor will it provide pedophiles with protections against discrimination, legal experts told The Associated Press. Its intent, according to the bill’s co-sponsors, is to modernize the definition of “sexual orientation” in Connecticut’s anti-discrimination laws by removing language seen as unnecessary and having offensive connotations. The bill also adds age as a protected class.

text: A video shows the pop singer Shakira’s house being physically moved from her former partner’s property.

claimReview.title: Video doesn’t show Shakira’s home being moved off ex’s land
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a historic home in Plano, Texas, being relocated to save it from demolition in 2018. There’s no evidence to suggest Shakira transported her house in response to her recent breakup.

text: U.S. District Judge Tanya Chutkan, who has

claimReview.title: Trump's judge isn't the only DC justice to give longer-than-requested sentences to Jan. 6 rioters
claimReview.textualRating: False. Although Chutkan is among the toughest punishers of rioters who stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, she is not the only judge who has exceeded recommended sentences in cases related to the attack. Judges Royce Lamberth and Colleen Kollar-Kotelly, for example, are among those who have also handed down harsher sentences, according to Justice Department records.

text: Everyone should ensure that their mouth and throat is moist and never dry. Take sips of water every 15 minutes because even if the virus gets into your mouth by drinking water or liquids, it will wash the virus down through your esophagus and into your stomach where your stomach acid will kill the virus.

claimReview.title: Drinking water won’t prevent the coronavirus
claimReview.textualRating: False. Drinking water prevents dehydration, but it will not prevent anyone from catching the new coronavirus.

text: California lawmakers are weighing a bill that would ban the Bible.

claimReview.title: California lawmakers not proposing to ban Bible, despite claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. A yearsold video being shared on social media discusses a 2018 bill proposed in the California State Assembly that has long been withdrawn and didn’t call for banning the Bible. It would have prohibited the discredited practice known as conversion therapy in the state. Leaders of the Democratic-controlled legislature also confirm there’s no bill currently before state lawmakers proposing to ban the Bible.

text: A video of an explosion near a gas station at night shows a “directed energy weapon” being used to start the wildfires in Maui.

claimReview.title: Old video of Louisiana power line explosion falsely tied to Maui wildfires
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip shows a 2018 explosion of transformers and power lines in Louisiana.

text: A photo shows U.S. Sen. Rand Paul sitting on the Capitol steps in a red bathrobe.

claimReview.title: An AI image of Sen. Rand Paul in a bathrobe is circulating online after Senate drops dress code
claimReview.textualRating:
False. A podcaster and political commentator confirms he created the image using artificial intelligence-generated software.
List (Page)

text: Coca-Cola is making soda cans printed with the phrase “Try to be less white.”

claimReview.title: Coca-Cola isn’t making cans urging people to ‘be less white’
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image of a Coke can being shared on social media has been manipulated to add the phrase “Try to be less white” on the side of the can. The company told The Associated Press that no such labeling has been added to its cans.

text: The COVID-19 vaccines contain HIV.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines don’t contain HIV
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence that any COVID-19 vaccine contains HIV, an expert in infectious diseases and vaccinology told The Associated Press. Experts have repeatedly shot down similar claims in the past, explaining that the vaccines also do not make recipients more susceptible to contracting HIV.

text: A Sept. 9 photo of Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden, Democratic Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, and Democratic Detroit Mayor Mike Duggan without masks at the Detroit Athletic Club in Michigan shows they are flouting mask guidelines during the coronavirus pandemic.

claimReview.title: Photo of Biden, Whitmer, Duggan without masks is from early March
claimReview.textualRating: False. This photo was not taken Sept. 9. It was taken in early March, before Michigan had its first confirmed case of the coronavirus, the Detroit Athletic Club confirmed in a statement.

text: In two recent incidents during flights departing from the Dallas Fort Worth International Airport, American Airlines pilots died from myocarditis caused by the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim vaccinated American Airlines pilots died in flight
claimReview.textualRating: False. These incidents didn’t happen, a spokesperson for American Airlines confirmed in an email to The Associated Press. The claim has circulated widely online after appearing on a satirical website last month.

text: Block of bricks was left for protesters on a street in Frisco, Texas, on the day of a march to demand justice for George Floyd.

claimReview.title: Bricks in Frisco, Texas, left for construction, not protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bricks were left for a construction project in a neighborhood outside where Monday’s protest was being held, and before the day of the march.

text: A video published by USA Today reports that a member of the Ukrainian delegation to the United Nations General Assembly got into a “drunken brawl” on Sept. 21 at The Campbell, a bar in New York City.

claimReview.title: Fabricated video spreads false report that a member of Ukraine’s UN delegation got into a bar fight
claimReview.textualRating: False. USA Today did not make the video, a spokesperson for the news outlet said, and both the bar and the New York City Police Department confirmed that no such incident occurred.

text: Video shows a roof being ripped off of a Naples, Florida, home during Hurricane Ian.

claimReview.title: Video shows 2018 damage from Hurricane Michael, not Ian
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed on Oct. 10, 2018, as Hurricane Michael hammered Panama City Beach, Florida.

text: A sign from the grocery store chain Whole Foods Market asks customers to avoid using gendered language — including terms like brother, ladies and sir — when talking to other customers and employees.

claimReview.title: Whole Foods Market didn’t post sign banning gendered language
claimReview.textualRating: False. This sign appeared in a student-run cafe called Monash Wholefoods at Monash University in Australia. It is not affiliated with the American grocery store chain Whole Foods Market.

text: A photo caption circulating on social media states that “Snapchat filters are a facial recognition database created by the FBI.” For proof, it refers users to “patent US9396354.”

claimReview.title: Snapchat filters were not created by the FBI for a database
claimReview.textualRating: False. Though Snapchat’s photo-altering technology recognizes a face in a photo, it does not use facial recognition to do so.

text: CTV News published an article stating that experts are worried that “conspiracy theorists keep getting things right.”

claimReview.title: Social media users share fake CTV News headline
claimReview.textualRating: False. The post is fabricated. The Canadian media outlet did not publish the article, a spokesperson for the company confirmed.

text: Video shows that Nashville explosion was caused by a missile or some kind of directed energy weapon.

claimReview.title: Nashville explosion caused by bomb, not missile
claimReview.textualRating: False. The explosion was caused by a bomb inside of a parked recreational vehicle in downtown Nashville. Social media users shared grainy surveillance video from the Dec. 25 explosion, and pointed to a streak of smoke to falsely claim that a missile caused the blast.

text: The U.K.’s University of Oxford is considering removing sheet music from its music curriculum as part of sweeping changes intended to “decolonize” the program.

claimReview.title: Oxford University is not scrapping sheet music
claimReview.textualRating: False. There are no plans under consideration to remove sheet music or western musical notation from the music curriculum at Oxford University. The music faculty are planning to add new offerings to the curriculum to be announced in the coming months, a representative from the university said.

text: Banners from the HBO series “House of the Dragon” are hanging from the Brooklyn and Manhattan bridges.

claimReview.title: Banners from HBO’s ‘House of the Dragon’ are not flying on New York bridges as videos online suggest
claimReview.textualRating: False. There are no banners hanging from either bridge, an Associated Press reporter who went to the area Monday confirmed. Videos spreading online that show the New York landmarks adorned with “House of the Dragon” banners circulated in the runup to the start of the second season of the “Game of Thrones” prequel. A spokesperson for the New York City Department of Transportation told the AP that the agency is “not aware” of any such banners.

text: The dress Melania Trump wore during Fourth of July celebrations featured drawings by various victims of child sex trafficking.

claimReview.title: Melania Trump’s dress did not feature drawings by child sex trafficking victims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The sketches on the dress were made by art students in a class, not by victims of sex trafficking.

text: Italy discovers through autopsies that COVID-19 is “not a virus, but a bacterium,” which clots the blood. COVID-19 can “easily” be treated with aspirin and blood thinning medicine.

claimReview.title: False claims circulate around Italian COVID-19 study
claimReview.textualRating: False. Posts circulating on social media misrepresent information from an Italian study of people who died of COVID-19. The study, which examined 100 autopsies, referred to COVID-19 as a virus, not bacterium. COVID-19 does not respond to antibiotics, and anticoagulants can’t treat the infection. Blood clotting is a complication that can happen in patients infected with COVID-19.

text: The FDA is meeting on Oct. 26 to discuss mandating vaccines for kids.

claimReview.title: FDA to discuss COVID vaccine authorization -- not mandates -- for children 5 to 11
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration Vaccines and Related Biological Products Advisory Committee is meeting on Oct. 26 to discuss Pfizer’s application requesting emergency use authorization for its COVID-19 vaccine shots for children 5 to 11 years old. The FDA does not have the authority to mandate vaccinations.

text: President Bill Clinton passed a law in 1996 that separates parents and children entering the U.S. illegally and President Barack Obama enforced that law. Now, President Donald Trump is being demonized for enforcing it.

claimReview.title: Clinton did not create a law separating families at the border
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no law that requires parents and children to be separated if they are entering the country illegally. Thousands of children were separated from their families after passing into the country illegally last year as a result of a temporary zero-tolerance policy under the Trump administration.

text: A packaging insert provided with the diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis vaccine shows it causes sudden infant death syndrome, or SIDS.

claimReview.title: Studies show no direct link between DTaP vaccine and SIDS
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says multiple studies over decades have found no causal link between childhood immunizations and SIDS. At least one federally approved vaccine for diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis, or DTaP, does list SIDS among a host of other potential adverse reactions on its packaging insert. But the drug maker and experts say the list includes voluntary reports of adverse medical events experienced by people after receiving the vaccine, which have not all been proven to be correlated to the immunization.

text: A stagnant glass of water seen in videos of Chinese astronauts proves the footage wasn’t actually filmed in space.

claimReview.title: Video of water in a glass on China’s space station is scientifically sound, not proof of ‘deception’
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say the footage is consistent with how water behaves in zero gravity, and there is no reason to doubt China’s presence in space. Other videos show one of the astronauts carefully putting the water in the glass using a container with a straw, as well as strips that adhere the glass to the table.

text: A video of a road shaking as cars bounce and people struggle to stay on their feet, and another of someone fleeing a supermarket aisle as products come crashing down, were both taken during the recent earthquake in Turkey.

claimReview.title: Old videos of Nepal and Trinidad quakes misrepresented as Turkey
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip of the street shows an earthquake in Nepal in 2015, while the supermarket footage was taken in Trinidad and has been online since August 2018.

text: California is registering noncitizens to vote.

claimReview.title: Noncitizens not eligible to register to vote in California
claimReview.textualRating: False. Voter registration in California is restricted to U.S. citizens who are state residents and at least 18 years old on Election Day. While one city, San Francisco, does allow noncitizen parents to vote in local school board races, those voters go through a separate registration process and the policy doesn't allow them to vote in any other elections.

text: Russian President Vladimir Putin didn’t attend the Orthodox Easter service in Moscow on Sunday.

claimReview.title: Putin did attend 2022 Orthodox Easter service
claimReview.textualRating: False. An Associated Press photographer was at the service and captured pictures of Putin at the event.

text: Disney shareholders are in a “panic” after losing $2.4 billion in one day.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent satirical article about Disney stock price
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim stems from a website that publishes satirical content. While The Walt Disney Co.’s stock price has dropped recently, and the company’s market valuation went down by several billion dollars some days last week, financial experts told The Associated Press that the fluctuations were normal for a multi-billion dollar company and not cause for panic.

text: Scenes from the Maui wildfires show cars and buildings badly damaged near trees and poles that remain standing, suggesting a wildfire wasn’t the cause.

claimReview.title: Trees and poles standing amid Maui fire wreckage aren’t unusual, contrary to conspiracy theories
claimReview.textualRating: False. Such observations from the fires on the Hawaiian island are not unusual, experts say. Wildfires often spew fiery embers that hit larger targets like homes and cars. Trees that catch fire are typically not completely vaporized, in part because of their water content.

text: A photo shows 700,000 migrants heading to the U.S.-Mexico border as pandemic-related asylum restrictions are set to expire.

claimReview.title: Photo of 2018 migrant caravan falsely shared online as current
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is being misrepresented. It was taken in 2018 and shows a migrant caravan making its way into Mexico from Guatemala, on its way to the U.S.

text: A video shows an ABC News billboard ad in New York City in which a pro-Ukraine message is replaced by a pro-Israel one.

claimReview.title: Video showing a pro-Israel ABC News billboard in NYC is fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video has been altered. The company that manages the billboard confirms that the display featured no such message. The billboard currently shows an ad for the upcoming Trolls movie.

text: Bill Gates’ former doctor says the vaccine advocate refused to vaccinate his own children.

claimReview.title: Bill Gates did not refuse to vaccinate his children
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Microsoft founder and billionaire philanthropist has had all his children fully vaccinated.

text: President Joe Biden’s initiative for a door-to-door campaign to encourage vaccination for COVID-19 is a violation of the federal law that restricts the release of medical information.

claimReview.title: Knocking on doors to promote vaccines doesn’t violate health privacy law
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden pitched a door-knocking campaign as a way to get vaccine information and assistance to more people, not probe Americans about whether they have been vaccinated. But even if officials or volunteers did ask people that question, it wouldn’t be a violation of federal health privacy laws, according to experts.

text: A video of camels in the middle of a snowstorm shows Saudi Arabia’s first snowfall in 100 years.

claimReview.title: Camel video does not show Saudi Arabia’s first snowfall in a century
claimReview.textualRating: False. Snow falls in Saudi Arabia every year or two, typically in the country’s northern regions at high elevations, a meteorologist told The Associated Press. The video was first posted online in 2021 by a nature photographer in northwest Saudi Arabia.

text: Local officials in Centre County, Pennsylvania, found ballots inside drop boxes before the boxes were opened for use in the midterm elections, which is proof of election manipulation.

claimReview.title: Pennsylvania drop boxes not preloaded with ballots
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Officials in Centre County found a total of 18 ballots that had been dropped off in three separate boxes prior to the official start time for their use, the county said in a statement. However, the county attributed the presence of the ballots to voters who did not follow instructions on when they could be submitted. A Pennsylvania Department of State spokesperson told The Associated Press that there is no evidence that points to fraud and election experts agree that such an incident does not suggest foul play.

text: Dr. Anthony Fauci said on CNN that COVID-19 vaccines will protect you 94-95% against clinically recognizable disease and almost 100% against severe disease, but did not say the vaccine will protect against COVID.

claimReview.title: Video misrepresents Fauci’s comments on vaccine effectiveness
claimReview.textualRating: False. A review of Fauci’s comments on CNN captured in the video show he was referring to vaccines protecting against clinically recognizable and severe cases of COVID-19.

text: During live CNN election coverage of the California recall election on Sept. 14, more than 350,000 votes to recall California Gov. Gavin Newsom suddenly disappeared.

claimReview.title: Human error caused TV networks to briefly air wrong CA recall vote tally
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Edison Research, the polling firm that provides election data to CNN, said a data reporting error by one of its staffers caused false vote totals to briefly appear on a live CNN broadcast. The error was fixed within two minutes.

text: Billionaire philanthropist George Soros owns Smartmatic voting machines. Don’t throw your vote away if you live in a state that uses them. Ask for a paper ballot. Under federal law the polling place must provide one.

claimReview.title: Soros does not own voting machine company Smartmatics
claimReview.textualRating: False. Soros, who donates to liberal political causes, does not own Smartmatic, a company that specializes in voting technology.

text: The FBI only relied on the word of a cybersecurity firm, CrowdStrike, to determine that Russia hacked the emails of the Democratic National Committee.

claimReview.title: FBI reviewed cybersecurity firm’s evidence in 2016 DNC election hack
claimReview.textualRating: False. CrowdStrike provided forensic evidence and analysis for the FBI to review during its investigation into a 2016 hack of DNC emails.

text: Fox News has announced former Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Donna Brazile will replace host Tucker Carlson on his prime-time show, Tucker Carlson Tonight.

claimReview.title: Fox News not replacing Tucker Carlson with Donna Brazile
claimReview.textualRating: False. Fox News has not tapped Brazile to replace Carlson on his show, a spokesperson for the TV network confirmed.

text: Donald Trump’s Hollywood Walk of Fame behind bars

claimReview.title: President Trump's star behind bars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. A Los Angeles-based artist installed prison bars on top of Trump’s Hollywood Walk of Fame star.

text: The BBC interviewed a “crisis actor” who pretended to be hospitalized with COVID-19 during a news segment.

claimReview.title: No, the BBC didn’t interview a ‘crisis actor’ in a news report
claimReview.textualRating: False. The person who was interviewed during the July BBC segment was a patient hospitalized with COVID-19 at King's College Hospital in London, not an actor, representatives for the BBC and the hospital confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: There is currently no FDA-approved vial of COVID-19 vaccine available in the U.S.

claimReview.title: Pfizer vaccine approved in US, marketed as Comirnaty
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Pfizer vaccine, which is now marketed as Comirnaty, is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for use by those 16 and over and is available in the U.S.

text: A Texas law requires the state education agency to provide DNA kits for students so their bodies can be identified after a school shooting.

claimReview.title: Texas student DNA kit law not prompted by school shootings
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. While the 2021 law requires the agency to provide in-home fingerprint and DNA identification kits to all school districts, it specifies that the intent is for parents to request and use them to help locate their child in the event they go missing. The law makes no mention of school shootings. Both the sponsor of the state Senate bill and the Texas Education Agency confirmed the legislation was not a response to school shootings.

text: People may be more susceptible to serious COVID-19 illness after they have been vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Post makes false claim about COVID-19 vaccine risk
claimReview.textualRating: False. Research has shown that the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines have been proven to be 95% effective in preventing COVID-19 illness. Experts say there is “abundant” evidence that people who get shots will not become more sick should they later get the virus.

text: A virologist at Johns Hopkins Hospital named Dr. James Kelly wrote a post that questions COVID-19 vaccines and mandates.

claimReview.title: Johns Hopkins doctor didn’t author post critiquing COVID vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no doctor at the hospital by that name. The text has previously circulated with different, vague attributions.

text: Newly signed legislation in Tennessee “banned Plan B and made it a crime punishable by a $50,000 fine to order it.”

claimReview.title: New Tennessee abortion pill law doesn’t ban Plan B
claimReview.textualRating: False. The law imposes strict penalties for distributing abortion pills via mail or delivery services and also bars pharmacists from dispensing the drugs. It still allows doctors to provide the medicine in person. The law does not ban Plan B or emergency contraceptives used to reduce the risk of pregnancy after sex.

text: An image shows CNN aired a chyron that said “Elon Musk could threaten free speech on Twitter by literally allowing people to speak freely.”

claimReview.title: Image of CNN report about Elon Musk came from parody site
claimReview.textualRating: False. CNN aired no such report about Musk “threatening free speech,” and the chyron was digitally altered to add the text. The image purporting to be from a CNN broadcast originated on a satirical website.

text: The man accused of throwing a boy over a balcony at the Mall of America was born with a Muslim name, but later changed it to Emmanuel Aranda.

claimReview.title: Man charged with throwing boy off Minnesota mall balcony did not change his name
claimReview.textualRating: False. The man charged in the case was born Emmanuel Aranda, according to Cook County birth records.

text: Data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that 99% of deaths attributed to COVID-19 were actually caused by something else.

claimReview.title: CDC data does not show that 99% of COVID-19 deaths were due to other causes
claimReview.textualRating: False. The percentage misrepresents CDC data. The agency’s most recent numbers show that for the week ending Aug. 19, 1.7% of all deaths in the U.S. were due to COVID-19.

text: Vaccines developed for COVID-19 contain a cancer-causing virus DNA found in monkeys.

claimReview.title: No, ‘monkey virus DNA’ was not found in COVID vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: False. Public health officials and the lead researcher of a study cited in many of the social media posts say there’s no monkey virus DNA in the inoculations approved by government regulators. Some COVID-19 vaccines utilize DNA molecules derived from Simian Virus 40, but that’s not the same as the virus itself and the molecules aren’t cancer-causing.

text: Wearing a mask can cause hypercapnia, and lead viruses to travel into the brain.

claimReview.title: False health claims circulate about wearing masks during pandemic
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s no evidence that wearing a mask causes hypercapnia, or that masks can trap the virus and lead to an infection in the brain. Hypercapnia occurs when there is too much carbon dioxide in the bloodstream. Mild cases can lead to issues such as headache and anxiety; severe cases can interfere with breathing.

text: Pope Francis says, “I am the devil,” reveals satanic leanings

claimReview.title: Pope says 'I am the devil'
claimReview.textualRating: It’s a mixture. Pope Francis did quip recently that he is the devil compared to St. John Paul II, but nothing he said revealed "satanic leanings.”

text: All funeral services in the U.K. have been canceled on Sept. 19, the day Queen Elizabeth II is set to be buried.

claimReview.title: UK didn’t cancel all funerals on same day as queen’s service
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The U.K. government’s declaration of a public holiday on Sept. 19 to mark the queen’s funeral does not force businesses to close, nor has there been a countrywide cancellation order for private funerals. While some families are opting to postpone or reschedule services on Monday, and some businesses providing funeral or crematorial services may close that day, many funerals are expected to proceed, multiple industry groups confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: 61% - That’s the new tax rate many Georgians will live with if the Democratic tax plan passes.

claimReview.title: Most Georgians won’t pay 61 percent tax rate under proposed Democratic tax plan
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Many won’t see their taxes go up drastically under the Democratic tax plan because Biden has vowed only to directly raise taxes on those making $400,000 or more _ less than 2% of U.S. households.

text: A video on Kelly Clarkson’s Instagram page shows the singer promoting weight-loss gummies.

claimReview.title: Bogus social media ad uses an edited video of Kelly Clarkson to sell weight-loss gummies
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. A clip and comments promoting the release of Clarkson’s latest album on her real Instagram account in June have been edited to add fake promotions for the diet product. Clarkson’s publicist told The Associated Press that the performer is not a spokesperson for any weight loss products or programs.

text: Video shows Dutch firefighters standing on their trucks as the lights flash and sirens blare, displaying solidarity with farmers who are protesting new environmental regulations in the country.

claimReview.title: Video of firetrucks shows fundraising event in Poland, not Dutch protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a convoy of firetrucks in Poland at an annual charity event to raise funds for medical treatments. It was filmed in the county of Krosno on May 21, 2022.

text: Blue Cross Blue Shield pays doctors a $40,000 bonus for administering childhood immunizations to at least 100 patients under 2 years old and an $80,000 bonus for vaccinating 200 children.

claimReview.title: Posts exaggerate insurance incentives for child vaccinations
claimReview.textualRating: False. Blue Cross Blue Shield Association is a national federation of more than three dozen locally operated companies, and doesn’t offer such an incentive across the board, the group confirmed. Every company can set its own performance-based incentives, and while vaccinations may be one category, that wouldn’t be the only measure taken into account, multiple experts agreed. The numbers being cited were incorrectly estimated based on data included in a 2016 incentive program for a Michigan Blue Cross Blue Shield plan, and actual payouts that year were well under $40,000.

text: Video shows Joe Biden's speech is impaired as he makes a “shocking admission.”

claimReview.title: Altered video misleads on content, style of Biden speech
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was slowed down and manipulated in other ways, and Democratic presidential candidate Biden did not make any sort of admission. Rather, he was referencing comments made about him by President Donald Trump.

text: The “Barbie” movie raised more money in one day than Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis has his entire life.

claimReview.title: ‘Barbie’ is a hit. But it didn’t make more money in a day than Ron DeSantis has ever raised
claimReview.textualRating: False. “Barbie” brought in about $48.2 million in North American theaters on its July 21 opening, plus another $22.3 million in early screenings the night before. DeSantis has raised more than that during his decade of political campaigns for Congress, Florida governor and now president.

text: Yavapai and Gila counties in Arizona are delaying the certification of their midterm election results.

claimReview.title: Arizona’s Yavapai and Gila counties are not halting election certification
