claimReview.textualRating: False. Gila County certified its results on Nov. 18, while Yavapai County plans to do so on Nov. 28, county officials tell The Associated Press. Two other Arizona counties delayed certifying their election results.

text: A mugshot shows that the suspect in the

claimReview.title: Incorrect photo of Maine shooting suspect spreads online
claimReview.textualRating: False. The post confuses two people named Robert Card. The person identified online using an incorrect mugshot is Robert W. Card, who was 32 years old when arrested in 2016 and charged with possession of sexually explicit material. Police in Lewiston, Maine, shared a photo of Robert R. Card, a 40-year-old U.S. Army reservist from Bowdoin, in connection with the mass shooting Wednesday night.

text: Helicopters are being used to spray disinfectant over neighborhoods to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Helicopters not spraying disinfectant over neighborhoods to stop virus
claimReview.textualRating: False. Officials have called the claim false and dangerous to spread. The false claim has also been knocked down in other countries as it circulated on social media around the globe as the virus spread.

text: COVID-19 tests cause cancer because they are sterilized with ethylene oxide.

claimReview.title: False cancer claim circulates around COVID-19 test
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ethylene oxide is a gas commonly used to sterilize medical equipment. It is also used in the sterilization of spices and cosmetics. While it is listed by federal agencies as a carcinogen with long-term exposure, experts say the gas is used only in small amounts to sterilize COVID testing kits and would not present cancer hazard.

text: Photo is said to show California wildfires from above the clouds.

claimReview.title: Aerial photo of clouds not of California wildfire
claimReview.textualRating: False. A photo of a blanket of gray clouds over a glowing red background was not taken over the fires ravaging California.

text: Public service announcement warns of a white supremacist who has been shooting at black people at traffic lights. He drives a white truck and was last seen in Mesa, Arizona.

claimReview.title: No evidence of gunman targeting black people at traffic lights in Arizona
claimReview.textualRating: False. State and local officials have not issued an announcement warning of a gunman targeting motorists in the state and no such shootings have been reported in Mesa, surrounding cities or other parts of Arizona, local and state police told The Associated Press. Organizations that track violence by white supremacists also had received no information about any such attacks.

text: Footage shows video from a camera mounted on a Ukrainian drone as it fires at and ultimately sinks multiple Russian warships at sea near Odesa during daylight hours.

claimReview.title: Clip shows video game, not Ukraine attacking Russian navy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage is computer generated, and shows gameplay from the video game Arma 3, a spokesperson for the company that makes the game confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: President Joe Biden stated that he attended a historically Black college.

claimReview.title: Biden launched early campaign from historically Black college
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Democratic president said he “got my start” at one of the nation’s historically Black colleges and universities, or HBCUs, at a recent campaign event. But he didn’t say he attended one. For years, Biden has mentioned launching his first campaign for Congress at Delaware State University, a historically Black college. A spokesperson for the university confirmed Biden announced his 1972 run for Senate on campus.

text: President Barack Obama skipped Memorial Day ceremonies at Arlington National Cemetery in 2010 to vacation and attend a BBQ in Chicago.

claimReview.title: Obama did not opt for a Memorial Day BBQ over a visit to Arlington National Cemetery in 2010
claimReview.textualRating: False. Obama attended Memorial Day services at a military cemetery in Illinois in 2010. He did not attend a barbecue that day as claims circulating on Facebook state.

text: Home pregnancy tests contain Plan B pills.

claimReview.title: Plan B pills are not hidden in home pregnancy tests
claimReview.textualRating: False. The small discs found inside home pregnancy tests are desiccant tablets used to absorb moisture, not emergency contraceptive medication.

text: A Sept. 10 CNN story reports that members of the Crips, a known street gang in Los Angeles, volunteered to fight wildfires after the sky turned red.

claimReview.title: LA gang did not volunteer to fight wildfires
claimReview.textualRating: False. The story was created as satire. The byline and time stamp are pulled from a real, unrelated CNN story, and the content is made up. A CNN spokesperson confirmed the image is fabricated.

text: President Joe Biden’s administration introduced a door-to-door campaign to offer COVID-19 vaccines as a way to confiscate guns or Bibles.

claimReview.title: Online reports mislead on vaccination door-knocking efforts
claimReview.textualRating: False. The door-to-door vaccination initiative aids states to enlist local officials and volunteers to provide information about COVID-19 vaccines as well as shots in areas where people haven’t yet been vaccinated.

text: Florida’s ability to report election results quickly during the 2022 midterms means states that have taken longer, such as Arizona and Nevada, are engaged in fraud.

claimReview.title: States report election results at different speeds
claimReview.textualRating: False. Because U.S. elections are highly decentralized, each state has different methods for counting votes. Florida has measures in place, such as pre-processing of ballots, early reporting requirements for results and a shorter period to fix ballot issues, to speed up its count on Election Day, while other states have their own set of regulations. The fact that Florida reports results faster than other states does not mean that those states are committing fraud or that their results are less reliable, elections experts told The Associated Press.

text: A stroke can be stopped by pricking the fingers of the person showing symptoms.

claimReview.title: Pricking a person's fingers will not stop a stroke
claimReview.textualRating: False. An expert on strokes says the best thing someone can do for a person showing signs of a stroke is call 911 and get the person to a hospital.

text: Canadian government agency Shared Services Canada sent a memo to employees banning them from using the phrase “Let's Go Brandon" or risk being fired “without recourse or labor union participation.”

claimReview.title: Purported Canadian memo about anti-Biden phrase is fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The memo, which purports to ban employees from referencing a meme popular among critics of President Joe Biden, was fabricated. Shared Services Canada confirmed to The Associated Press that the letter being shared online did not come from the agency and does not reflect existing policies.

text: Sex offenders are not required to carry cards identifying them as sex offenders because it is an invasion of their privacy.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim sex offenders don’t carry card for privacy reasons
claimReview.textualRating: False. Several states require registered sex offenders to carry special identification, and when states have rejected such laws, it has been based on the First Amendment, not privacy.

text: President Joe Biden called Donald Trump the “future president.”

claimReview.title: Post misleads on Biden’s reference to rival Trump
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Biden was speaking on Thursday about a disagreement he had with Trump and referred to him as “the former president and maybe future president,” immediately saying “bless me, Father,” before acknowledging he was “kidding.”

text: A phone number on the back of Texas driver’s licenses provides free state-run roadside assistance funded by taxpayers.

claimReview.title: Hotline connects Texas drivers to tow services, but they aren’t free
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The number, known as the Texas Department of Public Safety’s Motorists Helpline, does connect drivers to roadside assistance services, but its towing services are not free, according to DPS.

text: A video of a robot abruptly collapsing to the ground while stacking boxes shows the robot used its judgment from artificial intelligence to deactivate itself after 15 minutes of manual labor.

claimReview.title: Robot in popular video didn’t deactivate itself
claimReview.textualRating: False. The robot fell a couple of times during more than 20 hours of demonstrations over four days, according to Agility Robotics, the company that manufactured it. As a computer that follows a program, it didn’t deactivate itself and doesn’t have human intent, the company clarified.

text: In an August letter, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi encouraged Portland, Oregon, Mayor Ted Wheeler to adhere to the Democratic playbook and blame President Donald Trump in response to riots and protests taking place in the city following the death of George Floyd.

claimReview.title: Letter from Pelosi to mayor of Portland, Oregon, was fabricated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The letter was fabricated.

text: Walgreens employees can refuse to sell customers contraceptives such as condoms if doing so conflicts with their religious beliefs.

claimReview.title: Posts about Walgreens contraceptive policy lack context
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Walgreens' policy is that employees can decline to complete a customer’s transaction if they have religious or moral objections to the sale, but they must then hand it off to a co-worker or manager who can finish the transaction, a spokesperson for the pharmacy chain told The Associated Press.

text: Former President Donald Trump has won two-thirds of 2020 election lawsuits that have been adjudicated by the courts.

claimReview.title: Skewed data fuel questionable claim on Trump election lawsuits
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The claim is based on a tally that does not include several lawsuits filed by Trump or his supporters that were dismissed by the courts or withdrawn by plaintiffs. It also includes many cases filed months before the Nov. 3 election, as well as some cases that do not directly relate to the presidential election. In about 60 lawsuits Trump’s legal team and Republican allies filed since the election, only one resulted in a small victory in Pennsylvania. None of the cases has proven the presence of fraud in the 2020 election.

text: Video shows Mount Sinabung eruption on the island of Sumatra in Indonesia on June 9.

claimReview.title: Video does not show volcanic eruption in Indonesia
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is an educational simulation made with 3D technology.

text: ABC News published an altered photo of the Uvalde, Texas, elementary school gunman in which his skin was lightened and his facial features were changed.

claimReview.title: ABC didn’t publish altered photo of Texas school shooter
claimReview.textualRating: False. ABC News did not publish the altered image of the gunman. A spokesperson for the news organization confirmed to The Associated Press that the manipulated photo is being falsely attributed to the broadcaster.

text: CNN cut short its primetime town hall with former President Donald Trump on Wednesday.

claimReview.title: No, CNN’s Trump town hall was not cut short, it actually ran overtime
claimReview.textualRating: False. The cable news network says it had allotted one hour for the forum but it ended up running about 10 minutes longer. The New Hampshire college that hosted the event also confirmed the expected runtime for the event was an hour, not the nearly two hours that some claimed online.

text: The federal government gives people who enter the U.S. illegally a cell phone, a domestic plane ticket to a location of their choosing and a $5,000 Visa gift card.

claimReview.title: US Senate candidate spreads false claims about migrant aid
claimReview.textualRating: False. People who enter the U.S. illegally do not receive such assistance from the federal government, immigration experts told The Associated Press. Immigration and Customs Enforcement gives some immigrants phones, but they can only access a monitoring app called SmartLink. Those who cross the border illegally do not receive gift cards. And although limited federal aid can help get migrants where they intend to go, they typically must choose from a set list of destinations and are usually transported by bus, not planes.

text: WSMV-TV Nashville tweeted that the father of a victim of Monday’s Nashville school shooting called for “an end to tolerance” and “the end of the trans evil.”

claimReview.title: Nashville outlet did not tweet victim’s father calling for ‘end to tolerance’
claimReview.textualRating: False. WSMV-TV, an NBC affiliate in Nashville, Tennessee, did not report that claim and an image purporting to show such a tweet from the outlet is fabricated, the outlet confirmed to The Associated Press. No news outlet has publically reported that quote from any victim’s family member.

text: U.S. Supreme Court Justice Amy Coney Barrett cited a need for a "domestic supply of infants" in a leaked draft opinion for a decision that would overturn Roe v. Wade.

claimReview.title: Posts misattribute CDC quote in Supreme Court draft on abortion
claimReview.textualRating: False. The draft opinion was written by Justice Samuel Alito, and the term appears in a footnote quoting a 2008 document about adoption data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The footnote appears in a section of the opinion where Alito points to so-called “safe haven” laws, which allow parents to relinquish a baby at a safe location without criminal consequences. Barrett had made a similar comment about the laws during arguments in the case last year.

text: Yemen has declared war against Israel.

claimReview.title: Yemen hasn’t declared war on Israel, contrary to online claims. Houthi rebels have launched missiles
claimReview.textualRating: False. Yemen’s internationally recognized government has not declared war on Israel. Houthi rebels that control the country’s capital launched missiles at Israeli targets this week and threatened further attacks. But experts say the Iran-backed militia stopped short of declaring an all-out war against the Jewish state.

text: Video shows rainbow flag with the text, “FOR MORE TOP SECRET NUCLEAR DOCUMENTS RAID HERE” hanging from Trump Tower in New York City.

claimReview.title: Video altered to show rainbow banner at Trump Tower
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. The original video, which was published in July 2020 by The Associated Press, showed the installation of a “Black Lives Matter” mural on the street outside of Trump Tower. The video was altered to feature the fake banner and shared by a Twitter user who routinely shares manipulated video content as satire.

text: A video shows the motivational speaker and psychologist Umar Johnson giving an interview on the Fox News program “Tucker Carlson Tonight” that renders host Tucker Carlson speechless.

claimReview.title: Clip of Fox host is altered to add motivational speaker
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. This video was edited to add a clip of Johnson to an old episode of Carlson’s show. In the February 2021 episode, Carlson was interviewing a congressman, not Johnson. A Fox News spokeswoman confirmed the clip was fake.

text: President Donald Trump walked into North Korea by himself, without Secret Service or military protection.

claimReview.title: Trump didn’t walk into North Korea without security
claimReview.textualRating: False. Special Agent in Charge Anthony Ornato accompanied Trump into North Korea as he met with Kim Jong Un, the country’s leader.

text: There were 205,000 more votes than voters in the 2020 election in Pennsylvania.

claimReview.title: There were not more votes than voters in Pennsylvania
claimReview.textualRating: False. This analysis is based on incomplete data, according to the Pennsylvania Department of State.

text: When Vice President Kamala Harris and President Joe Biden were competing against each other in the 2020 presidential race, Harris told Biden in a debate, “You will do whatever the Chinese tell you! They gave your son over a billion dollars.”

claimReview.title: Harris didn’t accuse Biden of bending to China in debate
claimReview.textualRating: False. Transcripts of the five Democratic debates attended by both Biden and Harris show no such exchange. Harris did challenge Biden on other topics during the debates, including race.

text: Photo shows David DePape, the man accused of

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Pelosi attack suspect filming Jan. 6 insurrection
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo, published by The Associated Press, shows DePape recording a wedding outside San Francisco City Hall on Dec. 19, 2013.

text: President Donald Trump separated 1,900 children from their parents at the border while President Barack Obama separated 89,000 children.

claimReview.title: Trump separated more migrant families at the border than Obama
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Trump administration has acknowledged that at least 2,700 children were separated from their parents last year when a zero-tolerance policy was established in response to a massive increase in migrants arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border. The Obama administration did not have a similar policy.

text: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis called in the National Guard to block all entrances to Disney World.

claimReview.title: DeSantis didn’t order National Guard to Disney World, claim is satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim stems from a satirical article. Spokespeople for DeSantis and the National Guard confirmed to The Associated Press that the military force has not been dispatched to the House of Mouse.

text: An official government poster from Ireland’s Health Products Regulatory Authority says sudden death is a side effect of the COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Irish agency says poster listing ‘death’ as COVID vaccine side effect is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The poster is a fake and was not sent out by the Health Products Regulatory Authority.

text: “VAERS listed 4,941 miscarriages post-COVID vaccine. For comparison, the fetal death reports for all other vaccines reported to VAERS in the last 30 years is 2,239. But no worries, the COVID vaccine is safe and effective for everyone.”

claimReview.title: VAERS data distorted to falsely link vaccines and miscarriage
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. COVID-19 vaccines have not been linked to pregnancy loss, as this post implies. The post attributes its miscarriage data to the Vaccine Adverse Events Reporting System, a database from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration where individuals can submit unverified reports of health outcomes after vaccination. But VAERS data does not prove a vaccine caused any side effects, and an Associated Press review of data in that system did not return the same numbers.

text: A map shows what scientists say the United States will look like in 30 years if climate change isn’t addressed.

claimReview.title: Map shows Mediterranean Sea on U.S., not climate change impact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The map, which features much of the country’s interior under water, shows the Mediterranean Sea on top of the U.S. and was intended to compare their relative sizes, according to its creator.

text: Locked mailboxes in front of a post office in Burbank, California, are proof that massive voter suppression is underway ahead of the election.

claimReview.title: Locks on post office drop boxes meant to deter theft
claimReview.textualRating: False. The boxes were locked to prevent theft, postal officials said.

text: An Illinois high school will implement a “race-based grading system” for the next school year.

claimReview.title: Illinois high school didn’t adopt ‘race-based’ grading system
claimReview.textualRating: False. The school has adopted no such policy and said in a statement that it has no plans to do so. The school’s board gave a presentation on May 26 mentioning “equitable grading” practices, which value whether a student has mastered academic content. Some districts have sought such alternative approaches to eliminate bias from grading systems.

text: Photo showing a Vietnam veterans memorial wall marked with graffiti depicts recent vandalism by Black Lives Matter protesters.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show memorial defaced by Black Lives Matter protesters
claimReview.textualRating: False. This photo of a mural in Los Angeles to honor missing Vietnam veterans shows vandalism that occurred in 2016. That year, the mural was defaced by taggers, including a man named Angel Castro, who was sentenced to four years in prison for the crime, according to reporting by The Associated Press.

text: Jennifer Lopez told Time that she will perform a Whitney Houston tribute at the 2023 Grammy Awards, saying Houston’s songs “fit my vocal range very well.”

claimReview.title: Claim that J.Lo announced Whitney Houston Grammy tribute is false
claimReview.textualRating: False. A spokesperson for Lopez confirmed this conversation didn’t happen, and there is no report matching this description on Time’s website.

text: FEMA proposes “martial law to contain coronavirus”

claimReview.title: FEMA has not proposed martial law to contain virus outbreak
claimReview.textualRating: False. Officials with the Federal Emergency Management Agency confirmed that there are no plans to enact martial law in the U.S.

text: Republicans in several battleground states put up their own sets of electors for President Donald Trump. This sets the stage for dueling slates of electors on Jan. 6, where Vice President Mike Pence decides whether to accept or reject them.

claimReview.title: ‘Alternate’ electors won’t change presidential outcome
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Republicans in a handful of battleground states are trying to appoint themselves as “alternate electors” who cast votes for Trump, but their votes aren’t official, and their competing slates won’t deny President-elect Joe Biden the presidency. Pence’s role on Jan. 6 is to open and tally electoral college votes, not decide whether or not they are valid.

text: Reuters reported that U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi recently purchased 10 million shares in a cannabis company.

claimReview.title: Hoax tweet spreads false claim of Pelosi buying cannabis stocks
claimReview.textualRating: False. Reuters never published such a report. Additionally, financial disclosures show no record of Pelosi making such a stock purchase, and a spokesperson for the California congresswoman’s office confirmed she has not.

text: The $6 billion in aid President Joe Biden is seeking for Ukraine would have been enough to fund former President Donald Trump’s entire southern border wall project.

claimReview.title: Posts make false comparisons between Ukraine aid, border wall funding
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Biden administration last week told congressional aides it was seeking at least $6.4 billion in supplemental funding to help Ukraine amid Russia’s ongoing invasion, and has since upped the sum, asking for $10 billion. Still, the amount is well below the price tag for the border wall proposed by Trump. By 2021 his administration said it had secured about $15 billion for the border project.

text: Johns Hopkins University research shows that someone can “be vaccinated with a PCR swab test without knowing.”

claimReview.title: Posts distort research details to suggest secret vaccine campaign
claimReview.textualRating: False. Researchers developed tiny devices for potentially delivering drugs, but the technology was not tested or used with vaccines — or delivered through PCR swab tests. The technology has not been approved for use in humans.

text: New coronavirus variants are as contagious as the measles virus, according to a measure of infectiousness known as “R0.”

claimReview.title: Comparisons between new COVID variants and measles are misleading
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. While the new strains, BA.4 and BA.5, are more infectious than prior variants, the claim is based on a flawed calculation. The supposed R0 value circulating on social media came from an article by Adrian Esterman, an Australian epidemiologist and biostatistician, who told The Associated Press he now realizes his figure is “unlikely to be correct.” Experts say it would be difficult to accurately calculate the variants’ infectiousness using R0, let alone compare it to other viruses, as the measure is only applicable to populations with no exposure to a virus, and doesn’t account for prior infection or vaccination.

text: A photo of a child crouching and holding their head in rubble was taken in the aftermath of the earthquake that struck Turkey and Syria Monday.

claimReview.title: Stock photo of child misrepresented online as quake aftermath
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo is a stock image taken in 2018 in Ukraine.

text: Rep. Matt Gaetz had a $482,321 loan from the Small Business Administration’s Paycheck Protection Program forgiven even though he doesn’t own a company.

claimReview.title: Company where Gaetz owned shares had pandemic loan forgiven
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Caregivers Inc., a private at-home care company in Florida, had the loan forgiven. Gaetz reported in 2021 that he was a shareholder in the company, making him a partial owner. The company has sold and he no longer owns shares, his office said in an emailed statement.

text: Video shows sanitation trucks surrounding Madison Square in New York to protect Trump from booing protesters

claimReview.title: Sanitation trucks at NYC Veterans Day parade were not to protect Trump from booing
claimReview.textualRating: False. The sanitation trucks were for security purposes, and are often used during events drawing in large crowds in New York.

text: Photo of empty grocery shelves shows impact of President Joe Biden’s “Build Back Better” policies.

claimReview.title: Photo of bare grocery shelves show impact of winter storm, not ‘Build Back Better’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken during the winter storm in Houston, Texas, in February.

text: A state-by-state report of excess votes for President Joe Biden in the 2020 election suggests there was election fraud and affirms that former President Donald Trump actually won seven key states that were called for Biden.

claimReview.title: Report claiming ‘excess’ Biden votes doesn’t show fraud
claimReview.textualRating: False. This report, which bases its claims on assumptions related to voting and registration trends, provides no proof of fraud. Political scientists who spoke to The Associated Press confirmed that conclusions of likely fraud do not follow from the data.

text: Researchers used lung tissue from an aborted male fetus in the creation of COVID-19 AstraZeneca vaccine.

claimReview.title: Lung tissue from aborted fetus not used in AstraZeneca vaccine development
claimReview.textualRating: False. AstraZeneca did not use MRC-5 cells, which were cells first obtained from the lungs of a 14-week male fetus in the 1960s, in its production process for the COVID-19 vaccine.

text: Pfizer has been delisted from the New York Stock Exchange.

claimReview.title: Pfizer’s stock has not been removed from the NYSE
claimReview.textualRating: False. Drug maker Pfizer Inc. has not been removed from the NYSE, where it was trading on Tuesday under the symbol “PFE.”A company spokesperson also confirmed that the stock remains listed. Social media users are misrepresenting the delisting of a debt security issued by Pfizer.

text: Black tour buses wrapped with “Black Lives Matter” were seen in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, bringing in Black Lives Matter and antifa rioters for protests.

claimReview.title: Tour buses were transporting Toronto Raptors, not protesters
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photos being shared show tour buses that have not moved from the bus yard in Fort Lauderdale since they were wrapped for the Toronto Raptors basketball team on July 9.

text: A recent image shows former U.S. President Donald Trump looking very overweight and unhealthy.

claimReview.title: Image altered to make Trump look heavier, older
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. This photo has been manipulated to make the former president’s face and neck appear wider than they are and to make his wrinkles more pronounced. The original image, an Associated Press photo, shows Trump with a slimmer face.

text: Country singer Garth Brooks was “booed off stage” at the “123rd Annual Texas Country Jamboree.”

claimReview.title: A story about Garth Brooks getting ‘booed off stage’ was made up. It duped the Texas governor
claimReview.textualRating: False. That claim was published by a website that labels its work as satire, but shared online by others as factual.

text: A photo from this week shows House Speaker Nancy Pelosi huddled with other members of Congress and none are wearing masks.

claimReview.title: Photo of House members meeting without masks taken before virus outbreak
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken in December before the first known case of coronavirus was reported in the U.S.

text: George Floyd’s younger brother Dejywan Floyd was arrested for murder in North Carolina.

claimReview.title: North Carolina murder suspect falsely tied to George Floyd
claimReview.textualRating: False. George Floyd, who died while being handcuffed and pinned to the ground by Minneapolis police, does not have a younger brother named Dejywan. Robeson County sheriff, Burnis Wilkins, in North Carolina said he is aware of no connection between the suspect and George Floyd, noting that the last name “Floyd” is common in the area.

text: A video shows flooding that

claimReview.title: Old footage from Saudi Arabia misrepresented as scenes of devastating flooding from Libya
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The video has been online since April 2016 and shows flood waters pouring through a dry river valley in a mountainous region of Saudi Arabia at the time.
List (Page)

text: Singer R. Kelly sentenced to 104 years in prison.

claimReview.title: R. Kelly has yet to be sentenced
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 52-year-old singer, who is in federal custody, hasn’t been sentenced. Kelly is facing a series of sexual misconduct charges in state and federal cases in Illinois, New York and Minnesota.

text: Photo shows a gas station charging $9 per gallon in California.

claimReview.title: Northern California gas station didn’t charge $9 for gas
claimReview.textualRating: False. A store manager at the gas station — which is actually located just south of Sacramento in Stockton, California — said dollar amounts over $9 were briefly displayed on its sign on March 3 after a new pricing device was installed. But customers were not charged that price.

text: A new California law makes it illegal for someone to remove a condom after sex without their partner's permission.

claimReview.title: Post shares incorrect interpretation of California ‘stealthing’ law
claimReview.textualRating: False. A California law passed Oct. 7 makes it illegal to remove a condom without permission during intercourse, but not after. A spokesperson for the bill’s lead author told The Associated Press the law does not apply to removing a condom once the sexual act is over.

text: The Daily Mail, a tabloid newspaper in the U.K., published a 2017 front page with a headline that criticized prominent

claimReview.title: Manipulated Daily Mail front page spreads online
claimReview.textualRating: Altered image. The image that is circulating online is a doctored version of an authentic Daily Mail front page from that year. The original front page did not feature photos of Johnson or Farage, and its headline criticized U.K. officials for allegedly betraying voters who supported the 2016 Brexit referendum.

text: A video taken in Florida shows a helicopter releasing genetically modified mosquitoes that are part of an initiative backed by Bill Gates.

claimReview.title: No, a video does not show a helicopter dropping mosquitoes in Florida
claimReview.textualRating: False. While mosquitoes are being released in Florida as part of a disease-control initiative, they are freed slowly from boxes on the ground, not from a helicopter. And as The Associated Press reported previously, the work is not funded locally by Gates. The substance coming from the chopper appears to be smoke, and several helicopter charter companies that specialize in gender-reveal celebration agree it looks like the announcement of a baby boy.

text: Dr. Anthony Fauci, in a recent science paper, admits that COVID-19 vaccines don’t work.

claimReview.title: Fauci: recent paper doesn’t suggest COVID vaccines ineffective
claimReview.textualRating: False. The scientific journal article doesn’t say the vaccines don’t work. The article’s authors say their paper acknowledges current vaccines for respiratory viruses don’t prevent all infections, but that they do prevent the most serious symptoms. Fauci and another coauthor said the article makes the case for exploring new approaches to make respiratory virus vaccines more effective.

text: A video shows a giant crocodile in a lake in Maine.

claimReview.title: Video shows animatronic puppet, not a real crocodile
claimReview.textualRating: False. The crocodile in the video is not real. It is a 30-foot animatronic puppet created by special effects company Stan Winston Studio for the fictional 1999 horror film “Lake Placid,” Matt Winston, co-founder of the Stan Winston School of Character Arts, told The Associated Press. The video, which shows the studio testing the robotic reptile, was also shot in California, not Maine, Winston said.

text: There was fraud in California’s recall election because voters were given Sharpie pens or other permanent markers, which is illegal and will invalidate ballots.

claimReview.title: False claims about Sharpie pens bubble up again around California recall
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no California law that dictates what kind of pen can be used on a ballot. Marking a ballot with a Sharpie pen won’t invalidate your vote, according to Jenna Dresner, spokesperson for California’s Office of Election Cybersecurity, and Sharpies are actually recommended for use with some voting systems since they are quick drying. If a voting tabulation system can’t discern what a voter marked, election workers manually determine voter intent.

text: The World Economic Forum has declared “pedophiles will save humanity” and is calling for the decriminalization of sex with children because laws that prevent it “violate human rights.”

claimReview.title: Fabricated WEF story published by site known for false news
claimReview.textualRating: False. These claims originated on a website that is known to publish false news and misinformation. The WEF has not made any such declaration, nor is it calling for the decriminalization of sex between adults and children, according to a spokesperson for the WEF, who said the article was “completely made up.”

text: District of Columbia Mayor Muriel Bowser has paved over the “Black Lives Matter” street mural that was near the White House.

claimReview.title: Black Lives Matter Plaza mural to be repainted this week
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Black Lives Matter Plaza was repaved as part of planned improvement projects by Potomac Electric Power Co., the local utility company. The mural will be repainted this week, according to a spokesperson for the mayor’s office.

text: Two photographs show dolphins caught high above the water in Hurricane Dorian’s winds.

claimReview.title: Photographs do not show airborne dolphins in the midst of Hurricane Dorian
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photos were manipulated to add an image of a dolphin. They were published by a satire site.

text: A study published in The Lancet proves that COVID-19 mRNA vaccines are increasing people’s chances of contracting the disease after seven months, providing further evidence that people should not get vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Florida surgeon general misleads on vaccines’ value
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. The observational study out of Qatar found that people who received a booster shot with the original vaccine formulation had overall lower rates of infection than those with only two doses over the course of a year. It also found those who were boosted were 75% less likely to experience severe COVID-19. The report did find higher infection rates among the boosted specifically after seven months, but outside experts said the study doesn’t doesn’t prove the vaccines are biologically increasing recipients’ risk of infection.

text: A BBC graphic that cites health officials advises that monkeypox is a “form of herpes,” travels in the air over distances of up to 15 feet and lasts two to four months.

claimReview.title: Image falsely attributes monkeypox claims to BBC, health officials
claimReview.textualRating: False. The BBC confirmed it did not make the graphic, and health officials and experts say the claims it conveys are wrong or scientifically unsupported.

text: As of Jan, 1, 2024, T-Mobile is going to fine individual consumers for texting about topics that fall under the categories of sex, hate, alcohol, firearms or tobacco.

claimReview.title: No, T-Mobile isn’t going to start policing customers’ personal texts
claimReview.textualRating: False. The wireless carrier is instituting new fines for third-party vendors that send mass messaging campaigns on behalf of other businesses, not for individual consumers. These fines apply to texts that discuss sex, hate, alcohol, firearms or tobacco under certain circumstances, such as if the content violates federal law or is sent without an age verification system.

text: Video shows performers portraying COVID-19 victims in body bags for a staged news report.

claimReview.title: Video does not show staging of COVID victims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a behind-the-scenes look at the filming of a music video by Russian rapper Husky.

text: The CEO of The Walt Disney Company has been arrested for human trafficking in California.

claimReview.title: Posts spread false claim about Disney CEO
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no record of any such arrest related to Bob Chapek, the company’s CEO, in federal databases, nor with authorities whose jurisdiction covers his Southern California residence. The claim was first shared by a conservative blog that labels some of its content as “satire.”

text: Recently unsealed court documents show a list of defendants, including some celebrities, named as “co-conspirators” in Ghislaine Maxwell’s criminal case.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely conflate civil lawsuit with Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case
claimReview.textualRating: False. The list of defendants is from a since-dismissed civil lawsuit that is separate from Maxwell’s upcoming criminal trial. The civil suit was filed against the estate of late disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein and dozens of additional defendants in August 2020 by a plaintiff who alleged a group of celebrities, corporations and others were involved with Epstein in a human trafficking enterprise. The suit was dismissed as frivolous in September 2020, according to documents obtained by The Associated Press.

text: CDC warns that non-N95 masks will do nothing to protect you from wildfire smoke because “they do not catch small particles.” Smoke particles are larger than those of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, so masks do not work.

claimReview.title: Cloth masks do not stop smoke particles, still effective against COVID-19
claimReview.textualRating: False. Cloth and surgical masks are designed to prevent the spread of the coronavirus by catching respiratory droplets coming from the person wearing the mask. Respiratory droplets are larger than smoke particles.

text: The German newspaper Deutsche Welle, or DW, published a report about recent protests in which thousands of people gathered to kiss each other in opposition to COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: News report on anti-vaccine kissing protests is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image circulating on social media claiming to show the article is doctored, and an accompanying photo of couples kissing in public was captured years before the pandemic. A search across DW and other global news outlets found no proof of an actual event matching this description.

text: A video shows an 80 million-year-old shark discovered in Awashima, Japan.

claimReview.title: Age of prehistoric-looking shark exaggerated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shot in Awashima shows a rare frilled shark. Marine scientists told The Associated Press that the age of the shark could not be determined, but said that it could not live for millions of years.

text: President Joe Biden issued Executive Order 9066, which provides people who enter the U.S. illegally with a $5,000 Visa gift card.

claimReview.title: Executive Order 9066 authorized Japanese detention during World War II, not gift cards for recent migrants
claimReview.textualRating: False. Executive Order 9066 was issued by President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1942, authorizing the forced removal from the West Coast of anyone deemed a threat to national security. It paved the way for the relocation and incarceration of approximately 120,000 people of Japanese ancestry, including U.S.-born citizens, during World War II. The order was formally terminated in 1976 by President Gerald Ford. Immigration experts previously told The Associated Press that people who enter the U.S. illegally are not eligible for federal cash assistance, with exceptions for certain Cubans and Haitians. None of these benefits include a one-time payment of $5,000.

text: President-elect Joe Biden’s sister is married to Stephen Owens, the co-founder of the private equity firm Staple Street Capital, which owns Dominion Voting Systems.

claimReview.title: Biden family does not own Dominion Voting Systems
claimReview.textualRating: False. Stephen Owens has no relationship to the Biden family, a spokesperson for Staple Street Capital confirmed. This false claim is based on two people sharing a common last name.

text: Arizona has 9,871,525 registered voters but its population is 7,270,000.

claimReview.title: Post distorts facts on registered voters in Arizona
claimReview.textualRating: False. The state had about 4 million registered voters, which is millions less than its population of about 7 million people.

text: A video shows protesters in France storming and looting a Louis Vuitton store in 2023.

claimReview.title: Clip of looting at Louis Vuitton store in Portland misrepresented as French protests
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage being shared has been online since 2020 and the journalist who recorded the video confirmed to The Associated Press that it was filmed during a protest in Portland.

text: The turnout of registered voters in Wisconsin in the 2020 election was 94%, which suggests something suspicious about the results.

claimReview.title: Wisconsin’s turnout of registered voters in the 2020 election was not suspicious or abnormal
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. State data puts that figure at under 90%, but regardless, it is not uncommon for voter turnout to be this high if it is calculated based on the number of registered voters in a state. In fact, using data from KFF, a polling nonprofit, this method puts all 50 states and the District of Columbia at a turnout of more than 83% in the 2020 election, with the majority above 90%. However, many states, including Wisconsin, actually use metrics such as the voting-age population to calculate voter turnout, for a more representative estimate. By that measure, Wisconsin’s 2020 turnout was around 73%.

text: Video shows Italian truckers mobilizing in support of an anti-vaccine protest in Canada on Jan. 28.

claimReview.title: Video of Italian feast celebration falsely identified as Canada truck protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows truckers taking part in the annual Feast of San Michele event in Turin, Italy, in 2021.

text: Social media posts circulating recently stated

claimReview.title: Lincoln ordered execution of dozens of Sioux warriors, commuted sentences of others
claimReview.textualRating: True. Thirty-eight Native Americans were hanged on Dec. 26, 1862, as ordered by former President Abraham Lincoln, after the 1862 Dakota War, which was also known as the Sioux Uprising of 1862. The sentences of 265 others were commuted.

text: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled that the 2020 presidential election was “rigged.”

claimReview.title: Pennsylvania Supreme Court did not rule 2020 election was ‘rigged’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The court last week ordered Pennsylvania counties to refrain from counting absentee or mail-in ballots for the 2022 general election if their outer return envelopes lack accurate, handwritten dates. It directed the counties to “segregate and preserve” those ballots instead. Ballots contained in such envelopes were allowed to be counted in the 2020 race, but the court’s decision does not mean it determined the election was rigged, election experts told The Associated Press.

text: A CNN broadcast captured an Ohio woman illegally placing multiple ballots into a drop box on Election Day.

claimReview.title: Social media posts misleadingly claim a CNN clip shows ballot fraud in Ohio
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. In the video, which is from Oct. 31, 2020, the woman appears to be placing at least three ballots in a drop box as CNN is filming. Election officials and government watchdog groups in Ohio say there’s nothing inherently illegal about placing that many ballots in the box. The only requirement is that the ballots all must be from family members.

text: The Green New Deal is causing gas prices to spike.

claimReview.title: Green New Deal falsely identified as the cause of high gas prices
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Green New Deal, a broad plan intended to address climate change, has not been enacted into law and is not impacting gas prices, experts say. The current surge in gas prices is due to other factors, including the spiking cost of crude oil globally.

text: A voter will be able to vote four times because he received four vote-by-mail applications.

claimReview.title: Four vote-by-mail ballot applications do not mean four votes
claimReview.textualRating: False. The voter received four applications to vote-by-mail from a nonprofit organization — not four ballots. People who fill out multiple ballot applications will only get one ballot.

text: Video shows Spain’s

claimReview.title: Video of Spanish king shaking head at paratrooper blends two clips
claimReview.textualRating: False. The king was shaking his head as the flag of Spain became detached from its mast after it was hoisted, not at a paratrooper’s mishap. The video is edited to make the two separate clips look like they go together.

text: Former President Barack Obama lost the election in every state that required voters to provide identification at the polls, and he won every state without those laws.

claimReview.title: Obama won states with voter ID laws in 2008, 2012
claimReview.textualRating: False. Obama won Indiana in 2008, one of only two states with strict photo ID requirements at the time. In 2012, he lost the four states that had adopted those requirements, but won in several other states with looser ID laws. In both elections, he lost some states that had no ID requirements at all.

text: Police in Kenosha, Wisconsin, recently arrested 175 people who identify as anti-fascist or support Black Lives Matter.

claimReview.title: No evidence 175 arrested in Kenosha identified as ‘BLM-antifa’
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The Kenosha Police Department did issue a press release saying 175 people had been arrested there between Aug. 24 and Aug. 30, but the agency did not share information about their identities or affiliations.

text: French philosopher Voltaire said

claimReview.title: US congressman shares neo-Nazi’s quote wrongly attributed to Voltaire
claimReview.textualRating: False. Enlightenment-era writer Voltaire did not say this. The quote, which was paraphrased, comes from a 1993 radio broadcast by Kevin Alfred Strom, who has been identified as a neo-Nazi by organizations that monitor hate groups.

text: Video shows lines of cars waiting at the Finnish-Russian border after Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered a partial mobilization of reservists on Wednesday amid the war in Ukraine.

claimReview.title: Video of traffic at the Finnish-Russian border misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was filmed at the Vaalimaa border crossing point between Russia and Finland on Aug. 29, weeks before Putin announced the partial mobilization of Russian reservists to Ukraine. Finland’s border authority has been monitoring the traffic, and stated on Thursday that the increase of traffic at the Finnish-Russian border has been comparable to typical weekend traffic.

text: Officials have released audio of “banging” noises detected by search teams looking for the OceanGate submersible.

claimReview.title: Coast Guard did not release audio of noises from its search for the Titanic-bound submersible
claimReview.textualRating: False. The U.S. Coast Guard, which is leading a search for the submersible, has not released any audio related to these efforts, a spokesperson for the military branch told The Associated Press. Underwater sounds described as “banging noises” were detected in the search area by a Canadian aircraft, but the Coast Guard now says they were likely unrelated to the missing submersible. An audio clip circulating on social media does not sound authentic, an ocean acoustics expert told The Associated Press.

text: Longtime sports journalist Grant Wahl, who died in Qatar last week, was killed by the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: World Cup reporter’s fatal heart condition unrelated to COVID vaccine
claimReview.textualRating: False. Wahl died of a ruptured blood vessel in his heart — an injury unrelated to any vaccine, his wife, Dr. Céline Gounder, confirmed to The Associated Press. The COVID-19 vaccines have not been associated with the heart condition that killed Wahl, experts told the AP.

text: COVID-19 cases plummeted by 40 percent in Denmark and Norway after they removed restrictions implemented during the pandemic.

claimReview.title: Falling COVID-19 cases in Denmark, Norway attributed to vaccines
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Medical experts in those countries attribute the decline in COVID-19 cases to high rates of vaccination. Furthermore, both countries have been gradually easing restrictions since early summer.

text: Ivermectin and hydroxychloroquine were suppressed as COVID-19 treatments because the vaccines couldn’t receive emergency use authorization if such treatments were available.

claimReview.title: COVID treatments weren’t suppressed to OK vaccines’ emergency use
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is nothing in federal law or regulation that prohibits a preventative measure such as a vaccine from being authorized for emergency use because a treatment is available, experts and officials say. The body of scientific evidence available has not proven that ivermectin or hydroxychloroquine are effective in treating COVID-19.

text: The coronavirus is no worse than the flu and the pandemic is a hoax.

claimReview.title: Doctors falsely claim coronavirus no worse than the flu
claimReview.textualRating: False. A group of health professionals who call themselves the World Doctors Alliance make multiple false claims in a video being shared online, many of which have been debunked by experts working to stop the spread of the coronavirus.

text: Video caught comments between Fox News and New York Times journalists revealing they believe COVID-19 was a “hoax.”

claimReview.title: Video misrepresents journalists’ comments in White House briefing room
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video feed that was actively recording the White House briefing room captured an exchange between Fox News chief White House correspondent John Roberts and New York Times photographer Doug Mills, saying COVID-19 was a “hoax” and “we’ve all been vaccinated,” but the comments were taken out of context. Roberts told The Associated Press the comments were made in jest.

text: A photo shows Dr. Mehmet Oz, the celebrity heart surgeon who is running for a U.S. Senate seat in Pennsylvania, kissing former President Donald Trump’s star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

claimReview.title: Posts spread edited photo of Oz on Hollywood Walk of Fame
claimReview.textualRating: Altered image. An Associated Press photo of Oz smooching his own star in February 2022 has been edited to insert Trump’s plaque. A spokesperson for Oz’s senate campaign confirmed that the photo has been manipulated.

text: Congressional Republicans voted to cut federal funding to Meals on Wheels, the non-government organization that delivers meals to the elderly in their homes.

claimReview.title: Would the GOP’s deficit plan cut federal funding to Meals on Wheels? Maybe
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Meals on Wheels receives funding through a part of the federal budget that House Republicans have targeted for spending cuts. But the GOP bill approved by the House doesn’t specifically target or even mention the organization, and it remains unclear which programs will ultimately be cut as the legislation doesn’t provide details.

text: Former President Barack Obama took 30 million documents, many of them classified, to Chicago upon leaving the White House.

claimReview.title: Obama didn’t keep millions of classified White House documents
claimReview.textualRating: False. Obama administration records are exclusively held and maintained by the National Archives and Records Administration, the federal agency confirmed on Friday. Millions of unclassified documents were transferred after Obama left office to a NARA facility in Chicago, but neither Obama’s personal foundation nor the facility set to house his presidential memorabilia have control over those papers.

text: New York City police on Wednesday arrested several people, including a 9-year-old girl, for failing to present proof of COVID-19 vaccination at the American Museum of Natural History.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent after-hours arrests at New York museum
claimReview.textualRating: False. Six protesters who were initially denied entry into the museum for refusing to show proof of COVID-19 vaccination were arrested for trespassing at the museum after it had closed, NYPD spokesman Al Baker told The Associated Press. Officers did not charge the child with a crime, Baker said.

text: Photo shows former President Ronald Reagan meeting with Taliban leaders during his presidency.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show President Reagan meeting with the Taliban
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo, taken in 1983, shows Reagan meeting with Afghan mujahedeen. The Taliban did not emerge until 1994.

text: Photo shows Fox’s Chris Wallace with Jeffrey Epstein, who was accused of sexually abusing dozens of girls over the years, on his private island in the Caribbean.

claimReview.title: Photo does not show Fox News host with Jeffrey Epstein
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows Wallace, who moderated the presidential debate Tuesday, on a boat dock with actor George Clooney in Italy.

text: “Infertility is nutrient deficiencies” and a gluten-free diet will ensure women absorb nutrients and guarantee pregnancy.

claimReview.title: Video baselessly claims gluten-free diet guarantees infertility fix
claimReview.textualRating: False. There are many factors that can cause infertility. Experts say there is no evidence to support that a gluten-free diet with supplements guarantees pregnancy.

text: Photo shows President-elect Joe Biden with a walking boot on his left foot, even though he broke his right foot.

claimReview.title: Photo of Biden with walking boot on wrong foot was edited
claimReview.textualRating: False. This photo was edited to add the boot. The original photo is from 2018, when Biden was leaving an animal adoption center in Delaware with a new dog. Biden was not wearing a boot that day.

text: President Joe Biden has ordered the Department of Veterans Affairs to withhold health care benefits from unvaccinated veterans.

claimReview.title: Biden is not withholding benefits from unvaccinated veterans
claimReview.textualRating: False. President Biden has not directed the Department of Veterans Affairs to cut off benefits to unvaccinated veterans, and Biden’s existing coronavirus-related executive order does not mandate such actions. The erroneous claims were outlined in a satirical article published by a parody blog that some readers mistakenly spread as fact.

text: The IRS will issue a fourth round of stimulus checks to Americans in February 2022.

claimReview.title: No plan for fourth round of federal stimulus checks, despite claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. While some states have created stimulus programs for their own residents, Congress has not approved any plans to issue another round of nationwide stimulus checks. A spokesperson for the IRS confirmed that there have been three rounds of economic impact payments in total.

text: Twitter suspended Elon Musk’s account after the Tesla CEO

claimReview.title: No, Elon Musk was not suspended from Twitter
claimReview.textualRating: False. Musk’s account, @elonmusk, is still active. A separate account using an uppercase “i” instead of a lowercase “l” — resulting in a handle that appears identical in certain fonts — has been suspended.

text: A photo shows supporters of former President Donald Trump swarming President Joe Biden’s motorcade during his visit to Pennsylvania on July 28.

claimReview.title: Photo of Trump fans blocking Biden motorcade is from October
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. This image of Trump supporters crowding around Biden’s motorcade in Pennsylvania was captured months ago, in October.

text: “Teachers are the number one occupation of the antifa terrorist organization according to the FBI.”

claimReview.title: FBI did not say teacher is the most common occupation of antifa activists
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence that teachers make up an outsized portion of antifa, a shorthand term for “anti-fascists.” The FBI told The Associated Press it “has not made any such statements about the occupations of people who are attracted to particular ideologies.”

text: A photo circulating widely online claims to show Christine Blasey Ford standing with billionaire Democratic donor George Soros.

claimReview.title: Brett Kavanaugh accuser not pictured with Democratic donor George Soros
claimReview.textualRating: False. The woman pictured with Soros is not Ford but Ukrainian human rights activist Lyudmyla Kozlovska.

text: A photo of a person wearing glasses and a baseball cap in a field shows the shooter

claimReview.title: Posts falsely identify photos as Nashville school shooter
claimReview.textualRating: False. Both photos circulating widely on social media do not show the shooter responsible for the attack at the private Christian school in Nashville, on Monday. The photo of the person in a baseball cap shows an Instagram user from Pennsylvania who was the target of false claims, while the other photo shows a manipulated image of Sam Hyde, an internet personality who has been the subject of a long-running internet hoax.

text: COVID-19 only spikes during election seasons.

claimReview.title: There is no connection between rising COVID cases and elections, contrary to claims online
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no connection between rising COVID-19 cases and the electoral process, epidemiology experts confirm. Since the first U.S. case was confirmed in January 2020, the virus has spiked near the end of the year, but also during summer, nowhere near major elections.

text: President Donald Trump’s son-in-law and adviser, Jared Kushner, deleted all his tweets after The New York Times published a story on Trump’s tax returns on Sunday.

claimReview.title: Jared Kusher didn’t delete all his tweets after Trump tax story
claimReview.textualRating: False. Kushner didn’t have any tweets on his profile before Sunday. He did not delete posts.

text: Picture shows Mary and Fred Trump, wearing Ku Klux Klan robes, standing with son Donald Trump in 1999.

claimReview.title: Photo has been edited to show Trump’s parents wearing KKK robes
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo, which was taken of Trump with his parents in 1992, has been altered.

text: There is a simple self-check that can be done every morning to see if you have the coronavirus. Take a deep breath and hold it for more than 10 seconds. If you complete it successfully without discomfort, stuffiness or tightness it proves there is no fibrosis in the lungs, basically indicating no infection.

claimReview.title: Ability to hold your breath 10 seconds is not a test for coronavirus
claimReview.textualRating: False. Medical experts say that the test would not provide a clear indication of whether someone has the novel coronavirus.

text: A photo of a United Nations flag flying on a bridge at the U.S.-Canada border is being shared on social media with the suggestion that Canada’s liberal leader had it installed and is preparing to “cede control” of the border to the U.N.

claimReview.title: Canada’s leader did not erect U.N. flag at the border
claimReview.textualRating: False. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau did not install the U.N. flag on the Peace Bridge, which is pictured in the post; and there are no plans by the government to give the U.N. power over the country’s borders.

text: Photos show the White House erecting a concrete security wall around the entire building.

claimReview.title: Photos of White House maintenance prompt bogus theories
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photos show a barrier put up around the White House’s north fountain during scheduled maintenance.

text: People who are vaccinated against COVID-19 carry a “heavier viral load” if infected with the disease than those who are unvaccinated.

claimReview.title: Vaccinated people do not carry more coronavirus than unvaccinated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The erroneous information grew from comments a doctor made in an interview discussing the delta variant, which is more contagious than other strains of the virus. Scientists have found that vaccinated people who get so-called breakthrough infections carry about the same amount of coronavirus as those who did not receive the shots.

text: The U.S. military is planning to reinstitute the draft.

claimReview.title: The US isn’t planning to order young men to enlist in the military, despite claims made online
claimReview.textualRating:
False. Defense officials confirm the armed forces have made no such recommendation to Congress or the president, which are the entities empowered to authorize a draft.
List (Page)

text: Members of Congress gave themselves a 21% pay raise in early March.

claimReview.title: Congress members didn’t boost own salaries in March 2022
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are misrepresenting a government spending bill that increased funding for legislative office budgets, not lawmakers’ salaries. Members of Congress use these budgets to hire and pay staff, and to manage other official expenses. Annual salaries for members of the House and Senate will remain the same this year, as they have since 2009.

text: A headline published by The Atlantic reads, “At this weekend’s Pride parade a man exposed his genitals to my 6 year old. She was horrified. Am I raising a bigot?”

claimReview.title: Fabricated image shows made-up Atlantic headline about a Pride parade
claimReview.textualRating: False. The screenshot sharing the headline was fabricated. A spokesperson for The Atlantic confirmed to The Associated Press that the magazine never published an article with that headline.

text: More than 100,000 children are in “serious condition” with COVID-19 in the U.S.

claimReview.title: Justice Sotomayor incorrect on ‘serious’ child COVID-19 cases
claimReview.textualRating: False. Federal data shows that around 5,000 minors are currently hospitalized with confirmed or suspected COVID-19. Since August 2020, fewer than 83,000 kids have been hospitalized with the virus, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

text: The Kansas City Chiefs’ Super Bowl win is being “put on hold” while the NFL launches an investigation into whether quarterback Patrick Mahomes used performance-enhancing drugs during halftime.

claimReview.title: Tweet spreads false claim that Chiefs’ victory is ‘on hold’ for Mahomes probe
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim was made by a single Twitter account that posts seemingly satirical sports headlines. An NFL spokesperson confirmed to The Associated Press that the claims are “absolutely false.”

text: A photograph shared on social media depicts a building fire in Minneapolis amid protests in the aftermath of the officer-involved death of George Floyd.

claimReview.title: Photo shared by gun rights group shows 1992 LA riots, not Minneapolis
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows a mini-mall on fire during the 1992 riots in Los Angeles.

text: President Joe Biden is warning Americans to prepare for a food shortage in 2023 amid “rising COVID numbers” and an “immigrant influx.”

claimReview.title: No, Biden is not warning the US to prepare for a food shortage amid a migrant influx
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden has made no such statement recently. In March 2022, he was asked about what the U.S. would do in response to wheat shortages expected to impact many countries due to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine the month before. Biden in response said food shortages “would be real” and discussed plans to disseminate more food quickly.

text: Massachusetts destroyed over 1 million ballots and committed election fraud. Ballot images that must be saved for 22 months are nowhere to be found.

claimReview.title: Massachusetts primary ballots were not destroyed
claimReview.textualRating: False. Physical ballots have not been destroyed. They are being stored for 22 months as required by federal law. Massachusetts election officials do not capture and preserve ballot images when they tabulate votes. They are not required to do so.

text: Video shows Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden at his campaign event in St. Louis, Missouri, endorsing Republican President Donald Trump, saying “we can only re-elect Donald Trump!”

claimReview.title: Video doesn’t show Biden endorsing Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video viewed millions of times on Facebook and Twitter does not show Biden mistakenly endorsing Trump, and he was talking to supporters in Kansas City, Missouri -- not St. Louis.

text: The United States is on the verge of running out of diesel fuel.

claimReview.title: US won’t run out of diesel in weeks, experts say
claimReview.textualRating: False. While data from the Energy Information Administration shows that the U.S. has about a 25-day supply of diesel, the country will not actually run out of fuel soon, experts confirmed to The Associated Press. This figure doesn’t account for ongoing diesel production.

text: In Alabama, the penalty for a doctor who provides an abortion in the case of rape is more severe than the penalty for the rapist.

claimReview.title: Post comparing abortion, rape penalties in Alabama lacks context
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Alabama law does not require that outcome, though experts say it could happen. The law that bans most abortions classifies an illegal abortion as a Class A felony, the same as first-degree rape. Both are punishable with life in prison or a sentence of up to 99 years, though sentencing involves a judge’s discretion and other factors.

text: Footage from the Beirut explosion shows a missile striking the site just before the blast.

claimReview.title: Video showing ‘missile’ in Beirut blast was manipulated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, which was circulating on YouTube and Twitter, has been manipulated to add what appears to be a cartoon missile. There is no evidence Tuesday’s explosion was an attack of any kind.

text: A photograph shows a performer with a blue, glittery outfit smiling as he holds a microphone to a child’s face pretending that the device is a penis.

claimReview.title: Photograph of Argentine producer with his son misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows Argentine artist and producer Flavio Mendoza with his son, and Mendoza explained in a tweet that the photograph was taken out of context. A video reviewed by The Associated Press shows that the minor only sang part of a song and his father held the microphone at the level of his face for a few seconds.

text: Messenger RNA, or mRNA, is “an existential threat to humanity.”

claimReview.title: Contrary to post, mRNA is naturally in human cells
claimReview.textualRating: False. mRNA is part of human existence and occurs naturally in everyone, carrying information for cells and allowing for proteins to be created.

text: Law enforcement’s seizure of fuel at the ongoing protest against COVID-19 vaccine restrictions in Ottawa, the capital city of Canada, is a war crime that violates the Geneva Conventions.

claimReview.title: Police fuel seizure at Ottawa protest isn’t war crime
claimReview.textualRating: False. The fuel seizure doesn’t constitute a war crime or a violation of the Geneva Conventions because the rules only apply to armed conflicts, experts say.

text: A video shows President Joe Biden trying to sit in a chair that wasn’t there during a ceremony in Normandy, France, commemorating the 80th anniversary of D-Day.

claimReview.title: Video edited to make it appear Biden tried to sit down when there wasn’t a chair
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, in which Biden’s chair is for the most part clearly visible, is cut before the president sits down. Full footage of the ceremony shows the president looking over his shoulder for his chair and pausing before taking a seat.

text: Video shows an angry parent tearing down a Pride flag draped over a U.S. map in a classroom.

claimReview.title: Widespread video of a parent ripping down a Pride flag in classroom is a skit, not real
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip shows actors performing a skit, as a longer version makes clear. It was posted by a social media personality who has previously shared similar videos, including with some of the same actors, and who clarified that it was “openly fake.”

text: A class at Harvard Medical School trains students to treat transgender infants.

claimReview.title: Harvard med school class isn’t about ‘trans infants’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Harvard class, an elective about health care for LGBTQ patients, discusses intersex infants in the context of their physical development. Intersex is an umbrella term that refers to people with naturally occurring differences in sex traits or reproductive anatomy. The portion of the course that focuses on infants does not cover gender identity or sexual orientation and is one day in the month-long course, the class’s professor told The Associated Press.

text: The Minions in the popular “Despicable Me” animated film series were inspired by a horrific 1944 Nazi experiment that put hard metal helmets on children’s heads.

claimReview.title: ‘Minions’ not inspired by Nazi experiment
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s no evidence to support these claims, which misrepresent an image of an early 1900s submarine escape apparatus as a torture device.

text: A video shows Israel’s flag displayed on the outside of the Sphere in Las Vegas.

claimReview.title: Video showing Las Vegas’ Sphere projecting the Israeli flag is altered
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. The entertainment venue confirmed that a video was edited to add the flag.

text: Home Depot recently donated $1.75 million to Hershel Walker’s U.S. Senate campaign.

claimReview.title: Posts mischaracterize Home Depot political donations
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. Bernard "Bernie" Marcus, a Home Depot co-founder who left the company in 2002, made contributions totaling $1.75 million to a political action committee supporting Walker, according to Federal Election Commission data, not The Home Depot. While FEC records show the Atlanta-based retailer’s own political action committee has donated to the National Republican Senatorial Committee this cycle, the company said in a statement that it has not contributed directly to Walker’s campaign.

text: An activist who decried child sex abuse and was himself charged with child sex crimes used to work as a Hillary Clinton campaign official.

claimReview.title: Man sentenced for child sex crimes did not work for Clinton campaign
claimReview.textualRating: False. Joel Davis, an activist against child sex abuse who was arrested for his own child sex crimes in 2018, did not work for the Clinton campaign.

text: Video shows a train moving National Guard vehicles into Chicago.

claimReview.title: Video does not show train carrying National Guard vehicles to Chicago
claimReview.textualRating: False. The National Guard in Illinois said the vehicles do not belong to them, nor is the video related to their response to COVID-19.

text: Video shows President Donald Trump lost and meandering around the White House lawn.

claimReview.title: Video edited to make Trump seem confused
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was selectively edited, leaving out that the president was waiting for the first lady.

text: A video shows President Joe Biden essentially confirming that his team coordinated the indictment of former President Donald Trump to “stop Trump from taking power again.”

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent old Biden clip as related to Trump case
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video dates to November 2022 and shows Biden answering a question about how to reassure world leaders that Trump would not return to power. Trump was indicted by a Manhattan grand jury, in a process that did not involve the Biden administration. A conviction would not prevent Trump from running for or winning the presidency in 2024.

text: A tweet from Donald Trump Jr. asks Trump supporters to stay away from the former president’s Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida because “we have many important people coming through the club and need to keep it clean.”

claimReview.title: Fake Trump Jr. tweet about keeping Mar-a-Lago ‘clean’ was parody
claimReview.textualRating: False. This fake tweet was first posted on a parody account. It was not tweeted by the former president’s son.

text: England is giving up on efforts to create 15-minute cities because people have destroyed all the cameras and refused to pay tens of thousands of fines.

claimReview.title: England isn’t ‘giving up’ on 15-minute city efforts, despite social media claims
claimReview.textualRating:
False. British officials say the island nation continues to advance efforts related to the urban design concept, particularly by investing in more parks and open space. Moreover, they say, the cameras and fines referenced in the posts are associated with unrelated efforts to crackdown on old, polluting vehicles in London and other cities.
List (Page)

text: Democratic Sen. Maggie Hassan received 1,100 votes in a New Hampshire town with only 700 residents, suggesting fraud.

claimReview.title: New Hampshire town’s vote discrepancy was human error, not foul play
claimReview.textualRating: False. The town clerk of Columbia, New Hampshire, confirmed that she miswrote 106 votes as 1,106 votes, causing a temporary reporting error that has been corrected. The error didn’t change the results of the statewide Senate race, which Hassan won by more than 56,000 votes.

text: Beto O’Rourke is a burglar who wants to ban home defense weapons.

claimReview.title: Beto O’Rourke’s 1995 burglary arrest misrepresented
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. O’Rourke, a Democrat running for Texas governor, was charged with a misdemeanor burglary charge in 1995 when he tried to jump a fence at the University of Texas at El Paso, according to court records. The charge was later dropped. In the past, O’Rourke has said he supports a federal assault weapons ban.

text: Rep. Katie Porter said in a hearing before the House Oversight and Reform Committee that pedophilia is an identity, not a crime.

claimReview.title: Posts mischaracterize congresswoman’s comments on anti-LGBTQ rhetoric
claimReview.textualRating: False. Porter’s comments from the committee’s Wednesday hearing on the rise of anti-LGBTQ violence were taken out of context. The California Democrat was agreeing with Human Rights Campaign President Kelley Robinson, who spoke about online rhetoric painting LGBTQ people as “groomers” and “pedophiles.” Porter said that such rhetoric amounts to falsely “alleging that a person is criminal somehow and engaged in criminal acts merely because of their identity — their sexual orientation, their gender identity.”

text: A new study from researchers at the National Institutes of Health and Moderna shows COVID-19 mRNA vaccines “hurt long-term immunity to Covid after infection.”

claimReview.title: Paper didn’t show COVID-19 vaccines ‘hurt’ immunity
claimReview.textualRating: False. A senior author of the study and multiple experts who reviewed the paper for The Associated Press say its findings are being misinterpreted and that Moderna’s COVID-19 vaccine offers protection against the disease.

text: A man in Italy set himself on fire because he lost his job due to COVID-19 vaccine mandates.

claimReview.title: Video of man on fire in Italy not related to vaccine mandates
claimReview.textualRating: False. The man didn’t set himself on fire due to vaccine mandates, according to local authorities. While police did not offer a motive for the incident, they said the man is vaccinated and still employed as a teacher.

text: Scientists are warning that eggs are causing blood clots to suddenly form in thousands of people.

claimReview.title: Study from 2017 misrepresented to link eggs to blood clots
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim is based on a misrepresentation of a 2017 study that found that taking supplements in capsule form of choline — a nutrient in red meat, egg yolks and other foods — raised levels of a compound in the body that could make the blood more prone to clotting.
