However, that research didn’t find a direct link between egg consumption specifically and blood clots. In fact, the study doesn’t mention eggs at all.

text: Video shows COVID-19 vaccine being removed after injection using cupping therapy.

claimReview.title: Vaccines can’t be removed after injection, contrary to cupping video
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no way to remove a vaccine after injection. The video shows blood from a superficial layer of the skin, whereas the vaccine is injected deeper and into one’s muscle.

text: “A Muslim woman in Paris was arrested three days ago for planning a terrorist attack at Notre Dame Cathedral. Today, 3 days later, Notre Dame is in flames.” -- social media posts Monday.

claimReview.title: Woman was not arrested for plotting terrorist attack 3 days before Notre Dame fire
claimReview.textualRating: False. No terrorism-related arrest or charge was made days before the fire broke out at Notre Dame, the Paris prosecutor’s office said in a statement Wednesday to The Associated Press.

text: Kentucky Derby winner Medina Spirit’s jockey John Velazquez turned down a White House invite today, saying that if he wanted to see a horse’s behind he would have come in second place.

claimReview.title: Viral quote attributed to Kentucky Derby jockey is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. Velazquez hasn’t been invited to the White House, according to his agent, Ron Anderson. This fake quote has circulated as a joke online since at least 2018.

text: A screenshot from CNN shows the network labeled the Taliban’s takeover of Afghanistan “violent but mostly peaceful.”

claimReview.title: Screenshot of CNN report on Afghanistan is fake
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. CNN did not refer to the events in Afghanistan this way. The screenshot is manipulated, the network confirmed.

text: The U.S. accidentally sent Ukraine $6 billion in military aid.

claimReview.title: No, the US did not send Ukraine $6 billion by mistake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim misinterprets an announcement by a Pentagon spokesperson in June that the agency had overestimated the value of weapons it sent to Ukraine over the past two years by $6.2 billion. That meant more could be sent in the future without asking Congress for additional funds, not that billions of dollars had been sent in error.

text: CNN published an article with the headline

claimReview.title: CNN did not publish headline on Uvalde parent sentencing
claimReview.textualRating: False. An image purporting to show this CNN headline is fabricated. The outlet did not publish such an article, and the Uvalde County district attorney's office confirmed it has not received such a case. A photo used alongside the doctored headline shows an unrelated suspect who was charged with involvement in a 2013 killing in Michigan, not an Uvalde, Texas, parent.

text: A pro-Trump caravan of vehicles on highways circling the Phoenix area on Oct. 25 stretched 96 miles long and consisted of 41,000 cars, the Arizona Department of Public Safety reported.

claimReview.title: Arizona state police didn’t estimate pro-Trump caravan at 96 miles, 41,000 cars
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The Arizona Department of Public Safety put out a rough estimate of 7,000 cars in the caravan, not 41,000, spokesman Bart Graves told The Associated Press. He added that estimates of 96 miles did not come from DPS. It remains unclear how many vehicles were involved in the event and how far they stretched.

text: There are “far more votes” in Detroit than people.

claimReview.title: More votes were not cast in Detroit in 2020 than there are people
claimReview.textualRating: False. Around 250,000 votes were cast in Detroit in the 2020 election, which is less than half of Detroit’s population. The false posts appeared to refer to out of balance precincts where the number of names recorded in poll books does not match the number of ballots counted.

text: A post circulating widely on social media Tuesday says “three Muslim congresswomen just refused” to sign the oath of office to uphold the U.S. Constitution.

claimReview.title: Muslim congresswomen to take oath of office with colleagues
claimReview.textualRating: False. Two Muslim women elected to Congress will be sworn in on Jan. 3 and both plan to take the oath of office, along with their colleagues.

text: Video shows masked man at polling site “cheating” in front of cameras in Philadelphia.

claimReview.title: Clip shows poll worker in Wisconsin, not 'cheating' in Philadelphia
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video, which appeared on Fox News, shows a poll worker in Madison, Wisconsin, on Tuesday. He was initialing ballots to be handed out to voters, a standard procedure mandated by state law, said Dane County Clerk Scott McDonell.

text: Photo shows protesters carrying a banner that states “Assassinate Republicans that defeat Democrats. Make America Great.”

claimReview.title: Photo altered to change wording in protesters’ banner
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was altered to change the wording on the banner. In the original photo the poster says, “Trump makes America hate, our students make America great.”

text: Tesla CEO Elon Musk is suing Alyssa Milano, an actor and activist, for defamation in a $200 million lawsuit.

claimReview.title: Bogus claim about Tesla suing Alyssa Milano originated as satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such lawsuit has been announced. The story was fabricated by a site that labels its work as satire.

text: President Joe Biden swore on a “Masonic/Illuminati” Bible during his inauguration last week.

claimReview.title: False claims target Bible used for Biden’s presidential inauguration
claimReview.textualRating: False. Biden was sworn in on a Douay-Rheims Bible, which is an English translation of a Latin Bible. Religious scholars said Biden’s Bible, which has been in his family for generations, was translated by Rev. George Leo Haydock in the 1800s.

text: Video shows the Ukrainian air force shooting down a Russian air force fighter jet in Kyiv.

claimReview.title: Footage shows flight simulator game, not Russian fighter jet being shot down
claimReview.textualRating: False. The footage is from the video game Digital Combat Simulator, according to the YouTube user who uploaded the clip on Feb. 24.

text: A video clip shows a speech in Virginia by President Joe Biden being interrupted by chants of “F--- Joe Biden.”

claimReview.title: Video clip was manipulated to add anti-Biden chant
claimReview.textualRating: False. The original video, from July, does not include those chants; the clip was altered to add that audio.

text: The new vaccine for COVID-19 will be the first of its kind ever. It will be an "MRna vaccine" which will literally alter your DNA. It will wrap itself into your system. You will essentially become a genetically modified human being.

claimReview.title: Experts: mRNA vaccine for COVID-19 does not alter DNA
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say mRNA vaccines do not alter your DNA.

text: “Scientists Just Found The Tomb Of Egyptian God Osiris Next To The River Nile.”

claimReview.title: Archaeologists didn’t dig up a mythological tomb of Osiris
claimReview.textualRating: False. No such discovery occurred. Online posts recycle information about past archaeological findings in Egypt, including the 2015 discovery of a tomb modeled after Osiris' tomb.

text: A compilation of screenshots shows that Texas Sen. Ted Cruz has tweeted identical messages after 12 mass shootings in the U.S. from 2012 to 2022.

claimReview.title: Ted Cruz hasn’t posted identical tweets after 12 mass shootings
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image begins with a real message Cruz tweeted following Tuesday’s shooting at an Uvalde, Texas, elementary school, but the following 11 tweets have been fabricated to look like he used the exact same message with a different city name each time. A search of Cruz’s active Twitter accounts, web archives and a database of deleted tweets, shows he did not repeatedly tweet the same message.

text: A video shows Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy saying he uses cocaine.

claimReview.title: Video of Zelenskyy talking about cocaine is deceptively edited
claimReview.textualRating: False. A video of a 2019 interview with Zelenskyy was edited in a misleading way, rearranging statements he made about coffee and exercise to make it seem as if they were answers to a separate question about drugs.

text: Video featuring dozens of blue tents across two parking lots shows an encampment for antifa agitators in Portland, Oregon.

claimReview.title: Video shows Portland homeless camps, not antifa ‘war encampment’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The two adjacent lots shown in the video are temporary homeless camps for unhoused Portland residents, according to two nonprofits that helped install them. The campsites were set up in April, predating racial justice protests that have persisted nightly in Portland since late May.

text: Video shows that “Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau pays mainstream media $600 million to report in favor of him.”

claimReview.title: Trudeau’s 2019 joke about media coverage taken out of context
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video clip being cited was edited in a way that makes it unclear that Trudeau was making a joke — and actually referring to negative press coverage.

text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy bought two luxury yachts, named Lucky Me and My Legacy, through proxies for more than $75 million.

claimReview.title: Ukraine’s Zelenskyy did not purchase two luxury yachts in October. They’re still up for sale
claimReview.textualRating: False. The companies selling each yacht confirmed to The Associated Press that they are still on the market.

text: COVID-19 is “the greatest hoax ever perpetrated” and “just another bad flu.” Roger Hodkinson, a pathologist who identifies himself as the former chairman of the Royal College of Physicians of Canada Examination Committee in Pathology, made the comments by phone during a public meeting in Edmonton, the capital of the Canadian province of Alberta.

claimReview.title: Pathologist falsely claims COVID-19 is a hoax, no worse than the flu
claimReview.textualRating: False. Not only is COVID-19 deadlier than the flu, but symptoms can be long-lasting, according to medical experts. Some online posts referred to Hodkinson as a former chairman of the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada. Hodkinson has never been chairman of the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada, the group said.

text: A photo shows first lady Jill Biden wearing a long, bright, lobster-print shirt while walking with President Joe Biden.

claimReview.title: Photo of Jill Biden edited to add lobster-print shirt
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. A news photo of the first lady in an all-white outfit has been edited to add the lobster design. The photo, which is publicly available online, shows the Bidens returning from a trip to Camp David in May 2021.

text: A video shows the Olympic torch being lit at a church in Paris.

claimReview.title: Posts misidentify old videos as Paris Olympics torch lighting
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is a combination of two unrelated clips, neither of which has anything to do with the 2024 Paris Olympics. One from 2023 shows an Easter tradition in Florence, Italy, called the Scoppio del Carro, which translates to the Explosion of the Cart. The other shows a 2023 concert performed by German band Rammstein.

text: An aerial photo shows more than a million people at a “freedom convoy” protest in Canberra, Australia, this month.

claimReview.title: Photo shows UK music fest in 2019, not recent Australian protest
claimReview.textualRating: False. The aerial photo is from the 2019 Glastonbury music festival in the U.K., it does not show crowds at a rally against COVID-19 mandates in Australia’s capital.

text: The delta variant of the coronavirus is fake.

claimReview.title: Meme misleads about delta variant of the coronavirus
claimReview.textualRating: False. The delta variant, a mutation of the coronavirus named after the fourth letter in the Greek alphabet, has been identified in more than 90 countries since it was first detected in India.

text: Photo shows a woman carrying a dead “coronavirus victim” wrapped in a garbage bag with one hand, at arm's length. “If you’ve had to carry a body, you know why it’s called ‘dead weight.’ Raise your hand if you believe this crap.”

claimReview.title: Empty body bags are part of a protest, not a COVID hoax
claimReview.textualRating: False. The original photo does not claim to show an actual dead body.

text: Video shows Lara Trump singing an off-key cover of “I Won’t Back Down” during an appearance on Sky News Australia.

claimReview.title: A widely circulating video of Lara Trump singing was manipulated to sound wildly off-key
claimReview.textualRating: Altered video. The clip’s audio was edited to make it appear as if Trump was singing very off-key. The original footage published on the news network’s YouTube channel shows Trump’s actual vocals, and the user who posted the manipulated version on social media subsequently acknowledged he had changed it with audio-editing software.

text: MSNBC knowingly used fake footage from the movie “World War Z” to show protests and push a narrative that America is on fire.

claimReview.title: MSNBC did not use 'World War Z' footage in broadcast
claimReview.textualRating: False. A Twitter user created what was meant to be a spoof video of MSNBC coverage from protests on Sunday using a clip from “World War Z.” Alexandra Roberts, director of communications at MSNBC, confirmed in an email to The Associated Press that the video was fabricated.

text: More than 1 million people took part in the “Million MAGA March” in Washington.

claimReview.title: Thousands attended DC rally supporting Trump, not ‘1 million’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The number of people that attended was likely between 11,000 and 15,000 according to G. Keith Still, a visiting professor at the University of Suffolk in England. Still trains police departments on techniques to calculate crowd sizes.

text: Betty White told a news outlet she received a COVID-19 vaccine booster on Dec. 28, three days before her death, saying

claimReview.title: Fake vaccine quote circulates after Betty White’s death
claimReview.textualRating: False. The quote is fabricated. White did not receive a booster that day, her agent confirmed to The Associated Press. The news article cited by social media users does not contain the bogus quote or anything about vaccines.

text: Olive Garden is “funding” President Donald Trump’s 2020 re-election campaign.

claimReview.title: Olive Garden has not donated to Trump’s 2020 campaign
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Olive Garden said in a statement to The Associated Press that the company does not donate to presidential candidates. A search of OpenSecrets.org, which tracks political donations, shows no donations by Darden Restaurants, Inc., which operates the Olive Garden in 2020.

text: The Washington State Board of Health at a Jan. 12 public meeting was scheduled to consider a proposed rule change to allow the involuntary detainment of unvaccinated residents in COVID-19 quarantine camps.

claimReview.title: Washington state isn’t changing its quarantine rules
claimReview.textualRating: False. The board was scheduled to discuss changes to the Washington Administrative Code’s section on communicable and certain other diseases in accordance with a new law about how the state handles HIV, not COVID-19. The state’s quarantine and isolation procedures, which have been in place since 2003 and are similar to rules in several other states, aren’t undergoing any changes.

text: Putin told Russian citizens to isolate themselves for 15 days or face jail time for violating the coronavirus lockdown.

claimReview.title: Ignoring Russia’s virus lockdown can lead to jail in some cases
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Putin did not order citizens to isolate themselves or face jail time. However, Russian officials have introduced legislation that provides prison sentences and fines if others are sickened by someone who violates quarantine restrictions.

text: Photo shows Democratic protesters storming the U.S. Capitol during the confirmation of then-Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh in 2018.

claimReview.title: Photo shows 2011 Wisconsin protests, not U.S. Capitol during Kavanaugh hearings
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken in February 2011 in the state Capitol in Madison, Wisconsin, during labor demonstrations to protest a proposal that would take away union rights from public workers.

text: President Biden admitted that a top Federal Emergency Management Agency official was already on the ground in Hawaii even before the Maui wildfires started.

claimReview.title: Yes, a top FEMA official was in Hawaii before the Maui fires, but it was for a conference
claimReview.textualRating:
Missing context. Biden officials confirmed that Bob Fenton, a regional administrator for FEMA, had been in Hawaii for an annual gathering hosted by the agency on Oahu, an island separate from Maui.
List (Page)

text: Hitler also defunded the police and installed his own enforcers.

claimReview.title: Hitler did not defund the police
claimReview.textualRating: False. Hitler did not defund the police.

text: Former President Donald Trump wore his pants backward during a Saturday speech in Greenville, North Carolina.

claimReview.title: Trump didn’t wear pants backward for speech
claimReview.textualRating: False. An analysis of images and videos from the event show the former president wore his pants the correct way.

text: Ice cream at McDonald’s contains xylitol, a sweetener that's toxic to dogs.

claimReview.title: Xylitol not an ingredient in McDonald’s ice cream
claimReview.textualRating: False. The company confirmed that xylitol is not used in their ice cream, nor is it listed as an ingredient on their website.

text: Former President Donald Trump is facing the death penalty on

claimReview.title: No, Trump is not facing the death penalty on his latest federal charges, as some online claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. Trump’s possible sentence if convicted does not include the death penalty, the Justice Department and a legal expert confirmed. One of the four charges — conspiracy against rights — can be eligible for the death penalty, but only if the violation results in death or other aggravating factors. As the indictment does not hold Trump responsible for any deaths, the former president is not facing capital punishment.

text: Photo shows former President Barack Obama with Judge Emmet Sullivan, the guy holding up Michael Flynn’s dismissal.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Obama with his brother, not a federal judge
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows Obama with his brother, Malik Obama.

text: A photo shows a billboard in the U.K. featuring the Ukrainian flag with the phrase, “You’ll be cold in the winter. Because they need it more.”

claimReview.title: Photo of UK billboard manipulated to add message about Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The image has been manipulated to add the Ukrainian flag and text over a photo of an unrelated billboard. The original photo was posted by an arts organization in Manchester, England, earlier this year and shows that the billboard featured advertisements for concerts.

text: Administrators at Boston Public Schools are suspending advanced classes for students in fourth through sixth grades because of concerns over racial inequities.

claimReview.title: Boston schools aren’t suspending advanced classes
claimReview.textualRating: False. The school district is pausing a testing requirement for advanced classes for a year because of the coronavirus pandemic, according to an emailed statement from the district. The advanced courses will continue.

text: 1.38; margin-top

claimReview.title: Madonna has not become a supporter of President Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. The post, which contains the quote along with her picture, was fabricated. Madonna, a vocal critic of Trump, has not changed her politics.

text: A video shows that the Nile River recently turned red, portending catastrophes.

claimReview.title: Video does not show the Nile River filled with red water. It’s footage of a lagoon in Chile
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video does not show the Nile River. It was filmed at a lagoon in northern Chile that is naturally red.

text: The International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

claimReview.title: A warrant for Netanyahu’s arrest was requested. But no decision was made about whether to issue it
claimReview.textualRating: False. ICC Chief Prosecutor Karim Khan announced Monday that he is seeking arrest warrants for Netanyahu and Israeli Minister of Defense Yoav Gallant, as well as three Hamas leaders, over actions taken during the Israel-Hamas war. A panel of three judges will now decide whether to issue the warrants and allow a case to proceed. Such decisions typically take two months.

text: Teachers in the Dallas public school system can no longer say the word “slavery” in class.

claimReview.title: Dallas teachers not banned from saying ‘slavery’ in class
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Dallas Independent School District says it hasn’t banned use of the word. The Texas Board of Education said it is not considering curriculum changes that would downplay the role of slavery in American history, either. The statewide teachers’ union says it’s not aware of any other Texas school districts restricting use of the word “slavery."

text: A video clip shows Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau saying that “regardless of the fact that we are attacking your fundamental rights,” we are “still going to go ahead and do it.”

claimReview.title: Footage of Trudeau discussing ‘fundamental rights’ taken out of context
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The video was trimmed, which changed the meaning of what Trudeau was saying. He was describing, and disagreeing with, a specific clause in the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms that allows governments to temporarily override parts of the charter. He argued that it is “not a great thing” to have in the charter.

text: The majority of people dying from COVID-19 are vaccinated, suggesting the vaccines don’t work.

claimReview.title: Faulty interpretation underpins claim that COVID shots don’t work
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. A recent analysis found that more COVID-19 deaths now occur among the vaccinated, but it also stated that should not be seen as evidence that vaccines don’t work. Experts note that this shift was expected in part because more people than not are vaccinated, at least with their primary shots, and there are other factors, such as waning immunity among the vaccinated, also affecting the numbers. Additionally, unvaccinated individuals could have immunity from COVID-19 itself.

text: Photo shows that the global clothing retailer H&M is selling a children’s sweatshirt with printed text that reads “Koolest Kid in the Klan.”

claimReview.title: H&M not selling children’s sweatshirt with ‘Klan’ message
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. This manipulated image didn’t appear on H&M’s website. H&M is not selling clothing with this message, which “goes against everything we stand for,” the company told The Associated Press in an email.

text: Bill Gates obtained approval for an "air vaccine” that will be administered without people's approval.

claimReview.title: No, an ‘air vaccine’ tied to Bill Gates was not approved for use on non-consenting people
claimReview.textualRating: False. A website known for spreading misinformation is misrepresenting a Yale University study that tested an inhalable COVID vaccine on mice, one of the co-authors told The Associated Press. It was not tested on humans, nor funded by Gates. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has not approved such a COVID vaccine for public use in the U.S., and an agency spokesperson said informed consent would be required for any clinical research on people.

text: Photo shows a Turkish soldier helping a child drink water from a bottle with the implication that it occurred during the military offensive Turkey launched last week in northern Syria.

claimReview.title: Image of Turkish soldier was taken in 2015, not during recent fighting in Syria
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo was taken in Turkey in 2015, not during the recent offensive.

text: A video shows a large number of crocodiles that invaded a beach in Brazil, sparking panic among nearby residents.

claimReview.title: Video shows normal Brazilian caiman behavior, not invading crocodiles
claimReview.textualRating: False. The reptiles are yacare caimans, a species closely related to alligators, not crocodiles, multiple experts told The Associated Press. In the clip, they are congregating near a river during the dry season in Brazil’s Pantanal region to maintain their body temperature. This behavior is common in the area, which contains approximately 10 million yacare caimans, and happens every year.

text: Photos taken a century apart at Fort Denison in Australia’s Sydney Harbor are proof that climate change has not led to higher sea levels there or at other monuments near water.

claimReview.title: Photos of water at Sydney Harbor fort do not refute sea level rise
claimReview.textualRating: False. Sea levels at that site have risen and continue to rise, measurements show. Additionally, historical photographs used to support the claim are not a reliable indicator of rising sea levels, scientists say. Tides, seasonal weather patterns and other factors make a direct comparison between photos impossible.

text: Abortion is never medically necessary to protect the health of the mother.

claimReview.title: Posts falsely claim abortion is never medically necessary
claimReview.textualRating: False. Doctors say there are multiple situations in which abortion is medically necessary to save the life of the pregnant mother. Some posts claim that such an instance would be considered “preterm delivery,” but experts say that misuses medical terminology. A procedure to end a pregnancy before a fetus is developed enough to survive outside the womb is defined as an abortion regardless of the reasoning behind it.

text: Scientists in Massachusetts have developed a more lethal strain of COVID-19 in a lab

claimReview.title: COVID strain developed in lab less lethal than original virus
claimReview.textualRating: Missing Context. Researchers at Boston University say they created a strain of COVID-19 that was less deadly than the version of the virus first detected in Wuhan, China. The hybrid developed for the experiments was, however, more deadly than the omicron variant that’s now the most prevalent worldwide, which is generally less severe than prior variants.

text: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said her country doesn't have an issue with the “rage of older white men” because “we've never allowed Rupert Murdoch to set up a media outlet here.”

claimReview.title: Posts attribute bogus quote to New Zealand’s prime minister
claimReview.textualRating: False. The quote is fabricated. There is no record of Ardern making such comments, and a spokesperson for her office confirmed she did not.

text: Video shows the premier of Queensland, Australia, Annastacia Palaszczuk, faked getting a flu shot.

claimReview.title: Premier of Queensland, Australia, did not fake getting a flu shot
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are sharing an edited video clip that leaves out the part where Palaszczuk actually received the shot.

text: The website PhillyAntifa.org shows a photo of a bearded man who resembles a man in the mob that stormed the U.S. Capitol building on Wednesday, proving that the rioters in the Capitol were antifa activists, not supporters of President Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: No truth to alleged ‘evidence’ that Capitol rioter was antifa activist
claimReview.textualRating: False. The website PhillyAntifa.org was identifying the bearded man as an individual in the neo-Nazi movement. There’s no evidence the violent rioters who breached the Capitol were supporters of antifa, short for “anti-fascists,” an umbrella term for far-left leaning militant groups.

text: A video shows a fiery explosion in Ukraine following Russia’s invasion of the country.

claimReview.title: Video shows 2015 blast in China, not Russian airstrike in Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video was taken in Tianjin, China, by an American man who captured the explosion of a warehouse from his window in August 2015. The footage does not show recent Russian airstrikes in Ukraine.

text: Progressive groups are proposing a boycott of Olive Garden because of Italy’s election of far-right Giorgia Meloni as Italy’s first female premier, saying in a statement that “Pizza and pasta are now symbols of worldwide white supremacy.”

claimReview.title: Tweet about Olive Garden boycott over Italy’s election is satire
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim originated in a satirical tweet, but it was shared on other platforms without such a disclaimer and interpreted by some to be fact.

text: A photo of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy filming in front of a green screen shows he was “never in his own land.”

claimReview.title: Posts mislead on photo of Zelenskyy in front of green screen
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows Zelenskyy filming a message that appeared as a hologram at various digital conferences around Europe. It was taken in Kyiv last week, the director of the video message confirmed to The Associated Press.

text: A video shows a World Health Organization representative discussing plans the agency is developing as a way to disregard human rights protections in the name of pandemic preparedness.

claimReview.title: Woman describing pandemic plans for a ‘soft coup’ is not a WHO representative
claimReview.textualRating: False. The woman in the video does not work for WHO, nor was she speaking on its behalf, a spokesperson for the United Nations agency told The Associated Press. The spokesperson also confirmed that WHO is not developing any such plans to take away human rights, as described in the video.

text: Aspirin was found to be helpful against COVID-19. Now Aspirin is being attacked.

claimReview.title: New guidance on daily aspirin isn't connected to COVID-19
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. New draft guidance from a federal panel concerns whether adults over 40 should take aspirin daily to prevent having a first heart attack or stroke. It is unrelated to COVID-19. Scientists are still researching whether aspirin may benefit some COVID-19 patients.

text: Starbucks has a promotion offering a free Frappuccino drink of choice to anyone who goes to a Starbucks store and shouts “Black Lives Matter.”

claimReview.title: Starbucks isn’t offering free Frappuccinos to Black Lives Matter supporters
claimReview.textualRating: False. This is not a real offer, according to a Starbucks spokesperson.

text: A photo of a man with a bloody face shows Lagos State House of Assembly candidate Olumide Oworu after his team was attacked while campaigning in March 2023.

claimReview.title: Bloody photo of Nigerian political hopeful is from movie set
claimReview.textualRating: False. This image is from 2022 and shows Oworu in special effects makeup on a film set. While Oworu has said a member of his team was injured in an attack in March 2023, this photo doesn’t show the injury.

text: Thousands of children are missing following the deadly wildfires in Maui.

claimReview.title: Thousands of children are not missing in Maui
claimReview.textualRating: False. Lists compiled by the Maui Police Department and the FBI contained the name of only one minor who was unaccounted for following the August fires. The child was later identified as a victim of the blaze.

text: A video shows Hamas sympathizers driving through London shouting antisemitic remarks during Friday’s day of protests against Israel.

claimReview.title: Old video of pro-Palestine supporters shouting antisemitic remarks is being misleadingly shared
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The widely shared clip is more than two years old. London police at the time apprehended four men in connection with the incident.
List (Page)

text: The Democratic National Committee is working with the Biden administration to monitor private citizens’ SMS communications in a move to crack down on anti-vaccine text messages.

claimReview.title: DNC anti-misinformation push doesn’t involve reading private texts
claimReview.textualRating: False. The DNC has “no ability to access or read people’s private text messages” and is “not working with any government agency (including the White House) to try to see personal text messages,” according to Lucas Acosta, a senior spokesperson for the committee. The DNC does report fraudulent mass texts to SMS aggregator companies when it hears about them, Acosta said.

text: Kentucky is considering legislation that would require women to submit to the state every month a statement from a doctor indicating if they are pregnant — or else face penalties.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent 2019 ‘satirical’ amendment to Kentucky abortion law
claimReview.textualRating: False. The legislation was an amendment proposed in jest by a Democratic lawmaker in 2019 to express her opposition to a bill banning abortions. The measure wasn’t seriously considered.

text: Nasal swabs used for COVID-19 tests contain Morgellons disease fibers that are being put in your brain when you are tested for the virus.

claimReview.title: Video makes false claims about Morgellons disease and COVID-19 tests
claimReview.textualRating: False. COVID-19 nasal test swabs are not being used to implant disease particles or “fibers” into the brain. Morgellons disease, which some patients describe as fibers appearing from skin sores, is a controversial condition that has been labeled by some medical experts as a “delusional infestation.”

text: Merck is on trial for fraud regarding its human papillomavirus vaccine, which has been banned in other countries and has been found to cause cancer.

claimReview.title: False claims circulate about HPV vaccine amid Gardasil lawsuits
claimReview.textualRating: False. The New Jersey pharmaceutical giant faces a number of civil lawsuits regarding Gardasil but none of the cases have reached the trial stage, spokespersons for Merck and a law firm representing various plaintiffs claiming injuries from the vaccine confirm. They also confirm Gardasil has not been banned anywhere and federal health officials say the vaccine cannot cause cancer.

text: Video shows Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden mistakenly saying “Hello, Minnesota” at a campaign event in Tampa, Florida.

claimReview.title: Posts use edited video to falsely claim Biden greeted the wrong state
claimReview.textualRating: False. The sign behind Biden in this video has been edited to add the words “Tampa, Florida” and remove the words “TEXT MN to 30330.” The podium has also been edited to add “FL” instead of “MN.” Original video from this event confirms that Biden was in Minnesota and addressed the correct state in his greeting.

text: A chart of U.S. gas prices since 2010 shows that prices under former President Barack Obama were higher than prices under the Trump administration, before rising dramatically again when President Joe Biden took office.

claimReview.title: Chart misleads on gas prices under Obama and Trump
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The chart mislabels former President Donald Trump’s tenure, suggesting he was in office in 2015 during a period when gas prices dropped. Obama was in office at that time. Trump was not sworn in until 2017.

text: Newly surfaced video footage shows Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders making racist remarks that “Italians are gangsters, and Irish are drunk, and Jews are greedy, and black people smell” to a group of schoolchildren.

claimReview.title: Video edited to claim Bernie Sanders made racist comments
claimReview.textualRating:
False. The video of Sanders speaking to a classroom full of children in 1987 has been edited to remove remarks that show he was trying to explain how stereotypes and racism work.

HTML Embed

text: A clip shows an exchange between Georgia Democratic gubernatorial nominee Stacey Abrams and incumbent Republican Gov. Brian Kemp over voting rights during a debate in 2022.

claimReview.title: Clip of Abrams, Kemp debate is from 2018, not 2022
claimReview.textualRating: False. The clip is miscaptioned. This exchange took place at a debate between the pair in 2018, when they initially ran against each other. Abrams and Kemp are poised for a rematch for the governor’s seat in November, with debates set for later this fall.

text: Law enforcement found 39 missing children in a double-wide trailer in Georgia.

claimReview.title: 39 children were not found in a Georgia trailer
claimReview.textualRating: False. A law enforcement operation in August did locate 39 children in Georgia over a two week period, but the children were not all found in one trailer or in a single location.

text: Thailand is canceling its COVID-19 vaccine contract with Pfizer after its princess fell into a coma following a booster shot.

claimReview.title: Thai official: No plans to void Pfizer COVID vaccine contract
claimReview.textualRating: False. There are no plans to alter Thailand’s contract with the New York-based pharmaceutical giant, an official with the country’s National Vaccine Institute said. Thailand’s Department of Disease Control also rejected the claims as “fake news.” Princess Bajrakitiyabha’s condition was attributed to an irregular heartbeat caused by a mycoplasma infection, and medical experts confirmed the infection is not known to be a side effect of COVID vaccines.

text: Coroner’s report says missing graduate student Jelani Day was found with his organs missing, including his teeth, eyeballs and spleen. His jawbone was “sawed out.”

claimReview.title: Autopsy findings misrepresented in grad student Jelani Day’s death
claimReview.textualRating: False. The LaSalle County coroner who first examined Jelani Day’s recovered body said it was severely decomposed, but no body parts were missing. The coroner said the jaw was removed to assist with identification and that all parts of the body were returned to the family.

text: New York lawmakers will vote Jan. 5 on a bill that would allow for the “indefinite detention of the unvaccinated.”

claimReview.title: NY lawmakers aren’t voting on bill to detain the unvaccinated
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim is misrepresenting a bill, first introduced in 2015, that would allow for the temporary detention of individuals infected, or suspected of being infected, with a contagious disease during a public health emergency. The state Assembly’s health committee has no plans to take action on the bill, and its sponsor now says he will withdraw it.

text: Video shows a Victorian mansion where House Speaker Nancy Pelosi resides in California, comparing it to unsanitary conditions in the district she represents in San Francisco.

claimReview.title: House in video does not belong to Pelosi
claimReview.textualRating: Mixed. The image of a Victorian house used in the video is not Pelosi’s home, but the video highlighting poor living conditions in the city over the years is made up of local and national news reports.

text: A new study by Australian researchers shows that Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine caused vaccine acquired immunodeficiency syndrome, or “VAIDS.”

claimReview.title: A new study doesn’t show Pfizer’s COVID vaccine causes ‘VAIDS’
claimReview.textualRating: False. VAIDS is not a real condition, experts say. The co-authors of the study say their work is being misrepresented and doesn’t show that the vaccine is harmful to the immune system.

text: Texas is the only state whose flag can fly at the same height as the U.S. flag.

claimReview.title: All states can fly their flags as high as Old Glory, not just Texas
claimReview.textualRating: False. All state flags can be flown at the same height as the U.S. flag.

text: Social media posts suggest the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention does not currently recommend that healthy people wear face masks amid the coronavirus pandemic.

claimReview.title: CDC now recommends that even healthy people wear masks
claimReview.textualRating: False. The CDC did not recommend healthy people wear face masks at first, but that guidance has changed over time. The CDC now advises people to wear cloth face coverings in public settings where social distancing is difficult to maintain.

text: A court in the Philippines has issued an international arrest warrant for Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates over crimes related to COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Bill Gates not arrested in Philippines over COVID-19 shots
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Philippine court cited as issuing the arrest order for Gates does not exist. The clerk of court in Manila confirmed to The Associated Press that there is no such case involving Gates in any of the country’s courts. A spokesperson for Gates also said the claim is false.

text: A video shows musician Sam Smith crashing to the ground after attempting a stage dive at a show in Seattle.

claimReview.title: Video does not show Sam Smith crashing through audience during a failed stage dive
claimReview.textualRating: False. Smith is not the stage diver shown in the video, a representative for the musician told The Associated Press. Other footage of the failed dive filmed from different angles clearly shows that the incident took place during a performance by rapper Vanilla Ice and that Smith was not involved.

text: Pro-Palestine rallies at UCLA, Penn and elsewhere are calling for “Jewish genocide.”

claimReview.title: A chant used at anti-Israel protests on two college campuses does not call for ‘Jewish genocide’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The chant uttered during recent demonstrations is being misrepresented. Protestors aren’t saying “We want Jewish genocide,” but “Israel, we charge you with genocide.” Experts and advocates say it’s a typical refrain heard at pro-Palestinian rallies.

text: Video shows an election worker in 2022 committing fraud in Delaware County, Pennsylvania, by filling out blank ballots and stamping them.

claimReview.title: Clip shows Pennsylvania workers legally transcribing damaged ballots in 2020
claimReview.textualRating: False. This video, which dates to 2020, shows the election worker transcribing ballots that are damaged and cannot be scanned, according to a county spokesperson. This is a legal, established process to preserve the voter’s selections, and the damaged ballots are saved as county records, the spokesperson said.

text: A congressional bill to ban certain semi-automatic weapons would “turn 150 million Americans into felons overnight.”

claimReview.title: Bill would not turn current semi-automatic weapon owners into felons
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bill would only affect future firearm transactions. People who already lawfully own such weapons when the bill passes would be allowed to keep them, legal experts confirmed. The claim that 150 million Americans would be affected by the restrictions is also not supported by evidence.

text: A transgender woman posted a photo of herself holding a gun and calling for violence against Christians, referencing a “

claimReview.title: Photo of trans woman holding gun misrepresented after Nashville shooting
claimReview.textualRating: False. A Twitter account posted a years-old photo of Alana McLaughlin, an MMA fighter and trans woman, holding a gun and falsely suggesting she used the threatening language. McLaughlin confirmed she didn’t author the post.

text: Oregon has more registered voters than state residents.

claimReview.title: Oregon does not have more registered voters than residents, despite claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The population of Oregon is more than 4 million, according to the most recent U.S. Census. State election records show approximately 3.2 million people are eligible to vote in the state and approximately 2.99 million are actually registered. State and county officials also said there’s no county level data that suggests otherwise, as some of the posts claim.

text: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis wants bloggers to register with the state or face fines.

claimReview.title: Florida blogger bill falsely tied to DeSantis
claimReview.textualRating: False. A bill filed in the Florida Senate would require bloggers to register with the state and submit periodic reports if they are paid for posts about elected officials. However, the bill was filed by Republican Florida Sen. Jason Brodeur, not DeSantis. The Republican governor said at a press conference on Tuesday that he does not support the bill.

text: The Pfizer vaccine is only 42% effective against COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Claim about Pfizer vaccine effectiveness lacks key context
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The claim stems from a single preprint study that found in July the Pfizer vaccine’s efficacy at preventing COVID-19 infections, including asymptomatic and mild ones, dropped to 42%. A coauthor of the study, as well as other experts, told the AP the figure should not be used to discredit the Pfizer vaccine since the shot continues to maintain strong protection against severe disease and death, which are key metrics.

text: Democrats cheated in Pennsylvania elections with voting machines that were rigged to flip votes.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent voting machine error in Pennsylvania county as evidence of ‘rigged’ elections
claimReview.textualRating: False. Social media users are misrepresenting an issue with machines in one county where there is no evidence of fraud, according to an election integrity expert. Instead, the machines’ maker acknowledged it made a clerical error, which resulted in devices in Northampton County printing out records that mixed up the results on two ballot measures. Despite the inaccurate printout, the voters’ actual choices were properly recorded by the machines’ backend systems, county officials said.

text: Airlines recently met to discuss the risks and liability of carrying passengers vaccinated against COVID-19 since they could develop blood clots.

claimReview.title: No record airlines met to discuss liabilities related to vaccine
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s no evidence that major airlines had a recent meeting to discuss the risks of transporting vaccinated passengers or that flying will trigger blood clots in that population.

text: “Sesame Street” writer says that Bert and Ernie are gay

claimReview.title: 'Sesame Street' writer says Bert and Ernie are gay
claimReview.textualRating: It is true that “Sesame Street” writer Mark Saltzman told Queerty, an online magazine and newspaper, that when writing scenes for the characters he had always felt that the two were lovers.

text: Multiple people were shot in Uvalde, Texas, on Thursday at a memorial site for the 21 victims of the May mass shooting at Robb Elementary School.

claimReview.title: Shots fired at Uvalde park, not memorial for school victims
claimReview.textualRating: False. Two people were hospitalized on Thursday following a shooting at an unrelated public gathering space called Uvalde Memorial Park, police confirmed. That location is not the site of a memorial for the victims slain in the elementary school shooting in May, nor was it named to commemorate them

text: Ukrainian media is reporting that President Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s office was destroyed by a missile strike on Monday.

claimReview.title: Russian strikes in Kyiv didn’t destroy Zelenskyy’s office
claimReview.textualRating: False. The building wasn’t destroyed and the claim wasn’t reported by mainstream Ukrainian news outlets. Associated Press reporting documented damage at a park and other locations in the city center, but the president’s office, about a mile away, was not hit. AP journalists on the ground confirmed the building wasn’t struck, and Zelesnkyy filmed a video address outside of the undamaged building after the attacks.

text: Eating alkaline foods will stave off the novel coronavirus, which has a pH level of 5.5 to 8.5.

claimReview.title: Eating alkaline foods will not kill the coronavirus
claimReview.textualRating: False. A virus does not have a pH level. Eating a diet made up of alkaline foods will not prevent someone from being infected with COVID-19 since the body’s pH levels cannot be changed through diet.

text: When Vice President Kamala Harris was sworn into office on Wednesday, she placed a black clutch purse on top of the Bible so she wouldn’t have to touch the holy book.

claimReview.title: Kamala Harris rested hand on Bibles, not a purse, during oath
claimReview.textualRating: False. Photos of the swearing-in ceremony from a different angle show that Harris rested her hand on a Bible, not a purse. The vice president used two Bibles for her oath, one owned by a close family friend and one that belonged to the late Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall.

text: Video shows Pope Francis saying in Italian that “we are living in the end times,” that he has “a secret agenda” to deceive people and that he unites people under one world religion in order to “control them better,” among other foreboding messages.

claimReview.title: Video uses fake subtitles to misrepresent pope’s message
claimReview.textualRating: False. The version of the video circulating on social media uses fake English subtitles to mislead viewers. In the original video, filmed in 2014, the pope speaks about how he hopes Christians will find unity.

text: A transcript shows a conversation between former President Bill Clinton and former U.K. Prime Minister Tony Blair in the 90s in which the leaders discuss castles.

claimReview.title: Social media users share old, fake Bill Clinton transcript
claimReview.textualRating: False. The fake transcript was created by a British writer and comedian following the 2016 release of documents that showed actual conversations between Blair and Clinton. The comedian has repeatedly taken responsibility for satirical transcripts inspired by those conversations.

text: Photos show dozens of boxes of counterfeit ballots at a warehouse in Fulton County, Georgia.

claimReview.title: Photos show emergency ballots, not fake ballots, in Georgia warehouse
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photos show legitimate emergency ballots, not fake ballots, according to Gabriel Sterling, a top official with the Georgia secretary of state’s office. Every county in the state is required to print a certain number of emergency ballots in case voting machines are down or another problem arises.

text: Videos taken one day apart show a Palestinian “crisis actor” pretending to be seriously injured in a hospital bed one day and completely fine the next.

claimReview.title: Videos do not show a ‘crisis actor’ pretending to be a victim in Gaza. They show two different men
claimReview.textualRating: False. Two different people appear in the videos. In addition, the video of an injured man in a hospital bed dates to August.

text: An image shows a sculpture resembling the Statue of Liberty, built by a Syrian artist out of the ruins of his house. “This is the freedom they brought us,” states a slogan associated with the image.

claimReview.title: ‘Statue of Liberty’ image was created using Photoshop, not ruins from the artist’s home
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image is a digital photomontage by Tammam Azzam, a Syrian artist now based in Berlin. Azzam told The Associated Press that he created the image in 2012 using Photoshop to combine fragments of photographs showing destroyed buildings in Syria. He said it represents freedom sought by the Syrian people.

text: Photo shows a baby who was born clutching an IUD from his mother’s womb.

claimReview.title: Baby in photo wasn’t born holding IUD
claimReview.textualRating: False. This photo was set up after the baby was born, his mother confirmed to The Associated Press. Even in the very rare case of a pregnancy occurring with this contraceptive device still in the uterus, it’s not possible for a child to be born holding an IUD, an expert told the AP.

text: A screenshot shows a May 11 piece published by The Guardian in which columnist George Monbiot says he caught COVID-19 23 times despite “dozens of boosters.”

claimReview.title: Guardian columnist didn’t pen piece saying he got COVID for a ‘23rd time’
claimReview.textualRating: Altered image. A screenshot of a real column has been edited to add a fake headline. That headline does not appear on The Guardian’s website and the British outlet confirmed to The Associated Press that it never published that piece.

text: A Japanese study “says ivermectin is effective against Omicron in phase III trial.”

claimReview.title: False claim spreads about Japanese ivermectin study, despite correction
claimReview.textualRating: False. While scientists continue to conduct research into the drug’s use against COVID-19, the finding being cited refers to pre-clinical research — not a “phase III trial,” which involves testing the drug on humans.

text: A study from the Francis Crick Institute in London found that Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine destroys a type of white blood cell called the T cell and weakens the immune system.

claimReview.title: COVID-19 vaccines don’t destroy T cells or weaken immune system
claimReview.textualRating: False. The vaccine doesn’t destroy T cells or weaken the immune system. On the contrary, it generates a strong T cell response and boosts immunity, according to experts. A researcher at the Francis Crick Institute told The Associated Press the claim distorts his team’s work, which did not examine T cells.

text: A French doctor was arrested for prescribing ivermectin in French Polynesia.

claimReview.title: Doctor in French Polynesia arrested for assault, not prescribing ivermectin
claimReview.textualRating: False. The doctor, Dr. Jean-Paul Théron, was arrested for assaulting law enforcement authorities, not for prescribing ivermectin, according to the public prosecutor in French Polynesia overseeing the case. Ivermectin, a cheap drug used to kill worms and other parasites in humans and animals, has been falsely touted as a proven treatment for COVID-19.

text: Israel’s Mossad intelligence agency called the U.S. Air Force an “enemy” of Israel in a post on X after an active-duty member of the military branch

claimReview.title: Israel’s intelligence agency did not label the US Air Force an ‘enemy’ of the Jewish state
claimReview.textualRating: False. The account that made the post is not affiliated with Mossad and has previously published erroneous claims about Israel. Mossad’s official X account, to which the agency’s website links, has not posted anything since September 2020.

text: People who are vaccinated against COVID-19 are nine times more likely to be hospitalized than those who are unvaccinated.

claimReview.title: Vaccinated people aren’t nine times more likely to be hospitalized
claimReview.textualRating: False. The assertion is based on one former physician assistant’s claim that 90% of all patients admitted to her hospital during a recent period were vaccinated against COVID-19. In fact, the hospital records show that the vaccination rate was far lower. Also, there was no evidence of any connection between vaccination status and the various illnesses that led to the hospitalizations. Studies show that serious side effects from the COVID-19 vaccine are rare, experts say.

text: A video shows Bud Light drinkers using a “steamroller” to destroy beer cans in response to

claimReview.title: Video of roller destroying beer cans unrelated to Bud Light backlash
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video is from February 2023, prior to the controversy, and shows a road roller in Mexicali, Mexico, being used to destroy thousands of beer cases that had been confiscated during the COVID-19 pandemic. The municipality announced that the cases of beer were destroyed due to health risks.

text: The Trump administration was responsible for the treatment of migrants captured in photos that showed them wrapped in Mylar sheets and packed into cells inside detention centers.

claimReview.title: Photos show detention centers under Obama not Trump
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photos showing a group of migrants wrapped in Mylar sheets, packed into cells and sleeping on concrete floors were taken in 2015 when Barack Obama was president.

text: Video shows Finland moving military equipment toward its eastern border with Russia.

claimReview.title: Video shows tanks being moved for military exercise in Finland
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows a train in Finland transporting tanks from the city of Tampere to the village of Niinisalo for a two-week military exercise called “Arrow 22,” the Finnish Army confirmed to The Associated Press. The train was moving to the northwest. Russia is to the east.

text: U.S. gasoline prices are among the lowest in the world.

claimReview.title: US fuel prices not among lowest in world
claimReview.textualRating: False. While the U.S. is not one of the nations with the highest fuel prices in the world in 2022, it is also not among those with the lowest prices. Dozens of countries report lower fuel prices than the U.S.

text: Israel has had no deaths from coronavirus because people in the country have been cured by drinking hot water with lemon and bicarbonate of soda at night.

claimReview.title: Drinking hot water, lemon and baking soda will not cure coronavirus
claimReview.textualRating: False. The drink is not a cure for the coronavirus and there have been deaths attributed to the coronavirus in Israel.

text: Voting machines in Michigan do not count ballots marked with Sharpie markers.

claimReview.title: Michigan ballots marked with Sharpie pens were not invalidated
claimReview.textualRating: False. Election officials in Michigan confirmed that ballots marked with both blue and black sharpie are counted.

text: The Respect for Marriage Act would allow the Internal Revenue Service to revoke the tax-exempt status of churches that only support marriage between a man and a woman. Small business owners and religiously-affiliated groups could be sued or shuttered under this law for the same beliefs.

claimReview.title: Respect for Marriage Act doesn’t revoke tax-exempt status from churches
claimReview.textualRating: False. Nothing in the legislation — which is aimed at protecting same-sex and interracial marriages — would allow churches to be denied tax-exempt status or other organizations to be sued for their stance on marriage, constitutional law experts tell The Associated Press. In fact, recent amendments to the bill specifically clarify that it cannot impact tax status or the rights of private individuals or businesses already enshrined in the law.

text: Comedian Chris Rock issued a public apology for his joke about actress Jada Pinkett Smith’s shaved head at the Academy Awards, saying he “crossed a line that I shouldn’t have and paid the enormous price of my reputation as a renown comedian.”

claimReview.title: Chris Rock apology for Oscars joke is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. This apology is fake and didn’t come from Rock, a representative for the comedian told The Associated Press in an email.

text: The Biden administration is proposing amendments to the World Health Organization’s International Health Regulations that would transfer U.S. sovereign authority over health care decisions to the WHO director-general.

claimReview.title: WHO health regulations don’t infringe on US decision-making
claimReview.textualRating: False. The International Health Regulations, which are aimed at detecting disease outbreaks, allow the WHO director-general to declare a public health emergency of international concern. The proposed U.S. amendments seek to strengthen requirements for reporting such emergencies. Member countries agree to abide by the guidelines, but the WHO does not have the power to enforce them, nor can it interfere in other countries’ decision-making processes, according to experts.

text: Data from the European Medicines Agency shows more than 30,000 “fatalities” and over 1 million adverse reactions caused by COVID-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: EU agency data does not show 30k COVID-19 vaccine fatalities
claimReview.textualRating: False. The agency’s EudraVigilance database tracks possible side effects of medications — including vaccines — by allowing medical professionals in the European Union to report when patients experience a “medical event” after taking them. This information is not verified by the agency and the data doesn’t prove the events were caused by the medication, the EMA told The Associated Press.

text: Vaccines only reduce hospitalizations in the U.S., not in other countries.

claimReview.title: COVID vaccines lower hospitalizations across the board, not just in the US
claimReview.textualRating: FALSE. COVID-19 vaccines have been shown to reduce rates of hospitalization in several countries.

text: Drop in cellphone users in China is proof that the coronavirus has killed 21 million in the country, far more than the official count.

claimReview.title: Drop in cellphone users in China wrongly attributed to coronavirus deaths
claimReview.textualRating: False. The decline in cellphone users is not linked to the number of people who died after being infected with coronavirus. Major cellphone carriers in China attributed the drop to people with multiple phone numbers canceling some service during the outbreak.

text: Niraj Shah, chief executive officer of the furniture company Wayfair, has resigned amid child sex trafficking allegations against the company.

claimReview.title: Wayfair CEO has not stepped down
claimReview.textualRating: False. Shah has not stepped down, according to a Wayfair spokesperson, and claims the company is involved in child trafficking are part of an unfounded conspiracy theory.

text: Former President Barack Obama was filmed referencing an “international order,” saying men and women are “too small-minded to govern their own affairs,” and insisting that “order and progress can only come when individuals surrender their rights to an all-powerful sovereign.”

claimReview.title: Posts twist Obama quotes on international ‘order,’ ‘small-minded’ people
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. This spliced video misrepresents Obama’s words in a 2014 speech. The former president was referencing a perspective that runs counter to the American ideal that all men and women are created equal, not speaking in support of that perspective.

text: Facebook allowed a TED-sponsored advertisement calling pedophilia “a natural sexual orientation” to run on the platform.

claimReview.title: Facebook ad attributed to TED Conferences is fake
claimReview.textualRating: False. The advertisement, which has been circulating online since at least 2020, is not real. It was never promoted on Facebook, nor did TED, the group that hosts the popular TED talk series, create or sponsor any such ad, according to the organization.

text: Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden wants to introduce a 3% annual federal tax on your home.

claimReview.title: Biden tax plan does not include a 3% federal tax on homes
claimReview.textualRating: False. Nothing in Biden’s tax plan indicates homeowners would be subject to an additional 3% federal property tax. Experts who have analyzed the plan confirmed to The Associated Press there was no evidence to support the claim.

text: Guns, including handguns, are illegal in Chicago.

claimReview.title: Guns aren’t illegal in Chicago
claimReview.textualRating: False. While Chicago has strict gun laws, it is not illegal to own most guns, including handguns, in the city. Guns considered to be “assault weapons,” such as certain semi-automatic rifles, and “ghost” guns, which are privately-made firearms without serial numbers, are banned in the city.

text: Breathing the steam from a mixture of boiling water, salt and orange peel will prevent or cure the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Breathing steam from boiling water, salt and orange peel won’t prevent virus
claimReview.textualRating: False. Steam may help sooth symptoms of the virus, but it will not prevent or cure it.

text: A video shows former President Barack Obama “teaching” how to create public distrust through spreading conspiracy theories and misinformation.

claimReview.title: Posts distort Obama speech on disinformation
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context. The 40-second clip comes from an hourlong speech Obama made in April at Stanford University, in which he discussed the threat of online disinformation. The full speech shows that Obama was explaining the process other people have used to sow distrust, not endorsing such actions.

text: A video shows a “World Economic Forum agent” calling for a cashless society and saying those determined “less desirable” will be locked out.

claimReview.title: Video doesn’t show World Economic Forum speaker calling for a cashless society
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video shows Eswar Prasad, an economics professor from Cornell University, speaking at a June WEF event, but Prasad does not work for or represent the organization. The video misrepresents remarks Prasad made at the event about the benefits and the dangers of central bank digital currencies. Such currencies do not create “cashless societies,” nor did Prasad or the WEF itself ever call for one.

text: Bacon sold by Aldi grocery stores under its brand Appleton Meats does not come from pigs and is instead grown from cells in a lab.

claimReview.title: Confusion about brand name leads to false claims about Aldi’s bacon
claimReview.textualRating: False. Aldi told The Associated Press that products sold through its store brand — Appleton Farms — “are not produced through cultivated lab practices.” A Canadian company named Appleton Meats, which is not affiliated with Appleton Farms, was founded in 2017 with the goal of producing lab-grown meat, according to local news reports.

text: A sign endorsing Democratic candidates outside a high school polling site in northeast Philadelphia is a “violation” of election law.

claimReview.title: Partisan sign outside high school polling place in Philadelphia was legal
claimReview.textualRating: False. Pennsylvania law allows campaign workers, signs and other electioneering materials near polling places as long as they are “at least 10 feet away from the entrance to the room where the voting occurs.” At the high school voting site in northeast Philadelphia, the sign was posted on the exterior of the high school building. Voting occurred in a room inside the building, more than 10 feet away.

text: A recent analysis from the Florida surgeon general’s office found the COVID-19 vaccine led to an 84% increase in death among young men.

claimReview.title: Florida government vaccine analysis misrepresented online
claimReview.textualRating: False. The study, which has not been published or peer-reviewed, suggests men under the age of 40 have an 84% greater risk of suffering cardiac-related death soon after being vaccinated. It did not find an 84% increase in deaths among young men who received the vaccine. Epidemiologists and other public health experts have also raised broader concerns about the study itself.

text: Video shows deadly mosquitoes released at a Baltimore music festival.

claimReview.title: Deadly mosquitoes did not swarm Baltimore music festival
claimReview.textualRating: False. While concertgoers were swarmed by flying insects at one point during an African American music festival last month, concert goers were not bitten by the insects, which they described as gnats. Experts said swarming mosquitoes would behave differently than the bugs in the video. The Baltimore Health Department also said no insect-borne illnesses were reported following the event.

text: Denmark has banned COVID-19 vaccines for children.

claimReview.title: Denmark didn’t ‘ban’ COVID-19 vaccines for children
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Danish Health Authority will no longer recommend the COVID-19 vaccine for those under the age of 18, but it hasn’t placed an overall ban on the shots for that age group. Children and youths who are at risk of developing a severe case of COVID-19 can still receive the vaccine in Denmark if recommended by a doctor, the agency said.

text: Photo shows a shark swimming in a flooded train station in Sydney, Australia.

claimReview.title: Photo edited to add shark in flooded Australian train station
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo of a shark in a flooded transit station has been manipulated. The original image, which shows an emergency worker pumping water out of an inundated rail entrance, contains no fish and has circulated online since at least 2014.

text: The U.S. Postal Service is telling Americans to allow 14 days to receive and return vote-by-mail ballots, therefore voters should consider Oct. 20 Election Day, not Nov. 3.

claimReview.title: Ballots could take ’14 days round trip’ in the mail, but deadlines for returns vary
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. The U.S. Postal Service did issue guidance in May recommending election officials budget a week for ballots to reach voters, and a week for their return. But the assertion spreading on social media that Election Day should therefore be considered 14 days before the Nov. 3 election fails to take into account that states have different deadlines for returning mail-in ballots, and Postal Service guidance advising voters to request ballots as early as possible.

text: A screenshot shows a CNN chyron reading

claimReview.title: CNN screenshot altered to add fake chyron about Putin and Biden
claimReview.textualRating: Altered image. The text was added to a screenshot of a CNN news report from 2017. A CNN spokesperson confirmed the image was altered to add the fake chyron.

text: A photo with celebrity heart surgeon and Pennsylvania Senate candidate Dr. Mehmet Oz shows a woman holding his campaign poster on its side, which makes it look like the poster reads “No.”

claimReview.title: Photo of Oz campaign poster reading ‘No’ is altered
claimReview.textualRating: Altered photo. The original photo posted on Oz’s social media accounts shows the woman holding the sign right-side up.

text: “Women can fly planes in Saudi Arabia, but can’t drive cars.”

claimReview.title: Posts distort rights of women to get behind the wheel in Saudi Arabia
claimReview.textualRating: False. Women can navigate the roads in Saudi Arabia behind the wheel of a car or pilot a plane through the skies. A ban on female drivers was lifted by the government in 2018, opening the door to driving a car.

text: A photo shows a Ukrainian soldier from the Azov Regiment who lost both legs and his left arm in the Russia-Ukraine war giving the Nazi salute.

claimReview.title: Posts misrepresent a photo of a Ukrainian soldier balancing on his prosthetic limbs
claimReview.textualRating: False. The soldier, Roman Tsymbalyuk, was attempting to steady himself while waving and giving a traditional military salute on his new prosthetic legs, according to those present when the photo was taken. Tsymbalyuk posted the image on social media without realizing it could appear he was giving the Nazi salute, but removed it when he noticed the resemblance. He and others familiar with his military background say he has no connection to the Azov Regiment.

text: Photo shows a member of the U.S. women’s soccer team giving a Nazi salute in front of the Museum of Jewish Heritage in New York City.

claimReview.title: U.S. women’s soccer team player didn’t give Nazi salute
claimReview.textualRating: False. The photo shows soccer player Ashlyn Harris raising her hand in celebration next to her teammates, Allie Long and Megan Rapinoe, as they gathered outside the museum prior to a victory parade in New York City on July 10.
